column2: The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company plans to acquire full ownership of the Macmillan Company, a book publisher in which it holds 174,466 shares, or 52.8 per cent of the 330,553 shares outstanding. Directors of both companies have approved a proposal to merge, according to an announcement issued for publication today.

Mike Cucchiara of the Bruce Track Club, aided by a 2-minute 45-second allowance, won a five-mile Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union handicap cross-country race yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Thirty-seven started but only twenty-six finished.

THE Yankee Stadium was seething and boiling in yesterday's gloaming, as Forbes Field had been in the ninth inning of the final game of the world series. The Washington Redskins mounted a dramatic rally in the closing minutes that ambushed the New York Giants. It wasn't a complete scalping job but it was an unpleasantly close haircut.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Jack Larscheid's 87-yard touchdown run on the second play of the game ignited the Oakland Raiders to a 27-14 victory over the Boston Patriots today in an American Football League game before 11,500.

Despite Israel's "tremendous needs" for technological' and engineering research to cope with its vast development programs, half of its 2,500 scientists are engaged in pure or basic scientific studies, it was reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A rule of thumb for the non-economist who is trying to size up the economic outlook: There is something in the wind when the professional economists talk in subtotals.

Last year the eighty-two nonprofit voluntary hospitals under the blue flag of the United Hospital Fund of New York cared for more than 2,500,000 patients, nearly 1,000,000 of these at below cost or free. The eighty-two institutions sustained all told a $38,000,000 operating loss last year while caring for these patients. In the last twelve years, the hospitals' professional and technical expenses tripled, chiefly because of new developments.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Lenny Moore ran for three touchdowns and caught a pass for a fourth in leading the Baltimore Colts to a 31 -- 17 victory today over the Los Angeles Rams.
NEWARK, Oct. 16 -- New Jersey's Twelfth Congressiona District curves west from Newark and then north like a big hook to embrace the well-to-do outer suburbs of Essex County.
WARSAW, Oct. 16 -- Poland has launched an export drive to help finance an ambitious five-year plan of economic growth.
While the pace of trading in over-the-counter stocks was slow last week, along with the market for listed Issues, dealers reported a noticeable firming of bids.

GENEVA, Oct. 16 -- A spurt in trading at last week's closing session on the Swiss stock market put the prices of many issues above the preceding Friday's closing quotations. The leading Swiss banks, investment companies and industrials shared in the advance.
VICENTE ESCUDERO, that most venerable of Spanish dancers, made an appearance at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night as part of his second "farewell tour" of this country along with a small company.

DETROIT, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings unleashed their most explosive attack of the season tonight, scoring in every period to hand the league-leading Montreal Canadiens their first defeat, 6 -- 4.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 16 -- Lorin E. (Red) Ball, who has been coaching football on a college and schoolboy level since 1920, marveled over the wonders of modern science today. This was prompted by the presentation of movies of the Deerfield-Stockbridge game, which was played only yesterday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- The Soviet Union has quietly begun to expand its aid to the Algerian rebels.
Highway accidents took five live's on Long Island Saturday night and early Sunday morning.

TOUGH and truculent" are the words that best describe James Barren Carey, the fiery little president of the International Union of Electrical Workers who is leading a bitter strike against General Electric Company and is battling rebellious local leaders of his own union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A former Republican National Chairman said today that Vice President Nixon and his running mate, Henry Cabot Lodge, disagreed on the question of Federal aid to parochial schools.
With Syracuse continuing to sputter while continuing to win, Navy has gained stature as the East's top contender for college football leadership.

The experiences of two test pilots, both connected with the X-15 project, are the subject of two books to be published a day apart. One will be "First of the Spacemen: Iven C. Kincheloe Jr.," by James J. Haggerty Jr., which Duell, Sloan Pearce will issue Oct. 27.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 16 -- There is a fine new fountain in Accra at a traffic roundabout where a neon sign flashes "Kwame Nkrumah Circle" through the night.

The question of whether disarmament is possible or desirable will be debated by Dr. Edward Teller and Dr. Leo Szilard, nuclear physicists, or a National Broadcasting Company program to be televised at 9:30 P.M. Nov. 12.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 16 -- "Another election. A different candidate. But I expect the results to be the same."

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A 91-yard touchdown pass from Ed Brown to Willard Dewveall and two long scoring jaunts by Johnny Morris enabled the Chicago Bears to score a 27-10 victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners today in a National Football League battle.
The Federal Maritime Board has ordered an investigation into freight rates that the Mitsui Steamship Company has offered to a German importer of United States canned goods.
The American economy will have to make better use of research scientists if it is to keep safely ahead of the Soviet Union, according to a Princeton University report made public yesterday.
GUIOMAR NOVAES, looking more beautiful and younger than ever, opened the eighteenth annual concert series on Saturday evening at Hunter College.

DENVER, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Ben Agajanian kicked three field goals and Paul Lowe dashed 12 and 44 yards for touchdowns today as the Los Angeles Chargers defeated the Denver Broncos, the Western Division leaders, 23 -- 19, in an American Football League game.
Seven tow-truck operators yesterday admitted paying policemen for tips on auto accidents and for other favors, the Queens District Attorney's office said last night.

A report detailing many little-known rights and privileges granted American business abroad under treaties and trade agreements was issued over the week-end by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

The executive director of the Fair Campaign Practices Committee protested in a sermon yesterday plans by conservative Protestant churchmen to turn Reformation Sunday "into a gigantic anti-Kennedy rally."

Operas and casts for the Metropolitan Opera's opening week of the season have been announced. The company will begin its seventy-sixth year next Monday, with its first performance of Verdi's "Nabucco."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said tonight that he thought the Quemoy-Matsu issue "could properly be closed" because Vice President Nixon had joined him in support of the position of the Eisenhower Administration.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller's well - modulated campaign for Vice President Nixon, which moved into its critical phase in the state last Week, has raised questions about Mr. Rockefeller's future in Republican national politics.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Oct. 16 -- The Christian missions in the Congo are hopeful of weathering the storm.
THE first television bridge show of the season -- "Championsihp Bridge," which was seen on Channel 7 yesterday afternoon -- was a great improvement over last year's series in its technical aspects.
Roman Catholics were told yesterday not to let the religious issue in the Presidential campaign restrict their political activities.
A record turnout of voters Nov. 8 in New York State appeared likely yesterday on the basis of registration results.

The first bus built in the United States -- the ancestor of all Mack trucks -- will be driven to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel today as the twenty-seventh convention of the American Trucking Associations gets under way.

After thirty-two years at If Broad Street, Hemphill, Noyes Co., investment bankers, will move their executive offices and operating departments to the building under construction at 66 Beaver Street. The new site overlooks Hanover Square and is a block from Wall Street.

DACCA, Oct. 16 (AP) -- It was feared here that the death toll in the East Pakistan' cyclone-tidal wave disaster would go higher than the present estimate of 3,000 and might never be fully known because of bodies washed out to sea.
The Internal Revenue Service has more workers these days, and some say more people are being called in to explain their deductions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Is there a women's vote, and If there is, is it leaning toward Nixon or Kennedy?

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 16 -- For once the party conferences of the Labor and Conservative parties held in this genteel seaside resort on successive weeks, cannot be written off as full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.
One of tills country's leading nuclear physicists is to become scientific director of the twelve-nation European Organization for Nuclear Research.
A SLY monologue by Mort Sahl, in which Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy were among the targets, was part of last night's "Ed Sullivan Show" over Channel 2.
One of the most fascinating mailers of anti-Catholic literature in the Presidential campaign is a little old lady in San Francisco. Her name is Mrs. F.M. Standish and she does all her own work.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16 -- The four powers who are the guarantors of the terms of 1942 Peru-Ecuador bouudary treaty are to meet here this week to study the implication of Ecuador's denunciation of the pact.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 16 (UPI) -- Billy Krause drove his white birdcage Maserati to an easy triumph today in the $26,000 sports-car Grand Prix.

THERE Is a small and fascinating food shop at Ninth Avenue and Fifty-second Street that might possibly exist on the Franco-Italian border. Customers can, and frequently do, place their orders for meats, sausages and tinned goods in French, Italian or English. It is known as Molinari Brothers and it is located at 776 Ninth Avenue.

Though Ralph Guglielmi of the Washington Redskins went into yesterday's game against the New York Giants with a temperature of 101 degrees, he played well enough to have his coach, Mike Nixon, say that the quarterkack "had his best show as a professional."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- To improve flying safety the Federal Aviation Agency disclosed today plans to establish a circular zone around each airport. Within that zone all planes would be under strict orders from the control tower.
A plan to appoint and elect judges strictly on their qualifications and record after a year's trial on the bench is to be introduced in the next Legislature.

Unless the Federal Government comes to the aid of the commuter railroads, New York's business and financial districts will become empty "stone canyons," Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- New York and Houston received franchises in the National League today.

The Port of New York Authority plans to sell up to $35,000,000 of bonds in the public market, according to an announcement yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, chairman. No date has been set yet for the public offering.
Important games involving two unbeaten teams -- Iowa and Minnesota -- should heighten interest in Big Ten football on Saturday.

Adlai E. Stevenson told a Broadway theatre audience yesterday evening that the present campaign, in which he is working for the election of Senator John F. Kennedy, was "the most important campaign for the American people that I've ever been in."

The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York invited individuals, yesterday to subscribe to its medical services provided by groups of physicians. It will be the first time since the plan was established in 1947 that individuals have been enrolled.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points (50 cents a bale) off to 1 point up on the extreme July contract yesterday.
The biggest local in the strike against the General Electric Company returned to work yesterday in defiance of its national union leaders.

There is money in the air for the smaller radio stations but not for the big four major networks, according to figures covering last year released yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. The nation's 3,509 smaller radio stations had revenues of $499,600,000, up 9.3 per cent from the 1958 level and profits before Federal taxes of $46,900,000, up 11.9 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Senator Mike Mansfield said today he was willing to sponsor a bill that would provide "fair payment" to New York City for the cost of extraordinary police protection provided to the Unitied Nations during the recent attendance of many heads of governments at the General Assembly.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 17 -- Israel appeared headed today for a big political scandal.
Record registrations continued to be reported yesterday from the New York metropolitan area and from upstate.

The Lionel Corporation is issuing to the holders of its common stock fights to subscribe to $4,471,600 of 5 1/2 per cent convertible subordinated debentures, due Oct. 15,1980, at $100 face amount of debentures for each 23 shares of common stock held of record yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The second Arab Petroleum Congress opened today With a call for a larger Arab share in policy making and profits from oil operations.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 17 -- The same men who ran in New Jersey's Thirteenth Congressional District in 1958 are facing each other again.

On Nov. 2, 1957, Newark Central High defeated Weequahic, 21 -- 12, in a football game. No goal posts were uprooted that day, no rockets were set off. But they should have been. Central lost its next twenty games.
IN "The Velvet Glove," which began an engagement last night on Channel 13's "The Play of the Week," Rosemary Casey has written about the issue of academic freedom in a Roman Catholic college.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Following is the text of an address to the General Assembly today by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What is the matter with Americans? It is time they recovered their confidence and remembered their great past.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- The General Assembly unanimously approved tonight a resolution urging "constructive steps" to reduce world tensions and create greater harmony.

The Alleghany Corporation's chairman, president and controlling stockholder, Allan P. Kirby, met yesterday the chalenge presented by the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., in his direction of the big holding company over the last two and one-half years.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The British Government will attempt to discourage any proposals for early meetings among the Western heads of government or for a Western summit meeting in Paris in December.

The chairman of the Fair Campaign Practices Committee issued a statement yesterday deploring not only the injection of religious bigotry into the Presidential campaign but also the "false accusations of bigotry which are now being reported from every region."
The resignation of the chairman and four other directors from the fourteen-member board of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation was announced yesterday.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 17 -- "Of course the Communists are gaining in Ghana," the Ghanaian teacher said with a smile that showed more anger than mirth. "After all, they have all of the West working for them."
Jose Gonzalez, a welterweight from Puerto Rico, gained his sixth straight victory last night in the ten-round main event at St. Nicholas Arena.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for a main dish that is easy to prepare.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The News Chronicle and The Star, nationally circulated newspapers that have long Championed liberal causes, ceased publication today.

Potato futures were weak yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading was influenced by lower cash prices. The movement of Long Island potatoes to market has depressed quotations for actuals.

Departing for Hollywood over the week-end will be Peter Glenville, who staged "Becket" and "Take Me Along." He expects to be occupied there with the direction of two films, "Summer and Smoke," with Geraldine Page and Laurence Harvey, and "The Devil in Bucks County," with Simone Signoret.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 17 -- The State of North Carolina has not voted Republican in a Presidential election since 1928, but the Democratic margin of victory has been dropping steadily since 1936, and you can get a bet either way here now.
Only one major hurdle remains to be cleared before the city gives the final go-ahead for construction of the new 55,000-seat $16,226,250 sports stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.
Lunch-counter facilities of four major variety store organizations in 112 cities in the South and border states have been integrated during the last eight months.
The city's "extremely costly" policy of not providing enough new subway cars may jeopardize the 15-cent fare, the City Planning Commission was warned yesterday.
Dr. John J. Theobald said yesterday he would not tolerate political interference in the operation of the school system, "no matter where it comes from," not even from the Mayor.

The Christiana Securities Company and the Delaware Realty and Investment Company, both du Pont family-owned organizations, announced plans for a merger yesterday. If consummated, a split of the Christiana common stock of about eighty to one is contemplated.

NOT nearly so Early American in tone as in past years, the New York Antiques Fair, which opened yesterday, offers a broader representation of material. More English and European furniture is in evidence. There are more Spanish pieces, relative newcomers that some dealers are acquiring as decorative and moderately priced.

A WOMAN who has been involved for most of her adult life in horse racing and high society now looms prominently in the common man's sport -- baseball. She is Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, only daughter of the late Payne Whitney and sister of John Hay Whitney, Ambassa dor to Britain and publisher of The New York Herald Tribune.

A Presidential fact-finding board started taking testimony yesterday in the contract dispute between three unions and eleven railroads operating tugs, ferries and other floating equipment in the Port of New York.
Sales of the nation's major chains rose sharply in September to post the second best gain of the year, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

International harness racing received new impetus yesterday with the disclosure by Yonker Raceway that four outstanding European racers would compete against four United States horses in two "world championship" races for 4-year-old trotters.

Wild Beasts or Jewels Opinions on the subject of boys have varied throughout recorded history. Plato declared more than twenty-three centuries ago: "A boy is, of all wild beasts, the most difficult to manage."

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 17 -- A traditionally Democratic strong-hold -- New Jersey's Fourteenth Congressional District -- is again the target of a jut-jawed former longshoreman carrying the Republican banner.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 -- President Eisenhower started his "non-political" cross-country tour today with an appeal that voters not be swayed by "false or extreme propaganda."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The United States has resumed its military aid to Laos, State Department officials said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States Charles J. Hoeffler of New York N.Y., was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

CASSVILLE, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Thorn Lord, Democratic candidate for Senator, called tonight for an expanded national economy that would provide new jobs for a labor force that is growing by the millions.
No dancing in the streets, popping of champagne corks or other symptoms of joy greeted the news yesterday that New York would have a National League baseball team in 1962.

A human heredity clinic that will draw on New York's "melting pot" population for research in human genetics is being established at Albert Einstein College of Medicine-Bronx Municipal Hospital Center.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- Opportunities for United States business in foreign markets are improving at a time when a substantially higher level of exports is needed, a Department of Commerce official said today.
The Army-Syracuse football game at Yankee Stadium, Nov. 5, is a sellout. But the news that 67,000 spectators will attend the contest is of little moment to the cadet coaches.
On Sept. 13, 1845, an obscure gentleman named Davis split the calm air of the Elysian Fields in Hoboken, N.J., with several allegedly choice, but unrecorded, expletives. He was fined 6 cents.

EAST BROWNFIELD, Me., Oct. 17 -- Upland hunting has got to be good in this part of these burnt-over hills, if justice exists. It can't be spectacular a few miles away and not be at least fine here, unless wrong has turned to right.

A LIKELY IMPOSSIBILITY," Aristotle said, "is always preferable to an unconvincing possibility." Obeying this principle with enormous relish, Richard Bissell, begetter of "The Pajama Game," "Say, Darling" and other manifestations of galvanic folklore, has given us some of the wildest American comedy of our time.
Five teams ranked among the nation's top twenty last season are included in New York University's twenty-game schedule for the 1960-61 varsity basketball season.

VENTNOR, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Senator U. Case said here tonight that Premier Khrushchev's "disgraceful and ominous" performance at the United Nations illustrated as never before his determination to "rule or ruin."
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- Following is the prepared text of an address by Senator John F. Kennedy at Wittenberg College here today:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct.17 -- King Frederik IX of Denmark called on the General Assembly today to put aside "selfish national interests" in debating disarmament.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 -- President Arturo Frondizi and his economic advisers examined today the damage that had been done to Argentina's international credit by last week's military crisis as rumblings of the affair continued in the army and air force.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 17 -- Gen. Cemal Gursel, provisional head of state, said today he was ready to stand as a candidate for the Presidency in Turkey's first post-revolutionary elections, expected to be held next year.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct 17 (AP) -- Gov. Dwight Burney today missed Jack D. Obbink, State Aeronautic Director, but Mr. Obbink refused to give up his post.

Stockholders in the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation have approved a new agreement to sell the motion picture company's main studio property in Los Angeles to Webb Knapp, Inc., real estate development concern.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Much of this country's trouble in its recent relations with Latin America stems from a blurred image of the United States held by Latin Americans, Morris W. Rosenberg, news editor of the Associated Press World Service, said today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Soybeans scored further gains in the futures market today, but the grains finished barely steady to slightly lower.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 -- A statement calling on the United States and Canada to prevent war by engaging in peaceful cooperation and competitive co-existence with communism brought on a heated two-hour debate today at the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church In America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The telephone systems in four countries -- the United States, Britain, France and Germany -- hope to establish the first trans-Atlantic link with communications satellites in about a year.
LONDON, Oct. 17 (Reuters) -- Strikes broke out in the port of London today only a few hours after 15,000 dock workers had returned to the job following a four-week stoppage.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy pledged himself today to eight principles of ethical conduct to "restore" an atmosphere of "moral leadership" in the White House. In what staff aides described as a major policy speech at Wittenberg College in Springfield, the The text of Kennedy speech appears on Page 34. Democratic Presidential nominee laid down guidelines he would follow.

The Container Corporation of America, a leading manufacturer of paper packaging products, reported yesterday that its net income in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 declined to $4,180,000 from $4,984,000 in the 1959 period.

GENEVA, Oct. 17 -- The United States, Soviet Union and Britain approved formally today the legal framework of the projected control organization for enforcing a treaty that would ban nuclear weapons tests.
The British Aircraft Corporation, Ltd., a complex of four of Britain's major aircraft and missile manufacturing companies, is preparing for "another round of big subsonic jet plane purchases."

PARIS. AN American family newly arrived in Paris faces a complex problem in getting the youngsters, aged 6, 8 and 13, enrolled in schools. Like many Americans who take up residence in foreign capitals, the family begins with a language barrier.

The New York Rangers yesterday called up John Hanna, a defenseman, from the Springfield Indians of the American Hockey League. The action was aimed at bolstering the Blues, who have lost four straight games in the National League.

LONDON, Oct. 17--The British Government is expected to inform Parliament that a United States submarine tender is to be based at a port in Scotland to supply nuclear-powered submarines armed with Polaris missiles.
HYATTSVILLE, Md, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Henry Cabot Lodge used a heckler's sign tonight in defending the prestige of the United States.
BEIRUT, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- Iran was conspicuously absent from the oil congress here today.
The International Salt Company called Mayor Wagner's charges of rock salt price-rigging "absolutely untrue" yesterday.

The United Nations General Assembly has adopted by unanimous vote a resolution voicing deep concern over the risks to peace created by the deterioration in international relations. To meet this danger the resolution calls on all nations to refrain from any actions likely to aggravate tensions, to take immediate constructive steps toward solving world problems and to support the United Nations as an instrument for peace.
The New York Post announced yesterday its support of Senator John F. Kennedy for President.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The Roman Catholic Church in France published a declaration today condemning violent excesses by both sides in the Algerian war.
BOSTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- American League headquarters announced today that a league executive session had been called for Oct. 26 in, New York to discuss possible expansion of the circuit.
BUFFALO, Oct. 17 -- Vice President Nixon demanded tonight that Senator John F. Kennedy clarify his position on the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

ROME, Oct. 17 -- Pope John XXIII received in audience today 102 Jewish leaders from the United States. They expressed to him appreciation for "the outstanding role the Church played in saving many Jewish lives in the days of the Hitler terror."
Paul Richards, under whom the Baltimore Orioles developed into a pennant threat, was named yesterday as the American League manager of the year by United Press International.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Israel challenged the Arab states today to compete with her for the trade and goodwill of the new African nations.
BUFFALO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller urged Vice President Nixon privately tonight to step up his Presidential campaign efforts in New York State, informed sources said.
LONDON, Oct 17 -- Prices of most leading industrials fell on the stock market here today.
Iowa replaced Mississippi yesterday as the nation's No. 1 major college football team in the weekly poll of The United Press International board of coaches.
R.H. Macy Co., Inc., achieved record sales and earnings in its fiscal year ended on July 30, according to the department store concern's annual report, which is to be issued today.

Years ago the most original thinker among American social scientists, the late Thorstein Veblen, gave central importance to the differences in habits of thought between two types of Americans. One type, the business man, Veblen saw as preoccupied with a world dominated by financial facts, weighing gains and losses or opportunities and problems in terms of their dollar implications.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After carefully evaluating your editorial of Oct. 14, along with James Reston's comments on the Nixon-Kennedy encounter of the previous evening, it is apparent to me that you have indulged in the same faulty reasoning that Senator Kennedy has used regarding the defense of Quemoy and Matsu.

Ishbel Ross, biographer of several American women, has a new one on Harper's schedule for publication Oct. 26. It is "Silhouette in Diamonds: The Life of Mrs. Potter Palmer." Miss Ross shows the influence Mrs. Palmer had on Chicago's growth between 1870 and 1918, presenting her as wife, mother, humanitarian; "social strategist", and as a shrewd business woman who doubled her husband's fortune after his death.
PARIS, Oct. 17 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the section on Algeria from a statement issued here today by Roman Catholic Cardinals and Archbishops in France:

Fourteen contestants on two rigged television quiz shows, including Charles Van Doren, were arrested yesterday. They were accused of lying before a grand jury when they testified that they had never received questions and answers in advance of their TV appearances.
At noon today Casey Stengel and the New York Yankees will disclose whether Stengel will manage the team next season or retire.

The price level at which new prime issues of corporate bonds can be marketed fully was lowered further yesterday with the break-up of syndicates attempting to sell major new issues of debt securities of Union Electric Company of Missouri and the Columbia Gas System.
TODAY'S deal might remind one of the old prepared-hand duplicate contests, in which every hand was tricky and the secret of success was to look always for the most unusual play.

THE old struggle between virtue and vice is the subject of "Tenderloin," which opened last night at the 46th Street Theatre. If you scored it on points, you'd have to say the good won, which is too bad -- for a musical comedy.
SEVENTH AVENUE has a repuptation for being a tough business, but sometimes it has a heart of gold too.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's August Sun traveled in front all the way yesterday and won the feature at Belmont Park. The event was a seven-furlong sprint on the turf for 3-year olds and it attracted a half-dozen competitors.
The Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service will be the beneficiary of an Oct. 25 card party arranged for the Colony Club by Mrs. Robert McCurdy Marsh, the league's president.
A slum landlord whose operations have frequently stirred the wrath of civic groups in Greenwich Village found yesterday that he had become a focus of political turmoil there.
Stocks drifted down yesterday in quiet trading and closed moderately lower on the New York Stock Exchange.
The New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers warned yesterday that unless salaries were raised at the state colleges of education these institutions would be unable to obtain faculty members.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold defended today his administration of the United Nations' Congo program against Premier Khrushchev's charge that he had been "pursuing the colonialist line."
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 17 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Premier, confirmed today reports that the United States had asked Laos to halt its negotiations with pro-Communists.
Detective George Bermudez, who wrote beatnik poetry to infiltrate a Greenwich Village narcotics ring last year, revealed a new talent yesterday. He now can use sign language.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Production of the 1951 compact and smaller autos passed the 300,000-mark today.

Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's address last night at the National Automobile Show dinner in Detroit, is recorded by The New York Times, and his extemporaneous remarks earlier, at the City-County Building:

Textron, Inc., will pay the Bell Intercontinental Corporation $2,500,000 more for the purchase of its defense business than the price estimated at the time of the sale a few months ago, it was announced yesterday.
WARSAW, Oct. 17 - The collective farm movement in Poland is at best getting nowhere and at worst degenerating into a sly peasants' racket.
"You who have dreams, if you act, they will come true."

THE visiting Israel Philharmonic Orchestra moved last night to Carnegie Hall and played under a guest conductor, Josef Krips, in the second New York concert of its current American tour. On Sunday, the orchestra played at the Metropolitan Opera House under the direction of Carlo Maria Giulini.

FIGHT centuries ago Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, stood for principle. He has never been forgotten. Since the early Nineteen Thirties, two dramatists of first rank, T. S. Eliot and Jean Anouilh, have written about him with reverence, and audiences have contemplated his martyrdom with wonder.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 17 -- The South Korean National Assembly forwarded to the Cabinet today a proposal to permit the enactment of retroactive punishment for "traitors of democracy."

NICE, France, Oct. 17 -- Autumn here seems the season of scandals. Summer is over, together with water sports, track and field, cycling and car races, and the snow has not yet come. For the moment, soccer is alone on the sporting stage.
The application of Surrogate Maximilian Moss of Kings County to restore salary increases totaling $37,090 for sixty-seven employes of his court was approved yesterday.

IN mixing decorating styles, mid-twentieth century Americans were outdone only by mid-nineteenth century Americans. Proof of this went on view this week-end when the Fountain Elms "museum" opened in Utica, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy was pushing hard today for a fifth television debate with Vice President Nixon, but the chances for arranging it appeared remote.
NEFTYANANIYE KAMNI, U.S.S.R. Sixty miles out from the port of Baku, on this man-made island in the Caspian Sea, some 4,500 Soviet men and women operate an expanding cluster of oil derricks.
The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western and the Erie Railroads became yesterday the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad after more than three years of merger study.

There are now, as Secretary General Hammarskjold announced yesterday, "close to 20,000 men of the United Nations force in the Congo." These are soldiers, operating under the most difficult and dangerous circumstances. Their presence is made possible, to quote Mr. Hammarskjold again, "very largely through the generosity and sacrifices of other African states."

In what is considered to be an unusual request, Vice President Nixon has asked the Columbia Broadcasting System to delay the televising of his taped appearance on "Person to Person" until Oct. 27. The network, which had planned to present the tape Thursday evening, has agreed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- A fifteen-man committee was named today to combat red tape and cumbersome administration of Federal agencies.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 -- President Eisenhower called on all free nations tonight to help the United States lift the living standards of "disadvantaged" nations as a bulwark against the inroads of communism.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 17 -- Apparently suffering no ill effects from their 5,000-mile flight in the nose cone of a United States ballistic missile, three mice arrived back at the point of departure today.

FOR any number of reasons, a large group of women prefer to wear little heels. There is an exceptionally good selection of , them at Kamen's, 32 West Fifty -seventh Street, which is open from 9:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 -- The United States equestrian team captured the first event of the international low-score jumping competition tonight at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show in the State Farm Arena.
John W. Rumsey, a well-known play agent, died yesterday in Grand Central Hospital after an illness of several months. His age was 82. He lived at 155 East Forty-eighth Street.

WHEN a coloratura soprano from the Metropolitan moves into Town Hall and sings Purcell, Mozart Schubert and Faure, as well as a difficult contemporary work, that is news in itself. When she does it all beautifully -- as Laurel Hurley did last night -- that is cause for delight.

SO much excitement was generated by the world series that too many people lost sight of the fact that Lawrence Peter Berra was quietly making history. Although the stumpy little guy emerged with a loser's share, he moved massively in on the record book with fourteen marks -- eight in batting and six in fielding.

The Queens County Surrogate indicated strongly yesterday that the Civil Jail in Manhattan would not be home much longer for an 83-year-old woman he sent there for contempt of court nearly three and one-half years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -- The Navy flier with the seven rows of ribbons studded with battle stars was trying to figure exactly how he had drifted into show business and why he held a card in the Screen Actors Guild.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 17 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu announced today that he had won the "full moral, economic and financial backing" of Moise Tshombe, President of secessionist Katanga Province.

MANY husbands have told Evelyn Patterson that she has made a great difference in their lives. They are referring to the fact that, under her ministrations, the culinary abilities of their wives have improved out of all recognition.
ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- The State Education Department endorsed today the idea of compulsory driver training courses in all high schools, provided that the courses were required for a driver's license.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs fell back this week from last Monday's Jevels, but were still well above the two-year lows established in early August.
The president of City College issued a report yesterday that he said "documented" his recent charges that Marxist-oriented students controlled one of the six campus newspapers.
The sales of two apartment houses in the Bronx have been negotiated by Efim Fuhrman, broker.
French science, largely supported by the Government, has had its budget increased 75 per cent this year and in 1961 over 1959, it was reported here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Houston Sports Association, headed by Craig Cullinan Jr., an oilman and investment broker, is faced with the task of building a new stadium and putting together a baseball organization that can compete on major league level.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Robert G. Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia, has just returned home from the session of the General Assembly of the United Nations to face the critics of the thankless effort he made there to help President Eisenhower out of what Washington viewed as an embarrassing situation.
Before the year is out some bowler will earn a trip for two to Europe, with $500 pocket money, and many will contribute to the Children's Cancer Fund.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Presidential race may be decided in seventeen states now wavering between Vice President Nixon nd the Democratic candidate, Senator John F. Kennedy, according to a survey by The Associated Press.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- British soccer authorities said today that evidence about the alleged bribery of professional players was being referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Truck drivers in this sprawling transportation center show little disposition to make the Presidential election a popularity contest between their union chief, James R. Hoffa, and the candidate he wants to keep out of the White House, Senator John F. Kennedy.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 17 -- The Senate Subcommittee on Privileges and Elections began an investigation here today into the mailing of a four-page tract opposing the election of Senator John F. Kennedy because of his Roman Catholic faith.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- New steel figures gave added evidence today that continental Western Europe gradually is becoming an island of boom in a sea of world industrial stagnation.

YESTERDAY (Oct. 17, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Heard a statement by Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold on the situation in the Congo. Zenon Rossides, permanent representative to the United Nations of Cyprus, and V.K. Krishna Menon, Minister of Defense of India, made the last two formal statements of the general debate.

The Pennsylvania Tunnel and Terminal Railroad Company and the Manor Real Estate Company, subsidiaries of the Pennsylvania Railroad, have sold a plot of industrial land. It contains 80,000 square feet on the north, side of Skillman Avenue at its intersection with the east side of Thirty-ninth Street, Long Island City, Queens.
Charges that lawyers and physicians may have been paying tow-truck operators to refer cases to them were being investigated yesterday by District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens.

Samuel Weiss, a 23-year-old television coordinator, walked down Fifth Avenue yesterday for a last look at the city, then went home to prepare for an event that he is approaching with mixed feelings of elation and sadness.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 17 -- A slightly built grandmother jumped into the cab of a 45,000-pound oil truck today and delicately moved the vehicle enough to free a man who had been trapped under a rear wheel.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Oct. 17 -- Fred Fellows and Pete Cassella, of Brookville scored 31-32-63, nine strokes under par, to win the Long Island Professional Golfers Associaton amateur-pro tournament at the North Shore Club today.
CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 13 -- New Hampshire Democrats are looking to Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts to lead them out of the political wilderness.
The prosecution completed its presentation of evidence against Jacob Brownstein and George S. Meissner yesterday in Special Sessions.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Troops from Communist-bloc countries are being trained in Czechoslovakia for service in Cuba, directors of the Inter-American Press Association were told today.

Tickets to the inaugural Ball land seats for the Inaugural Parade in Washington next Jan. 20 have been promised to the supporters of Senator John F. Kennedy who will attend tonight's $100-a-plate dinner at the Commodore Hotel.
Buying interest reappeared in the bond market yesterday' with all types of fixed-interest securities registering gains.
The tall, ornamental flagpoles atop the Queensboro Bridge are being removed because rust has made them a danger.

If the Democrats win next month's election, Senator Kennedy would invite key Republicans to join his Administration. Thus he hopes to insure bi-partisan support for his foreign policy and defense programs.
THE one theory that did not occur to "Darwin's Theories" is that somewhere in a revue there should be a shred of talent.
This newspaper has always believed that the judiciary should be, as far as humanly possible, taken out of politics. That it ig now deeply enmeshed in them here in New York State cannot be denied.

R.M.S. Properties, Inc., has purchased the former yard of the West Side Lumber Company at 231 West Twenty-fifth Street. The lumber concern vacated the property recently. The sellers, clients of Walter Scott Co., recently acquired the parcel of 100 by 100 feet.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Doug Ford of Yonkers and Pat lannicelli of the Harrison Country Club won the Westchester County Golf Association's final pro-amateur tourney of the season with a net bestball of 30, 30 -- 60 at the Knollwood Country Club today.
following are excerpts from, Senator Kennedy's address to the American Legion convention in Miami Beach yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times over a telephone line from radio station WKAT:

The Chicago Board of Education raised $15,000,000 in the public bond market yesterday to finance public school construction. The Board borrowed the funds on serial bonds due from 1962 to 1980 at an interest cost of 3.485 per cent.

In the future, foreign trade undoubtedly will play an ever increasing role for United States business. Shifting world trade patterns and how Midwestern industries are adjusting to them is the subject of an article by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago in its latest review.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson charged today that Vice President Nixon had found it "hopeless" to argue the issues and had turned to demagoguery instead.
RED WING, Minn., Oct. 18 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's talk at the Hiawatha Bridge dedication ceremonies here:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee decided today to give priority in debate to proposals on disarmament and nuclear weapons.
In his swing around the country President Eisenhower has emphasized again several aspects of our foreign policy which would seem to be above controversy and should merit bipartisan support.
The Board of Education was accused yesterday of protecting former Communists who became informers, while penalizing those who refused to inform.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Cuba formally accused the United States in the United Nations tonight of aerial aggression against her.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 18 -- Senator John F. Kennedy charged Vice President Nixon with "malicious distortion" today in suggesting that Mr. Kennedy would follow policies of "surrender."
The National Horse Show, starting Nov. 1 at Madison Square Garden and running through Nov. 8, got some enthusiastic advance notices yesterday from two of the men who will run it.

The chairman of the Democratic National Committee predieted here last night that if Senator John F. Kennedy were elected his Administration quickly would adopt a medical-care program for the aged as part of the Social Security program.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- In the Twenty-Eighth Congressional District the Democratic contender is running against formidable odds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I believe I may claim to speak not only for myself when I say that one of the disturbing aspects of the Presidential campaign is the Republican attempt to decry any criticism of our foreign policy as an act of disloyalty to our country in a time of peril.

A series of twelve plays and musicals will be presented in more than 100 of the city's secondary schools next spring under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing, the Superintendent of Schools announced yesterday.
Securities of the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America valued at $40,000,000 are being placed on the market today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Senator Clifford P. Case urged 1,800 students and faculty members at Montclair State College today to support the Nixon-Lodge ticket and the political philosophy of the moderate wing of the Republican party.
The men whose business it is to forecast the ups and downs of the economy will gather here today for a two-day convention.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The loss of Cuba to Fidel and Raul Castro is no isolated case, but a symptom of the general bankruptcy of American foreign policy under the Republicans, Thorn Lord, the Democratic candidate for the Senate, said tonight.
Nineteen city departments and other public bodies were directed by Mayor Wagner yesterday to coordinate their building operations to reduce disruption of the city's streets.
Perhaps not even during his moments of great triumph was Casey Stengel so popular with the fans as he was yesterday during his hour of unemployment.

M. Robert Steel, realty investor, has Contracted to buy Fairfax Hall, a five-story apartment house for ninety families at 1 Club Drive, Woodmere, L.I. The building, which occupies one and one-half acres and fronts on four streets, contains two self-service elevators, an underground garage for fifty cars and outdoor parking for thirty cars.

Adlai E. Stevenson said last night that peace was paramount to all other issues of the campaign and that the best way of assuring peace was to keep Vice President Nixon and his "dangerous impetuosity" out of the White House.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute announced today that it had adopted as a general policy the enrollment of women. The policy to go into effect next fall, recognizes that women in growing numbers are seeking careers in engineering, architecture and other science fields.

EAST BROWNFIELD, Me., Oct. 18 -- This may not be the best woodcock territory in Maine, especially in this great woodcock year, but it will do until something better turns up. A morning of hunting yielded twenty-seven flushes, and more than that have been recorded here recently.
The use of scent in advertising will receive a fillip when an aroma will be used in the Oct. 22 issue of the Eastern New England edition of TV Guide magazine.

COMPETENCE has ceased to be the measuring rod in the Yankee scheme of things. It can be overruled and negated by the date on a man's birth certificate. The Yankees cold-bloodedly jettisoned Charles Dillon Stengel as their manager yesterday, not because his immense skills had become impaired but only because he had passed his seventieth birthday.

GIOVANNI BATTISTA GIORGINI, the Florentine aristocrat who created a postwar Italian high fashion industry out of pure audacity, is taking on another project that will make the made-in-Italy label still more popular among American women.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Starting Jan. 1, taxpayers who are 65 years or older must file a special form if they want to claim deductions for medical expenses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Eisenhower Administration borrowed cash today for the last time, barring unforeseen circumstances. It was a far cry from the first time.

Fred W. Hooper's 3-year-old bay filly Teacation, the betting outsider among the 20,127 fans at almost 10 -- 1, won Belmont's Manhasset Handicap yesterday by a neck from Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Sister Antoine.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A warning that the 40 8 Society may withdraw from the American Legion was sounded today as a Legion committee rejected a move a restore the organization to good standing.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The case of "the mummy in the cupboard" ended today when the judge presiding at the trial of Mrs. Sarah Jane Harvey, ruled that the prosecution had not been able to prove she had committed murder as charged.
KATONAH, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The redevelopment of State Route 22 into a superhighway from Katonah, north almost to Croton Falls was scheduled today by the State Department of Public Works.

CANNES, France, Oct. 18 -- The International Air Transport Association reached agreement tonight on lower-class fare reductions between North and South America and between the West Coast of the United States and Tokyo.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru welcomed today the unanimous adoption by the United Nations General Assembly yesterday of a resolution urging the members to take immediate and constructive steps to lessen international tension.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- New crop wheat firmed on the Board of Trade today, but other wheat contracts ended down. The rest of the futures list closed steady to easier.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Henry Cabot Ladge, speaking in upstate New York, predicted to day that there would be a Negro in the Cabinet if Vice President Nixon were elected President.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture removed restrictions today on the production of sugar beets in this country to help assure ample supplies of sugar.
LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A list of twenty soccer players was drawn up today to be handed over to Scotland Yard in a report to police on alleged bribing and fixing of English League matches.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 18 -- The Southern Rhodesian Government prepared today to declare a state of emergency if African political demonstrations interrupt vital services. African troublemakers would be taken into custody as part of such a program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Considering the needs of the City and State of New York, as well as of the United States, for more facilities for higher education, is it too late to plan that the 1964-65 World's Fair facilities, after their important use, become the site for a great university?

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The dollar price of gold soared to a level of $35.33 an ounce in the bullion market here today, a record since the market reopened on March 22, 1954, after the sharpest increase in a single day since then.

A NEW concern, with a very experienced designer, showed its first collection yesterday and the future looks fine. The concern of Paul Blumenstein, and its designer, Edward Beckham, showed that the garment industry always welcomes a sound alliance.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The nation's railroads and the men who operate the trains agreed today to submit their dispute over work rules and practices to a Presidential commission.
Another contractual wrangle involving "Rhinoceros," Eugene Ionesco's first work on a purely political theme, appears to be developing.
Within a few months the Transit Authority's eighty miles of elevated structure will begin to blossom with signs, billboards and neon displays.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The United States called on the United Nations today to act as a broker in the transfer of surplus foodstuffs to the needy peoples of the world.
Complete details of indoctrination courses for Soviet university students have been published for the first time in the United States.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The Republic of Guinea called today for independence for all the world's colonies before the end of 1961.

TEN days ago my wife and daughter and I made a week-end motor trip in Vermont. Our goal was the Shelburne Museum of antiquarian Americana, but just as important an incentive was to admire the autumn foliage of the Green Mountains. Several thousand other motorists had the same idea most equipped with a camera arid some with several, amd I meditated on the social phenomenon of such a mass movement in search of beauty.

Cocoa futures prices again moved upward yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Gains of from 20 to 28 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) were recorded, reflecting estimate of a 5 per cent smaller cocoa crop and a 3 per cent rise in grindings.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Italy rejected today Austrian demands that she grant regional autonomy to 250,000 German-speaking South Tyroleans.
MIAMI, Oct. 18 -- Vice President Nixon was taken by surprise today by his running mate's statement on the possibility of a Cabinet place for a Negro.
Six medical laboratories have been put out of business as a result of the Health Department's investigation into improper procedures that produce worthless medical tests.
The One William Street Fund, Inc. reported yesterday net assets on Sept. 30 of $246,572,122, equal to $11.76 a share. This compared with $277,827,649, or $13.18 a share, a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Home building activity declined sharply last month, the Commerce Department reported today.
MOUNT HERMON, Mass., Oct. 18 -- Mount Hermon School always has been proud of its excellent academic program, its natural scenic beauty and its ability to turn out fine athletic teams.

THE defensive play made by East in the deal shown today has been extensively written about, and it is worth learning because it usually works. However, this deal is noteworthy because for once the play did not work.
PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 18 (AP) -- One of the co-medalists was eliminated and the other played a close match today as the North-and-South seniors golf tournament began match play.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 18 -- President Eisenhower denounced today "fear-mongering people who like to peddle gloom," and colled for the election as President of Vice President Nixon as "the man of our choice."
Casey Stengel, who in the last twelve years brought ten American League pennants and seven world series championships to New York, was let go yesterday as manager of the Yankees.

Banking circles in New York attributed the sharp rise of the price of gold in London more to weakness in the French franc than to any buying of gold against the dollar. They said that purchases had been made chiefly through Swiss and West German sources.
The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company showed a profit for the third quarter while operating at only 48 per cent of capacity, it was disclosed yesterday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 18 -- The United Nations said today the situation in Northern Katanga was "confused" and dangerous. At least twenty-two persons were reported to have been killed in savage fighting there in the last few days.
The city hag set up a special squad of inspectors "to see that the people of New York get better bus service" on the eight private bus lines.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 -- A way was cautiously opened today that may eventually permit many Lutheran churchgoers to receive communion in company with other Protestants.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A specialist in Russian affairs reported today that the Soviet Union probably could double its cheap oil exports to the West by 1965.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Master William and Ksar d'Esprit of the United States equestrian team, both ridden by Hugh Wiley, captured the second event of the international jumping low-score competition in the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.

The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community borrowed $35,000,000 in the United States market yesterday. The borrowing consisted of $25,000,000 of 5 3/8 per cent secured twenty-year bonds and $10,000,000 of serial secured notes bearing interest rates of 4 3/4, 4 7/8 and 5 per cent, on Oct. 15, 1963, 1964 and 1965 maturities.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points off to 1 up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
The first permanent national headquarters of the Boys Clubs of America was dedicated yesterday by former President Herbert Hoover, chairman of its board since 1936. The headquarters is named for him.
TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- Emperor Hirohito appealed to the Japanese today to "esteem the principle of obeying the laws" and to "cooperate with each other."

A defense of the qualities of the Electra airliner is being circulated by American Airlines among some of its regular customers. Another major Electra operator, Eastern Air Lines, is considering a similar move.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The State Department denied today that the United States had ever cut off all economic aid to Laos.
The Department of Marine and Aviation has completed a plan designed to speed traffic along the five-mile stretch of Hudson River watrefront from the Battery to West Fifty-seventh Street.
YESTERDAY (Oct. 18, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY First (Political) Committee -- dacioed to give priority to proposals on disarmament and nuclear weapons at the current session.
LONDON, Oct. 18 (Reuters) -- British newspapers began an intense circulation battle today for the 2,000,000 readers of the defunct News Chronicle and The Star.

THE chances are that Charles Dillon Stengel will not remain bitter at the Yankees for long, although his pride obviously was hurt when he was told his services no longer would be desired. It would be wholly foreign to his bouncy nature to be bitter at baseball or anyone in it.
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm and Jockey John Sellers dominated the card at Garden State Park today.
The American League's meeting here next week may make some franchise shifts before getting down to the scheduled business of adding two more teams to the circuit.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold counterattacked today against another thrust by the Soviet Union. He warned that "the best members of the Secretariat may withdraw" if they could not accept conditions under which the United Nations "is permitted to survive."
Following is the text of Adlai E. Stevenson's address last night to the dinner of New York Citizens for Kennedy and Johnson at the Commodore Hotel, as recorded by The New York Times:
Every year at least one new star rises in the sports car racing world. This has been the year for Augie Pabst, a member of the Milwaukee brewing family.
A total of 1,047 persons were injured in traffic mishaps in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This is a decrease of twentyeight compared with the same period in 1959.
