VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 18 -- Premier Souvanna Phouma acted today to show his Government was dependent neither upon the young paratroop officer who brought it to power nor the support of pro-Communist leaders.
RED WING, Minn., Oct. 18 -- President Eisenhower urged the nation today to "struggle ceaselessly for the success of the United Nations" as man's best hope for removing1 the causes of war.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 25 -- Behind the Balkan Hotel in midtown Sofia there is an attractive new fruit store with windows full of big baskets of grapes and apples.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 18 -- After considering the usual run of fund-raising projects -- card parties, theatre parties, fashion shows, dances and fairs -- and finding the field overcrowded and the financial commitments high, the Greenwich College Club, an affiliate of the American Association of University Women, has decided to try a new, modest, close-budgeted venture.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 18 -- Two of Long Island's best known Ivy Leaguers are opposing each other again in New York's First Congressional District.

In discussing two original screen comedies currently being prepared at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayor for Doris Day, Joseph Pasternak indicated yesterday some of the problems facing producers under the present Hollywood system that gives final authority to the stars.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson today carried the Democratic campaign deep into the citadel of Republican strength in Pennsylvania's Alleghany Mountains, then moved into Democratic territory.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The Metropolitan Regional Council was urged today to help prevent the movement of industry from the area to the South.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Ten freighters a year at a cost of $10,000,000 each could be built with the money going for increased insurance premiums to meet the high rate of accidents on American ships, the Marine Section, National Safety Council, was told here today.
A comprehensive zoning resolution was adopted unanimously yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
The United States team led Rumania, 2 -- 1, with one game adjourned, in the first round of Section 4 in the chess Olympics at Leipzig, according to reports from East Germany yesterday.

TOURISTS and authors of travel books often declare that the visitor either falls in love with Rome at first sigh or he has had enough of the city after one quick turn. Those who are in the former category and who have tossed a coin in the Fountain of Trevi with the wish for an early return will enjoy Mrs. Beverly Pepper's "See Rome and Eat" (Doubleday, $6.95).
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright charged today that Vice President Nixon had in effect expressed "regret" to Premier Khrushchev over Captive Nations Week.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Stock market prices moved irregularly here today with a few buyers tempted by the lower prices. However, losses, generally no more than a few pence, outnumbered gains in the important industrial lists.

Chicago's Black Hawks, the team regarded as having the best chance to dethrone the Montreal Canadiens as National Hockey League champions, will supply the opposition for the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Jack Rohrbach of Brown, Tom Vasell of Columbia and Ed Shaw of Perm are engaged in a tight battle for the Ivy League's total offense leadership.

The transfer of pupils from predominantly Negro and Puerto Rican elementary schools to schools in other neighborhoods began here yesterday. School officials said all of the transfers should be completed by the end of the week.

A 29-year-old law student who is a victim of multiple sclerosis won his legal battle yesterday to cast an absentee ballot from a Welfare Island hospital and thereby vote for an old school friend -- William J. vanden Heuvel.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Unit for unit and dollar for dollar, world trade outside the Communist sphere shattered all existing records in the first half of 1960. If this momentum is sustained through the second half of this year, the value of imports and exports for 1960 would exceed that of 1959 by almost 11 per cent.
Iowa's Hawkeyes, 28-21 victors over Wisconsin Saturday, captured the No. 1 ranking in The Associated Press football poll yesterday.
A law was urged yesterday to give the boards of education in the state's six largest cities the right to manage their own fiscal affairs.
The Queens tow-truck investigation turned yesterday to a city detective who was said to be practicing law in violation of Police Department orders against outside jobs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America agreed on one thing today: no quotas or tariffs should be imposed on iron ore imports. In a hearing before the United States Tariff Commission, spokesmen for Wisconsin and Minnesota iron mining districts expressed anxiety over the 200 per cent increase in iron ore imports since 1953, and the doldrums in domestic iron mining.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Discovery of a type of cell inheritance controlled by the structural organization of the cell itself, regardless of its gene content, was reported here by Dr. Tracy M. Sonneborn, president of the American Institute of Biological Sciences.
Once upon a time there was a football coach who saw a routine game on the horizon. Quick-thinking neighbors had this heretic committed.
ROME, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- A survey of voter opinion in this upstate New York city points toward the election of Senator John F. Kennedy this year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your Oct. 12 editorial "What Are We Waiting For?" in which you draw an analogy between what President Nasser said regarding "direct negotiations between Mr. Eiaenhower and Mr. Khrushchev," and Israeli Foreign Minister Golda Meir's demand that President Nasser should do what "he advises President Eisenhower and Chairman Khrushchev to do," overlooks certain important factors.
PARIS, Oct. 18 -- A motion hostile to President de Gaulle's plan for a French nuclear deterrent force was defeated this evening in the National Assembly. The vote was 264 to 213.

RIGHT in the middle of one of New York's most elegant shoe salons (Delman at Bergdorf Goodman) is a table spilling over with hand-beaded and jeweled shoes that should make the most blase sultan blink. Needless to say, fashion-conscious women will have a similar reaction when they get a close look at them.

Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy will both campaign in the city today. Nixon forces said last night they had been blocked in a plan to have a helicopter drop leaflets on a Kennedy ticker-tape parade at noon.
Private art collections in the homes of their New York owners will be seen in a tour being arranged for Nov. 15.

PAUL BEN HAIM'S Capriccio for Piano and Orchestra was the novelty last night at Carnegie Hall when the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra gave the third and last of the concerts it is giving in New York before starting on a cross-country tour.

VIENNA, Oct. 18 -- Two United States tourists, one of whom was sentenced to seven years' internment on a charge of espionage by a Soviet military tribunal, arrived late last night in Vienna on their way to New York.

Two candidates for judgeships in next month's elections were found "not qualified" in committee reports submitted to a membership meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night.

Both Democrats and Republicans will have the last word in this year's television campaigning. The final Presidential campaign rallies of the two major political parties will tie televised over separate networks on Nov. 7 from 11 P.M. to midnight.
YONKERS, Oct. 18 -- Dorman Creed, driven by Jack Ackerman, scored a one-and-one-half length victory before 18,057 fans tonight in the pacing feature at Yonkers Raceway.

A plan to harness the tides on the French side of the English Channel with hydroelectric plants that might supply half the electricity needed in France was discussed at New York University here yesterday.
Representatives of 61,000 striking General Electric workers rejected a company truce proposal last night, but countered with a bid of their own for a quick settlement.
Registration for the election Nov. 8 has been high throughout the country, and of record proportions in some places, according to a survey conducted by The New York Times.

ALTHOUGH fall foliage is just beginning to glorify the countryside, it is not too early to think about ordering Christmas cards, particularly if some are to be sent overseas. The following is a list indicating where cards can be found in New York shops, as well as the length of time needed for imprinting the sender's name.

An account of the only attempt to impeach a President of the United States is given by Milton Lomask in "Andrew Johnson: President on Trial." The story begins on the tragic night of Good Friday, 1865, and throws "fresh light" on all the activities of Andrew Johnson on the evening of Lincoln's assassination.
A New York grand jury assailed "certain lawyers and bondsmen" yesterday for "unethical, improper and reprehensible practices." The offenders were not named.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The election will be held three weeks from today. The first half of the campaign, which has been a conflict of maneuver and movement, is over. The last half starts tomorrow when both candidates move into New York and begin the climactic battle for the big states.
The American Hardware Corporation of New Britain, Corin., offered yesterday to buy 15,000 common shares of the Plymouth Cordage Company from stockholders of that company at $63 a share.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 18 -- A school opened here today to teach African and Asian trade unionists how constitutional democracies can achieve results in economic planning and social development. The contrast is with the programs of totalitarian regimes.

A bridge, fashion show and tea will be given by the women of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest on Nov. 2 in the parish house auditorium, 2 East Ninetieth Street. Proceeds will go to Missionary Quota and the General Church Fund.

ICE-SKATING enthusiasts can get back into shape at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink which has reopened for the winter. Morning sessions charge a 50-cent admission and are held dally from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M., except on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, when the morning sessions end at noon and children under 14 then are admitted free.
Bridget Hayward, 21-year-old daughter of the late Margaret Sullavan, the actress, apparently committed suicide by an overdose of sleeping pills, the police said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, former Democratic National Chairman, predicted today that Senator John F. Kennedy would carry thirty-five of the fifty states on Nov. 8.
MOSCOW, Oct 18 -- "I would study in any country that gave me the opportunity," Sumith Deunuwre of Ceylon said as he sat in a lunchroom of Moscow's University of Friendship of Peoples.

Coming to the superintendency of the school system from a term of service as Deputy Mayor, Dr. John J. Theobald had a sharp break to make from politics to nonpolitics. Sooner or later, probably, he was going to have to make the declaration of independence from City Hall and all its old friendships that sound management of education requires.
Casey Stengel received praise from his colleagues after his twelve-year term as manager of the New York Yankees ended yesterday.
Slowly but steadily, stocks wended their way down yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite a minor upturn in the closing minutes, there were sizable losses both in averages and prices.
PORTLAND, Orea., Oct. 16 -- A dozen chattering women, lounging cozily in a television studio, had "Coffee with Maurine" here the other day.
TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 18 -- Two major innovations in United States foreign policy were proposed by Vice President Nixon today.
An African, odyssey by the 20-year-old son of a socially prominent New York family ended in his death during last summer's violence in the Congo.
A new concept of college football was reflected in the major college offense statistics, released yesterday by the National Collegiate Service Bureau.

Many a man carries memories of his college days that include along with the clinging ivy and the Saturday football afternoons fading into dusk, thoughts of Philip Morris wrappers and evenings spent searching for them about the streets.

Bank of America The board of the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, raised yesterday the quarterly dividend to 50 cents a share from 45 cents and declared an extra dividend of 10 cents a share.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 19 -- The campaign in the Third Congressional District is being marked by bitter antagonisms between the candidates.

PIERRE, S.D., Oct. 15 -- Sparsely settled North and South Dakota have only eight electoral votes but there is little question who will get them Nov. 8. This vast prairieland is Vice President Nixon's private range.
The United States may impose a form of harbor dues on foreign ships entering this country's harbors, a leading inland waterway official said yesterday.
The Hospital Council of Greater New York warned yesterday that the number of physicians holding staff appointments with voluntary or municipal hospitals had declined from 1948 to 1958.

IF there was anything pleasurable about the sacking of Casey Stengel as Yankee manager, it was the way this once Artful Dodger manipulated the proceedings. With an adroit sidestep he made inferentially clear that he wasn't quitting of his own choice and that the instigator of his ousting was Dan Topping, the president of the ball club.
Henry Cabot Lodge will be asked by four foreign newsmen on Channel 5 on Oct. 30 what a Republican victory would mean to their countries.

THERE are about 6,000 professional bridge teachers in the United States and nearly every one of them uses a bridge hand exactly like the one shown to illustrate two basic principles of the game, one in bidding and one in Play.

Never on Sunday," the newly opened film that was praised by four of the seven critics, is headed for the musical stage. Three of those involved with the motion picture will be affiliated with the stage transition.

Mail Order of Modie Spiegel's Alamode Farm won the $30,200 Vosburgh Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Although the seven-furlong event was run on a sloppy track, Mail Order turned in the good time of 1:22 3/5 in beating Kenneth Godby's Wiggle II by three and a half lengths.
EAST BROWNFIELD, Me., Oct. 19 -- This was the day for a big young bobcat hound to hunt woodcock with a certain style and to confound a neighbor of Arthur Bucknell's who said:
A special grand jury will be impaneled to hear evidence in the Queens tow-truck investigation, Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange was 3,757,480 shares on Oct. 14. That represented an increase of 132,509 shares from 3,624,971 (revised) shares on Sept. 15 and the highest level since March 13, 1959, when the short position on the Big Board totaled 3,793,575 shares.
A "runaway" clothing manufacturer, under court orders to pay a union $204,861 in damages for moving his plant to Mississippi, has closed his operations there and resumed business in New York.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Jacques Soustelle, ex-Gaullist politician who helped set up two successful political movements in the name of General de Gaulle, launched a third one today in his own name and that of "French Algeria."
In an unusual request in open court, Federal Judge Richard H. Level asked newspaper men yesterday to be circumspect in reporting the arguments on pretrial motions before him.
Stocks closed down on average yesterday for the third straight day despite a moderate recovery movement in the afternoon. Trading continued to be light and the business news was mainly depressing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The United States' second Polaries missile-launching submarine has successfully completed her initial firing test, the Navy announced today.

Cocoa futures prices fell yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The decline was influenced by news that producing countries would not establish a world minimum export price as a method of stabilizing quotations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 12:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 -- San Francisco's fourth international film festival opened tonight at the Metro Theatre with a showing of France's entry, "Love Game." The event will end Nov. 1 with Spain's "Little Guide of Tormes."
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 19 -- In the eyes of the law a scouring pad is worth $150 -- if it isn't in the box as advertised.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 19 -- Hitting hard on foreign policy again today, Henry Cabot Lodge said it would be "intolerable" for Cuba to become an active base of Communist imperialism.

Wide-ranging changes are taking place in the boys' apparel industry, the annual achievement award dinner of the Textile Veterans Association was told at the Commodore Hotel last evening by Miss Shirley Trosk, executive secretary of the Boys' Apparel Buyers' Association, Inc.

A LUXURIOUS addition to the fake flower family has just arrived from France. Called the Fleurs de Versailles Collection, more than 300 varieties of flowers are included, each of which is beautifully handmade of silk in a style inspired by eighteenth-century flower paintings.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Short-covering and export demand accounted for most of the good gains in all grain contracts on the Board of Trade today.

WERNER EGK'S first opera to be presented in America, "The Inspector General," was heard last night at the New York City Center. The 59-year-old German composer was on hand to lead it, and this was his United States conducting debut as well as the work's American premiere.

AS this writer sprinted for the exit last night in Car- negie Hall, he heard a mighty roar go up. Sviatoslav Richter, the latest Russian import, had just finished the Beetho- ven "Appassionata" Sonata, and there could be no doubt that the New York audience had accepted him as one of the world's great pianists, an opinion with which it would be hard to disagree.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 18 -- The Soviet Union and Communist China are reported to be competing intensively for the "understanding" of President Sukarno.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- The United States Ambassador to Mexico warned today that Cuba might attempt to disturb the American elections with a move against the Guantanamo Naval Base.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Many suburban housewives who formerly drove car loads of children to school every day for free now get $40 a week for it, with all expenses of the vehicle paid.

Following is the text of a statement issued by Vice President Nixon yesterday in which he charges Senator Kennedy with a series of "misstatements and distortions." The statement presents the Kennedy quotations together with Mr. Nixon's version of the record:
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The right wing of the Labor party launched today its long-delayed counter-offensive against the rebels of the left who are supporting unilateral nuclear disarmament and neutralism.
A combination of rain, fog and low, fast-moving clouds enveloped the city yesterday afternoon in a dark, sullen mantle.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- One theatre owner has solved one of the most vexing problems of the movie business -- how to persuade people to go to a movie house on a Monday night, the worst night of the week for the movie owners.
Ten thousand city firemen will contribute $1 each to pay the salaries of eight fellow firemen who were suspended without pay for taking outside jobs in their spare time.

The agreement between the railroads and the five operating brotherhoods to submit their work rules dispute to a Presidential commission is the best news from the labor-management front in many a day. In fact, the whole course of the negotiations for the new railroad contracts has been a striking example of a maturity in labor relations urgently needed these days.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 19 -- Salim Basol, the presiding judge at the trial of the leaders of Turkey's fallen regime, is described by his friends as a man who leaves his genial disposition on the doorstep when he departs for work.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Dr. George L. Ford, executive director of the National Association of Evangelicals, charged today that the purpose of Reformation Sunday had been distorted because of ignorance.

Casey Stengel was honored by more than 200 persons at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. The testimonial was staged by the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

Directors of the Brunswick Corporation proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. They also voted to increase the quarterly dividend on the present stock to 20 cents a share from 15 cents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service said today the 100,000,000 instruction booklets it was printing for distribution with next year's income tax forms were misleading in one section.
The United Federation of Teachers, which says it is the largest teacher organization in the city, voted last night to call a strike on Nov. 7.
The New York Knickerbockers, with three outstanding rookies scheduled to make their professional debuts, will open their fifteenth National Basketball Association campaign tonight against Cincinnati.
Senator John F. Kennedy has received 51.1 per cent of the sample votes in the first returns from the secret straw poll conducted in New York State by The Daily News.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A new and inspired Cincinnati Royals quintet set a team scoring record tonight in defeating the Los Angeles Lakers, 140 -- 123, in the National Basketball Association's season opener.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Lawyers for Delta, Northwest and Continental Airlines tried without success today to keep out of the record at a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing testimony linking them with possible merger talks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to strike down a recent Alabama law that changed the boundaries of Tuskegee so as to exclude most Negroes from the city.

The six-story apartment building at 61 Harrison Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by a syndicate of investors headed by Simon Rappaport to I. Millstein, an investor. The structure, on a plot 200 by 100 feet, occupies the blockfront on Harrison Avenue between Penn and Rutledge Streets.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Casey Stengel became a case history yesterday at a conference on aging.

"THE VIEW FROM HERE,"* by Robert M. Coates, is an agreeably relaxed venture in autobiography. It is uninsistent, cheerful and urbane. You may find this hard to believe, but in the course of his personal history Mr. Coates does not solve a single malaise now stirring fevers in mankind.
A 51-year-old chemical engineer was named president and chief operating officer of the United States Rubber Company yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Despite a Soviet charge today that the United States was attempting to win the farmers' vote in sponsoring a surplus food plan in the United Nations, there were indications that the project would be approved easily.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor Robert F. Wagner recently proposed that a national organization patterned after his Committee for a Quiet City be set up. Your readers may be interested to learn that such an organization does already exist and is actively engaged in the educational program which the Mayor's Committee for a Quiet City recommends.
Three judges, a former judge, and three state Senators, all Democrats from Brooklyn, testified as character witnesses yesterday in Special Sessions for Jacob Brownstein and George S. Meissner.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I comment briefly on your report in The Times of Oct. 19 on the question of the status of the German-speaking element in the Province of Bolzano. In my opinion, it outlines the terms of the question in a way that might be misleading.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Following is the text of an explanatory memorandum provided by Cuba in connection with the submission of a complaint concerning "various plans of aggression and acts of intervention being executed by the Government of the United States" against Cuba:
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The dollar price of gold moved up again today on the London bullion market after one of the busiest sessions the market has seen since it reopened on March 22, 1954.

ALTHOUGH our grandmothers thought nothing of knitting and purling a king-sized afghan or laboring by the hour over a fine piece of needlepoint or a hooked rug, there was a long lull during which following generations were loath to pick up such mundane handiwork.

The nation's fifth largest brokerage house, Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, said yesterday that it planned to buy three electronic computers for $1,097,970 in what was said would be the first outright purchase of any data-processing system by the brokerage industry.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 -- The United Lutheran Church in America called on the world's major powers today to halt "all kinds" of nuclear weapons testing under a system of "adequate inspection and control."

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's exchange offer to Baltimore and Ohio Railroad shareholders was criticized yesterday by Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, which, like the C. O., has made a unilateral exchange offer to the B. O.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 19 -- Top United States and Laotian officers here denied today that United States military aid to Laos had been resumed.

Revenues and earnings of the American Machine and Foundry Company rose to record highs in the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30, Morehead Patterson, chairman, reported yesterday. A.M.F. is a leading manufacturer of industrial equipment and machinery and of bowling equipment.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY First (Political) Committee -- began consideration of disarmament proposals made since the breakdown of ten-nation talks in Geneva last summer.
A STORE buyer needs a split personality. Several times a year she ought to be in two places at once. October is one of those times.

CITY-DWELLERS who fancy fresh mushrooms are faced with an acute difference in the price of mushrooms during summer and winter. It follows the ancient law of supply and demand. Mushrooms prosper in moderate cold, they flounder with excessive heat.
HONG KONG, Oct. 19 -- The leading Chinese Communist newspaper said today that the "pushing around of the Socialist camp" by United States "imperialism" must be dealt with seriously.
Adlai E. Stevenson charged here yesterday that the Eisenhower Administration had "talked loudly and carried a small stick."

WOMEN who are less than satisfied with their reflection in the mirror and would enjoy being pampered should invest in a visit to Lucille Bouchard's restful little salon. Located in the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, Mme. Bouchard's tiny emporium is dedicated to relaxing the customer while, at the same time, revivifying her skin.
LEIPZIG, East Germany, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The United States team took a 2-1 lead over Cuba in the third round of Section 4 play today at the Chess Olympics. One game of the match was adjourned.

On the eve of the fifteenth birthday of the United Nations Charter the United States has joined hands with Canada and other nations in a program to strengthen the United Nations by making it the central agency in a great humanitarian enterprise to feed the world's hungry millions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The public has now witnessed the third of the Presidential television "debates" (so-called), and the general view seems to be that they are a good thing. I should like to express a contrary view.

Against a Trend Part of the appeal of "Candid Camera," the new television show that uses the familiar device of having camera and microphone catch our reactions in amusing situations when we are not aware that we are being spied on, is that it runs against a developing trend.
The Milwaukee Braves landed four players on the 1960 Associated Press major league all-star team named yesterday.

The "religious question" is one of several unusual factors that in combination make the 1960 Presidential campaign unique and unpredictable. Another, which exists despite high registration figures, is the widespread lack of interest in, or even understanding of, the issues.

Following are the texts addresses made at the sixteenth annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night by Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon, as recorded by The New York Times:

PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 20 -- Premier Michel Debre, amid howls of rage from Opposition Deputies, asked the National Assembly early for vote of confidence in President de Gaulle's plan to create an independent French nuclear deterrent force.
Life insurance companies were accused yesterday of "a gross and misleading abuse of statistics."
Both Presidential candidates have pledged to continue the People-to-People international sports program, George V. Alien, the director of the United States Information Agency, said last night.
Leaders of 61,000 striking General Electric employes scaled down their settlement demands yesterday, but the company rejected the proposal and broke off the peace talks.
Joseph B. Rosenblat, realty investor, announced plans yesterday for converting the loft building at 307 to 321 East Sixty-second Street to showrooms for interior decorators.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The Soviet Union threatened today to boycott United Nations discussions of disarmament if the General Assembly's Political Committee should "waste time" on the consideration of futile proposals, such as it termed those put forward by the Western states.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Senator John F. Kennedy endorsed today a detailed program aimed at solving "the vital problems of our cities and suburbs."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The United States and Argentina declined today to side with Austria in her dispute with Italy over the South Tyrol.
Designers in America's garment district now are showing their spring collections to the fashion press and store buyers. The clothes will be in the shops in mid-December.
YONKERS, Oct. 19 -- The harness (standardbred) horse is gaining in international stature.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Following is the text of an announcement by the State Department today on a ban on exports to Cuba:
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The stock market became more cheerful today as bargain hunters showed interest in a wide range of industrial shares after the recent extended decline.
YASSIADA, Turkey, Oct. 19 -- Former Premier Adnan Menderes made a spirited denial today of charges that he fomented anti-Greek riots in Istanbul five years ago.

Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy agreed last night that religious bigotry was less of a factor in this year's Presidential election than it was in 1928. They both expressed accord on this point at the sixteenth annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at which they were featured speakers.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 -- West Coast maritime employers have agreed to pay longshoremen $5,000,000 a year for work lost through gradual replacement of men with machines.

Today at noon, the Yankees are expected to name Ralph Houk as their new manager. The announcement is expected at a news conference in the Savoy-Hilton Hotel, where 70-year-old Casey Stengel told the world on Tusday that he was leaving the club because his "services were no longer desired."

Bond prices advanced yesterday for the second successive trading session. The volume of business broadened with the rising demand, giving assurance to observers who had been maintaining that the market for prime fixed-interest securities was in a good technical position.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The United States equestrian team gained two more first places in jumping today at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 15 -- The great debate in Vermont this year centers on whether the Republicans can regain the seat in the House of Representatives they lost in 1958.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 19 -- Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss gave West Germany's public backing today for the suggestion to make the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation an atomic power.

SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Henry A. Wallace, Vice President from 1941 to 1945 under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, said today that the national election next month would be the most important since 1860.

Eastern Air Lines has opened a saturation campaign in print and on radio in Miami and Pittsburgh on behalf of its new Air-Bus service between the two points. The service was started last Friday with the fare set at $40 for a one way trip compared with $47.15 for the coach flight at night and $53.60 for a day coach flight.
Vice President Nixon issued a "white paper" here yesterday charging Senator John F. Kennedy with thirteen "misstatements and distortions" in the Presidential campaign.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19 -- President Arturo Frondizi conferred today with his military secretaries and Economy Minister Alvaro C. Alsogaray for a critical examination of the Administration's economic plan.

Enthusiastic New Yorkers surged around Senator John F. Kennedy during a tumultuous ticker-tape parade yesterday. Thousands broke through police lines along lower Broadway in attempts to shake his hand and wish him well.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 19 -- Mrs. Gordon McGrath of the home club scored a 38, 40 -- 78 to win the low-gross prize from a field of sixty-four in the closing one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Piping Rock Club today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Tom Nieporte, the touring pro from Siwanoy, today anchored the first three teams in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association's pro-amateur event with a 4-under-par 33, 34 -- 67 over the Round Hill Club course.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Ethiopian exports of canned meat will reach 8,000 tons in 1960, or 150 per cent more than in 1958, an expert of the Food and Agriculture Organization has reported to his headquarters in Rome.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 19 -- President Eisenhower approved today United States-Canadian development of water resources of the Columbia River Basin. The Pacific Northwest project would cost $1,159,000,000.
The exhibitionistic, "do-nothing" beatnik is losing his foothold in the Greenwich Village coffeehouses.
Philadelphia is planning to borrow $35,085,000 in the bond market on Nov. 16 to finance public improvements. The funds are to be raised by the public sale of serial bonds secured by general taxation.

ATLANTA, Oct. 19 -- Fifty-one demonstrators, including the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., were arrested here today during sit-in protests at downtown stores. Fourteen Negroes, including Dr. King, refused to post bond and went to jail.

SIMCOE, Ont., Oct. 19 -- Junius Spencer Morgan, a director of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and a member of the famous Morgan banking family, died here tonight in a hospital of an attack of ulcers.

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined by 483,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Supplies fell despite a production increase to 28,518,000 barrels from 27,733,000 a week earlier.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 19 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu's military police arrested at least fifteen persons during Leopoldville's curfew between 8 P.M. yesterday and 5:30 A.M. today.
Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, a convert to Roman Catholicism, said yesterday that every Catholic would take into account the religion of Senator John F. Kennedy in making his choice for the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The United States took the first step today toward building solid-fuel rockets that would dwarf any space vehicles now being used or under development.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Until James A. Farley in 1932 coordinated the Presidential campaign machine of the Democratic party which had been scattered by the defeat of 1928, and then magnetized it to attract and hold voting groups which had been rovers, campaign discipline was the special asset of the Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The United States imposed a far-reaching embargo today an exports to Cuba.

When Homerun Bess, a 3-year-old pointer owned by Claudia Phelps of Aiken, S.C., won the national open pheasant championship at the Three Rivers Game Management Area in Baldwinsville, N.Y., on Monday, the grumbling about October's pleasant Indian summer weather subsided.

The estate of Howard Gould totaled $62,745,139, of which $47,592,898 remains after administrative expenses so far, according to a final accounting of the temporary administrators made known yesterday.

Earnings of the Radio Corporation of America continued to decline from 1959 levels in the third quarter, despite a high volume of sales, executives of the giant electronics, broadcasting and communications concern reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Following is the text of the report on urban problems endorsed today by Senator John F. Kennedy, the Democratic candidate for President. It was prepared by the Kennedy-Conference on Urban Affairs held in Pittsburgh on Oct. 10.
A few tickets are still available for the Nov. 17 performance of "Irma La Douce" at the Plymouth Theatre, which has been arranged as a benefit for the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.
Research aimed at developing a new field for X-rays in cancer diagnosis was described yesterday at a forum sponsored by the American College of Radiology.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A record number of United States citizens overseas are expected to vote in the Presidential election Nov. 8, but this is not expected to have a substantial influence on the outcome.
PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 20 -- For the first time, The New York Times was published this morning in Europe at the same time as the regular edition went to press in New York.
Federal legislation to curb illegal trucking operations in interstate commerce was requested yesterday by the trucking industry.
The Now York Giants and the New York Titans put in a long, hard day yesterday. The Titans will play on Sunday and the Giants won't, but their coach figured they needed the practice.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 to 13 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
The president of City College held to his position yesterday that one of the six campus newspapers was Marxist-oriented under questioning by thirty student reporters.
The Baltimore Colts, the defending champions, have replaced the Pittsburgh Steeters as the total offense leader in the National Football League.
An industry-wide plan to provide severance pay to garment workers whose employers go out of business was adopted yesterday by union and management representatives.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- "Settled Out of Court," by William Saroyan and Henry Cecil, opened tonight at the Strand Theatre.

One of New York's most unassuming pianists is also one of the best Mozart stylists. So it was an important evening at Kaufmann Concert Hall at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association last night when Mieczyslaw Horszowski gave the first in a series of four programs there he is devoting this fall to the nineteen Mozart piano sonatas.
The Pacific Lighting Gas Supply Company borrowed $25,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday.
United States marine insurance underwriters announced yesterday that the nation's major syndicate was revising several clauses to broaden war risk and other forms of coverage for shipowners.

Wertheim Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have acquired for their account 28,200 shares of Baldwin Lima Hamilton Corporation common stock, of which 12,600 shares was purchased by the firm last month.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- Snow laid a blanket three inches thick over Moscow today. It signaled an early start for the Russian winter.
MERCURY, Nev., Oct. 19 -- Science took another laborious step toward the moon today with the successful testing of a third precursor of an atomic rocket engine.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 19 -- The only similarities between the candidates in the Second Congressional District are that both are young lawyers, both have three children and both are big men who once played tackle on their high school football teams.

HAVANA, Oct. 19 -- The embargo on shipments to Cuba announced today by the United States is expected to complete the nationalization of American-owned companies here. The value of such concerns that are not yet nationalized is estimated at about $250,000,000.
TORONTO, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Third-period goals by Bobby Pulford and Bob Nevin sparked the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-1 National Hockey League triumph over the first-place Montreal Canadiens tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The Soviet Union threw its support today behind Havana's complaint that the United States had committed "aggression and acts of intervention" against Cuba.

The fourth annual Golden Harvest Dance for the benefit of Planned Parenthood of Manhattan and the Bronx, an affiliate of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, will take place the evening of November 4 at the Roosevelt.

Hugh Campbell, a Washington State sophomore, is well on his way to setting two major college football pass-receiving records.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The closest Presidential election since 1916 may be in the making if the apparent trend in eight counties is maintained throughout the nation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Oil company men argued today with Government officials from oil-producing countries in a spirited, but even-tempered, debate over a country's right to change or terminate oil concessions.

DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Fifteen residents have entered a controversy here over a proposed parochial school.
SIKESTON, Mo., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman accused Vice President Nixon tonight of making wild and reckless charges in trying to set the consumers in the cities against the farmers.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 20 -- A mechanized post office whirred into operation officially here today as a model for a modernization of the country's mail service.
Both sides rested yesterday in the trial in Special Sessions of Jacob Brownstein and George S. Meissner. A decision is expected today.
The city agreed yesterday for the first time to give paid holidays to 40,000 members of the Police and Fire Departments.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $74,000,000, to $74,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $209,000,000, to $900,000,000.
