Forces making for higher prices for prime debt investments prevailed in the bond market yesterday, but the volume of business slackened and price irregularity showed up in United States Government securities.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- A speculative "gold rush" hit Europe today.
Major advances in the production of shoes and allied lines were disclosed yesterday by two manufacturers.

The Florida Power Corporation borrowed $25,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday. The money was raised through a competitive sale of thirty-year first mortgage bonds to an investment group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The United States won approval today of its plea for urgent consideration of a plan to distribute surplus food to needy nations through the United Nations.

THE last time I saw Hamilton Basso he was traveling again, but only in America and not more than six or seven hours by automobile from his home in Fairfield County, Conn. Mr. Basso, who began life in New Orleans, has been traveling intermittently for much of his life, sometimes for fun, quite often for fun plus the strict- ly professional intention of writing a magazine article about his trip.

YONKERS, Oct. 20 -- United Nations delegates from sixtysix nations sought -- and received -- "mutuel" aid tonight. They all were dinner guests of Yonkers Raceway, and in the fifth race, they graciously applauded the efforts of four wellbred horses from foreign lands -- Canada, France, the Netherlands and the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Philip W. Bonsal, United States Ambassador to Cuba, has been recalled to Washington for "an extended period of consultations," the State Department announced today.

Earnings of the Union Carbide Corporation in the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30 were below the 1959 levels despite increases in sales, Morse G. Dial, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Gardner C. Taylor, a prominent Negro clergyman, yesterday questioned the "good taste" and "determination" of Henry Cabot Lodge in pledging to a Harlem audience recently that a new Republican Administration would name a Negro to the Cabinet.

THE 41-year-old Ralph George Houk doesn't have a single gray hair in his dark brown locks. The new manager of the New York Yankees strikes observers as a fellow who won't acquire any silver thatching as a direct result of this or any other job he tackles.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet official told surprised Middle Eastern oil men today that Russia intended to recapture oil export markets it held before the war.
Thousands of women shoppers in Brooklyn screamed their support of Senator John F. Kennedy last night and, adapting the elbow-driving assaults of bargain-basement forays, tried to get close to him.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Capital Airlines, fifth largest of the domestic airlines, testified today to a desperate and immediate need for cash.
The College Entrance Examination Board started yesterday the first nation-wide program to halt the deterioration of high-school English instruction.

YASSIADA, Turkey, Oct. 20 -- The High Court trying former Turkish leaders here completed hearings today on the case of a gift Afghan hound that former President Cetal Bayar had sold to the Ankara Zoo.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- An effort to have the Supreme Court outlaw all prior censorship of motion pictures ran into heavy weather during oral argument before the court today.
The United States team gained a 3-1 victory over Cuba in the third round of the Section 4 preliminaries of the chess Olympics at Leipzig, according to a report yesterday from East Germany.

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 20 -- There are eleven interscholastic teams at Williston Academy playing football and soccer from the midget to varsity levels. Yesterday, ten of them saw action against rival schools.
Following is the text of a statement on Cuba issued here last night by Senator John F. Kennedy:
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that, "no matter what anyone says," United States prestige throughout the world had declined. He said that it would be "silly" to contend otherwise.

MISSING from the second Yankee press conference of a rather historic week were drama, excitement, pyrotechnics, emotion, laughter -- and Casey Stengel. The naming of Ralph Houk yesterday as the successor to Ol' Case was handled in a fashion that was businesslike and dull.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- Parliamentary opposition that has rarely been more angry with President de Gaulle submitted to the National Assembly tonight a motion of censure on his plan for an independent French nuclear deterrent.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman labeled Vice President Nixon a threat to civil liberties last night.
The Federal Aviation Agency has begun a program to simplify and consolidate safety regulations. The project is expected to take about two years.

New York School District The New York State central school district composed of Bath, Cameron, Wheeler, Urbana, Thurston, Avoca and Howard borrowed $1,265,000 in the bond market yesterday. The district sold serial bonds due from 1961 to 1990 to an account managed by the Marine Trust Company of Western New York.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard and Fritz Berg buried the hatchet publicly today. But even as they professed their friendship they conceded that differences between them on how to meet the threat of inflation in West Germany remained unsolved.
Senator John F. Kennedy called last night for United States aid to "fighters for freedom" in exile and inside Cuba who are seeking to overthrow Premier Fidel Castro's regime.
The General Council of the United Presbyterian Church expressed "outrage and concern" yesterday at the "exploitation of the religious issue in the Presidential campaign."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency detailed plans today for a $163,250,000 expansion of the nation's air navigation and trafficcontrol systems.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 20 -- An Australian Professor of Experimental Medicine and a British Professor of Zoology were named today as winners of the 1960 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine. They are Sir Macfarlane Burnet, 61 years old, of Melbourne University, and Peter Brian Medawar, 45, of University College, London.

Predictions that racial segregation would be eliminated within the next forty years and that world peace would be achieved by the year 2000 have been voiced in answer to questionnaires sent out by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- Adlai B. Stevenson challenged today Vice President Nixon's contention that American prestige and power are at a high level.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- The Soviet Union renewed today its assertion that it would out-produce the United States by 1970.

WOODBRIDGE TOWNSHIP, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Emmett Avenue property owners in the Hopelawn section of this sprawling Middlesex County township are battling the Lehigh Valley Railroad over the parking of box cars loaded with explosives.
The Queens District Attorney said yesterday that a Federal tax agent had been picked up for questioning in connection with an alleged plot by a towtruck operator to avoid paying Federal taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Stereotypers Union was guilty of unfair labor practices in its long dispute with two newspapers in Portland, Ore.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial comment of Oct. 15 relating to the downtown traffic pattern stemming from construction work on the Manhattan Bridge inferred that in exercising Chartergiven responsibility for the maintenance and operation of the bridge the Department of Public Works arbitrarily prescribed a pattern which created chaotic congestion at the Manhattan end of the bridge.
ATHENS, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- One thousands ships, ranging from large oil tankers to transAtlantic liners and cargo ships, now are flying the blue and white Greek flag.

President Lincoln's master spy, Gen. Lafayette Baker, is the subject of "Death to Traitors," which Doubleday will publish next Friday. The author is Jacob Mogelever, former city editor of The Newark (N.J.) Star-Ledger, who is now promotion manager of the Savings Bonds Division of the Treasury Department.
Scientists in several American laboratories appear to be on the verge of finding out what it is that makes fat people fat -- aside from eating too much, that is.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The chairman of Volunteers for Nixon-Lodge denied today that Vice President Nixon had changed his views on the Connally Amendment.
George M. Weiss is not retiring from the New York Yankees. However, it still hasn't been decided what title he'll hold or what duties he'll perform.

Britain's first nuclear submarine, the Dreadnought, is to be christened by Queen Elizabeth today, thus ushering in a new era of British sea power. The Dreadnought will be followed by a second nuclear submarine, and then, if the Royal Navy has its way, by nuclear missile-firing submarines.

Statistics of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's service bureau disclosed yesterday that Mississippi finally had dislodged Syracuse as the country's leading football team in rushing defense.

A panel of thirteen leading business economists were unanimous in voicing the belief yesterday that this country had entered a recession that would grow worse before it became better. But most of the panelists foresaw an early upturn -- probably by mid1961.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange soared 13 to 30 points (65 cents to $1.50 a bale) yesterday, scoring the widest rise in several months.

The speculative fever that has gripped the London gold market is at sharp odds with a basic improvement in the United States' balance of payments outlook over recent months, specialists in international monetary relations emphasized yesterday.
Vice President Nixon called yesterday for a revision of personal and corporate tax rates, and for lower but broader excise taxes to stimulate national economic growth.

George Champion, president, will be advanced to chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank to succeed John J. McCloy when Mr. McCloy retires Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday. David Rockefeller, now vice chairman, will become president and chairman of the executive committee.
The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., announced yesterday that its directors had authorized a write-off of $30,519,000 in connection with its DC-8 jet liner program.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- South African gold-mining shares advanced sharply on the stock market here today as the price of the metal rose on the London bullion market. Elsewhere, prices remained buoyant and most industrial shares responded to increased demand with not much stock coming on offer.
COLLECTING, "no mere illness but obviously a virulent disease," was the subject under discussion yesterday at a Fashion Group luncheon at the Astor Hotel.

If it is any comfort to the Southwestern and Western railroads, which have complained bitterly this year that profits to date have been somewhat discouraging and the immediate outlook uncertain, their trucking competitors have not been so happy about their operations this year, either.

IT does not matter too much this week if one man's meat is another man's poison. Each wife can shop according to her husband's tastes and still find good value. Beef, perk, lamb and veal all are in good supply.
"The Canfield Brothers," a one-hour weekly, drama series with a Civil War background, will make its debut early next year over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

Both cocoa and copper futures prices, which had dropped the day before, rose sharply yesterday, partly reflecting the rise in the price of gold. Many of the purchasers, it appeared, are using commodity futures as a hedge against inflation.
Ralph Houk, who never rose higher than a third-string catcher but who apparently was tabbed for one of baseball's top jobs two years ago, yesterday was named the new manager of the New York Yankees.
Columbia University's football team will be short two letter men when it takes the field at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow against Holy Cross at Baker Field.

ONE way of appraising a new hair style is to look in a store window. Most of the mannequins in Fifth Avenue windows wear wigs that show the latest trend in coiffures. Recently, most of them have had short hairdos.
ON the back jacket of "Good Bye, Ava," a photograph of Richard Bissell, the author, makes a silent statement.

Soviet Russia now threatens to walk out of the latest disarmament discussions in the General Assembly unless that agency promptly adopts its demand for an immediate treaty on general and complete disarmament -- under fraudulent controls.
Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan yesterday urged a White House conference on health care as one of the first duties of the next President.
The Transport Workers Union scoffed yesterday at the city's special inspection squad to improve service on eight private bus lines.

GROTON, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Three young members of a pacifist group succeeded early this afternoon in boarding two Polaris-equipped atomic submarines. The three managed to stay aboard for a few minutes before being either tossed into or pushed back into the Thames River by sailors manning water hoses.

Subscribers have been announced for the October Cocktall Dance to be held in the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East on Sunday for the benefit of the Catholic Big Sisters. Miss Margot M. Murray is chairman of the organization's junior committee, which is sponsoring the event.
Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy will end their series of face-to-face television debates with a fourth one-hour appearance tonight.

A MINIATURE gamut running from the severest purity of abstraction to a kind of bawling gusto of delight in the physical world -- represented especially by the opulently female nude -- is offered by three of the current gallery shows.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters has devised a method by which it hopes to bypass the stringent picketing and "hot cargo" provisions of the Landrum-Griffin Labor Reform Act.

TWO companies have this week ushered into widespread distribution margarines containing, for the first time, corn oil in the liquied state as a major ingredient. These products are an obvious attempt to answer the increasing concern over the relationship between saturated fats and heart disease.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Long Island's professional golf team took a half-point lead in a new triangular tournament today by scoring 10 credits.
Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized 420 slot machines aboard two trailer trucks yesterday as the trucks moved through Brooklyn streets.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Peter Brian Medawar, a winner of the Nobel Prize for Medicine, is Jodrell Professor of Zoology at University College, London. He is renowned for his work on the reactions of the body to various methods of transplanting living tissues, such as skin grafts.
Seven alleged loansharks, including a former patrolman said to have been lending money while he was on the force, were arrested yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 3 per cent below the level of a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Treasury Department said today that a sharp increase in the price of gold in Europe would cause no change in United States policy.
The rain that swept the eastern, seaboard yesterday may have fallen on the just and the unjust with equal intensity, but it seemed to have dampened Harvard's spirits more than Dartmouth's.

YONKERS, Oct. 20 -- Since building is the dominant industry in the Twenty-seventh Congressional District of Westchester and Putnam Counties, the candidates for Representative are hammering at the issue to nail down votes.
Negotiators for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the International Union of Electrical Workers agreed last night on terms of a new three-year contract.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 20 -- Cleophas Kamitatu, President of Leopoldville Province, threatened the province's secession from the Republic of the Congo today unless the army halted political and tribal violence.
Wall Street struck "gold" yesterday. Gold stocks ran up sharply on the New York Stock Exchange. Otherwise, most of the market declined steadily and ended on average with a moderate loss.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower struck out tonight against "misguided people" who lament that the United States is becoming a second-class power and that its prestige was at "an all-time low."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A business slowing was reflected today in the weekly freight loadings reports of the rail and truck industries.
It is unfortunate, and unfair to Vice President Nixon, that his name is now being associated with Admiral Arthur W. Radford in the controversy over the defense of Quemoy and Matsu.
A YOUNG woman whose sewing skill won her a trip to Paris and a chance to tour the haute couture houses admitted yesterday that she took her fashion inspiration from American designers.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to ask the Government to turn over to the city the now unused Federally owned Manhattan Beach Hospital in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- In the Negro districts of the South Side, a fortress of Democratic strength here since Franklin D. Roosevelt's second term, usually meek Republican ward leaders are getting chesty and talking tough.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 -- The United Automobile Workers made public today an editorial, scheduled for publication in its union newspaper, that strongly condemns religious bigotry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, the Chairman of the Democratic Committee, wasn't kidding when he warned his forces against overconfidence in the victory of the Kennedy-Johnson ticket this year. He called this condition "Deweyitis," the reference being to the certainty of Republicans and almost all Democrats in 1948 that Thomas E. Dewey would surely defeat President Truman.
The Board of Education is convinced that New York parents want their children to attend schools near their homes, the Board of Estimate was told yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- Bob Hope, who has starred in musicals on Broadway and in films, believes he has "opened a whole new barrel of apples," by producing a musical for television, in which he co-stars with Perry Como and Ginger Rogers.

THE Metropolitan Championships, one of the principal tournaments conducted annually in this city by the Greater New York Bridge Association, will begin today and last through Sunday. It will be played at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would appoint a citizens' committee to study a scheme -- not used here before -- under which the builder of a private housing development could avoid Federal taxes on his mortgage bonds.
A surprisingly long list of American and world speed records have been receiving authentication by the American Power Boat Association.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- In flation talk was credited for advances today in practically all grain futures on the Board of Trade.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- A McLouth Steel Corporation vice president, C.T. Murphy, said yesterday the concern could not consider expansion in the Detroit area until the Detroit River's channel is deepened.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company said today it sold more cars but made less money in the first months of 1960 than in the like period of last year.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 20 -- Henry Cabot Lodge proposed tonight a program of United Nations action to eliminate economic and social shortcomings in "less-developed regions." He said his eight-point program was also designed to prevent international tensions.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Bill DeWitt's turbulent reign of less than one year as the Detroit Tigers' president ended today with his resignation under fire from the post that paid him $50,000 a year.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Harold Wilson announced today that he would challenge Hugh Gaitskell for the leadership of the Labor party.

TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- Leaders of all the major Japanese political parties joined today in a public tribute to Inejiro Asanuma, chairman of the Japanese Socialist party, who was assassinated eight days ago.
Following is the text of an address by Henry Cabot Lodge last night at Vocation High School in Minneapolis, as recorded by The New York Times

MOUNT HERMON, Mass., Oct. 20 -- The Massachusetts upland game season opened today with hard rain and an unlovely example of why farmers post their land against hunting even in this New England area, where tradition is strongly against it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Labor spokesmen, reported today that twelve unions had officially endorsed Senator John F. Kennedy.
The continued sharp rise in the price of gold in the London market was felt in other markets yesterday.

GENERAL ASSEMBLY Received pledges for extra-budgetary funds: $29,487,500 from thirty-four countries for Palestine refugees in the Mid-east and over $3,000,000 from thirty nations for the programs of the High Commissioner for Refugees.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20 -- The United States equestrian team, registering its sixth international jumping event victory of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show, tonight clinched the team championship.
The Ford Foundation announced a grant of $280,000 yesterday to help test the Highfields approach to the rehabilitation of juvenile delinquents.
The New Rochelle Board of Education was charged with operating "racially segregated public elementary schools" in a suit filed in Federal Court yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The price of gold soared again today on the London bullion market.
It was a well-kept secret. So there was much surprise among viewers of WCBS-TV's 11 o'clock news on Wednesday night.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 20-Senator John F. Kennedy appears to be heading for an unusually large share of the urban vote in central New York.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $135,900,000 for the first nine months of this year. This was equivalent to $2.80 each on the 48,589,543 capital shares outstanding.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower's Council of Economic Advisers estimated today that the over-all level of business activity declined slightly last summer.

YONKERS, Oct. 20 -- Tie Silk of Canada rallied in the stretch and captured the $50,000 United Nations Trot before 23,396 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The first five finishers in the test of a mile and a quarter swept under the wire less than a length apart.
Following is the text of a statement by Senator John F. Kennedy yesterday, replying to a "white paper" issued on Wednesday by Vice President Nixon:
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The Government today announced a ban on demonstrations that had been called for Oct. 27 in Paris by students and workers in support of a negotiated peace in Algeria.

ATLANTA, Oct. 20 -- A second day of widespread downtown sit-ins and picketing by Negroes resulted in twenty-three new arrests here today. A Negro student leader said demonstrations would continue "all day every day" until integration objectives were achieved.

The future of "Taffy," starring Kim Stanley, is in doubt. Yesterday it became known that Anna Marie Barlow's play, directed by Alfred Ryder (Miss Stanley's husband), had canceled its pre-Broadway booking in Philadelphia.

Clever improvisations in the backcourt -- mainly by Oscar Robertson -- enabled the Cincinnati Royals to down the New York Knickerbockers, 113 -- 105, last night before 7,184 fans. It was the first National Basketball Association game of the season at Madison Square Garden.
Following is the text of Vice President Nixon's address yesterday before the Association of Business Economists at New York University:

Arthur Maxwell Co. has sold the seven-story air-conditioned apartment building at 1500 Parker Street, northwest corner of Lyon Avenue, the Bronx, to an investing client of Giller Stein, lawyers. Irving M. Nason and Bernard Kaufman were the brokers.
Designers in America's garment district now are showling their spring collections to the fashion press and store buyers. The clothes will be in the shops in mid-December.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., 20 -- Delegates from Italy Austria politely exchanged discriminations about "nazism," fascism" and "racism" today a new note of bitterness not into their dispute over charges that Italy discriminates against Austrians living in Alto ge of the South Tyrol.

Margaret Rutherford, the British comedienne, visited a junior high school in Brooklyn yesterday. But her appearance brought absorbed attention rather than the comic uproar that usually surrounds her move and stage roles.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The United Nations is confronted with an acute financial crisis as a result of the commitments it has undertaken in the Congo.
A banquet has been arranged for Nov. 6 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza to mark the centennial of the birth, of Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist and Polish patriot.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Though our exports have strengthened most encouragingly after the setbacks of 1958 and 1959, the outflow of private short-term capital is imposing new strains on the United States balance of international payments.
A strike by 800 lighter captains against seven port railroads scheduled for this morning has been postponed and will be mediated under the Railway Labor Act.

The wholesale commodity price index continued its downward trend reaching 83.3 on Wednesday from 83.4 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 85.7 on October 16, 1959.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the Eisenhower Administration had suppressed reports showing that the prestige of the United States had declined around the world.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The foreign ministers of Poland and Czechoslovakia demanded today that the United Nations give concrete instructions to any new committee to negotiate disarmament.

Arnold Praver Associates, builders, have purchased the property at 1689 Second Avenue, which they are adding to adjoining parcels they own. The latest purchase was made from an investing client of Walter J. Dickerson, the broker in the transaction.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Defense Department inau- gurated today a tri-service project to develop a transport plane that can take off and land vertically for use in combat areas.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was greatly interested in your editorial on Quemoy and Matsu -- a republication of an editorial published in April, 1955.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange have been sagging quietly to within striking distance of the lows of the year, but there has been little buying interest at "bargain" prices.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- A return match is being played this year in Westchester County's Twenty-sixth Congressional District.
The New York Titans yesterday signed Don Herndon, a halfback, in an effort to bolster their defensive unit for Sunday's game at the Polo Grounds against the Houston Oilers.

EGG splatters the "Face of a Hero," which opened at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre last night. Some was flung by intent; a great deal more landed inadvertently, thanks to the ineptitude of the playwright.
OWENSBORO, Ky., Oct. 20 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson challenged Vice President Nixon today to disavow the support of anti-Catholic groups.
The appointment of Sidney L. Solomon as chief executive officer of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn department store, was announced yesterday by Federated Department Stores, Inc.
The Superintendent of Schools warned teachers yesterday that he would invoke the CondonWadlin Law if they carried out their threat to strike on Nov. 7.
Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $22,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Admiral Arthur W. Radford said yesterday that Senate John F. Kennedy's stand on Quemoy and Matsu might lead to war in the Pacific.
Republican candidates for the State Senate in New York City and its suburbs decided yesterday to emphasize local and state issues in the remaining days of the campaign.

The agreement between the Longshoremen's Union and the waterfront employers on the West Coast carries the joint attack on the employment problems of automation into new ground -- a pioneering operation that will be closely watched by labor and management in every industry.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The American Legion called today for a total economic boycott against Cuba and if necessary a military blockade of the island to force overthrow of the Fidel Castro regime.

Contrary to state law forbidding strikes by governmental employes the membership of the United Federation of Teachers, A.F.L.-C.I.O., has voted to strike the New York City public schools on Nov. 7. About 90 per cent of 3,500 teachers present, out of a claimed union membership of more than 10,000, voted to take this illegal course.
TORONTO, Oct. 20 -- Gold issues set a frantic pace on the Toronto Stock Exchange today, with more than 2,000,000 shares traded and prices at new highs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Navy officials made it clear today that they believed the United States was many years ahead of the Soviet Union in the development of nuclear-powered, rocket-firing submarines.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings climbed into third place to the National Hockey League tonight by blanking the Boston Bruins, 5 -- 0. The game was enlivened in the second period by a flurry of fisticuffs.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- Premier Khrushchev declared today that the Soviet Union had nuclear submarines capable of firing rockets with nuclear warheads. He asserted, however, that they would not be sent to cruise near American shores since this would be "a criminal policy of the brink of war" and could turn the "cold war" into "a hot one."
Nautilus of the triple entry trained toy Mickey Walsh was the "big" winner of the New York Turf Writers Cup at Belmont Park yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Those man-made icebergs, the modern glass skyscrapers, may be fine to work in, but many families seem to think, not to live in.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower has cautioned against pessimism in the Republican ranks. He did this in an effort to dispel any gloom over Vice President Nixon's chances of victory in the November election.
Although the Fifth Congressional District of Queens is predominantly Democratic in party registration, its voters since 1952 have sent a Republican to the House of Representatives.
The board of directors of the Western pacific Railroad Company decided yesterday to oppose plans to make the system a part of the Southern Pacific Company.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Mike Fetchik, the anchor man, carried Long Island's team of professionals to victory over Westchester and New Jersey in a new $6,000 tournament today over the lower course of the Baltusrol Golf Club.

The American Trucking Associations, Inc., trade organization of the nation's motor freight carriers, yesterday elected John J. Gill as president to succeed Welby M. Frantz, who was named chairman. Both offices carry one-year terms.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Debate craokled overtime through the second annual Arab Petroleum Congress today over the Saudi Arabian claim that oil company transport and price calculations cost oil countries $2,500,000,000 in the last seven years.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that while "some reverses have been suffered" the over-all prestige of the United States remained high.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A team of Government scientists disclosed today a new way to detect earthquakes, tornadoes and other natural phenomena at great distances.

We would all do well to think seriously about the warning we have been given by the London gold market's gyrations these last few days. On Wednesday and Thursday the London price of gold soared from about $35.25 an ounce to, at the peak, more than $40 an ounce, an indicated depreciation of the value of the dollar in terms of gold of about 14 per cent at the extreme.
Two members of the liberal wings of the Republican and Democratic parties are waging a hard-fought contest in New York's Fourth Congressional District, in central and north-eastern Queens.
DIGNE, France, Oct. 21 -- President de Gaulle warned political extremists today against plunging France into suicidal strife over the Algerian war.
CAMBRIDGE, England, Oct. 21 (AP) -- An emergency court set up in a maternity hospital has saved the life of a day-old boy and made British legal history.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The West won by a narrow margin over the Soviet Union today in a race to produce a declaration of world economic cooperation.
Jacob Brownstein and George S. Meissner, Brooklyn lawyers, were found guilty yesterday of violating the Multiple Dwelling Law in five tenements on Manhattan's West Side.

CAMDEN, N.J. Oct. 21 -- With clear weather and a fast track in prospect at Garden State tomorrow, thirteen 2-year-old fillies will match strides in the $153,055 Gardenia Stakes at a mile-and-a-sixteenth.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21 -- The Venezuelan equestrian team captured the Prix des Nations international jumping event of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.
Although the present monetary "gold rush" is drawing all the attention, the metal also has been experiencing an increased demand from other sources.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 21 -- Belkacem Krim, Vice Premier and Foreign Minister of the Rebel Algerian Provisional Government, expressed the belief tonight that the United Nations could achieve without delay a peaceful solution to the Algerian problem.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- Communist China still is receiving more than three times as much Soviet aid in industrial construction as any other country within the Communist bloc, according to official data published this week.

NECKLINES are wide open for scarves this season. With stand-off collars or cardigan styles (no collar at all) coats and suits depend on scarves for a finished effect. In response to this demand, stores are laden with a colorful variety of neckpieces that run the gamut from fur to filmy chiffon.
A detective proved yesterday in Felony Court that a man he had arrested for a larceny last week was not guilty. He had worked on his days off to prove himself wrong and free an innocent man.
HAVANA, Oct. 21 -- Maj. William A. Morgan, a native of Toledo, Ohio, and an officer of the Cuban Army, has been arrested on a charge of "counter-revolutionary activities."

THE way tournament bridge has been booming in the United States during the last ten years, it would not be surprising if the optimistic estimate of 35,000,000 American bridge players shown by "sampling" polls should be revised upward.
Flolowing is the transcript of last night's television debate between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy, as recorded by The New York Times.:

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 21 -- The 2,000,000 members of the Disciples of Christ denomination, officially known as the Christian Churches, were called upon tonight to establish at least 1,500 new congregations in the coming decade and to raise more than $400,000,000 for the work of the church at home and overseas.

Senator John F. Kennedy asked the State Department last night to release reports on the status of United States prestige abroad on the ground that Vice President Nixon had said he had no objection to their disclosure.
Two leading tobacco companies reported yesterday that their sales and earnings in the third quarter of this year were below the levels of the 1959 period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets fell 0.2 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 119 per cent of the 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Willie Toweel of Benoni, South Africa, will take a record of twenty-three knockouts and high hopes for a welterweight title shot into the ring tonight when he meets Emile Griffith in the ten-round main event at Madison Square Garden.
The United Nations, which responded to the Congo's call for help, is now running into both a financial and a political crisis that call for new action.
ROSLYN, L.I., Oct. 21 -- Residents of this community are lending their moral and financial support to three young men who are attempting to bring legitimate theatre to Long Island.
Commodity prices closed mostly down yesterday on the New York exchanges in dull trading. Evening of positions before the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

AT the end of the New York Philharmonic concert yesterday afternoon, Leonard Bernstein returned to the podium, looked out into Carnegie Hall, and said: "I'm delighted, and I compliment you for having stayed."
Actors Equity Association has scheduled an emergency meeting of its governing body for tomorrow at 2 P.M. to act on the dispute involving the canceled Equity Library Theatre production of "Dead End."

"THE SNAKE HAS ALL THE LINES,"* by Jean Kerr, is a splendid encore to her "Please Don't Eat the Daisies." Little by little the titles of her book are creating an impression of a pastoral scene rich in the hazards of paradise.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 21 -- The three highest Roman Catholic prelates of Puerto Rico have forbidden church members to vote for the Popular Democratic party of Gov. Luis Munoz Marin.
ATLANTA, Oct. 21 -- Mayor William Hartsfield sought a truce today in the sit-in and picketing demonstrations now in their third day here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an average rise in freight rates for the nation's railroads of more than 1.5 per cent, effective Monday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 21 -- Tension mounted today in relations between Ghanaian soldiers of the United Nations force here and the Congolese army police.

Columbia will meet Holy Cross this afternoon at Baker Field in its first non-Ivy League encounter of the season. Coach Buff Donelli's Lions will be as close to top strength as they have been all year. The game will start at 1:30.
NEWARK, Oct. 21 -- The growth of Essex County's cities and suburbs is dependent on the development of commuter transportation, the state Division of Employment has found.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 21 -- Promising results from tests on animals and humans of two synthetic hormones that may prove effective in the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis were reported here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Directors of Amalgamated Sugar Company, Ogden, Utah, announced today that stockholders at the annual meeting on Dec. 22 would vote on a capital reorganization plan that in effect would split the common stock two for one.

What has happened to the European Jew since World War II is discussed by Herbert Agar in his new book, "The Saving Remnant: An Account of Jewish Survival." The book is the result of a trip the author made to Israel, where he was impressed with the vigor of the new nation and by the stories of people who had fled there from Europe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Officials here hope that the gold bubble has burst, as reports from abroad say it has, but they regret that it bubbled at all.

Pierre Salinger, press secretary for Senator John F. Kennedy, denounced last night what he said were erroneous reports in certain London newspapers that the Democratic candidate had said privately that, if elected, he would devalue the dollar.
The Brazilian Government has acted to achieve stable trade conditions for her exports through reliance on shipping operated under the conference system of rate making.

A five-minute television film being used by the Democratic National Committee was denounced by Vice President Nixon's forces yesterday as "vicious political trickery" and stoutly defended by aides of Senator John F. Kennedy.

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 21 -- This Pacific "oceanside city is playing host over the week-end to one of the finest groups of the world's leading auto race drivers and racing machinery ever assembled for an American sports car event.
Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy last night barred any member of the Police Department from soliciting or accepting money to pay any fine or penalty for holding an outside job.

The United States tied Spain for the lead in Section 4 of the chess Olympics at Leipzig by beating Ireland, 4 -- 0, in the fourth-round preliminaries, according to a report yesterday from East Germany. The pacesetters have scores of 12 1/2 -- 3 1/2.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Page 1 of your Oct. 16 issue Mr. Kennedy was reported to have asked potential voters in Newcastle, Pa., "What is Mr. Nixon, anyhow?" May this small town independent voter presume to answer?

DECATUR, Ala., Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Former President Harry Truman, in a denunciation here tonight of Republican "bums," called Vice President Nixon a "no good" and declared that President Eisenhower lacke dthe "guts" to stop the spread of communism in Cuba.
The chairman of the Federal Maritime Board appealed to American business this week to ship more goods on American-flag vessels.

A pontoon-equipped helicopter operated by the Port of New York Authority made a "precautionary" landing on the East River yesterday and was towed to a ferry slip at Ninety-second Street. The pilot and three passengers were unhurt.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the opinion of this maverick Democrat, neither of the two great political parties possesses a monopoly of virtue. Each is encumbered by its troglodytes. Yet, on the basis of performance in the twentieth century, the Democratic party, in spite of its Southern wing, seems more entitled to be considered the party of compassion and progress than its Republican rival.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 21 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson told 40,000 Missouri farmers today that the Republicans were plowing under the American people.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company applied to the federal Communications Commission today for permission to establish an experimental space communications system across the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- H. L. Hunt, the Texas oil millionaire, is being sought for an interview by the Senate Subcommittee on Privileges and Elections.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 21 -- The United States Embassy said here today that it had received authority to release funds for paying the Laotian Army for September.
A big deal to import Soviet cars has fizzled. A dealer who had contracted to bring in 10,000 Moskviches in two years said one of the reasons was the deterioration of East-West relations.

BY thundering out objections to an anti-Soviet remark in Beethoven Hall in Bonn yesterday, the Soviet Ambassador to West Germany sacrificed the reputation he has long enjoyed as "soft-spoken." Andrei Andreyevich Smirnov showed that he could raise his voice, not to mention his blood pressure, in the most vivid show of Soviet outrage since Pemier Khrushchev used his shoe as a sort of outlaw gavel in the United Nations General Assembly two weeks ago.
CONTEMPORARY life lacks those values that create public purposes, according to August Heckscher, Director of the Twentieth Century Fund.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Army's football forces are hopeful of snapping a two-game losing streak when they encounter Villanova at Michie Stadium tomorrow.

Bormar Properties of Long Island City has bought a parcel of vacant industrial land containing 90,000 square feet on the north side of Thirty-first Avenue, west of the New York Connecting Railroad in Woodside, Queens.

Stocks declined yesterday in expanded trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The price erosion was general and no one group withstood the inroads. Key averages ended down for the fifth successive day.
Radio station WCBS will expand its own programing next month when the Columbia Broadcasting System cuts its radio network time each evening.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board is expected to approve proposed major reductions in international air fares by early next year.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Grain futures prices closed irregular today with most wheat contracts in new high ground for the season. Soybeans also finished higher, but other grains ended mostly lower.

The Imperial Commodities Corporation, importer and exporter of rubber and tobacco, has leased a floor in the office building at 1 Liberty Street for its rubber and accounting divisions, now at 70 Pine Street. The lease was negotiated by Charles L. Goldenberg and Ira Koerner of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agent for the building.

The long-awaited $250,000,000 debenture issue of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is to be offered at competitive sealed bidding next Tuesday. Few other new issues are scheduled for offering in the market for new capital next week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Twenty member nations asked the United Nations today to urge the powers administering colonies or territories to include natives in the work of United Nations bodies as part of their progress toward independence.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an effort to explain away President Nasser's refusal to apply in the Middle East the same prescription for the solution of world problems he offered in his address to the U.N. General Assembly -- namely, direct negotiations between the two parties, Sami Hadawi, in The Times of Oct. 19 again repeats the often exposed stock Arab propaganda arguments against Israel.

WARSAW, Oct. 21 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Poland's Communist leader, challenged the Western powers today to accept a Polish proposal for an atom-free zone in Central Europe to prove that they want disarmament.
For the first time within the memory of man or blocking dummy, the New York Giants donned shoulder pads and helmets for a regular-season workout at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

SO far, no foolproof recipe has been devised for turning a pumpkin into a Cinderella's coach. Nevertheless there art some near-magic formulas that can transform pumpkins into tasty dishes. And the resultant fare need not be the traditional pumpkin pie.
FLORIDA, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Federal, state and local officials joined today in ceremonies to keep alive the names of Liberty ships that served in World War II.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A struggle is going on within the Administration over the question of reducing United States ground forces in Europe.

THE brilliant, proud and irascible Alexander Hamilton was the central figure in "Not Without Honor," a dramatization on Channel 4 last night. Despite certain shortcomings, it was a commendable study of the last years of the life of the first Secretary of the Treasury.
Mrs. Richard M. Nixon took off her gloves yesterday and gave her husband a hand -- and gave it and gave it and gave it.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 21 -- Andrei A. Smirnov, Soviet Ambassador to West Germany, was ushered out of a public meeting here today after having shouted interruptions of a speech in which a Cabinet Minister attacked "Communist totalitarianism" as "worse than colonialism."

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 18 -- The hopes of Senator John F. Kennedy in Minnesota rest to an important degree on the shoulders of the man he defeated in the Wisconsin and West Virginia Presidential primaries -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Hal Price Headley's Rash Statement drove past Indian Maid and Royal Native, who were locked in a head-and-head duel, and won the $87,750 Spinster Stakes today at Keeneland.

BARROW - IN - FURNESS, England, Oct. 21 -- Queen Elizabeth II launched Britain's first nuclear-powered submarine today and assured the West of another weapon against the growing threat of the Soviet Union's underwater fleet.
The handful of survivors in the scramble for undefeated glory will be exposed to heavy fire today as the college football campaign reaches its midpoint.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Cape goldmining shares dropped sharply when the stock market opened today on the denial by the United States Treasury of any change in the buying price of the metal. They lost more of their shine after the London bullion market had fixed a lower gold price.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The "gold rush" slowed to a crawl on the London bullion market today.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday lifted the sixty-day suspension imposed last Sept. 6 on a fire officer for taking spare-time private employment.
Company and union negotiators will meet with Federal mediators this morning in an atmosphere of quickened hope for a settlement of the twenty-day-old strike of 61,000 General Electric workers.

When Oscar Obert steps into a chilly court in the Brownsville Recreation Center today he will not only be defending his national one-wall handball championship but twenty-three years of family tradition as well.
One of the world's largest corrugated box plants was dedicated in Los Angeles yesterday by the National Container Corporation of California, a subsidiary of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company.
It must be a long time since a musician of such artistic eminence as Louis Kentner has appeared in New York in a public concert hall seating only 275 people. That is what happened last night.

Benguala jumped flawlessly in carrying Montpelier's colors to victory in the $50,000-added Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. Under the steady urging of Albert Foot, Benguala finished three lengths ahead of June McKnight's Chufquen in the grueling test of about two and a half miles.

An American business man cheered some Britons yesterday. In a talk to British Ford dealers, Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, their American parent company, called the present slowing in the British auto industry temporary.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 21 -- Vincent J. Squillante, reputed head of garbage collection rackets in Nassau County, was reported missing today as his trial on two counts of extortion neared.

The Small Business Administration has continued to liberalize rules governing financing of small business by its licensees -- the small business investment companies. Yesterday it announced four new change in rules.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 21 -- Henry Cabot Lodge predicted tonight that the "cold war" might last for another twenty-five years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency announced today a five-nation international air traffic survey aimed at better use of the airspace across the North Atlantic.
Early autumn finds three of the most prominent non-commercial theatres here busy with exhibition plans on three different levels.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y. Oct. 21 -- This village of commuters' homes, clubs and estates will vote Wednesday in a special referendum on whether a controversial $500,000 village hall should be built.
VIENNA, Saturday, Oct. 22 -- The Austrian coalition Government of conservatives and Socialists headed by Chancellor Julius Raab resigned early today.

The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation had net income of $647,902, or 17 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1960. This was in contrast to a net loss of $3,913,320, after a tax credit of $4,255,400, in the 1959 period, when operations were affected by the nation-wide steel strike.

A Musical Olympics Now that the young competitors in history's biggest Olympic games have returned from Rome to their homelands with cherished medals or shattered dreams, the youth of the world have assembled for Olympic competition in another of Europe's venerable cities.
The Flight Engineers International Association declared yesterday that the introduction of jets on the nation's airlines had brought flight crew unemployment "far ahead of expectations."

YONKERS, Oct. 21 -- A dilapidated bakery truck containing pure heroin that would retail for $5,000,000 was seized here today on the edge of the Cross County Shopping Center. The vehicle had just left the New York State Thruway.

YONKERS, Oct. 21 -- F.E. Ross' Air Record, a 4-year-old brown mare by Bombs Away out of Torrid Scot, clinched a place in the International series, which starts at Yonkers Raceway next Thursday, by winning the Ardsley Trot in 2:03 2/5 before 21,317 fans tonight.

HALIFAX, Vt., Oct. 21 -- With the Vermont deer season coming on, it will be necessary for the good of the soul pretty soon to try out Dr. John Olson's tree platform. This structure has been getting by unnoticed too long and human psychology, even more than forest biology, demands that it be noticed.

Ralph Houk, who wasted little time making decisions when shrapnel was buzzing around his ears in World War II, yesterday released Eddie Lopat as the Yankees' pitching coach. This move came on Houk's first full day as the manager of the New York club.

The Purple Gang, the roughest bunch of non-delinquents in suburbia, invade White Plains today for their biggest rumble of the football season. It will be the fifty-fifth game between New Rochelle and White Plains. The winner will be the Westchester County public school champion.
Joseph Silverstein, 28-year-old violinist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, last night won the largest prize ever offered a string player in this country.
Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy clashed before a national television audience last night over United States policy toward Cuba and the Chinese offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu.

EARLY Christmas shoppers might take care of several youngsters on their lists in Altman's sixth-floor toy department. One of the main attractions here is a group of wind-up trains from Germany. They are made of a sturdy wood and finished in fire-engine red enamel.
A further improvement in prices paid for high grade corporate bonds took place yesterday in a trading session that otherwise was uneventful.

LATE afternoon concerts are common enough on Saturdays and Sundays. Yesterday saw the opening of a Friday series at 5:45 in Town Hall. Before the season is out, twenty-eight programs, largely devoted to chamber music, will be given in this series.

TOKYO, Oct. 21 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda and other Cabinet members told the Diet (Parliament) today that Japan must continue to support the United States and the Western Allies while pushing economic expansion at home.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- An Army general has patented a traveling case in which two officers' caps can be carried safe from crushing. There is also space for a flat briefcase of loose papers.
Rabbinic and lay leaders of Reform Judaism expressed concern yesterday over what they held was an "intensified drive to inject religious bigotry into the final stage of the Presidential campaign."
Leaders behind the threatened walkout of teachers on Nov. 7 were accused yesterday by the president of the Board of Education of "acting in bad faith."
Two established concert musicians testified in Magistrates Court yesterday in defense of the right of a coffeee house to serve Bach without a cabaret license.
Cotton futures moved 5 points off on October and were steady to 12 points up on the other contracts yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. A point is equivalent to 5 cents a bale.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Italy sharply criticized the Soviet Union's disarmament plans today as lacking in control measures that would inspire international confidence.
YASSIADA, Turkey, Oct. 21 The court trying former Turkish leaders pressed witnesses today for evidence that the 1955 ant-Greek riots in Istanbul had been planned by the Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Nixon - Kennedy debates are probably over, and the general feeling here tonight was that it is none too soon.

IN what may be the last of the television debates -- and it certainly seems wrong that they should end so many weeks before Election Day -- simultaneously confirmed last night the essential usefulness of the new campaigning technique and the need for greater flexibility in the rules.
There is no place in a women's liberal arts college for such "practical" studies as cooking and interior decoration, Henry Boorse, dean of the faculty at Barnard College, said yesterday.
Members of three major faiths are celebrating United Nations Sabbath this week-end on the fifteenth anniversary of the founding of the world organization.
Nina Simone, who appeared with her trio at Hunter College last night, is a singer and pianist who defies easy classification.
The State Commission Against Discrimination was accused yesterday of having "damaged irreparably" the reputation of Queens College and the Board of Higher Education.

Senator Kennedy plans, if elected, to revitalize the administration of our foreign policy in the following ways: He would appoint a major American figure as ambassador to NATO. He would insist that all envoys in vital posts abroad should, wherever possible, speak the local language.

Last May, Chekhov's "A Country Scandal" was the subject of an experimental audience reaction test. Part of the data gathered was employed to meet the expressed tastes of the theatregoers. Subsequently, the play's long off-Broadway run was attributed by Amnon Kabatchnik, co-producer, to script changes made accordingly.

PAGAN and mythological subjects vie with religious themes in the rewarding exhibition, "Italian Master Drawings of Three Centuries," at the Este Gallery, 965A. Madison Avenue. The chronological range here extends from about 1550 to 1800, with the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries dominating.

Vice President Nixon indicated last night that he would accept Senator John F. Kennedy's proposal for a fifth nation-wide television and radio debate. But the Republican Presidential candidate said it would depend "solely on my schedule" and suggested he might make a debate of two hours' length a condition of his acceptance.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller, after consulting 100 of the country's top industrialists, said today there was better business ahead.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Czechoslovakia said today that the United Nations had played a "dirty role" in the Congo. She served notice that the Soviet bloc would not share the costs of the United Nations operation.
Two hundred Queens tow-truck operators and owners will be subpoenaed on Monday by Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor in his search for evidence of possible pay-offs by truckers to policemen.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21 -- Yale's Ivy League leaders take time out from their quest for the conference title to play Colgate tomorrow in the Bowl.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Oct. 21 (Reuters) -- The Johannesburg Stock Exchange erupted into bedlam today as almost every dealer in the city scrambled to deal in booming gold shares.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Yale's unbeaten eleven, taking a day off from the rigors of Ivy League play, fattened up at the expense of Colgate today, 36 -- 14. The Elis used a simple formula in sweeping to their fifth straight success of the season. They waited for their rivals from upstate New York to make mistakes and then pounced on them.
The Women's Service for Asthma will hold a dinner-dance and fashion show in the Versailles Suite of the Astor on Nov. 12.
Auxiliary committee heads for the Imperial Ball have been announced by the co-chairmen, Mrs, Walter S. Gubelmann and Mrs. Stanley C. Hope.
PROVIDENCE, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Brown University scored its first football victory of the season today, turning back the University of Rhode Island, 36 -- 14.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 -- Patches of the fatty substance that clogs blood vessels in atherosclerosis have been grown in artificial arteries of plastic, a Baylor University scientist reported here today.

HAVANA, OCT. 22 -- The Cuban economy has now become almost entirely dependent on the Soviet Union and the Communist bloc as a result of the United States' embargo on exports to this island. The fact that the United States exempted food and medical supplies from the embargo will mean little to the Cuban people, as the Castro regime is determined not to buy from the United States.
Bigger and bigger splashes are being made at launching sites along the nation's inland waterways as a result of water carriers' ordering larger and more powerful towboats.
ATLANTA, Oct. 22 -- Negro leaders reached an agreement with Mayor William Hartsfield here today to suspend for thirty days the sit-in campaign that began on Wednesday.

SIEGFRIED KRACAUER has combined scholarship and a deep love of camera work, from daguerrotype to modern cinema, to produce an extraordinary work. His "Theory of Film" supplies endless ammunition for anyone who wants to discuss the pros and cons of the motion picture as an art form.

ROME. THE names Alberto Moravia, Carlo Levi and Vasco Pratolini are familiar to every American reader of Italy's postwar literature, but the name Brunella Gasperini -- who has a much wider audience in Italy than any of them -- is almost completely unknown.
BOULDER CITY, Nev. -- A good share of the 50,000 persons expected to attend the championship boat races on Lake Mead next month will pass through this, the newest incorporated city in Nevada.

NEW METER -- A new international standard of length, replacing the platinum-iridium meter bar which has been kept near Paris as the international standard since 1889, was adopted last week by the General Conference on Weights and Measures in Paris.

Through most of Vice President Nixon's campaign speeches there runs one dominant theme: The next President of the United States must be a man Nikita Khrushchev and the Communists cannot mislead or delude.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A United States citizens advisory group to strengthen the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is expected to be set up soon after the elections next month.
Brooklyn Tech won its third straight Public School Athletic League game by defeating New Utrecht, 27 -- 12, at Boys Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.
NEWARK, Oct. 22 -- A 9-year-old boy who had spent a day and a night away from home trying to earn enough money to get his dog back from the city pound was found by the police today.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct., 22 -- Iowa's passing attack faded, but an 84-yard scoring run with a fumble paved the way to a 21-14 victory over Purdue today.

Leaders of major Protestant denominations denounced yesterday plans of a number of conservative church groups to use Reformation Sunday, a week from today, for political rallies against Senator John F. Kennedy.
Lufthansa, the West German airline, is an international illustration of the economic recovery of the Federal Republic of Germany.
A SELECTION of work by the Photo - Secession group founded by Alfred Stieglitz in 1902 to demonstrate that photography was a fine act went on view last week at the George Eastman House in Rochester.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass, Oct. 22 -- The reverse pass, one of the leading topics of John Yovicsin's outdoor football seminars at Harvard this week, enabled the Crimson to beat Dartmouth today, 9 -- 6.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Republican leaders in four of the state's southern tier counties are becoming increasingly concerned over the election.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Ohio State's one-two offensive punch of Tom Matte and Bob Ferguson overpowered Wisconsin, 34 -- 7, today in a Big Ten football battle before 83,246 fans.

The country's retail stores are still counting on final figures for 1960 to show a gain of perhaps as much as 4 percent in dollar sales above the 1959 level, but they are not nearly so optimistic on profits.

THE dominating figure of Casey Stengel swaggered across the sports pages last week, commanding most of the space and most of the attention. On his way to the exit he shouldered aside other news of considerable moment. Great men invariably go out in that fashion.
NICE, France, Oct. 22 -- President de Gaulle, in his strongest public attack on the Soviet Union, assailed today what he called a threat of Soviet intervention in Algeria. He said:
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Communist China's rulers publicly bowed today to Premier Khrushchev and spoke of the "monolithic solidarity" of Communist China and the Soviet Union.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Vice President Nixon accused Senator John F. Kennedy tonight of having made "a shockingly reckless proposal" on Cuba that might lead to World War III. Mr. Nixon's indictment of Senator Kennedy was the sharpest of the campaign. His comments bristled with condemnatory language.

The reform of American high-school education last week advanced a giant step. Following the example of the earlier Commission on Mathematics, the rewriting of physics, chemistry and biology programs and the pioneering of modern American language instruction, English teaching is now to get a blood transfusion.
ALTHOUGH they cannot hope to compete with TV, radio or even book publishers, record companies are doing their bit to keep the election pot bubbling as the campaign gets down to the wire.

Jack McCartan, who achieved his first National Hockey League shutout in his season debut last Wednesday, will be in the nets for the New York Rangers against the Stanley Cup champions, the Montreal canadiens, tonight at 7 o'clock ion the Madison Square Garden ice.
Staff changes in two transport concerns were announced last week.
THE Seventh Annual Japan Camera Show, which will be held tomorrow through Saturday at the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue, heads a list of three annual photographic events announced recently.
MONTREAL, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 4-2, tonight and moved into first place in the National Hockey League, a point in front of the Canadiens.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 22 -- Any West German who wants to know about the American election campaign has plenty of information at his fingertips. His morning newspaper gives him a steady diet of day-to-day developments, If he has a television set -- and he probably does -- he could have seen the second and third of the Nixon-Kenndey debates, which were shown here on film flown over from America.
The city's first housing for the elderly under a special provision of last year's National Housing Act will be built in Chinatown.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 22 -- The Disciples of Christ, Protestant body officially known as the Christian Churches, has embarked on a "pilot project" of concrete aid to interracial congregations.
When the United States went off the gold standard in 1934, Congress forbade American citizens to buy or sell gold for dollars or to hold gold coin or bullion.

LAHAINA, Hawaii. THINGS have changed in these exotic islands. This former capital of the ancient Hawaiian Kingdom and of Pacific whalers has been transformed by Hollywood to look as it did many years ago for the filming of "The Devil at 4 O'Clock."

PERSONS who disappear never to return have a universal fascination. They provide fodder for newspapers, magazines and endless barroom and dinner-party discussions. Was the one who vanished kidnapped or murdered, did he or she commit suicide or just go off to start a new life far away under a new name?
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 -- Seven hundred city administrators, mostly from this country and Canada, sat down here this week to discuss common problems such as taxes and "suburbia."

ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- A 3 1/2year-old, 105-pound English sheep dog came back to the show ring after being absent since last spring to take the top award in the seventeenth event of the Albany Kennel Club today.

AFTER listening to one of the latest records for children between 7 and 14 in the field of American history, a youngster was prevailed upon to set down an Instant reaction. "This record is about General Pershing and his troops.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 -- Can "electric brains" be put to work on legal problems?

THIS is far from the usual ghosted job of an athletic star who never sees the book until printed. It is the interesting life of a vital American. Col. Earl "Red" Blaik, coached intercollegiate football thirty-four years, twenty-five as head coach at Dartmouth and West Point.
YONKERS, Oct. 22 -- Indictments by a Westchester grand jury will be sought next Tuesday against three or more persons in an alleged narcotics ring.

CHOPIN: Piano Concerto No. 2, Fantasy; Witold Malcuzynski with London Symphony Orchestra, Walter Susskind, conductor (Angel 35729, stereo S35729). In one of his best disks to date, the Polish pianist presents broadly conceived performances spiced with a very free use of rubato.

IT is 1842 and young Giuseppe Verdi is in Milan, alone and dispirited. Two years previously, in the space of three months, he had lost his wife and his two children. His first opera, "Oberto," had quietly faded from memory shortly after its production in 1839.
STORKS, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Bill Minnerly's running game paced the University of Connecticut to a 16-14 victory over Boston University before 13,168 fans today.

BURAS, La., Oct. 22 -- The Alcoa Corsair, moving down the Mississippi River, collided with an Italian freighter before dawn today. At least nine persons were killed and more than twenty-five were injured. The victims had been passengers and crew members aboard the Alcoa Corsair.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 -- Michigan's gubernatorial race presents a curious parallel to the Presidential contest, but with party positions reversed.
Modern paintings from the Gladys Lloyd Robinson collection will be auctioned on Wednesday at 8 P.M. at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

WHEN the Government recently announced payment of $1,000,000 for infringing patents by the late Dr. Robert H. Goddard, it specifically acknowledged that the Air Force's Atlas and Thor, the Army's Jupiter and Redstone, and the Navy's Vanguard had used what were essentially Goddard rocket engines and Goddard liquid propellants.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- "We're in very good shape," Henry Cabot Lodge said of America's foreign policies as he campaigned here today.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Rutgers remained in the ranks of undefeated football teams today after a thrilling 8-0 triumph over Lehigh.

Persons perplexed about the strange pre-election course of the securities markets here -- stocks and bonds going down in price at the same time -- were handed something more to ponder -- a sudden rise in the London free market price of gold. Probably Wall Street's biggest concern the continuing decline in the stock market -- is the easiest to understand.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 22 -- The forty-ninth state is eyeing an issue that may widen a sectional split in this biggest of states -- the $23,000,000 ferry bond issue that will be voted on Nov. 8.

Open warfare broke out last week between Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of New York's City College, and The Observation Post, one of the institution's six student newspapers. The feud puts the spotlight on the embattled frontier between student journalism and college administrations.
A TELEVISION producer who bought what he thought was an antique and later learned he had been swindled has decided to take an editorial stand. He will produce a program titled "The Antique Swindle."
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- More than 500 persons attended the seventy-second annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball tonight in the Tuxedo Club, where ten debutantes were presented to society.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Thorn Lord advocated a program tonight that he said would better portray the United States to the world and thus help restore what he called its declining prestige.

THERE is to be a change in the schedule of international match points (called I.M.P. or "imps") by which all knockout team-of-four matches are scored. This will be the first change since the I.M.P. schedule was introduced almost twenty-four years ago.

A special attraction of the National Business Show, opening tomorrow at the New York Coliseum for a five-day run, will be a center to provide on-the-spot lease-financing arrangements to users of "big ticket" office equipment.

The head of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations appealed to Americans last night to "change their ways radically" in espousing freedom lest the United States default to communism in the struggle for men's minds.

IN the current issue of the magazine Art News, its editor and chief critic, Thomas B. Hess, states that the "uniquely necessary qualification" for a critic of modern art is "interested sympathy." That word "uniquely" pushes things a little far; surely there are criteria for the judgment of modern art that are more important than a predisposition in its favor.

Emile Griffith of New York continued his rapid rise toward a welterweight title fight by scoring a technical knockout over Willie Towell of Benoni, South Africa, in their scheduled ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 21 -- Ghana's Ministry of Agriculture hopes to receive advice from the United States, Soviet Union, United Arab Republic and Israel on the new state farms to be set up throughout the country.
Gold is again making the headlines and for the same reasons that it has hit the world's spotlight before -- fears. Fears of devaluations of currencies. Fears of war. Fears of economic depressions.
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Neither of the candidates for the United States Presidency has made much impact on French consciousness, and popular interest in the campaign is slight here.
ATREND toward treelike house plants is giving a new look to the interiors of many apartments and homes. So pronounced is the trend that one could use the phrase, house trees, instead of house plants.
Increased purchases of knit suits and costumes, along with reorders on cashmere coats, trimmed and untrimmed, were a marked trend in reports last week from resident buying offices here.

Mort Bromfield of Boston Bay, sailing Challenge, is the 1960 champion of the International 210 Association. He heads the final standing with 64 1/4 points to 59 for the runner-up, Robert W. Sides of Eastern Point.
Sir Andrew Cohen, British member of the United Nation Trusteeship Council, deplored yesterday a tendency he found in this country to misrepresent the true nature of the conflict that beset the world.

One of the two propositions to be submitted to state voters in the election next month, according to housing officials, is vitally important to the state's low-rent housing and urban renewal programs.

NEWARK, Oct. 22 -- Senator Clifford P. Case today proposed a Senate study of the caues, effects, and ways of combating the migration of industry from New Jersey and other mid-Atlantic states to the South.

LONDON. WALTER SHENSON, ex-Hollywood, publicist turned British-based producer, is back from an American trip that included some justified gloating over the success of his first film, "The Mouse that Roared."

MARK TWAIN once wrote that everyone wants to have read the classics, but no one wants to read them. Not so Richard Armour, English professor errant, who ambles through the required reading list on the wackiest literary journey since the days of Don Quixote.

YONKERS, Oct. 22 -- Widower Creed, driven by Howard Beissinger, scored a three-quarter-length victory over O.F. Brady in the Monitor junior-free-for-all pacing feature, an $8,000 event, before 28,384 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 22 -- Troop carriers loaded with green-helmeted soldiers race through the geometrical streets, Congolese gendarmes with a red circle on their helmets brandish tommy guns, white United Nations Jeeps with multiracial loads of "blue helmets" patrol the city, provincial police (in gray uniforms and steel helmets and carrying rusty rifles) mutiny and arrest their officers because "it's time for a raise."

If the United States Senate and the Canadian Parliament agree to the proposed international program for developing the waters of the upper Columbia River system, a great new source of wealth will be opened on both sides of the border. The project was worked out by negotiators from both Canada and the United States after a hard ten years of bargaining.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 19 -- Premier John M. Chang has virtually completed negotiations among political factions that portend a period of tranquility for South Korea.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Amherst, seeking to retain its Little Three title, beat Wesleyan today, 13 -- 0, before an Alumni Day crowd of 5,200 at Andrus Field.

HOLLAND is a small country with big plans, according to Joop Strijkers, director of the Amsterdam Tourist Association. Mr. Strijkers, here to encourage Americans to place Holland at the top of their European travel itineraries, predicts a tourist-filled future for the land of wooden clogs and tulips.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- A new neutralist effort to avoid an intensified East-West crisis on the disarmament question and the possibility of a Soviet walkout at the United Nations were reported today in diplomatic circles.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- At first glance, the only similarity between the Mississippi River and the Loxahatchee River here in Florida is that each has the same number of letters in its name.

An American Football League rematch between the New York Titans and the Houston Oilers will be staged today at the Polo Grounds. Game time is 2:30 P.M.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 -- Walter P. Reuther has agreed to a suggestion of President Eisenhower that labor and business leaders sit down far from the bargaining table and discuss their common responsibility to the country.

The three-week-old General Electric strike was settled yesterday on the company's pre-strike terms.

More than 1,000 Bronx residents took part yesterday in the first Civil Defense test to see how quickly such a group could be evacuated if New York City were about to be bombed.

An indoor fleet of 450 craft of all types and sizes will be assembled in the New York Coliseum for the fifty-first National Motor Boat Show, Jan. 14-22. So far, 423 exhibits by 416 firms have received space allotments.

The arrest of seven men accused of complicity in the theft of $22,000 worth of furs on Sept. 18 from a vault of the Zwerdling Fur Company, 9 Hamilton Street, Paterson, N.J., was announced yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The Metropolitan Opera Association has released the names of the boxholders for Its seventy-sixth opening night tomorrow at the Metropolitan Opera House. Verdi's "Nabucco" will be sung.
