MOST modern homes contain many potential sources of irritating noise. In addition to a large number of motor-driven appliances and machines, they also contain radios, television sets and phonographs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- High teamsters union sources estimated today that the union was spending about $1,500,000 in the election campaign.

MORRIS ERNEST, who is not only a successful lawyer, but, what Is more important, a lively and witty lawyer, says toward the end of this day-by-day account of one year in his recent life: "I do wish I dared write a real diary."

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Petrified II, a chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. F. Eugene Dixon Jr. of Philadelphia, surprised a crowd of 6,000 today by winning the sixteenth Monmouth County Gold Cup steeplechase race.

HOUSTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A second unit headed by Alvin Hartman did most of the damage tonight as the Rice Owls ground out a second-period touchdown for a 7-0 Southwest Conference victory over the University of Texas.

Mrs. Tucker Ridder, benefit chairman of the anniversary dinner dance to be held for the Children's Health Service on Nov. 10 in the Roof of the Pierre, has announced the names of additional members of the fete's committees.

Last Sunday this column discussed three health issues on which both Presidential candidates agree. They were a separate Department of Health with Cabinet rank, Federal regulatory powers to control the cost of drugs, and governments determination of the efficacy of drugs as well as their safety.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Missouri Tigers spiced a powerful and methodical ground attack with an 88-yard punt return by Donnie Smith and made the Iowa State Cyclones their sixth victim of the season, 34 -- 8, today.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 20 -- The big chartered airliner was high above Wisconsin and Emily Sears Lodge, making her sixty-eighth flight since Labor Day, was discussing the campaign.

ONE of the rewards of parenthood comes with the somewhat startling revelation that one has -- despite parental qualms to the contrary -- raised a child who does, after all, observe the amenities of life in the presence of friends and relatives.

HEADS of four sixteenth century Spanish explorers who vainly searched for Florida's fabled Fountain of Youth have been issued by Spain. These stamps, M. Galver of Madrid advised J. and H. Stolow last week, commemorate the discovery of Florida four centuries ago.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday defied Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy's ruling that policemen could not hold outside jobs.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Japan's chief interest in the United States Presidential campaign centers on the Quemoy-Matsu issue, which is on Tokyo's own doorstep. Otherwise, Japanese generally are concerned with their own national elections next month, to the almost total exclusion of political affairs in other countries.

THE tight, self-sealed, symbolist lyric, which has been the staple of modern American verse, seems to be on the way out. The poetry replacing it -- whether it is proclamatory, narrative, or autobiographical -- is a more public poetry, tied rather directly to the modern scene.

To the Music Editor: Ross Parmenter was right in reporting that the Carnegie Hall audience reacted with "almost stunned silence" when Leonard Bernstein announced that none of the concerto-tossers just heard was good enough to get the Leventritt award this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- There comes a moment in every Presidential campaign when, as they say along the Potomac, the bees begin to settle. Nobody quite knows why, but suddenly the air is different, the restless hum subsides, and the swarm begins to come to rest on one side rather than the other.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 22 -- The Government will attempt Monday to win the quick passage of legislation to allow it to take over Ceylon's 2,500 private schools.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 22 -- Westchester County Republicans are "running scared," not from fear of losing local co tests, but because of what they see as a greater need for heavy suburban voting for Vice President Nixon.
The American Museum of Natural History has allocated $2,000,000 from its private funds to initiate a ten-year exhibition expansion program.

AFTER a year of careful hearings, a Senate judiciary subcommittee reported not long ago that the Federal regulatory process "has been brought into serious disrepute." According to the Senators, "undue influence," "illegal ex parte communications between private individuals and Government agencies" and a record of "inaction, endless delays, favoritism and arbitrary actions" by the commissioners have created "a wide-spread lack of public confidence in the fairness of agency decisions."

THERE is no doubt that Paul Goodman is one of the most brilliant American intellectuals today. ROME, Oct. 22 -- The Vatican declared itself unaware today that Puerto Rican Bishops had issued a pastoral letter forbidding Catholics to vote for the party of Governor Munoz Marin. No comment was consequently forthcoming nor would anyone hazard an opinion on the reason for the Bishops' action.

A mortgage loan program by which members of the faculty of New York University may buy homes within commuting distance of any of the school's campuses has been started.

Holy Cross, which made more mistakes than correct moves in the early minutes of play yesterday, got squared away in plenty of time to turn on Columbia and move to an easy 27-6 victory at Baker Field before 10,414 fans.

The National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers will hold its semi-annual market week today through Thursday at the New York Trade Show Building. About 7,000 men's wear buyers are expected to shop the spring lines shown by more than 250 manufacturers.

THREE pianists representing as many countries and styles have produced new recordings of exceptional distinction: Malcolm Frager, the 25-year-old American prize-winner; Samson Francois, 36-year-old Frenchman, and Artur Rubinstein, the great Polish-born pianist whose age doesn't matter, since he seems eternally young.

ONE of Japan's distinctive contributions to the world is ikebana (the art of flower arrangement), which literally means "living flowers." Though Japan inherited some basic principles from China, it was the Japanese genius which, through a love of naturalism, developed an art of sublime beauty with unlimited opportunity for expression.

There is a little blue-covered book of 187 pages that many a seaman calls his "bible." It is a serious book, one that frequently takes the place of so-called escape reading when a man is on the high seas, or when he is in his home port waiting to ship out.

This year is the first in which the gross national product -- the dollar value of all goods and services-reached an annual rate of a half trillion dollars. It occurred in the first quarter; the record figure was $500.2 billion. The rise continued in the second quarter -- to an annual rate of $505 billion -- but signs of hesitancy in some setors of the economy indicated the pace would not be sustained.

ANTWERP -- The Gevaert Company of this city will enter the American market next year with a full line of color film, including a Kodachrome type of reversal (slide) film which can be processed in Kodachrome solutions.

LIKE a wedding ceremony, what meets the eye on stage at the Metropolitan Opera, which starts its seventy-sixth season tomorrow, is only the spectacular part of the activities that went before. In THE MAGIC OF THE OPERA (Praeger, $10), photographs by Gjon Mili and text by Mary Ellis Peltz, illustrate the complex of skills required to keep a music drama running smoothly from overture to curtain call.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 22 -- Polls and politicians give a Democratic newcomer, William A. Barlocker, a substantial lead over Republican Gov. George D. Clyde in Utah's gubernatorial race.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 22 -- Syracuse unleashed a corps of hard running backs and a fierce passing attack today in overwhelming West Virginia, 45 -- 0. The defeat was the worst ever pinned on the Mountaineers on their home field.

The eighth-inning double-play ball that struck Tony Kubek in the Adam's apple and set the stage for the Pirates' seventhgame world series victory cost each Yankee regular approximately $3,200.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -- Vice President Nixon intensified his attack on Senator John F. Kennedy tonight, saying his "immature and irresponsible judgment" might lead the nation into war and fiscal disaster.

The International Longshoremen's Association argued yesterday that a 1956 Federal injunction against multipleport bargaining for a contract was no longer operative and charged it was a restraint on the union.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 24 -- Tom Strafaci, the professional at Dyker Beach in Brooklyn, and Barney Lobel of Gold Spring gained top honors today in the pro-amateur tournament of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association.

YONKERS, Oct. 24 -- Tie Silk of Canada, the winner of last week's $50,000 United Nation Trot, drew the No. 4 post position today for the first part of the "world's championship" series at Yonkers Haceway for 4-year-olds on Thursday France's leading stallion, Mick d'Angerieux, drew the No. 2 post and will be driven by Edouard Berger.

EAST BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- A new system of separating the horse player from his dollar was started tonight as the thirtythree-night harness racing meet began at Suffolk Downs. A crowd of 10,000 fans caught on quickly despite thunder, lightning and hailstorm.

THE distinctively American process of choosing and electing Presidents was the theme last night of a theatrically interesting and historically vapid revue entitled "The Right Man," which was a feature on Channel 2.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- General Motors and Ford are continuing to increase production of 1961 model cars but Chrysler is hanging back.
TOKYO, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Giants won for the first time in their sixteen-game series today by defeating an all-star Japanese team, 1-0.
Ralph Houk continues to move on the double-quick in setting up his Yankee field organization for 1961.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Oct. 24 -- Senator John F. Kennedy assailed Vice President Nixon today as the leader of a Republican "wrecking crew" as he campaigned through heavily Republican downstate Illinois before large and enthusiastic crowds.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Hugh Gaitskell received support today from two prominent party members in his struggle to retain leadership of the Labor party.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- Recently, when Eli Wallach was working in Nevada on the movie, "The Misfits," he telephoned his wife in New York to ask what she thought about a television show he had done that was being shown that night in New York.

A WOMAN just cannot have too many fine feathers this fall. There is a collection of pheasant, coq and peacock hand-bags now at the Fantasia Shop on the third floor of Lord Taylor. All have one side made of pretty feathers covered by a protective layer of very fine black net.
A diner in an East Side Chinese restaurant was startled the other evening when she broke open a fortune cooky.
An underground movement in the Police Department to halt or slow down the issuance of traffic summonses began at midnight last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Every Presidential campaign is "historic" and "great" because its outcome can and often has shaped the course of history and the stake is the greatest in politics. But the 1960 contest may prove historic in the special sense that, in the area of foreign policy, as soon as one candidate has made a huge mistake, his rival balances it with one of his own.
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet Union saw good prospects today forits early return to a position of influence in the Congo Republic.
The United States won, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, against Spain in the seventh round of the preliminaries of the chess Olympics in Leipzig, according to a report received from East Germany yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The United Nations today marked the fifteenth anniversary of its birth.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Mr. Nixon sent another telegram to Mr. Kennedy today on the snarled issue of a fifth television-radio debate.

The stock market broke out of its recent lethargy with vengeance yesterday as price, on average touched new low for the year on the New York Stock Exchange. There was brisk late rally which reduce earlier losses, but it was to little and too late to prevail large net losses for the day.

HAMILTON, Ont., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Tolls on the Welland Canal will have to be increased if recent improvements are to be paid for in the next fifty years, Gen. Howard D. Graham, president of the Great Lakes Waterways Development Association, said today.
The number of men investigating four recent bombings here has been doubled from fifty to 100, the police said yesterday.
One of the largest tracts of private, undeveloped land in Queens was purchased yesterday for more than $3,500,000 by the First National Realty and Construction Corporation.

The most recent Republican victory in Brooklyn's Eighth Congressional District occurred forty years ago, and there is little reason to suppose that that single moment of G.O.P. glory will be repeated this year.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 24 -- President Eisenhower pledged the American people today to "stand with Berlin in its great task of maintaining and extending human freedom."
The more than $300,000,000 financing program for Trans World Airlines, Inc., under which Howard Hughes agreed two weeks ago to trustee his 78 per cent stock interest in T.W.A. has broken down.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Wheat and soybeans advanced but other grain futures finished mostly lower in mixed dealings on the Board of Trade here today.

Bankers here estimated yesterday that Thursday's volume on the London bullion market ran between $7,000,000 and $10,000,000 and that turnover both on Friday and yesterday was smaller. They added the following points:

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The demand for South African gold shares was further stimulated in the stock market here today by news that dealers had fixed the opening price of the metal at $1.35 an ounce above Friday's closing price.

A legacy of the secret treaties of the first World War, often regretted by their authors, has risen up again to trouble two Western friends and the United Nations. At issue is the status of South Tyrol, more particularly of the Bozen, or Bolzano, or Alto Adige Province with its German-speaking majority ceded to Italy in 1919 to give it a strategic frontier on the Brenner Pass.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The big Democratic majority in the House of Representatives is theoretically vulnerable to heavy Republican inroads this year. Yet strong doubts have now arisen over whether any great change is in prospect.
Electrical workers began to return yesterday to General Electric plants throughout the nation, but picketing continued at some plants and more than 26,000 company employes remained out.

The thoroughbred horses in this vicinity should know their way to Aqueduct without a road map by this time. For the fourth time this season yesterday, a meeting opened at the "Big A," where the horses will run until the end of the New York State season on Nov. 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Democrats were standing almost pat today on charges by Robert F. Kennedy that some Republican organizations were responsible for the distribution of anti-Catholic literature.
Lox and bagels, missing from the election campaign so far, were pressed into service by Governor Rockefeller yesterday on behalf, of the Republican ticket.

The last Republican elected to Congress from Brooklyn's Ninth Congressional District was Andrew N. Peterson, who was swept into office in the landslide that sent Warren G. Harding to the White House in 1920.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 -- The campaign caravan of Henry Cabot Lodge was probing today for votes in strongly Democratic territory.

The latest concepts in the office of the future were put or display yesterday at the opening of the National Business Show at the New York Coliseum. The show is sponsored each year by the Office Executives Association of New York.

An almost unanimous belief that the Soviet Union is the leading military power was disclosed in a survey of nine or ten foreign countries conducted for the United States Government during the summer, reliable sources abroad report.
YESTERDAY (Oct. 24, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY First (Political) Committee -- Heard statements by Yugoslavia and Britain in continuing the debate on disarmament.
Al Dorow, the Titans' quarterback who was taken to a hospital last Sunday with severely bruised ribs, a wrenched knee, a sprained ankle, a sore neck and a swollen jaw, said yesterday:
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 24 -- The 350-year-old sovereignty of township government in Suffolk County was used today in dealing a staggering blow to an elaborate recreation proposal.
New local legislation designed to prevent cheating by distributors of fuel oil was sent to the City Council by Mayor Wagner yesterday.
Physicians in the future are going to be increasingly concerned with the so-called genetic diseases that now afflict about two out of every hundred persons.

Lorne (Gump) Worsley, the more seasoned of the New York Rangers' two goalies, yesterday was named by Coach Alf Pike to replace Jack McCartan tomorrow night against the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

The Superintendent of Schools announced yesterday that emergency plans were being made to keep the schools open in the event the United Federation of Teachers carried out its threat to strike on Nov. 7.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 24 -- Heavily armed Congolese soldiers brusquely disrupted the celebration of United Nations Day here today by preventing many Africans and some Europeans from attending the ceremonies.

The rising tempo of the campaign and the rising tempers of the two Presidential candidates have new introduced, in the argument over Cuba, a second major blunder in the dangerous area of foreign policy -- some of the statements made in the argument over Quemoy and Matsu being the first.
Overtures to play in the first Gotham Bowl game at Yankee Stadium on Dec. 10 have been made to Navy, but the middies' status is still in doubt.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission opened public hearings today on a plan to authorize a full-scale tryout of pay television.
The city's Board of Elections is speeding the tasks entailed in preparing the voting lists in an effort to prevent any serious tie-ups in the balloting Nov. 8.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Supreme Court put off today a decision on the constitutionality of a Pennsylvania law requiring that portions of the Bible be read aloud every day in public school.

"FIDDLE HILL," by James McCague, is a wild and wonderful story of snorting iron horses and the Western railroad saga in America. At least for an interval it should take precedence over Thomas Wolfe's lonely trains full of lonely peopie tootling through the lonely nights of our literature.

The writer of the following letter. was formerly Ambassador and a representative of the United States and other nations contributing force, to the U.N. in Korea at Pahmunjom. He was chairman of the United States Delegations to the United Nations Law of the Sea, Conference.

THE rules describe a football as a prolate spheroid with a leather or pigskin covering. It's time the officials took a closer look. Some varlet has smuggled the lively ball into the Great Autumnal Madness and it acts as if covered with jackrabbit skin.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 24 -- President Romulo Betancourt faced a new crisis today as a result of demands by The Republican Democratic Union for a complete reorganization of his Cabinet.
Allegheny Ludium Steel Corporation said yesterday it would form a new company in Belgium in conjunction with two Belgian concerns to build a steel plant costing more than $10,000,000.

ATLANTA, Oct. 24 -- Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Negro integration leader, remained in jail here today waiting a hearing tomorrow on traffic charges revived by his arrest of last week in a student sit-in.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 24 -- A set of drastic new laws, designed to stamp out rioting and other violence in Southern Rhodesia, will be introduced tomorrow by the Prime Minister, Sir Edgar Whitehead.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (AP) -- In a statement issued by his press secretary, Herbert G. Klein, Mr. Nixon charged today that the Kennedy forces were "attempting to exploit the religious issue to solidify what they regard as 'a Catholic vote.'"

Commercial finance companies and factors expect to handle $14,960,000,000 of business this year, $1,530,000,000 or 11.4 per cent above last year's volume. This report was made yesterday to the industry's trade association, the National Commercial Finance Conference, Inc., which is holding its annual convention at the Pierre Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Britain told the United Nations today that acceptance of Soviet disarmament plans would be "totally crippling" to the Western nations in their attempt to defend the smaller countries of Europe against potential Communist aggression.

The rapid growth in the data-processing equipment field, including digital computers, is creating a need for a standard language that would be interchangeable for users of the various types of systems.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Treasury's short-term borrowing costs tumbled this week, the average discount rate on today's sale of ninety-one day Treasury bilis was the lowest in twenty-six months.
The Federal Trade Commission has charged Lanolin Plus Inc., of Newark and Approve Formulas, Inc., of New York with false advertising.
An examiner of the Federal Maritime Board has recommended that a steamship company pay a shipper $259,812.26 for refusing to carry his bananas.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct 24 -- The earth apparently travels through space in a halo of dust far more concentrated than had previously been thought, it was reported here today.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said here yesterday that Senator John F. Kennedy had compounded one error with another error in attributing to him the statement that the nation's prestige Had dropped.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Construction of the world's largest rotating radiotelescope at Sugar Grove, W. Va., has been delayed at least two years by unexpected engineering difficulties in building the huge structure.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- There has been no change in United States policy on the German-Polish frontier, the State Department said today.

Undefeated Joey Archer of the Bronx scored his twentyninth straight victory last night when he defeated Joe Rubino of Brooklyn in the eight-round feature -fight at St. Nicholas Arena.

The nation's voters will be asked to approve a record of $3,636,512,113 worth of bonds proposed by nine states, and 314 cities, counties, school districts and other governmental units on Nov. 8, The Daily Bond Buyer has reported. This year's total is 35.5 per cent above the previous high of $2,682,552,457 of tax-exempt bonds put to a vote during the last Presidential election.
The Brooklyn Dodgers had the Flatbush Faithful, the French kings had the Swiss Guard and, though years may pass and passes-fail, New Rochelle High has Don MacArthur.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Dr. Auguste R. Lindt, the United Nations' High Commissioner for Refugees, said today that a "breeze of liberalism" had swept away many age-old barriers to immigration.

The field for the Garden State Stakes in Camden, N.J., now numbers fifteen, with one or two likely to drop out before the big race Saturday. Everett Clay, the track's publicity director, revealed the line-up yesterday at a luncheon in the 21 Club.
The appointment of Louis N. Cogie as vice president of the Sabre Shipping Corporation was announced yesterday.
Payless furloughs for twenty inspectors of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity were imposed yesterday by Armand D'Angelo, Commesioner of the department.

GENERAL ASSEMBLY General (Steering) Committee -- Decided to put on the agenda of the Political Committee items on the question of Oman, charging Britain with aggression, and on a Cuban complaint of aggression against the United States.

Massachusetts has decided to reduce the amount of a bond market borrowing scheduled for this fall from $69,500,000 to $34,780,000 -- a 50 per cent cut. The bonds will be offered at public sealed bidding on Nov. 15.
NO MATTER how familiar they may become, miracles remain miracles. Last night, in his thirs New York recital, Sviatoslav Richter was working them with his uncanny, almost inhuman abilities.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Caution was the keynote in the stock market here today. Yesterday's sharp setback on Wall Street and the disappointing British trade figures for September, particularly the sharp drop in automobile exports, combined to make buyers reluctant to extend their commitments.

CONAKRY, Guinea, Oct. 24 -- The history of the Republic of Guinea is the story of a gamble that began two years ago. The stakes are getting higher and as the game goes on, the Soviet Union has started to collect winnings.

SAN GERMAN, P.R., Oct. 25 -- Gov. Luis Muaoz Marin, seeking a fourth term, toured rural areas of Puerto Rico today, pressing the issue of the separation of church and state in what appears to be a one-sided contest.
SINCE Verdi and Puccini are the Metropolitan's one-two popularity punch, it was understandable that early Verdi on opening night would be followed by early Puccini on evening No. 2 of the season.
The American League club owners will meet today in the Savoy-Hilton Hotel to consider expanding the league to ten clubs by 1962.
The Secondary School Teachers Association, one of the three major groups in the city, refused last night to support the strike threatened by the United Federation of Teachers on Nov. 7.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- A French-West German accord paving the way for training of West German Army and Air Force units in France was signed today by representatives of the two countries at the French Foreign Ministry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Eisenhower returned today from his 6,500-mile "nonpolitical" tour. He apparently was convinced that a more forthright effort in support of the Nixon-Lodge ticket was needed to bring about a Republican election victory.
The United States beat Chile, 4 -- 0, in the eighth round of the preliminaries to the Chess Olympics at Leipzig, according to a report received yesterday from East Germany.
The college football team that holds the longest unbeaten streak in the nation might be excused for getting jittery and expecting doom each Saturday.
Commodity futures trading continued dull and lackluster yesterday on the New York exchanges. The activity was slower than Monday's unusually quiet session, with prices moving narrowly.
Industrial properties in New Jersey have passed to new control in leases and sales reported by realty agents.

To let a student, without proper preparation in the use of the English language, enter college is equivalent to sending a surgeon into the operating room without instruments. Yet expert testimony shows that this is exactly what has been happening. Law schools as well as engineering colleges complain that students lack that basic tool -- the power to express themselves clearly.
The American Cancer Sosiety is seeking, on a nationwide scale, to woo teen-agers away from smoking.
THE man couldn't pay the $150 board bill for the mare he had left over the winter on Jack Price's horse farm near Cleveland.
State and local governments of New York and Connecticut agreed yesterday on a program to help the New Haven Railroad.
Abuses have crept into the installment financing of incomeproducing equipment purchases by industry, a leader in the field warned yesterday.

WINDSOR, Ont., Oct. 25 -- An explosion shattered a downtown department store filled with scores of shoppers today. Rescue workers said at least eleven persons had been killed and more than seventy-five injured.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The television and radio networks proposed today that the Presidential candidates meet "face to face," without a panel of questioners, if they agree to a fifth debate.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) off to 10 points (50 cents) up yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association today told Archie Moore it no longer recognized him as the light-heavyweight champion of the world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A barge line operates said today that West Virginia coal would continue to move to Chicago in barge-rail service regardless of what rate action the Interstate Commerce Commission took.
"You ought to be a Democrat!" a man in Wall Street shouted angrily at Governor Rockefeller yesterday. "I wish you were a Democrat!" a man in Union Square shouted cordially.

In a development of immense importance to the North Atlantic alliance as the bulwark of free world defense, President de Gaulle has surmounted the sharpest challenge to his two-year-old rule and has won the deciding Parliamentary approval for an independent nuclear striking force to make France the fourth atomic world power and the third such power in the alliance.
Gordon Stott of Manhasset, the Long Island amateur titleholder, today was elected president of the Long Island Golf Association. He succeeds William Slader of Wheatley Hills.
MILTON, Mass., Oct. 25 -- If balanced diets, regular sleeping hours and healthful exercise, produce proper growth, Milton Academy's football team must be offered as Exhibit A.

IN MAY, the written reports on the coming fall fashions started. In July, the first photographs were published. In August, some of the clothes appeared in the stores. But it was in September that the fate of most of them was decided.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Philippines Government says it has warnings of a possible outbreak of major violence in South Vietnam.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If history repeats itself -- and it frequently does, with variations -- Nixon will be elected to the Presidency and will be defeated by Kennedy for re-election in 1964.

What the funds do always olds a fascination for investors. A survey of third-quarter portfolio changes made by forty-one major trusts provides some information in this respect.

American Telephone and Telegraph Company borrowed a quarter of a billion dollars in the public capital market yesterday at an interest cost of 4.686 per cent. In the largest new corporate financing of 1960, A.T. T., raised the money through a competitive sale of $250,000,000 of thirtytwo-year debentures carrying a five-year protection against a lower-cost financing.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 25 -- Troops patrolled the streets and political demonstrations were prohibited here and in the interior today in the wake of a series of disturbances.

A plot of vacant land fronting 175 feet on the south side of East 233d Street, near Bussing Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Ivory Cleaners, Inc., for improvement with a drive-in cleaning plant.

THE country dweller probably would chuckle on beholding a city bumpkin's surprise at the scope of the Grand Union supermarket that has opened across the street from Greenwich Square Village. Insular Manhattanites are not too familiar with the type of market that is virtually all things to all departments of the home.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- American companies expect to invest $3,852,000,000 this year in facilities abroad, the Department of Commerce reported today.

YONKERS, Oct. 25 -- Leonard Cohen's Swain from Passaic, N.J., with Al Thomas in the sulky, scored a neck victory over Winbee in 2:05 in the Sleepy Hollow pacing feature before 14,871 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

There will be more "equitable competition" for Blue Jay Class skippers on Long Island Sound next year, according to James A. Rousmaniere. He spoke yesterday at the annual meetings of the senior and junior organization of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound at the New York Yacht Club.
Stocks declined yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange for the seventh straight session and in the process fell not only to new lows for 1960 but back to the lowest level in more than two years.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues, net income and sales of electricity, gas and steam for the twelve and nine months ended on Sept. 30. Share earnings in both 1960 periods, however, trailed the 1959 levels because of the additional shares outstanding -- $15,514,177, against 15,086,195 shares on Sept. 30, 1959.

The Western Pacific Railroad, whose directors rejected last week the plans of the Southern Pacific Company to acquire control of their line, got another bid for control yesterday. This was from the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway, fourth largest in the country from the standpoint of operating revenues.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Presidential campaign has created an unprecedented confusion for fair-minded Protestants with respect to the role of religion and education. They have inherited a deep conviction in favor of public schools and against public aid for Roman Catholic parochial schools.

Willard Connely, author of a number of biographies, will have a new book published Nov. 14 by Horizon Press. Titled "Adventures in Biography," it describes the author's experiences tracing ancient documents and otherwise searching for new information to provide a "living background" for the subjects of his books.

A hectic schedule that will rush Senator John F. Kennedy into four boroughs is being planned for tomorrow by Democratic chieftains here. The Democratic Presidential candidate will even campaign on Staten Island ferryboats.

Plans are being completed for a theatre party at the Nov. 3 performance of "Irma la Douce" at the Plymouth Theatre. Proceeds will go to the Humane Society of New York for support of its animal clinic.

OTTAWA, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press) -- The Federal Government won support today from a cross-section of the community for a plan aimed at putting more buying power in consumers' hands, raising industrial productivity and placing Canadian business in a better competitive position.
Massachusetts Investors Trust, the nation's oldest and one of the two largest mutual funds, reported yesterday declines in net assets.

ST. CHARLES, Ill., Oct. 25 -- The contrasts in this election are startling: the contrasts between the candidates themselves, between their arguments to the voters, between the reactions of the audiences, and between the America they talk about and the real America they seek to lead.

THE best-known works of the American painter Joseph Stella (1877?-1946) are undoubtedly his rhapsodic futurist pictures of New York and particularly of the Brooklyn Bridge. That he was also a figure draftsman of great distinction and accomplishment is brought out in the loan exhibition of thirty-nine of his drawings and two etchings opening today at the Museum of Modern Art.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- A new conciliation committee is expected to leave for Leopoldville within a few days to seek a peaceful settlement of the Congolese Government crisis. The members will be chosen from countries that have supplied personnel for the United Nations force in the Congo.

DECATUR, Ga., Oct. 25 -- The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was ordered today to serve four months in prison. A judge here ruled that his participation in an Atlanta sit-in demonstration had violated the terms of a suspended sentence in a traffic case.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The United States accused Cuba today of "incessant propaganda and reckless charges" to generate an "atmosphere of false crisis."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Austria moved today to avoid the virtual certainty of defeat in the United Nations in her quarrel with Italy over the South Tyrol.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday a consolidate net income of $237,910,000 for the nine months to Sept. 30. This was equivalent to $2.31 each on the 103,138,376 shares that will be outstanding following the payment of a 3 per cent stock dividend declared on Sept. 27.
Sales and earnings of Mead, Johnson Co., Inc., continued to soar in the third quarter, ac cording to figures indicated by an interim report issued yes terday.
Aqueduct's highest daily double, 1,778.20 for $2, took some of the chill out of the Ozone Park track's racing-on-the-rocks program yesterday.
Robert Moses said yesterday that a modern Tivoli Cardens, which was projected for the 1964 New York World's Fair, had been abandoned as impractical.
Members of the diplomatic corps from around the world were guests yesterday of leaders of New York society at the Salute to the United Nations Ball.

Founded in 1920, the League of Women Voters celebrates its forty years of service with a record of usefulness to the American people hard to match among civic organizations. There are 1,097 local leagues throughout the fifty states and the District of Columbia. They spend $1,500,000 annually in the promotion of effective citizenship.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 25 -- The governing Christian Democratic Union approved today a series of fiscal measures to halt the inflationary boom in West Germany.

CITY children may handle a variety of snakes, lizards, rabbits and other animals at two museums here. Sales and earnings of the American Can Company in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 were sharply below those in the 1959 period, William C. Stolk, chairman, reported yesterday.
A survey of twenty-seven states with gubernatorial elections this fall indicates that the Democratic party should substantially maintain its overwhelming control over the nation's state houses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- With only fourteen campaigning days left before the election Nov. 8, the Democrats are showing "moderate optimism" and the Republicans are calling the Presidential battle "about as close as it could be."

JOHN BROWN'S raid on Harpers Ferry, Va., was compressed last night into an awkward dramatization that seemed more concerned with the use of video tape on location than with the abolitionist's character.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, which provides technical education for Jewish youth in nineteen countries, made plans today to of fer its facilities to non-Jews from some of the world's under-developed areas.

A first mortgage loan of $1.252,000 has been obtained by Baldwin Town House, Inc., builder of a garden apartment development with 105 units at 1570-1600 Grand Avenue, Baldwin, L.I. The financing, which was' for ten years at 6 per cent interest, was arranged by the Sonnemblick-Goldman Company, broker.

The reported loss during the last two weeks of more than $500,000 in securities in Wall Street -- some of which are negotiable -- seemed last night to be turning into a full-scale mystery in more than one way.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- An executive director of the Bank of England visited the United States Treasury today and talked about gold. The Treasury confirmed that much and no more.
BURLY, red-faced, forceful James Edward McManus, Bishop of Ponce, Puerto Rico, has been feuding with Gov. Luis Munoz Marin for twenty years.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 25 -- Important Brazilian newspapers criticized Senator John F. Kennedy today for his suggestion that the United States aid the forces that seek to overthrow the Cuban regime of Fidel Castro and said that the time had come for Latin-American mediation in the Cuban situation.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Henry Cabot Lodge said today the United States "could lead the world to a new plateau where the shadows of war are behind us."

COLRAIN, Mass., Oct. 25 -- A boisterous wind following a furious rain mixed with a little snow is taking the last of the leaves off the trees now, stripping the proud upland hunter of one of his soundest excuses for not killing birds.

Birgit Nilsson's first and only New York concert this season will benefit the City Symphony Orchestra of New York, Inc., and the Clarion Music Foundation, Inc. The Swedish soprano will be accompanied by the Symphony of the Air, conducted by Tibor Kozma, at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 4.

Five professional actors, playing with a minimum of props and costumes, took parts from several of the theatre's hoary classics and brought them to life yesterday before more than 1,000 interested New York high school students.

A firm of consulting engineers will be commissioned soon by a group of business men to develop plans for improving the appearance of Times Square and its surrounding area. This was announced yesterday by James V. Edwards, president of the Broadway Association at a luncheon honoring Robert W. Dowling, president of City Investing Company, and Eugene Picker, president of Loew's, Inc., for their contributions to improve the Times Square district.

The food processing industry was warned yesterday by a leading nutritionist that the American public was "awakening to the importance of nutrition that comes in those pretty packages" containing food products.

VENICE, James Morris says in his "The World of Venice,"* is cold, damp and dismal in the winter. In the spring and in autumn it is beautiful. But in the summer the great museum-city comes to throbbing life and assumes its proper function. "Perhaps the supreme tourist attraction of the world," Venice feeds, houses, instructs, delights and enrages 700,000 tourists a season and for three delirious months becomes "one great itching palm."

THE ANTA Matinee Series began its fifth season yesterday at the Theatre de Lys with three one-act plays totally disparate in style. One was a long, interesting character study by Samuel Beckett, one an overwrought case history by Harry Tierney Jr. and the third a mildly diverting spoof of playwrights -- Broadway and off-Broadway varieties -- by Edward Albee.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Gabe Paul resigned as general manager of the Cincinnati Reds today to take a similar job with Houston, which will have a team in the National League in 1962. His successor was not named.

AS far away as Liberty's of London, Bonnie Cashin has become a name synonymous with creative American design. Since 1953 Bonnie Cashin has designed for Philip Sills. She has established herself as one of the most imaginative and masterly craftsmen in the sportswear world.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Prime Minister Macmillan announced today the conclusion of a "satisfactory" revised agreement with the United States on the use of United States Air Force bases in Britain.

IT was generally agreed that no one was really to blame for what happened on this deal -- it was "just one of those things" -- but it is still a question whether there can be such a bad result that is nobody's fault.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The United States will not need to buy sugar from Cuba next year and does not plan to do so, Government officials said today.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson said today that Vice President Nixon was "throwing the desperation punches of a desperate man" in his closing bid for the Presidency.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that its sales and earnings for the third quarter were sharply below levels for the second quarter, and its chairman said there was no sign of improvement in the company's order pattern.

LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Alphonse Hallmi, a 28-year-old French Algerian, tonight gained a narrow decision over Freddy Gilroy, the European and British champion, in a fifteen-round bout for the European version of the world bantamweight championship.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yesterday that its net income and sales in the third quarter and the first nine months of this year exceeded the levels for the 1959 periods.
A total of 1,051 persons were injured in traffic mishaps in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This is a decrease of 258 from the same period in 1959.

Rank-and-file members of the Police Department staged a twenty-four-hour holiday yesterday on issuing summonses for minor traffic and Administrative Code offenses. The move was characterized by Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy as a strike.
The Transit Authority announced plans yesterday to improve service on the BMT subway lines by Christmas time.

The Department of Health said yesterday that two medical laboratories that had surrendered their permits after inspection by the department should not have been identified as having done so because of the city's investigation of improper practices in laboratories.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration took the first step today on a program to send a three-man space craft on a reconnaissance trip around the moon by 1970.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- The chief of the Soviet Rocket Command, Marshal Mitrofan I. Nedelin, has been killed in a plane crash, it was officially announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The United States Information Agency has turned down a request from a Congressional subcommittee for information on polls conducted abroad about attitudes toward the United States.
The Wagner administration proposed a plan yesterday to provide a "painless" $40,000,000 to $50,000,000 for the expense budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1961.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that the United Nations drastically cut its expenditures to operate on a budget of not more than $50,000,000 net.
Station WNEW-TV said yesterday it had postponed a documentary on Sir Winston Churchill at the request of a competitor -- the American Broadcasting Company.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- One of the major battles of the 1960 Presidential campaign is being waged in five New Jersey counties that gave President Eisenhowner nearly 300,000 ballots of his record state plurality of 757,000 four years ago.
Senator John F. Kennedy's proposal for aid to forces seeking to oust Premier Fidel Castro in Cuba was upheld last night as "absolutely right" under inter-American treaties.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 25 -- Kenneth H. Leeds, 55-year-old land speculator of Ronkonkoma, was fined $500 in State Supreme Court here today for conspiracy in a zoning racket.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Hedge selling and profit taking weakened most grain future on the board of trade today.

Screen and television rights to two autobiographical books by Sir Winston Churchill, "My Early Life" and "The World Crisis," have been purchased by Paramount Pictures, the company announced yesterday. Present plans call for a high-budget, wide-screen feature film in color, using an as yet unnamed "all-star" cast and describing events in the statesman's life before 1908.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Delta Air Lines and Eastern Air Lines opposed at a hearing today the proposed merger of the United Air Lines and Capital Airlines.

The Wagner administration is suffering from a rash of labor troubles within its ranks of civil service employes. The most serious of these at the moment is the threat of illegal strike by several thousand public school teachers. Policemen and firemen are also disgruntied over too low salary and the prohibition on outside jobs to increase their income.
BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson accused Vice President Nixon today of supporting "impulsive and dangerous" policies toward Cuba that would drive it "further into the Soviet orbit."
Ten young major leaguers and Al Cicotte, the minor league player of the year, hit town yesterday for a three-day social whirl.
MASSENA, N.Y., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The United States section of the St. Lawrence Seaway wUl close Nov. 30 for the winter, the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation said today.

There is every reason to believe a crisis is shaping up within the secret world of communism, although it will be some time before we know with any surety just if or how it is resolved. One may suspect this crisis despite recent Peiping asseverations of "monolithic solidarity" with Russia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion is engaged in a bitter power struggle against opponents within his own political party, according to uncensored reports reaching Washington from the Middle East.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Today was about the quietest day the London bullion market has had since the so-called gold rush began early last week.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 -- The United States announced today a new loan program for housing and highways, designed to help Argentina's "magnificent effort to establish sound bases for the economic growth and for improved standards of living."
The City Council approved a bill yesterday increasing the punishment for contractors and builders convicted of obstructing sidewalks and roadways.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 25 -- King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand, who has displayed his love for music by writing popular tunes and playing jazz in his own country with Benny Goodman, was surprised tonight to hear melodies he wrote in a symphony by a Dutch composer.
In an unexpected move yesterday, the P. Lorillard Company took its Old Gold Spin Filter and Spring cigarette accounts away from Lennen Newell, Inc., and awarded them to Grey Advertising Agency, Inc.

Two major new imports from Italy and Russia are scheduled to open at first-run theatres here in dubbed English versions, marking a departure from standard foreign film booking procedure.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union, with little to show for its starters in two previous running of the $100,000 Washington D.C. International, will be represented again in this year's race on Nov. 11.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Frank Chapot won the first international jumping trophy of the Washington International Horse Show at the National Guard Armory tonight.
There was little activity or price fluctation in the bond market yesterday.

YASSIADA, Turkey, Oct. 25 -- Archbishop Spyrou Athenagoras, Patriarch of the Greek Orthodox Church, upheld today as true a letter he wrote five years ago that described antiGreek riots in Istanbul as having been planned.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 -- Vice President Nixon and his running mate, Henry Cabot Lodge, tonight joined forces in a roof-raising rally designed to shift the Republican Presidential campaign into high gear.

The Police Department announced yesterday that two policemen who are to be questioned in the inquiry into a towing-truck racket had put in for retirement.

CHICAGO Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks routed the Montreal Canadiens tonight, 8 -- 4, and took a onegame lead in the National Hockey League race with their sixth victory in nine games. The two teams had been tied for the lead before tonight's game.
The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service agreed yesterday to intervene in a contract dispute between The New York Times and the New York Newspaper Guild.

Studio Three will be reactivated. Last March, the nonprofit testing laboratory for new scripts was initiated with Sam Robins' "Answered the Flute." Since then, the project has been dormant. Now Southward Bound Some dramatic flights over the western United States are taking place between now and early December. A bureau of the Government has alerted its personnel from Montana to Texas to watch for these flights, and individuals in the area are also asked to cooperate.
The American League, taking the most revolutionary step in its history, voted yesterday to become a ten-club circuit.

The Cooper-Bessemer Corporation of Mount Vernon, Ohio, manufacturer of gas and diesel engines and gas turbines and compressors, has leased offices in 548 Fifth Avenue, corner of Forty-fifth Street. The space was acquired through the Cross Brown Company, brokers.
Contributions to the American Cancer Society have dropped 6 per cent in its first year of complete independence from federated fund drives.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 25 -- Evidence of a swing to Senstor John F. Kennedy has brought cautious optimism to the Democratic Presidentisl candidate's supporters in this state.

The New York Times, speaking as an independent newspaper, today announces its support of John F. Kennedy for President. Two considerations have carried special weight in determining our judgment. One of these is a matter of foreign policy. The other is a question of assuring a unified direction of the nation's affairs at a difficult moment in history.
CONAKRY, Guinea, Oct. 24 -- "The Democratic party of Guinea, guardian of the peoples' will, shall lead the nation In honor and dignity toward progress, justice and solidarity."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that secret files of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee showed that the Administration had sought the withdrawal of some Nationalist Chinese troops from the islands of Quemoy and Matsu.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency said today it had asked airports throughout the country to take "all necessary action" to reduce the menace of birds along the flight path of airplanes.

ATLANTA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Political leaders of five Southern states assailed the Republican party tonight as one of inaction and broken promises. They called on the South to solidify for the first time since 1944 behind the Democratic Presidential standard, borne this year by Senator John F. Kennedy.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Sports and Government leaders were generally jubilant today over the American League's announcement that it would move into Los Angeles.

The story of civil defense in New York State and New York City -- lavishly illustrated with maps, graphs, charts and tables of organization -- was told in military style to twenty-four Canadian civil defense officials here yesterday.
Earnings of the Phillips Petroleum Company for both the third quarter and first nine months of this year exceeded the levels of the 1959 periods, according to the company's interim report.

The first section of the proposed $99,000,000 state-financed Concourse Village housing development in the Bronx was unanimously approved by the City Planning Commission yesterday. This section will have 1,693 cooperative apartments and cost $31,000,000.

The financial plight of the Eastern railroads, particularly those operating into New York, is dramatized by the ninemonth operating statements filed by the carriers this week with the Interstate Commerce Commission.
A Norwegian steamship company that has carried about 30 per cent of Brazilian coffee imports through United States Gulf ports has been left out in the cold through action of the Brazilian Government.

Stella Holt, Carlo Salmaggi and George White have acquired William Gunn's new play, "Marcus in the High Grass," and plan to present it at the Greenwich Mews Theatre on Nov. 21.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- More than 200 Britons and Americans prominent in government, business, advertising and publications attended a reception given by The New York Times tonight to celebrate the beginning of its new International Edition.

Velasco Ibarra, regarding the already famous Protocol of Rio de Janeiro, I consider myself under the moral obligation, as a newspaper man and nephew of the Foreign Minister who signed it in the name of Peru, to inform the public of the truth of the historical events involved.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Ireland captured its first international jumping victory of the Washington International Horse Show tonight.

Robert Tyre (Bobby) Jones of Atlanta was in town yesterday in a new role. The golfer, who carried off four of the world's major championships in 1930, was the guest at a reception honoring him as an author.

PERHAPS the dean of the active bridge players in this community is Lewis Schamberg, who at the age of 92 plays regularly in the tournaments at the Harmonie Club. He was South and declarer in today's deal.
An 83-year-old woman who has spent more than three years in the Civil Jail in an estate dispute is scheduled to be released tomorrow.

With Lorne (Gump) Worsley back in goal, the New York Rangers beat the Detroit Red Wings, 4-3, last night in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. The Wings had won three of their previous four games.

Erasmus Hall came up with a low total of 63 points to take the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League cross-county championship in Prospect Park Brooklyn, yesterday.

After seven successive declines, stocks rallied yesterday and scored good gains. The advance was general and sustained in moderately active trading. THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Atlantic City Electric The Atlantic City Electric Company yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share, payable on Jan. 6 to stockholders of record of Dec. 15. The utility has paid 27 1/2 cents a share the previous quarters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The sharp nouns and adjectives which the rival Presidential candidates are now exchanging as descriptive of each other's shortcomings and types of campaigning are about the normal crop of a contest near its close: "nonsense," "distortion," "disgraceful," "reckless," "two-faced," and so on.
Robert Moses said yesterday that free attractions to be offered at the 1964-65 World's Fair by industrial sponsors and foreign governments would outshine anything an amusement company could offer.

GIENS, France, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Alexis Leger was setting out for a Mediterranean fishing trip today when he learned that he had been awarded the 1960 Nobel Prize for Literature.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The price of gold slipped again today on the London bullion market. At the morning "fixing" dealers pegged the price at 536.60 a fine ounce, 90 cents below yesterday's closing price.

LIKE many another New Yorker, Barbara Kraus lives in an apartment with a notoriously small kitchen. Her cooking area is not much larger than one of those double-unit telephone booths that suddenly have cropped up.

The Department of Hospitals is preparing short and longrange plans to cope with an antcipated "critical" shortage of physicians.

A plan whereby the American food industry could assume the active leadership in a world-wide assault on human hunger was proposed yesterday by Charles H. Bell, president of General Mills, giant food processing concern.

Designers in America's garment district now are showing their spring collections to the fashion press and store buyers. The clothes will be in the shops in mid-December.

The focal center of modern jazz in New York, which was once crammed into a single earshattering block on Fifty-second Street and later shifted westward to Broadway, has seeped down into Greenwich Village.

The nation's inventories of gasoline dropped 1,157,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A dip in output to 28,301,000 barrels from 28,518,000 in the preceding week accounted for part of the decline.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Democratic and Republican representatives after a day of offand-on negotiations, apparently came to tentative agreement today on a fifth television debate between the Presidential candidates.

Commodity futures continued dull and, featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. The volume thus far this week had been lighter than for some time.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 10 points (50 cents) up yesterday.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 26 -- The Tree Warden here was in a lively dispute with other town officials today over his ruling sparing a century-old elm from destruction.
SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Henry A. Wallace said today that the farm program of Senator John F. Kennedy would increase food prices in grocery stores and meat markets by 25 per cent.
BANGOR, Me., Oct. 26 -- Capt. Joe Savage of Loring Air Force Base, Me., gave a little extemporaneous lesson in gun safety last night on the Maine Turnpike that might profit every hunter everywhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 19:

THE career-seeking woman must realize that her resume may be as crucial to her success as her small talk may be in acquiring a husband. When a woman is looking for a job, her resume is the first way to put her best foot forward.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee said today that a lack of money had forced the cancellation of some paid local telecasts in six states by Senators John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 -- Senator John F. Kennedy appealed tonight for business and labor support. He charged that, under Republican leadership, "our economy is slipping into its third recession in six years."

Following is the text of a "confidential" report entitled, "Post-Summit Trends in British and French Opinion of the United States and the Soviet Union," prepared by the Office of Research and Analysis of the United States Information Agency under date of June, 1960:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: William Buckley's letter of Oct. 17 is curious in the extreme in addition to being difficult to fathom. Along with his usual sacrifice of clarity to rhetoric, Mr. Buckley engages in backhand political discussion as well.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The United States was credited today with leading the world in the discovery and development of antibiotic drugs.

THE New York City Opera presented its third and final "Rosenkavalier" of the season last night. Two of its major roles were in new hands. Doris Jung made her debut with the company as the Marschallin and Adele Leigh sang her first Octavian at the City Center.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 26 -- Alexis Leger, a former French diplomat widely acclaimed for poetry written under the pseudonym of Saint-John Perse, has won the 1960 Nobel Prize for Literature.
YONKERS, Oct. 26 -- Continuing its efforts to further the world-wide prestige of harness racing, Yonkers Raceway will stage another international event tomorrow night.
Milt Plum of the Cleveland Browns, who hasn't had a throw intercepted all season, leads the National Football League in passing, and his team-mate, Jimmy Brown, leads in ground gaining.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Organized labor has prepared for an all-out effort to get out the vote on Nov. 8.
SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 26 -- Three army officers and three civilian professional men took over the Government of El Salvador at dawn today in a bloodless coup.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Midsummer Night II, a Virginia-bred horse owned by Paul Mellon of Pittsburgh, plowed through flying mud and driving rain today and won the Cambridgeshire Handicap at odds of 40-1.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Oct. 18 condemning the proposed strike of city teachers is wide of the mark.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Teamsters Union Local 688 and four of its leaders were freed today of charges of making illegal political contributions in Federal elections.

In the Thirteenth Congressional District in Brooklyn, Representative Abraham J. Multer is so confident of returning to Washington for an eighth term that he is not printing any campaign posters, leaflets or cards.

SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 26 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson charged tonight that the disclosure of the United States Information Agency survey on declining American prestige showed that the Republican Administration had suppressed public information paid for by taxpayers.

The city's 18,000 physicians are being urged by health authorities to consider giving influenza vaccines to all patients over 65 years old, to those with chronic debilitating diseases and to pregnant women.

Despite the continuing lag in steel production, the National Steel Corporation cleared $8,061,074, or $1.06 a share, in the third quarter and operated at slightly more than 75 per cent of capacity, it was disclosed yesterday. Some steel companies operated at less than one-half of capacity in the quarter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A newspaper column by Drew Pearson connecting the name of Vice President Nixon to a possible conflict of interest brought a "smear" charge today from the Nixon camp.
The closest thing to a certainity in the elections is that the Democrats will continue their control of the United States Senate.
Thirteen major unions with a combined membership of 350,000 have organized a nonprofit corporation to run a chain of cut-rate drugstores in the metropolitan area.

The New York Alumnae of the Shipley School have chosen the Dec. 12 performance of "Advise and Consent" for their ninth annual theatre benefit. The new play, starring Ed Begley and Otto Kruger, is scheduled to open at the Cort Theatre Nov. 17.
New Orleans, La., borrowed $9,600,000 in the bond market yesterday.

The American League's two new clubs will be manned chiefly by players made available from the rosters of the eight 1960 member teams. This means that there will be a general dilution of talent in the junior circuit in 1961.

The search for new ways to present advertising messages to the public goes on. But one of the most obvious means Is being handled in a cautious fashion because of the special problems that are involved.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 26 -- On Chancellor Adenauer's advice, the West German Bundestag [Parliament] acted again today to avoid provoking the Communists over West Berlin.

OTTAWA, Oct. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's net indebtedness to other countries rose to a record $15,300,000,000 at the end of 1959 -- double the 1952 figure and four times as much as at the end of 1949.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- British Government bonds provided the one bright spot in an otherwise dull stock market here today.
Governor Rockefeller, who has eaten his way through blintzes, bagels and lox in the cause of Republican politics, lunched yesterday on veal scallopine marsala with mushrooms in a Bronx pizzeria.

Senator John F. Kennedy will resume his campaigning in New York City today with an intensive schedule of afternoon meetings in mid-Manhattan and on Staten Island and night addresses in Brooklyn and Queens.

SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A communique issued by the junta that seized power today declared that President Lemus had been overthrown because "he governed outside the law, trampled on the Constitution and the rights of citizens, committed illegal acts and created a climate of general discontent."

A spirited campaign is under way in Brooklyn's Twelfth Congressional District, where a long-time Republican legislator is being challenged for his seat in the House of Representatives by a Democratic first-time aspirant for public office.

Measures to strengthen American industry in meeting export and import competition were advocated yesterday by Senators Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, and Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.
PARIS, Oct. 26 -- German troops crossed the frontiers of France today for the fourth time in ninety years but for the first time as invited guests instead of invaders.
Earnings of the General motors Corporation for the first nine months of 1960 showed a decline from last year's levels despite a jump in dollar and unit sales, it was announced yesterday.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 26 -- It may be necessary to devote more than half of the weight of man's early space ships to protective radiation shielding for the crew, a space medicine symposium was told here today.

The Superintendent of Schools announced yesterday that a budget allocation of $243,460 had been approved for the employment in February of 760 lunchroom assistants. The United Federation of Teachers, which has threatened a strike for Nov. 7, said the move, one of several by the Superintendent, was still not enough.

THE workings of the digital computer, including its ability to conceive of alternate plots for a television Western, were explained last night in the first installment of "Tomorrow." The new science series was prepared by the Columbia Broadcasting System in cooperation with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
DALLAS, Oct. 26 -- Desegregation tensions in the South have had "no serious adverse effect" on relations between Christians and Jews, according to a two-year study issued here today.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 26 -- Following is the text of Vice President Nixon's proposals on nuclear-test negotiations at a meeting of Sigma Delta Chi here:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- A plan to provide food to needy areas through the United Nations from the surpluses of member states was approved unanimously tonight by the General Assembly's Economic Committee.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The halfway mark of the Washington international horse show found division leads narrow.
In Buffalo and Rocheste, New York's second and third largest cities, Democrats have a problem: how to retain Senetor John F. Kennedy's preser, lead through Election Day.
With reservations, Commissioner Ford C. Frick yesterday gave his blessing to the American League's spectacular move in expanding to ten clubs for next year.

THE precipitate action of the American League in setting next season as the target date for its start as an expanded ten-club circuit must be regarded as needless impetuosity. What's the hurry? This is far too monumental a step to be handled like instant coffee. It requires time and preparation. It is getting neither.
Net earnings of the Chrysler Corporation in the first nine months of this year rose to $25,100,000, or $2.84 a share, the highest for a similar period since 1957, it was announced yesterday.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was confined to the near December contract which fell 3 points and the near March, which was unchanged, yesterday.
SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 27 -- El Salvador's six-man ruling junta erased today what it called several causes of the friction that led to its bloodless coup here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Labor union and management attorneys clashed before the National Labor relations Board today over whether an agency-shop clause in labor contracts was legal.
Further progress in coordinating plans for the Golden Anniversary Ball of the Junior League of Brooklyn was made at a recent luncheon in the Louis XVI Suite of the St. Regis.
The Boston Celtics, champions of the National Basketball Association in three of the last four seasons, will demonstrate the remarkable talents that led them to such heights here tonight.

VIENNA, Oct. 27 -- An open letter to Dag Hammarskold, Secretary General of the United Nations, demanding the right of self-determination for the German-speaking minority in the South Tyrol of Italy was published today in Innsbruck, the capital of the Austrian Tyrol.
Robert Gatling led Bronx Vocational to victory yesterday in the Bronx Public School Athletic League cross-country championship at Van Cortllandt Park, the Bronx.

When Robert Burns sadly observed that Man's inhumanity to man makes countless thousands mourn," he spoke of a world simpler and even kindlier than our own. Man's inhumanity in this generation of wars, persecutions, tyrannies and refugees has affected millions, not merely thousands. This is the story partly told in refugee reports that come all the way around the world.
A Texas company that manufactures snack tables and whose stock is not even traded received more attention in Wall Street yesterday than most actively traded securities on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Unions in the printing trade opened today a drive for legislation aimed at stopping the importation of professional strike-breakers in labor disputes.
In these days when someone speaks up for more creative advertising, it is hardly news. But when an advertising executive finds fault with what he calls the "cult of creativity," it is of interest.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $166,000,000 to $240,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $262,000,000 to $588,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Treasury offered today new issues of fifteen-month and fiveand-a-half-yenr securities to holders of $10,843,000,000 of Government securities maturing in mid-November.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Miss Jennie Lee, widow of Aneurin Bevan and Labor Member of Parliament for Cannock, turned today against Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the party.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The lightweight champion, Joe Brown of Houston, will establish a record for title bouts in his division when he defends his crown against Cisco Andrade of Compton, Calif., tomorrow night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- In the less responsible days when Melvin Frank and Norman Panama did nothing but write for movies, they were able to make sport of their work. During one story conference in the backyard they whipped a baseball back and forth.

CUCUMBERS usually are associated with coolness. The fact remains, however, that when the weather becomes cool, the cucumber becomes scarce. The result is a further 6 cent jump in the price of the vegetable this week, bringing the general cost up to a luxurious 25 cents a pound.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The joke in this election is on the experts. All the techniques of the sociologist and all the skills of the electronic engineer have been added to politics. The hucksters and the pollsters, the mass psychologists and the makeup artists, have all been mobilized by Nixon and Kennedy alike, but to no avail.

The consolidated net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) in the first nine months of this year were $102,826,000, or $2.87 a share. This compared with $106,189,000, and $2.97 in the 1959 period.
Earnings of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation in the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30 were above the 1959 levels, the company reported yesterday.
HAVANA, Oct. 27 -- The Government is waging an intense campaign to whip up a "war spirit" among the Cuban people to resist an "imminent invasion" by the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- In Their contest for the farm vote Vice President Nixon and Senntor John F. Kennedy appear to have traded words without enlghtening farmers or consumers.

DALLAS, Oct. 27 -- The executive head of the American Jewish Committee charged today extensive discriminatory practices by big American corporations. He said this was resulting in "serious losses" in "management manpower resources."

Geechee Lou made herself mighty popular with the favorite players among the 20,616 customers at Aqueduct yesterday. This 4-year-old daughter of Noble Hero was installed the even-money choice against five female rivals in the feature turf race of a mile and a sixteenth and she responded with a half-length triumph over Mrs. John Galbreath's Sauchrie.

The bond market rally caused by the announcement of new moves by the Federal Reserve System to case bank money carried over in the trading session yesterday to impart the best price rise to prime debt securities in recent weeks.
A 34-year-old Korean War hero is challenging the 74-year-old incumbent in the Fifteenth Congressional District, which includes Staten Island and part of Brooklyn.

Stocks advanced yesterday for the second straight day in a sustained rally. The forward movement on the New York Stock Exchange was not as decisive as on Wednesday, but it was still strong and general.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -- The West German Government has proposed Gen. Adolf Heusinger to be chairman of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Military Committee in Permanent Session in Washington.

LITERALLY thousands of combinations have been analyzed and published in bridge books and magazines to guide bridge players in the play of the cards, but occasionally even the most experienced player encounters one that is not part of the standard technique of the game, and then he must figure out for himself how best to play.

More important even than saving and improving passenger service on the New Haven Railroad, which is important enough, is the precedent-making all-government cooperation represented in the Rockefeller-Ribicoff agreement on program.
