With the arrest of a Russian and a German artist on spy charges here yesterday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation made another entry in the voluminous dossier of Soviet espionage in the United States.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 27 An overflow crowd of 4,000 persons came to a rally in this Republican stronghold tonight to hear Adlai E. Stevenson urge the election of Senator John F. Kennedy, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Reliable sources said today that the African and Asian members of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's Advisory Committee on the Congo had reached a tentative agreement on arrangements for a new conciliation committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- By circulating in Virginia many copies of a speech in which he repudiated the Democratic national platform pledge to nullify the "right-to-work" laws of twenty states, Senator Harry F. Byrd has moved to put this issue in the forefront of the Presidential campaign in that state.
The president of the Board of Education urged the president of the United Federation of Teachers yesterday to call off his threat to strike on Nov. 7.
The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday the election of E.D. Brockott, formerly executive vice president, as president. He was named also vice chairman of the executive committee.

Office and showroom space in the former Russeks store building at 390 Fifth Avenue, at Thirty-sixth Street, has been leased by three leading manufacturers of men's and boys' wear. The Williams Real Estate Company, agent for the building, arranged the leases.

The four-story apartment building at 149 East Thirtyninth Street, near Lexington Avenue, has been resold by clients of Walter Scott Co. to Dr. Evelyn T. Clerico. The buyer plans to remodel the house for her own occupancy.
YESTERDAY (Oct. 27, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Unanimously approved a plan for the distribution of surplus foods for needy peoples.

The Public Education Association called upon the Board of Education yesterday to force a court review of a recent decision of the State Education Department giving parents access to confidential school records.

THERE, are two genuinely praiseworthy features about the volume entitled "Great Restaurants of America" (J.P. Lippincott Company), which was published this week. It is written with such a facile and fascinating style that it is a joy to read And while some of the nominations for "great restaurants" are confounding to put it without malice any guide to the nation's dining establishments must be better than none.
Enroachments by highways, industry and housing on parks and open land is increasing at an alarming rate, a conference of 100 leaders in park, recreation and conservation fields was told yesterday.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City fell $12,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a rise of $1,000,000 in the 1959 week.

Just as husbands have wallet worries about their wives buying new clothes each season, big industries, grown cost-conscious, have begun to ponder whether model changes each year are necessary. In fact, some writers have condemned them as economic waste.
THE mystery shows and Westerns of television were joined by something new last night: Gross national product, balance of payments and the Federal Reserve System.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- The Vatican says that Bishops in all countries not only have the right but also the duty to advise voters at election time because voters elect legislators who pass laws that can be either, "good or bad" from the Catholic viewpoint.
Busts of Thomas Alva Edison, Henry David Thoreau and Edward Alexander MacDowell will soon join those of eighty-six other prominent figures in the Hall of Fame for Great Americans.
The new off-off-Broadway theatre movement that has been thriving in Greenwich Village coffeehouses faced the threat of a serious setback yesterday.
Federal mediators began a drive yesterday to prevent a newspaper strike that is threatened for midnight Monday, and will continue their efforts today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Available scientific evidence indicates that a seismic disturbance, which Vice President Nixon suggested might have been a clandestine Soviet nuclear test, was a large earthquake in the Kamchatka Peninsula off Siberia.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain today called "ridiculous" charges that he had received an automobile in violation of National Collegiate rules while at Kansas University.
William O'Dwyer, who resigned as Mayor in 1950 to become Ambassador to Mexico, said yesterday he was changing his permanent residence from Mexico City to New York City.

A companion volume to John S. Blay's "The Civil War" will be published by Crowell on Nov. 14. It is "After the Civil War: A Pictorial Profile of America from 1865 to 1900." The volume, which contains more than 400 illustrations, depicts the transformation of the country in those thirty-five years.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Royals, down by 13 points in the first half, tied the Syracuse Nationals with four seconds remaining tonight and went on to post a 143-140 National Basketball Association victory in overtime before 5,987 fans.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., withstood the challenge of Mrs. Julius Page, the former National Amateur champion, today and won the North and South senior Women's golf title by one stroke with a 153 total.
HARTFORD, Oct. 27 -- The political climate in the small towns east and west of here does not seem normal this year.
SALISBURY, L.I., Oct. 27 -- The Long Island Professional Golfers Association, a chapter of the metropolitan section of the national P.G.A., will attempt to become an independent body.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 27 -- The athletic program at the Kingswood School has received new impetus this year. For the first time since this busy country day school was founded in 1916, sports activities have been placed on an interscholastic competitive basis at four levels.

This week's announcement that the United States Navy has contracted with Outboard Marine Corporation of Waukegan, Ill., for the purchase of the first outboard gas turbine engines for small craft leads to speculation concerning use of this type of power plant in recreational craft.

A Georgia newspaper publisher has agreed to appear with the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in a television debate on the question of whether Negro sit-in demonstrations are justifiable. The program, originating here, will be presented by the National Broadcasting Company on Nov. 26 at 9:30 P.M.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Whatever became of Senator Kennedy's "New Frontier" and Vice President Nixon's "Extension of Freedom" which these Presidential nominees proclaimed so vigorously in their respective acceptance speeches These great objectives have been conspicuously absent from the campaign.

The net consolidated income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the first nine months of this year was estimated yesterday at $501,000,000, or $2.31 each on the 216,533,000 shares outstanding.
SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 26 -- The most depressed people in this chronically depressed area are Vice President Nixon's boosters.
Benjamin Franklin High, paced by Ray Jackson, scored an easy victory yesterday in the Manhattan Public Schools Athletic League cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
The Queens County District Attorney's office reported yesterday that known racketeers might be involved in charges that tow-truck operators have been making pay-offs to policemen.
Despite the vexing problems encountered by the incoming "Camelot," the local advance sale continues unabated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Western Big Three have warned the Soviet Union that any interference with their air corridors into West Berlin "would create a dangerous situation."

TWO exhibitions that opened this week, one of painting and one of sculpture, are demonstrations of craftsmanship offering different answers to the question, "Of what importance, this meticulous means toward the demonstrated end?"
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Igor Yagovlevich Melekh, the Russian arrested on espionage charges today, has been working at the United Nations since 1955, when he arrived from the Soviet Union.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Jerry Toppazzini and Bronco Horvath scored twice each tonight as the Boston Bruins registered their first victory of the National Hockey League season, beating the New York Rangers, 6 -- 4.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Citizens Union renders Invaluable service in this city to the independent-minded voter who wants nonpartisan information and advice on issues and the qualifications of candidates for local office. There is no other comparable source as to candidates, and for this reason I have been a member of Citizens Union for a number of years.
The Uniformed Firemen's Association told Mayor Wagner yesterday it would accept the city's offer to give six paid holidays a year to members of the Fire Department.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday the appointment of a five-man board of fiscal experts to advise him on' the management of the city's five actuarial pension funds.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Oct. 22 were 4 per cent above the level of the 1959 period.

DO you read for pleasure with some pretension to taste? If so, you belong to a worthy company that Robortson Davins, author of "A Voice From the Attic," calls the clcrisy. If you read for pleasure and lack taste (and who is to judge whether you have it?) you are not eligible for membership among the elect.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Until James Harold Wilson openly challenged Hugh Gaitskell to a test of political strength, many were the men who coveted the Labor parly leadership. But when Mr. Wilson entered the arena, the others backed away.
YOUNG masquerading "trick or treaters" who knock or any door in their quest for candy and or cash sometime are victimized by their intender prey, past experiences indicate.
ATLANTA, Oct. 27 -- Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy have been asked to pledge, "in unmistakable terms," moral leadership in the struggle against racial discrimination.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The Government reduced the bank rate today, but cautioned that this did not mean any change in its policy of credit restriction.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The stock market responded mildly today to the reduction in the bank rate from 6 to 5 1/2 per cent. Its effect had largely been discounted by recent buying on expectations that the cut was due.
STAUNTON, Va. Oct. 27 -- President Eisenhower cautioned Virginians today against following "false leaders to their destruction."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Navy announced today that the nuclear-powered, missile-armed submarine George Washington would begin sea duty Nov. 15, opening a new military era.

George C. Sherman Jr. of New York and Southampton, L.I., yesterday was elected chairman of the United States Polo Association at the annual meeting of delegates at the Links Club. He had been vice chairman since 1953.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Eisenhower made his strongest nationally broadcast political appeal in a five-minute telecast last night.

Arthur Godfrey, the radio and television entertainer, proposed last night that the next President summon a White House conference to establish standards for fund - raising groups.
The sidewalks of New York are being made cleaner, but 9,000 of the 60,000 blocks of city streets are still littered with paper, beer cans, watermelon rinds, discarded mattresses and other refuse.

The United States team finished in first place in Section 4 of the preliminaries of the chess Olympics at Leipzig, according to a report yesterday from East Germany. The Americans had a score of 29 -- 7.
The Right Worshipful James Redington, Mayor of Galway, Ireland, yesterday recovered a magnificent silver mace and sword that have been out of his city for more than a century.
The Florida. Development Commission is planning the sale of $14.500,000 of road revenue bonds in behalf of Hills-borough County on Nov. 30.

Coach Buff Donelli is going to call the plays. . . . Oops! Check signals on that! Coach Buiff Donelli is going to direct Columbia's football team from the press box, rather than from the bench, in tomorrow's game with Cornell at Baker Field.
Barrie Stavis may not be the theatre's most honored playwright, but yesterday morning he certainly was its most pampered.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The American Medical Association defended today the present level of medical-care costs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Dag Hammarskjold has demanded in a note to the Belgian Government that it withdraw all its "military, paramilitary and civilian" personnel from the Congo and route all aid to the Congo through the United Nations.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Newcomers in this fast-growing suburban area of northern Westchester County today were given a composite opinion on the proper pattern of social conduct for teen-agers.
Third-quarter earnings of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., showed a slight gain over the year-ago period, John E. McKeen, president of the pharmaceutical manufacturing concern, reported yesterday.
A Russian employe at the United Nations and a German freelance illustrator were arrested here yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of espionage.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 27 -- A large industrial concern that is transferring its operations here is using colorful pictures and colorful prose to retain its employes.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Most wheat and corn contracts finished steady in the futures market today but other grains and Soybeans turned downward.

Trading in commodity futures continued dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Unless volume increases substantially today, this will be one of the most inactive weeks in several years.
IN "The 49th Cousin," which reached the Ambassador Theatre last night, Menasha Skulnick gives a peerless performance as Menasha Skulnik.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Spokesmen for two labor unions urged today that the Civil Aeronautics Board approve a merger of Capital Airlines into United Air Lines -- but with better terms for employes than had been proposed.
The New Rochelle Board of Education denied in Federal Court yesterday that there is segregation in its school system.
The will of a former New York City deputy police inspector who left an estate of $400,000 is being contested by six nephews and nieces.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points (50 cents a bale) off yesterday. Sales were 1,900 bales.
Forty policemen accused of holding outside jobs appeared for departmental trials at Police Headquarters yesterday and all pleaded not guilty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- An increase in defense contracting lifted new orders at the manufacturing level last month and backlogs increased for the first time since last winter.
The caliber of some of the American schools to which African exchange students are being sent was criticized yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University.
The Clark Equipment Company announced yesterday sharply reduced net income for the September quarter and the first nine months of this year, as compared with the like periods last year.

CARNEGIE HALL was packed, again last night for the fourth in the series of five piano recitals the astounding Sviatoslav Richter is giving, there, and once again his performances justified all the fantastic praise that has been heaped upon him.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 28 -- India is expected to increase sharply her purchases of petroleum products from the Soviet Union, an official Indian spokesman said today.

Fifteen subsidized American steamship lines complained yesterday that the Department of Defense, by shifting the overseas transport of military personnel from sea to air travel, was depriving the lines of more than $8,000,000 a year in passenger revenues.

METROPOLIS, Ill., Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Walter J. Goodpaster, whose brother, Brig. Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, is a White House aide, was found guilty today of the murder of a mother of twelve children. He was sentenced to 199 years in prison.
A "news essayist" will have his own half-hour each week to discuss items of world interest on WNEW-TV (Channel 5).
Spokesmen for automobile insurance companies at a legislative hearing yesterday strongly opposed any attempt by the state to regulate their freedom to cancel policies to reduce their risks.

The state's attack on slum landlords gained momentum yesterday. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz obtained court orders permitting action to dissolve five corporations charged with operating six vermin-ridden tenements.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Right-wing extremists, apparently surprised at the strength of last night's demonstration for a negotiated peace in Algeria, announced today their intention to stage a big rally for "the maintenance of French sovereignty in Algeria."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I ask your indulgence in my criticism of your editorial "The Choice of a Candidate."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Democrats and Republicans traded charges of "bad faith" today but continued their negotiations for a fifth television debate between the Presidential candidates.

Up until yesterday, the battle between the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway and the New York Central Railroad of control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was still going on, but the fighting had quieted considerably.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 28 -- Archbishop James P. Davis of San Juan defended today the recent intervention of three Roman Catholic prelates in the political activities of Puerto Rico.
The stock market went downhill yesterday after the good rally of Wednesday and Thursday. The price decline was general but moderate in extent on the New York Stock Exchange.
Following is the text of President 'Elsenhower's speech at last night's Republican rally at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia, as recorded by The New York Times:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Attorneys for Universe Tank-ships, Inc., an affiliate of Natoinal Bulk Carriers, argued before the Common Pleas Court today that the jobs of 7,000 steel workers were at stake as a result of a picketing operation by three American maritime unions.

A greatly expanded program to help the city's aged "keep physically and mentally sound and economically selfsufficient" was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner. He said it would be put into effect as soon as possible.

Having won a Hollywood Oscar last season for his highly picturesque "Black Orpheus," Marcel Camus, the French writer-director-producer, is obviously determined to go on making films in his own distinctive manner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Farm product prices rose 1 per cent between mid-September and mid-October.
The president of the Board of Education took to the air yesterday to defend the board's action in the face of a strike threatened for Nov. 7.

ALAS, the poor quince. Its fall from grace has been so swift and complete that nowadays only the more comprehensive fruit stands in this area number it among their wares. Those who have the patience to look for the fruit, however, will discover that it is now in season and costs from about 25 to 35 cents.
The finals of the chess Olympics at Leipzig got under way yesterday, according to a report from East Germany.

Mrs. Richard C. du Pont's 3-year-old Kelso was the overnight 3-5 choice in the field of nine that will contest the two-mile Jockey Club Gold Cup at Aqueduct today. If all nine start in the forty-second running of the stamina-testing stakes, the winner will net $70,855 of the $110,700 gross purse.
WAYNE, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Thorn Lord outlined tonight a four-point program that he said would do much to stimulate economic growth and meet the threat of a recession.
The return to Standard Time takes place here at 2 A.M. tomorrow.
DALLAS, Oct. 28 -- A Protestant educator indicated anti-Catholicism in the Presidential campaign here today. He linked it to a drive to "discredit liberals" and to promote manipulation "by fear."

LOON BAY, N.B., Oct. 28 -- Sometimes it seems as if a man ought to give up hunting and studying the Lore of the Wildwood and just take up knitting sweaters. This is especially so when a woman who has been trying to knit a sweater for five months calls up a ten-point buck while fooling inquisitively with a deer call, and kills the buck because her rifle kicked.

Warren C. Giles, the president of the National League, said yesterday that, so far as he was concerned, his circuit would toss no obstacles in the path of the American League's announced plan to operate as a ten-club league next year.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Senator John F. Kennedy was acclaimed by more than 500,000 persons today on a 150-mile motorcade through economically depressed industrial and mining areas of northeast Pennsylvania.

The commander of the At- lantic Fleet's Submarine Force said yesterday that the Navy had a "terrific lead of four years in nuclear propulsion" and could exert "preventive power over the entire earth's surface."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a regular reader of your paper I have generally agreed with your editorial comment, but I cannot agree with your endorsement of John F. Kennedy for President. In making your decision "on balance," I believe that you overemphasized the considerations of foreign policy and unification of government.

Federico Thompson of Argentina will risk his chance at the world welterweight title in Madison Square Garden tonight when he faces Gaspar (Indian) Ortega of Mexicali, Mexico, in a scheduled ten-round bout.

Saint-John Perse, the pen name of Alexis Leger, who has just been awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature, is the type of man not commonly seen in our country. For this 73-year-old Frenchman is a man of action and a man of letters: the diplomat in foreign service, the poet of singular originality.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Los Angeles crushed Boston, 45 -- 16, tonight in an American Football League victory fashioned by a pair of Pauls -- Maguire and Lowe.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today production of 1961 model cars passed the one-million mark in the United States this week, nearly a month earlier than that milestone was reached with 1960 models.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 28 -- The Chancellor of the Ponce Roman Catholic Diocese warned today that anyone who voted for or supported political parties disapproved by the bishops of Puerto Rico could be excommunicated.

The comprehensive ten-point program for the city's aged launched yesterday by Mayor Wagner before the Community Council for Greater New York is a full-dress attack on problems that greatly trouble the public conscience. Its dimensions, the care with which it was prepared, and the importance obviously attached to it by his advisers all mark this declaration of policy as the stepping off on a major course of action.

Following is the text of a United States Information Agency Office of Research and Analysis report, under date of Oct. 10, 1960, entitled "The World Reaction to the United States and Soviet Space Programs -- A Summary Assessment" described as "for use in O.C.B. [Operations Coordinating Board] discussions.''
HAVANA, Oct. 28 -- Reliable sources here reported today that during the last month the Cuban Government has purchased arms in large quantities from the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia.
A plan by thirteen unions to operate a chain of cut-rate drugstores in New York was attacked by retail pharmacists yesterday as economically unsound and dangerous to public health.
Mrs. Hattie Gibson Hallowell emerged yesterday from the Civil Jail, where she had been imprisoned for three years and five months in an estate dispute.
ATER pondering new and ancient volumes of forgotten lorre Burke Davis has produced an unusual book of Americana. It is called "Our Incredible Civil War."* Only that and nothing more.

WHAT can one say about the Fifth Piano Concerto by Prokofieff? Powerful, knotted, dissonant, bleak, alternating between strongly defined melody and what sounds almost like percussive tone clusters, ungrateful to play, unlovely and yet fascinating, a strange work that only a dedicated pianist would take time out to memorize.

The New York Newspaper guild asked the United States Attorney General yesterday to investigate whether New York newspapers were planning to use strike insurance to import strikebreakers and whether such insurance was in the public interest.
NEW YORK'S oldest bridge club of its kind, Bridge House at 645 Madison Avenue, near Sixtieth Street, celebrated its thirtieth anniversary last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- New York State's Republican finance committee reported today that it has collected more than $500,000 in contributions since Sept. 1.
Two schools in the metropolitan area were damaged, one of them severely, by fires of unknown origin yesterday afternoon. Classes were not in session at the time and no children were reported injured.

THE contemporary Dutch painter Karel Appel, a champion of "all-out" abstract expressionism, is showing new paintings at the Martha Jackson Gallery, 32 East Sixty-ninth Street. Examples of his printmaking are on view at the Robert Anderson Gallery, at the same address.

NAUGATUCK, Conn., Oct. 28 -- The proxy fight for control of Peter Paul, Inc., of Naugatuck, a candy manufacturer, was waged here today at a heated meeting of more than 400 stockholders, but the victor will not be known until Tuesday, when the tabulation of ballots is completed.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Oct. 28 -- Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong discovered the Congo today and the uninitiated in the Congo discovered "chahss."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The United States charged today that the Soviet bloc was shipping large amounts of weapons to Cuba that the Cubans could use to seize "other parts of the Americas."

French instrumental, music from the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, vocal works from Italy in the sixteenth century and compositions by J.S., Bach were performed in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon by the Canticum Musicum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Average wholesale primary market prices dipped 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 118.9 per cent of the 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 28 -- The Arab League is scheduled to open an office here shortly in an effort to counteract recent Israeli overtures toward South Asia.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 28 -- The heads of Istanbul's two leading universities resigned today in protest against the military Government's dismissal of 147 professors.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I believe you are very wise in supporting the candidacy of Senator Kennedy for President.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Julian Amery, Prime Minister Macmillan's son-in-law, was appointed Secretary of State for Air today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have scheduled private talks here that they hope may lead to a resumption of the disarmament negotiations broken off in Geneva last June.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower accused Senator John F. Kennedy tonight of having "cruelly distorted the image of America" abroad.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Oct. 28 -- Vice President Nixon declared tonight that Senator Kennedy's farm proposals would destroy 1,000,000 jobs on farms and increase consumers' costs 25 per cent.
A rocket sixty feet long, decoratively painted with black-and-white checkerboard squares, was displayed by the Army in Times Square yesterday.
Assurance about the prevailing values of prime fixed-income investments dominated the bond market as the trading week came to a close yesterday.
A Government survey of world opinion on the relative space achievements of the United States and the Soviet Union has found there is wide belief that the Soviet Union is well ahead.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 -- Henry Cabot Lodge appealed today for a chance to let Republicans lead America toward a "sunlit plateau" of future unmenaced good times.
Cocoa futures prices led a general decline in commodities yesterday on New York exchanges, ending one of the dullest weeks of trading in several years.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 26 -- Coattalis appear to be a factor in determining what will happen in Rhode Island in the election Nov. 8.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, devoted special efforts today to a rebuttal of charges in the West that the Soviet Union maintains an oppressive colonial rule over the non-Russian republics in Central Asia and the Baltic region.

In its efforts to cope with the Congo crisis the United Nations has undertaken two new moves which are logical and in keeping with the resolution adopted by the General Assembly by a 70-to-0 vote. But these new moves are subject to serious reservation unless they are carried out in strict impartiality and absolute good faith.
DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- A residents' quarrel with the Noroton Heights volunteer firemen over an unoccupied house that burned last Monday was still smoldering here today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Prices in the grain futures markets were mixed at the close of the Board of Trade today.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Money will go after more money tomorrow with the eighth running of the Garden State Stakes. This mile-and-one-sixteenth test for 2-year-olds, billed as the world's richest horse race, has attracted fifteen entrants and if all start it will have a gross value of $287,970.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters union, won an important court battle today in his fight against the "watch-dog" board of monitors.
CESARE VALLETTI's Town Hall recital last night was one of those events that ought to inspire rapture but actually produce something more like mixed feelings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- A two-gun robot invented by a Texan shoots it out with a human opponent. True, it fires only blanks, but it inflicts humiliation on any man who loses the draw. Arthur C. Ross, the electrical engineer who conceived the robot, intends it primarily for police training, although he isn't overlooking the growing "fast draw" clubs as a market.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 28 (AP) -- A state court judge refused today to throw out one of three libel suits pending against The New York Times and four Negro integration leaders.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- A busy fortnightly account ended quietly here today. Gains in South African gold-mine shares were the highlight of the stock market. They finished on a firm note, helped by a rise in the gold "fixing" price and buying orders from the Cape and Continent.
The Canadian Pacific Railway, unlike most American railroads, showed gains in revenues and earnings this September over those of the 1959 month.

WHILE New Yorkers were busy summerizing their homes last April, Richard Harding, Lord Taylor's gift buyer, was consumed with decorating the house for Christmas. The world was his shopping area. And he canvassed it from Japan to Denmark for new ideas in holiday ornaments.

ANYONE who feels Christmas is months off will be in for a shock at Black Starr Gorham. Here on the second floor a chic gold and chartreuse striped awning and a completely trimmed tree adorn the store's Christmas shop.

The New York State Athletic Commission has decided that Archie Moore is still the light-heavyweight champion of the world. In another decision, the commission has declared the world bantamweight title vacant.
The Air Force put $30,000,000 in military flying business on the block this week. It invited twenty-one qualified commercial carriers to bid.

CENTER ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 28 -- When schools let out today, 9,000 pupils in districts here and in neighboring Brentwood found themselves, without, bus transportation because of a labor dispute. Service will be resumed Monday, the bus company said.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 28 -- Utah shippers, business men and labor spokesmen have reacted coolly to efforts of the Southern Pacific Railroad to purchase control of the Western Pacific Railroad. They are only slightly less cool to the Santa Fe's speedy counter-proposal for acquisition of the San FranciscoSalt Lake City carrier.

Safeway Properties, Inc., Bernard Siegel, president, has bought for investment the industrial building on a plot 350 by 160 feet at 445 Devoe Avenue, the Bronx. The building contains 70,000 square feet of space and is equipped with conveyor belts and elevators.

YONKERS, Oct. 28 -- A crowd of 21,266 braved bad weather to see Stormy Dream, handled by Jimmy Cruise, score a three-quarter length victory over the favored Flying Time in 2:05 in the Chester pacing feature at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Protestant churches tomorrow will observe the most widely heralded Reformation Sunday in the country's history. The observances will be of two types -- the sacred and the political.

A panorama of this country's past as portrayed in the pages of The New York Times in the last 108 years will be published by Simon Schuster or Nov. 28. It will be titled "America's Taste." In reviews, pictures, cartoons and editorials, it presents cultural and political events and the villains, heroes, scandals and delights of the national scene.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- India put the abolition human want ahead of disarmament today as the greatest problem facing the world.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Leland Hayward, movie and stage producer, praised pay television today. He described movie-going as a "misery" complicated by traffic and parking problems.

BUFFALO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Switchmen's Union of North America has rejected the second wage agreement offered by its officers to seventen Western and Southern railroads and switching companies, Neil P. Speirs, president of the union, said here today.

As the ruling Junta of the National Basketball Association the Boston Celtics dropped in at Madison Square Garden last night to exact the first regular-season installment of the tribute they had every right to expect from the lowly New York Knickerbockers.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 28 -- A beaming Premier Souvanna Phouma said today that United States military aid to Laos had been resumed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- (UPI) The Senate Elections Committee released a sworn affidavit today attesting that certain Texans paid $10,000 to have an anil-Catholic sermon distributed through the mails.
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 28 -- The five-member Nobel Peace Prize Committee said today it had decided to withhold the prize for 1960.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Sheriff Custer Dunifon theorized today that a twenty-five-pound metal can had been lashed to rails in the path of Vice President Nixon's campaign special in a deliberate attempt to wreck a train.

Representative James C. Healey, a track star at the University of Pennsylvania twenty-seven years ago, is running so confidently in the Twenty-second Congressional District here that he usually ignores himself in campaign speeches.

Although registration for the Nov. 8 election ended on Oct. 15, the Board of Elections yesterday granted thirteen former residents of Puerto Rico the right to have their names entered on the voting rolls.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Prime Minister Macmillan tonight assailed as "illogical" the doctrine of unilateral renunciation of nuclear weapons by Britain.
OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Former President Truman has suggested that Vice President Nixon open an amusement park "when he has to leave Washington on Jan. 20."
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The controversial new United States Embassy building here was defended today by Eero Saarinen, its architect.
ROME, Oct. 28 -- Pope John XXIII celebrated his second anniversary as leader of the Roman Catholic Church today by personally consecrating eight new Bishops in Saint Peter's Basilica.
Mayor Wagner will depart today on a two-day upstate speaking tour in five counties on behalf of the Kennedy-Johnson ticket and Democratic candidates for Congress and the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Following is the text of a letter from John C. Dreier, United States representative, to Dr. Jose A. Mora, Secretary General of the Organization of American States, requesting an investigation of arms shipments to Cuba:
A gold watch presented as a memento of a notable rescue at sea in 1929 is soon to be returned to its owner after being missing for twenty years.

The work of the Children's Village, a treatment school for disturbed and delinquent boys at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the Jan. 27 performance of "Camelot" at the Majestic Theatre.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The General Electric Company discharged fifteen employes and suspended eighteen today for alleged misconduct on the picket line during the recent strike against it by the International Union of Electrical Workers.

Monday, Oct. 31 America House, 44 West Fifty-third Street. The continuing exhibit and demonstrations of "From the Hand to the Home" this week features weaving on looms. Craftsmen will be on hand Monday through Saturday from 2 to 4 P.M. to demonstrate techniques.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union has notified Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold that it has furnished aid worth about $3,662,000 to the Congo in "pursuance" of a Security Council decision and "in conformity" with the Congo's own request.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 28 -- In an apparent effort to stave off integration of New Orleans public schools, Gov. Jimmie H. Davis summoned the Legislature today into a twelve-day session beginning Nov. 4.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Joe Brown of Houston, the lightweight champion, remained a 2-1 choice to whip Bobby (Cisco) Andrade of California in fifteen rounds or less tonight.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28 -- The three top officials of the Carpenters Union were found guilty tonight of bribing and conspiracy to bribe a State Highway Department official.

Changing the Time In theory at least, if not in fact, the sun will pause for sixty minutes wherever it happens to be at 2 A.M. tomorrow morning so that the nation can get back to Standard Time again for the shorter days of winter.

FRENCHTOWN, Mont., Oct. 28 -- A Northwest Airlines passenger plane crashed in flames into the pine-studded Cayuse Hills eight miles from this western Montana farming community today. The police said all twelve aboard were killed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon agree that a "challenge" in education exists, but they disagree on the response to the challenge.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation has bought an interest in the forty-five-story hotel planned on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets, and will operate it.
Iowa, Mississippi, Syracuse and Navy, rated in that order as the nation's leading college football powers in this week's news service polls, face opponents today that jeopardize their high estate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -- West Coast ship owners and unlicensed offshore unions agreed today on a 7 per cent wage increase for members of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, the Marine Firemen's Union and the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union.

A sizable volume of fixed-interest securities is scheduled for sale at competitive bidding in the public capital market next week. About $185,000,000 of securities is involved, but relatively few issues.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Premier Khrushchev has expressed the wish that his pledge to defend Cuba with rockets against any United States attacks should stand as a "symbolic" declaration.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The careers of Julian Amery and his father, the late Leopold S. Amery, show striking similarities.

A West German military truck attempting to cross into France was met at the border at Saarlouis last Wednesday night and fired upon -- but by cameramen instead of artillerymen. Saarlouis, as some American veterans of the second World War remember, is northeast of Metz in what used to be the German province of Lorraine.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- A strong move against racial discrimination in trust areas won overwhelming support here tonight.
The sorriest aspect of the so-called prestige issue is that it should exist at all. One is reminded of the tale of J.P. Morgan and the aspiring yachtsman.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller brought smiles for the women and brickbats for the Democrats as he passed through Nassau County on a political barnstorming tour today.
ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 28 -- A ship arrived here today with a varied collection of fish -- most of them seasick -- for the Aquarium at Coney Island.

Edward Albee, author of the off-Broadway, off-beat one-act play, "The Zoo Story," is at work on his first project, for the Broadway theatre. It is an adaptation of Carson McCullers' novella, "The Bailad of the Sad Cafe," and it is earmarked for presentation next fall.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union charged today that the arrest of a Russian United Nations ofificial in New York yesterday on spy charges was a "dirty political provocation."

THIS week's news that, during the last year, 13,000,000 persons have saved $1,452,770,000 in Christmas Clubs is bound to ruin the day for several million non-savers to whom Christmas is still an annual end-of-December surprise.

CHARTRES, France, Oct. 28 -- The Cathedral of Chartres marked its 700th anniversary here tonight. It served as a setting for a performance of Beethoven's Missa Solemnis by the Radio Symphony Orchestra of West Berlin, a French choir of 150 and four soloists.
Accenting the pink, fuschia and white decor in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night were the beautiful and interesting fans carried by women guests at the eleventh annual Fan Ball.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 28 -- Wally Holly of Alexandria, Va., rode first and second-place jumpers in tonight's knockdown-and-out open jumper class and moved Joe Schneider's Sky Rosie, from Middleburg, Va., a giant step closer to the open title.

The history of the southeast Bronx is characterized by ethnic change and political constancy. The Twenty-third Congressional District has remained a Democratic stronghold despite successive immigrant waves of Irish, Germans, Poles, Jews, and, most recently, Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

Robert P. Burroughs of Manchester, N.H., who recently returned from an official visit to Africa, issued a statement yesterday disputing Senator John F. Kennedy's charge that United States prestige is low abroad.

TO THE EDITOR: UNTIL I.B.M. or somebody comes up with a Book-o-vac that will ingest a novel and disgorge a definitive review, we will just have to stick with Oscar Wilde's view that in matters of art all interpretations are true and no interpretation is final.
William L. Bijur, vice president of Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., advertising agency, died yesterday in his home at 1130 Park Avenue after a long illness. He was 46 years old.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 29 -- Syracuse's scoring machine came to a complete stop today and so did the nation's longest major college winning streak -- sixteen games.
Details of the itinerary of President Eisenhower's campaign trip here Wednesday, were announced yesterday by New York Republican campaign headquarters.

Mrs. Richard C. du Pont's lean, hard-muscled, 3-year-old gelding Kelso set an American track record of 3:19 2/5 yesterday when he won the two-mile Jockey Club Gold Cup by three and one-half lengths in the slop at Aqueduct.
"THE most important American composer?" The young European avant-garde composer paused but a moment. "Edgard Varese, of course."

CUMBERLAND, Md., Oct. 29 (AP) -- A letter from Bishop James E. Walsh of the Roman Catholic Church, the first since he was arrested by the Chinese Communists early in 1958, has been received here by his sister, Miss Mary A. Walsh.
A TAPS recording of a West Berlin concert By Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Nov. 24 (Thanksgiving from 5 to 6 P.M.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Religious affiliation is the most accurate social indicator of how many children a couple will have, according to a study by the Office of Population Research at Princeton University.

Railroads in this country seeking corporate mergers have been meeting with some fickle treatment lately from would-be brides. For example, the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway has been vigorously wooing the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, whose management has indicated that it prefers New York Central Railroad, and then later possibly a three-way union.

The mother of invention has nudged a golf instructor into setting up a "bank" of woods and irons from which youngsters may borrow without cost. The bank, started a few weeks ago, is being built up with contributions of new as well as used clubs from golfers in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The United States has no evidence that the Soviet Union has been cheating on the present voluntary moratorium on atomic tests, a high Defense Department official said today.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 29 -- The 800 families and 300 businesses on the site of a proposed redevelopment here can be relocated without undue hardship, according to a survey just completed.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 29 -- The American Jewish Committee assailed today what it termed a "growing international network of nazism." The network functions aggressively in Europe, South America and the Middle East, according to a report issued here.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 29 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, appealed tonight to Texans to vote for the Kennedy-Johnson ticket or lose the chance "to share during our lifetimes in the executive leadership nationally."

What appeared to be a "homing" football kept flying back into Columbia hands in the first half yesterday, abruptly stopping Cornell and starting Lion marches that led directly to 44-6 triumph at Baker Field.
PATERSON N.J., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Editorial employes of The Morning Call today asked the American Newspaper Guild for permission to take a strike vote at a meeting of about thirty members of Local 173.

IN America a blonde is not just a blonde but a national institution, and in our current folklore no girl is more of an institution -- or, for that matter, more of a blonde -- than Marilyn Monroe. Proof of her eminence is the fact that she is now the subject of a long and serious biography, an honor that doesn't ordinarily fall to 34-year-olds.
