Police summonses for traffic and other violations of the city's Administrative Code have risen sharply under Mayor Wagner and his two successive Police Commissioners -- Francis W.H. Adams and Stephen P. Kennedy.
A Chinese emperor of the Ming Dynasty in lustrous imperial robes brushed past an American cowboy munching papar and mango pickle from India.

NOW that Sviatoslav Richter has five Carnegie Hall concerts to his credit -- and it is rumored that New York has not seen the last of him on that stage this season -- it is possible to assess his art a little more accurately.

Key workers are permitted to carry on outside business activities in almost two-thirds of 195 manufacturing companies questioned, the National Industrial Conference Board reported in a study released yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Willard Coddington of Highland Park, N.J., and Roger Bohl of Plainfield, N.J., who had been in second place after Saturday's leg, won the Appalachian national rally today.
Eastern Air Lines has established a special taxi line for short-haul transportation from it's passenger terminal at New York International Airport.

ALTHOUGH the chemise is still a fighting word in many households, one segment of the population owes a vote of thanks to this controversial style. With the advent of the chemise and its immediate successor, the trapeze, the pregnant woman was liberated from a fashion desert.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Vice President Nixon proposed tonight that Social Security benefits be extended to 2,600,000 of the 4,000,000 Americans over 65 who are not now covered.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Dissension among Government agencies, common enough in private, is on public view in a case before the Supreme Court.
BUFFALO, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Billy Atkins, bulwark in the American Football League's finest defense, today paced the Buffalo Bills, to a 25-24 upset victory over Houston, the Eastern Division leaders.

A report made public yesterday by the Fund for the Republic offered a program for combating racial discrimination in housing. It estimated that 27,500,000 Americans suffer to some extent from such bias.
Following is the text of a statement made last night by The New York Times negotiator, C. Raymond Hulsart, in connection with an offer to The Times unit of the Newspaper Guild:
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Demand for wheat futures, particularly the old crop months, was fairly good last week, but soybeans, while basically firm, experienced several setbacks.

WHAT makes popcorn pop? At a time when witches and witchcraft are the order of the day, it seems sad to admit that there is a simple, nonmystic solution. Popcorn pops when heated because of the expansion of steam within the kernel, which finally gets too much even for the reasonably robust exterior and breaks it with a resounding report.

Presbyterians from various parts of Brooklyn and Nassau County, carrying heather to symbolize the Scottish tradition of their church, met in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday morning to celebrate the Festival of the Reformation.
BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- East Germany warned today that Berlin's traffic with the West would be imperiled when the EastWest German trade pact expires at the end of the year.

The British Government has undertaken what could prove to be a historic initiative in seeking to foster international cooperation in space. Its proposal amounts in effect to an effort to create a third venture in space exploration by uniting the resources of the British Commonwealth and Western Europe. If this initiative is successful then sometime in this decade this proposed coalition will presumably join the Soviet Union and the United States in space-exploration activity.
New lows were established by over-the-counter securities last week as they were on the stock exchanges. Prices firmed subsequently, but not nearly to the extent of listed issues.

Widespread and growing discontent among city employes over wages, salaries and working conditions is giving Mayor Wagner and his chief aides grave concern. They are looking for a quick cure that will fall short of almost complete capitulation to employe demands, which they consider unreasonable.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (AP) The Los Angeles Rams broke out of a long losing streak today, defeating the Detroit Lions, 48 -- 35, for their first victory in fourteen games.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 -- October steel sales were a disappointment to steel makers. More of the same is in store for the industry in November. That wag the concensus of a special check with various steel sales people made a few days ago.

TEN American Indian children have been placed for adoption in the Greater New York area. The placements were effected by Louise Wise Services, a Jewish agency that has pioneered in nonsectarian, interracial adoptions.
Sales and net income of the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries in the third quarter declined from the like 1959 period, Frank L. Magee, chairman, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The National Committee for an Effective Congress announced its endorsement today of twenty-three candidates for the Senate and House of Representatives.
Patrolmen are being reassigned from radio patrol cars to foot beats as a result of a Police Department investigation into a ticket-writing slowdown last Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Vice President Nixon's bro ther, Donald, confirmed today that a $205,000 loan obtained in an effort to save his restaurant business had come from the Hughes Tool Company, owned by Howard Hughes.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported over the week-end a consolidated net income of $12,841,764, or 84 cents each on an average of 15,403,398 shares outstanding, the highest for a third quarter since 1957. The latest profits were 61 per cent above the $7,971,022, or 52 cents a share, in the 1959 quarter.
The United States tied the Soviet Union for first place in the chess Olympics at Leipzig, East Germany, yesterday on an adjourned second-round game with England and a 2 1/2-1/2 victory over Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Do they love us or loathe us in Lagos? What says the latest poll in France? Are we up or down in the eyes of the Indians? Of the Brazilians? Are we winning or losing the "cold war"?

Syracuse, Mississippi, Baylor and Rutgers were drummed out of college football's elite corps Saturday, leaving Navy, Yale, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Utah State and New Mexico State as the only major teams still undefeated and untied.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Closing night was "Ballard Night" at the Washington International Horse Show.
UNDER a mantle of fantasy Arthur Laurents has fashioned "Invitation to a March" into a crisp, wise-cracking, Broadway-style comedy.
Progress in Educating the Gifted Our examination of Russian educational practices, particularly their success in the training of scientists and technicians, has had a good effect.
EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Oct. 29 -- The vote-switching found a month ago in this rural western Wisconsin area is still going on, although the undecided vote appears to have narrowed significantly.
TERENCE REESE, who has been the most prolific writer on bridge for several years, has had another new book published in this country, his third within the year.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Thursday's reduction in the bank rate from 6 to 5 1/5 per cent had little effect on the stock market.
An elderly woman and a man were shot and seriously wounded last night on Third Avenue, between Thirty-first and Thirty-second Streets. Their assailant escaped.

A pool of qualified pilots for operation on the St. Lawrence Seaway has been organized at Cape Vincent, N.Y., and will be offered to the Secretary of Commerce for work between Cape Vincent and the Snell Lock, near Massena, N.Y.
THE directors of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts assumed two risks yesterday when they named Gen. Maxwell Davenport Taylor as the center's president.

FOR the first time in many years, Billy Steinkraus will not be able to compete in the jumping events at the National Horse Show, which opens tomorrow at Madison Square Garden. The captain of the United States equestrian team has yet to recover from a broken collarbone. He was thrown by a horse in Venice.

"IT'S a rough game. It's for the men, not the boys." This was a statement on television yesterday by Sam Huff, the middle linebacker of the defensive unit of the New York Giants professional football team.

Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Army Chief of Staff, has been elected president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, and John D. Rockefeller 3d is to become chairman of the center's board of directors. Both will take office early next year.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 30 -- The generals and some of the top civilians in the Ministry of Defense are feuding over a question that boils down to how much civilian control the generals will accept.

SINISTER rumors now circulating in the book trade predict that with the coming of the centennial of the outbreak of the Civil War next year the number of books about America's most deeply felt national experience will be doubled. Since too many Civil War books are published annually without any special inducement this is a prospect that cannot be regarded with equanimity.
The city's expense budget revenues for the fiscal year that ended June 30 exceeded expenditures by $2,380,943, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa reported yesterday.

Our next President is going to be under immediate pressure to take major foreign policy decisions. He will be urged from many quarters to participate in an early spring summit meeting. He must make a series of important diplomatic appointments.

Three floors in the twenty-four-story office building being constructed by the Durst Organization at 733 Third Avenue, southeast corner o Forty-sixth Street, have been leased by the Associated Metals and Minerals Corporation.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy's adamant stand against policemen holding a second job in private employ, the so-called "moonlighting," is well known but his reasons for it have been somewhat obscured in the controversy over detection and punishment of offenders. Believing that it would contribute to public understanding of this problem, we have assembled some of the Commissioner's remarks, in statements and press conferences.

The National Broadcasting Company has decided to try happiness where crime appears not to have paid. Early in January, it will drop "Dan Raven," a detective series, and substitute a happy hour -- two thirty-minute comedies, one entitled "Happy" and the other "One Happy Family."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 30 -- James Madden's fifty-seven-foot sloop Gesture from Manchester, Mass., today won the tenth annual 100-mile skipper invitation race over a record fleet of thirty-three yachts.

The eleven-story apartment building at 43 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Eleventh Street, has been sold for a price reported to have been almost $1,000,000. It is assessed for tax purposes at $450,000, including the cost of the land.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Deeply dissatisfied as I am with the discussion of foreign policy by Messrs. Nixon and Kennedy, I had about come to the conclusion that in this all-important field I was more against Nixon than against Kennedy.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Investigators examined the wreckage of a plane today in which nearly half the thirty-five members of a college football team were killed last night.

Week Ended Oct. 28, 1960 Foreign exchange market showed signs of nervousness at times during the past week. This was due to the wide specula- tion in gold and the reduction of the London bank rate to 5 1/2%. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar both finished strong after selling off in mid-week.
New York had a Sunday bomb scare last night. A small powder charge in a cardboard cylinder flashed up with a loud hiss in a telephone booth in the Times Square subway station.
PONCE, Puerto Rico, Oct. 30 -- The Bishop of Ponce denied today reports that some of Puerto Rico's political leaders might be excommunicated.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- The Soviet Union and Communist China will give "multiform aid" to the Algerian insurgents, Ferhat Abbas, head of the Algerian Provisional Government, said in an interview reported today in the Italian Communist newspaper L'Unita.
New York's Twenty-fourth Congressional District is the heartland of one of the nation's classic political machines -- the Bronx County Democratic organization.

New York elects a new Legislature every two years. The voters on Nov. 8 will tie choosing a Senate of fifty-eight members and an Assembly of 150 members. This means that there are nearly 500 candidates, Republican, Democratic or Liberal. While there are some able members sitting in Albany, for this important task of state lawmaking, the average quality is poor to mediocre, subject to vast improvement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States has signed a technical and economic aid agreement with Guinea, Leftleaning new republic in Africa.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Nine days to go. It has been an improbable election campaign. Whether Premier Khrushchev affected it as he stalked Manhattan Island for three and one-half weeks is uncertain.
A patrolman captured a burglary suspect in a back pew of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon after chasing him in and out of the church and firing at him on the street.

Everything was moving along nicely for the New York Rangers last night at Madison Square Garden until the third period. Then the roof fell in. Johnny Bower, a former Ranger, shut the door as the Toronto Maple Leafs whipped the Blues, 3 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game.
Ten rank-and-file members vowed yesterday to continue the battle to clean up the Teamsters Union despite a court ruling that, they said, had "destroyed" the monitor board set up for that purpose.
Members and friends of Christ Church, Methodist, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street heard their new organ in a recital yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Green Bay's Packers turned back the Pittsburgh Steelers, 19 -- 13, today on the field-goal kicking of Paul Hornung and a 66-yard touchdown drive in the closing minutes.
An inquiry by mail has resolved a mystery that for almost two years puzzled the inhabitants of Tristan da Cunha, perhaps the most isolated community in the world.
Conservative Protestant pastors in many parts of the country turned their pulpits into political stumps yesterday, cautioning their congregations riot to elect a Roman Catholic as President.

HAVANA, Oct. 30 -- An American can fly into Cuba with no more identification than his airplane ticket in this twenty-second month of Fidel Castro's reign. He can also go to a private Halloween party with United States diplomats and find himself under temporary arrest.

Five minutes before the end of his first entertainment show on television Danny Kaye gave the cue for "Minnie the Moodier." In seconds he had the studio audience going along with his linguistic gyrations, and the home screen came alive with the warmth and humor of a capital performer in full command of the stage.
Taxes probably are a necessary evil. But there are ways of reducing the evil to a relatively painless one through the blunt instrument of withholding.

RECIFE, Brazil, Oct. 22 -- The makings of a revolutionary situation are increasingly apparent across the vastness of the poverty-stricken and drought-plagued Brazilian Northeast. In the area 20,000,000 people live on average annual incomes of less than S100. Racked by chronic malnutrition and rampaging disease, they seldom live much beyond the age of thirty.
HAVANA, Oct. 30 -- Thousands of Cuban militiamen were concentrated at various points in this capital today following warnings to the people that an "invasion" by the United States was "imminent."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Following is the text of a statement issued here today by Senator John F. Kennedy outlining a program aimed at reversing the country's adverse balance of payments:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It has become overwhelmingly evident in the past fortnight that if Senator Kennedy is defeated for the Presidency it will be because he is a Catholic. Events have completely verified a prediction I made on March 4 of what would happen in a Presidential contest between Nixon and Kennedy.
Just when it appeared that Mutual fund salesmen were selling everything they possibly could, real estate moved in on the scene.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Cramming two touchdowns into the space of forty-seven seconds, the San Francisco Forty-Niners beat the Chicago Bears, 25 -- 7, in a National Football League game dedicated to the victors' late president, Tony Morabito.

Walter Cooper of the New York Athletic Club captured the six-mile Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union cross-country handicap run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. Four of the thirty-nine starters failed to finish.

Before giving the football to the St. Louis Cardinals on fumbles and interceptions yesterday, the New York Giants gave a silver football to their regular left tackle in observance of "Roosevelt Brown Day" at the Stadium.

AFTER weeks of waiting the television season appears to have its first new hit: "Family Classics." The initial show of the monthly series, "The Scarlet Pimpernel," was an exciting and richly mounted production with superb performances by Michael Rennie and Zachary Scott.

A new approach to the function of the United Nations is given by Lincoln P. Bloomfield in "The United Nations and U.S. Foreign Policy." The book, which Little, Brown will issue Nov. 16, evaluates the United Nations as an instrument for furthering United States national interests, gauging its effectiveness in the struggle to preserve the Western concept of freedom.

Six of the city's seven major daily newspapers, including The New York Times, offered their editorial, commercial and mainitenance employes an increase of $3 a week in wages and welfare benefits last night.
GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- Three Nuclear Age powers will mark a Nuclear Age anniversary tomorrow -- the start of the third year of talks to achieve a treaty reducing the dangers of nuclear weapons.
Two theatre parties have been planned for the benefit of the Goddard-Riverside Community Center.

Ch. Willets Red Jacket, a Pembroke Welsh Corgi belonging to Mrs. William B. Long of Carlisle, Mass., was named best in show last night in the thirty-ninth event of the Bronx County Kennel Club. The show drew 754 dogs to the Kings-bridge Armory.

HAVANA, Oct. 30 -- Roman Catholics in Cuba cannot "support the tendencies toward a materialistic communism and totalitarianism in the Cuban revolution, Msgr. Eduardo Boza Masvidal, Assistant Bishop of Havana, declared in an article distributed today.
The French Line, one of the major trans-Atlantic steamship operators, is "in good shape" according to Jean Marie, chairman of the board of the unsubsidized French company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The upward trend of the nation's money supply since midyear has been more persistent than earlier reports indicated.
The first American production of Bertolt Brecht's "In the Jungle of Cities" will join the repertory schedule of Off Broadway's The Living Theatre on Dec. 16.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The General Assembly begins its sixth week tomorrow with attention focused on Cuban charges that preparations for an invasion are being made in the United States.

The third week of the Metropolitan Opera season will open next Monday with a repeat performance of Bizet's "Carmen," in which Nikola Nikolov will make his American debut. The Bulgarian tenor will sing the part of Don Jose, and Lorenzo Testi will assume the role of Escamillo for the first time here.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly last week and closed generally lower.

The Planned Parenthood Federation of America reported yesterday that a group of Roman Catholic laymen who support their church's stand against artificial birth control has endorsed the right of non-Catholics to exercise "freedom of conscience" in regard to contraception.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson accused the Eisenhower Administration today of "drift, delay and dilution" in meeting the Soviet challenge in space.

TOKYO, Oct. 30 -- Japan's political campaigners took to the streets today following a formal announcement by the Government that national elections to the House of Representatives would be held Nov. 20.
Gabriella Tucci, Italian soprano, made her Metropolitan Opera debut Saturday night in the company's first performance of Puccini's "Madama Butter- fly" this season.

ONCE again the New York City Opera has demonstrated its rapidly developing strength in the presentation of the standard operatic repertory. This time it is Verdi's Rigoletto," given at the City Center last night, that deepens one's respect for the company.

The controversial issues of collective bargaining and voluntary dues check-off, which are major issues in the teachers strike called for next Monday, will not be considered by the Board of Education until the following week.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Senator John F. Kennedy pledged himself today to maintain the value of the dollar.

No country ever needed what the diplomats call "good offices" more than does the young Republic of the Congo. Yesterday was an unhappily typical day in this fall's Congolese life. The army was still not under firm control, even around Leopoldville. Tribal disturbances were continuing in Katanga and Kasai provinces. No Congo delegation has yet taken its seat at the United Nations, for nobody is sure who represents what or whom.

While waiting for their regular fourth-quarter pick-up yesterday, the New York Football Giants fell into a 3-point hole. It kept getting deeper, with the help of the St. Louis Cardinals, and time ran out before a rescue party could be organized.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 27 -- Bill Toth, a burly crane operator, jerked his thumb toward the chimneys that tower over the hushed blast furnaces at the huge Campbell Mill of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Before English actors arrive in Hollywood, they are informed, warned and advised about many things, ranging from gossip columnists to the evening damp. But, somehow, no one thinks to tell them about the pitfalls of shopping in grandiose supermarkets.
Only an overwhelming Democratic sweep by Senator John F. Kennedy for. President would be likely to upset the pattern of Republican victory in the Twenty-fifth Congressional District in the Bronx.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The music department of the Admiralty, working on a revised anthology of 200 national anthems the navy plays on visits abroad, came to a halt when it reached No. 107 -- "The Salutation and March to His Highness the Sultan of Muscat and Oman."

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 30 -- The next National Administration should give "top priority" to resolving of human relations problems as "its most powerful means" of retaining the nation's moral leadership in the world, top leaders of the American Jewish Committee declared here today.

Gerry Mulligan calls his new thirteen-piece group a "concert jazz band." His reason is that he will have no truck with dances -- this band is for listening only. The band made its first New York concert hall appearance at Hunter College Saturday night.
Saturday night's Composers Forum concert at the Donnell Library missed landing on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the series by only one day.
BOSTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Jimmy Bartlett scored two goals and set up a third tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 5-3, and vacated the National Hockey League cellar.

Foreign producers of textile fibers have problems very similar to those of their United States counterparts. This is as true in the field of man-made fibers as it is in cotton or wool, and there is reason, therefore, for Americans to join with foreign manufacturers to work out solutions.

ONLY Greek-speaking persons with an extremely indulgent sense of mirth should find much diversion in "Moussitsa," which opened Saturday at the Cameo. While the import can claim a very pretty blonde heroine, Aliki Vouyouklaki, it's still pretty awful.
TRENTON, Oct. 30 -- Hard-hitting Democratic organizations in Mercer, Burlington and Camden Counties predict a three-county plurality of at least 70,000 votes for the Kennedy-Johnson ticket.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Browns ran into unexpected trouble on the ground today, but mustered an aerial attack and beat the Washington Redskins, 31 -- 10.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 38 -- Vice President Nixon enters the final week of the Presidential campaign in a mood of quiet confidence that the tide for Senator John F. Kennedy has reached its high point and that his own has begun to run more strongly.

DALLAS, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Johnny Unitas passed for 270 yards and four touchdowns and set up another score today as the Baltimore Colts crushed the Dallas Cowboys, 45 -- 7, in a National Football League game.
LOVANIUM, the Congo, Oct. 30 -- A key educational institution in the Congo -- Lovanium University -- is opening a new academic year, thanks to American aid.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Alex Delvecchio, the leading goal-scorer for the Detroit Red Wings, produced the winning shot in the waning minutes tonight to give the home team a 2-1 National Hockey League victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

On Oct. 13, 1959, Explorer VII was launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla. The satellite weighed 91.5 pounds and to the uninitiated ear of a man unable to interpret its electronic signals, its radio transmitted a sound closely resembling the hee-haw of a donkey.

GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- The midweek pickup on New York's Big Board gave a lift to the Swiss stock markets that helped to offset their weak showing in the first days of trading last week. The result was that the prices of Swiss issues ended the week pretty much where they were at the preceding Friday's close.
Henry Cabot Lodge urged yesterday that the United States play a major role in the development of trade unionism abroad as a means of stemming the advance of communism.

PARIS THE English Channel, which has proved a formidable challenge to so many invading armies, in no way perturbs Parisian shoppers. They regularly make the pilgrimage to London for those accessories to gracious living for which the English are renowned.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 30 -- Three Ministers comprising the Left Wing of Premier David Ben-Gurion's six-party coalition Government angrily walked out of a Cabinet meeting in Jerusalem today.
The Commonwealth Fund plans to curtail its grants for medical research and increase its support for medical education and other community health activities.
The Transit Authority disclosed yesterday that it had maintained the 15-cent subway fare for the last five years by reducing its work force by 7,658 in that period.
Asked what Northern Ireland 5 noted for, a bright pupil light correctly reply "shipbuilding and linen."
HELEN VANNI'S Town Hall program last night was calculated to show off her musicality and versatility, and it did so very nicely.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: To say anything seemingly critical of Catholicism nowadays is to risk being charged with bigotry. This state of affairs should not exist in the land of the free, if by bigotry we mean the obstinate and blind attachment to a creed.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 30 -- A man identified only as "Captain Roberts" and described as a soldier of fortune was taken into custody today with three Belgians by the United Nations forces in the Congo.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- Alvin Dark, an infield star on pennant-winning Giant clubs in 1951 and 1954, was signed today to manage the San Francisco club for the next two seasons.
JERSEY CITY, Oct 31 -- It was Thorn Lord Day here in the Democratic bastion of Hudson County, and the party faithful jammed to capacity rally after rally to welcome their Senate candidate.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 31 -- The Post Office Department has found Representative Edwin B. Dooley guilty of having used the Congressional franking privilege improperly to mail campaign material to voters.
For the second consecutive month construction contracts throughout the country rose in September above those for the same period in 1959, according to a report by the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which charged a $67,000,000 write-off to its second-quarter operations this year to take care of losses on its Electra jets, restored its operations to a profitable basis in the third quarter.

Under a competent ride by Eddie Arcaro, John Burrow's Dirce moved up steadily and won the Rock Hill classified handicap race at Aqueduct yesterday. Six colts and geldings competed in the mile-and-a-sixteenth turf race and Dirce beat the favored Eurasia of the Greentree Stable by a head.

Gross revenues of the New York Stock Exchange fell to $15,613,180 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 from $15,900,422 for the 1959 period. The exchange's expenses climbed to $13,820,109 from $12,966,922 the year before; and net revenues fell to $820,871 from $1,402,900.

Democrats in New York's three big suburban counties are counting on Senator John F. Kennedy's popularity to bring them within shooting distance of ending the long Republican domination of their areas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Government suspended today the operating certificate of the supplemental airline whose chartered C-46 plane crashed at Toledo, Ohio, Saturday. Twenty-two of the fortyeight persons aboard were Killed, sixteen of them members of the California Polytechnic College football team.

ALGIERS, Oct. 31 -- The Algerian nationalist rebellion began six years ago tonight and French authorities braced for anticipated effort by the rebel National Liberation Front to make the anniversary a bloody one.

A facade of glass and textured masonry -- gistening quartz chips embedded in concrete -- will be used for the thirty-story Bankers Trust Building, which is to rise on the west blockfront of Park Avenue, between Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets.
Net income of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., in the fiscal year ended on July 31 rose to $28,367,102 from $27,131,333 a year earlier, Samuel Bronfman, president, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The stock market opened the new book-keeping account today on a firm but quiet note.

Anniversary for the Weather It may be difficult to believe that the familiar reports one gets on the weather by radio, television and newspaper would have been considered sacrilegious by ancient peoples.
Stock prices ended October down slightly. The market moved in a narrow range. Trading was the slowest for any month since August, 1959, and for any October since 1959.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The purchase of the Oliver Corporation's farm equipment business by the White Motor Company was approved today by stockholders of both concerns.

Mrs. Marshall Field is in charge of planning for the theatre benefit for the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York. It will be the Dec. 14 performance of "Advise and Consent" at the Cort Theatre.

Coach Vince Gargano thinks his team defeated Jefferson High last Saturday. Coach Moe Finkelstein is sure his team clobbered Lincoln High yesterday. And Prank Galloway, the head of the Public Schools Athletic League, will not know until Nov. 15 whose end zone he will be caught in -- if he is caught at all.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 -- India's largest opposition party appeared to be in critical difficulty today after the resignation of its principal Parliamentary spokesman.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- Sentiment for Senator John F. Kennedy appears to have solidified in the Tenth Congressional District of his native state.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- A Government spokesman indicated today that the major military secrets of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces were not known to the Bundestag Deputy arrested last Friday as a spy for Communist Czechoslovakia.

Abraham Lincoln an his legend are appraised by seventy-two Americans in a volume titled "Lincoln for the Ages." It aims to give an "interpretation of the man," an explanation of his hold on the minds of people and an understanding of why Lincoln "lives for the ages."
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 31 -- A debate on the "Lavon affair" was cut off abruptly in the Israeli Parliament today.
Charges of bias against the State University College of Education were declared unfounded yesterday by the State Commission Against Discrimination.
YASSIADA, Turkey, Oct. 31 -- A former mistress of Adnan Menderes exonerated the ousted Turkish Premier today of any guilt in the death of a new-born son she bore him.

WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 28 -- Hope that Senator John Kennedy would pep up this state's listless economy appears to be triumphing over worries about his Roman Catholic religion among voters in West Virginia's see-saw First Congressional District.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- For the first time since the beginning of the Reformation, in the sixteenth century, an Archbishop of Canterbury will meet with a Pope.
Army's coaching staff made known yesterday its disappointment at the way the cadet football team played against Miami of Ohio last Saturday.
Just one week from today about 66,000,000 persons will go to the polls, and about half of them will use machines -- accurate, secretive and fast -- to register their judgments.

THE era began with the patrician pose in the ascendant. It ended with sedulously acquired proletarianism rampant. In the interval -- 1914 to 1936 -- there bloomed in this country a magazine of the arts now memorialized by Cleveland Amory and Frederic Bradlee in a rich, welcome anthology called "Vanity Fair: A Cavalcade of the Nineteen Twenties and Nineteen Thirties."*
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
One of the hottest issues in the transportation world -- how far an airline, railroad, trucking operator or a water carrier can reduce its regulated freight rates -- has become a hotter one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- On two things Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy are fully agreed -- that foreign policy is the paramount issue in the Presidential campaign and that leadership is the first essential in foreign policy.
TOKYO, Oct. 31 -- The twelfth Colombo Plan conference opened today, with the growth of populations in Asia's less developed countries its principal topic.
Steel production this week is scheduled to decline to its lowest level for a non-holiday week since the start of the present industry downturn.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday he had heard a report that policemen might absent themselves in large numbers on Election Day. He asserted he would ask for troops, if necessary, to assure orderly voting.

Mike McCormick of the San Francisco Giants and Frank Baumann of the Chicago White Sox topped the major league earned-run ratings in 1960, final averages showed yesterday. Both pitchers are left-handers.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 31. -- The United Nations command here warned today that it "cannot be a party to any internal disputes." It declared again that it was operating only under the mandate of the Security Council.

BUFF DONELLI watched the opening kick-off from in front of the Columbia bench and then hurried upstairs to the press box for a long-range look at the Lions in their game with Cornell last Saturday. Like all other coaches, the Buffer had always stayed on the field and made his strategic decisions from down below.

COUNTESS MARIA ASSUNTA ZOLTOWSKA refutes every rule set down as to what a tiny woman should wear. This Hungarian-French designer of some of today's most imaginative jewelry is one and a half meters tall (four feet, nine inches) and weighs seventy-two pounds.

ONE of the most endearing dresses that a little girl might wear for any occasion in any climate is on the third floor children's department of De Pinna. In size 1 to 5, the dress is made of white pique and stitched across the bodice, under a small, round collar, are the words, "things i own myself" in red and blue.
TOWNSHIP 24, Me., Oct. 31 -- The deer around these blueberry barrens are still running in herds, late as it is in the year, but Dan Hartford says there is still too much air around them.

YESTERDAY (Oct. 31, 1960) GENERAL, ASSEMBLY Approved a report of the Special Political Committee on the South Tyrol urging Austria and Italy to resume negotiations; approved putting the question of Oman on the agenda and allocating it to the Special Political Committee; approved putting a Cuban complaint against the United States on the agenda and began debate on allocation of the item.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- Two keynote speakers, a psychologlst and a sanitary engineer, took a hard look at contemporary American society at the opening here today of the eighty-eighth annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

There is only one Senatorial contest this year in the tri-state region of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. That is the gentlemanly campaign being waged in New Jersey by the Republican incumbent, Clifford P. Case of Rahway and the Democratic contender, Thorn Lord of Princeton. Both are extremely high-type candidates; and the voters of New Jersey are in the fortunate position of knowing that, whoever wins, the state will be well represented.

NORTH HILLS, L.I., Oct. 31 -- Pat Stanley of Island Hills and Bill Remsen of Clearview combined for a 34, 35 -- 69, three strokes under par, to win the annual Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro - pro tournament at the Links Club today.
Man has learned a lesson from the birds and now he can work barehanded on extra-high-voltage wires.
Alvin Dark, the Giants' new manager, starred in football at Louisiana State University before signing a bonus contract with the Boston Braves in 1946.
The air is full of exhilaration in Manhattan's Seventeenth Congressional District, where the haut monde enjoys a wide majority over hoi polloi.
Coach Alf Pike of the New York Rangers, seeking "more scoring punch,"' made two line changes yesterday in an attempt to "get the team moving."

The city is not likely to act soon to carry out plans for a Lower Manhattan Expressway beyond the steps already taken, Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday. He regretted, he said, that he could not give an "exact timetable" for the project's construction.

YONKERS, Oct. 31 -- Mick d'Angerieux, France's winner in the first half of the world trotting championship for 4-year-olds at one and a half miles last week, today drew post position No. 6 and was made the 9-5 favorite in the morning line for the second half of the event.
A former Guatemalan Ambassador and six other men were indicted yesterday as members of an international ring that has smuggled millions of dollars worth of heroin into this country since 1952.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your persuasive editorial in support of Senator Kennedy was a highly important addition to the rapidly growing power behind his candidacy.

A LITTLE more than a year ago a slender girl clad in a sweater and blue jeans and wearing her lustrous black hair down to her shoulders, sometimes spent evenings after classes at L'Ecole Speciale d'Architecture, dancing and talking in Left Bank Parisian cafes.
The marketing spotlight the early part of this week is on packaging and what it can and cannot do to help keep goods moving along to the consumer.
Public offerings of new securities in October fell sharply from the 1959 level.

All rubber futures positions fell to new lows for the lives of the contracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Futures declined 30 to 49 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,790 tons.
Heretofore, Jack Cole has been connected with various shows as a choreographer. In "Donnybrook!" he will step forth in the capacity of director-choreographer.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Canada has decided to propose the establishment of a committee composed exclusively of small and medium-size nations to help solve the disarmament deadlock.
Stuyvesant and Flushing played to a 14-14 deadlock yesterday at Memorial Field. Flushing, Queens, in a Public Schools Athletic League game.

The same old black soil, used over and over again, was trucked into Madison Square Garden for the same old event yesterday. The event was the National Horse Show, held the first time seventy-seven years ago.

OLDER persons in every economic bracket dread the possibility of financial dependence on their grown children and consequent second-class status in the home, according to a specialist on problems of the aging.
The Chinese Communist party appears to have made a partial but significant retreat in its ideological dispute with the Soviet Communist party.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- The Soviet Union warned today that until Communist China was admitted to membership in the United Nations, Moscow would oppose any move to increase membership in the Security Council or the Economic and Social Council.

The Iowa Hawkeyes retained their position as the nation's top. major college football team yesterday by accumulating the highest number of points in the weekly United Press International ratings since 1953.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 31 -- Queen Farah Diba gave birth to an heir to the Iranian throne today. The son was the first for Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and there was wild rejoicing throughout Iran.

NICE, France, Oct. 31 -- Immediately after Alfonse Halimi of France beat the British Empire champion, Freddie Gilroy, for the bantamweight championship of the world (European version) at London last week, a television announcer leaped with his microphone into Halimi's corner.
WASHINGTON, Oct 31 -- Reports from two Federal agencies today accentuated two aspects of the United States balance of international payments situation.
The aggregate of bonds called for redemption in October before maturity, although less than in September, was the heaviest for an October since 1955.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Eisenhower has asked Chancellor Adenauer for the cooperation of West Germany in solving the United States' problem of a continued deficit in its balance of international payments.
Dr. John J. Meng, who was installed yesterday as the sixth president of Hunter College, called for a return to the teaching of absolute values and norms of human conduct.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Miss Mildred Paperman, secretary of Bernard Goldfine, pleaded guilty today to a Federal indictment charging her with income tax evasion.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Sewell Avery, former president and chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., died of a cerebral hemorrhage this afternoon in his home here. He was 86 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Treasury's shortest-term borrowing costs held virtually steady this week. The average discount rate on today's regular weekly sale of ninety-one day bills was 2.127 per cent, compared with 2.129 per cent on last Monday's issue which was a twenty-six month low.

HONG KONG, Oct. 31 -- The Chinese Communist press printed today an authoritative article declaring that revolution "cannot be imported or exported" and that no Marxist-Leninist party favors the spread of revolution by Socialist countries through war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed today to re-examine an application of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad for a Government guarantee of a $6,000,000 loan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Eisenhower decided today to speak in Pittsburgh and Cleveland on Friday in the hope of swinging Pennsylvania and Ohio behind the Nixon-Lodge ticket.

The soil in which anti-American revolutionary movements can grow in this hemisphere is described in two articles by our correspondent Tad Szulc from Brazil, the second of which appears today. Mr. Szulc found appalling conditions in the Brazilian northeast -- the great bulge which brings South America closest to Africa.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points off to 10 up. A point is 5 cents a bale.
A SECOND play about the terrible events in the Warsaw ghetto almost two decades ago reached New York last night. It was Kenneth Green's "Behind the Wall," which opened at the Jan Hus Playhouse.

Six of the city's seven major daily newspapers reached an agreement on a two-year contract early this morning with the New York Newspaper Guild. The accord came almost two hours after a scheduled strike deadline had been passed.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Oct. 31 -- Luis Ferre, the Republican Statehood party's candidate for Governor, said today that he thought the current controversy over church intervention in the political campaign "will be a good thing in the end."
SOME of the best opportunities for good play occur when the contract is low and seemingly inconsequential. Today's deal, played in a rubber bridge game in New York Sunday night, is an example.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP) -- American auto makers have built about 704,000 more cars so far this year than last year. Production thus far in 1960 totals 5,550,033 cars, against 4,846,024 last year.
Two native Virginians have been elected to head the Duke Endowment, the trustees announced yesterday.
Policing an election in New York City is a job that puts all 23,500 members of the force to work.

MALCOLM FRAGER is a pianist with nerve and confidence. Only such a combination could have accounted for his activity last May. The previous year he had come out first in the 1959 Leventritt Competition.

A Baltimore savings and loan association that is accused of using the name of a Negro bishop to persuade Negroes to invest in its stock has been temporarily enjoined from further sale of its stock in this state.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- A jockey, two stablehands and a druggist's assistant were found guilty at a criminal court in Gloucester today of conspiring to drug race horses.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- It is doubtful that even a few thousand -- possibly not even a few hundred -- of the millions of Americans who will turn to Channel 4 tomorrow night for "Alfred Hitchcock Presents," will know five minutes after the closing credits has passed, what Joan Harrison had to do with the show.

Only routine reports and processing yesterday held up the delivery of a million-dollar insurance check to the owners of Bally Ache, the 1960 Freakness winner, who died Saturday from an intestinal disorder.

MIAMI, Oct. 31 -- The issue of psychological compulsion was ruled out by Circuit Judge A. Fritz Gordon in the lawsuit testing the constitutionality of Bible reading and other religious practices in Dade County public schools.
George V. Bonhag, a onetime Olympic runner and walker, died of a heart attack Sunday in his home at 2824. University Avenue, the Bronx, at the age of 79. He was a retired civil engineer.
Bond prices fluctuated narrowly yesterday in an inactive trading session. High-grade corporate and local government bonds were firm, but United States Government securities moved irregularly.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 31 -- Senator John F. Kennedy called on Americans tonight to tell the world in the election on Nov. 8 that "this country is going to start moving again." The Democratic candidate made the plea on a nation-wide television address that wound up three days of campaigning in the Philadelphia area.
Billy Hunter, a Detroit heavyweight, spoiled the American debut of Ray Lopez last night when he knocked out the Cuban champion in the sixth round of their ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- If it were to be assumed that the large number of citizens who refuse to tell their voting intentions to the sample pollsters are still uncommitted, then it could be prophesied that this year's Presidential contest is to be one of the few in history which apparently were decided by events, even of relatively minor importance, in the final week of the campaign, thus violating Parley's Law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Defense Department, in a reversal of Administration policy, ordered today a major expansion in developmental work on the B-70 supersonic bomber. The department said that the Air Force had been authorized to proceed with a "substantially augmented development program" on the B-70, including construction of two prototype bombers.

After an early sinking spell, stocks rallied yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and managed to squeeze out a small net gain on the average. Volume was moderate and there was no particular impetus to either downward or upward movements.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With all of that impetuous enthusiasm with which the beautiful daughter of a heavily mortgaged farmer, accepts the hand of an ugly, elderly banker who holds the notes, The New York Times has editorially announced its support of John F. Kennedy for President.

THIS morning one of Manhattan's oldest custom butchering establishments has opened at a new address. It is A. Tingaud Sons, which has moved from its premises on the Avenue of the Americas to 1070 Second Avenue (between Fiftysixth and Fifty-seventh Streets).
Paul G. Hoffman, managing director of the United Nations Special Fund, called yesterday for a "grander strategy and greater vigor in the war against want" around the world.
Following is the text of Senator Kennedy's address last night at Convention Hall in Philadelphia, as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The nation's three leading news magazines today published surveys giving Senator John F. Kennedy a substantial edge over Vice President Nixon in the Presidential race.
TUNIS, Oct. 31 -- Ferhat Abbas, Algerian nationalist leader, said here tonight that the French Government had "put an end, once and for all, to a negotiated solution of the Algerian conflict."

NEWARK, Oct. 31 -- Vice President Nixon struck back tonight at Senator John F. Kennedy for what he called his rival's "juvenile school-boy comments" in saying that Mr. Nixon might accept a fifth television debate if he could have the active participation of President Eisenhower.

ATLANTA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver criticized John F. Kennedy today for telephoning the wife of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. while the Negro integration leader was in jail last week.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Fair demand and an absence of selling accounted for steady to firmer grain futures markets today.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson declared here tonight that Vice President Nixon had "pushed the panic button" and was "sweating through his make-up."

GALILEIA, Brazil, Oct. 24 -- "We fight for the happiness of all of the 40,000,000 Brazilian peasants and until it comes we shall fight beside you and you must help us," the thin, hollow-cheeked man said.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A trip with Vice President Nixon in the final days of the campaign is a study in the science of gloom prevention.
Governor Rockefeller was served with a subpoena yesterday while preparing to speak to a street crowd.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Cuba accused Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy today of having discussed Cuba as if she were a "piece of real estate belonging to the United States."
A floating drydock that is to cost more than $5,000,000 is being built by the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa.
Eugene O'Neill's "The Iceman Cometh" will be presented by "The Play of the Week" in two two-hour installments over station WNTA-TV (Channel 13) later this month.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- The Soviet Union charged today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was obscuring a "deteriorating" situation in the Congo by restricting official information.
New debt securities of the United Gas Corporation totaling $60,000,000 will be offered for public subscription today by investment banking syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
The General Motors Corporation will back its belief in continued prosperity with a record outlay of $1,250,000,000 in 1961 for plant, machinery, equipment and tooling.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Henry Cabot Lodge downgraded public-opinion polls today as he campaigned by train and motorcade through northern New Jersey.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- The rebirth of the Jewish communities of Europe was marked here today when their leaders met in special session with representatives of the American Joint Distribution Committee.

National Audubon Society members were warned yesterday of a sharp decline in the country's wildlife refuges, a dwindling number of bald eagles -- America's national symbol -- and increasing pollution of waterways from agricultural pesticides.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Investors Mutual, Inc., the nation's largest mutual fund, reported today gains in assets and stockholders for the year ended on Sept 30.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Two men were chatting in front of a bank in Greenwich the other noon. One was wearing a Nixon-Lodge lapel button; the other had none.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he fully supported School Superintendent John J. Theobald's handling of the current controversy over a possible teachers' strike.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Los Angeles' four metropolitan daily newspapers will increase their subscription rates tomorrow.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 31 -- The Republican "truth squad" treated the Midwest today to a political show worthy of old-time vaudeville.

No one has bothered to bake a cake for the occasion, but it would be a shame to let the 120th anniversary of bowling in this country pass without at least a tip o' the hat. The first recorded match took place at the Knickerbocker Alleys here on Jan. 1, 1840, although there was lawn, bowling on the green in New York's earliest days and Washington Irving alluded to pin bowling as early as 1818.
Wally Moses, who for sixteen seasons strummed the short outfield with banjo hits, became the batting coach of the New York Yankees yesterday.
ACCORDING to Abe Weatherwise in the Old Farmer's Almanac (out today), 1961 will be "on the whole, a good year for almost any enterprise."

WASHINGTON, Oct. (UPI) -- George M. Humph President Eisenhower's for Secretary of the Treasury, today a trip abroad had con- vinced him that Western Europe never had appreciated the United States more than it does now.

ALBANY, Ga., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Georgia's Democratic Chairman, James H. Gray, said today he would refuse to meet the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a national television debate because Dr. King had "openly defied Georgia laws."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Political Action Fund of the United Steel Workers of America reported today contributions of $13,500 to campaign committees for Senator John F. Kennedy and $97,000 in behalf of 107 Democratic Congressional candidates.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- The United States warned the Soviet Union today that time was running out on the moratorium on nuclear testing.
DALLAS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Dave Smith, the Houston Oiler fullback, led in American Football League rushing for the eighth straight week today.

The climactic Republican bid for New York's forty-five electoral votes will bring President Eisenhower, Vice President Nixon, Henry Cabot Lodge and Governor Rockefeller together tomorrow for a full day of campaigning in the metropolitan area.
LIKE the mountain going to Mohammed, an appliance manufacturer finally has geared his 1961 models to women, instead of trying to train the women to adapt to the machines.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 -- The Grand Prix of the United States, to be run over the 3.27-mile Riverside, Calif., course on Nov. 20, has several highly significant aspects.

A motor hotel, the first in the City Island section of the Bronx, is planned at the southeast corner of City Island Avenue and Reville Place, where the Directors Realty Corporation, the builder, has bought a plot of vacant land.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Government took action today aimed at turning the country's oil industry over to state companies, or to contractors nominated by the Government.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers have offered Casey Stengel the job of managing the club, but the ex-New York Yankee pilot told them he would make no decision for two or three weeks.

WHAT we have forgotten in the meantime is how much hung on the issue. The future of the world was in the charge of a few hundred high-spirited young men. Like the Battle of Waterloo, it was a very close thing."

HOW durable and stageworthy is Oliver Goldsmith's "She Stoops to Conquer"! In the Phoenix Theatre's revival, which opened last night, it plays as genially as a broad comedy tailored to contemporary tastes.

MIAMI, Nov. 1 -- Religious observances in Dade County public schools are "educational" activities and not religious ceremonies, four educators contended in Circuit Court here today.

THE paintings, drawings, water-colors and etchings in the big Whistler exhibition opening today at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, are hung chronologically, and in passing from the front door to the back room you may feel that the artist is vanishing before your eyes.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will prepare a onehour television report on Quenioy and Matsu, the Chinese offshore islands that have become an issue in the Presidential campaign.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- In one of its strongest of several active sessions recently, the grain futures market moved well ahead on nearly all contracts today.

An investment banking group managed jointly by the First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won the competitive bidding yesterday for $60,000,000 of Pacific Gas and Electric Company mortgage bonds, due in 1992.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The Administration's program in the development of defense weapons was lauded here tonight by Senator Clifford P. Case at a rally in the auditorium of the Peddie School.
Cook County, Ill., borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of express highways.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Two early craft shops, lost to this community in 1946 and reproduced in a museum in Delaware, will be the objects of a pilgrimage this week-end by a group of East Hampton residents.

The exodus of gold from the United States has become an issue in our elections, if somewhat gingerly handled ,by both candidates But it has not become an issue in the cold war. That fact, after all is of primary concern to the nation.

EACH season some of California's key designers, usually tanned and relaxed, breeze into town just to show their designs. Yesterday two of the youngest and most creative, Gustav Tassell and Paul Whitney helped brighten a gray wet day on Seventh Avenue.
Seven boys, one of them 12 years old and the others 14 and 15, were arrested yesterday after a homemade bomb exploded outside a grocery store in West Brighton, S. I.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The total value of business inventories declined again in September, but there is reason to believe that it was a decline in value rather than in the physical volume of inventoried goods.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Vice President Nixon charged today that his Democratic Presidential rival was spreading "vicious" rumors that those who voted for Mr. Nixon would lose Social Security benefits. He used the phrase "bare-faced lie' in the charge.
The teachers' strike threatened for next Monday was condemned yesterday by the Teachers Union.
TWO composers occupied the attention of Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall -- Mozart and Mahler.

Al Wittine of St. Francis Prep easily won the Brooklyn-Rockville Centre division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association sectional cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.
The Long Island Rail Road operated in September at a net loss of $522,354. In the 1959 month, it cleared $64,847.
Thirteen women were trapped for an hour and a half in a stalled automatic elevator yesterday near the eighth floor of a fourteen-story office building.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The Republican and Democratic National Committees have each spent about $2,500,000*during the campaign.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain led the urbeaten Philadelphia Warriors to a 131-113 victory over Cincinnati tonight in the National Basketball Association.

The recent flareup in the price of gold in London could have been avoided if the United States Treasury had been willing to make a limited offering of gold there, according to the First National City Bank of New York.
Major investment rating agencies welcomed yesterday the pending first public borrowing of the Tennsesee Valley Authority by awarding to the new bonds their highest rating.

ENGLISH cooking does not have the best of names in this country yet its very stick-to-the-ribs quality is ideal for winter days. Many dishes of that nationality provide plenty of fuel to combat penetrating cold.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Eisenhower is now engaged in the greatest rescue operation since Bill Mazeroski of the Pittsburgh Pirates hit that ninth inning homer in the seventh game of the world series.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Eisenhower and his Secretary of the Treasury emphasized money issues tonight in a half-hour political telecast.

A SKETCHING class for adults and children 10 years old and older meets Saturday afternoons at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. When weather permits, the class will be held in Central Park.
A Government purvey of world opinion dated Aug. 29 shows a decline in United States standing relative to the Soviet Union. This is the report that the White House has refused to release.

NEWARK, Nov. 1 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission inquiry on the application of the Lehigh Valley Railroad to abandon all passenger service heard protests today from a dozen witnesses, most from the Bethlehem-Allentown area.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Post Office Department began speed mail today, an electronic process by which it can deliver first-class mail across the country in seconds.

TUNIS, Nov. 1 -- More than 30,000 Tunisians at a mass rally shouted "Down with America!" and "Down with NATO!" tonight in response to an anti-Western speech by an official of the Algerian rebel regime.
In a drive for greater influence and recognition, the city's Puerto Rican and Spanishspeaking community has built up a record strength of 230,000 registered voters.
CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Thorn Lord called today for a long-range Federal program to develop atomic power and space techniques.
Kramer Bros., Freight Lines, Inc., of Detroit, has purchased a new truck terminal being built to its specifications on Talmadge Road, Edison Township, N.J.

The first stages of a multi-million-dollar textile yarn manufacturing plant has been placed in operation in Aiken, S.C., by the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation. When completed, it is expected to be the largest and most modern synthetic fiber plant in the nation.

The city is "looking very seriously" at the proposal that it join with the state to enable the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts to participate in the New York World's Fair 1964-65, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.
Henry Cabot Lodge received a rousing reception last night from a crowd of 3,500 persons that jammed the St. George Hotel in Democratic Brooklyn.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, Nov. 1 -- All commercial and administrative activity ceased here today and throughout the country in commemoration of the sixth anniversary of the Algerian nationalist rebellion.

The war in Algeria, which began with rebel raids on Nov. 1, 1954, enters its seventh year amid rising international tensions, mounting discord in France itself and growing involvement of the Communist bloc seeking to make this unhappy land a pawn in the cold war.
General Motors will have a seven-acre exhibit at the 1964-65 World's Fair in Flushing Meadow Park that will "rival its fabulous Futurama" there twenty years ago.

MANY of the "castles," "chateaux" and other dwellings inspired by the Old World and built here in the earlier, extravagant Nineteen Hundreds have disappeared. Their Renaissance ceilings and their period paneling were either taken down or destroyed, their antique furnishings scattered.
ROME, Oct. 30 -- The provincial and municipal elections that are to be held Nov. 6 and Nov. 7 have produced the most popular television program in Italy.

OTTAWA, Nov. 1 -- The defeat of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Conservative party in three of four by-elections yesterday in Quebec and Ontario was interpreted on all sides today as further evidence that the party in power is slipping.

Following is a portion of the text of a report by the United States Information Agency, dated Aug. 29, 1960, as obtained by The New York Times. This is the report, classified as "secret," that the White House declined to make public when requested, to do so by the Democrats.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The Port of New York Authority today filed in Superior Court a reply and counterclaim to a complaint by the Borough of Moonachie. The Borough is seeking to collect taxes on an industrial building the agency constructed on Teterboro airport land.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- The Soviet Union's "Ballad of a Soldier" was selected by the judges today as the best motion picture shown during San Francisco's fourth International Film Festival.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission relieved some of the financial woes of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States would take "whatever steps may be appropriate" to defend its naval base at Guantanamo, Cuba.
Penn Fruit Co. The Penn Fruit Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had purchased Schreiber Bros., Inc., a Baltimore supermarket chain, for an undisclosed amount of cash.
Plans for eight middle-income housing projects in four boroughs were announced yesterday by State Housing Commissioner James W. Gaynor.
WEST could not quite believe what happened to him in today's deal.

Stocks advanced smartly yesterday. It was the second straight rise and one of the market's best showings in some time. The advance was general and encompassed most major groups, though issues involved in military activities had the best strength.
Are Roman Catholic voters flocking to the banner of Senator John F. Kennedy, the Democratic Presidential candidate ?
Republicans worked feverishly yesterday to insure that Vice President Nixon's final campaign visit to New York today would be a smashing success.
Jack T. Blume, president and chief executive officer of Trans-United Industries, Inc., for less than a month, resigned yesterday.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for a main dish that is easy to prepare.

Despite the loss of a selling day last month, sales of eight major New York department stores advanced 0.5 per cent above those of October, 1959, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

YASSIADA, Turkey, Nov. 1 -- Twelve witnesses built up a strong defense today against prosecution charges that former Premier Adnan Menderes had "encouraged"' the killing of a son newly born to his onetime mistress, Ayhan Aydan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Government moved today to speed development of a nuclearpowered rocket.

Vice President Nixon strongly opposes the merger of the four armed services into one service. He is against the replacement of the Joint Chiefs of Staff by a single Chief of Staff or any other immediate major reorganization of the services.

WASHINGTON Nov. 1 (AP) -- A special investigative unit today cleared in effect present employes of the Food and Drug Administration of charges that some had engaged in private activities in conflict their official duties.

United States Government obligations sold off in light trading yesterday. The price declines extended to as much at 14/32 among long-term 2 1/2 per cent bonds issued during the war. Intermediate-term obligations generally fell 2/32 to 4/32.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Ben Schwartzwalder today sent his battered Syracuse University eleven through a long offensive and defensive drill that ended under the lights in Archbold Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The president of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. told a meeting of fellow Protestant clergymen tonight that enlightened discussion of the religious issue in the Presidential campaign "is a healthy thing."

The January potato futures contract climbed to a new high for the life of the contract and the March future equaled the old high on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Trading reflected stronger cash markets throughout the country and improved demand for potatoes.
The McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will benefit from a luncheon and bridge party to be held in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 10.
