WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Along with Nixon-Lodge buttons, Republican headquarters began handing out copies of a literary attack on Senator John F. Kennedy and his family today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The chairman of a House investigating panel recommended today that the 130-member administrative staff of the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., be reorganized. The institution trains officers for the merchant marine.

In the world of intercollegiate football, Great Scott is the nickname of a Princeton tailback Hugh (Great) Scott. When rivals of the Tigers say "Great Scott," it generally denotes consternation. Scott and his alternate, Jack (Silky) Sullivan, are the two men most responsible for Princeton's first-place tie with Yale in the Ivy League standings.
The directors of the American Machine and Foundry Company increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock by 7 1/2 cents a share yesterday.
A theatre party at the Dec. 16 evening performance of Meredith Willson's new musical, "The Unsinkable Molly 'Brown," at the Winter Garden Theatre will benefit the Hamilton-Madison House.
Traffic sumonses here on Monday increased by 84 per cent over the comparable day a year ago, making it the sixth successive day of a stepped-up ticketing drive by the city's patrolmen.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 -- Los Angeles gave Senator John F. Kennedy a blizzard-like reception of ticker tape and confetti today. Observers said the reception exceeded that given three weeks ago to Vice President Nixon.
A fall-out shelter with wall-to-wall carpeting, television and Scrabble went on display yesterday at the New York City Civil Defense Headquarters, at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In connection with your editorial of Oct. 29 "Coping With the Congo" I would like to bring the following facts to your readers' attention:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee accused Senator John F. Kennedy today of deception in a television film on medical care for the aged.
Following are estimates of 1960 Puerto Rican-Hispanic voter registration in New York City as compiled by the committee on nationalities and intergroup relations of the Democratic State Committee:

YESTERDAY (Nov. 1, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Adopted Steering Committee's recommendation to discuss in Political Committee Cuban complaint charging the United States with aggressive acts after rejecting motion to discuss item in the full Assembly.
Dr. Edward V. Sittler petitioned yesterday for restoration of his American citizenship. A Federal judge reserved decision.
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday a capital budget of $645,391,672 for 1961. In doing so, it warned that New York was facing "an acute financing dilemma."

HOWARD CHARLES GREEN, the Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, is a tall, angular bespectacled man who keeps out of the limelight. A wry smile softens the over-all impression he gives of austerity and severity.

Independent film-makers seeking freedom from major-studio commercial restrictions could solve most of their problems by adopting the Broadway system of financing through private investment, according to one New York authority, producer George Justin.
MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- The Soviet Union reported tonight the arrest of a man described as a spy for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

Back in 1955, the Comedie Francaise made its first visit to the United States during its 275th anniversary year. The reception here, to put it mildly, was a happy one. The famous Gallic company, also known in France as the House of Moliere, will pay a second visit to this country Feb. 21.

THE National Design Center seems destined to be a joy forever. It was established two years ago as an exhibit hall for the furnishings that families can buy only through decorators and thus, unless they have retained the services of a decorator, rarely see.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that the equal time regulations did not apply to President Eisenhower's talk Oct. 28 in San Francisco during what the White House called a nonpolitical trip.

In this space yesterday, we offered our recommendations for the Congressional contests in central and northern New Jersey. Today we continue with the New York suburban areas of Fairfield (Conn.), Suffolk and Nassau Counties, and, in the city proper, Queens and Kings. Tomorrow we will complete the list with endorsements in Richmond, Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 1 -- Chancellor Adenauer will try to persuade France to abandon her plans for an Independent nuclear force in favor of making the North Atlantic Treaty Organization the world's fourth nuclear power, informed sources reported today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Attorneys for Montgomery's Police Commissioner sought today to show that some persons who read a dispute advertisement in The New York Times had connected it with him.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Mrs Clare B. Williams, head of the women's division of the Republican National Committee, said today that Lyndon B. Johnson might be defeated for the Senate.

Following is a table showing how residents of many foreign countries see the comparative strength of the United States and the Soviet Union twenty-five years hence, as compiled by the United States Information Office in a report dated Aug. 29, I960:
EXQUISITE is the word that springs to mind to describe much Japanese art. It is also the word for the NHK Symphony, which played last night at Hunter College.

After gaining a victory over Yugoslavia, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, yesterday in an adjourned fourth-round match, the United States met the powerful Soviet Union quartet in the fifth round of the chess Olympics, at Leipzig, according to a report from East Germany.

Lieut. John P. Daly of Ireland and a mount named Loch Garman impressed at the start of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday by taking a first place in the evening after a third place at the matinee.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Twenty-four Unitarian and Universalist clergymen said in a statement today that "the assertion that no Roman Catholic should be President of the United States, irrespective of his record and views, is an affront to all true Americans and to the Constitution."

MONTREAL, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens, paced by Dickie Moore and Bernie Geoffrion, again dominated the National Hockey League scoring race this week, placing five players among the circuit's top ten point-makers.
Old-crop cotton futures rose 5 to 22 points (25 cents to $1.10 a bale) yesterday, with July making the greatest advance. The other positions were unchanged on the New York Cotton Exchange.
VIENNA, Me., Nov. 1 -- Maine's southern zone deer season opened today and it was perfect for testing rain gear, which was duly tested.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (AP) -- An optimistic Hank Greenberg settled down for a quick visit today as a committee of one to establish an American League baseball club in Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower created today a commission to study a long-standing dispute between the country's railroads and about 200,000 workers who run the trains. The dispute is over work rules and practices.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Nigeria, the most populous and newest African member of the United Nations, warned today that the Asian-African bloc was determined to win greater representation for both Africa and Asia in key United Nations agencies.

PINE BEACH, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Admiral Farragut Academy's varsity football squad is one of extremes this season. Its backfield is unusually light, averaging 151 pounds. Its line is a whopper, hitting 209 pounds.
LONDON, Nov 1 -- The robin has won an informal poll of Britons asked to name their choice as a national bird.
Automobile production in the nation climbed last month sharply above the September level and was also higher than that for October, 1959.

Two hundred men worked around the clock last night to convert the main exhibition floors of the Coliseum into an auditorium for the Republican party rally there tonight and the Democratic meeting on Saturday night.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Two countries laid new disarmament plans before the General Assembly's Political Committee today.
Plans for city construction projects that will interfere with street traffic will be circulated among city departments before the work begins, it was decided yesterday.
BUFFALO, Nov. 1 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, assailed Vice President Nixon today as a "dangerous" candidate for President because "he ignores our troubles by claiming they do not exist."

C. Wright Mills, Professor of Sociology at Columbia University and author of "White Collar" and "The Power Elite," will have a new book published on Nov. 28 by McGraw-Hill, called "Listen, Yankee -- The Revolution in Cuba."

IF Alvin Dark can transmit his own qualities to the San Francisco Giants, they will make a runaway of the National League pennant race next season. Few big leaguers can match him for character and class. But nobility of nature and purpose is no guarantee of managerial success. Infact a contemptuous Leo Durocher once consigned all nice guys to last place.

Iowa, which retained its rating as the No. 1 college football team in the nation yesterday, will be challenged Saturday at Minneapolis when it meets a Big Ten rival, Minnesota, which was ranked third in the weekly Associated Press poll of forty-eight sports writers and broadcasters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- A group of Negro leaders today accused the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. of participating in a "clear-cut, unholy, diabolic conspiracy" to help the Democratic party.

The full impact of the population explosion and the social and economic changes that have taken place since World War II can be expected to affect retailing in the decade ahead, it was asserted yesterday by Ralph Lazarus, president of Federated Department Stores, Inc.
Ed Duchini led Power Memorial to victory yesterday in the sectional cross-country championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association, New York division.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 1 -- Eleven Congolese Army officers, representatives of Col. Joseph D. Mobutu's military regime, received United States visas today.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- With buyers adopting a cautious policy in the stock market here today, most sections had no decided trend.

When Catherine Dewey's Dark Invader won the sixth race at Aqueduct yesterday, there was a general yell of approval from the crowd of 19,395. The cheer was not meant to applaud a success in a stakes or feature race, but only to salute the termination of a streak.

Evidence was disclosed yesterday that Joseph Nardone, New York director of the Federal Housing Administration, had accepted free electrical and carpentry work in his Bronx home from the sponsor of a Federally aided housing development.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Western diplomats are convinced that the Soviet and Chinese Communists are working overtime to try to patch up their differences. Yet the evidence to date suggests that they have not had any conspicuous success.

HAVANA, Nov. 1 -- The Cuban Government's recent ostentatious show of military strength is thought by some diplomats here to be an effort to demonstrate to Moscow that the Castro regime is a viable concern.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Pentagon is expanding its plans to develop bacteriological and chemical weapons for use in limited war situations.
Former President Harry Truman, buoyant and wildly hailed, made a dawn-tin-after-dark, free-swinging tour of Manhattan yesterday for Senator John F. Kennedy.

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Sales of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for the first nine months of 1960 were maintained at substantially the same level as those of the 1959 period, but earnings were moderately lower, E.J. Thomas, chairman, said today.
A 35-year-old railroad track laborer was awarded $178,500 in damages late Monday night for a back injury that he said had bothered him for six years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The General Assembly rejected tonight Cuban and Soviet-bloc demands for an urgent debate on Cuba's charges that the United States threatened the Castro Government with aggression and an imminent invasion.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Clarence W. Sayen, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, informed members of the organization today that he would resign if the board of directors adopted "unfortunate decisions." He said such decisions would divide the union "into hostile groups" and "permanently impair its functioning."

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Holy Loch on the Firth of Clyde in Scotland has been chosen as a base for United States missile submarines in the northern seas. Prime Minister Macmillan announced today to the House of Commons the conclusion of the agreement for Britain to provide the base in the loch for the depotship Proteus and a floating dock.

MOSCOW, NOV. 1 -- The director of the Cuban economy, Ernesto Guevara, has declared in Moscow that his country is seeking more trade and aid from Communist-bloc countries to help break what he terms an economic blockade imposed by the United States.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Nov. 1 -- Sir Robert Tredgold, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, resigned today while Southern Rhodesia's Parliament was debating the second reading of the Law and Order (Maintenance) Bill.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Harlem's fiery preacher-Congressman, may be running his last race for the seat he has occupied through sixteen turbulent political years.

Corporate earnings declined 11 per cent in the third quarter from the April-June period but were 8 per cent above the steel strike-troubled 1959 third quarter, the First National City Bank of New York reported yesterday. The report, published in the bank's monthly letter, was based on the earnings statements of 764 corporations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- A panel of specialists of the American Public Health Association here agreed today that the present hazard in using pesticides on food crops lay in accidental poisoning by those using the chemicals.

THE American Opera Society opened its eighth subscription season last night in Town Hall with a concert version of Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice." But this was not the "Orfeo ed Euridice" familiar to Metropolitan operagoers.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Owners of the Dallas-Fort Worth franchise in the American Association today said they no longer would seek a major league berth and would get out of baseball if a satisfactory purchaser of their properties could be found.
GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- The United States underwent its annual raking over the coals by major foreign exporters of agricultural products today for the protection it gives its farmers.
The New Yorld Post and the New York Newspaper Guild settled their contract dispute last night, ending a thief of a strike there.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Dean concludes, in his letter published Oct. 25 that a good defense of the U-2 flights can be made under international law, on the ground that they were at a height beyond the limits of effective control by Soviet air or missile power.

Net Income of the Corning Glass Works in the forty weeks ended on Oct. 9 declined to $17,580,333 from $17,944,084 in the 1959 period, the company reported yesterday. The 1960 earnings excluded a nonrecurring net capital loss of $1,868,418 from the sale of investments.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A United States Judge was informed today that the New York Stock Exchange was making arrangements to make good $700,000 in losses suffered by customers of a Boston brokerage concern, now in receivership, which was a member of the exchange.
Seaboard and Western Airlines, Inc., an all-cargo airline, announced yesterday it was proceeding with a financial reorganization proposed last August.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 1 (AP) -- International Typographical Union printers have refused to drop their contract "reproduction" clauses, which result in the setting of "bogus" type.
The three top men in baseball agreed at a meeting here yesterday that the National and American Leagues should cooperate in any further moves to expand the majors.
YONKERS, Nov. 1 -- Del Insko drove four winners at Yonkers Raceway tonight, including Silver's Dream in the feature Peekskill Pace. He also had two seconds.
The Transit Authority promised yesterday that the New York subway system -- one of the oldest and dirtiest in the world -- soon would be among the cleanest.
The Federal Aviation Agency has endorsed a new British landing aid, the Red-White System, for use at this country's airports.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The big Third Illinois Congressional District, which has voted Republican in Presidential years but Democratic in off-years, appears to be swinging against tradition and toward the Democrats this year.
Politics at the precinct level is part of the way of life in much of Manhattan's Eighteenth Congressional District.
Last night's opening of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden had much of the color and sparkle that has made its annual eight-day stay a highlight of social seasons here for generations.

Felix Jeffrey (Jeff) Farrell, the 23-year-old swimmer who qualified for a relay berth on the United States Olympic swimming team six days after an appendectomy, received the 1960 Gustavus T. Kirby Memorial Award from the Sportsmanship Brotherhood yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The Army football squad may not be up to par physically for its major test at Yankee Stadium against Syracuse on Saturday, but there is no doubt that the cadets will put forth an all-out effort.
"We've been far too complacent and we're not knocking the other guys hard enough."

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- French Protestants urged today that the leaders of all religious communities in France seek the proclamation of a truce in Algeria from President de Gaulle and the Algerian Provisional Government.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Wednesday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Michael Fekecs, the Hungarian refugee charged with murdering six persons, died in Elizabeth General Hospital early today after three and a half months in a coma.
CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Keystone Stable's Our Jody found her kind of track today and won the Oaklyn Purse at Garden State Park.
AN exciting new voice -- provocative, sensible and challenging -- came to television last night: Dr. Albert Burke, former director of graduate studies at Yale University.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Harold Wilson, candidate for the Labor party leadership, declared today that the party, despite its Internal differences, would be united and resolute in attacking what he termed the Government's "failures."

The status of Aluminum Company of America's $15,000,000 bauxite mining project in the Dominican Republic has been jeopardized by the recent introduction of a bill in the Dominican Senate that would cancel the agreement covering the project, it was disclosed yesterday.
The Soviet Embassy tried unsuccessfully yesterday to post $50,000 cash bail for a Russian employe of the United Nations who is charge with espionage.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The collegiate football career of Mike McKeever, one of the University of Southern California's twin all-American candidates, is at an end.

Policemen continued their pressure on motorists yesterday as Police Headquarters disclosed that a total of 9,881 traffic summonses were issued Tuesday -- an increase of 93 per cent over the same day a year ago.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- More than 16,000 shouting, waving suburbanites hailed President Eisenhower and the national Republican candidates at a party rally this morning at Westchester County Airport.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- South Africa's gold and foreign exchange reserves rose by L1,000,000 ($2,800,000) in the week ended last Friday to L90,430,466 ($253,205,305), a Reserve Bank statement said today.
YESTERDAY (Nov. 2, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY First (Political) Committee -- Continued general debate on question of disarmament.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- The United States said today that the "three blocs of states" proposed by the Communists to run the United Nations Secretariat did not exist.

YONKERS, Nov. 2 -- This city on the north rim of the Bronx gave an enthusiastic reception to Vice President Nixon today. Observers said it slightly exeeded the recent welcome given to Senator Kennedy.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- If depth of material means anything, the Army football squad is given something less than a good chance in its game with Syracuse at Yankee Stadium on Saturday.
AN unusual project, aimed at replenishing the New York fashion industry's dwinding supply of skilled personnel, is under way at a settlement house on the lower East Side.

The stock market's latest rally died out late yesterday, but before it did good gains had been posted in both prices and on average. The volume of trading increased for the third straight session on the New York Stock Exchange, an encouraging sign to many Wall Street observers.

President Eisenhower whipped 10,000 partisans into a frenzy of shouting and applause last night with an aggressive speech for the Nixon-Lodge ticket at a tumultuous rally at the New York Coliseum. The crowd, hanging on his every word, would hardly let him finish a sentence without stomping, whistling or yelling approval.
The death of Dimitri Mitropoulos yesterday will precipitate difficult replacement searches by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic.
A plan to facilitate voting by Puerto Ricans and other Spanish-speaking groups in the city was presented to Mayor Wagner yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Britain, France and Nationalist China joined here today in criticizing the Soviet Union for blocking Asian and African nations From greater participation in key United Nations agencies.

IN 1947, a 23-year-old Hungarian tenor made an unheralded debut in Town Hall and was immediately acclaimed as a vocalist of exceptional gifts. Although Mik-los Gafni, the singer in question, has appeared here since, he gave his first New York recital in several years last night in Town Hall.

Net income of Spiegel, Inc., in the three months ended on Sept. 30 rose to $1,885,392, or 62 cents a share, from $1,501,686, and 52 cents in the 1959 period, the mail-order concern reported yesterday. Sales increased to $55,756,972 from $42,580,361.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 -- Three principal objections to the proposed mechanization pact between longshoremen and employers were outlined today to 3,300 members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

"I don't know whether to clout you or kiss you," sneers John Ericson to a troublesome moll in one of the quieter moments of "Pretty Boy Floyd." Characteristically, he chooses the former course -- and thus, the script maintains, a petty thief is catapulted into a moderately notorious criminal career.

IN 1940, a Fifth Avenue furrier named I.J. Fox displayed in his window a single pelt that bore an $11,000 price tag. It was the first Platina fox to be sold in America and Mr. Fox outbid Lord Taylor and Saks Fifth Avenue to become its owner.

Hank Aaron, hard-hitting outfielder of the Milwaukee Braves, and Maury Wills and Charley Neal of the Los Angeles Dodgers have been fined heavily by Commissioner Ford Frick, it was learned yesterday. Aaron was assessed $1,000 and the two Dodger infielders $500 apiece for failing to go through with a barnstorming tour to which they had been committed.

A public offering of $50,000,000 of Commercial Credit Company twenty-year 4 3/4 per cent notes is being made by an investment banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co. The notes are priced at 99 to yield 4.83 per cent.
State Senator William T. Conklin, Brooklyn Republican, charged yesterday that the Department of Hospitals had been "seriously lax in governing the operation of nursing homes.

Broadway has seen five of William Inge's plays, one of which, "Picnic," received the Pulitzer Prize as well as the Critics Award. He is now putting the finishing touches to a sixth, "Natural Affection," a title with ironic implications.
AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The farm and lake (counties of Central New York are witnessing, a political phenomenon this fall: Representative John Taber is campaigning for re-election.
The Princeton Club of New York announced yesterday it had bought the property at 15 to 21 West Forty-third Street, near Fifth Avenue, for improvement with a new clubhouse.

The Modern Jazz Quartet and the Ornette Coleman Quartet are holding what might be considered a jazz summit meeting at the Village Vanguard this week and next. These two groups, which opened an engagement there Tuesday night, have achieved status as the most controversial jazz groups to appear during the past decade.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Mrs. S. Helene Sadacca's outsider, Lou Pelton, lighted the tote board with boxcar figures today when he took the measure of eleven other juveniles in the Westmont Purse at Garden State Park.
A Champion on Staten Island A century ago at this time a new nation was emerging from, among the older patterns of Europe to try parliamentary methods under a king instead of a president.
The Soviet chess team defeated Argentina, 3 1/2 -- 1/2, in the sixth round of the chess Olympics at Leipzig, East Germany, yesterday, according to a report received here.
The nation's production of crude oil rose by 50,400 barrels a day last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., in a temporary modification of policy, yesterday authorized all firemen earning less than $8,000 a year to hold outside jobs.

This is the year of the religious issue.
Texas Gas Transmission Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 22 per cent in net income for the third quarter. Share earnings rose 15 per cent in the period from the 1959 level.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it was assigning $4,000,000 of additional billings to Ketchum, MacLeod Grove, Inc.
ALBANY, Nov. 2 -- A record registration of 8,352,742 voters in the state was indicated today for Tuesday's election. The previous high of 7,841,613 was set in 1952.

TOKYO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Hitachi Shipbuilding Company disclosed today it had signed a contract to construct three 12,000-deadweight-ton freighters for the Soviet State Ship Export-Import Corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- Senator John F. Kennedy detailed today a proposal to create a "peace corps" of young men who would serve with technical aid missions abroad as an alternative to the military draft.

TORONTO, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- A goal in the third period by Bronco Horvath, his second of the game, earned a tie for the Boston Bruins in their National Hockey League game with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

Mrs. George S. Piroumoff and Mrs. Madison H. Lewis, co-chairmen of the twelfth annual theatre party in behalf of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service, have been meeting at Carlton House with members of their committee to complete plans for this year's event.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Public Health Service announced today the award of ninety-four Federal grants totaling $1,869,027 for research in various aspects of aging. Thirty-six of the grants are for continuation of earlier projects.

IN his first visit to this country three seasons ago, Leonid Kogan showed that he was one of the aristocrats of the violin. In a recital at Carnegie Hall last night he reaffirmed his position, as a distinguished instrumentalist.

A change in the Social Security Law forced the retirement of eighty-seven policemen at midnight last night. All had been permitted to remain on duty past the mandatory retirement age of 63 to become eligible for Social Security payments supplementing their police pensions.
The Republicans were in a dispute with the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday over an hour-long paid political telecast that is scheduled for next Monday.

The nation's independent liberal arts colleges are threatened by a shortage of teachers that may assume crisis proportions within five to ten years, in the opinion of Dr. Earl J. McGrath, a former United States Commissioner of Education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The agreement for a Polaris submarine support base in Scotland was said authoritatively today to leave the United States free to launch nuclear-tipped Polaris missiles without prior consultation.

AT the request of the photographers, Dan Topping slid closer to George Weiss on a green leather couch in the sumptuous Yankee offices on Fifth Avenue. As he moved into position the president of the Bombers noticed a picture on the windowsill in back of them. He turned it face down.

DYRON JANIS, the young American pianist who concluded a triumphant Russian tour yesterday, first showed the world that he had musical talent by whacking on a xylophone. It was an instrument he had been given for Christmas when he was 4 or 5 years old.
One of the many multiple-choice questions that Dick Colman is putting to his Princeton football players this week is "Harvard has won its last two football games chiefly because of:
Soviet high-school students receive a detailed and clear, though heavily biased, picture of American history. This is the conclusion of a study of high-school textbooks now in use in Russian schools.
Louis Wolfson's 2-1 favorite, Quiz Star, conceded weight to each of his nine rivals in the mile - and - five - eighths Knickerbocker at Aqueduct yesterday, and galloped home a six-length winner.

ALTHOUGH the countries are oceans apart, there is only a small gulf between the cuisine of Taiwan and that of many Chinese kitchens in America. This is the opinion of Mrs. Yuan-Shan Chi, a cookbook author and newspaper columnist of Taipei who visited this country recently.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The mists which rise from Presidential campaign oratory obscure not only the positions of candidates on public problems but also their retreats when, these positions have become precarious. On one point, however, Vice President Nixon and Senator Kennedy have agreed.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (AP) Dr. Linus Fauling expressed indignation today at a Senate subcommittee report, particularly a past sayiag he had "a long record of service to Communist causes."

The Dec. 12 performance of "Camelot," the new Alan Jay Lerner-Frederick Lowe musical, starring Richard Burton and Julie Andrews, has been chosen for a benefit by a committee representing the Browning School.
The population of the Nineteenth Congressional District is divided among almost a dozen different national origins, but is united by an overwhelming devotion to the Democratic party.
There are 1,200 insuring organizations in the health-insurance field in the United States, the Health Insurance Institute announced this week.

A WORLD traveler may be defined as the first person singular of the noun tourist. This happy convention gives us all an appropriately objective view of our fellow citizens when we encounter them abroad. And its benison is extended to readers of books by gifted world travelers, such as Enrico Verissimo's "Mexico,"* translated from the Portuguese by Linton Barrett.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- After absorbing a moderate sporadic volume of profit taking and hedge selling, the grain futures market here rallied briskly in spots just before the close of the Board of Trade today and finished with fairly broad gains.
VIENNA, Me., Nov. 2 -- Beer has more calories than whisky, the deer-hunting woman said in the beech woods today, and therefore she confined herself virtuously to whisky, though not while hunting.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- African and Asian members of the United Nations are drawing up their own version of a manifesto calling for an end of colonialism.

George M. Weiss, unquestionably baseball's most consistently successful general manager -- certainly its highest paid and probably its most misunderstood one -- yesterday announced what is tantamount to his retirement from the Yankees and from the sport.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The space agency found itself under suspicion today of re-scheduling two space shots for their political impact on the Presidential election.

GUANTANAMO NAVAL BASE, Cuba, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The United States Navy has put mine fields around Guantanamo Naval Base as a precaution against any possible attack by the forces under Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Senator Clifford P. Case today reaffirmed his support of an atomic power development program in which private industry would play a major role in partnership with the Government.
The final day for investors to participate in the United States Treasury's $10,800,000,000 refunding caused a flurry of activity in short-term Government securities yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- The eighteen-member advisory committee on the Congo is expected to get a first-hand report on the Congo situation, probably on Saturday.

The City Planning Commission has written to Mayor Wagner asrain, as usual at capital budget time, to tell him that things are not going well. The Mayor keeps telling them to send him a good capital budget. They keep sending him the best budget they can but still a bad one, because there isn't enough borrowing power. They keep asking him, in effect, will he do something about it.

President Eisenhower teamed up yesterday for the first time in this campaign with Vice President Nixon and Henry Cabot Lodge, drawing hundreds of thousands of spectators in Manhattan, Nassau and Westchester.

GARDEN CITY. L.I., Nov. 2 -- An enthusiastic crowd variously estimated at 10,000 to 60,000 persons greeted President Eisenhower and the Republican candidate today as the President made his first visit to Nassau County since 1953.
The Queens tow-truck scandal spread yesterday to the Bronx, where policemen, lawyers and insurance adjusters were accused of shakedowns and payoffs that totaled "vast sums of money."
CINCINNATI, Nov. 2 (AP) -- William O. DeWitt today was appointed general manager of the Cincinnati Reds of the National Baseball League.

Stand-ins for the Cleveland Browns found the latest changes in the New York Giants' rushing attack utterly baffling yesterday. Holes in the line during the dummy scrimmage at Yankee Stadium were as wide as sidewalks.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- A jury of three women and nine men decided today that "Lady Chatterley's Lover" was not obscene.

NEWARK, Nov. 2 -- A plan to provide more frequent railroad service between Allentown, Pa., and Newark was offered at an interstate Commerce Commission hearing today. The commission is conducting hearings on the request of the Lehigh Valley Railroad to abandon its passenger service.
In the city's low-income Negro districts, the banner of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal still flies high.

A group of prominent Roman Catholic laymen of New York, organized as the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, was asked yesterday to join in a drive for $25,000,000 to build four new high schools and a seminary in the Archdiocese of New York.
Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's addresses yesterday at the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center on Long Island, at the Westchester Airport, at Herald Square and at the Coliseum:

The Twenty-first Congressional District, in Manhattan's far north, a hilly residential area dotted with institutions of higher learning and possessing a variety of ethnic communities, has as great a dearth of campaign issues as any district in the city.
Cotton futures advanced 5 cents to $1 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading was the most active in some time.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2 -- A 21-year-old junior is receiving the first course credit at Princeton University for writing, directing, producing and editing a twenty-five-minute surrealist film.
Mayor Wagner's office contended yesterday that there was no inconsistency in proclaiming Learn English Week on the one hand while sanctioning ungrammatical pedestrian safety posters on the other.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Everett Scott Sr., former major league shortstop, died at his home here today. He was 68 years old.
Luis Ferre, candidate of the Republican Statehood party for Governor of Puerto Rico, gave support yesterday to bishops who intervened in the island campaign.
Empire National Empire National Corporation, formerly the Empire Millwork Corporation, offered yesterday to buy the outstanding shares of E.L. Bruce Company at $37.50 a share.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A candidate for re-election In the Ninth Assembly District, John R. Brook, recently stated he plans to introduce legislation aimed at over-hauling the state parole system. Many of his constituents are interested in knowing what changes he would propose.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 Spencer Tracy observed today his thirtieth anniversary in the movie business by expressing opinions on the industry that ranged from the unorthodox to the heretical.

LONDON, Nov.2 -- Announcement was made here today of the forthcoming wedding of Miss Janet Mercedes Bryce, daughter of Mrs. Gladys Bryce of Hamilton, Bermuda, and the late Major Francis Bryce, to the Marquess of Milford Haven.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Spain and Portugal were criticized today for refusing to submit information on colonies that they contend do not exist.

The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area rose last month by L11,000,000 ($30,800,000). At the same time, the decline in the United States monetary gold stock topped $1,000,000,000 for the first time this year.
The modern 24,830-dead-weight-ton tanker Perseus lay at anchor in Havana harbor yesterday as a "stateless" vessel after having delivered Soviet crude oil to Cuba.
Net income of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing (3-M) Company in the third quarter rose to $17,768,363 from $16,101,243 in the 1959 period, Herbert P. Buetow, president, reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- Byron Janis, the young American pianist, received an overwhelming reception here tonight from Russian music lovers.
IN the deal shown today, the use of the "compulsory false-card" gained a trick.
HAVANA, Nov. 2 -- The Cuban Government will never order an attack on the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay, President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado said today.

A long, green line of cardboard will begin to crawl like an endless reptile up and down a printing press Monday until it is chopped into thousands of little, annoying pieces. Each piece is designed to fit into a policeman's pocket, decorate the windshield of an illegally parked car -- and relieve the motorist of $15.
The State Supreme Court allowed the State yesterday to bring an action to dissolve a Queens corporation that owns an allegedly hazardous and unsanitary East Side tenement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Despite efforts in various states to reorganize and consolidate small school districts, about one-third of all United States school systems provided education for fewer than fifty pupils in 1959-60, the Census Bureau reported today.
The Baltimore Colts are the offensive leaders in the National Football League and 62 per cent of their yardage has been gained through the air.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 recently completed Army study has found the nation's air raid warning system "basically unsound" and obsolescent in missile era and has recommended corrective steps.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 2 -- Emperor Haile Selassie observed today the thirtieth anniversary of his coronation with a speech opening Ethiopia's Parliament.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Hank Greenberg and Ralph Kiner told the Memorial Coliseum Commission today the new American League baseball team here would like a two-year lease to play in the Coliseum starting in 1961 -- with a two-year option.

Joseph Nardone, New York director of the Federal Housing Administration, began an "annual leave" yesterday during which his superiors will investigate charges that he had accepted favors from a builder under Federal contract.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The White House released a report on Negroes today, which Labor Secretary James P. Mitchell said indicated "steady improvement in their social and economic status."
Aviation Week says the Air Force will seek a $20,000,000 allocation for a radical space vehicle able to take off like a conventional airplane.
Democrats are looking forward with confidence to making their best Presidential-year election showing in New York City since 1936.
Some long unbroken dividend records are under scrutiny in Wall Street these days. The question is whether the dividend records will continue.

The final class at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night will be competition among hunt teams for the Amory L. Haskell Trophy. Last Sunday many of those entered took part in a hunter pace at the Goldens Bridge Hounds kennels at North Salem, N.Y. Mrs. Jere Lord and her son, Jere 3d, of North Salem won in a field of seventy.

The January and March potato futures climbed to a new high for the lives of the contracts and the November position equaled its old high on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Trading reflected higher cash markets in Maine and Long Island and continued good demand for actuals.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Testimony was completed late today in the trial of a $500,000 libei suit against The New York Times and four Alabama Negroes. It will go to the jury tomorrow after closing arguments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 26:

Hunters of people with diamonds in their teeth and such items as historic bagels and the mummy case that first used varnish find what they want in a cellar treasury at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
LULUABOURG, the Congo, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A young Briton told today of having led a punitive raid by Baluba tribesmen against their hereditary enemies, the Kaniokas.
DETROIT, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers snapped a two-game losing streak by trouncing the New York Knickerbockers, 106-96, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

A substantial number of the 173 manufacturing companies questioned on the business out look expect new orders, billings and profits in the first half o 1951 to be higher than in the first half of 1960.
Following is the text of a broadcast by Vice President Nixon over WCBS-TV and the Columbia Broadcasting System vtenoorfc from New York last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- Following are excerpts from the text of a, speech by Senator fohn F. Kennedy tonight at San Francisco's Cow Palace:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 2 -- An Arab League spokesman said today that Western oil companies had promised to try to protect the royalies of petroleum producing countries from loss incurred in any future cuts in oil prices.
Allan Haymes, realty investor, has contracted to buy the seven-story business building al 5 and 7 East Fifty-ninth Street, between the Sherry Netherlands Hotel and the C.I.T. Building.
PAISLEY, Scotland, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Unbeaten Chic Calderwood of Scotland stepped to the fore as a light-heavyweight contender tonight with a four-round technical knockout over Rolf Peters of Germany.

The alumni of City College and many New York dignitaries paid tribute last night to Bernard M. Baruch and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. The two distinguished New Yorkers were the guests of honor at the eightieth annual dinner of the City College Alumni Association in the Astor Hotel.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Michael Fekecs, who died this morning after three and a half months in a coma, was described as "unquestionably" the slayer of six persons.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 2 -- The religious question continued to boil today in the tight Presidential race in Texas.

Today we complete our recommendations in the Congressional contests in New York City and adjacent areas. We have made our choice not on the basis of party affiliation but rather from the point of view of the independent voter.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- The chairman of the United Nations Disarmament Commission suggested today that the General Assembly refrain from voting this year on opposing arms proposals and give the commission another chance to compose the differences between East and West.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 2 -- Leopoldville and the Lower Congo area were hit today by a transport strike that brought further hardship to the population and affected United Nations supply system.
Everything General Motors makes for the highway and the home will be on collective display here today as the world's largest manufacturer stages another of its famed Motoramas.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Opportunely for Burma, a caprice of fashion in the furniture field, has brought teak back into popularity. Coupled with this rising preference, inherent qualities of the wood are helping to rebuild the war-ruined industry in which Burma once led the world.

SISSONNE, France, Thursday, Nov. 3 -- The silence of the countryside was broken early today with the arrival in this little Marne village of West German armored infantry to take up military training on French soil that still bears the scars of past German invasions.
Three thousand persons enthusiastically greeted Vice President Nixon and Mrs. Nixon yesterday morning at a break-fast rally in the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.
TRENTON, Nov. 2 -- Ground-breaking ceremonies for the state's largest reservoir project in more than thirty years will be held in the Round Valley area of Hunterdon County at 11:30 A.M. on Friday.
WARSAW, Nov. 2 -- Mark Twain's sardonic comments on man and his works were spun out before appreciative Polish audiences today.

The Textile Fabrics Association, a trade group of converters of cotton textiles, counseled members yesterday to reject any fabric test results that mentioned L22 standards. These standards were issued recently by the American Standards Association under the sponsorship of the National Retail Merchants Assocation.

The State Banking Board approved yesterday an application by the Chase Manhattan Bank to establish a public accommodation office at 351 East 148th Street, the Bronx. It was the first such office approved under a law passed at the last session of the Legislature, permitting New York City banking institutions to have limited facilities for taking deposits, processing withdrawals and the like within 1,000 feet of their present offices.
SAN FRANCISCO. Nov. 2 -- The nation's battle against air pollution is going to be a long struggle in which no sudden scientific "breakthrough" will be decisive.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Thursday, Nov. 3 -- The United States fired into orbit today a ninety-pound satellite to investigate the ionosphere. This is the unpredictable "atomic roof" that makes long-range radio and television communications possible and sometimes impossible.
Jewish voters have shed the apathy and have swung over mightily to Senator John F. Kennedy, according to a survey of Jewish opinion in New York.
YVES ALLEGRET, the French director, can't seem to get prostitutes and sailors and the old French film, "Port of Shadows," out of his mind.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Nov 2 -- Former President Harry S. Truman used a civil but sharply political tongue today to heap remonstrance upon the heads of leading Republicans.
YONKERS, Nov. 2 -- European trotters, who have the edge in the local season's international events, will mate gaits again with the best in North America tomorrow night.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 2 -- This city plans to expand one of its public beaches to cope with a demand for increased recreational facilities.
The Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company yesterday moved up their starting time for full-scale television election coverage Tuesday.

GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- Jewish leaders of fourteen European countries announced here today the formation of a standing conference on European Jewish communal services to promote cooperation across frontiers.

MILAN, Italy, Nov. 2 -- Dimitri Mitropoulos, former conductor of the New York, Philharmonic, toppled from the podium at La Scala Opera House today and died, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The passion and bitterness aroused by the Algerian issue in France will focus tomorrow on a Paris courtroom, where twenty men will go on trial for defying the Government last January in the name of a "French Algeria."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson assailed Vice President Nixon sharply today for what he called the Republican candidate's "ugly" assertions that Senator John F. Kennedy had "lied" to the voters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Committees that are promoting the campaigns of Democratic candidates for the Senate and House reported today that they had collected at spent about a third as much money as their Republican counterparts.

The eight colleges of the Ivy League have distributed a joint "Memorandum to Secondary Schools" to clarify their common admission policies. They took the action in view of the "national distress" created by current college admission pressures.

The United States, which has been doing well in international horse show competition, continued in the forefront by winning the first phase of the low-score jumping event at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- The Air Force, cognizant of the Napoleonic axiom that an army travels on its stomach, has come to grips with the question: How do you feed a space man?
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Mrs. Ruth Sprague has notified Mayar Motors here that next week she will pick up a 1950 Dodge car she purchased new ten years ago.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 3 -- Otoya Yamaguchi, 17-year-old slayer of Inejiro Asanuma, Japan's top Socialist leader, committed suicide by hanging himself in his cell last night, the police reported.

The President of the Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools agreed last night to meet with the president of the United Federation of Teachers in an effort to prevent a teachers' strike on Monday.

SURELY the freshest exhibition in New York at the moment is Berthe Morisot's, although this enchanting impressionist died sixty-five years ago. The seventy canvases assembled at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, in a show opening today, are the largest comprehensive exhibition of her work ever held in the United States, and should extend the list of conquests that this most irresistibly feminine of painters has been making for three generations.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Criticism of a United States Polaris missile submarine base in Scotland appeared to be of less immediate interest to the British Government today than an apparent conflict between the United States and Britain over the degree of control that London would exercise over the use of the missiles.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 2 -- When Radcliffe College alumnae in this area go vacationing in foreign lands, some of them by agreement have a special mission. They are to bring or send back in quantity moderate-priced items that are likely to excite interest when seen on or under a Christmas tree.

Many persons entertained at prefatory parties and at last night's performance of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, which was a benefit for the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
Richard E. Howell, secretary-treasurer of the Magna Oil Corporation, sold his 1,500-share holding in the company's common stock last month, thus removing his name from the stockholder list.

Avon Products Inc. The directors of Avon Products, Inc., yesterday voted to raise the quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from the 20 cents a share paid in previous quarters. The board also declared an extra dividend of 5 cents a share.

RESEARCH in child psychiatry is expanding back-ward. Intensive studies currently being pursued by research teams are probing the emotional character of infants as early as the first six months of life.
The University of Kentucky borrowed $8,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance building construction.
A kind of self-possessed enthusiasm prevailed yesterday among the large crowds that turned out here to see President Eisenhower, Vice President Nixon and Henry Cabot Lodge.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored twice in the last nine minutes tonight and gained a 4-4 tie with the New York Rangers. The point thus gained enabled the Hawks to break a tic for first place with the Montreal Canadians in the National Hockey League.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Thorn Lord today advocated a realignment of the Democratic and Republican parties that would shift conservative Southern Democrats into the Republican fold.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 31 -- Baseball and football have not obscured the Presidential election here but bets on both sports are easier to get than On the Presidential candidates.

Low Associates, Inc., has sold five three-story garden apartment buildings known as Pinewood Gardens at 60 to 110 Pinewobd Road, Hartsdale, in Westchester County. The building, on a tract of six acres, have ninety-five apartments and a fifty-car garage.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Nov. 2 -- The resignation of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Federation of the Rhodesia and Nyasaland, Sir Robert Tredgold, shook political circles in Salisbury today and threatened to plunge the ruling United Federal party into an internal crisis.
GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- The Soviet Union charged today that the "Pentagon and the cold warriors" had brought about a reversal of United States policy on a treaty to ban tests of nuclear weapons.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Business in the stock market here today was small. Despite improved conditions on Wall Street yesterday and the satisfactory October figures for Britain's gold and convertible currency reserves, buyers entered the market only for selected issues.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Children's Bureau said today that nine foreign countries had better records than the United States in infant death rates in 1958. It added that only five of those countries had better rates in 1950.

The massive Chinese Communist counter-attack against the United Nations forces in November, 1950, is examined in a book by Alien S. Whiting of the Rand Corporation. To be called "China Crosses the Yalu: The Decision to Enter the Korean War," it will be published Nov. 14 by Macmillan.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The answer to your questions as to Vice President Nixon's policy with regard to our unilateral intervention in areas of the world where ideological conflict explodes into internal warfare is negative. It is his policy not to intervene actively in the internal affairs of a sovereign country.

Reversing its performance of the preceding two quarters, Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., showed a modest profit for the first quarter of its present fiscal year. The profit followed a substantial loss for the large office machine and electronic manufacturing company in its latest fiscal year, which ended on June 30.
For the first time in its 168-year history, the New York Stock Exchange has offered to make good losses suffered by the clients of one of its members who has been charged with fraud.
Hazel Scott, estranged wife of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Harlem, said yesterday that she wanted a divorce, according to The Associated Press.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- A move to grant Negro parents the right to register their children in elementary schools outside their home districts has been defeated by the Board of Education by a vote of 5 to 3.

The annual Xavier Award of the Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau was conferred last night on Bishop James Edward Walsh, former Superior General of the Maryknoll Fathers, who is now in a Chinese Communist prison.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 3 -- Senator John F. Kennedy assailed tonight Vice President Nixon's competence in the field of foreign policy.

IN revealing plans yesterday for a mammoth, versatile New York sports and entertainment center -- a kind of Lincoln Center for the perspiring arts -- John Joseph Bergen, Rear Admiral, U.S.N.R., was carrying out the credo that is imbedded in his favorite saying: "It is just as easy to aim at an eagle as to aim at a sparrow."
The Standard Oil Company of California announced yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter rose to $70,666,000 from $01,962,000 in the 1959 period.

TRENTON, Nov. 3 -- Morris County, long populated predominantly by New York and New Jersey commuters, is becoming so industrialized that job opportunities there are developing at a faster rate than the population.
Prices of prime fixed-income securities moved irregularly yesterday in a quiet trading session similar to those of other days this week.
THE journey of "The Unsinkable Molly Brown" at the Winter Garden is rocky, like its name character's passage from poverty to high society.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE New YORK TIMES: This has been a good year for America's cities. For the first time, both Presidential candidates have spoken out on "the urban issue," the serious challenge to our cities and suburbs. Both party platforms have recognized that slums and blight are threats to the future of our metropolitan areas.

OUJDA, Morocco, Oct 30 -- "This city is a powder keg; one well-placed spark and the entire Morocco-Algerian border could go up in flames," the Governor of Oujda Province warned as he studied reports of the latest border incidents.
Forty-one speeches were made in New York yesterday in connection with advertising.
General Motors put on a private showing of the Motorama early yesterday morning for President Eisenhower at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
BEEF supplies leave little to beef about right now. The meat is unusually abundant, with the result that most supermarkets are offering one or other of the cuts at unusually attractive prices.

AN article in the latest issue of the principal French bridge magazine, Revue Frangaise du Bridge, indicates that in France, as in this country, it is a continuing problem to control bidding systems and protests in tournaments.

New York's State Education Department has ruled that "as a matter of law" parents are entitled to see their children's school records. This opens the door to controversy and danger. The ruling was made, according to the department, in the interest of full cooperation between parents and schools, based on complete understanding of the child.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 3 -- United Nations officials here declared today that a state of "civil war" existed in South Kasai and alleged that Katanga Province authorities and Belgian nationals were involved in it.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- The chunky, swarthy man with the pleasant smile and the soft voice said he was the Rev. King M. Ihaka, an Anglican Maori missionary whose parish covers about 2,500 square mile in the Wellington area of New Zealand.

An ambulance driver who was found guilty of speeding and then turned out to have ten unanswered traffic tickets on his record lost his driver's license yesterday. The Bureau of Motor Vehicles revoked it for sixty days.
WHICH pays off, buying early or waiting until the last minute? With Thanksgiving three weeks away, there still is time for the Christmas shopper to settle this perennial question.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- A White House economic adviser who has worked closely with Vice President Nixon charged today that the Democratis used "phony figures" when they criticized the country's economic growth rate.
Tom Gayford, showing the form that made him the individual champion rider two years ago here, scored Canada's first international jumping victory last night at the National Horse Show.

Since Robert Morse first appeared here five years ago in "The Matchmaker," he has had only two other roles, "Say, Darling" and the current' "Take Me Along." Each succeeding assignment has given the young actor added stature.

Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight boxing champion, said yesterday that he expected to meet Ingemar Johansson of Sweden in a third world title bout sometime between January and March in this country.
VIENNA, Nov. 3 -- The fourth conservative-Socialist coalition Cabinet headed by Chancellor Julius Raab was sworn in today at the Hofburg Palace in the presence of President Adolf Schaerf.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The new Russian generation may find difficulties between the Soviet Union and the United States "less insurmountable than their elders," Senator John F. Kennedy said today.
Nomadic linebackera -- the bane of ambitious ball-carriers -- were prosecuted verbally and physically in the New York Titans' football camp yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States will supply $10,000,000 to a new development bank that is to be established by four Central American countries, the State Department said today.

In preparation for the forthcoming United Nations debate on colonies, the forty-five African and Asian nations now constituting the largest group in this world organization are drawing up a manifesto of their own, calling on the General Assembly to proclaim the end of colonialism.

Consolidated Natural Gas Company reported yesterday that the volume of gas it sold all customers during the first nine months rose to 415,471,000,000 cubic feet from 403,309,000,000 in the like 1959 period.

A group of prominent Protestant scholars and churchmen said yesterday that exclusion of a Roman Catholic from the Presidency for religious reasons would injure not only the nation, but Protestantism as well.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Two top officials of the Amerian Dryer Corporation, accused of Issuing unregistered company stock, must resign by the end of the year under terms of a settlement reached in a stockholder suit.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The Government announced today that it would give the Cunard Line a direct grant of u3,250,000 ($9,100,000) and a loan of u14,750,000 ($41,300,000) toward the cost of constructing a replacement for the Queen Mary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Vice President Nixon's search for Southern electors, which he pursued today in South Carolina and Texas, is being conducted among an overwhelmingly Democratic voting majority that is the center of three conflicting pressures.
Henry Cabot Lodge yesterday denounced as "a last-minute smear" Democratic literature picturing him as anti-Israeli and pro-Arab during the Suez Canal crisis of 1956.

An anthology of articles from The New York Times Magazine, spanning more than three decades, will be published Nov. 22 by Channel Press of Great Neck, L.I. Titled "Background and 'Foreground," it has teen edited by Lester Markel, Sunday editor of this newspaper since-1923.
POLITICIANS are not the only personages who have been racing in and out of New York this fall. The bigwigs of the European fashion world have been setting arrival and departure records themselves.
The response of exhibitors and investors already assures the 1964 World's Fair in New fork of "overwhelming financial success," John W. Hanes, the finance chairman of the fair, said yesterday.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld late yesterday authorized the release of Igor Y. Melekh, a Russian employe of the United Nations accused of espionage, in $50,000 bail.
Senator John F. Kennedy will make a sweep through New York, New Jersey and New England beginning tomorrow in an intensive three-day wind-up of his campaign.
DALLAS, Nov. 3 -- "Vote For John Tower," the billboards say, "A Man Who Puts TEXAS First."
The Institute of International Education will receive the proceeds of the second Global Gala, a dinner dance arranged for Jan. 25 at the Plaza.
OSAKA, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Orlando Cepeda smashed a two-run homer to help the San Francisco Giants defeat the Japan All-Stars, 4 -- 2, before 30,000 fans at Nishinomiya Stadium today.

A theatre party has been arranged for Nov. 17 by the Big Sisters, Inc., which for more than half a century has been aiding Protestant children here. It will be at the performance of "Tenderloin" at the 46th Street Theatre.
The record of Vice President Nixon and the Republican party on medical care for the aged was assailed yesterday before an audience of 4,000 members of clubs for the aged here.

The owners of Madison Square Garden announced plans yesterday for the construction of a $38,000,000 sports and entertainment center in the city. The main feature will be a 25,000-seat modernistic arena.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Eisenhower put the finishing touches today on major political talks tomorrow a Cleveland and Pittsburgh. They are intended as an eleventh-hour appeal to voters to elect the Republican ticket.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 3 -- Two University of California professors won Nobel Prizes in science today. The 1960 Chemistry Prize was awarded to Prof. Willard F. Libby, 51 years old, of the university's Los Angeles branch.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Industrials experienced a sharp setback in the stock market here today on some disappointing dividend results and the prospect of fresh capital calls.
MONTREAL, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Jean Beliveau scored three goals in the first period to lead the Montreal Canadians to a 3-1 victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
A physicist has put a definite date on Doomsday.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined by $51,000,000 to $189,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements increased $78,000,000 to $589,000,000.
Republicans are facing the strongest challenge in many years to their traditional domination of the Legislature.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 3 -- New controversy entered the campaign picture here today with charges of forgeries in the lists of petitions needed to form the new Christian Action (Roman Catholic) party.
CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Howell E. Jackson's 7-year-old Tick Took teat the 3-year-old Chief of Chiefs by a neck in the Erlton Purse at Garden State Park today before 14,881.

When and if it materializes, the new Madison Square Garden will have to go some to win a place in the affections of New York comparable to that held by the last two of the three arenas that have borne the name.

The "cold war" in the Alleghany Corporation erupted yesterday into a full scale proxy fight when the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., again demanded a list of Alleghany's more than 25,000 shareholders. Yesterday's demand was in the form of a motion in New York State Supreme Court.
Two men stood in a fishbowl office on the thirty-ninth floor of the new Union Carbide Building yesterday and toasted each other in vintage Madeira.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 4 -- A controlled thermonuclear reaction of extreme brevity was reported today by University of California scientists.

Governor Rockefeller made a last-minute appeal yesterday in a letter to the state's 22,000 Republican county committeemen for an all-out effort to "put New York's forty-five electoral votes in the Nixon-Lodge column."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that President Eisenhower had misrepresented his Administration's record in foreign affairs during a campaign speech in New York last night.

TEANECK, N.J. Nov. 3 -- Dominick St. Angelo is an unusual barber. He not only talks, but he also listens. He even listened when his bald-headed customers grumbled about the standard price of $1.75 for a haircut.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Thomas E. Murray, former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, warned today that the Soviet Union could be developing a radically new type of nuclear weapon that would upset the present "balance of terror."

WHERE only a year ago there was an open city market, there is now (as of yesterday) a modern new supermarket. Located at Eighth Avenue and 142d Street, it is the third shop of a series known as Family Food, serving the Harlem area.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Angry protests in the House of Commons and a demonstration in Scotland today fed the campaign against basing United States missile-firing submarines in the Firth of Clyde.
IF you love your country, buy a new automobile in 1961, or earlier, if possible.

WOMEN are a "lost generation" today when it comes to housekeeping lore. In an era when machines do the laundry and a frozen food package contains the dinner, even mothers need a refresher course before they can teach their daughters the facts of homemaking.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would appear that the letter published Oct. 24 signed by Sidney E. Ahlstrom and others discussing the prohibition of the religious test contained in Article VI of the United States Constitution considerably misses the mark.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 3 -- The proposed 1961 budget for Suffolk County calls for a surprise reduction in taxes.

Low taxes, secretive and able bankers, availability of skilled personnel, low interest rates, a strong currency, an orderly economic and political system, and a central location in Europe -- such factors have enticed American companies to set up European headquarters in Switzerland.

The turf-racing season ended at Aqueduct yesterday, with the feature event, the Eastchester Purse, being contested in two sections. The first section produced as clean-cut a race as one would want to see with Manuel Ycaza coming through aboard the Tartan Stable's Bergamot to win by four lengths over William Haggin Perry's Desert Vision, in a field of seven.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- The State Department denounced today as "completely spurious" Communist charges that "war goods" were being manufactured in West Berlin and shipped to West Germany. The department accused the East Germans of illegally interfering with commercial transport from Berlin.

Sales and earnings of the National Dairy Products Corporation rose to new highs in the first nine months of 1960, E.E. Stewart, chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday. Third-quarter profits, however, showed a slight decline from the 1959 level.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Textron, Inc., a diversified manufacturer, today reported a sales increase but a drop in earnings in the nine months ended on Sept. 30.
The Georgia Power Company raised $12,000,000 in the bond market yesterday by the sale of first mortgage obligations due in 1990.
FORT WORTH, Nov. 3 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson expressed confidence today that Texas' twenty-four electoral votes would be in the Democratic column Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The downward business trend was reflected today in seasonal declines of freight loadings in both the rail and truck industries.

The January, March and November potato futures contracts continued to climb to new highs for the lives of the positions yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Steady to firm cash markets and good demand for actuals influenced trading.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- The ability of algae to capture the energy of sunlight will spark new industries, a symposium of the American Public Health Association heard today.

The mutual fund industry appeared unperturbed yesterday over a group of stockholder suits that had been filed against some of its members attacking various management and distribution fee arrangements.

of the moves would be to reduce the amount of outstanding common stock, thereby increasing the percentage of control held by the Getty interests, which now own about 65 per cent of Tide-water common.

PIERRE, S.D., Nov. 2 -- Up and down Main Street it is difficult to get even a partisan bet on the United States Senatorial face in South Dakota.

Canada's two largest airlines -- Trans-Canada and Canadian Pacific -- announced yesterday a wide-ranging series of fare changes and service improvements for North American routes.

The Federal Reserve System made one of its infrequent departures from its practice of dealing in "bills usually" in the week ended on Wednesday. But there was no suggestion that it had abandoned its hands-off policy in regard to long-term interest rates.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- George Meany said today that the Government was making "a bare-faced attempt to suppress bad news" about October un-employment.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 3 -- The state of Maharashtra announced today that it hoped to sterilise 15,000 men in the next month in a drive to curo its rapid population growth.
Stocks climbed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange for the fourth straight day as volume contracted.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower may make a trip to Nigeria, in West Africa, either before or after he leaves the White House Jan. 20.

THE last five games between the Cleveland Browns and the New York Giants produced an average attendance of 65,794. They also produced five Giant victories. As the general manager of the Clevelanders, Paul Brown was pleased with the first statistic. But in his companion role as coach of the Browns, the clever Paul was horrified by the second.

ONE of the nicest things about the Metropolitan Museum of Art's imposing musical program is that it provides treats unobtainable elsewhere in New York.

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $152,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a rise of 107,000,000 in the 1959 week and was the largest increase for any week this year except at tax payment dates.

YASSIADA, Turkey, Nov. 3 -- A score of prosecution witnesses testified today why they thought the deposed Government of Adnan Menderes had been responsible for the destructive riots in Istanbul and Izmir on Sept. 6 and 7, 1955.

DELTA, Utah, Nov. 3 -- Forty-five miles north of here, geologists are chipping out ore samples and marking claims with neat stone mounds and stakes. On the steps of the Juab County Courthouse, prospectors guardedly exchange information with tourists who drive from Salt Lake City to hunt ore on a part-time basis.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Another broad advance in wheat futures raised prices to further highs for the season today on the Board of Trade.

To no one's surprise, H. Roy Hamey yesterday was named general manager of the Yankees, twenty-four hours after his predecessor, George M. Weiss, had retired to an advisory position with the American League champions.

SYLVIA ASHTON-WARNER, a retired New Zealand schoolteacher, is specializing in emotionally unstable women. MANY egg whites, usually in lots of two or three, have gone down the drain after the home cook has eased her conscience by storing them a few days in the refrigerator.
