YORK, Pa., Nov. 4 -- The Democrats, with the support of a group of independents, are pressing a split-ballot drive designed to retain Pennsylvania's Nineteenth Congressional District seat in the event Senator John F. Kennedy fails to carry the tri-county area.

The bond market lapsed into inactivity yesterday with the exhaustion of buying flurries that appeared late Thursday following word of a shift in Federal Reserve System open market practice. Bond men said that yesterday's lapse probably had frozen the market for prime fixed-income investments until after the election next Tuesday.
Stocks rose yesterday for the fifth successive day, rising in every hour and closing at the highs of the session.
THE hand shown today comes from this year's renewal of the annual tournament played in August at Deauville, the fashionable resort on the north shore of France.

How the Nineteenth Amendment granting the vote to women became a reality is told by Maud Wood Park, first president of the National League of Women Voters, in "Front Door Lobby." The story presents portraits of Senators Borah La Follette, the elder Henry Cabot Lodge, Claude Kitchin and some of the suffrage leaders, particularly Mrs., Carrie Chapman Catt, president of the National American Woman Suffrage Association.
Downtown parcels were among properties In Manhattan passing to new control In deals reported yesterday.

The last major problem for President Eisenhower and the first for his successor is how to halt the present gold outflow while still maintaining our NATO commitments and the existing level of American forces in Europe.

AN increase in "non-feminine aggressiveness" in mothers, paralleled by an increase in "non-masculine passivity" in fathers, has created many of the widespread personality disorders observed in children today, a psychiatrist charged yesterday.
Governor Rockefeller named a five-man committee yesterday to suggest ways of tightening two provisions of the state rent-control law.

WARSAW, Nov. 4 -- Communist China is expected to renew with increased vigor and confidence its assault on Premier Khrushchev's policy of peaceful coexistence at next week's Communist summit meeting in Moscow, according to Communist sources here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Official reports today showed that the Democratic National Campaign Committee had collected and spent nearly half again as much as the rival Republican committee in the recent September-October period.

An assistant district attorney charged yesterday in Special Sessions Court that a lawyer convicted of faking arrest records for gambling-case defendants held "the key to an investigation into corruption."
AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 4 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith appeared today to be piloting her campaign course safely in a rising Democratic tide in Maine.
"Christian forces in East Germany are much stronger than, people can see," Bishop Otto Dibelius, European president of the World Council of Churches said here yesterday.

LAUREL, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The biggest daily-double pay-off of the Maryland turf season was posted at Laurel race course today at $2,437.60 for $2 after Kamal Bey won the opening race at $351.40 and Cohansey took the second at $9.60.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 4 -- The military regime alerted. the Congolese people today to be ready to fight "to the death" against what it called United Nations designs to make the Congo a "colony."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4 -- Harvard's defense, statistically the best in the Ivy League, will try to contain Princeton's league-leading offensive unit in the fifty-third meeting between the two squads at Palmer Stadium tomorrow.
Matthew Prior, an Eighteenth Century English poet who never saw a homecoming football game, once wrote:
MINBOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Attempts to woo Jewish voters in Nassau County were being undertaken on behalf of both Democratic and Republican Presidential candidates today.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 4 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., here to address a Democratic rally, said this afternoon that 75 per cent of New York City's Negroes would vote for Senator John F. Kennedy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : David Acheson has implied, in his letter published Oct. 31, that the Catholic citizens of Connecticut ire responsible for Connecticut General Statutes No. 6246. This act forbids the use of any drug, medicine, article or instrument whatsoever for the purpose of preventing conception and the use of such articles for the purpose of causing unlawful abortion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Holders of two issues of maturing Government securities exchanged them this week for $9,096,000,000 of a new issue of notes and $1,207,000,000 of a new issue of bonds, according to a preliminary report by the Treasury today.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower derided Senator John F. Kennedy today as an inexperienced "young genius" who would lead the nation to "self-destruction" if elected to the Presidency.
Senator John F. Kennedy will open his final bid for New York's electoral votes today with a series of appearances in the city and Nassau County.

Trail Guide, 21 years old and covered with glory, died during the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. He was the last of the great United States Army mounts of bygone years still in competition.

Sometimes fame is fleeting for rolling stock, even when it's lavishly upholstered and still rolls smoothly. Recently the president of the Rutland Railroad told the Vermont Public Service Commission that business was so bad he could not afford to use the palatial president's car owned by the railroad for some thirty-five years.

"ARSENIC AND RED TAPE,"* by Edmund G. Love, is a fraud. Ostensibly it is merely one more of those hard-breathing geewhizzers attacking waste and conformity. As a matter of fact, though, it turns out to be a wildly merry book about freaks, fools and men of destiny.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A new meter measures the flow of liquid in a pipe by "listening" to it. The movement is recorded from outside the pipe, without anything touching the liquid. Gulton Industries, Inc., of Metuchen, N.J. manufacturer of precision instruments and electronic components, will receive a patent for the flowmeter next week.
Profit taking and hedge selling yesterday ended this week's rally in potatoes futures, during which time prices climbed on a broad front to new contract highs.
YESTERDAY (Nov. 4, 1960) GENERAL, ASSEMBLY First (political) Committee -- Continued debate on the question of disarmament.
Universal Oil Products Company, Des Plaines, Ill., has announced it has purchased the Catalytic Combustion Corporation, Detroit. The transaction Involved Universal Oil stock valued at about $500,000.
Prince Abdul Rahman, Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, went up and down New York City yesterday in the ritual dance required of all official tourists.

Bernard H. Gordon, Bronx realty operator, has contracted to buy the two-story building occupying a plot 100 by 45 feet at Rockaway Avenue and West Mineola Avenue, Valley Stream, L.I. The deal was negotiated by Joseph R. Ruffino, who recently opened his own office in Kew Gardens under the name of the Ruffino Realty Company.
Prices of cotton futures or the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off to 10 points up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that he had set up a corps of volunteer physicians to examine immediately any policemen who may report sick on Election Day.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 4 -- A United States industrial and financial group offered today to build and operate a $380,000,000 natural gas pipeline in Argentina.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Industrial share prices drifted lower here today on moderate selling. A rally in the afternoon lifted some prices above their lowest levels.

What is believed to be the first special mass ever celebrated for the advancement of civil rights in this country will be offered at 10 A.M. today in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, Sixteenth Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Officials here said today that it would be most unlikely that the submarines that will use the support base in Scotland would be called upon to launch their weapons from British territorial waters.

H.L. Mencken scowled behind cigar smoke, Rebecca West beamed aboard the Mauretania, and Max Beerbohm swaggered through a snowy London street with a cane for a motion-picture photographer thirty years ago.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Yale's football team, with an eye on the Ivy League crown currently worn by Pennsylvania, entertains the defending champion tomorrow afternoon in the Yale Bowl. The starting time is 1:30 P.M.
A week-long series of "people to people" Soviet-American meetings on "cold war" tensions ended yesterday at Dartmouth College.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 -- Senator John F. Kennedy appears have made solid gains in Michigan's marginal Seventeen Congressional District during the last six weeks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A experiment in giving groups of students from French-speaking Africa an American education is beginning under the auspices of the African-American Institute.

Governor Rockefeller charged last night that "the Kennedy organization" had paid small groups to heckle him during an evening stumping tour in East Harlem, the upper West Side and the lower East Side.
LEIPZIG, Germany, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Union gained a 2 -- 1 lead over Czechoslovakia, and the United States went ahead of Argentina, 1 1/2 -- 1/2, tonight in the chess Olympics.
Santa Clara, Calif., sold yesterday bond issues totaling $5,650,000 to finance public improvements, including expansion of the sewer and electric power systems.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Two points after touchdown kicked by Dave Gouldin, a sophomore, gave Princeton a 14-to-12 victory over Harvard today in one of the most bruising, spine-tingling games these old rivals have played since their first meeting in 1877.
FICTION DANGLING MAN. Saul Bellow. (Meridian. $1.25.) Four agonizing months in the life of a young Chicagoan after he has quit his job and awaits induction into the World War II Army.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Mickey Cissell kicked the Arkansas Razorbacks into position for a Southwest Conference football championship today. His 26-yard field goal with twenty-five seconds left beat Rice, 3 -- 0.
HARTFORD, Nov. 5 -- Political observers here are convinced that Senator John F. Kennedy will carry Connecticut with a substantial plurality.
MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- As Soviet commentators see it, the United States Presidential campaign is nothing more than a contest between "Tweedledum and Tweedledee."

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- In a state where ballot splitting is an ancient art, Massachusetts Democrats this week were looking forward to the home-coming of Senator John F. Kennedy, on election eve, to convince the party faithful to hew close to the line.
The Board of Education expressed hope last night that the teachers' strike threatened for tomorrow morning could be averted.

PARIS -- Europe has a big, bright and pleasant surprise for next season's visitors: there will be no mammoth extravaganza or spectacular event on its program. The 1961 tourist season on the Continent will be free of such recent international, pivotal attractions as the Olympic Games, the 2,000th birthday celebration of Paris, Lafayette Year, the pageantry of Oberammergau and the magnetic force of Belgium's world exposition.

LONDON (Science Service) -- A twelve-year study of the case records of pregnant women who had abdominal X-ray examinations before their children were born has challenged the belief that X-ray exposure during pregnancy may cause a greater risk of leukemia to the child.
There's a bit of talk going on in Irish International Airlines about how to spell the name of the Patron Saint.
Too Early to Mulch The purpose of a winter mulch is to keep plants dormant and to protect them from the thaws that often occur curing warm spells. A mulch bids in stabilizing the ground temperature.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Utah's Redskins maintained their slim chance for a share of the Skyline Conference football title today as Terry Nofsinger threw two touchdown passes in a 27-6 triumph over Colorado State University.

The sort of people who sometimes pay $100 a plate for dinner paid $60 for breakfast here yesterday with Senator John F. Kennedy. The paying guests came at 10 A.M. and ate; the Democratic Presidential nominee arrived at 11 and spoke.
Four judicial contests to be decided in Tuesday's election are likely to provide a new measure of the Liberal party's political strength in New York.
Senator John F. Kennedy will make his final New York State appearance this afternoon at a rally in the Commack Arena in Suffolk County.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 27 -- A principal contractor says the international combination formed to build Lockheed Starfighters for the West German, Dutch and Belgian Air Forces will stimulate the growth of a powerful aircraft construction industry in Europe.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 5 -- Brown's football team indicate to a homecoming crowd of 7,500 today that it wanted to move out of the Ivy League cellar. The Bruins scored their first league victory of the season in six starts by beating Cornell, 7 -- 6, at Brown Stadium.
BUFFALO, Nov. 5 -- A political double-feature will be run off in Erie County in Tuesday's general election.
MONTREAL, Nov. 5 -- Canada's two major railway systems, threatened with a strike early in December, may be able to prevent it with a subsidy from the Federal Government.

THE clash of love and duty in the troubled breast of young Ted Applegate, third officer aboard the trans-Pacific liner Manila, is the theme of this hard-hitting adventure novel by Kenneth Dodson. How this division of impulse is fatefully resolved provides substance for a stirring tale.

THE third (and youngest) of Canada's ballet companics to tour south of the border, Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, was in the neighborhood last week, and in as much as visits to small companies from Paris and Berlin and Helsinki have proved rewarding in the past, it seemed very much in order to hop out to Freeport, L.I., to see this one.

With the New York World's Fair still three and a half years away, more than twenty-five major corporations have applied for more than a third of the acreage available to industry, Robert Moses said yesterday.

Mrs. Henry N. Sachs, and Mrs. Robert G. Janover, cochairmen, and Mrs. Albert O. Silverman, associate chairman, have announced two theatre benefits for the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House at 436 West Twenty-seventh Street.

Divine Comedy of the Llangollen Farm won the Roamer Handicap by eight lengths over the Alamode Farm's Ouija Board at Aqueduct yesterday. Even with the great margin that he enjoyed, the 3-year-old-son of Khaled covered the mile and three-sixteenths in the record-breaking time of 1:55 4/5.

SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 5 -- The newspaper of the General Association of Students of San Salvador University, which played an important role in the ousting of President Jose Maria Lemus, has expressed disillusionment with the regime of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.
OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 5 -- When a Japanese meets an acquaintance in Osaka the standard polite greeting is "Mokari makka." That means, roughly, "Are you making plenty of money?"
Like independent voters, independent eaters are on the rise -- crossing ethnic lines at will.
Sponsors have been announced for the third annual motionpicture premiere and supper dance of the New York Chapter of the World Adoption International Fund of the International Social Service.
ON Wednesday the Horticultural Society of New York will present two lectures on gardening at Essex House, 160 Central Park South. A Thanksgiving Flower Show also is scheduled.
Members of the United Nations General Assembly have extended a warm welcome to Canada's proposal that the non-nuclear powers be given a role in future disarmament negotiations.
HAVANA, Nov. 5 -- David Salvador, former labor leader and close friend of Premier Fidel Castro, was arrested early this morning when he tried to flee the island in a small yacht.

Don Cavalli, the national leader in touchdown passes, threw three more yesterday in leading undefeated Wagner to a 26-8 victory over Hamilton at Grymes Hill, S.I.

An expert observer of American higher education warned last week that the nation's independent liberal arts colleges are in a serious crisis and may be drifting toward disaster. Dr. Earl J. McGrath, head of the Institute of Higher Education, said that a "personal letter" sent to 544 presidents of independent liberal arts colleges revealed that well over three-fourths of the 513 who replied already report serious difficulty in recruiting qualified faculties.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Charlie Sturgeon's shattering power runs sent Kentucky into an early lead today and the Wildcat defensive unit battered Vanderbilt into 27 -- 0 submission in a Southeastern Conference game.

MINNEAPOLIS Nov. 5 -- Headed this way, in addition to big league baseball and big league pro football, is the Big Ten gridiron championship. The first two items are certainties, slated for 1961. The third may come to pass considerably sooner -- two weeks from today, to be exact.

Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower's name heads the long list of patrons for the annual International Ball, to be held in the Sheraton Park Hotel, Washington. The event will take place place Thursday on the eve of the running of the International Race at Laurel (Md.) Race Track.
FROM the time the Lord punished the children of man for trying to reach Heaven by way of the Tower of Babei, the world has been sundered by communication troubles.

LAST week brought an unusual number of interesting shows to town, including a couple that fall short for reasons that are interesting in themselves. The Guggenheim's great big Biennial International Award exhibition is a gaudy display so uneven in quality and with such curious inclusions and exclusions that you would think the paintings had been selected at random instead of by eighty-one men on twenty-seven juries.

FUSION PROGRESS -- An "encouraging advance" in the quest for a controlled thermonuclear (hydrogen fusion) reaction was reported last week at a meeting of the American Physical Society in Gatlinburg, Tenn., by a team of four University of California physicists in a paper presented by Dr. Frederic H. Coensgen.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Boston University, picking up three yards and a load of mud on each play, rolled 76 yards in the third quarter today to gain a 7-7 tie with West Virgina.

WITH the closing of the current exhibit of photographs by Claudia Andujar next Sunday night, Limelight Gallery at 91 Seventh Avenue South will end its career. After six and one-half years of uninterrupted exhibiting of top-level photography, both American and foreign, the gallery will go out of existence owing to a change of ownership of the coffee house which has supported the venture.

THE old bugbear of Japanese fanaticism which so haunted us in the Nineteen Thirties (and which seemed safely buried after the war) seems to be peeping again from its hiding place. The recent assassination of a Socialist leader by a rightist youth, pictured horrifyingly on the front pages of newspapers around the world, has caused some voices to announce authoritatively that, beneath the surface changes, the Japanese character remains unchanged.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- An energetic widow of a New York textile executive has started an effort to change the system of choosing candidates for President.

THE magnificent photographs of FROM PERSIA TO IRAN: An Historical Journey (Viking. $10), a generous number in color and all reproduced with impeccable Swiss craftsmanship, capture the look and feel, almost the sounds and smells of an austerely beautiful country.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov 5 -- Muscular redoubts enabled Yale backs to lead rather sheltered lives today. They responded by romping for 226 yards in a 34-9 triumph over Pennsylvania in the Bowl.
ITHACA, N.Y Nov. 5 -- Cornell University is nearing the midway point in a huge building program.

THIS significant book recounts two great struggles in the formative period of Soviet history, 1917-25. One was the Russian people's struggle for primitive simplicity and lay control in the new court system; foredoomed to defeat, it faded as early in 1922.

WHEN Norman Bel Geddes, the designer, died on May 8, 1958, at the age of 65, he had not finished his autobiography. NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 5 -- The supporters of rival African political parties clashed here today. One man was killed by a spear thrust and five persons were badly injured.

ON Jan. 26, 1950, India was proclaimed an independent republic, and on next Jan. 26, the United States Post Office will issue a stamp in its Champions of Liberty series honoring India's great nationalist leader and holy man, Mohandas K. Gandhi (1868-1948).

The nation goes to the polls this week with the hope that election results will help clear up some of the sticky situations that affect the economy. Both Democrats and Republicans agree that some action is nec- essary.

Arrangements have been made for members of the American Federation of Arts at 1083 Fifth Avenue to view the art collection in nine private homes here.

WARSAW, Nov. 5 -- Bishop Maksymilian Rode, Primate of the Polish Catholic Church, flew to North America today to rally popular support of Polish national aims and those of his national church.

Nutritional deficiencies can cause some forms of "alcoholic psychosis," it was stated at a recently concluded session of the World Health Organization's Expert Committee on Mental Health, according to the United Nations Information Office.

The George Junior Republic, an upstate school community for boys and girls with problems of adolescence, will benefit from the Nov. 30 preview performance of "Send Me No Flowers" at the Brooks Atkinson Theatre.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Voters in Bergen County will elect sixteen Mayors, four Freeholders, a Sheriff and numerous Councilmen on Tuesday, as well as cast ballots for President, United States Senator and two Representatives.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Once exclusively a winter resort, this fashionable island playground has become more and more of an all-year vacation spot. Although the formal winter season this year will begin, as usual, with the opening of the Breakers, the Palm Beach Biltmore and the Brazilian Court in the third week of December, a gradual shift to a year-round schedule is apparent.

SARASOTA, Fla. -- The-first skyscraper resort hotel to be built in almost two years on Lido Beach here will open, its doors Dec. 15. This is the $1,500,000 Landmark Resort Hotel, a twelve-story structure facing the Gulf of Mexico on 300 feet of beach frontage.
VIENNA, Nov. 5 -- Rumania's industrialization program appears to be making considerable headway in the chemical field, according to reports published in Bucharest.
Hugh Wiley of Towson, Md., and the United States Equestrian Team won the $1,000 International Jumping Stake at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 5 -- Vice President Nixon will get in the last political licks here, but Senator John F. Kennedy is expected to win Alaska's three electoral votes in Tuesday's election.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 5 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus, who pushed a school-closing constitutional amendment through the 1959 Legislature, has made a belated effort to obtain popular approval of the measure in Tuesday's general election.
Sunshine reaching the earth will be infinitesimally weaker tomorrow because of Mercury, the sun's smallest planet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A record Election Day turnout is expected next Tuesday -- perhaps 67,000,000 voters out of the 107,000,000 civilians of voting age.

PARIS. LAST month was the month of the Salon de l'Automobile in Paris, the time when light comedies and other entertainments considered suitable for provincial and foreign visitors come into their own.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Rockland County with a record registration of 71,476, is expected to give Vice President Nixon a majority. But leaders of all parties agree that his vote will be far from the record plurality of more than 20,000 that President Eisenhower received in 1956.

To be elected President, Vice President Nixon or Senator Kennedy must get the votes of a majority of the full number of electoral votes, which, this year, is 537. In other words, the winner must carry enough states to obtain 269 electoral votes.
BEAUMONT, Tex., Nov. 5 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson said today that he had had calls from all over Texas deploring the demonstration against him in Dallas yesterday noon.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Bill Kilmer scored two touchdowns and set up two others today in an outstanding exhibition of passing, running and kicking as the University of California at Los Angeles whipped the California Bears, 28 -- 0.

The annual theatre party for the benefit of the scholarship funds of the Manhattan School of Music will be held this season at the Nov. 28 performance of "The Unsinkable Molly Brown," at the Winter Garden.

Thousands of miles of travel, millions of spoken and written words of passionate argument, uncounted hours of grinding physical labor come now to an abrupt end.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The man with the button reading "NEITHER" may still be closer to the mood of the country than anybody else, but we have our consolations. ALMOST 130 years later, the story of a Negro slave, Nat Turner, the leader of the Virginia slave insurrection, still stirs the imagination. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The General Assembly postponed debate on the Congo crisis today for twenty-four hours to await a statement by President Joseph Kasavubu of the Congo.
The Federal Government gave formal approval and a promise of more funds yesterday to two major urban renewal projects here.

SALEM, Ore., Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Gov. Mark Hatfield said today ha had sent telegrams to the national networks and wire services in New York asking that no electronic predictions on the outcome of the election be released until the polls close in Oregon at 11 P.M., Eastern standard time.

The bond market stayed on the defensive yesterdsy as dealers waited out the last trading session prior to today's Presidential election. Little business was transacted, either in United States Treasury obligations or in other prime-risk debt securities.

Three of four major professional samplings of voter preferences indicate that Senator John F. Kennedy will win the Presidentiarelection today. The fourth nation-wide poll, which had Senator Kennedy in the lead Friday, reported yesterday that a week-end shift in straw votes had given.
The theft of $44,000 in crew wages from a safe on the liner United States brought thirty-eight members of the Federal Bureau of Investigation abroad the vessel yesterday morning.

TWO Viennese masterpieces, one from the early nineteenth century, the other from the early twentieth, made a fascinating program at the Gramercy Chamber Ensemble's concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

An agency-client relationship that has lasted sixty years is worth marking. Steinway Sons and N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., are taking note of their durable relationship with an advertisement in this month's issue of Music Trades Magazine.
Tom Gayford of the Canadian equestrian team became the individual champion in the international jumping compatition of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Long liquidation and hedge selling dropped potato futures prices in early trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The activity was influenced by a Canadian crop report released late Friday which showed a larger yield than generally expected by the trade.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Supreme Court resumed today what has become an annual tradition of beginning the term with an argument over whether the court is wasting its time on trivial cases.
Distress conveyances in Manhattan for the first nine months of this year show fifty-one liens, the same number as in 1959, but a decrease in dollar volume.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union has reported campaign contributions ranging up to $1,843 to fifteen House candidates-all but two of them Democrats.

THOSE planning to send Christmas gifts to Europe have no time to lose. The shipping deadline is only two days off. Thereafter, presents should be sent by air to ensure delivery before Dec. 25. Here are a few gift suggestions to help the last minute shopper. Although the success of these gifts can not be guaranteed, each has proved to be welcomed by overseas recipients.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Whoever wins tomorrow's election will be confronted with proposals for greatly expanded foreign aid and new approaches to it.

Following are the texts of closing campaign statement last night by Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, and Senator John F. Kennedy, the party's Presidential candidate, recorded by The New York Times.
Prices of cotton futures were unchanged to 8 points off yesterday in modest business on the New York Cotton Exchange. A point is 5 cents a bale.
A strike of teachers disrupted operations at scores of public schools here yesterday, causing some to curtail class schedules. It was the first teachers' strike in the city's history.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Nigeria's imports have a value of $535,000,000 a year. Yet its purchases from the United States, about $20,000,000 a year, have been declining despite the tendency of the new nation to expand imports on a global scale.

The National Labor Relations Board in Washington is expected shortly to set the time and conditions for a new representation election for about eighty-five pursers aboard passenger and cargo vessels of the American Export Lines.
School took on a holiday atmosphere yesterday for many students.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The stock market started the week on a quiet but confident note today, with buyers still adopting a selective policy in extending ther commitments.

Consolidated net income of the Cities Service Company in the three months ended on Sept. 30 declined to $7,865,730, or 73 cents a share, from $8,396,852, or 78 cents a share, in the 1959 period, the oil concern announced yesterday.

Kyle Rote, the pass-catching end, will be lost to the New York Giants for a week, at least. The former Southern Methodist ace, who jammed his left hand in a fall during Sunday's National Football League game against the Browns at Cleveland, will miss the return meeting with the Pittsburgh Steelers at the Stadium on Sunday.

WITH the showing of his spring collection. Ferdinando Sarmi was faced with living up to and surpassing, if possible, his previous collection. It was for his masterly efforts last fall that the suave, handsome designer won the fashion world's most coveted honor, the annual Coty award.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Australian champion racehorse, Tulloch, who is to be retired to stud next year, will stand at a fee of $1,176. This is the highest service charge here for a sire bred in New Zealand or Australia in his first season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- The Democratic national chairman, Henry M. Jackson, repudiated today the endorsement of the national ticket by H. L. Hunt, Texas oil man.
A train crashed into a crowded school bus at a Staten Island crossing yesterday afternoon, killing an 8-year-old girl and injuring thirty-one other youngsters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can make declaration of a belief in God a requirement for public office.

SUMMIT, N. J., Nov. 7 -- Senator Clifford P. Case, and Thorn Lord, his Democratic opponent, got into a heated controversy tonight over the Port of New York Authority's proposal, now dormant, to build a $220,000,000 jet airport in adjacent Morris County.

NAGOYA, Japan, Nov. 7 -- Japanese voters generally are apprehensive over the possible implications of the Unitied States-Japanese mutual security treaty. However, a majority are widely expected to vote for candidates of the pro-American incumbent party anyway for reasons not related to foreign policy.

NICE, France, Nov. 7 -- What does a fine upstanding politician, Democrat of California, do if urgent business takes him to Europe just before the election ? Why, he carries a satchel filled with Kennedy-for-President buttons, of course, and he pins them on astonished eustoms officials in Rome, London and elsewhere while waiting for his baggage to clear.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said yesterday he would ask the next Administration to back an investigation into remarks by Vice President Nixon that most Representatives and Senators had private political funds.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Auto production has begun its post-introduction slip. The big question is how far it will slide.

The city provided itself with the legal tools yesterday for cracking down on contractor and builders who obstruct side-walks and streets.

The 1963 football game between Syracuse and Notre Dame will be played in New York, it was disclosed yesterday. The city also is attempting to bring other big games here.

Domestic shoe production will be 605,000,000 to 615,000,000 pairs this year, compared with the record figure of 632,108,000 pairs last year, according to David Herrmann, new chairman of the National Shoe Institute.

Bishop Herbert Welch, elder statesman of American Methodism, was honored last night on his ninety-eighth birthday.
Minnesota, a football doormat last year, completed a stunning drive to the No. 1 spot in the national rankings yesterday.

The emergence of a broad and active market for dollar deposits in Europe is enhancing the importance of the dollar as an international currency but is reducing the importance of New York as an international lending center, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

THERE may be some hope for hunters and fishermen in the statistics about them issued recently by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, but not much. Hunters and fishermen decreased a little last year, which might give both a little more room.

As six Fire Department teams began hotel inspections in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh visited one hotel and described conditions that he considered particularly dangerous.
HONOLULU, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Hawaii's three electoral votes, originally recorded for President-elect John F. Kennedy, may belong in the column of Vice-President Nixon because of auditing errors.
BONN, Nov. 9 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, a man who values personal contacts in politics, is expected to visit Washington early next year for talks with President-elect John F. Kennedy.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Senator Kennedy cut sharply into traditional Republican Presidential pluralities in Nassau County yesterday, but failed to carry any local Democrats into office.
ON a recent shopping torn of Europe Macy's buyers smoked out a batch of pipes, cigar cutters, hookahs and matches that will delight tobacco fanciers.

At the historic moment of an election victory which will alter the course of world events and deeply affect every human being on earth, Messrs. [Herbert H.] Lehman and [Irving M.] Engel [leaders in the Democratic reform movement] had the ill grace to make a variety of sordid statements which illustrate the depths to which some people will go in order to achieve their ends at all costs and by employing all possible means.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Roger Maris today was named the American League's most valuable player for 1960. The slugging outfielder edged his New York Yankee team-mate, Mickey Mantle, by three votes in the balloting.

A Russian employe of the United Nations charged with espionage was described yesterday as the second secretary of the Soviet Union's Foreign Ministry, and therefore protected against prosecution by diplomatic immunity.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- President de Gaulle and the French Government rejected today the resignation of a high civtt servant in Algiers and dismissed him instead for opposing the President's policies for ending the six-year-old war there.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation recorded another $3,120,000 loss during the third quarter of this year, raising its nine-month deficit to $16,088,000, after a tax refund of $16,313,000 the company reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- The General Assembly voted tonight to postpone the debate on the Congo indefinitely.

Four real estate operator and a lawyer were held for trial yesterday on charges of perjury and obtaining illegal rents and bonuses from Puerto Ricans seeking apartments in the Bronx. The real estate men were released on bail and the lawyer was paroled.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- United States missile-carrying submarines may be detected and blown up at their projected anchorage in the Firth of Clyde, with "horrible consequences" for Scotland, the General Council of Scottish Trades Unions warned today.

The four-story business building with store at 63 Nassau Street opposite the new Chase Manhattan Bank Building has been resold by clients of Walter Scott Co. to Jack and Rose Ullman. The deal was for cash over mortgages of $100,000.
The election of John Fitzgerald Kennedy as thirty-fifth President of the United States breaks precedents right and left.

The report of Kathleen Teltsch published in your Nov. 2 issue describing the result of the plenary session in which the allocation of the complaint by the Revolutionary Government of Cuba was discussed, leaves very important aspects in darkness.

American Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that its consolidated net income from operations in the first nine months of this year dropped to 6,924,000, or 82 cents a share, from $10,132,000, or 1.21 a share, in the 1959 period.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- California's no longer vital thirty-two electoral votes tantalized Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon today.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 9 -- Vice President Nixon clung to a narrow and surprising lead in Alaska today as election results slowly flowed in from the far corners of the state.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Senator Kennedy's victory led to a temporary but excited demand for South African goldmine shares in the stock market here today. Despite his denials some investors still harbor the hope that the new President might increase the price of gold.

Jacob Ruppert, the brewing company, last month purchased 95,950 shares of the class A stock of the Kratter Corporation, real estate organization. This acquisition increased Ruppert's holdings to 110,250 shares of the A stock.
OTTAWA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Minister of Labor Michael Starr announced today that the, Seafarers International Union had heeded his call to end a walkout on Great Lakes shipping companies.
It is going to cost one group of Kennedy supporters between $5,000 and $10,000 -- perhaps more -- because the man on whom they gambled won the election.

WHEN the air is filled with remarks like: "I never thought we'd see this in Amerca. . . . It's like Paris in the aid days of Dior when you used to gasp after every dress. . . . Boy, is this creative!," and when a professional audience applauds continuously and shouts "Bravo!" at the finale, it is obvious that something rather spectacular has happened.

The United States monetary gold stock declined $218,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The stock on Wednesday was $18,116,000,000, a decline of $1,340,000,000 since the first of this year.
Volunteer leaders in community service programs in three diverse areas were honored yesterday at the twelfth annual Lane Bryant awards luncheon at the Plaza Hotel.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposed appointment, reported in The Times of Oct. 28, of Lieut. Gen. Adolf Heusinger to a key NATO position is disturbing.
SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 10 -- Trials of persons accused of abuses under the deposed regime of former president Jose Maria Lemus will get under way soon.
Edgar I. Levy and Howard W. Woolf, who contracted to buy the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 175 East Seventy-ninth Street last March, have resold their contract.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Nov. 10 -- Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, told the Federal Parliament today he had seriously considered resigning and holding a general election when he learned of the secession clause in the Monckton Commission's report.

Heavy hedging and liquidation induced stop-loss selling of cocoa contracts yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Scale-down short covering and manufacturer buying for price fixing absorbed the offers. Trading was influenced by only light demand for actuals and heavy supplies available.

New York State's new pleasure boating regulations, which went into effect during the past season, require new demands, especially instruction for children before they can become boat operators. Because of these demands, the State authorities are combing waterways, yacht clubs, power squadrons and the Coast Guard auxiliary flotillas for new instructors.
Pleading in the cases of thirteen winners on rigged television quiz shows was adjourned to Dec. 1 yesterday after lawyers for the defendants said they would attack the legality of the charges.

Electo, a big 6-year-old horse from little Uruguay, splashed through the slop at Aqueduct yesterday and won the mile-and-five-eighths Ocean Parkway Handicap by half a length from Alexander J. Ostriker's Catapult.

A MONG many penetrating comments on "The State of the Theatre" in the current Harper's, Arthur Miller makes some marginal remarks about the state of the artist in America. He is using the word "artist" to include writers, musicians, painters and all people concerned with the arts.
The president of Columbia University called last night for "abnormal efforts" by countries of the Western Hemisphere to prevent the spread of totalitarian regimes in Latin America.
YESTERDAY (Nov. 10, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Credentials Committee -- Voted to recommended the seating of a Congolese delegation headed by President Joseph Kasavubu.
IF ever a bridge hand was devised to convince the average player that experts do not know what they are doing, this one is it.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- Dr. Franz Goldmann of New York outlined here today a program for strengthening the health services for the chronically ill and aged among the Jewish people.

The care and feeding of stockholders' minds via the annual report has become of increasing concern to the nation's corporations. The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants reports that the diet offered is meatier this year than ever.

Hershey Chocolate An extra dividend of $1 a share, as well as the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share, was declared yesterday by the board of directors of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation. The declarations will be paid on Dec. 15 to shareholders of record of Nov. 25.

President-elect Kennedy is now facing the first critical test of his victory. He has started to pick the men who will run his Administration, and since a man is usually as big as those he gathers around him, we shall soon have a measure of the new young Chief Executive.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 11 points up to 2 off yesterday. A point equals. 5 cents a bale. Only October showed a decline.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- Of all the appointments President - elect John F. Kennedy will be making in the next few weeks the one perhaps most awaited by Massachusetts politicians is that of his successor in the Senate.

A new book by Cleveland Amory, "Who Killed Society?" will be published on Dec. 14 by Harper. It is a 576-page history of the American social scene, with more than 130 photographs, ten drawings by Charles Dana Gibson and special inserts listing the names of the original "400" and all American families entitled to coats of arms.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Al Balding of Toronto, a last-minute entry, posted a six-under-par 66 today and shared the first-round lead of the sixteenth Mexican open golf tournament. Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., the 1956 Mexican champion, also shot a 66.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -- A horse that commanded scant respect only a month ago is the "horse to fear" in tomorrow's Washington, D.C., International at the Laurel Race Course. There are eleven starters listed for tomorrow's ninth annual $100,000 pageant, with one United States representative, the Sag-Je Stable's Harmonizing, rated the overnight favorite.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- In his fifteen years in Washington Clark McAdams Clifford has demonstrated a sure-footed ability to run political interference for Presidents and would-be Presidents. From 1946 to 1950 he was special counsel and chief speech writer for President Harry S. Truman.

A plot of vacant land at Boston Road and Barnes Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Harry Heiman to the H.C. Bohack Company, operator of the Bohack chain of supermarkets. The buyer plans a market and parking area there for its own occupancy.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 10 -- United Nations forces today rescued two survivors of an Irish patrol ambushed by tribesmen in North Katanga Tuesday.
The Deep South's fourteen unpledged Presidential electors all appeared yesterday to be wavering toward the column of Senator John F. Kennedy.
ALGIERS, Nov., 10 -- A crowd of about 2,500 Europeans of Algiers chanted "Algerie Francaise and "De Gaulle to the Gallows!" for about an hour tonight.
HYANNIS, Mass., Nov. 10 -- Following is a transcript of the news conference of President-elect John F. Kennedy today at the Hyannis Armory:
A magnificent collection of ancient Chinese jade and bronze objects and Central and Western Asian bronzes is serving a dual purpose at Columbia University.

The transient glory of American politics is nowhere more briefly tasted than among the members of the Electoral College. In New York State, the electors discharge the functions of their office in one day between noon and 3 P.M., with time out for lunch.
Plans for $6,384,600 in improvements at New York International Airport were announced yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The Coliseum Commission today gave unanimous approval to an application by the new American League baseball franchise for eighty-one playing dates next year in the 100,000-seat stadium, provided there is no conflict with established tenants.
WHEN Knute Rockne was asked where the original idea had come from for his virtually invincible Notre Dame style of attack, Rock never hesitated.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 10 -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, called today upon the nation's business men to help President-elect John F. Kennedy to maintain the stability of the dollar and fight inflation.
TENNESSEE WILLIAMS has written a serious comedy that is neither especially serious nor notably comic.
Top labor leaders met yesterday in the first of a series of conferences on questions stemming from the teachers' strike of last Monday and to explore the facts that led to it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A mixed freight-loadings pattern was reported today by both the rail and truck industries.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The grain futures market slipped today into its broadest general decline in several weeks, carrying all corn contracts to their lowest levels of the season.
Mrs. James Dormant of Montclair was elected present of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the annual meeting yesterday at the Savoy-Hilton Hotel.

THERE is plenty of purple passion involved in Australian cookery. In fact, the extensive use of the native passion fruit and other locally grown fruits, such as strawberries, represents the main difference between the cuisines of England and the land of the Kangaroo and the wallaby.
Queens County boasts a longstanding reputation for political independence, but it has never been better illustrated than by what happened in the Fourth Congressional District in Tuesday's election.
"SCHOLARLY, self-contained and discreet" have been used to describe Allen Dulles. . . . The Central Intelligence Agency, which he heads, has been called the nation's first line of defense.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Canada asked the United Nations today to name a committee of non-nuclear states to review the world's disarmament programs and to make recommendations that might lead to a resumption of negotiations among the major powers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 11 -- Five crack South Vietnam battalions staged a bloody pre-dawn uprising today. Five hours later a Military Revolutionary Committee claimed it had overthrown President Ngo Dinh Diem's Government.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Two Algerian terrorists sprayed submachine-gun bullets for thirty seconds into a crowded cafe at Epinay, a northern suburb of Paris, tonight. They killed seven fellow-countrymen and wounded an eighth.

The sixth annual Internaional Debutante Ball, to be held at the Astor on Dec. 22, will benefit the Kidney Disease foundation of New York, which supports research programs on nephrosis, nephritis and allied kidney diseases.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 10 -- Indians seemed today to expect a marked change in United States foreign policy after Senator John F. Kennedy becomes President in January.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 10 -- Gov. Jimmie H. Davis tonight called a second special legislative session to block desegregation of public schools here.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Yale expects to serve its bread-and-butter offense with a little added flavor to Princeton in the Bowl on Saturday.

Washington State's Hugh Campbell is the top pass receiver in major college football. After eight games, the Cougar sophomore has caught fifty-three aerials for 712 yards and seven touchdowns, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Service Bureau statistics released yesterday.
Catholic teachers group yesterday won Mayor Wagner's sympathetic consideration of some of its complaints against policies of the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Lookback on their history, Americans have developed a belief which has taken form in the cliche that "This is a lucky country." The thought conveyed is that, somehow of other, the choices between alternatives that could, if wrong, endanger our democracy and the life of our free institutions always turn out to be the best.

HYANNIS, PORT, Mass., Nov. 10 -- Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy, wife of the President-elect, said today that she felt '"enormous happiness and relief" that her husband had won. But she said that the last few days still seemed "unreal" to her.
The New York Shakespeare Festival opened a drive for "audience sponsors" yesterday and showed designs for the new amphitheatre scheduled for construction, in Central Park next year.
The Holland-America Line will introduce an unusual kind of ship profile in the harbor this morning.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Willie Mays and Willie McCovey hit successive home runs in the fourth inning today as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Japan All-Stars, 4 -- 1, before 12,000 fans at the Hiroshima Stadium.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Hank Bassen's brilliant goaltending steered the Detroit Red Wings to a 4-1 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight in a National Hockey League game before 12,075 at the Garden.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Vice President Nixon is being urged to enter the Presidential campaign in 1964, his press secretary said today.

Aldo T. (Buff) Donelli Columbia's head football coach, is a man with many angles. He has been using reverse English in whipping his players into a fighting pitch for tomorrow's game with Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A Peruvian newspaper man, Pedro de Mesones, informs the public, with half-truths in his letter to you (published on Oct. 27), on "Peru's Borders."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- The Atomic Energy Commission made a strong appeal here today for the resumption of testing nuclear weapons underground.
Heavy rains, which turned the Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds turfs into soggy cushions unfit for football, drove the Giants and Titans, indoors yesterday.
In the industrial cities of the North, Negro voters, largely Protestant but traditionally Democratic, gave John F. Kennedy a powerful assist in achieving his narrow victory over Vice President Nixon.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Dr. Joseph Wickham Roe, past president of the Society of Industrial Engineers and professor and chairman of the Department of Industrial Engineering at New York University from 1921 to 1937, died yesterday in his home in Southport.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., is a great world political dateline now becasuse of the alarums and excursions of John F. Kennedy, who lives there and is in residence now, but to many of the residents, or Natives, the, thunder of great events appears to be nothing much but a low muttering.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Before we take too much pride in the fact that a record number of voters participated in Tuesday's election I think we should also remember that an estimated 19,000,000 persons of voting age were ineligible to cast their ballots because of the restrictive quirks in the election laws of the various states.
The merger of the OPW Corporation, Cincinnati, into the Dover Corporation, Washington, D.C., has been approved by the boards of directors of both companies, it was announced yesterday.

THIS year, more than ever before, internationalism flavors the handsome, often handmade wares that many fortunate American, children will be receiving from doting relatives and friends at Christmas time. Vying for attention along with imports from England, France, Spain, Italy, Switzerland, Belgium, Ireland, Scotland and parts of the Orient are many fine American designs for youngsters, too.

The latest vogue among steamship conferences, the establishment of "neutral bodies" to police the activities of steamship companies for malpractices, is facing its first major survival test in the Transpacific Freight Conference of Japan.

In the six years that Ngo Dinh Diem has kept his firm hold on South Vietnam his rigid nationalism has made him almost as disliked by his patriotic countrymen as his ardent anti-communism has made him disliked by the Communists to the north.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Pentagon assigned satellite identification and tracking stations to the country's continental air defense network today.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- After a two-day debate, the House of Commons gave approval tonight to the Government's public investment policy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A rail industry spokesman said today that short-sighted Government policies toward the railroads had opened a major gap in the nation's defense.

ELECTIONS may come and elections may go, but shopping goes on forever. Unfortunately, this election week, the trip to the supermarket will be more expensive, due to a rise in the price of two staples. Butter is up 2 cents a pound, while medium Grade A white eggs have risen another 2 cents a dozen.

SYLVIA ROSENBERG, a violinist who has won some important competitions and who has studied in Europe on a Fulbright scholarship, gave a recital last night in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Young Artists Series.

England's Shakespeare Memorial Theatre, with headquarters at Stratford-on-Avon, is having growing pains. Its young director, Peter Hall, is opening a London branch at the Aldwych. Operations commence there Dec. 15 with "The Duchess of Malfi" as the first of five productions announced thus far.
A plan to treat narcotic addicts medically rather than as criminals was described last night by Richard H, Kuh, administrative assistant to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
Research advances described as crucial for understanding the electric sparks of life that course through the nerves of men and animals were announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- United States Government authorities welcomed the reduction of interest rates in West Germany today. It was a long awaited move.
ROME, Nov. 10 -- Pope John XXIII sent a personal message of congratulations and cordial good wishes today to President-elect John F. Kennedy.

Radio and television performers voted here yesterday to strike any time after midnight on Tuesday if new contract agreements were not reached with the networks. Negotiations between the networks and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists are continuing.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The resignation of Cameron F. Cobbold as Governor of the Bank of England was announced today. He will be succeeded by the Earl of Cromer, economic minister at the British Embassy in Washington next June 30.

Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Staten Island yesterday ordered the closing of the grade crossing where a Staten Island Rapid Transit train struck a school bus Monday. An 8-year-old girl was killed and thirty other children were injurd in the accident.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Retail sales in the nation increased last month by about one-half of what they had slipped in the preceding five months, the Department of Commerce estimated today. Improved auto sales dominated the picture, but there were improvements in most other lines, too.
The annual Veterans Day parade will take place at 10 o'clock this morning on lower Fifth Avenue.

The funeral of an airline stewardess believed to have been killed in an auto crash near San Francisco Monday was called off here yesterday after the body was identified as that of another stewardess in the accident.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 10 -- A newly elected State Supreme Court justice, a City Court judge, a police sergeant and some housewives and business men today took over the schools here for one day.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Macmillan and his government were described today as convinced that close and friendly cooperation would continue under the administration of President-elect John F. Kennedy.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Three members of the United States Davis Cup team, making their first appearance of the season in Australia, scored easy victories today in the first round of the New South Wales championships.

HYANNIS, Mass., Nov. 10 -- John F. Kennedy announced today that Allen W. Dulles would remain as director of the Central Intelligence Agency in the new Democratic Administration. He also said that J. Edgar Hoover would continue as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
NAOMI NEWMAN'S vocal program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall consisted of an excellent group of old and new songs.
Carmine G. De Sapio is planning a full-scale Democratic primary battle in Manhattan that will challenge all the leaders of the so-called reform faction in their own districts.

A decline of 2,465,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute for the weak ended last Friday. At the week-end, total supplies were 184,350,000 barrels, compared with 186,815,000 a week earlier and 175,800,000 a year ago.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The West German Central Bank cut its discount rate from 5 to 4 per cent today, thus making West Germany the fourth European country to lower interest rates in the last month.
James M. Landis said yesterday that his candidacy for the presidency of the airline pilots' union would not be affected by the study he will do for President-elect John F. Kennedy.
MONTREAL, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens rallied twice tonight and defeated the New York Rangers, 9 -- 7, in the wildest-scoring National Hockey League game in years.
The high point of last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center -- and very high one it was -- was the season's first performance of "Prodigal Son."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Employment conditions continued to worsen in October, the Labor Department reported today.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $53000,000, to $136,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New fork reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $32,000,000, to $584,000,000 from a corrected figure of the week before.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 10 -- President Alberto Lleras Camarco warned Colombians last night that his bipartisan Government was still endangered by petty political disputes.
The city's 23,500 policemen have all been ordered to sign individual forms saying they do not hold outside jobs. They face departmental punishment if they fail to comply.
NEWARK, Nov. 10 -- The reelection of Dennis F. Carey as Essex County Democratic chairman was voided today in the courts.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- Chile's trading partners exempted her today for another year from some of the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) because of the country's economic difficulties.

WHEN Joyce Cary died in 1957 he had completed but not revised the manuscript of a full-length novel, "The Captive and the Free," which was published in this country two years later, and also four short stories. These and twenty-nine other short stories that had appeared in various English and American magazines are now published in a collection called "Spring Song and Other Stories."
Senator John F. Kennedy's slim popular vote edge over Vice President Nixon held at about 300,000 yesterday as the counting of ballots dragged toward an end.

ON CHRISTMAS morning Americans will open an estimated $7,350,000,000 worth of gifts wrapped in about $150,000,000 worth of wrappings. Before that time the average family will have spent $147 on Yuletide parcels at an estimated value of $4.91 for each.

Net income of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 fell to $1,919,788, or 21 cents a share, from $3,652,038, or 36 cents a share, in the corresponding period of last year. Sales of the manufacturer of aircraft components and industrial metal and plastic products dropped to $57,623,241 from $79,314,385 a year earlier.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Hollywood -- even the Republican part of it -- was congratulating itself today on having won a Presidential election.

A strong, silent "Protestant vote" cut into Senator John F. Kennedy's margin of victory, an analysis of election returns indicated yesterday. This was offset by a more strategically placed "Catholic vote," which aided the Senator in large states he needed to win.
Prices of high-grade debt securities fluctuated irregularly yesterday in light trading.
Labor in this city has taken the first step in a pioneering effort to unite unions, employers, the medical profession and hospital administrators in holding down the cost of medical care.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Casey Stengel conferred for four hours with executives of the Detroit Tigers today and then advised them to look elsewhere for a manager of their team in 1961.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- The Soviet negotiator refused today to assess the influence that the coming change in the United States Administration might have on the course of the two-year-old nuclear test-ban talks here.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday that the heads of two organizations representing firemen were leaders who upheld the traditions of the department.

The change of Administration from Republican to Democratic will for the first time in six years bring the White House into party alignment with both branches of the Congress. This situation ought to make it a little easier for the new President to carry through his program after he takes office in January, provided he exercises the legislative leadership that is expected of him.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- Chancellor Adenauer suggested today that President-elect John F. Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev should meet "to achieve a rapprochement."
MOSCOW, Nov 10 -- The Soviet Union welcomed today the election of Senator John F. Kennedy to the Presidency as an opportunity to open a new round of East-West negotiations on "cold war" problems.

Carl A. Gerstacker, 44, has been named chairman of Dow Chemical Company, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Earl W. Bennett, 80, who has retired. Leland I. Doan, 66, remains president and chief executive officer.
HAVANA, Nov. 10 -- Baseball, once the favorite sport in this island, is about to become a casualty of the Cuban revolution.
There have been exceptions -- many of them -- but by and large real-estate advertising has lacked warmth, humor and imagination.

Central Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Aileen Timothy Turnbull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Roome Turnbull of 179 East Seventieth Street to Eugene Maxwell Geddes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Geddes of Locust Valley, L.I.
HONOLULU, Nov. 10 -- Hawaii's three electoral votes remained in doubt today pending a probable recount in the Presidential race.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The General Assembly's Credentials Committee recommended tonight the seating of a Congolese delegation headed by President Joseph Kasavubu.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Buyers again moved cautiously in the stock markets here today, apparently still awaiting a more definite reaction from Wall Street to the Presidential election.
Traditionally, Thursday is Red Cross Day on Ivy League campuses.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Vice President Nixon crept slowly ahead of President-elect John P. Kennedy in Alaska's election count today as returns trickled in from outlying places.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Congressional conservatives may have been strengthened in Tuesday's elections but not enough to thwart many items in a progressive program backed by a strong President.

Hampton, Va., borrowed $2,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The city sold an issue of new debt securities at public bidding to a syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. The price paid amounted to an interest cost of 3.1845 per cent.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 -- New Jersey's State Commissioner of Education tonight called upon the teaching profession to provide the leadership to improve the art of teaching.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Unconfirmed reports reaching the State Department tonight said that the South Vietnam Government of President Ngo Dinh Diem had been overthrown by a military group.

Far from the madding crowds that populate the football stadia, one of college sports' more colorful events will be staged for the fifty-second time on Monday. That's the championship cross-country run of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- This aging city on the north rim of the Bronx is about to take a stride toward modernization by building a $7,500,000 high school on a big campus.
JAN PEERCE and Licia Albanese made their first appearances of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. They sang their familiar roles of Rodolfo and Mimi in Puccini's "La Boheme."
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The eleventh Salon des Oiseaux, or bird show, gave its opening squawks and chirps today at the Hotel Moderne on the Place de la Republique.
YONKERS, Nov. 10 -- Bye Bye Byrd, the capitalist of harness racing, rebuffed the challenge of a 20-1 shot in the stretch tonight to win the $58,700 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

The wholesale commodity price index climbed from a ten-year-low of 82.6, registered on Friday and Monday to 83 on Wednesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 86 on Nov. 6, 1959. There was no report for Tuesday, Election Day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 -- Senator John F. Kennedy has recorded a lead of 37,146 votes over Vice President Nixon in California, This figure is based on the actual votes cast behind the curtained polling booths all over California on Tuesday by 6,250,000 voters.
Following are newspaper editorial comments gathered by The New York Times, the Associated Press and United Press International on the election of Senator John F. Kennedy to the Presidency.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 10 -- Lyndon B. Johnson, the Vice President-elect, is eager to play a strong supporting role in the Kennedy Administration, especially since he feels that his work in the South helped to clinch Tuesday's victory.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union reaffirmed today that it would never agree to the enlargement of key United Nations councils until Communist China was admitted to membership.

Business loans of the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City declined $88,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to a report yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Thomas J. Watson Jr., president of International Business Machines, Inc., proposed today that the United States embark on a program to raise educational standards in Latin America.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 -- An educator suggested today that the Jewish community support Government aid to Jewish schools instead of maintaining a "dogmatic and inflexible policy" on church-state issues. He drew a swift rebuttal.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Under the system of permanent personal registration operating for the first time in a Presidential year in New York City a record number of voters were eligible to cast their ballots on Nov. 8. According to early reports in The Times on Nov. 9, 85 to 90 per cent of those eligible cast their ballots.
A trade agreement involving oil and pipeline materials has been arranged between the Soviet and Italian governments that would link one major sector of the Italian economy to the Soviet bloc.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Friday, Nov. 11 -- Brazil's Federal transportation workers voted late last night to resume work at 7 o'clock this morning. A Government show of strength forced the workers' leaders to reverse an earlier decision to maintain the three-day-old nation-wide strike.
Stocks beat off a wave of selling in the hour before noon yesterday and advanced to the best gain so far this year. It was the eighth successive advance.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower expects meet with President-elect John F. Kennedy here over the Thanksgiving week-end, Nov. 24-27.

A NINETEENTH century English painter who freed color and three contemporary Californians who are putting it back into a new harness are represented in excellent exhibitions that opened this week on Tuesday and Wednesday respectively.

Showing surprising speed in the late stages, the New York Knickerbockers came hopefully close to breaking a five-game losing streak last night before bowing to the unbeaten Philadelphia Warriors, 116-112, at Madison Square Garden.

TORONTO, Nov. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Rio Algom Mines, Ltd., has reported a net profit in the three months ended on Sept. 30 of $2,670,000, or 27 cents a share, compared with $3,840,000 by predecessor companies in the 1959 period.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are those who hopefully commend the United Nations for continuing the debates on disarmament, despite their futility and redundancy, on the theory that words are less dangerous than bombs.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 11 -- An army battalion chief announced today that he had cast aside any loyalty to the neutralist Government and rallied instead to the pro-Western Rightist side in Laos' political triangle.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- The main outlines of 1961 fund-raising objectives and methods for American Jewish communities was formulated here today at the twenty-ninth general assembly of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds.

Steel production during October amounted to 6,865,000 tons, against 6,458,000 in September and 1,704,000 in October, 1959, during the steel strike, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The New York City Ballet last night gave Jerome Robbins' "Afternoon of a Faun" and George Balanchine's "Stars and Stripes" their first performances of the current City Center season.
"IT will not be forgotten that Solomon sang of 'an orchard of pomegranates.'" This is the unforgettable information regarding the fruit contained in one food encyclopedia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Eisenhower and his foreign policy aides followed closely today the reports of ferment in South Vietnam and Laos.

Uneasy lie the heads today that have been fitted for college football's major crowns. Yale, Minnesota, Missouri and other teams that stand on the threshold of glory face opponents of stumbling-block potentialities on this next-to-the-last Saturday of the season for all except a few late finishers.

LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Britain's automobile industry faced a mounting crisis today as more than 30,000 additional workers of the giant British Motor Corporation (B.M.C.) were switched to part-time employment.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Princeton and Yale, each undefeated in five Ivy League football games this season, will meet in the Yale Bowl tomorrow. The game time is 1:30 P.M.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The grain futures market hit bottom hard today in corn, oats and rye, while soybeans and old crop wheat contracts attracted strong support and moved well ahead.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 11 -- The unrest in Saigon today emphasized a point Thai leaders have been trying to make in recent weeks-that Thailand should receive priority economic and military aid from the United States because she is the only really stable bulwark of anti-communism in Southeast Asia.
A day in the country, often a panacea for those afflicted with pernicious quarterback sneaks and chronic off-tackle slants, may prove less than a tonic today for three city teams.
HAVANA, Nov. 11 -- An attempt to halt the exodus of professionals and technicians from Cuba is being made by the Castro regime through an intensive propaganda campaign.

As a step to bring order out of the Congo chaos, the Credentials Committee of the United Nations General Assembly has voted to recognize the delegation headed by President Kasavubu and has rejected the rival delegation representing the deposed Premier Lumumba. As the Assembly has always ratified the committee's action, it must be expected to do so in the present case.
Air and sea links between the United States and Cuba have been sharply curtailed in the last year as a result of the deterioration of United States-Cuba relations and subsequent trade restrictions.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Ground-work was laid today for a demand that the new Administration and Congress pay more attention to state legislatures.

Land with a frontage of 300 feet on Lincoln Highway in South Kearny, N.J., has been sold by the Pennsylvania Railroad to the American Handling Equipment Company. The site is adjacent to a plant bought recently by American Handling from the United States Steel Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. put majority members of the House Committee on Education and Labor to work today, nearly two months before the convening of the Eighty-seventh Congress.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 11 -- New Jersey school teachers were urged by Gov. Robert B. Meyner tonight to seek political support for additional taxes to finance state education.
Two large-scale film adaptations of classic French novels, Voltaire's "Candide" and Mme. de La Fayette's "La Princesse de Cleves," are nearing completion in France.

BIDDING systems in contract bridge are based on the principle that a partnership needs eight trumps in the combined hands, and bids are designed to find a trump suit in which the combined holding is eight cards or more.
NEXT Monday, Aaron Copland will celebrate his sixtieth birthday. This weekend, almost as if by design, he is conducting the New York Philharmonic's three subscription concerts in Carnegie Hall.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 -- Bald Eagle of the Cain Hoy Stable won the $100,000 Washington D.C. International for the second year in a row today. With Manuel Ycaza keeping him in front all the way, Bald Eagle scored by two lengths over the Sa-Je Stable's Harmonizing.

RIO DB JANEIRO, Nov. 11 -- A United States-built atomic reactor for research and the production of isotopes -- Brazil's second in three years-was installed today at the Engineering School of the University of Minas Gerais at Belo Horizonte.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 -- Gov. Jimmie H. Davis speeded today a special session of the Legislature to block the Integration of New Orleans schools. The Legislature will meet Sunday instead of Tuesday.

VALLEY SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Two children crawled through chilling darkness up a 200-foot cliff last night, then walked three miles home to tell their father of the automobile accident that killed four members of his family.
Marilyn Monroe, Hollywood's foremost symbol of glamour, and Arthur Miller, Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, have separated.

Those who were fortunate enough to get into Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night heard a magnificent piano recital by Claudio Arrau. The Chilean pianist was in his best form, playing a program in homage to Chopin and Schumann, both of whom were born 150 years ago.
Ed. Duchini led Power Memorial Academy to the team championship yesterday in the sixteenth annual Irish Christian Brothers high schools' cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Sir Hugh Taylor, president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation, said tonight that the "emerging nations and underdeveloped areas of Africa, Asia and South America offer the greatest challenge that has confronted American youth since World War II."

A NEW addition to the traditional Thanksgiving decor -- the nuts, Indian corn, fall leaves, fruit, pumpkins -- is the squash at Peb's, 146 East Fifty-eighth Street. This store has scooped out a large squash and filled it with imitation fruits and vegetables to make an imaginative holiday centerpiece.
ALGIERS, Nov. 11 -- Several thousand young men of Algiers rioted and fought with the police today in a "patriotic" demonstration in favor of a "French Algeria."

BAROQUE and rococo drawings, Italian and French, of irreproachable fancy and deftness yield, in the old master drawing show at Jacques Seligmann's, 5 East Fifty-seventh Street, to some outstandingly important nineteenth-century French drawings.

Lyndon Baines Johnson is at the moment the Vice-President-elect, the Senator and Senator-elect from Texas, the majority leader of the Senate and one of the most effective, resourceful and ambitious men in American politics. When he has doffed all his other titles, he will spend the next four years as Vice President of the United States and, if he remains in character, he will make of that office a center of restless activity.
South Vietnam and Laos, which were buffeted yesterday by new political storms, were once parts of France's overseas domains.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 11 -- Vice President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson confirmed today that he would attend the parliamentarians conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Paris starting Nov. 20.

THE life story of Marilyn Monroe, nee Norma Jean Baker, is a kind of nightmare soap opera, particularly in her early years. Somebody once called it "Oliver Twist in girl's clothing."
