TORONTO, Nov. 11 (Canadian Press) -- The United States equestrian team tonight won the first round In the international jumping competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.

The victory-starved New York Knickerbocker's finally found a basketball team they could beat and a king-sized crowd to see them do it.

TO THE EDITOR: Senator Jacob K. Javits' contribution to your symposium "Thoughts On Fame: Infamous and Otherwise" (Oct. 23) that "those who hunger for fame most usually never taste it" is pure milk of the Word; indeed, it is the modern version of the apothegm, "He who pursues honor, honor flees from him."

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 12 -- The search for Vincent J. Squillante is nearing the end of its first month. The reputed head of the garbage collection rackets in Nassau County is now being caught by the Federal Bureau of investigation as well as the county police.

IT is important to realize that monkeys have souls -- at least in the eyes of certain Chinese and Indian people. So, when the weather gets cold in oriental parts, any monkeys that are hanging about and likely to freeze to death are rounded up by the pious locals and put aboard special trains that carry them home to their native jungle.

A LITTLE more than a year ago, Gilbert Briggs, author of a number of books on high fidelity, asked the question, "Do you think tape will ever achieve worthwhile performance at the 3 3/4 inches-per-second speed?"

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 -- Lacking a smashing mandate, President-elect John F. Kennedy began this week-end to shape major administration policies and appointments in the shadow of an unexpectedly thin hair-line margin of victory over Vice President Nixon.
An unusual service organization has been provided at Colonnade Park, the new apartment house community recently completed in downtown Newark.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Tom Singleton was the hero of a shining hour for the Yale football team today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 12 -- The leader of secessionist South Kasai threatened today to order another military offensive unless the United Nations forces halted what he described as a massacre of his Baluba tribesmen by their traditional enemies.

POLITICS makes strange bedfellows and sometimes even splendid box-office. Aristophanes may not have been the first to discover this, but the ancient Athenian must have been one of the earlier dramatists to find that there could be profit in hurling satiric barbs at the political foibles of his time.

WHEN the implausible and mercurial Johnny Blood became the playing coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers some twenty-odd years ago, he stationed himself on the goal line for the opening kick-off of the opening game. The ball spun through the autumn air and landed in his arms.

BASED on the proposition that the path leading to the public's affections is twofold, possessing both visual and gastronomic branches, the forty-fifth National Hotel Exposition opens at the New York Coliseum tomorrow for a four-day run.

ALONG the streets where I work, Broadway, Madison Avenue and Sunset Boulevard, my private career of writing books for children stops conferences. It disrupts production meetings. Client negotiations come to a stop with the question "Why?" sharper scrutiny of some of the values by which I lived. So that the complete answer to why I write books for children is that I find it therapeutic, it's a way of doing myself some good.
A pre-theatre buffet at the New York Yacht Club and a party at the Dec. 2 evening performance of "The Unsinkable Molly Brown," will benefit the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

FOR those who have found, in the vastness of the polar regions, a special serenity and cleansing of the soul, Herbert G. Ponting has, for almost half a century, been the photographic master. His artistry caught the grandeur of Antarctica; it revealed the spirit of the men who, with Capt, Robert F. Scott, made the fatal dash to the South Pole in 1911-12.
FOOTBALL Unbeaten Yale routed Princeton yesterday for a clear Ivy League lead. Purdue toppled previously undefeated Minnesota. Scores of leading games:

PERHAPS it is because we have come to expect so much from Mary Stolz -- more than we get from almost any other writer for older girls -- that her first collection of short stories is a little disappointing. The compact form does not allow for the gradual unfolding of personality, the intricate development of situations, the colorful secondary characters and the detailed backgrounds which are the hallmarks of her novels.

STOCKHOLM. TWO years ago, on a November night, Ingmar Bergman handed me a poem entitled "The Virgin Spring" and said, "read this!" At that time I knew nothing about the thirteenth-century ballad that dealt with a miracle that followed a rape (see photo above).

The Cancer Foundation of the Variety Club of New York will benefit from a buffet luncheon, fashion show and dance to be held Dec. 4 in the Ballroom of the Sheraton-East. At the event a queen will be elected to reign over the Jamaica and Antigua Carnival Ball at the hotel Feb. 14.

AARON COPLAND writes about music in the same way that he composes. The qualities of clarity, liveliness, elegance, precision and directness which distinguish his music make him a fine essayist. And, beneath the clear and simple surface of both lies a wealth of ideas.

GERALD DURRELL is a collecting naturalist with a sense of humor, an ability to write, a feeling for animals and an enormous capacity for locating the extraordinary. He wrote, several years ago, under the title of "The Bafut Beagles," a hilarious account of zoological collecting in a small and quite unsophisticated principality in the Cameroons ruled over by a gentleman called the Fon who had a prodigious thirst and a very warm heart.

THOSE who remember Hervey Allen's "Anthony Adverse" will recognize the pattern in Winchcombe Taylor's narrative of the global adventures of Ram Anstruther. He is introduced as an infant clinging to the corpse of his mother in a wrecked coach near a battleground in 1706 -- the field of Ramillies, one of the many settings for the Duke of Marlborough's continental forays against the enemies of England.
The Port of New York played host to more international travelers by ship and air during the first ten months of this year than it did during all of 1959.

LONDON. MORE than 20,000 books were published in Britain last year. Of these, a tenth were children's books, the second largest category, about half the size of that of fiction. They came in all kinds and all shapes, rag books for babies, books run up by hacks for the undiscriminating, books by people who have the right to be called craftsmen engaged on professional jobs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The 1960 Presidential election is bound to have important effects on the structure, leadership and future policy directions of the Democratic and Republican parties. These effects will be clearly visible in the executive acts of the next President, the legislative product of Congress, the national organization of the Democratic party, and the prospective rivalry in the Republican party for the nomination in 1964.

IF there is any virtue in probabilities, something more than 400 black bears will have been shot to death in New York State before the end of the current big game seasons. Most of them will be the chance victims of deer hunters.

Two West Germans and a Yugoslav qualified for the interzone women's chess competition that will be held at Mar del Plata, Argentina, next April by finishing in a tie for first place in the Western Zone tournament.

THE New York City Ballet is the most modest and unassuming of institutions. It came back to the City Center on Tuesday without a single novelty on its first week's schedule, and it chose Election Night for its premiere as if to make sure of trickling in without attracting too much attention.

IT is impossible to choose between these two collections of Celtic folktales, for they both evoke the magic of which they speak. The Welsh one has more, but shorter stories, and some of the pictures are in color; the Scottish one is perhaps more romantic in tone.
The most valuable land in the years ahead, a land economist predicts, will be around high-ways, airports and shopping and industrial centers.

To the Music Editor: IN his thoughtful article on contests, Ross Parmenter stated, they "left some gnawing questions.'' Perhaps I can answer some of them to clarify the picture, at least as far as the Board of Directors of the Naumburg Foundation sees it.
MINEOLA, L.I. Nov. 12 -- Milk could be purchased for as little as 5 cents a quart on Long Island today as a result of a spreading price war among milk distrubutors in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- In the lives of all Columbia football players -- past and present -- this was a most eventful day at Franklin Field. On this sunny afternoon, Columbia beat Pennsylvania on the gridiron for the first time since 1937.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The director of the Ford Foundation Fund, for the Advancement of Education has urged all states to set up a central agency to improve education.
After Close Race John Fitzgerald Kennedy has said of the office he captured last Tuesday:

THREE or four centuries ago, according to a somewhat oversimplified picture, the Western world was religious in its basic presuppositions. Religion in general and the Christian faith in particular constituted the glue that held together the arts and sciences, the lubrication that aided the meshing of social processes.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 12 -- Missouri beat determined Oklahoma, 41-19, today after the Sooners had fumbled away an apportunity to topple the nation's No. 2 college football team from the unbeaten and untied ranks.
The eighth annual luncheon of the National Women's Division of the American Friends of the Hebrew Universty will be held tomorrow in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The destroyers, once the cavalry of the fleet, now face a functional crisis in design that will shape their future.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 11 -- Vice President Nixon ran one of the "worst" Presidential campaigns in recent years, according" to an analysis of the election, by some of Senator John F. Kennedy's closest associates.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Bill Kilmer of the University of California at Los Angeles went on an 88-yard touchdown irun from scrimmage as the Bruins beat the Air Force, 22 -- 0, today.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Favored Phillips Andover Academy spotted Phillips Exeter three touchdowns and then stormed back to gain an 18-18 tie in the eightieth game of the nation's oldest schoolboy football rivalry today before 6,500 fans at Brothers Field.

Park Commissioner Newbold Morris, whose family has been active here since the days before the Revolution, will address the 175th anniversary celebration of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen next Saturday night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 11 -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said last night that crash programs, no matter how expensive, could not solve metropolitan area problems unless they were made part of an over-all Federal urban program.
Archaeological excavations at Shechem, Israel's first capital, have established that the Biblical Abimelech reigned briefly about 1150 B.C., Harvard University said yesterday.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Mississippi crushed Tennessee, 24 -- 3, today on the passing of Jake Gibbs and the running of James Anderson.

A crowd of 60,000 is expected to see the New York Giants play the Pittsburgh Steelers at Yankee Stadium today. The New Yorkers are slight favorites in the National Football League contest, which will get Under way at 2:05 P.M.

MOST Americans recall the Nisei combat team that fought so valiantly in Italy in World War II. Less well known is the fact that several thousand Japanese-Americana served elsewhere with great distinction. This splendid novel, grounded on fact, tells the story of a young Nisei who proves himself in combat in Burma.

THE audience in New York's old Aeolian Hall that afternoon in 1925 was unhappy. Walter Damrosch had just led the New York Symphony Orchestra in a new symphony by a young and unknown American composer. The public-conservative and predominantly female -- did its best to hide a sense of acute displeasure.

TWO Canadian airlines -- Trans-Canada Air-Lines and Canadian Pacific Airlines -- have lighted beacons for their fellow and rompeting airlines to follow on and after Jan. 2, when a whole new schedule of passenger fares, with many reductions, larger free baggage allowances, cheaper excess baggage charges and excursion rates will be introduced on Canadian routes and trans-border flights between Canadian and United States cities.
Artur Rubinstein's first recital of the 1961 season at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 17 will be the annual benefit for the Recreation Service for the Children of Bellevue.

THE romantic vision of the world as a spectacle of grandeur and catastrophe, and the romantic search for the spirit of nature "whose dwelling is the light of setting suns" finds its greatest and most heroic embodiment in the art of J.M.W. Turner.

NEWARK, Del., Nov. 12 -- Rutgers University clinched its second Middle Atlantic Conference football championship in three years with a 22-0 victory over Delaware before 7,500 fans today. The triumph gave a 4-0 won-lost record to the Scarlet in Conference competition and was the victors' seventh success in eight games this fall.
Taxes should not be reduced until the nation's schools are improved, Eric A. Johnston, president of the American Motion Picture Association, has told several thousand educators.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Former President Truman arrived here today with a drumfire of observations on Tuesday's election.

ALGIERS, Nov. 12 -- The possibility of an experiment in western Algeria in applying a "unilateral truce" to the six-year-old Algerian war was reported here tonight. No confirmation of the project was available, however.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- In a recent book Salvador de Madariaga writes somewhat bitterly of the chaos and incoherence that afflict Labor party opinion in Britain and the resultant deplorable effects on British foreign policy.

The period between the election of a President and his inauguration was shortened considerably by the Twenty-second Amendment. But there is still a gap of more than two months between the day when the candidate usually knows that he has been elected and the day when he takes the oath of office. This gap has never been bridged with complete success.

A new barge built especially to carry Saturn boosters for space vehicles is on its way to the George C. Marshall Flight Center at Huntsville, Ala., from where the vessel will take the boosters to the launching site at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

IN his latest novel of merchant-marine life (the sixth of his steadily improving invention) Robert Mirvish recounts the story of Steen Carton, and his tempering in the fires of two great loves. Steen has grown up in a waterfront section of Baltimore known as The Block.

AUTHOR of several novels for teen-agers, Elisabeth Ogilvie addresses her latest book to a younger age group. The coast of Maine is again her background and her protagonists are two island boys, cousins and best friends, Eric Marshall and Jamie Sorensen.
THE Vineyard Gazette, published weekly (twice a week in summer) on the island of Martha's Vineyard, Mass., is ordinarily a conservative newspaper with small headlines and an old-fashioned air.

TOO often, adventure stories for children fail because the young heroes meet their problems with maturity unnatural for their years. This frustrating element is happily lacking in Marion Garthwaite's beautifully told story of Mario.

The item: a ballpoint pen, returned to New Orleans Postmaster Frank Fairley. The message: "Other night I had to take this pen from the post office because my fountain pen became dry. Of course that's a low excuse. But it was late at night and I had to write."

This week's exhibitions include a large number of one-man shows of painting and sculpture by new and unfamiliar artists. Veteran artists on the list are Alexander Brook, Reuben Nakian, Kurt Seligmann, and Simon Elwes.

ON opening day Roger Maris hit two home runs, a double and a single, thereby supplying his own fireworks in his debut as a Yankee. RIVERHEAD, L.I, Nov. 13 -- The Suffolk County Planning Commission recommended today that the county adopt now an $8,000,000 program to buy 11,300 acres for parks and conservation. It recommended that Suffolk sell an $8,000,000 bond issue to finance the purchases.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- A great deal was heard in Europe during the United States Presidential campaign of the youth, vigor, intelligence and erudition of Senator John F. Kennedy. Mayor Wagner was criticized yesterday as a "fence sitter" by Representative-elect William Fitts Ryan of Manhattan, a Democratic reform leader. Mr. Ryan implied that the reform group might oppose Mr. Wagner's renomination if he sought a third term.

Week Ended Nov. 10, 1960 The past week was a short one in the foreign exchange market as banks were closed here on Tuesday, Election Day, and Friday, Veterans Day. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar were generally steady.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns, after building a 14-0 edge, had to fight today to score a 28-27 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. By winning, the Browns remained, in contention in the National Football League's Eastern Conference.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Thirty thousand hairdressers from forty countries assembled here yesterday for the first World Festival of Coiffure to be held in Paris in fifteen years. Half of the participants were French.

Three boy football players were hit by stray bullets yesterday afternoon during a Little League game in Flushing, Queens. None was injured seriously.

Because of their bountiful supply in France, they frequently are referred to as the poor man's asparagus. Since leeks are rather costly whenever available locally, they could logically be called in this country the rich man's asparagus.

A vivacious 4-year-old girl has been named the 1961 poster child of the New March of Dimes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : One of the more constructive byproducts of the Presidential campaign is Senator Kennedy's suggestion to allow young people to serve in a "peace corps" in under-developed countries as an alternative to military service.

CHRISTMAS shopping done well ahead of the rush, in a charming setting off the beaten track is an ideal achieved by few. Ordinarily it is accomplished only by farsighted travelers who pack their Christmas lists in their suitcases.
OSLO, Norway, Nov. 13 -- Princess Astrid, 28 - year - old daughter of King Olav V, will marry a 33-year-old commoner, an announcement said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Price swings in the grain futures market were somewhat broader than usual this week in generally heavy trading, but the trend was downward and losses in most contracts ran more than 2 cents a bushel.
DALLAS, Nov. 13 -- The nation's increased capacity for financing home purchases may make it possible for eight out of ten American families to own their homes by the end of the coming decade.
A convention of barbers quieted down long enough yesterday to learn how to make a man hold still for a $4.50 haircut.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The President-elect's wife is the former Jacqueline Bouvier. It is also fairly common knowledge that her mother is Mrs Hugh D. Auchincloss, wife of a Washington and New York investment banker.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 13 -- Two hundred children were being held hostage today by rebel forces barricaded in a church boarding school in the town of Diriamba, just south of this capital city.

Three of Norman Corwin's enormous output of radio plays have been tied together in one bill by the author for stage production. They are "The Undecided Molecule" (1945), "The Odyssey of Runyon Jones" (1941) and "The Descent of the Gods" (1941).
NAHA, Okinawa, Monday, Nov. 14 -- Early returns from yesterday's elections for the legislature of the Ryukyu Islands indicated a victory for the pro - American Liberal - Democratic party.

HAVANA, Nov. 13--Groups of youthful Castro followers marched into the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Santiago de Cuba this morning in an attempt to prevent the reading of a pastoral letter issued by Archbishop Enrique Perez Cerantes. The letter was sharply critical of communism.

A performers' union and the national radio and television networks will resume contract negotiations at 10:30 A.M. today in the Columbia Broadcasting System Building, 485 Madison Avenue. Contracts will expire at midnight tomorrow.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13 -- President Arturo Frondizi pictured the Roman Catholic Church and the armed forces today as allies of the people in under-developed countries seeking economic advancement.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 13 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem smiled in triumph from the steps of his palace this morning as he reviewed a parade by thousands of soldiers, marines and civilians.

A man locked in a car trunk by gunmen for nearly six hours Saturday night saved his life by using a tire iron to force a tiny hole to get air in the sealed trunk. Another man trapped in the trunk of another car died of suffocation.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- A 13-inch beagle unknown in he East, even to her handler, came out of California to win best in show tonight in the thirty-fourth event of the Onondaga Kennel Association. She vas Ch. Wandering Cinderella, a 2-year-old dog belonging to Arthur and Carroll Gordon of Menlo Park.

The Raymond Vernon book "Metropolis 1985," summing up and interpreting the previous volumes of a massive study for the Regional Plan Association by the Harvard University School of Public Administration, fulfills its assignment and its responsibility. It leaves to the people of the tri-state New York metropolitan region the task and challenge of creating the "more tolerable metropolitan environment" that Mr. Vernon concludes is our objective.
A Coast Guard hearing examiner last week dismissed the last remaining charge, of negligence brought by the Government against the second mate of the liner Santa Rosa.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- President Kasavubu said today that there was "something wrong" in the United Nations report that accused the Congolese of having invited the Belgians back to their former colony.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 George Blanda to defeat the (AP) -- Jack Kemp hit Ralph Anderson for two touchdowns in the first quarter and the Los Angeles Chargers stood off a counter aerial attack by Houston Oilers, 24-21, today.
The Senior Warden of Trinity Parish, Protestant Episcopal, substituted for the rector yesterday in inducting the Rev. William W. Reed as vicar of Trinity's Mission of the Lower East Side.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Keeping a close watch on the American elections and Wall Street's reaction to them, the stock market had a cautious week with a small decline in the industrial index.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The long awaited conference to review the Constitution of the Federation of Northern and Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland will open here Dec. 5, the Common-wealth Relations Office announced today.
Col. Edward Carey, executive director of the Salvation Army, said yesterday that all Christian organizations, lay and clerical, shared the task of propagating the Gospel.

Macey-Fowler, Inc., has leaded a floor in the new Pepsi Cola Building, 500 Park Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street, for the sale of office furniture and equipment. James J. Prior, a vice president of William A. White Sons, was the broker.

Treasury agents smashed a smuggling ring of Chinese art dealers yesterday. The agents recovered masterpieces valued at more than $400,000 that they said had been brought into this country from Communist China.
Similar in-and-out patterns figured in the scoring of the New York Football Giants and the Pittsburgh Steelers in yesterday's game at Yankee Stadium.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Fifty-six senior executives of commercial banks in all parts of the country arrived here today to attend the second annual session of the Commercial Bank Management Program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department predicted today that farm income in 1961 -- the first year of the new Democratic Administration -- would continue at about this year's level. Democrats have promised to put more money in farm pockets.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A menu is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency has developed a method of airport runway lighting so cheap and effective that it may be used at even the smallest airports.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 -- The New York Hakoahs defeated the Baltimore Pompei, 3 -- 0, in an American Soccer League game at Kahler Park today.
A 12-year-old girl who is allergic to fur was allowed to pet a 12-foot python in the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Johnny Unites, blood streaming down his face from gouges on the cheek and brow, today hurled a 39-yard scoring pass to Lenny Moore in the final forty-two seconds of the game as the Baltimore Colts scored a 24 -- 20 victory over the Chicago Bears.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 -- Moses L. Feuerstein of Maiden, Mass., was unanimously elected today for his fourth two-year term as president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America.

A New York broadcasting company reported last night that it had, signed an agreement with the Israeli Government by which it would make a complete recording of the trial of Adolf Eichmann for showing on television and motion picture screens.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 13 -- President Cemal Gursel announced today that he had dismissed fourteen of the thirty-seven members of the National Unity Committee.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 13 -- Latin America has pinned such high hopes on the election of President-elect John F. Kennedy that diplomats are worried about what will happen if the United States does not meet the expectations.
GENEVA, Nov. 13 -- Swiss investors jumped the gun on Wall Street last week in calling the Democratic victory.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy last night curtailed traditional police participation in a meeting of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association scheduled for tomorrow.

An account of the migration of American artists to Paris is given by Yvon Bizardel in "American Painters in Paris," which Macmillan will publish on Nov. 21. Beginning in Colonial days with Benjamin West and John Singleton Copley, the story moves up to the end of the nineteenth century and shortly thereafter and ends with James McNeill Whistler, John Singer Sargent and Mary Cassatt.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- A sixteen-hour school day was urged today by the president-elect of the New York State Citizens Committe for the Public Schools.

Except for selected specialty issues among industrial stocks, over-the-counter shares generally went their own way last week. Most issues failed to take a clue from the post-election rally on the New York Stock Exchange.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 13 -- Under United States prodding, the Bonn Government has drawn up a foreign assistance program for 1961 that goes far beyond any previous effort by West Germany to extend aid abroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The Philadelphia Eagles, who were expected to roll up the score against the Washington Redskins, narrowly escaped a stunning upset by their National Football League rivals today.
ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- New York State is on the verge of a dramatic acceleration of its highway building program.
Permanent personal registration "functioned very well this year," James M. Power, president of the Board of Elections, declared yesterday.

Tanker operators are expected to affirm their opposition on Thursday to plans suggested by the Army Corps of Engineers as alternatives to deepening the Kill van Kull and Arthur Kill, between New Jersey and Staten Island.

Chief City Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch disclosed yesterday that he had warned several lawyers handling an "inordinate" number of gambling cases in Gamblers Court that their activities were being "carefully scrutinized."

THE student of contract bridge strives for perfection and often considers it reasonable to suppose that perfect bidding and play can be achieved; but it has been demonstrated in both theory and practice that even the best players are incapable of playing perfectly over any protracted period.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Pentagon threatened today to draft medical doctors for the first time in three years unless more internes enlisted in the Army, Navy and Air Force.

DALLAS, Nov. 14 -- A formal concordat permitting the 2,000,000-member Philippine independent church to enter into full communion with the Protestant Episcopal Church in this country was presented here today to the House of Bishops of the latter church.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 14 -- Following are transcripts of the news conferences held today by President-elect John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon following their meeting:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The three military services, joined by the civilian space agency, are building a satellite designed to help map the earth with new accuracy.

For some time leaders of organized labor have complained about the increasingly high costs of medical and hospital care. Union officials have bitterly attacked each of the big rate raises which have been allowed to Blue Cross and several unions' plans for "direct action" to cut costs have been proposed or put into effect in the New York area.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Disorderly conduct charges against eight Negroes who tried to enroll children at an all-white school here were dismissed in City Court today by Judge Robert J. Burton.
ROME, Nov. 14 -- Pope John XXIII inaugurated today the preparatory phase of the forthcoming ecumenical, or universal, council of the Roman Catholic Church.
A political sociologist said yesterday that Vice President Nixon could have won the election if he had spoken out more forcefully and more specifically against anti-Catholic bigotry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A belief that President-elect John F. Kennedy will propose to Congress a sweeping reorganization of the foreign aid program is gaining ground here.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- West Germany's intention to establish a large-scale program of foreign assistance wag given a cautious welcome here today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -- A leading economist said here today that the brightest spot on the 1961 economic horizon was construction.

IN "The Alligators" Molly Kazan has written a role full of pride and poignancy, and Jo Van Fleet plays it with furious intensity. This performance in itself justifies a trip to the York Playhouse, where Mrs, Kazan's double bill, beginning with "Rosemary," opened last night.
BQCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 14 -- Southern newspaper publishers were urged today to help make the South the nation's No. 1 economic success.

Investor attention turned reluctantly yesterday from the envisioned bright mornings of 1961 and 1962 to the setting sun of 1960. There were discourag- ing developments for steels and motors and some of the oils and the market took them into account.
A monkey-eating harpy eagle, captured in a net camouflaged with hundreds of wild orchids, arrived in town yesterday with a lean and hungry look.

Boeing engineers for a time either overlooked or did not believe advice about the power of a woman, particularly of a woman dressed to the nth degree of fashion. More specifically, the airplane manufacturing company has confessed, it did not prepare for those extrathin spike heels.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Britain's soccer fans, numbered in the millions, were faced today with the possibility of a strike by players on their favorite clubs.

"MONEY MONEY MONEY,"* by Ralph G. Martin and Morton D. Stone, is an amazing book of travel and adventure. It presents a stimulating safari through brightest Wall Street in words and pictures -- glowing words and brilliant pictures. See it now and you may imagine an immodest fortune awaiting you down there.

President Eisenhower meets with Treasury Secretary Anderson today in what is officially described as an "important conference" to give a Presidential send-off to Mr. Anderson's and Under Secretary Dillon's mission to European capitals next week. This mission is being dispatched in view of the changing political and economic climate in the world.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 14 -- The United Nations agreed in principle today to contribute token contingents of its international military force in the Congo to a Congolese National Army parade here later this week.
When the North German Lloyd liner Berlin sails for Bremerhaven today she will be primarily a tourist-class vessel.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 14 -- President Eisenhower summoned the Secretary of the Treasury, Robert B. Anderson, today for what the White House termed an "important conference" here tomorrow on United States economic and technical aid to underdeveloped areas.
"The theatre is a dwindling business in an expanding economy," according to Robert Whitehead, president of the League of New York Theatres, the organization of stage producers and theatre operators.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 14 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon held an hour-long conference today amid signs that Mr. Kennedy might be seeking a government of national unity that would include liberal Republicans.
City College plans to use a closed-circuit television system for instruction in its classrooms.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- M.J. Rathbone, president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) deplored today the Soviet Union's thrust into Western markets with cut-rate oil.

A preview of an exhibition of paintings entitled "Birds and Beasts from the Museum of Modern Art" will be held Dec. 2 at the Country Art Gallery, Westbury, L.I., for the benefit of the museum's thirtieth anniversary fund drive.

Jose Gonzalez, a 20-year-old Puerto Rican welterweight, scored the most important victory of his career last night when he gained a majority decision over Isaac Logart of Cuba in the ten-round feature at St. Nicholas Arena.
An amendment to the city Health Code requiring that all gas refrigerators be connected to a flue leading to the open air is being prepared by the Department of Health.

The Government's seven-year international oil cartel antitrust action against two of the nation's largest petroleum companies -- the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Gulf Oil Corporation -- was ended yesterday in Federal Court here with the entry of a consent judgment.
TOKYO, Nov. 14 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda pledged Japan's assistance and cooperation "with even greater vigor" today to the economic development of the less advanced nations.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The secrecy and sanctity of the ballot is a basic tenet of our democracy. It is guaranteed by the Constitution.
THE newest shopper's paradise in the city is in the Brooklyn Museum, where a Mexican market has transformed the dignified, echoing entrance hall into a scene as colorful and noisy as a circus.
A Soviet scientist has predicted disaster, instead of prosperity, if a countryman's proposal to dam the Bering Strait is carried out.
Residence requirements for public welfare applicants serve no useful purpose and should be abolished, speakers said yesterday at the opening of the New York State Welfare Conference here.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Andre Jacomet, former Secretary General of the French administration in Algeria, announced today his intention to fight a Government order dismissing him for the expression of opposition to official policy.

Patrons and patronesses have been announced for the fortieth annual "Ye Olde English Faire," staged by the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women in Ossining, N.Y.
Against the Skyscraper Nearly every day of the year in this city old buildings are in the process of being torn down and new buildings are in the process of being erected.

A far-reaching reorganization of operations in Asia, Africa and Australia was announced yesterday by the nation's two largest oil companies, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc.
A "summit conference" of labor and management in the bus industry before engaging in collective bargaining was urged by a union leader yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 14 -- President Cemal Gursel's purge of fourteen members of the ruling military junta yesterday was being interpreted here today as a measure to speed the restoration of democratic government in Turkey.

The horse-racing program at Aqueduct started at noon yesterday, but this comparatively early hour didn't hurt the attendance at all. A crowd of 24,587 attended. The feature was a mile race for 3-year-olds.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 14 -- An increase of 16 cents in the Nassau County tax rata was proposed in the 1961 budget made public today.
The Living Theatre, one of Off Broadway's most successful avant-garde groups, has received an invitation to participate in the Theatre des Nations Festival in Paris next June.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The General Assembly's Social Committee approved today a covenant declaring a person's right to protection of the law against interference with his "privacy, family, home or correspondence."
EARLY Christmas shoppers have one sure advantage. By thinking ahead they have the wider scope afforded by specialorder gifts. These often take ten days to a month to receive.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 14 -- The Legislature voted tonight to remove New Orleans education officials who carried out a Federal Court desegregation order.

FOR the first time in ninetytwo years, the Salon of Culinary Art, held annually in New York, will be open to the public. Sponsored by the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique, the exhibition may be visited tonight and tomorrow from 7 P.M. to 11 P.M. at the New York Coliseum.
DALLAS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Abner Haynes, the do-everything halfback of the Dallas Texans, has taken over the lead in rushing in the American Football League.

Top labor leaders met for a second time yesterday with representatives of the United Federation of Teachers. They said afterward that they next wanted to hear the Board of Education's side of the dispute that led to last Monday's teachers' strike.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Following is the text of a letter from Patrice Lumumba, deposed Premier of the Congo, to Frederick H. Boland, President of the General Assembly:
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- In another general sell-off, the grain futures market slumped again today for broad losses that carried corn, oats and rye contracts further into low ground for the season.

The appointment of William Rodney Leathes, formerly the joint managing director of Harrods, a leading department store in London, as vice president in charge of foreign operations for Associated Dry Goods Corporation was announced yesterday by Robert J. McKim, chairman of Associated.
With the city's first Gotham Bowl contest less than a month away, the job of signing two top teams is becoming more difficult.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14 -- Higher operating costs were forecast, while fewer capital improvements and a lower tax rate were proposed today in a 1961 Westchester budget by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian.
Laws to curb landlords who overcharge welfare recipients and to save the city exorbitant hotel expenses were urged here yesterday by Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The stock market started the new two-week bookkeeping account period today on an undecided note.

TAORMINA, Sicily, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Walter C. Ford of the United States Maritime Administration said today that the nuclear-powered merchant ship Savannah could enter any port used by other merchant ships without danger to the local populace.

The New York Rangers, reeling from five straight National Hockey League defeats, yesterday farmed Jack McCartan, the hero of the 1960 winter Olympics, to the Kitchener-Waterloo Beavers of the Eastern Professional Hockey League.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A deplorable flaw in the logic of many who want to be fair-minded is evident in a belief that all bias is practiced by majorities against minorities. The truth is that the biased mind is not neatly limited to numerically larger groups, but can be found in equal proportion in all ethnic, racial and religious groups whatever their site.
The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists reported "some progress in minor areas" yesterday in contract negotiations with the television and radio networks.
A familiar figure will be missing tonight when the New York Knickerbockers meet the Los Angeles Lakers in the finale of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Pierre Wigny, Belgian Foreign Minister, said today that the United Nations operation in the Congo was a "failure."
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 14 -- The National Municipal League was told today that the Gross National Product would be $2,200,000,000,000 by the year 2000.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 14--Three Suffolk County policemen were accused today of lying to the grand jury that is investigating cheating on police tests.
EVEN for the most dedicated advocates of ballet, the thought of a full-length film devoted to six lightweight dance works from an avant-garde French troupe must be a little disconcerting.
John Cowell, composer-pianist from Seattle, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. It was his second appearance in New York. His first was his debut in January, 1956.

ALTHOUGH Oliver Goldsmith has been gone since 1774, he has not been forgotten by his family. Miss Blythe Parsons of East Sixty-third Street, an eighthgeneration niece, was elated by the friendly notices "Uncle Nolly" received, when "She Stoops to Conquer" opened at the Phoenix.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Canada and Iceland told the United Nations today that unless the nuclear arms race was ended at once it would be too late to control it at all. They warned that world destruction was the alternative.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Treasury bill rates jumped sharply again this week, to levels which have been exceeded only two or three times since last spring. It was the second successive weekly increase, and presumably reflected Federal Reserve System, purchases of Government securities other than bills in the last two weeks.

WHEN Earl (Red) Blaik was a 16year-old schoolboy in Dayton, Ohio, the turbulent Miami River broke through the levees and inundated the city. The Dayton flood was his introduction to catastrophe and the retired West Point football coach uses it as the taking-off point for his swift-moving, long-awaited autobiography, "You Have to Pay the Price," written with the unobtrusive ghostly assistance of Tim Cohane.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 -- India was reliably reported today to have placed a sizable order for Soviet aircraft to help develop her northern communications.
Confidence in the ability of he United States to "maintain he edge in world-wide free ompetition" was voiced yesterlay by H. E. Humphreys Jr., chairman of the United States Rubber Company.

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Tire market competition, termed the "most severe in over a decade," caused a decline in sales and earnings of Seiberling Rubber Company for the first nine months of I960, J. P. Seiberling, president, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Hearings were opened today on whether Louisiana should be denied further Federal aid to dependent children. The Department of Health, Education and Welfare argued that funds should be cut off.

As the metropolitan area's scholastic football teams prepared for their final games yesterday, the figures in the won-and-lost columns commanded as much attention as the numbers called from quarterback.
DENVER, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Francis McKinley, a Ute Indian official, said today the Indian must develop "an image of himself, and so must the public, before he can become capable of self-determination."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Average wholesale primary market prices were unchanged in the week ended Nov. 8 at 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. Although processed foods prices registered a slight increase of 0.2 per cent, the averages for farm products and industrial commodities held steady.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 13 points (65 cents a bale) off yesterday. The near months were weakest. To, July, 1962, contrast was steady.
WHEN Lloyd James Rittiner, president of the Orleans Parish School Board, was a boy he used to play baseball with Negroes but "always with the understanding we were on different levels."

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14 -- As in other shows still holding in the main to the Early American line, the Eastern States Antiques Fair at the Westchester County Center here is experiencing some foreign infiltration.

DIRIAMBA, Nicaragua, Nov. 14 -- Sixteen rebels who had held 260 children as hostages in the Christian Brothers boys school here since early Saturday released the youngsters, and surrended today. The surrender came after a two-and-a-half-hour conference between rebel leaders and Msgr. Isidro Caldero, Bishop of Matagalpa.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The Ford Motor Company of the United States is seeking the consent of the British Treasury for a u128,000,000 ($358,400,000) deal that would give it complete ownership of the Ford Motor Company of Britain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The effect and purpose of President-elect Kennedy's visit to Vice President Nixon at Key Biscayne seem to be that while Nixon naturally will continue to assert his political differences, there will be no projection of any personal resentment aroused by the inevitable asperities of a Presidential campaign that will bar the intrusion of other Republicans in the next Administration.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 -- Federal deputy marshals escorted four Negro girls into two white elementary schools today while angry crowds hurled jeers and insults.

Was Benedict Arnold, America's first traitor an unconscionable scoundrel, or was he driven by adverse circumstances into the arms of the enemy? The question is the theme of Cornel Lengyel's new book, "I, Benedict Arnold," which Doubleday will publish Friday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The British Commonwealth asked today to supply the United States with some of the sugar it is no longer buying from Cuba.
The crisp autumn air has quickened the buying intentions of American consumers, according to the National Industrial Conference Board's latest survey for Newsweek magazine.

WHAT the Circle in the Square needs now is coffee and cake. Last night, the impresarios of the hallowed haven of off-Broadway theatre introduced "Stewed Prunes," a revue featuring three zany young performers recently discovered in Greenwich Village tickling the funnybones of coffeehouse patrons.

If the New York Giants are to repeat as Eastern Conference champions of the National Football League, they will have to beat the front-running Philadelphia Eagles twice in the next two weeks -- first at Yankee Stadium and then at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.
FOR one hour last night the Roy L. Robertsons and their family starred in a television program on Channel 4.

MANILA, Tuesday, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Rear Admiral Arthur F. Spring, commander of United States naval forces in the Philippines, was killed with his wife and four other Navy men when their plane crashed into the jungle-covered slopes of Mariveles Mountain, the Navy said today.
NICE, France, Nov. 14 -- Whatever else this week in sports has lacked, it has not lacked violent denunciations in the European press.

Mayor Wagner ordered last night a sweeping investigation of charges of police corruption made by the newly organized Citizens Emergency Committee. He directed Commissioner of Investigation Louis I. Kaplan to "check every phase" of the situation.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Damascus officials said today that 152 school children died in a movie house fire yesterday in the Syrian border town of Amude. The town is in Northeast Syria on the Turkish border.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Carolyn K. Stable's Brandy Sea, a 2-year-old ridden by Bill Hartack, captured the $7,500-added Pimlico Breeders stakes today. The return was $3.40 for $2.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa accused the seven-member City Planning Commission yesterday of being confused in its analysis of the city's financial situation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 14 -- Stockholm's new airport at Arlanda, twenty-five miles north of the center of the city, will go into operation April 1, 1962, Swedish air traffic authorities announced today. This is a year earlier than originally planned.

A fine team effort by Penn State and a sparkling performance by Bobby Lowe of Brown were the top items at the thirty-seventh annual cross-country championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America yesterday.
Hulan E. Jack appeared in court yesterday for the start of his second trial on charges of conspiracy and violation of the city Charter and promptly lost two motions to dismiss the indictment.
An 11-year-old boy did something "just for kicks" that brought death to a house painter yesterday.
Quick action by President-elect John F. Kennedy to permit Government help in limiting the world's population increase was recommended here last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A bitterly divided Supreme Court affirmed today a contempt of Congress conviction based on a refusal to produce records of the Civil Rights Congress.
Lord Beaverbrook, the Canadian-born British newspaper publisher, last night received the Gold Medal Achievement Award of the Canadian Club of New York.

The November potato future contract was sharply higher yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The position, which went off the board yesterday, was under the influence of short covering. The January contract reflected the strength in the spot month.

Prices of United States Govrnment securities and other prime debt investments drifted down yesterday as the bond market went through another listless session, one little different from those right before and after the election.
The construction of a community field house for amateur athletic events was proposed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Council of Higher Educational Institutions in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--Representatives of the incoming and outgoing Administrations conferred today in the first of a series of meetings designed to bring about an orderly transfer of power.

DALLAS, Nov. 14 --Pension funds, widely regarded as a growing and important source of mortgage funds, are not a complete solution to the home building industry's financing problems, realty men were told today.
Steel output this week is scheduled to decline slightly from last week's low level.
A six-point program to strengthen family life in the city was set forth yesterday by the Community Service Society, as it started a campaign to raise $2,000,000 in gifts by Jan. 31.

Eighteen members of the Board of Higher Education yesterday expressed their "complete confidence in and support of" Gustave G. Rosenberg, the board chairman, and Dr. Harold W. Stoke, president of Queens College.

I.U.E, and 454, U.S.V. I.U.E,).
The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company raised $20,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday at an interest cost of 4.759 per cent.

The Standard Fruit Steamship Co. experienced , a sharp setback in the thirty-six weeks to Sept. 10 with a consolidated net loss of $6,407,000, according to the report yesterday of Joseph S. D'Antoni, president. In the similar period last year a loss of $995,000 was incurred.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At the start of the present session of the United Nations the representatives of some of the new African nations which were formerly French possessions -- highly cultured men -- were quoted in the press as complaining about the bad manners encountered on the part of New Yorkers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Federal interference in the internal operations of state and local governments was condemned today by the National Conference of State Legislative Leaders. The conference particularly denounced Congressional attempts to assert control over interstate compacts.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Two Australian and two United States teams reached the semi-finals of the men's doubles competition in the New South Wales tennis championships today.
President-elect John. F. Kennedy's lead in California was cut to 24,091 votes yesterday as Vice President Nixon inched upward in the counting of absentee ballots.
A survey of advertising agencies throughout the county indicates that they favor the development of a master layout of agency offices that could be modified to suit individual requirements.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- The relative vigor with which the heart pumps blood may be a guide to the prediction of heart disease years in advance, a noted specialist said here today.
DETROIT, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The inventory of new, unsold domestic automobiles was estimated at 913,807 units on Nov. 1, a record for the date, Automotive News reported today.
Graz Castellano is a professional bowler, but ha should hava been a purchasing agent. Ha often buys a nightful of noise for 15 cents.
HONOLULU, Nov. 14 -- An Air Force C-119 today made the second aerial catch of a capsule from an orbiting space satellite.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov.14 -- There was a lively exchange of opinion about advertising and advertising, people as the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertising got under way today at this Virginia mountain resort.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY First (Political) Committee -- Continued discussion on the question of disarmament.

The Alleghany Corporation was the target yesterday of still another lawsuit questioning the legality of an out-of-court settlement reached by the company's chairman and president, Allan P. Kirby, and a group of associates, last December with a minority stockholders' group.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor is finding the pilferage problem one of the most difficult of its policing assignments.
BELHAVEN, N.C., Nov. 14 -- Everything seems to be conspiring now to make a hunter kill game around Lake Mattamuskeet in spite of anything he may do to spoil his own chances.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 -- Upton Close, author and former radio commentator, was killed when his auto collided with a train yesterday in Guadalajara, Mexico, members of his family here were informed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The Supreme Court held today that a state may not change the boundaries of a city if the effect is to exclude virtually all Negro voters.

Ford of England was established in 1911 as an adjunct of the parent, Ford Motor Company, at a cost of $20,482,970. This involved $70,970 in cash and 4,200,000 shapes of common stock of the Ford Motor Company (England) plus capital stock of Henry Ford Son, Ltd., Cork, Ireland.

There was little evidence that the present economic rolling readjustment or recession was affecting the nation's hotel and motel industries at the opening of the forty-fifth annual National Hotel Exposition yesterday at the New York Coliseum.

The Alleghany Corporation was the target yesterday of still another lawsuit questioning the legality of an out-of-court settlement reached by the company's chairman and president, Allan P. Kirby, and a group of associates, last December with a minority stockholders' group.

BELHAVEN, N.C., Nov. 14 -- Everything seems to be conspiring now to make a hunter kill game around Lake Mattamuskeet in spite of anything he may do to spoil his own chances.
Missouri became the nation's No. 1 college football team yesterday in the weekly ratings by The United Press International Board of Coaches.

ALGIERS, Nov. 14 -- A spokesman for the Algerian civilian Government disclosed tonight that a number of localities had been designated as models of what Algeria as a whole would be like after a cease-fire agreement.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 14 -- Guatemala has decided to ask the Organization of American States to take action on the revolt that broke out here yesterday. The Guatemalan delegate was instructed to act with the greatest possible speed.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 14 -- Scientists at the University of California Virus Laboratory have discovered secrets of structure of the tobacco mosaic virus that may yield important clues to the chemistry of life itself.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation is in the process of disposing of its $47,000,000 interest in two African gold mines at a considerable loss, it was learned yesterday.

The Society of the Silurians, composed of men who became New, York City newspaper men twenty-five or more years ago, held its thirty-sixth annual fall dinner last night at The Lambs, 130 West Forty-fourth Street.
The United States Maritime administration took a second yesterday to curtail the availability of ships for the Soviet Union's trade with Cuba.
The net effect of the Soviet Union's planned conversion of the ruble will be to permit Moscow to assert that the ruble is worth more than the United States dollar.
Orange County, Tex., received bids yesterday on $3,200,000 of road bonds due serially from 1961 to 1990.

YONKERS, Nov. 14 -- The JFL Farm's Quick Jo from Great Neck, L.I., scored by a head over Keen's Victorwin in the Saxon Woods featured pace before 18,072 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The winner's time for the mile was 2:02 2/5.

A TOURNAMENT played at Turin, Italy, last week drew the attention of international players here and in many other countries because it included a challenge match between British and Italian teams composed substantially of players who represent those countries in worldchampionship play.

Yesterday was Aaron Copland's sixtieth birthday, and the Juilliard School ou Music gave him a party. It was the nicest kind of party a composer could receive, for it consisted of a program of his music; and there will be still another one up at the Juilliard tonight.

A TOURNAMENT played at Turin, Italy, last week drew the attention of international players here and in many other countries because it included a challenge match between British and Italian teams composed substantially of players who represent those countries in worldchampionship play.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 15--The Soviet Union announced today that starting Jan. 1 it would institute a newly converted ruble, to have a value of ninety kopecks to a United States dollar. [A ruble has 100 kopecks, so one ruble would equal $1.11.] The present official exchange rate is four rubles to a dollar.

The Condon-Wadlin Law that forbids and penalizes strikes by governmental employes in New York State has been on the statute books unchanged since 1947. Nobody can say how many strikes it has prevented. Obviously it hasn't stopped all, including the one-day strike by some New York City teachers last week. For two years or more we have been urging revision of this law; the Legislature does not act.

The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has ordered the filing of briefs by next Monday in an appeal for an injunction to restrain three American maritime unions from picketing the Liberian-flag ship Ore Monarch.
LONDON, Nov. 15--The bid of the Ford Motor Company of the United States for complete ownership of its British subsidiary aroused protests today in the House of Commons and in the press.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 15 -- The Navy sent to sea today its first nuclear-powered submarine armed with thermonuclear missiles.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 15 -- Floyd Patterson, the heavyweight champion, and his wife, Sandra, have filed suit against Rockville Centre beauty parlor, charging that the shop refused to serve Mrs. Patterson because she is a Negro.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- A leading business economist today urged President-elect Kennedy to call a conference on unemployment caused by technological change and automation as soon as he got settled in the White House.
Two cosmic ray flares have erupted from the sun with what, in some respects, appears to be the greatest intensity ever recorded.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, whose president was blocked by the Police Department from attending an association meeting in Manhattan, took the meeting to the president's home in Brooklyn last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad today revised downward its figures on the cost of carrying fresh fruits and vegetables from the southeast into New York City.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 14 -- The arrival of United States military equipment for the Royal Moroccan Army has provoked a bitter reaction in Left-wing quarters.
The enlarged flow of new and pending public offerings of corporate and local government debt securities continued to be the major influence in the bond market yesterday.

In the eighteen months since the emergence of the French new wave," the second rank of stars and directors has been almost completely replaced by new faces, one of the freshest of the young replacements, Genevieve Cluny, said yesterday.

This is the week of The Game (Harvard-Yale) and The Big Game (California-Stanford) in college football. At Cambridge, at Berkeley and at intervening and surrounding centers of culture, the fierce concentration on the gridiron affair at hand lowers an impenetrable screen on all events outside the pale.

Stocks marched and countermarched on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. They opened down sharply, as if continuing the sell-off of the two preceding days, Prices dropped until about midway in the sea-rid hour, then started slow but steady climb that gained momentum in the final thirty minutes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Louisiana disclosed today changes in state-relief regulations made in the hope of preventing a cut-off of Federal funds for aid to dependent children.

There is one feature about the present economy that has not generally been recognized: there is a strong demand for end-products, especially on the retail level. This was pointed out yesterday by Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, at the first annual meeting of the insulating materials division of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association at Rye, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it had not found any similarity between the Electra airline crash at Boston on Oct. 4 and two earlier Electra crashes, one in Texas and one in Indiana.
PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The Government of President de Gaulle was accused today of the "politics of treason" by the chief defendant in France's trial of the Algerian barricades.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Representative John Bell Williams, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that Southern Congressmen might retaliate if House Democratic leaders tried to oust Representative William H. Colmer from the House Rules Committee.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 15 -- An investigation of the Lavon affair was suspended today by the Foreign Affairs and Security Committee of the Knesset (Parliament).
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- India proposed today that the General Assembly make a finding that "general and complete disarmament" is "not only imperative but urgent."
The State of Massachusetts harrowed $34,750,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The General Assembly's Economic Committee summed up for its newly admitted members today United Nations economic goals in helping under-developed nations.
TO television has come a moment of enrichment and excitement unequaled in the medium's thirteen, yeavs: the production of Eugene O'Neill's stark and searing tragedy, "The Iceman Cometh."
EIGHT-MAN teams repreresenting New York and Los Angeles will play an intercity match of eighty deals here today and tomorrow.

The Tennessee Valley Authority raised $50,000,000 in its first public borrowing yesterday at a net interest cost of 4.43894 per cent. Acting under authority granted by Congress in 1959, the seven-state power system raised the money through a competitive sale of twenty-five year power bonds to an investment group.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points off to 3 up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Miss Louise A. Wood of Chicago was named national executive director of the Girl Scouts of the United States today.
Radio and television networks and a union representing 16,000 performers continued to negotiate early today after a midnight strike deadline had passed.

A prominent Protestant theologian warned yesterday that expressions of bigotry by clergymen during the Presidential election had jeopardized their freedom to influence other elections in which real moral issues might be at stake.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- Two specific methods have been found by which viruses injure the cells they infect, the autumn meeting of the National Acade- my of Sciences was told here today.
SHIRLEY, L.I., Nov. 15 -- A. young atomic scientist was killed here this morning when a huge truck loaded with used atomic reactor fuel skidded on wet pavement and struck his car.

NEWARK, Nov. 15 -- Louis B. Saperstein, former Newark insurance broker, and Eugene C. James, former official of the International Laundry Workers Union, were sentenced to terms of one to two years in the state prison today.
Only three telephone calls were received by Channel 13 in protest against the earthy language that besprinkled the first telecast of Eugene O'Neill's play, "The Iceman Cometh."
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, Nov. 16 -- Denmark's Social Democrats, who have headed a three-party majority coalition since 1957, scored a major victory in yesterday's parliamentary elections.

NOVELS about doctors are published every season. Historical novels glut the book shops. But a historical novel about the world's first distinguished doctor and still one of the world's most celebrated is something new, and that is what Dr. Wilder Penfield has written in "The Torch."* Who is Dr. Penfield's hero?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A final tabulation showed today that New York would lose two of its forty-three seats in the House of Representatives as a result of the 1960 census. New Jersey will gain one seat.

MIAMI, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The net profit of the country's major airlines in the first eight months of this year aggregated only $930,000, Stuart G. Tipton, president of the Air Transport Association, said here today.

A public offering of 750,000 common shares of Champion Spark Plug Company is being made today by Blyth Co., Inc., Glore, Forgan Co., Hornblower Weeks and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. at $42.25 a share.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- A former University of Florida student testified today that he had received $1,250 for his part in an alleged attempt to "fix" a college football game here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Saudi Arabia called today for giving Soviet-bloc representatives and neutrals a majority in the Palestine Conciliation Commission, which deals with the Arab-Israeli problem.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15 -- The new Congress will be "delinquent" is if fails to adopt a specific program to curb juvenile delinquency, Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York tod 425 Westchester County welfare leaders today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 -- Though the United States Grand Prix, to be run at Riverside, Calif., on Sunday, is the last race of the year on the world championship calendar, it may prove to be one of 1960's finest auto sports events.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Oscar Robertson poured In 44 points tonight as the Cincinnati Royals raced to a 124-115 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors, leaders of the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.
An intensive economy drive, spurred by rising costs and guided by "value engineering," his saved the Navy's Bureau of Ships $45,000,000 in one year.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., achieved record sales in the quarter ended on Oct. 29, first of its fiscal year, and raised net earnings to $2,525,000 from $2,360,000 a year before. The preliminary figures were disposed by Wheelock H. Bingham, president, at yesterday's annual meeting attended by 700 stockholders here.
MIAMI, Nov. 15 -- More than 1,000 Cuban refugees are arriving in this community every week. Jobs and funds to care for them are nearly exhausted.

The New York City Ballet will present its first two new works of the season at the City Center tonight in a performance designated as a Salute to Italy, in celebration of the centennial of Italy's independence as a unified nation.

Stockholders of Royal McBee Corporation were told yesterday that the outlook wag favorable for a rising volume of computer business. Allan A. Ryan, chairman, told the annual meeting of the backlog of orders for seventy-seven computer systems.

IN New Orleans, Federal Judge James Skelly Wright, who ordered the integration of New Orleans public schools, is being called a traitor to his class by some of his former friends. He no longer is invited to their homes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The United States rejected today a Belgian assertion that United Nations operations in the Congo had been a failure and pledged continued efforts to establish "peace and welfare" through the world organization.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 15 -- The pastor of the Roman Catholic cathedral parish here stood firm today on his view that those who had publicly disobeyed a religious ban on voting for Gov. Luis Munoz Marin should not seek communion until they had confessed the voting as a sin.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Morocco charged today that France's grant of independence to neighboring Mauritania was a ruse to keep military and economic control over the vast West African territory.
The recently discovered Mossbauer effect has been used to measure the intense magnetic fields that surround the nuclei of atoms in magnetic materials, it was reported here yesterday.
The Kroger Company of Cincinnati, Ohio, the nation's third argest supermarket chain is entering the drug store chain field through the purchase of Sav-On Drugs, Inc., of Plain field, N.J.
Governor Rockefeller's office disclosed last night that it was studying a petition from the Citizens Emergency Committee requesting a state investigation of the New York City Police Department.
A three-man committee called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to set in motion a multi-billion-dollar, long-range program to revamp higher education in New York State.
Missouri and Utah State, two of the nation's four major unheaten teams, are good examples that you don't need a strong passing game to win consistently in college football.

IT has been claimed that mixing dry mustard with boiling water produces a hotter result than the addition of cold water. Anyone bent upon discovering the truth of this statement is brave indeed. When something already is as hot as proverbial Hades, it is difficult to judge whether another version is even hotter.

TRENTON, Nov. 15 -- A state report on commuting p s in Mercer and Burlington Counties disclosed today that about 22,500 of the 129,507 j in the two counties were filled by commuters from other counties.
Mayor Wagner renewed yesterday his fight for legalizing and taxing off-track pari-mutuel betting on horse races. This will be the Mayor's third annual effort to win state approval of his plan.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- There is vast appeal in the kind of grand negotiation hypothetically outlined in my last column. This would seek to end soluble East-West disputes by compromise, throw the rest into U.N.'s hopper and freeze that organization's status for ten years.

A six-story building containing seventy-two apartments and four stores at 1803 Riverside Drive, near Henshaw Street in the Dyckman Street area, has been bought by Leston-Riverside Associates. It was sold subject to mortgages amounting to $383,000.

DALLAS, Nov. 15 -- Rumblings of strife between the real estate and legal professions were heard here today. Spokesmen for the nation's realty men served notice that they would continue to pursue what they consider their legitimate functions even though some lawyers insist that they are in effect practicing law.
The New York Rangers, in last place in the National Hockey League, will present three revised forward lines tonight when the Blues meet the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

IN two short plays of fewer than two hours' duration, which were presented yesterday at the Theatre de Lys as the second bill of this season's ANTA Matinee Series, Yukio Mishima, their author, demonstrates why he is regarded as Japan's leading post-war author.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 15--One of the nation's leading fighters for civic betterment, never active in partisan politics until this year, declared today it was "imperative that our best young people get on the political firing line."
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 -- Policemen armed with night sticks, supported by a police unit on horseback, held back jeering demonstrators today at two desegregated public schools here.

After nearly four years of affluence in United States markets, manufacturers of foreign cars are finding that Detroit's compact autos are making inroads on their sales in this country. The result is a reappraisal of manufacturing plans by automobile makers in Britain, France, West Germany, Italy, Sweden and Japan.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The Rockland County Board of Supervisors will present, at a public hearing here next Tuesday, a 1961 budget of $7,603,819, an increase of $446,508 over 1960.

The Philadelphia National Bank and Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank, Philadelphia's second and third largest banks, announced plans yesterday to merge. With total resources of more than $1,750,000,000, the resulting bank would rank as first in the city and eighteenth in the nation.
A labor leader and the head if one of America's largest corporations were jointly honored by the National Urban League last night for their efforts to establish equal job opportunities for Negroes.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The United States Davis Cup hopes suffered a jolt today when both Earl Buohholz and Chuck McKinley of St. Louis were eliminated from the New South Wales tennis championships.

A NEW look in Carmens came to the Metropolitan Opera last night. It was also a very short look, for the new Carmen, Jane Rhodes of the Paris Opera, is due Thursday for a performance in Brussels and will not return this season.

Short in the price and speedy in the running, Darby Dan Farm's 2-year-old chestnut filly Primonetta had no trouble in defeating four rivals yesterday at Aqueduct in the North Bellmore, a $5,000 allowance sprint.

Traffic injuries in the city last week involved 985 persons in 1,675 accidents, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was a decrease of forty-five in comparison with the 1959 similar period.
The Association Home, an Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged and Indigent Females, will hold its 146th anniversary benefit at Radio City Music Hall on Dec. 21.
Federal aid to dependent children will never do what it was designed for until it is changed by law, an official of the Social Security Administration said yesterday.
Eighty persons here have contracted polio so far this year, compared with 132 for the same period in 1959, the Health Department reported yesterday.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY First (Political) Committee -- Began consideration of the problem of Mauritania and continued consideration of question of disarmament.

Many countries are seeking a share of Cuba's sugar export quota, to the United States, which was cut off last July. And it must be made clear to countries filling quotas that were taken from Cuba that these export allowances are temporary, according to Lawrence Myers director of the Sugar division of the Commodity Stabilization Service of the United States Department of Agriculture.
MUROC, Calif., Nov. 15 (AP) -- An X-15 equipped with the most powerful aircraft engine ever built made a test flight today.
It became more and more apparent yesterday that the American League's plans for expansion to ten teams in 1961 were not proceeding smoothly or according, to schedule.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 15 (AP) -- The National Grange beleives in an agricultural policy based on abundant production, but with safeguards to prevent either scarcity pushing consumer prices above fairlevels or surplus marketings that depress farmers' prices.

ALGIERS, Nov. 15 -- The French project for "pacified zones" in Algeria is recruiting "men of goodwill," whatever their views might be, as long as they are "liberal and moderate," Jacques Coup de Frejac, Director of Information, declared here today.

Tarding was dull yesterday in most New York commodity futures markets. Prices closed irregularly -- cottonseed oil, copper and cocoa rose; potatoes, wool and zinc declined, and price movements for rubber, hides, coffee and sugar were mixed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the holidays approach, volunteers are needed to cheer the spirits of patients confined to hospitals. What greater gift is there than a kind person who has come to the hospital as a friend? The director of volunteers at neighborhood hospitals will be happy to grant an inter- view.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a former high school teacher of English and as a taxpayer I would like to state that the tax-supported school system is not getting the most out of its teachers -- but who is at fault?

VIENNA, Nov. 15 -- A train crash killed 110 persons and injured seriously 106 in Czechoslovakia last night. According to broadcasts monitored today in Vienna, two passenger trains collided sixty-eight miles east of Prague.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Murray Oliver's third-period goal capped a rally tonight that lifted the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks and back into second place in the National Hockey League.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 15 -- Morocco has accepted an offer of Soviet military aid, the Government announced here tonight.
