WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Higher education was accused here today of producing a silent generation of students without moral courage and faculties that hide behind a "curtain of sterile objectivity."
Rail commuter lines are just as essential to the metropolitan area today as they were sixty years ago, the executive director of the Port of New York Authority said yesterday.

Nobody wearing the livery of the New York Knickerbockers came close to keeping up with Elgin Baylor of the Los Angeles Lakers last night. The penalty was a record 71-point spree for the star forward and a 123-108 victory for the Coast quintet at Madison Square Garden.

BELHAVEN, N.C., Nov. 15 -- There are certain sound reasons why some people didn't get their limit of geese here today but there is little agreement and no cordiality about what reason is the soundest.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday gains in sales and revenues and net income for the third quarter and the first nine months of the year despite the seizure of the Cuban Telephone Company by the Castro Government.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Paul Richards, who built the Baltimore Orioles from a second-division team into a pennant contender, became the highest paid manager in baseball today.
BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 15 -- Dr. Frank P. Graham urged moderate Southerners today not to ignore the racial issue.

ONE of the country's most successful fashion models finds the careers of twelve other women more exciting than just her own. Dark-haired Gillis MacGil, a 32-year-old model who is paid $60 an hour for walking the way she does, has opened her own model agency in the city.
Two prominent foreign speakers emphasized to the Economic Club of New York last night the danger of the growing gap of wealth between "have" and "have not" nations.
Spokesmen for six architects' groups in the city yesterday reasserted their opposition to the new zoning resolution that will be considered by the Board of Estimate next week.

The Boys Athletic League, which coordinates and supervises the athletic and cultural programs of many boys' clubs and settlement houses In the city, will be aided by a theatre benefit on Jan. 14. It will be at the evening performance of "Camelot" at the Majestic Theatre.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek warned last night that effective inter-American cooperation was essential to prevent the Latin-American peoples from turning to "revolutionary heresy."

Marcus Samuel, the first Viscount Bearsted and founder of Shell Oil, is the subject of a book by Robert Henriques that Viking is planning for Dec. 29 publication, Called "Bearated," it traces the viscount's career in business and government, his fights with the Dutch oil company and Standard Oil and with the British Navy to have its ships converted to oil-burners.

YONKERS, Nov. 15 -- The Wheatly Hills Stable's So Quick, from Westbury, L.I., With Joe MacDonald at the reins, scored a head victory over Silver's Dream in the Pleasantville Pace before 16,890 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Survival of Western capitalism depends on its giving sustained economic aid to underdeveloped nations during coming decades, Aziz Ahmed, Pakistani Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday.

A charge that Negroes are systematically and intentionally excluded from jury lists in New York County interrupted for several hours yesterday the questioning of prospective jurors for Borough President Hulan E. Jack's second trial.
DALLAS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Houston's Oilers have dropped two of their last three games but the statistics released today don't indicate it.

The board of directors of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway fixed yesterday an "absolute final" deadline of Dec. 14 for the company's exchange offer for Baltimore and Ohio Railroad shares.

Sidney Kingsley, winner of a Pulitzer Prize ("Men in White") and two awards from the Critics Circle ("The Patriots" and "Darkness at Noon"), is trying to solve a problem that affects two new plays he is writing, "Ghost Dance" and "The Uncertainty Principle."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- United States foreign trade improved last summer but higher interest rates abroad drained off short-term capital and caused a rise in the United States balance-of-payments deficit.
Population shifts within the state make it likely that New York City will lose three seats in the House of Representatives and the upstate area one, while Long Island gains two.
Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio lost a court move yesterday to have the city pay $35,000 in counsel fees in his legal battle to retain his judicial post.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Westchester golf and country clubs were asked tonight to join in greater promotion of junior golf in 1961.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A St. Louis group headed by Elliot Stein bought the Kansas City Athletics' baseball club today for $3,500,000.

Eggheads and Business Widespread use of economists from the college campus by both recent Presidential candidates points up the growing rapprochement between the so-called eggheads and the business community.
Unbeaten Missouri was ranked No. 1 yesterday in the weekly Associated Press college football poll.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Bernard Newman, New York County Republican chairman, told a luncheon meeting yesterday that prospects for ending Democratic control of the city administration next year were unusually bright.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 15 -- A series of Presidential directives to Federal departments and agencies to help cut the deficit in the nation's balance of international payments will be issued in the next forty-eight hours.
ATTRACTIONS that may be of interest to children are listed below. Inclusion in this listing does not constitute vecommendation or endorsement of The New York Times.
The Air Force has decided to develop an all-new transport plane for rapid airlift of troops and cargo anywhere in the world, it was reported yesterday.
The president of the Board of Education said yesterday the board believed in the principle of collective bargaining for teachers.

Charles Rosen, whose first New York recital in 1951 established him as a pianist of exceptional gifts, returned to Town Hall last night for his first New York recital in five years. He is still a pianist with a very special talent but also with a very specialized appeal.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 15 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy had lunch and played golf today with Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, an early Kennedy-for-President leader.
DALLAS, Nov. 15 -- Two doctors of medicine proposed here today that the Protestant Episcopal Church establish a national organization designed to help physicians combat alcoholism.
HARTFORD, Nov. 15 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors, in a unanimous decision, ruled today that the state's birth control statutes were constitutional.
Princesses Birgitta and Desiree of Sweden went museum hopping yesterday, from the Guggenheim to the Metropolitan, and then faced up to another American institution -- the press conference.
THANKS to the plethora of Japanese shops in the city, the word "oriental" has come to mean popularly just the wares from the Land of the Rising Sun.
The Board of Education made its final appeal yesterday for the full amount of its proposed capital budget of $130,500,000 for the 1961 school construction program.
The Black and Decker Manufacturing Company, power tools maker, observed its fiftieth anniversary with record sales and the second highest earnings in its fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 15 -- Fourteen officers dismissed from the ruling junta here have been offered a choice between accepting civilian "advisory" posts at embassies in undisclosed countries or remaining under close surveillance or possibly arrest in Turkey.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Twelve educators were appointed today as an advisory committee in the development of the Counseling and Guidance Institutes Program.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 15 -- The United Nations command warned today that it would not tolerate a flare-up of tribal warfare in Kasai Province and said it had imparted "necessary orders" to its there.
Unemployment will have a strong bearing on future immigration policy, Representative Francis E. Walter said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- George Meany asserted tonight that the union movement expected President-elect John F. Kennedy to carry out the Demlocratic platform.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Excited dealings in Ford Motor shares dominated the stock market here today following the American parent company's bid for full ownership of the common stock. Dealers were inundated with orders.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Persistent selling snuffed out a rally in the grain futures market today and prices closed generally weak on the Board of Trade.

It appeared yesterday that Frank Gifford would be the Giants' starting left end against the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday at the Yankee Stadium. Gifford earns a living as a left halfback, be he was at left end when he caught a touchdown pass from Charlie Conerly against the Pittsburgh Steelers last Sunday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In vain have I looked for the United States to make use of a prime propaganda advantage. The democratic system has too often failed to call attention to its assets while the Soviets have been all too clever in calling world attention to our liabilities.

With the attention of so many Eastern football fans focused on the Yale Bowl last Saturday, it was almost a foregone conclusion that the Ivy League back of the week selection would stem directly from the result of the Yale-Princeton game.

RAW winds knifed In from Lake Michigan and blunted themselves against the ornate coping and windows of the Grand Palace Hotel in Chicago on Nov. 21, 1900. In a third-floor room sports history was being made. In a clear and flowing hand the secretary of the group wrote out baseball's Declaration of Independence. He began it this way:
President-elect John F. Kennedy's popular vote lead over Vice President Nixon was cut to 240,399 yesterday.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 15 -- A major break with the traditional 15 per cent commission arrangement for compensating in agency for its services was made known here today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I believe Prof. Harold J. Berman (Times, Nov. 2) has misunderstood my letter published Oct. 25 on the legality of the U-2 flights.

Education is concerned with the "cold war" more profoundly through religion than through science and mathematics, Brother Augustine Philip, president of Manhattan College, said yesterday in the college's annual report.

The National Republican Club agreed yesterday to sell the eleven-story building at 54 West fortieth Street, facing Bryant Park, that has been its home for fifty-one years. The purchaser is the Overseas Press Club.
So many Giants reported for yesterday's football practice at the Yankee Stadium wearing sneakers that Jim Lee Howell, the head coach, wondered whether they were out for tennis or basketball.
David Greenglass, the atom spy whose testimony helped to send his sister Ethel and her husband Julius Rosenberg to the electric chair, was released from Federal prison yesterday.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen moved yesterday to block a reduction of commuter service in northern Westchester, Putnam and lower Dutchess Counties by the New York Central Railroad's Harlem Division.

Spurred on by the triple threat of present malaise at home, imminent Afro-Asian condemnation at the U.N. and prospective Russo-Chinese infiltration in North Africa, President de Gaulle has taken one more step toward a hopeful solution of France's most difficult and dangerous problem: Algeria.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 15 -- Chancellor Adenauer is seeking to give a new look to Soviet-West German relations, a course that is baffling his associates and perplexing Western diplomats.

DALLAS, Nov. 16 -- The Right Rev. Richard Ambrose Reeves, leported Anglican Bishop of Johannesburg, South Africa, delivered today a scathing indictment against the white supremacy policies of the Union of South Africa.
ALGIERS, Nov. 16 -- The police expelled five Right-wing European militants from Algeria today and ordered the expulsion of two others who could not be found.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Two Puerto Rican farmhands, once imprisoned for ten to 30 years for the armed theft of a handful of cigarettes, won their freedom today in a retrial.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--Among the pending problems of national policy that could be jointly determined when the President and the President-elect have their meeting is the increasingly perilous moratorium in nuclear testing. President Eisenhower will have the power until Jan. 20, 1961, to order a resumption in two areas: weapons testing in underground experiments, and testing of the adequacy of present seismic detection devices.

Daan Prentice gave new life to the New York Rangers last night. He scored with one second remaining, enabling the Blues to gain a 4-3 triumph over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Clark Gable, for thirty years "king" of Hollywood actors, died tonight of a heart ailment that first struck him Nov. 6. He was 59 years old.
The production of crude oil in the nation last week was at the highest level in almost seven months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 9:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 -- Rear Admiral Merrill K. Clemenston, retired, former Chief of Staff of the Pacific Reserve fleet and holder of the Navy Cross, was accused on seventeen counts of grand theft and one count of conspiracy in San Mateo County today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- Plans for the construction of a 45,000-seat baseball park were announced today by Robert R. M. Carpenter, the owner of the Phillies.

Two more men were arrested yesterday in connection with the theft of $219,574 in securities from Bache Company, brokers of 40 Wall Street. The two, along with four others arrested last June, were indicted on charges that included grand larceny, criminally receiving stolen property and forgery.

NEW YORK held a slight lead over Los Angeles midway in their intercity bridge match last night. In the first forty deals of the eighty-deal match, played yesterday afternoon and last night, the New York team outscored its opponents, 90 to 73 international match points.

A soft-spoken grandmother who had done jury duty four times before was chosen yesterday to be foreman of the jury in the second trial of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack. He is charged with conflict of interest and conspiracy.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 16 -- Though construction declined in Westchester County in the last year, 3,836 new structures were built and the assessed value of all real estate rose to $3,356,943,087.
The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists began discussions within the union yesterday on contract proposals submitted by the radio and television networks.

Dr. Hadley C. Stephenson of Ithaca, N.Y., recommended at the meeting of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club in Luchow's Restaurant yesterday that in order to increase the effectiveness of vaccines against distemper the vaccinations should be repeated annually.

MANY women college graduates embark on their first round of job hunting with the amorphous plan of finding something "creative ... possibly in research." They soon learn that jobs that sound as though they would fill the bill are merely clerkships with euphemistic titles.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- The departure for the Congo of a fifteen-nation conciliation committee was postponed tonight in the hope that President Joseph Kasavubu could be persuaded to accept it.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Labor and Liberal members of the House of Commons pressed the Government today for more information on the bid by the Ford Motor Company of the United States for complete control of its British subsidiary.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- The General Assembly today elected four members to the International Court of Justice at The Hague.
Philadelphia borrowed $35,085,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements on obligations secured by general taxation.
One of the largest subsidy awards ever considered by the Federal Maritime Board will be argued in an unusual action today before the United States District Court in the District of Columbia.

The United States Plywood Corporation announced yesterday that it had purchased a half-interest in the Bohemia Lumber Company, Inc., Culp Creek, Ore. The amount involved in the cash transaction was not disclosed.
A "vigorous technological offensive" by American industry to meet foreign competition at home and abroad was urged yesterday by Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman of the General Electric Company.
The largest cable-laying ship in the world has been ordered by American Telephone and Telegraph Company through its Long Lines Department.

Charles L. Patterson, chairin of the Transit Authority, made an unscheduled trip to City Hall yesterday to defend the agency against a charge that its proposed 1961 capital-improvement program would jeopardize the 15-cent subway fare.

A long-time city employe was arrested yesterday on a bribery charge. A few hours later it was discovered that he had more than $150,000 in government securities, stocks and bonds and saving bank deposits.

An offering to the public of $60,000,000 of twenty-five year 4 5/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of B.F. Goodrich Company is being made today by Goldman, Sachs Co. and associates. The price is 100.
FRANK GLAZER split his Town Hall piano program last night between Germanic and French composers.

Publication of the Federal Reserve Board's industrial production index of 107 for October -- unchanged from the September level and only reasonably above the 102 for the strikebound October of 1959 -- turned the stock market downward yesterday afternoon.
The Menninger Foundation's Child Psychiatry Service will be furthered by the proceeds of the Nov. 29 performance of "Under the Yum-Yum Tree" at Henry Miller's Theatre.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 16 -- President Eisenhower ordered all Federal agencies today to cut their foreign spending to the bone to stem the increasing deficit in the United States balance of payments and the consequent drain on the nation's gold reserves.

Kerstin Meyer, Swedish mezzo-soprano who made her New York debut two and a half weeks ago singing the role of Carmen at the Metropolitan Opera, appeared here for the first time as a recitalist last night.

THE United Lightning Protection Association, Inc., of Onondaga, N.Y., has issued a warning to homeowners stating that, although lightning is one of the leading causes of fire in rural and suburban areas, many modern homes are not properly protected.

Cocoa futures prices fell in active trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trade selling against purchases of actuals, commission house liquidation and stop-loss orders were influenced by continued reports of heavy production in Africa.
DALLAS, Nov. 16 -- Americans in greater numbers than ever will participate in the ownership of income-producting real estate in the future, realty men were told today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- The leader of Orthodox Jewish Zionists in America called on President-elect John F. Kennedy tonight to arrange a speedy meeting in Washington between Israeli and Arab leaders for a firm, enduring peace in the Middle East.
Sales of new cars in the first ten days of November touched a new record for the period, according to an unofficial compilation yesterday.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 15 -- President - elect John F. Kennedy flew west from his Florida vacation retreat today for a major policy conference at the ranch home of Vice President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson near here.
John Daly has resigned as vice president in charge of news, special events and public affairs for the American Broadcasting Company.
THE Orchestra of America honored three birthdays last night at Carnegie Hall. They were the seventy-fifth of Wallingford Riegger, the sixtieth of Aaron Copland and the fiftieth of Samuel Barber.
Cotton futures moved 7 points (35 cents a bale) off to 4 points (20 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

In 1948, after ruling the Nethlands for fifty years, Queen Wilhelmina abdicated her throne n favor of her daughter, Juliana. In her autobiography, "Lonely But Not Alone," she tells of the troubled years of her reign, of her religious faith and of God's guidance in all great events of her life.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Ford shares again were the center of interest in the stock market here today with brokers reporting a large turnover.
New friction between rival craft and industrial unions is worrying officials in charge of the lagging missile program.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Pierre Lagaillarde, the young ex-paratrooper who became the hero of the French Right wing behind the barricades of Algiers, was suddenly freed on bail today during the third week of his trial for insurrection.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is with considerable satisfaction and pleasure that the delegation of the Congo to the United Nations read your editorial comments of Nov. 12 on the situation in the Congo. You demonstrate a clear understanding of the very fundamental problems, and your sympathetic treatment made us hopeful that many people in this country truly understand what we Congolese are facing.
A Queens charter - revision commission recommended yesterday that any changes of the City Charter retain the offices of Borough President and their membership on the governing body of the city.
Sight-seeing trips around New York City in an Electra airliner are being sold by American Airlines as part of its program for building public confidence in the airplane.

Mayor Wagner declared yeserday that both he and the people of the city would have to be convinced of the "wisdom and necessity" of charging tuition and extending state supervision in the city's free municipal colleges.
A Palace of Labor, now rising on the banks of the Po River in Turin, Italy, was shown here yesterday in a small-scale model.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 16 -- The fifteenth International Congress of Local Authorities heard a suggestion today that the older and better-estbalished citties of the world give advice and guidance to their poorer counterparts in newly independent countries.
In view of reporters and television cameras yesterday, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy tore up his membership card in the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and dropped it into an ash tray.

The unfavorable American balance of payments, which has already precipitated one "gold rush," has deteriorated so sharply that President Eisenhower has announced an emergency program to save $1 billion a year in overseas spending and has called a meeting of the National Security Council to discuss the defense of the dollar as a key factor in our own economic defense and that of the free world.

Dividend payments this year apparently are headed for a record, despite a notable attrition in recent weeks. The New fork Stock Exchange reported yesterday that cash payments declared in the first nine months of 1960 on common stocks listed on the Big Board added up to a new high.

BELHAVEN, N.C., Nov. 16 -- Fog helped the geese put on a weird show this morning over the fields on the south side of Lake Mattamuskeet but did not save all of them from the bag. A few just didn't know how to make the best of a good fog.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, neutralist Premier of Laos, charged today that the United States was illegally supporting the right-wing rebel regime of Gen. Phoumi Nosavan. The Premier said this support was making the general less willing to compromise.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The orbiting Discoverer XVII carried artificially grown human cells and vegetation successfully retrieved in an aerial catch of the satellite capsule, the Air Force disclosed today.
A 46-year-old Yonkers man, described by Assistant District Attorney Melvin Stein as "the kingpin in the pornography trade in this country," was convicted yesterday in Special Sessions Court.
The Baltimore Colts remained the National Football League's top yardage-gaining team yesterday, but for a balanced offense, no club could match the St. Louis Cardinals.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 16 -- A group of property owners is asking the Court of Common Pleas to overrule a decision by this town's Zoning Board of Appeals.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Roman Catholic woman Mayor of San Juan said today she would challenge her pastor's right to deny her Holy Communion because of the way she voted in the Nov. 8 election.

PARK, Nov. 16 -- President de Gaulle will ask France to approve by referendum, probably early in January, his plans for letting the Algerians make their own choice between independence and continued association with France.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 16 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement and directive to Federal agencies on the international balance of payments of the United States:

City Products Corp. The City Products Corporation has purchased the Herst-Allen Company, Chicago supplier of general non-food merchandise to supermarkets and food chains. The purchase was for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 16 -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today dealing exclusively with the balance-of-payments problem:

The reallocation of seats in the House of Representatives on the basis of 1960 census figures just announced constitutes a significant shift of political power within the United States. In 1964 a candidate could be elected President by carrying only the eleven most populous states. This year it took a minimum of twelve states to produce an Electoral College majority.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 16 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu's army regime disclosed today that it had arrested a secretary of the Ghanaian Embasy near the residence of Patrice Lumumba, deposed Premier.

TRENTON, Nov. 16 -- The 1961 governorship campaign got off to an early start today with the disclosure by State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr., Republican of Warren County, that he would announce his candidacy Dec. 1.

Electric power production rose to 14,111,000,000 kilowatthours in the week ended last Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the preceding week the figure was 13,982,000,000 and 13,270,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year ago.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Elected four judges to the International Court of Justice in concurrent session with the Security Council.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Government, issuing its first 1961 buisness forecast today, predicted that total con- structlon outlays would increase about 4 per cent in 1961 to a record of $57,300,000,000. However, the Department of Commerce report contained a hint that prospects for the first six months of the year weren't that rosy.
Protocol broke down briefly yesterday and a little girl kissed a princess.
The City Commission on Local School Boards urged yesterday that the fifty-four local school boards here be strengthened.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Arthur H. Dean warned today against undue fear and pessimism about growing Soviet penetration of world oil markets.
Frank Sinatra and other star entertainers may testify in the city's widening investigation into charges of police corruption in the issuance of performers' cabaret permits.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- A puzzling characteristic of the Syrian hamster is giving scientists a clue to one of the most fundamental problems of modern biology.
The whine of a sawmill is heard there days within sight of the towers of Manhattan.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Warren Godfrey's third-period goal gave the Detroit Red Wings a 3-3 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game tonight. The deadlock moved the Wings to within a point of the league-leading Montreal Canadiens.
FOR television audiences, John Charles Daly's role as a vice president of the American Broadcasting Company -- a post from which he resigned yesterday -- has long been a matter of secondary interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The idea of a single Federal agency to evaluate expenditures abroad was supported today by Dr. John Kenneth Galbraith, an economic consultant to President-elect John F. Kennedy.
There were skimpy reports about Charlie Ravenel and Capt. Terry Lenzner as Harvard practiced yesterday for its final games of the season against Yale on Saturday.
ALBANY, Calif., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Five bettors won $8,711.40 each today on the daily double at Golden Gate Fields.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Industrial production showed "little change" last month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

DRINK a toast to Hogan! Without him "Under the Yum-Yum Tree" would be an exercise in the art of teasing in three acts. With him Lawrence Roman's play, which opened at Henry Miller's Theatre last night, is a gay, frothy comedy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The United States is planning to reassure the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that it will not hesitate to use nuclear weapons to fight aggression in Europe.

HAVANA, Nov. 16 -- Premier Fidel Castro has warned the Cubans working at the United States Guantanamo Naval Base to refrain from any action that would give the United States a pretext for attacking Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Department of Justice will proceed soon to prosecute three high officers of the Port of New York Authority for contempt of Congress.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 16 -- The Association of National Advertisers concluded its threeday meeting here with a discussion of creativity and its relationship to advertising.

DALLAS, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Commissioner Joe Foss said today the American Football League would conduct a telephonic player draft of six rounds late this week. The remainder of the selections will be held sometime in December.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Union is lagging behind Western nations in developing an organic chemical industry, a United States Government report says. The report asserts that Soviet chemists lack originality and are backward in learning.

An appeal for the apparel and textile Industries to unify in a fight against increasing imports was issued yesterday by Lawrence S. Phillips, president of the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufactuers.
TELEVISION'S frequent difficulty in preserving the gentle touch of fantasy asserted itself last night in the presentation of "Heaven Can Wait" on the "Du Pont show of the Month" over Channel 2.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Independence for African colonial territories has opened a new front in the "cold war," Lynn Heinzerling, foreign correspondent for the Associated Press, said today.
The Federal Maritime Board ordered yesterday a formal hearing into a controversial revenue pooling agreement submitted by Moore-McCormack Lines and Lloyd Brasileiro for approval.
James E. Dumpson, city Commissioner of Welfare, promised yesterday that members of his department who testified about conditions in it would not suffer reprisals.

DENVER, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Karl Menninger, the psychiatrist, said today that with the election of John F. Kennedy as President, "it looks as if we who are concerned for Indians have some one in high places who will listen."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- California absentee ballots continued to help Mr. Nixon narrow the lead of Senator Kennedy in the national popular vote.

Chesebrough-Pond's Directors of ChesebroughPond's, Inc., voted yesterday to pay an extra dividend of 7 cents a share along with the quarterly dividend of 22 cents a share on Dec. 15 to stockholders of record of Dec. 1.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 (AP) -- America's hopes of regaining the Davis Cup from Australia were jolted today when both United States doubles teams were beaten in the semi-finals of the New South Wales tennis championship.

ALBANY, Nov. 16--Governor Rockefeller said today he would ask next year's Legislature to approve a 10 per cent rebate in 1960 personal income taxes. The Governor thus confirmed a proposal he made on June 14, when he said he would recommend a 10 per cent rebate if state revenues maintained their high levels.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The principal impact of President Eisenhower's order to cut the Government's spending overseas will fall on Western Europe and Japan, officials said today.

John M. Foley, president of the Airex Corporation, a subsidiary of the Lionel Corporation, sold 13,100 shares of Lionel stock on Oct. 5 reducing his holding to 10,000 shares. Mr. Foley, in addition to his remaining stock interest holds $37,000 of 5 1/2 per cent subordinated convertible debentures of Lionel.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The grain futures market posted its biggest number of gains in a week today, even though they were small.

A vacant plot 180 by 100 feet at 51 to 69 East Eighty-seventh Street, adjoining the northwest corner of Park Avenue, has been purchased by a group of builders represented by Leight, Drimmer Weinstein, lawyers. Henry Baker was the broker.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Union held today that controlled disarmament was impossible until the structure of the United Nations was reorganized.
The paperboard industry will continue to be bothered by surplus productive capacity for several years, the new president of the National Paperboard Association said yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16--Vice President Nixon captured California's thirty-two electoral votes from President-elect Kennedy tonight on un-official returns from absentee ballots.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 16 -- The state Supreme Court today ordered the East Meadow School to show why it should hot permit a parent to inspect his son's school records.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Bus and trolly mechanics struck here today in defiance of a court order.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 16 -- Two authorities on government warned the National Municipal League today that the new metropolitan way of living sharpened "a crisis of monumental proportions" that confronted the nation.
Intensive promotional efforts to meet the threat of foreign competition were urged yesterday by Stanley C. Hope, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers.

The apparent indifference of the investment community to the enlarged flow of high-grade corporate bonds in the new capital market stayed in force yesterday in another quiet trading session in which prime-risk corporate debt investment lost further ground.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 16 -- The board of directors of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association voted today to consider participation in a proposed program for further economic development of the South.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov 16 -- Hostile Nagas continue to be active in the northeastern border areas, attacking convoys and the civilian population, Parliament learned today. The Nagas are seeking independence from India.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Sir Winston Churchill fell yesterday and broke a small bone in his back.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is no department of our State Government which has more important responsibilities than does Mental Hygiene. The public has been made increasingly aware in recent years of the crushing burden of mental illness on the vast number of its victims, on their families and on the economy.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 -- Marauding youths surged through New Orleans streets today in demonstrations against school integration that were marked by sporadic rioting, assaults and vandalism.
RICHARD BRINSLEY SHERIDAN (1751-1816) lived in an ambiance where much was forgiven the unjust and little was spared the unwise.

Broadway's newest "angel" is the American National Theatre and Academy. The nonprofit, tax exempt group has invested $100,000 in the $300,000 musical, "The Conquering Hero." In view of ANTA's status, it is assumed the ticket tax will be suspended.
FLORAL PARK, L.I., Nov. 16 -- Some amateur singers here are offering their talents without charge to fund-raising organizations to stimulate interest in opera on Long Island.

April Skies, possessor of a good record on the New England circuit, contributed a surprise against higher-rated opposition at Aqueduct yesterday. The crowd of 22,045 gave April Skies little consideration in the feature race, the $27,500 Sport Page Handicap at six furlongs.

Consolidated net earnings of Kaiser Industries Corporation for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 fell to $4,342,000, or 13 cents a common share, from $11,802,000 or 46 cents a common share, for the 1959 period.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- On the Twentieth Century-Fox skating rink unused since Sonja Henie's heyday more than a decade ago, Miss Henie's cinematic heir apparent swooped through graceful double-Paulsens and camel-skins today to spontaneous bursts of applause from bystanding supernumeraries.
Princess Shahnaz, 20-year-old daughter of the Shah of Iran, addressed more than 400 persons here last night at a dinner to raise funds for a 300-bed hospital in Teheran.

Folk music Is leaving the imprint of its big country boots on the night life of New York in unparalleled fashion, from the grimiest Greenwich Village espresso joint to the crooked-finger elegance of the Waldorf Astoria.
If Washington State's Hugh Campbell catches just one pass against Washington Saturday, he will have a National Collegiate Athletic Association record.
Capt. James D. Armstrong, a British captain who commanded many of the Cunard Line's passenger vessels, has been named master of the cruise liner Ariadne.
The city has recovered $350,000 from Bulk Carriers Corporation to compensate for six years of short-weighting in rock salt deliveries, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

Unless the American League adopts a conciliatory attitude in its efforts to place a team in Los Angeles, it may have to start the 1961 season with eight or nine clubs, instead of the ten it had planned.
IT wasn't too many years ago that Mal Stevens used to dream a big fanciful dream.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Russians took their two racehorses back home tonight after a $500,000 price tag on them brought "no sale" from Americans.
Dr. Paul Block Jr., an organic chemist who became a newspaper publisher, defended the nation's press against its critics yesterday.
The cost of the Interstate Highway System will not exceed the current estimates of $40,000,000,000, Federal Highway Administrator Bertram D. Tallamy declared yesterday.

WARSAW, Nov. 16 -- Jerzy Albrecht, a member of Poland's inner circle of Communist party leaders, was moved today to the administrative post of Finance Minister. The appointment was a significant move in the intricate maneuverings in the small group of Communists who rule Poland.

THE New York City Ballet got around last night to its first premieres of the season at the City Center and gave them to us in a pair on a special "Salute to Italy" program honoring the centennial of the unification of Italy.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- Rockwell Kent, New York artist who is distinguished for his portrayals of American landscapes and figures, announced today that he had donated his collection of his own work to the Soviet Union.

Living Out of a Suitcase The tourists, both airborne and seaborne, have returned from Europe and are back at work, in office. classroom, store, factory and farm. Most of them wholeheartedly agree that it is good to be home again, for living out of a suitcase can become both wearing and wearying.

ONE of Manhattan's most active food personalities is Rudolph Stanish. Frequently called the omelet king of America, he estimates that he has traveled more than 100,000 miles and fed an equal number of guests while working four skillets at a time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The National Science Foundation named four scientists today to top posts at United States Antarctic stations. Two other were named as United State representatives for cooperative | programs with Australian and Argentine scientists.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Johnny Michelosen, head football coach at the University of Pittsburgh for almost six years, today got a permanent job there and a salary increase too.

The steel industry, already troubled by reduced profits and a 51 per cent operating rate, has something new to worry about. Exports of steel, which had been rising for eight consecutive months until July, appear to be sharply on the wane.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 16 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion vigorously denied today that a military clique had forced the resignation of Pinhas Lavon as Defense Minister in February, 1955.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 -- W. Willard Wirtz, Chicago lawyer and arbitrator, was named a member of the Public Review Board of the United Automobile Workers today. He will fill the vacancy left by the death of Dr. Edwin E. Witte, former Professor of Economics at the University of Wisconsin.
Two leaders in this country's maritime industry have endorsed President Eisenhower's order to cut Government spending abroad.

Babcock Wilcox Co. The board of the Babcock Wilcox Company voted yesterday to raise the fourth-quarter dividend to 35 cents a share. The company paid 30 cents a share in the previous quarter. The new declaration will be distributed on Jan. 4 to stockholders of record of Dec. 9.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- President Eisenhower's directive for reducing by 284,000 the number of dependents living abroad with United States servicemen was received with sympathetic understanding here today, but it was not welcomed.

LOS ANGELES defeated New York by one international match point last night in their intercity match that began Wednesday. The point may represent no more than a single trick. The final score was 164 to 163.
ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- The Rockefeller Administration's court reorganization plan, approved by the Legislature this year, was pre-filed today for consideration at the 1961 session.

The heavy drain on the United States monetary gold stock has been accompanied in the last three weeks by a reduction of almost $250,000,000 in foreign Official holdings of United States Government securities.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- A mass movement of "volatile" private capital, both American and foreign, across the Atlantic to Europe has drastically worsened the United States balance of international payments this year mostly since June.
Hundreds of City College students met in a mass demonstration on the uptown campus yesterday to protest a proposal that the municipal colleges charge a $300 tuition fee.

IN this age of narrow specialization it is refreshing to be reminded that some men can do almost anything -- at least in the arts. Consider the manifold talents of Peter Ustinov who, to the best of my knowledge and belief, has not yet composed a symphony or danced in "The Nutcracker Suite" but who probably could do either easily.

In Hollywood, and especially at the studio of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, where he had been a contract player for almost a quarter of a century, Clark Gable was known informally but respectfully as The King. It was a sobriquet accepted ungrudgingly by his peers. Even among the hierarchy of great motion-picture stars, of whom there were many in the happy years of his ascendance, he was acknowledged supreme.

Eastern region national board members of the American Fedration of Television and Radio Artists have voted to reject a contract offer by the networks. The stand thus prolongs the possibility of a strike by the performers.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Poland proposed today hat the United Nations estabish a new committee to warn the peoples of the world of the consequences that would follow a nuclear war.
The Shell Oil Company will announce soon that it is putting its entire advertising budget into newspapers.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 -- Zionism and Americanism are completely compatible, the leader of the Orthodox Jewish Rabbinate in the United States asserted here today.
President-elect John F. Kennedy was reported yesterday to be planning to bypass Michael H. Prendergast and Carmine G. De Sapio in Federal patronage distribution in New York.
An invitation by a State Senator to Mayor Wagner to attend a public hearing on welfare was dismissed yesterday by City Hall as a "publicity stunt."

Quote and Unquote Among curious lapses committed during the and haste and hurry of the recent Presidential campaign it is reported that a pamphlet circulated by the Democratic National Committee attributed to Lincoln's Gettysburg Address his famed statement about "A house divided," actually spoken by Lincoln five years earlier in Illinois instead of Pennsylvania.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Premier Michel Debre today staked the life of his Government for the second time on President de Gaulle's plan for an independent French nuclear striking force.
The Broadway Association has hired a firm of design engineers to draw plans for an improved mall down the middle of Times Square from Forty-seventh Street to Forty-third.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 17 -- The first performance in America of an opera by Handel, and the first appearance in America of Joan Sutherland coincided here last night at the Dallas Opera.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The French Right wing is working in a courtroom here to build a legal and political foundation for its plans to try to block President de Gaulle's Algeria policy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy appeared almost certain today to have less than a majority of all votes cast on Nov. 8 for President.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Six Parliamentary by-elections yesterday resulted in a clean sweep by the Conservative party and a Liberal revival at the expense of the divided Labor party.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- When a titan dies, a standard comment is that it marks the end of an era.
Alling Cory Co. Plans for a merger of the Alling Cory Company, Rochester, N.Y., and the J.L.N. Smythe Company, Philadelphia, were announced yesterday. Both companies are wholesale paper distributors.
The Metropolitan Opera is preparing to take free opera Into the public schools.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines has sold its three-story garage and service building at 4 to 20 East 102d Street, near Fifth Avenue, to the firm of Frederick Brown, realty investors. The sale was negotiated for all cash by Anton L. Trunk, broker.

Olive Deering will impersonate Elizabeth I in "The Young Elizabeth," to be presented Off Broadway in late January, Dave Collins is producing the drama, which was written by the husband and wife team of Francis and Jennette Letton.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The State Department emphasized today that United States forces would render assistance to Guatemala and Nicaragua only if those countries requested it.

Schubert's cycle of twenty-four songs, "Winterreise," presents one of the greatest challenges to a vocal recitalist. Its unrelieved atmosphere of despair and resignation must be lit by countless details of interpretation to keep it from bogging down in monotony.
Things were quiet for two radio-car patrolmen in Brooklyn last night. Then they came across Cleo, a lion.
Three major airlines -- Eastera, National and Northeast -- plan to put higher jet coach fares to Florida into effect this Sunday.
The New York Central Railroad announced a new train schedule for its upper Harlem Division yesterday. It goes into effect Sunday and affects thirteen trains.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Joseph Kasavubu, President of the Congo, announced today that he would soon call a conference of "all Congolese leaders," including tribal chiefs, to form a government of national unity.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zea -- land, Nov. 17 -- More than 600 men who are taking part in the United States research program on the Antarctic continent 1,200 miles south of here, have been shut off from contact with the rest of the world by the worst magnetic storm on record.

NO one can question the high principle enunciated by "Advise and Consent" that integrity rather than expediency should inform the decisions of the President and the Senate. One doubts, however, that the play, which opened at the Cort Theatre last night, proves this point as convincingly as its authors seem to believe.
Rumors crackled through Wall Street yesterday, adding a fillip to an otherwise unexciting session that closed with prices down moderately.

The Port of New York Authority charged yesterday that Representative Emanuel Celler proposed to "jump the gun" on a scheduled trial of contempt citations "with a self-serving, one-sided 'trial' of his own."
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The acceptance of Soviet warplanes by the Moroccan Government was viewed in Paris today as a manifestation of Morocca's internal political problems and international ambitions.

The economics of the dollar has again come to the center of attention in the wake of President Eisenhower's order for vigorous governmental measures to reduce our balance of payments deficit. In the wake of this order attention is naturally centered on the elements of our international economic position which have contributed to the present situation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- There is a word much in use by the pressure-groups, which managed to transmute nearly all their special-interest programs into Democratic platform pledges, that can only add to the crushing weight of the burdens the next President must assume.

The city's largest organization of architects expressed firm support yesterday of the proposed new zoning resolution. Earlier in the week, six smaller architects' groups went on record as being strongly opposed to the new code.

If Penn State defeats Pittsburgh tomorrow and Army defeats Navy a week later -- and neither eventuality is unlikely -- it will take the wisdom of a Solomon to decide who rates the Lambert Trophy as the East's 1960 college football champion.

Carl Braun, the coach of the New York Knickerbockers, resumed active playing status yesterday. He will be a spot performer when the Knicks face the league-leading Philadelphia Warriors tonight in Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock in a National Basketball Association contest.
Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane yesterday announced new methods of checking rock salt to guard against short-weighting.

ONE of the most interested observers of the parade of Congo Army troops in Leopoldville yesterday was a slightly built man who has represented the United States in the turbulent Congo since it gained independence from Belgium last June.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 17 -- President-elect John P. Kennedy said today that Lyndon B. Johnson was equipped to be "the most effective Vice President in the history of our country."

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $32,000,000 to $168,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $6,000,000 to $613,000,000 from a revised figure the week before.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- It is the big week in Paris for "off-thepeg" fashion and this rapidly expanding business is attracting more and more foreign buyers each season. Each day is packed with showings, and many manufacturers come up from the south of France to show their increasingly popular beach and sportswear.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- The Westchester medical profession today urged controls to reduce the toll of injuries stemming from a recent increase in organized football for elementary school boys.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 17 -- Three thousand troops of the Congo Army staged an orderly parade here today that earned for Col. Joseph D. Mobutu the praise of United Nations officials and foreign diplomats.
Robert M. White 2d has resigned as president and editor of The New York Herald Tribune.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 17 -- The trend of business spending for new plants and equipment in 1961 is expected to be downward, but only moderately so, according to a nation-wide survey by the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, Inc.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago has confirmed what many observers of the economic scene had long suspected: consumer spending for services rose faster in the last ten years than spending for goods. The share of consumer expenditures going for services has increased from 33 to 39 per cent since 1949.

Hawaii sold $6,500,000 of harbor revenue bonds yesterday to a syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation and Blyth Co. on a bid of 100.21999 for obligations with 4.30 per cent interest coupons. The bid set an interest cost of 4,2912 per cent.
Diet-conscious persons were cautioned yesterday not to eliminate fats from their nourishment or subsist on other unbalanced menus.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The Government gave the 1960 cranberry crop a clean bill of health today.
There was hex in the air yesterday as Yale and Harvard left no omens unturned prior to their seventy-seventh football meeting tomorrow.

A state enforcement officer as barred in Federal Court yesterday from testifying in state court or before the State Waterfront Commission against longshoreman who was illegally arrested by Federal Customs agents.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17 -- School officials asked Federal Judge J. Skelly Wright today to suspend his school desegregation order until a Federal-state controversy here is settled.

The American League implemented its reiterated plan to expand to ten teams next season by outlining last night a player-stocking program that would cost the two new member clubs substantially more than $2,000,000 apiece.

DUNOON, Scotland, Nov. 17 -- Tucked away among the mistwrapped hills and waterways of west Scotland, the site for the projected supply base for United States nuclear submarines in Holy Loch may be physically snug and secure.

Business leaders and economists yesterday generally approved President Eisenhower's actions to cut the gold outflow by ordering Federal agencies to buy less overseas and "Buy American," as well as ordering home a large number of military families.

Lou Rossini, New York University's head basketball coach, is up to his old tricks. He's been perplexing fellow-riders as he travels between the Violets' University Heights campus and his Middle Village home in Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The continued downward business trend was reflected today in sharp declines in rail and truck freight loadings figures for last week.

The market for prime-risk corporate debt securities showed further weakness yesterday. Dealers reported that most issues were moving out of syndicate sluggishly with no established price level for the double A market.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 17 (AP) -- A New York souvenir vendor, who admitted paying a Florida fullback, Jon Macbeth, $1,500, was convicted today of bribery charges with the intent to affect the result of a football game.
BELHAVEN, N.C., Nov. 17 -- Everything came right in the goose hunting this morning but a little later the bears weren't where bears were supposed to be.

A Senate group was told yesterday that thousands of small businesses for which foreign trade is a strange, forbidding field could add considerably to the nation's exports if given a helping hand by the Government.

A new plan to help finance a college education for children now in the eighth to tenth grade has been developed by the Prudential Insurance Company in cooperation with forty-five major American banks.
The full impact on the Army and Air Force Exchange Service of President Eisenhower's directive Wednesday will not be determinate for some months, officials said here yesterday.
New advances in physics research that raise the possibility of a whole new family of electronic devices were made public yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Lanky Barry MacKay lifted America's Davis Cup hopes today when he rallied brilliantly to defeat the Australian champion Rod Layer, in a strenuous five-set semi-final of the New South Wales tennis championship.

A DEMAND for Victoriana is pressing old molds into action again. Thanks to factory find foundry owners from Toledo, Ohio, to Paris, France, nineteenth-century forms for Stoves, architectural elements, toys, mechanical banks and eighteenth-century glass table ornaments had been preserved for the current renaissance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy today declared himself in favor of day-care centers for children of working mothers. In a letter read before the joint conference on that subject opened here today by the Women's Bureau and Children's Bureau, Mr. Kennedy said:

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 17 -- Speed boating's regatta headliners and pleasure boating's non-racing elite assembled today for the November week-end selected for the sessions of the American Power Boat Association.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Completed elections to fill six vacancies in the International Court of Justice in concurrent session with the Security Council.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- While awaiting President-elect John F. Kennedy's post-Thanksgiving return, his aides were organizing a shadow White House in a downtown office building today.

AN unending wonder of the New York City Ballet is its refusal to allow itself to grow stale. Its program at the City Center last night might well have been a routine one, for though Frederick Ashton's "Illuminations" was down for its first presentation of the season, it has had first presentations in many previous seasons.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Reaction to President de Gaulle's plan to submit his Algerian policy to a popular referendum was muffled today by uncertainty over details of the plan and its probable final consequences.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Internal Revenue Service is investigating churches and other organizations to determine whether they violated their tax-exempt status by political activity in the 1960 election campaign.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- An Eastern Air Lines jet plane halted its take-off at Logan International Airport today when it collided with a flock of birds.

PAUL BROWN, the moody genius who coaches the Cleveland Browns, is not given to idle laughter. Only a gigantic jest can provoke a faint smile in this deadly serious man. He stepped slightly out of character at one point in the thrilling Browns-Eagles game a few weeks ago and he has been regretting it ever since.
FORT LEE, N.J., Nov. 17 -- The State Highway Department will start construction here soon on one of the largest and most complex traffic interchanges in New Jersey.

A two-year moratorium on demolition of middle-income housing here has been proposed to Governor Rockefeller in a letter from Harris L. Present, chairman of the New York City Council on Housing Relocation Practices.

Commodity futures prices closed irregularly lower in dull and featureless trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Potatoes, rubber, sugar, cocoa and wool declined; copper, hides and cottonseed oil rose, and price movements for zinc and coffee were mixed.
The Brooklyn rackets grand jury was ordered yesterday to start a full inquiry into alleged corruption in the Brooklyn office of the city's Tax Department.

The State Commission Against Discrimination said yesterday that it had conducted eighty-two investigations of alleged employment bias by public educational agencies without having its jurisdiction challenged judicially.
The darting, elusive hummingbird can be examined at leisure these days at the American Museum of Natural History.
Club owners of the American League, after a day-long struggle, cleared two hurdles yesterday in their determined efforts to complete their ten-club expansion program for 1961.

The Rockburn Farm's Cee Zee flashed a closing drive to win the Landmark Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Bill Hartack, riding the 4-year-old daughter of Heliopolis, guided her to a triumph by three-quarters of a length over Alvin Handmacher's Meticulous.
Mississippi has taken over the runner-up spot behind Wyoming in the race for the total defense lead in the major college football ranks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The grain futures market faltered again today under the pressure of heavy selling. All contracts except rye ended with losses ranging from major fractions to more than a cent a bushel.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Ford Motor shares were active again in the stock market here today. The price dropped sharply in early dealings on renewed heavy profit taking, but rallied to such good purpose in late dealings that they ended with a net gain of 2s 6d (35 cents.
Two playwrights and a novelist urged yesterday that the church serve as a patron of the arts, much as it did during the Renaissance.

Four hundred acres of land forming part of the Breezy Point area in Queens are being sold to 2,650 of the 2,900 families who own and occupy their homes there on land leases.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- A u60,000,000 ($168,000,000) merger is planned by two London banking houses, it was announced tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Eloy Sanchez of Mexico and Eder Jofre of Brazil, who between them have fought only seventy-two matches, meet tomorrow night for the National Boxing Association version of the world bantamweight title.
The Campbell Soup Company is expanding its food line into the bakery products field with the acquisition of Pepperidge Farm, Inc., of Norwalk, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended on Nov. 12, were 2 per cent below the level of sales in the corresponding week last year.

The Columbia football staff places a special value on a victory over Rutgers at Baker Field tomorrow. If the Lions win, Buff Donelli their coach, believes the triumph will mean much in rebuilding interest in the sport on Morningside Heights.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The United States will ask the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to permit shifts in troop dispositions and responsibilities borne by American forces in Europe. Official sources indicated that the request, would be made through the alliance's Military Committee, which is to meet in Paris just before the NATO ministers' meeting opening Dec. 16.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 17 -- The neutralist Government of Premier Souvanna Phouma has decided to establish "good neighbor relations" with Communist China and to send goodwill missions to Peiping and to Communist North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Herbert S. Marks, a Washington lawyer who served as the first general counsel on the Atomic Energy Commission, died in his sleep at his home here last night. He was 53 years old.

NOW is the time to give thanks for an abundant supply of high-grade turkeys. This country is particularly fortunate in the relatively low cost of poultry as opposed to other meats, and highly efficient processing methods ensure finest quality.

The traditional concept that dry cargo ships on regular runs can be operated profitably only if they carry both outward and inward shipments has been disproved in the opinion of the Matson Navigation Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Pete Quesada set records for speed and endurance while flying planes for the old Army Air Corps. He also has occupied a hot seat in government and business.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 17 (AP) -- One of the nation's top admirals today hailed the managing editors of Associated Press member newspapers as representatives of "the conning tower of one of the world's largest organizations, an organization dedicated to keeping the world informed."
Encouraged by their Wednesday night victory over the Boston Bruins, the New York Rangers yesterday planned practices at Long Island's Commack Arena today and tomorrow.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points off to 3 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
The twenty-sixth annual dinner dance arranged in behalf of Jewish Guild for the Blind will take place Wednesday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Citizens Union prodded Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate last night to back Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.
The Metropolitan Opera will give four performances in Chicago next spring in its first visit to that city since 1957.

Newsprint production in Canada in October declined slightly from the level of the 1959 month, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday. Although the decline was small, it was the first on a year-to-year basis in nineteen months.
THERE'S no making out anything, as Chekhov once ruefully remarked about a world that defies reason.
THE coin-operated laundry "is the modern version of the riverbank," according to Marc Van Buskirk, vice president of Ironrite, Inc., manufacturers of ironers.

PAINTINGS and drawings by Charles Shoup at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixtyfourth Street, prove how deeply this young American artist living in Greece is steeped in the somber tradition of late Renaissance Italian painting.

In announcing his measures for the defense of the dollar President Eisenhower and his aides have taken pains to assure our allies and friends that these measures are designed not to diminish but to enhance our military and economic strength and that the United States will continue to be a "strong partner" in the military and economic defense of the free world.
LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Jerry Pittman shot a six-under-par 65 today and took the lead in the first round of the $15,000 Cajun Classic golf tournament.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As it cannot call the leaders of the recent unsuccessful coup Communists, the Ngo Dinh Diem regime in South Vietnam calls them "reactionaries and tools of French colonialism."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flamming declared himself today a part of Vice President Nixon's "loyal opposition" to the incoming Administration.

HAVANA, Nov. 17 -- The Government-controlled press and radio denounced as "Yankee intervention" today the decision by President Eisenhower to send Navy units into the Caribbean to protect Guatemala and Nicaragua against any Communistdirected attack.
A former "cigar-smoking, whisky-drinking, tobacco-chewing lady killer" was honored yesterday by the West Point Society at a luncheon at Leone's Restaurant.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Final agreements were reached today to enable the Agora Development Corporation to build a combination shopping, office and transit center on eighteen acres in the deteriorated core of this city.
The three-day task of selecting a jury for the retrial of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan was completed yesterday afternoon in General Sessions Court.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday stepped into the weeklong inquiry by the city into charges of corruption in the Police Department. The Governor intervened by requesting Mayor Wagner and Ponce Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to send him reports "on the matters contained" in a complaint by a citizens' committee alleging irregularities in police operations.

Alfred A. Tananbaum, a textile converter who is also chairman of the trustees of Yonkers Raceway, has been named one of the defendants in a $6,000,000 suit accusing them of fraudulently withholding funds from former clients and causing their insolvency.

Governor Rockefeller's renewed pledge of a rebate next spring on personal income taxes, to amount to 10 per cent and cost the state about $90,000,000 in revenues, is good news that is subject to qualification. Once made, in a political season, the promise had to be kept unless the bottom fell out of the economy and threw all budget computations out the window.

James C. Hagerty, press secretary to President Eisenhower, will become vice president of the American Broadcasting Company in charge of news and public service. John Daly resigned from that post on Wednesday.
A CORNUCOPIA of holiday gifts is pouring out its bounty today on Ninety-second Street, with Christmas thirty-seven days away.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 17 -- President Eisenhower has ordered United States naval units to patrol Central American waters and to shoot if necessary to prevent any Communist-led invasion of Guatemala or Nicaragua.
MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- Premier Khrushchev formally opened Moscow's new Friendship University today for those he called "the children of workers" of Asia, Africa and Latin America.
Eight young women will make their formal bows to society Nov. 26 at the second annual Doric Debutante Cotillion at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East Sixtieth Street.

PHELPS, Wis., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The body of Carl J. Kohler Sr., a member of the industrial and political family that produced two Governors in Wisconsin, was taken today from the island hunting lodge where he died alone last Friday.

The Maritime Administration's war-risk insurance programs pose "a potential exposure to United States taxpayers of perhaps $10,000,000,000" in liability, Ralph E. Wilson, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, said here last night.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 -- The way finally seems clear for negotiations leading to an understanding between the Roman Catholic Church and the Communist Government of Yugoslavia, informed sources said today.

The Public Service Company of New Hampshire sold $5,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds yesterday to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates on a bid of 100.162 for obligations with 5 1/8 per cent interest coupons.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks preserved their home unbeaten record tonight with a 4-2 victory over the Boston Bruins. It was the seventh triumph on home ice this season for the Hawks, who also have tied two here.
Sales of the nation's leading retail store chains rose 1.9 per cent for October from the comparable 1959 level, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.
Coach Jim Lee Howell put his New York Giants through a vigorous two-hour drill on the Yankee Stadium turf yesterday, but the man most Important to the team's offense sat in a chair on the sidelines.
The Indus River development plan and the sharing of its waters by India and Pakistan were called last night "a billion-dollar investment in peace."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Superior Judge Lloyd Nix today gave leaders of the mechanics union until Sunday to halt a strike against the Metropolitan Transit Authority or face penalties for contempt of court.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Dick Groat, who led the Pittsburgh Pirates to their first pennant in thirty-three years and their first world championship in thirty-five years, today was named the most valuable player in the National League.
MORRIS, Ill., Nov. 17 -- The world's first electronic central office telephone system was dedicated here today in this city of 7,958 residents seventy-five miles southwest of Chicago.

Two new books by Saul K. Padover, author of seventeen works about America and Americans, will be published five days apart. One will be "The World of the Founding Fathers: The Basic Ideas of the Men Who Made America."

YONKERS, Nov. 17 -- James A. and Mary L. Blanchard's Time To Pace, with Harold Fisher in the sulky, scored a three-quarter-length victory over Smart Set in the Crestwood Pace before 17,059 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 18 -- The Congo Army regime announced tonight that the Congo had severed diplomatic relations with Ghana. It also threatened to prevent the proposed visit of a United Nations conciliation commission, by force if necessary.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18 -- Business will continue its moderate decline for several months but will turn upward in mid-1961, according to a group of economic experts here.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 18 -- Tribal warfare in northern Katanga is increasing dangerously, the United Nations warned here today. It said it had received a report that the bodies of eighty slain Africans had been found near the village of Langwe.
Two men in a hit-and-run car were shot dead and two companions were captured last night after a pursuit through Queens at speeds up to ninety miles an hour.
The blaze on lower Broadway last night touched off a total of nine alarms -- five in Manhattan and four in Brooklyn -- a rare occurrence in the annals of New York firefighting.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A peculiarity of our election system which we seldom think about is our practice of throwing out of active political life the defeated candidates for President and Vice President. Certainly it would seem that men thought by their party to be qualified for these positions would have much to contribute and that it is unwise to deprive the country of the value of their experience.

A ten-acre tract on Bellevue Avenue in Butler, N.J., has been sold by the Good Will Industries, a charitable institution that formerly used the site for a camp for under-privileged children. Charles Gualemi of Little Ferry bought the property through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Harvard cleaned up on the intramural level but Yale won the football contest that counted most today in the mass competition that precedes the game between the Blue and Crimson varsity elevens.
BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Ed (Butch) Songin passed for three touchdowns in Boston's 42-14 American Football League victory over Dallas tonight. It was the worst defeat of the season for the Texans.
A governmental agency to promote the development and consumer use of textiles was urged here yesterday by a union of textile workers.
GUATEMALA, Nov. 18 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes recommended today that police action similar to that taken by the United Nations in Korea be taken against Cuba.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 -- With an unusually broad accent on The Game between Harvard and Yale here, the football season will end for most of the varsity elevens tomorrow.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Michael Foot, advocate of Britain's nuclear disarmament and neutralism, won Aneurin Bevan's old seat in Parliament for the Labor party today.

A specialist on crime and delinquency told the Women's City Club yesterday that the present system of dealing with crime and juvenile delinquency could be changed only through citizen action committees. The system is now costly and inefficient, he said.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Dartmouth and Princeton, both picked to finish near the bottom of the ivy league in pre-season polls, will be battling for high first-division places at Palmer Stadium tomorrow. Game time is 1:30 P.M.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- Chancellor Adenauer pledged West Germany today to undertake increased economic aid to developing countries as a "political and moral obligation of special importance."

A corporation that collected $25,000 from residents of New York's Puerto Rican community for elaborate bus tours to Mexico, and then, it is charged, failed to provide the promised hotel accommodations, meals and bullfight tickets, faced state action yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -- The United States was urged today to support Israel and to oppose the United Arab Republic for membership in the Security Council of the United Nations.
Columbia and Rutgers will close out their respective football seasons this afternoon at Baker Field at 1:30. A crowd of 12,000 is expected to view the contest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The State Department today urged the American Medical Association to do something to ease the plight of about 2,500 foreign doctors who have failed to pass qualifying examinations and now face deportation.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Nov. 18 -- Operation Deep Freeze Sixtyone, which has already lost more than twenty days in the Antarctic as a result of bad weather and communications blackouts, was frustrated again today by new radio difficulties.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 18 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy is giving serious consideration to the appointment of his younger brother Robert as Attorney General.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 18 -- Wolfgang von Trips of Germany arrived here unexpectedly today. His presence assured a four man contest for third place in the 1960 world championship auto driver standing when the United States Grand Prix is run here Sunday.

The St. John's basketball team, considered by many as the metropolitan team to watch this season, has its problems. The Redmen have four returning starters, plenty of depth, a top coach and an attractive campus.
"DAVE'S PLACE," an hour-long telecast over Channel 4 last night, starred Dave Garroway in what was primarily a promotional feature in behalf of the National Broadcasting Company.
A new television show called "The World Of..." will probably make its debut on the National Broadcasting Company network early next year.
WARSAW, Nov. 18 -- The Polish Government has imposed new controls on private United States fellowship programs under which more than 150 Polish scholars and scientists study abroad each year.

The highly coveted title role in the screen version of "Lawrence of Arabia" has been given to Peter O'Toole, a 27-year-old Irishman acclaimed as one of the most gifted young performers on the British stage.

For the first time in its 168-year history, the New York Stock Exchange has made it mandatory that its members doing business with the public and the general partners of those member firms be bonded.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A spokesman for the State Department said today that the United States viewed the developments in Laos with concern.
