A comedy by the late Ferenc Molnar, entitled "There Is a Play Tonight," will be presented in January at an off-Broadway theatre by the new team of Rosemary Murray and Joyce Henry.
A program to strengthen the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation has been proposed as part of the legislative program of the United States Savings and Loan League.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- In a blow aimed at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, thirty nations have been instructed by the International Bureau of Expositions not to take part in any fair in the United States for the next ten years except the Seattle Exhibition of 1962.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: J.J. Singh's letter published Nov. 8 raised the question of the legal position of Tibet.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Australia named its team for the Davis Cup challenge round after rain prevented play today in the New South Wales tennis tournament.
SANTA FE, N.M., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The College Entrance Examination Board was accused today of trying to impose a standard program of instruction on the nation's schools.
The Kings County rackets grand jury voted its first indictment yesterday in its investigation into possible corruption in the Brooklyn office of the city's Tax Department.

The Government filed a suit in Federal Court here yesterday to test the validity of a change in policy by the Internal Revenue Service that no longer permits corporate deductions for losses resulting from devaluation of foreign currency.

Jack Brause, realty investor, has contracted to buy three five-story loft buildings at 90 to 94 Grand Street and 42 to 50 Greene Street, the northeast corner. The property, 211 by 100 feet, is a block from the proposed Broome Street Highway from the Holland Tunnel to the Manhattan Bridge.
The $75,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap will be run at Aqueduct today, but the two "big" horses, Capt. Harry F. Guggenheim's Bald Eagle and Mrs. Richard du Pont's Kelso, won't be in it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Justice Department issued today a finding that the National Labor Relations Board lacked authority to rule on disputes between American maritime unions and American owners of foreign-flag vessels.

The Elysian calm of suburbia will be shattered today by an annual event more compelling than crabgrass -- the Rye-Harrison football game. All this week there have been giant rallies in both towns, barbed repartee among the supermarket carts, and even some sharp words over Westchester County dinner tables.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The stock market ended the week on a subdued note, with small gains and losses among both industrials and British Government securities evenly distributed.
THE fall national tournament of the American Bridge League begins today at the Statler-Hilton Hotel and will continue through Sunday, Nov. 27.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Selwyn Lloyd conferred today with officials of the Ford Motor Company of the United States and the Ford Motor Company, Ltd. (England) concerning the bid by the American company for complete ownership of its British subsidiary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The transition from the Eisenhower to the Kennedy Administration gained some speed on several fronts today.
Something disastrous always seems to befall the New York Knickerbockers in the closing seconds, and last night's National Basketball Association game with the Philadelphia Warriors was no exception.

The American Stamp Dealers' Association opened its twelfth annual national postage stamp show yesterday at the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street. The show will continue through tomorrow.
The state legislative hearing on public welfare wound up here yesterday concerned almost as much with social graces as with social welfare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 119.6 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The advance reflected a 1.2 per cent increase in the farm products index.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 18 -- Last week's fiasco on Lake Mead, Nev., which caused a cancellation of this year's Gold Cup regatta, provided one of today's big discussions at the fifty-seventh annual meeting of the American Power Boat Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Eisenhower's brother, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, who a president of The Johns Hopkins University, has served the outgoing Administration in a number of capacities, but all were advisory rather than executive.

At least two men are watching the official recanvass of the vote in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties with more than casual interest. They have spent most of the last few days, in fact, peering over the shoulders of election officials.
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- President de Gaulle's plan for an independent French nuclear striking force was the target today of another censure motion introduced in the National Assembly.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 18 (AP) -- William A. Mackie lost his long fight against deportation today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The outgoing Eisenhower and incoming Kennedy Administrations are pondering further measures to ease the deficit in the country's balance of international payments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming told the closing session of the Conference on Day Care for Children of Working Mothers today that the Federal Government must provide leadership in this field.

Striking out at economists and observers who believe the nation should have a fixed rate of growth each year, Leslie B. Worthington, president of United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that such persons were afflicted with "economic myopia."
Residents of two more Murray Hill buildings were rendered homeless yesterday as a result of the collapse of a five-story building at 145 East Thirty-fourth Street Thursday night.
Last night's fire at Broadway and Grand Street, which halted service on the Broadway line of the BMT subway, recalled the Wanamaker fire in 1956, which shut down the subway for two days.
Most commodity futures prices again drifted lower yesterday in generally dull and listless trading.

Three firemen were trapped and killed last night in a savage blaze that swept a downtown loft building and touched off fires in five near-by structures. Five other fire- men were injured and sent to the hospital. At least six more were treated at the scene for cuts and bruises.

In a move to keep the Castro regime of Cuba from stirring up Communist revolutions in Latin America United States warships and planes now patrol Central American waters with orders to shoot if necessary to prevent armed Communist-led aggression from abroad against two countries in that area -- Guatemala and Nicaragua.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A young New York woman scored a stunning success in a violin concert at Tchaikovsky Hall tonight.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Began consideration of Credentials Committee's report on seating of Congolese delegation.

A one-volume collection of Walt Whitman's prose writings on his experiences during the Civil War will be published by Knopf on Monday. Called "Walt Whitman's Civil War," it has been edited by the American poet and critic, Walter Lowenfels.

SAXOPHONE recitals are not unknown in New York. They are rare enough, however, to make them a novelty when they come along. Late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, Paul Brodie presented one in his local debut reminding listeners that they can be both musical and entertaining.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the General Assembly defeated today a motion to postpone discussion of its Credentials Committee's report on seating the Congolese delegation:

American-Standard The American Radiator Standard Sanitary Corporation has acquired the assets of the Rochester Manufacturing Company, Inc. in exchange for about 125,000 shares of its common stock, it was announced yesterday.

TWO of New York's finest young musicians -- David Soyer and Harriet Wingreen -- appeared in Town Hall last night as interpreters of four sonatas for 'cello and piano, and their performances were first-rate from start to finish.

Fifteen hundred leaders of finance, industry, labor and government watched themselves lampooned last night on the stage of the Astor Hotel's grand ballroom by members of the New York Financial Writers' Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- On a winter night two years ago, Lawrence Lea drove home along the New Jersey Turnpike through a snowstorm, with his nose pressed against the wind-shield. He decided to do something about the bewildering red lights on the cars ahead, and his idea matured this week in a patent.
A strike of clerical workers of American Export Lines, Inc., was authorized last night at a meeting of union delegates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Republican campaign officials ordered field checks today that might lead to vote recounts in eight states -- and even possibly a turnabout victory for their Presidential candidate, Vice President Nixon.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Eder Jofre of Brazil captured the National Boxing Association's version of the world bantamweight championship tonight with a spectacular one-punch knockout of Eloy Sanchez of Mexico in the sixth round of their scheduled fifteen-round fight.

BRINGING home the bacon can he a sad task for anyone on a low-salt diet since it generally means playing spectator while the rest of the family enjoys, a fragrant breakfast. Fortunately, however, such a sacrifice is no longer necessary -- provided the diet restrictions are not too severe.
The American League's bold move to expand to a ten-club circuit for the 1961 baseball season moved yesterday into a state of suspended animation.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Corn and oats futures continued their decline today on the Board of Trade, but other grains and soybeans firmed somewhat after a succession of fairly broad losses.

Two metropolitan New York colleges that will play their final games today entertain hopes of winning the Lambert Cup, symbolic of the Eastern small-college football championship. They are undefeated Wagner of Grymes Hill, S.I., and once-beaten Hofstra of Hempstead, L.I.

The ninth annual Hungarian Piarist Ball will be held Dec. 2 in the Plaza. Proceeds will go to a scholarship fund that supports students in the schools conducted in this country by the Piarist Fathers, a teaching community of Roman Catholic priests founded in the seventeenth century.
BASKETBALL Detroit Pistons vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Detroit. (Television -- Channel 4, 2 P.M.)

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 18 -- The temporary White House here was standing pat today on its statement that it had dispatched United States Navy surface and air units to Central American waters to "seek out and prevent" any intervention by Communist-led forces in the internal affairs of Guatemala and Nicaragua.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 -- The Chrysler Corporation said today that production of its De Soto automobile would be discontinued at the end of this month. The company said the reason was poor sales and declining consumer interest in cars in the medium-price field.

HAVANA, Nov. 18 -- Revolucion, a semi-official newspaper, accused the United States today of having taken the first step toward attacking Cuba and called on Latin America to protest against United States "intervention" in sending naval ships and planes to protect Guatemala and Nicaragua against any communist-led invasion.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This letter has been written to express fully my views and those of a thousand other teen-agers on the subject of the feud for power in the Democratic party between the Lehman-Roosevelt-Finletter reformists and the De Sapio-Prendergast regulars.

Defensive issues rolled forward in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Such "money rate" or "sure dividend" stocks virtually dominated the market, possibly in anticipation of next week's $1,050,000,000 addition to the reserves of Federal Reserve member banks.
RICHARD STRAUSS' "Arabella" is an exquisite opera, and those of us who love it are grateful to Rudolf Bing for his faith in the work.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 18 -- The University of Tennessee voluntarily adopted a policy of desegregation on the undergraduate level at its regular trustees meeting yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The objectives of brush-fire peace, if properly defined, are attainable. And, If attained, they would unquestionably produce an easier world atmosphere. These objectives may be stated accordingly:
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A dispute over who should handle certain electrical work halted construction today on launching facilities for two huge space rockets, Saturn and Centaur.

Georgetown, Ky., sold $2,500,000 of industrial revenue building bonds yesterday to an investment banking group headed by Fox, Reusch Co. The group bid 97.05 for the bonds with coupons of 3 1/2, 3 1/4, 4 and 4 1/2 per cent, setting a net interest cost to the borrower of 4.4359 per cent.
Dealers in high-grade corporate securities whittled away at their inventories of new bonds and debentures yesterday in a steady market.

BACK in the middle Nineteen Twenties Shura Cherkassky first made a name for himself here as a gifted Russian-born teen-age pianist. His recitals in the two following decades were provocative for the tremendous virtuosity he showed.

There was much speculation in baseball circles yesterday concerning the players who have been made available to the new Washington and Los Angeles clubs. Baseball experts guessed that a number of "name" players have been offered, but foresaw no surprises when the list is released.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Navy has acquired a new plastic boat that flies -- a hydro-skimmer that travels over the water on a cushion of air.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 18 -- The neutralist Government of Premier Souvanna Phouma has apparently agreed to form a coalition Cabinet that would include the pro-Communist Neo Lao Hak Xat party.

BEFORE an audience of approximately 3,000 experts in the field, the Fashion Group yesterday presented its semiannual showing of American designer fashions at the Sheraton Astor Hotel. The clothes shown were suitable for all seasons, all climates, for work and for play nearly twelve months of the year.
The Bell Intercontinental Corporation and its subsidiaries (formerly Bell Aircraft Corporation) reported yesterday a net income of $2,113,186 for the first nine months of this year.
The short interest figures released by the New York Stock Exchange showed yesterday an increase to 4,135,870 shares on Nov. 15 from 3,757,480 shares on Oct. 14.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke disclosed tonight that he planned to retire next August when his term as Chief of Naval Operations expires.
MIAMI, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Favored Syracuse stopped a fierce Miami drive 6 yards from the goal line with thirty-six seconds left tonight and beat the Hurricanes, 21 -- 14.

YONKERS, Nov. 18 -- Mockig Byrd scored a one-and-one-quarter-length victory over the late-challenging Glenville before 24,173 fans in the Hartsdale Pace at Yonkers Raceway toight. The winner paid $15.10 or $2 to win.
TODD BOLENDER's "Souvenirs" had its season's premiere by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night, in a crisp, skillful and very funny performance.

BELHAVEN, N.C. Nov. 18 -- Geese are Irresponsible, brainless birds without any sense of the fitting. They are always acting on inane irresistible whims. They are so exasperating that hunters ought to boycott them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service today struck at gambling operations across the country. Its agents, some using helicopters, mounted 105 raids in fifty-four cities.
In so far as guests are concerned, the concerts of the New York Philharmonic this week-end could be called south-of-the-border events.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The Air Force today banned travel of dependents overseas after Feb. 1, 1961, thus becoming the first service branch to put President Eisenhower's orders into effect.

Shareholders of Campbell Soup Company were told yesterday of a $30,000,000 program of investment in foreign subsidiaries during the present fiscal year. William B. Murphy, president, noted at the annual meeting in Camden, N.J., that the program consisted, in part of a $2,000,000 production plant in Mexico and a $4,000,000 manufacturing plant in Australia.

Strange Native Habits An outlander visiting the city recently was startled by what seemed to him the strange mass behavior of some New Yorkers. He was on a ferry at the morning rush hour when suddenly, without warning and while the boat was still some distance from shore, the people around him stood and moved together to a forward position.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- "Well, the dog days are over," said a Conservative Member of Parliament tonight. "Michael's back and things will hot up a bit." Michael Foot, newly elected Labor Member for Ebbw Vale, Aneurin Bevan's old constituency, can be guaranteed to make the House of Commons a livelier and more interesting place for spectators if not for the Conservative Govern- ment or for Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Parliamentary Labor party.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 18 -- The New York State Psychological Association said today it intended to state its position in a Supreme Court case involving school psychological records.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 -- A Federal court ordered today a continuation of integrated classes in the city schools pending its study of a plea for a temporary suspension.

The city is now ready to make direct loans to owners of rundown multiple dwellings who wish to rehabilitate them for rental to low-income tenants, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

A lean future for United States shipyards that make military and commercial vessels was forecast here yesterday by the incoming president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Garwol, owned by Louis E. Wolfson, will be a slight favorite in the $50,000-added Pimlico Futurity tomorrow.

HAVANA, Nov. 18 -- The Soet Union has been urging a course of "prudence" and "moderation" on the Government of Premier Fidel Castro in recent weeks.

Mixed Thanksgiving Day services for Christians and Jews as well as joint services for varied Christian denominations have been scheduled for Thursday at a number of Protestant and Jewish houses of worship here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The General Assembly rejected two moves today to postpone discussion on seating a delegation from the Congo headed by President Joseph Kasavubu.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 8 points (40 cents a bale) yesterday. October was the only contract to resist the decline; it closed unchanged at 33.35 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Investors whose United States savings bonds of Series F and G will mature in 1961 were invited today to exchange them for regular nine-year Treasury bonds carrying 4 per cent interest.

A contractor testified in General Sessions yesterday that Sidney J. Ungar, a real estate operator, had paid him to make extensive renovations in the apartment of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack at 45 West 110th Street.
The bid of the Ford Motor Company earlier this week to take over complete control of its British subsidiary has produced an immediate reaction here and abroad.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy ordered yesterday a wide investigation of the city's cabarets and the police who issue work permits to employes of the night clubs.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Contracts were signed today for a low-income public housing development that will resemble a spacious suburban neighborhood.

Kyle Rote, the New York Giants' pass-catching left end, had a new cast placed on the broken finger of his left hand yesterday. The arrangement turned out so well during an offensive workout at Yankee Stadium that it is likely Rote will see limited duty against the Philadelphia Eagles in the National Football League game there tomorrow.
GENEVA, Nov. 18 -- Poland moved closer today to the non-Communist trading countries by becoming associated with the thirty-eight-member General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Washington State almost shattered Washington's hopes for a return to the Rose Bowl but the Huskies rallied in the final period for an 8-7 victory.

PARIS. THE local movie scene could hardly be more lively since Parisians have had a rich choice of film fare from top directors presented to them in one glamorous gala after another in past weeks.

Committee members have been announced for the fifth annual Humanitarian Award Dinner of United Cerebral Palsy of New York, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Dec. 5.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The American Medical Association, under pressure from the State Department and hospitals, moved today to grant a six-month reprieve to 1,902 foreign physicians who failed a qualification test.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Maryland recovered two fumbles, blockel a kick and got two long kick-off returns today for a 44-12 Atlantic Coast Conference football romp over Virginia.

The national board of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists has cleared the way for a strike against the networks. The board rejected contract proposals made by the employers last week.

NERVE PROTEIN -- Isolation for the first time of the protein that combines with the chemical named acetylcholine to make possible the transmission of the electrical impulse along the length of the nerve fibers was reported last week by Dr. Seymour Ehrenpreis, assistant professor in the Department of Neurology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University.
Downtown real estate still holds the loyalty of many investors in commercial property, despite the current vogue for outlying sites.
In forty-one years of watching people travel and helping them over the rough spots, Mathew Romes has found that tourists haven't changed much.
EVER since a man named L. Slade Brown from Orange, Tex., turned up in New York, life for Edward Padula has been a series of golden surprises.
The pre-Christmas season will bring an ironic blend of good and bad financial tidings for the country's steel workers.
The first test version of a statellite able to intercept and inspect other orbiting vehicles will be launched by the Air force in two years, according to Aviation Week.
A basic two-family house, already in production at a New Jersey colony, is being enlarged to serve as a prototype for the remainder of the development.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Senator John L. McClellan announced today that his Investigations subcommittee would hold new hearings, starting Dec. 13, to show continued "racketeer control" of New York City locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

With all reserved seats sold early last week, the New York Giants and Philadelphia Eagles are expected to attract a crowd of 63,000 to Yankee Stadium for their football game at 2:05 P.M. today. About 11,000 bleacher seats and 1,000 special children's seats will go on sale at 11 A.M.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica -- Even out of season, this is a wonderful holiday spot, as more and more lucky autumn visitors are beginning to discover for themselves.

The two-part presentation of Eugene O'Neill's tragedy, "The Iceman Cometh," now being shown on New York's discerning independent television station, WNTA-TV, is more than a local treasure; in time the implications of the extraordinary theatrical triumph may be felt nationally.
When the whistles blow at 9:45 A.M. Thursday they will signal the start of the thirty-fourth production of Macy's annual Thanksgiving Day Parade.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 19 -- Minnesota's Rose Bowl-conscious Gophers captured a share of the Big Ten football championship today by rolling past Wisconsin, 26-7.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- A complicated set of figures, once looked at only by ivory-tower scholars, and a drastic Presidential directive illustrated dramatically this week the last agony of the outgoing Eisenhower Administration.
LONDON. FRIDAY, the West End will celebrate a theatrical phenomenon -- the eighth anniversary of Agatha Christie's "The Mousetrap."

DURING a performance of "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera a short time ago the question came up in intermission talk as to what really constituted a great Carmen. An old-timer spoke resonantly of Farrar and Jeritza.
CAIRO, Nov. 12 -- Startling new population figures and a slow start on the building of the Aswan High Dam is troubling Egypt's planning experts.
Tests administered to 450,000, high school students from all parts of the nation have shown that only one in 100 could write a five-minute theme without making mistakes in English.
A record of $45,000,000,000 in total personal income was set last year in New York State, the State Commerce Department reported last week. This was 3,000,000,000, or 7 per cent, higher than in 1958.

IN a ten-page introduction to the valuable volume of "Four Screenplays of Ingmar Bergman," published here (in English, of course) last week by Simon and Schuster, timed to coincide with the New York opening of Mr. Bergman's new film, "The Virgin Spring," the dis- tinguished Swedish director has this to say about himself.
GUATEMALA, Nov. 19 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes said today that basic military training for the greater part of the Guatemalan Army was being reoriented to guerrilla warfare tactics.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -- Eleven leading theologians in South Africa's influential Dutch Reformed Church published today a book denouncing the country's race policies.

THE high school band is an American phenomonon. Because so many school bands are so good and because so many of their instrumentalists have gone on to college, the American college band has developed, too.

EDUCATION is off to a lively season as a subject of fiction. Already we have seen John Hersey's biting, entertaining, challenging look at public schools and the corraling of "genius" types in "The Child Buyer."
On Dec. 3, 1935, the first lowrent housing project built by the New York city Housing Authority was dedicated.

A good deal of the exuberance went out of the stock market last week. The post-election "Kennedy rally" -- as some analysts and observers had dubbed it -- ran out of steam and prices showed a net loss for the week for the first time in a month.

To the Drama Editor: IT is a pity that your critic could not find Anouilh's play, "Becket" more fully worthy of its great theme. Even that truly great actor, Laurence Olivier, in what you describe as an immensely resourceful performance of "Becket," coupled with Anthony Quinn's performance of the King, is apparently unable to pull the play across that tenuous line which divides failure from success.

In spite of the disturbing news from New Orleans and other parts of the Deep South, the situation of the American Negro is not wholly discouraging. It is helpful to look at the Department of Labor's report, "The Economic Situation of Negroes in the United States," just published. This document is more than its title implies.

IN the early death of the Austrian painter Egon Schiele (1890-1918), twentieth-century art suffered a major loss, whose extent can be measured in the important loan exhibition of his oils, water-colors and prints, organized by the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston and shown here until Dec. 15 at the Galerie St. Etienne.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- An extracurricular program in the Pearl River Junior and Senior High School called "Exploring and Enjoying New York City" has proved so successful that it is to be continued indefinitely.

THE author of this book, James Morris, has been the correspondent of several important newspapers -- among others, The Times of London and The Manchester Guardian -- in various remote and exotic parts of the world.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Lehigh's eleven bounced back from five straight defeats today and closed its season with an impressive 26-to-3 triumph over Lafayette in the ninety-sixth football game between the schools.
Conveniences unthought of a few years ago are being included today in housing projects designed for lower-income and middle-income families -- even though the projects must be built on tight budgets.
The cooling menthol brands of cigarettes, which had only a small percentage of the cigarette market a few years ago, have become one of the hottest items in the industry.
DALLAS, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Baylor defeated Southern Methodist, 20 -- 7, today but saw its chance for a share in the Southwest Conference title washed up when Arkansas downed Texas Tech.

ON the surface this latest book by William O. Douglas exalts the beauties of nature in eleven of our present wilderness areas, and it does that extremely well. The heart of the book, however, is a vigorous plea for the preservation of our wilderness.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Ohio State, outplayed for nearly three periods, struck savagely for a touchdown early in the final period today and downed Michigan, 7 -- 0.

ABILENE, Tex., Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Bob Gaiters and Pervis Atkins sparked undefeated New Mexico State to its ninth vic- tory of the season tonight as the Aggies whipped Hardin-Simmons, 40-3, in a Border Conference game.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Clark Mayfield's 26-yard field goal in the final period led Kentucky to a 10-10 tie with Tennessee today in a game that ended with a five-minute free-for-all by players and fans for the ball.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- Henry Ford 2d said today that the Ford Motor Company intended to make its offer in sterling for the minority shares of its British subsidiary -- Ford of England.

Richard C. (Dick) Charles of Dallas, the commissioner of the new National Bowling League, says he is a novice on the alleys too. He averages 155 now but should do better when he is surrounded by the wealth of talent the twelve-team loop expects to sign soon.

HONG KONG. IN the last few months, a new wave of extravagant praise of "Mao Tsetung Thinking" has swept over China. One realm of this thinking which, Peiping says, has made new and creative additions to Marxist-Leninist-Stalinist theory, is literature and the arts.
YONKERS, Nov. 19 -- George U. Coger's Hoot Dolmont from Rochelle Park, N.J., scored a nose victory over Paleface Hanover in the feature trot before 27,844 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs crushed the Montreal Canadiens, 6 -- 3, before 17,420 fans in a National Hockey League game tonight. The victory extended the Leafs' unbeaten streak to four games and moved them to within a point of the league-leading Canadiens.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Utah wrecked Utah State's dreams of a perfect season today and prevented the Aggies from gaining outright possession of the Skyline Conference title. A final period touchdown produced a 6-0 victory for the Redskins before a crowd of 29.261.
The Netherlands recently defeated England in chess at Flushing, the Netherlands 10 1/2 -- 9 1/2.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- On the stage of Congress Hall in Berlin six men faced a thousand or more students, anwering questions about Germany's Nazi past.

THE awareness of the demand to choose begins, for an American in Africa, immediately -- sometimes on the first day. Africans keep asking: Where do you stand? Are you supporting Africa or your allies -- the French or the Algerians, the Portuguese or the Angolans, the British Kenyans or the African Kenyans?

WESLEYAN PLAN -- What is described as the first center for advanced studies in non-technical fields has opened at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn. Visiting fellows will include professional scholars, writers, artists, jurists, industrialists and others who will devote most of their time at the center to their own research and creative work.

IN a benevolent mood Ten- nessee Williams has written a comedy, "Period of Adjustment." But his basic view is unchanged. As one of the characters sums it up in the final moments of the new play at the Helen Hayes Theatre, "The whole world is a big hospital, a big neurological ward."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- An undercover policeman, William Powell, 30 years old, was found slain in his automobile today under an approach to the Benjamin Franklin Bridge.

"WHAT are the benefactions bestowed by this book?" asks Robertson Davies about one of his innumerable subject-volumes. If we turn the question back toward his own "A Voice from the Attic," we are likely to find its benefactions so many and so various that no single characterization will suffice.

HERE at last is a survey of surrealist painting which treats its subject with breadth, thoroughness, sympathy and judgment. Without apparent effort it avoids the sectarian approach which we have come to expect from those who have been involved in the movement as its author, Marcel Jean, has.

THE science of rocketry reached one of its imaginative high points in the concept of a missile that could be popped up from a submerged submarine, fired by delayed impulse after clearing the water, and then guided to an enemy target as far as 1,200 miles away.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics posted a 58-38 lead in the first half, then repulsed a Syracuse rally in the third period and scored a 114-94 victory tonight.

BAGHDAD. IN the Bab el-Sharja, which is the Times Square of Baghdad, stands an unintentionally eloquent symbol of Iraq's unfinished revolution. Above the heads of the listless curry vendors and the ever-hurrying, black-robed women a broad concrete slab rises like an enormous billboard, resting on concrete pillars.

THE central theme of Adda Bozeman's broad and thoughtful survey is that world relationships today are confused by a critical misconception. We have taken it for granted too readily that the legal and political ideals of the West can be understood and adopted by non-European peoples.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- A number of delegations here are now considering the possibility of revoking the South-West Africa mandate held for forty years by the Union of South Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--The President's Science Advisory Committee expressed concern today that an "artificial and fundamentally wrong division" was developing between research and teaching in the nation's universities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The torment of New Orleans as the first touch of desegregation came to her public schools this week suggests important guidelines for both sides in the continuing struggle over segregation.

BURLINGTON, Vt, Nov. 19 -- Mrs. Electra Havemeyer Webb of 740 Park Avenue, New York, and Shelburne, widow of J. Watson Webb, an insurance executive and international polo player, died today in Mary Fletcher Hospital.
BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Phil Mariner of Centerport won the opening Region I regatta of the Peneuin class today. The five-raca sailing series was conducted by the Babylon frostbite fleet.

PROVO, Utah, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Wyoming tied for the Skyline Conference football title today by trouncing Brigham Young University, 30 -- 6.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP) -- A sophomore quarterback, Randy Gold, passed for one California touchdown and scored another today as the Bears whipped Stanford, 21 -- 10.

Department store sales in the nation fell 2 per cent in the week ended Nov. 12 from the 1959 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. In the preceding week there was year-to-year decline of 4 per cent.

ONE of the striking aspects of a big bridge tournament today -- and the national tournament now in progress at the Statler-Hilton Hotel here is one of the biggest -- is the extent to which the hosts go to entertain the out-of-town contestants.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Oregon State and Oregon played a 14-14 tie in the sixty-fourth game of their football rivalry today.

Christmas shopping tradiionally begins right after thanksgiving and the toy industry is girding for about 60 per cent of its volume for the year. Figures are spotty but sales are expected to top last year's record retail level of $1,608,500,000.

Wagner College wrapped up its first perfect season in football yesterday by beating Upsala, 19 -- 14. It was Wagner's thirteenth straight victory over a two-season span.

NAHA, Okinawa, Nov. 16 -- The top United States official in this strategic island base, with a population of nearly 900,000 Japanese-speaking people, believes that the governmental system installed here by the Americans "lacks a lot of refinements that a United States administration should have."

Here he disembarked and proceeded by road and air to Rhodesia, where he stayed with friends before catching another liner home from Cape Town.

DEMING, N.M. -- A treat is in store for winter motorists who take U.S. 80 through the heart of Texas to the West Coast. They not only avoid much of the disagreeable weather of the more northerly routes but also pass through a part of New Mexico that is rich in Indian ruins, historic lore and mountain vistas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Mickey Vernon was named manager of Washington's new American League team tonight.

FIVE prominent flower arrangers in the metropolitan area will be taking a busman's holiday on Thursday when they fashion Thanksgiving Day designs for their own homes. They will use fruits, nuts and flowers in glowing autumn colors to interpret the harvest theme.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N.J., drove a new Cooper Formula to victory today in a prelude to tomorrow's United States Grand Prix.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Restoration of the Thomas Halsey Cottage, the state's old- est frame dwelling, is proceeding on schedule despite some difficulty in acquiring authentic interior furnishings. The house dates to 1648.

SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The Summit Cotillion will be held Dec. 27 at the Canoe Brook Country Club here.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 16 -- A new edition of the Bible will be published by the Hebrew University. It will be based on a 1,000-year-old codex rescued from a burning synagogue in Syria in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq has taken new steps against Iraqi Communists.

Writing from Havana, Times Correspondent Max Frankel reports that the Soviet Government has been counseling "prudence" and "moderation" to the Castro regime. Premier Khrushchev, it appears, does not like to have Fidel Castro rattling Moscow's rockets. Understandably, the Soviet leader would prefer to reserve that right for himself.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson arrived here today to participate in the sixth annual parliamentary conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The United States delegation consists of eight Senators, one Senator-elect and ten Representatives.

TWO audiences -- one at 3 P.M. and the other at 9 -- crowded into the auditorium of the New School for Social Research yesterday to hear eight musicians pay tribute to Alban Berg by giving beautiful performances of his works.
The Committee for Modern Zoning urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to adopt without delay a proposed new zoning ordinance for the city.

Spectator interest in yesterday's important meeting of the New York Football Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles all but exceeded the fervor normally associated with The Game in various collegiate circles.

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame urged yesterday that the city earmark an additional $9,700,000 for new school projects in its proposed capital budget for 1961. The City Planning Commission had asked |67,948,165 for the projects.

WHEN Elizabeth Spencer's first novel was published twelve years ago I wrote in this space: "Fire in the Morning' is an unusually good first novel. Miss Spencer is not only intelligent and able; she is a natural storyteller with an original twist all her own. She should go far." She has gone far indeed.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- The Pittsburgh Steelers, tackled by destiny all season long, barely averted a last-second defeat by the Cleveland Browns in a violently played National Football League game at Forbes Field today.

SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 20 -- About 5,000 persons, mostly students, staged a demonstration here late today in protest against an alleged "counter-plot" to overthrow the regime that seized power last month.

"Richard II" will usher in the New York Shakespeare Festival's program, of free performances on June 19 in Central Park's new outdoor theatre, seating 2,500. Located in the Belvedere Tower area, near the West Eighty-first Street entrance, the festival's showcase is being built with municipal funds at a cost of $225,000.

The announcement in Hot Springs, Va., last week that the Shell Oil Company was compensating its agency with a flat fee rather than through the regular 15 per cent commission system has stirred widespread interest in the advertising world.

NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- The Old English sheepdog, Ch. Fezziwig Ceiling Zero, continued rolling along as a successful show dog tonight. The big white and pigeon-blue campaigner belonging to Serena and Hendrik Van Rensselaer of Basking Ridge became best in show in the forty-second event of the Newark Kennel Club at the 113th Infantry Armory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A long-range plan being developed within the Government proposes that the United States take the initiative in using satellites to provide weather forecasts to all the nations of the world.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 20 -- Six former United States first-team or reserve-team players were selected today to represent the New Atlantic region in the National Field Hockey Association women's tournament in California next month.
While Harold Rome was doing an oil painting of Jerome Weidman, they chatted about their forthcoming musical variation of Mr. Weidman's popular book, "I Can Get it For You Wholesale."
PARIS, Nov. 20 There is more talk about the boom in Europe petering out than evidence of it.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 20 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu, head of the Congo's military regime, insisted today that Nathaniel A. Welbeck, head of the Ghanaian Embassy, leave the Congo tomorrow morning.
Pupils who have transferred as a result of the Board of Education's open enrollment program were reported yesterday to have adjusted well to their new schools.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 20 -- A group of United States Embassy personnel narrowly escaped being lynched by an infuriated African crowd this morning after their auto had knocked down and killed a Congolese man.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -- The Religious Zionists of America, representing Orthodox Judaism in Zionism, ended their national convention here today with a call to the United Nations and the United States State Department to halt United Arab Republic interference with Israeli ships and cargoes in the Suez Canal.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 20 -- Yugoslavia's Communists are battening down the hatches for an anticipated storm from the East.
Two Cardinals were present in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning as the recently elevated Auxiliary Bishop Edward E. Swanstrom offered his first solemn pontifical mass at 10 A.M.
Development work has begun on an infra-red homing device to navigate American space probes during the final stages of their flights toward Mars and Venus.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. threatened yesterday to close down "an awful lot" of buildings in downtown Manhattan unless their owners acted quickly to end fire hazards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Civil Defense officials here are hopeful that President-elect John F. Kennedy will put some muscle into the home front's capacity to survive -- and thus help to deter -- a massive nuclear attack.
GENEVA, Nov. 18--Prices slid on the Swiss stock markets last week. Both domestic and international issues were affected by the weaker trend that set in at the start of the week.
The New Haven Railroad announced yesterday that it was accelerating its car-washing and cleaning program as a result of pledges by New York and Connecticut to give "cooperative remedial tax relief."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- Steel-order volume was down and output appeared to be leveling off again last week. Enthusiasm, for any significant change in the steel picture in the near future was lacking. Even so, the ability of the industry to keep the rate from falling to a level below 50 per cent of capacity may be significant.

Recent Federal attitudes toward the treaty rights of American Indians were condemned yesterday at the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, as the church observed its fifth American Indian Sunday.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 20 -- The only way to beat Stirling Moss is to wait for his car to break down. This remark is widely heard in international auto road racing. Moss' Lotus ran like a charm today, and the little Englishman scored a ridiculously easy victory in the Grand Prix of the United States.

COMPOSERS teaching in the Midwest and on the West Coast were featured at the Composers' Forum at the Donnell Library Auditorium Saturday night. The first was Robert Lombardo, a native of Hartford, who is on the faculty of the State University of Iowa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A majority of Latin-American states favor invoking the inter-American defense treaty against Cuba in connection with Guatemala's charge that Havana was behind the recent revolt in Guatemala, diplomatic informants said today.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The incoming Administration comes face to face with one of its gravest foreign policy problems tomorrow.
Stanley M. Isaacs, minority leader of the City Council, yesterday urged reimposition of the auto-use tax as a way of raising municipal funds to increase police salaries.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- For the last half century the economy of Ghana has depended almost wholly upon a single crop -- cocoa. Prior to 1911, however, the former Gold Coast ranked third in the world in output of rubber.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 20 -- Five representatives of the Louisiana State Government demanded of President-elect John F. Kennedy today a clear-cut stand on future Federal policies toward judicially enforced racial integration of public schools.

The rigors and joys of life in New York -- from subways and skyscrapers to pretty girls -- were evaluated over the week-end by twenty-eight foreign marine and naval officers. They arrived Friday from Quantico, Va., under a Government program to familiarize visitors from overseas with the United States.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20 -- The United States Supreme Court, a few days ago in a copyright suit, clamped down on the exhibition here of the silent-movie classic, "The Covered Wagon."
A thorough study of the size and qualifications of the staff needed to enable the Department of Purchase to operate with top efficiency and economy has been requested by Commissioner Roger J. Browne.
A state commission on the city's charter is studying methods of guaranteeing minority representation in the city's legislative body.

The New York Rangers were back at the old stand last night at Madison Square Garden and looked great for one period. Then they sent 10,307 fans home cold as they dropped a 4-3 decision to the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game.
Hyman R. and Irving J. Shapiro, builders, have purchased the property at 222 to 232 East Nineteenth Street under the name of Shapco Builders, Inc., for improvement with an apartment house.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 20 -- A brand new production of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" this afternoon opened the final week of the Dallas Civic Opera. It was sung by what on paper was a dream cast, and it was directed and designed by Franco Zeffirelli.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The forward-looking report of the Heald Commission on Higher Education in New York State is to be commended for focusing attention on an area too long neglected in the richest state of the Union. But at least in one respect the report takes a long step in the wrong direction.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Many United States diplomats who planned to return home on leave or move to new posts early next year have been told to unpack their suitcases.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Premier Souvanna Phouma announced today that he had signed an agreement with the leader of the Pathet Lao movement on ways, to end Laos' six-year civil war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- A Congressional group said today that "important and urgent" decisions relating to radiation protection faced the country.
DALLAS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The San Francisco Forty - Niners capitalized on Dallas mistakes, John Brodie's passing and Tommy Davis' toe for a 26-14 victory in a National Football League game today.

The Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, hailed yesterday President Eisenhower's decision to comply with Guatemala's and Nicaragua's requests for aid to prevent a Communist invasion.
LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Lionel Hebert of Lafayette won the $15,000 Cajun Classic golf tournament today with a twelve-under-par 272.

The Presidential directive last week ordering a reduction in United States military dependents abroad has created concern in the airlines. The industry is disturbed over the possibility of sharp cuts in military traffic on commercial planes.

Two Brooklyn savings banks have moved swiftly to apply for branches in West Hempstead, L.I. Until last week, neither savings nor commercial banks could establish branches in the Nassau County community because it was the location of the head office of a commercial bank, the Meadow Brook National Bank and state law prohibits branches in such places.
FOR many of the people who work in the city's department stores and specialty shops, Christmas is not just a matter of longer hours, gift wrappings and more cash sales. It is something to sing about.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 20 -- West German-United States financial talks, stemming from Washington's pressure for a greater West German contribution toward the non-Communist world's military and foreign aid costs, begin here tomorrow.
Bank stocks and selected specialty industrial issues led over-the-counter shares generally to higher ground last week in moderate trading.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- A private study deplored today what it described as a "loss of momentum" in the liberalization of trade policies between the United States and Canada.

An International Festival, to be held at the Sheraton-East on Dec. 12, will benefit the New York County Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Miss Brenda McCauley and Carl B. Menges are co-chairmen for the organization's fourth annual benefit, which will be a reception and cocktail party featuring booths representing many nations and a variety of games.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Slowly, reluctantly but steadily, British political thought on the highest levels is turning from national sovereignty toward some new grouping of the Atlantic states. In the British Government's present state of mind, half complacent, half apprehensive, nothing will be done quickly or clearly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The capital city waited quietly last week for the new men to come to town and get ready for the New Frontier.
SHARON, Conn., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Phyllis Haver, actress in the era of silent films, has been found dead in her home here. The State Police suspected today that she had committed suicide.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- The United States is expected to reply tomorrow to Soviet bloc charges that it has sabotaged efforts to restore peace and unity in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The deficit in the United States balance of international payments has produced new talk of a need for better coordination between the financial authorities of the principal industrial countries.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 20 -- The Rev. Thomas Maisonet, pastor of the Roman Catholic Cathedral here, said today that San Juan's woman Mayor would be expected to do penance publicly through the radio, television or newspapers before she; could receive communion.

LAST night's production of "Macbeth," which was seen on "The Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4, was an exciting and absorbing two hours. Maurice Evans and Judith Anderaon once again scored outstanding successes as Macbeth and his Queen.

HAVANA, Nov. 20 -- Maj. Raul Castro denounced today what he called United States "intervention" in the Caribbean. But he avoided reference to promises of Soviet rocket support for Cuba in the event of any United States attack.

SEATTLE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Representative Don Magnuson of Seattle, a Democrat, was declared today the official winner in one of the last undecided Congressional races, that in the Washington Seventh District.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cards wrecked Washington's defense today with a devastating passing attack in a 26 -- 14 National Football League victory over the Redskins.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 20 -- The shipping lines forming the Brazil-United States-Canada Freight Conference have agreed to maintain their rates on transportation of coffee to United States ports despite rate-cutting competition by tramp vessels.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Frank Mahovlich and Johnny Bower led the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-2 National Hockey League victory over the fifth-place Boston Bruins tonight before a crowd of 11,829 at Boston Garden.
Week Ended Nov. 18, 1960 A nervous undertone prevailed in the foreign exchange market during the past week. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar were erratic at times in active dealings.
Goodhue Livingston announced yesterday he would retire from the City Planning commission when his term expired Dec. 31.

Folks From Home Since the postwar revival of interest in sports cars, devotees of these high-powered little vehicles have developed a pronounced and somewhat snobbish attitude toward lesser motorists who travel the highways and byways in more conventional automobiles.
Five new films will open in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

MIAMI, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Vice President Nixon on a filmed television program released today, said he hoped President-elect Kennedy would have "tough sledding" in pushing Democratic spending programs through Congress.

IT was a tremendous football game that the Eagles and the Giants played at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, a drama of savage intensity that enthralled a turn-away gathering of 63,571 and left the New Yorkers in the uncomfortable position of being unable to afford another defeat this season. That ancient Australian weapon,the boomerang, came whirling back to conk the musclemen from Alma Mara on the back of their necks and fell them.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,017,784,391. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20 -- The Negro has forced a reversal of roles on the Southern police officer, according to an analysis of three riots in the region.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears combined long passing strikes and a brutal rush against Detroit's passers today to trounce the Lions, 28-7, in a National Football League game.
Three separate deals on the two Bronx blocks bounded by Zerega, Munn, Green and Newbold Avenues have been negotiated by J. Clarence Davies, Inc., brokers.

While various other leaders faltered or stumbled in the college football season's last Saturday of general activity, Yale marched with positive stride to its first perfect record in thirty-seven years.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with great interest in your Nov. 9 issue the letter from Edward Corsi, chairman of the board of the American Council for Nationalities Service, referring to the Oct. 24 report by High Commissioner Auguste R. Lindt to the General Assembly and to the subsequent article published in The New York Times.
One thousand policemen inspected 2,478 cabarets, dance halls and other licensed premises late Saturday and early yesterday in a mass check of the city's night spots.
Soviet scientists still have a long way to go before they will be ready to send a man into space, the official organ of the Soviet Academy of Science reports.
EASTERN players captured most of the top places in the first championship contests of the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament yesterday.

IF Jordan Olivar had not become a football coach he most certainly would have made an outstanding diplomat, which was his original goal. This subjective observation was offered yesterday by his wife, Stella, as they sat in the home of a friend just outside New Haven, Conn., and watched the Giants - Eagles football game on television.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The strengthened conservative coalition will be a force to be reckoned with in the new House of Representatives, according to the chief Republican strategist of the two-party alliance.

A GROUP of beautiful portraits of East European Jewry are set against the stark background of shattered post-war Vilna in "Mother's Sabbath Days," which started week-end performances at the Folksbiene Playhouse on Friday.

Verdi's "Nabucco" will be the subject of the first Metropolitan Opera broadcast of the season on Saturday afternoon, Dec. 3. It will be the first time the opera has been presented on the Metropolitan radio broadcasts, which are heard over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
Gerard Souzay's first recital here in four years last night at Town Hall was a triumph of sensitivity and musicianship.
The President's order to the services to reduce the number of dependents overseas and to take other measures to halt the outflow of gold has some negative aspects as well as some positive aspects.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams hurt Green Bay's National Football League title hopes today by beating the Packers, 33-31. The winning points came or Danny Villanueva's fourth field goal of the game, this one with twenty-two seconds remaining.

RINGOES, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The eighth annual National Field Trial Championship Stake for cocker spaniels ended its two-day competition today on the Amwell Shooting Preserve with the 1960 national title awarded to F.T. Ch. Berol's Petey Boy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A milestone in the development of this city was reached on Oct. 18 with the adoption by the City Planning Commission of a comprehensive amendment to the zoning resolution of the City of New York.

For a long while yesterday it appeared that the Giant handily ahead by 10-0 at the half, would wallop the Philadelphia Eagles and take first place in the National Football League's Eastern Conference.
Investment companies are like people. When the going gets rough, they turn to greener pastures.

A Harvard economist closely associated with President-elect Kennedy said in a telephone interview over the week-end that a 4 per cent growth rate would add $20,000,000,000 to this country's annual gross national product.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 20--After twelve days of golf, President Eisenhower made plans today for a day of quail shooting around Albany, Ga., before returning to Washington on Wednesday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Frank Carlucci told today how a screaming African mob beat and knifed him after a car in which he and United States Embassy personnel were riding, accidentally killed a Congolese man.

A GROUP of dynamic women with a cause has been annually providing auction-goers with an intriguing sale. Each year, a growing circle of potential buyers looks forward to the latest edition. It is an event that offers a variety of paintings, of antique furniture and decorations, the latest things in fashions, jewelry and, usually, a smart new automobile.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed sharply lower. This was in marked contrast to the preceding two weeks, when the trend had been upward.

As the Board of Estimate begins today its public hearings on the comprehensive rezoning resolution so important to intelligent, orderly future development of New York City it is appropriate to recall the early and influential leadership of Mayor Wagner toward zoning revision.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The grain futures market hit a succession of new low prices for the season last week as it extended its general decline through a second week.

Now that the Presidential election is over, Mayor Wagner's problems are multiplying rapidly. They involve not only his own future but the leadership of the Democratic party in the city; next year's Democratic city ticket; morale and discipline among city employes; the city's governmental structure, and many subsidiary and related questions.
"Sing Along With Mitch," first televised on "Ford Startime" last spring as a special program, will become a regularly scheduled feature Jan. 27 on the National Broadcasting Company network.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 21--Premier Hayato Ikeda's pro-American Government was swept triumphanty back into office in yesterday's election to the House of Representatives.
New York State's population grew more in the last ten years than in any decade since European immigration was at its peak in the Nineteen Twenties, the state Commerce Department said yesterday.
Peter McArdle, who works all week at putting buses into motion, resorted to man's oldest form of transportation on his day off yesterday and the outcome was a pleasant one for him.
The Rev. Hugh McCandless asked yesterday that the celebration of Christmas remain distinct from the traditional preparations for it during Advent.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The dominating influence in the stock market last week was the announcement of the bid by the Ford Motor Company of the United States for complete control of its British subsidiary.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 20 -- Nine thousand parents, educators and taxpayers of the metropolitan area visited a "dream school" today that this suburban city has built for $9,670,000 on a seventy-acre site.

Had owners of old buildings in the downtown loft district and city officials been standing on Grand Street just west of Broadway on Friday evening they would have seen an unforgettable demonstration of the terrible menace of fire that exists in that area -- one to spur them to effective preventive action.

IT takes more than fashion moguls and Seventh Avenue sportswear designers to change campus dress. Whether coed, Ivy League or strictly nonconformist, college girls along the Eastern seaboard have one thing in common: They have not taken to culottes.

THE epithet "gourmet" is overworked and underdefined in these days of increasing (but still far-from-complete) gastronomic awareness. It also is inclined to be overworked in the recently published "Holiday Magazine Book of the World's Fine Foods" (Simon Schuster, $15), where the word appears in the heading to each section.

Alex Quaison-Sackey, Ambassador of Ghana to the United Nations, called the United Nations, in a talk last night, "the only hope in the world today for the preservation of peace." He said the independent Africa nations would support it "through thick and thin."
Labor will urge Presidentlect John F. Kennedy this week not to let the narrowness of his election victory deter him from moving ahead at full speed on a liberal program.
Rapid-fire "automatics" proved the most deadly weapons in the arsenal of the Philadelphia Eagles in yesterday's victory over the Giants at Yankee Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana has made a special effort to reassure the West that his country is "neutral and nonaligned."
Stocks went through a vacillating, equivocating session yesterday and, despite the fact that The New York Times com- bined average ended down slightly, seem to have closed a little higher.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Tuesday, Nov. 22--Fighting between the United Nations forces and the Congo Army broke out last night for the first time.
The Republic of Panama will seek to join a Central American common market, it was disclosed yesterday by Vice President Jose D. Bazan.

Dr. Marion B. Sulzherger, a leading authority on skin disorders, venereal disease and immunology, was honored last night at a dinner in the Pierre Hotel on the occasion of his sixty-fifth birthday and his retirement last June as chairman of the Department of Dermatology and Syphilology at the New York University Medical Center.
JONES BEACH, L.I., Nov. 21 -- One-hundred and fifty well-wrapped men, women and children stood in pitch darkness at Jones Beach for an hour last night to gaze through telescopes at the stars.

The St. Louis Hawks, first in the Western Division, and the New York Knickerbockers, last in the Eastern Division, will meet in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The board of the Martin Company approved today a two-for-one split of the company's capital stock and increased the regular quarterly cash dividend from 40 to 50 cents a share.

WORLD WAR II taught some young writers to attack the art of the novel as if flame throwers were the best way to burn out their material. One thinks of James Jones, Norman Mailer and Vance Bourjaily as outstanding members of that energetically incendiary lot. But there were more; many, many more.
Rochester officials announced yesterday a pilot project to provide public housing for hardcore problem families that have been unable to qualify for such housing.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Industrial share prices weakened after early bouyancy in the stock market here today. Net changes at the close were small and irregular.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Senaor Dodd of Connecticut interrupted the current self-seeking chatter that national party platforms are a set of specific commands on all those elected to office in Washington, by telling some truths about these documents.
An unpublished and hitherto unknown poem by Walt Whitman has been discovered in an attic in Glendale, Calif.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued consideration of Credentials Committee's report on seating of Congolese (Leopoldville) delegation.

GEORGE RAPEE of New York and Mrs. Ralph Kempner of Los Angeles, with 214 match points against an average of 156, led a record field of 456 pairs into the second of three rounds of the masters' mixed pair contest in the American Contract Bridge League's fall national tournament last night.
Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut formally divorced himself yesterday from support of any section of the Democratic national platform "merely because it was adopted by our party convention."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Two weeks after the election, only ten of the fifty states have completed their official count of the nearly 68,000,000 votes cast.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Bronx District Attorney Isidore Dollinger moved yesterday to smash a tow-truck racket that he said had caused some unwary motorists to lose their automobiles to unscrupulous garagemen.

IF the nation's turkey growers have their way, a greater volume of the traditional Thanksgiving bird will be sampled next Thursday than ever before. That is not to say that more turkeys will be consumed, only that they will weigh more.
ROME, Nov. 21 -- Prime Minister Macmillan arrived by air shortly after noon today for two days of talks with Italian leaders.

TWO traditional methods of roasting turkey are given below. The first method, which requires frequent basting, will result in a bird with a crisp, browned surface and juicy meat. The low-temperature method produces a less crisp skin and meat that is also juicy, but which some people find has a more steamed than roasted flavor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- By a vote of 5 to 4 the Supreme Court decided today that a Detroit resident whose citizenship was canceled in 1953 might not have his case reopened on the basis of high court rulings in 1958 on other cases.

YONKERS, Nov. 21 -- The College Farms' Curly Harry from College Point, N.Y., won the Hutchinson Trot before 17,661 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The time of 2:04 2/5 for the mile was the fastest ever turned in by Curly Harry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Following are the conclusions and recommendations of the Interstate Commerce Comtnission's hearing oficers for rehabilitation of the New Haven Railroad:

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- Boston University announced today establishment of a six-year program of combined liberal arts and medical study for the "exceptionally gifted" student. The program will replace the traditional eight-year sequence for such students.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Union demanded tonight that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold report immediately on conditions in Leopoldville following today's clash between Congolese and United Nations troops.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 21 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors amended the County Charter today to clarify the duties of the County Planning Department and the Pathology Department.
Two United States-flag steamship lines are discussing with the Federal Maritime Board a plan that would permit them to invade the rich New York winter cruise trade.

"These are the hardest bargaining bunch of customers I've ever seen," one leading Manhattan automobile dealer confided yesterday. "Look at that fellow over there," he said pointing to one corner of his chrome-bedecked showroom.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 21 (AP) -- The State Commissioner of Education tonight urged President-elect John F. Kennedy to appoint a committee to determine the "proper role of the Federal Government in education."

ANY woman who ever has envied the ease with which a man can pack for an extensive journey will be gratified to learn that three pairs of pants plus half-a-dozen blouses and sweaters will see her through two weeks of a European vacation.
CLAUDETTE SOREL, who made her debut in Town Hall in 1943 at the age of 11, was back in that auditorium last night for an all-Chopin recital.
DALLAS, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Tom Brown, a guard from Minnesota, was the first choice of the New York Titans in the American Football League draft today.

Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. rose 2.9 per cent in the nine months ended on Oct. 31 to a record of $3,159,138,000 from $13,070,331,920 in the 1959 period, the company reported yesterday. Earnings however, declined 8.3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Two officers of the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended fare rises and tax relief today for the New Haven Railroad to prevent its financial collapse. The investigators, who made an eightmonth study, called for fare increases ranging from 20 to 30 per cent, the abandonment of little-used lines and better management.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21--Archbishop James P. Davis of San Juan issued special instructions today to the Roman Catholic clergy in Puerto Rico directing them not to apply sanctions or punishments to the supporters of Gov. Luis Munoz Marin's Popular Democratic party.

ONCE there was a man who had a week's vacation and decided to spend it in Philadelphia so it would seem longer. This was one of the old wheezers about the City of Brotherly Love revived last night by the Columbia Broadcasting System in "Big City -- 1980."

An investment banking group headed jointly by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Drexel Co., Glore, Forgan Co., and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. was awarded $25,000,000 of Port of New York Authority 3 5/8 per cent bonds yesterday.

WITHIN recent years, a new method of roasting turkey has been developed. It calls for wrapping the bird snugly in heavy-duty aluminum foil and cooking at a high temperature. This cuts the roasting time almost in half, as long as the oven maintains an accurate 450-degree temperature.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- Communists clashed with Vienna's security police tonight when they staged a demonstration outside the concert hall where a small group of monarchists was celebrating Archduke Otto von Habsburg's forty-eighth birthday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The kingpin of the Bantam League at the United Lanes of Fleetwood is Deirdre (Didi) McKeown, an 80-nound colleen who rolled a 133 game in duckpins a couple of weeks ago at the ripe old age of 9.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy will make an on-the-spot investigation to determine whether the Executive Branch has been complying with the atomic law in sharing custody of nuclear warheads with North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies.
A Federal mediator has invited representatives of the broadcasting networks and two performers unions to a meeting this morning in an effort to avoid a possible strike.
The British know how to reach the heart of an American Southerner -- through Gen. Robert E. Lee, of course.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Air Force launched a 500-pound space capsule to an altitude of thirty-two miles today and brought it safely back with the aid of a drag balloon and a parachute.
Minnesota's once beaten Gophers regained first place yesterday in The Associated Press' weekly football poll in a close battle with Iowa and Mississippi.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 -- Scheduled action on 1961 dividends was postponed here today until next month by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
HONG KONG, Nov. 21 -- Cuba is telling Latin Americans that only through bloody revolution can dictatorships be overthrown.

Investors centered their attention on the high-grade corporate sector of the bond market again yesterday. Dealers reported "pretty fair" volume in seasoned issues, but close bargaining by retail buyers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Treasury sold its latest weekly issues of short-term bills today at smaller discount rates than on last Monday. On last Monday's sales and the one before, the discounts had increased substantially.

In stinging condemnation of the Left-Wing riots which prevented President Eisenhower's visit to Japan, the Japanese people have returned Premier Ikeda and his Liberal-Democratic party to power with the biggest parliamentary majority accorded to any post-war Japanese Government. The Liberal Democrats, who made the election in effect a national plebiscite on the American-Japanese security treaty which they backed as their principal campaign issue, won 296 out of the 467 seats in the lower house.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 21 -- Prime Minister Nehru accused the Indian Communist party today of persistent subversive propaganda activities in frontier areas near Tibet.
ASHY talent occasionally illuminates "Whisper to Me," which opened last night at the Players Theatre on Macdougal Street.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 21 (AP) -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., today declared a year-end dividend of $2.25 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 14 to stockholders of record of Nov. 29.
Management, is becoming a leading factor in the decision of major mortgage lenders on refinancing commercial buildings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for independent oil companies endorsed today the Government's proposal to cut oil imports. But they complained that the planned reductions were not enough.
THE stolid, staring sphinx famed resident of the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, might well have blinked once or twice at the sight before his eyes last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A case that could strongly affect the controversial ban on "hot cargo" clauses in union contracts was argued today before the National Labor Relations Board.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 21 -- The United States' hopes of rocketing a man into space early next year were dealt a crushing blow today by the third straight failure of an unmanned space capsule launching.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today that the United Nations was facing the coming year with a "virtually empty" treasury.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Directors of Automatic Retailers of America, Inc. voted today a two-for-one split of the common stock, subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting on Jan. 10.
The large Soviet fishing fleet in the Norwegian and Barents Seas probably have been alerted against the United States missile submarine George Washington, which will patrol in these waters.

Ben Bedini, shirt-tail flapping and tie askew, trudged to the center of the Harrison High football field last Saturday. It was the first time in five seasons that he had used the word this way and it came hard. "Congratulations," he mumbled.
A theatre party has been arranged for the Dec. 22 performance of "The Little Moon of Alban" at the Longacre Theatre. Proceeds will go to the Maternity Center Association.

"Do We Need the Junior High School?" The Conant Report, "Recommendations for Education in the Junior High School Years," recently published by the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N.J., assumed that the junior high school is here to stay.
It may be that people swear most when they are happy and stop swearing when they are really glum.

Dr. Luther H. Gulick charged yesterday that architects and builders fighting the proposed new city Zoning Resolution were motivated by "a distinct personal interest in a chaotic development of this town."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 10 points (50 cents a bale) off yesterday. The near May contract was steady.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -- The United States has asked West Germany to furnish approximately $650,000,000 yearly to relieve part of the dollar expense of maintaining United States forces abroad.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Union renewed today in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization the drive initiated by Premier Khrushchev to replace the executives of international organizations with boards representing the Soviet, Western and neutralist blocs.

Norman Mailer, the writer, was arrested last night and accused of stabbing his wife, Adele. Mrs. Mailer, 37 years old, was in critical condition last night at University Hospital, Second Avenue and Twentieth Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Former President Truman has generally given me more cause for admiration than for disagreement, but his comments on the Electoral College appear to defy reason. In his article of Nov. 14 he wrote: "As it stands today, no combination of the larger states can impose their choice on the other states, even if all the larger states could get together for such a purpose.
Cargo volume on the St. Lawrence Seaway from April to October this year declined slightly from 1959, according to statistics released yesterday by the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.
"Europeans have a proprietary interest in Mark Twain. He is not just an American, but somebody who belongs to them."
IN "Marcus in the High Grass," Bill Gunn has given us a first play that is strongly influenced by the worst of Miller, Williams and Inge, not to mention the playwrights' best friend, Dr. Freud.
LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The Southern Zone deer season opened today and if all shots fired around here were aimed at bucks, there are no horns left in Sullivan County.

All Hands of the Cain Hoy Stable ran quite the way he was expected to in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The crowd of 24,067 backed down the 3-year-old son of Turn-To to 3 -- 4 favoritism in the mile race, and he won by four lengths.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov 21 -- The General Assembly's Economic Committee voted today for a $40,000 study of the economic effects of disarmament. The tally was 66 to 0, with 4 abstentions.
