TOKYO, Nov. 21 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda will continue at the head of Japan's pro-Western Government with one of the biggest parliamentary majorities any post-World War II Japanese regime has had.
Labor is gloomy about the results of state legislature elections in most parts of the country.

Steel production this week is scheduled to plunge below 50 per cent of rated capacity for the first time since the Labor Day week as a result of the Thanksgiving Day holiday and reduced demand for metal.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 21 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, neutralist Premier of Laos, said today that his Government had reached an agreement with the pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement to try to form a national union Government that would include Right-Wing representatives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- The Catholic legion of Decency said today that Hollywood was turning out an increasing number of morally objectionable films, Many were not suitable even for "adult only" audiences it declared.

Montgomery Ward announced yesterday that on Dec. 28 it would close its retail store at 150-18 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens. When it was opened in 1931, it was the largest department store in Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- City dwellers won another Supreme Court Hearing today in their long unsuccessful effort to compel redistricting of state Legislatures and thus cut down the power of rural voters.
Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and associates are offering to the public today 430,000 common shares of Berman Leasing Company stock at $14 a share.
NICE, France, Nov. 21--Wine and liquor companies do not exactly run professional sport in this country. They merely, to a large extent, pay for it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Proposals to reorganize the Government by creating the post of "super-secretary" or "first secretary" with higher than Cabinet rank were rejected today in a staff report of the Senate subcommittee on national policy machinery.

Business men throughout the country feel less optimistic about the first quarter of the new year than they did this time a year ago. That is the finding of a survey of 1,480 executives by Dun's Review and Modern Industry.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Tax reduction, as proposed by Governor Rockefeller, is bound to receive popular acclaim. Along with others, some reduction would be welcomed by the writer, too.
CAIRO, Nov. 21 -- The Cairo press charged today that the Zionists had opened a campaign to put pressure on Presidentelect John F. Kennedy to seek a Middle Eastern settlement on Israeli terms.
LONDON, Nov. 21-The British Government agreed today to let the Ford Motor Company of the United States make an offer for the minority shareholdings in its British subsidiary.

Reinforced by a Republican gain of at least 22 seats in the House, Minority Leader Charles A. Halleck of Indiana says he is looking forward to doing business as usual with his friend Howard W. Smith of Virginia, chairman of the Rules Committee and unofficial leader of the ultraconservative Southern Democrats of the House.

Sidney J. Ungar, the real estate operator who picked up the bill for renovating the apartment of Borough President Hulan B. Jack, refused to pay the contractor all that was owed him for the work, a witness testified yesterday.

The rapid and major changes which are taking place in our national thinking on the proper relation between science and government are vividly illustrated in the latest report of the President's Science Advisory Committee. Issued with Mr. Eisenhower's endorsement, the report proposes a massive increase in the Federal Government's role in financing and otherwise facilitating university basic research and training in the physical sciences.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- A Rumanian exile and a Frenchman from Alsace won two of France's most respected literary prizes today, the Prix Goncourt and the Prix Theophraste-Renaudot.
DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Bob Scheffing, a former catcher, with a reputation for handling young players, today was hired to manage the Detroit Tigers.
Although Columbia's basketball team doesn't open its season for more than two weeks, it already boasts a school record. It's the tallest squad in Lion history.
A lawyer who went to the trouble of retrieving his own summons from a forgetful patrolman was found not guilty yesterday in Vehicle Accident Court.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Following is the text of a speech today by Vice President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson to the parliamentary conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization:

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Vice President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson urged today that the Western powers "add new dimensions" to their military alliance by using it to promote economic and social gains throughout the world.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court charged six colleagues today with nourishing critics who say the court is incompetent in tax cases.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- For the first time in about twenty years the Supreme Court reversed today a jury's verdict awarding damages to an injured railroad worker.

Delaware Hudson Co. The Delaware and Hudson Company completed the sale of the assets of the Hudson Coal Company, a subsidiary, to the Blue Coal Corporation of Maine yesterday. Blue Coal is a subsidiary of the Glen Alden Corporation, a leading producer of anthracite coal.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 21 -- A leader in the trucking industry called today for an end to the "cold war" between railroads and truckers and between railroads and water carriers.
The Police Department yesterday suspended the cabaret license of the International Theatre Restaurant for four days, starting tomorrow, for violating police regulations.

Fashions change so rapidly today that for many style-conscious Americans there is no "wear-out" to clothing any more. Thus, many items of apparel in excellent condition are given to charity and others are rather self-consciously placed outside apartments for disposal by the superintendent.
DETROIT, Nov. 21 -- The Detroit Edison Company declared a quarterly dividend of 55 cents a share today on its common stock.

STAN MUSIAL was 40 years old yesterday, but the youthful glow has not faded from his boyish face. He was in town over the week-end and was discovered at the Yankee Stadium, taking in the Eagle-Giant football game.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 21 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy let it be known today that he intended to exercise the powers of the Presidency without interposing policy-making assistants between himself and top Administration officials.
Syracuse elected yesterday to bypass all post-season college football games and left New York's Gotham Bowl on fourth down, deep in its own territory.
WINSTON SALEM, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP) -- The National Grange drafted a program today calling, among other things, for reduction of the nation's grain surplus.
The Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday flatly opposed American League Expansion into their territory in 1961.

THERE was a time when shoes with flashing sequins or large fluffy pompons were reserved for Hollywood in many women's minds. No longer. It takes only a little daring and a lot of dash to make the sauciest shoe a natural accessory for an indoor evening.
Different ways of preparing a gravy or sauce for the Thanksgiving turkey are given here:
Nathanael V. Davis, president af Aluminium, Ltd., warned yesterday against excessive expansion of the aluminum industry that might greatly aggravate the present overcapacity problem.
DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -- United States automobile production for the calendar year will go over the 6,000,000-mark this week.
MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Union ordered today the immediate expulsion of an assistant air attache of the United States Embassy, Maj. Irving T. McDonald Jr., on charges of espionage.
LUCKY is the world of music and ballet. Since it is not cluttered with words, it sweetens one corner of sour international relations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company today was denied a Supreme Court hearing of its attack on the validity of Tennessee's Motor Vehicle Sales Licenses Act.
Kings County Judge Hyman Barshay criticized this city's tax assessment system yesterday, saying it gave too much discretion to individual assessors.
A television-like device acquired by the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium is designed to serve as a sort of electronic slide rule for probes into space.

The Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., were charged in State Supreme Court here yesterday with "gross misconduct and gross abuse of trust" in their management of Investors Mutual, Inc., prior to last April.
IN recent seasons the National Symphony of Washington has become a regular visitor, and last night it returned to Carnegie Hall for the sixth consecutive year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- United States diplomats regard the present Algerian situation as a race between President de Gaulle's efforts to find a solution and Communist efforts to enlarge the problem.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 21 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy advised Louisiana officials today that he could not properly comment on legal issues involving racial integration of public schools now pending before Federal courts.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- The latest fad in Hollywood is learning foreign languages.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Babe Simmons of the Bronx was awarded a knockout victory over Bartolo Soni of the Dominican Republic at the end of the seventh round last night in their light heavyweight main bout at the St. Nicholas arena.
Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday in full trading on New York Exchanges.
Few nations can match the degree of racial democracy that exists in Brazil, the Rev. Dr. John F. Soren, president of the Baptist World Alliance, said yesterday.
A Filipino woman doctor, her white coat crackling with starch, sat in a municipal hospital in the Bronx yesterday and said quietly:

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries attained the highest sales in its history during the three, nine and twelve months ended with October, Bruce A Gimbel, president of the big department store chain, announced yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 -- A campaign of harassment has developed here against the families of Negro pupils enrolled at two previously white schools.
Frank Gifford and Jim Katcavage, key men who were severely injured during Sunday's fiercely waged football game at the Yankee Stadium, will be lost to the Giants for the remainder of the season.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov 21 (AP) -- The University of Houston today placed runners first and second and won the team title in the National Collegiate cross-country run.

The five-story apartment building at 2676 Morris Avenue, at the corner of Kingsbridge Road, in the Bronx has been sold by the Sorkin Corporation, realty operator, to a client of George Dines, lawyer. The transaction, which was for cash above mortgages of $178,000, was negotiated by Schiffman Goldkopf, brokers.
SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 21-- A decision on United States recognition of the Salvadoran junta Government is expected shortly.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- In a strong closing spurt wheat futures moved up on a wide front on the Board of Trade here today and finished near the season's highest prices on most contracts.
A strike by clerical workers of American Export Lines forced 941 passengers to carry their baggage off the luxury liner Independence yesterday after she docked at 6:45 A.M. at Pier 84, North River.
NATHANIEL AZARCO WELBECK, Ghana's man in Leopoldville, began his political career, as have so many of the leaders of the newly independent states of Asia and Africa, in jail.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday that inspections made almost two years ago showed major fire hazards in the lower Manhattan loft building where three firemen lost their lives in a fire Friday night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The authority of the United Nations force of about 20,000 men in the Congo is to restore law and order. Orders have been given to the international contingents to defend themselves against attack, as they did in Leopoldville today, but not to become involved in internal quarrels.
Governor Rockefeller has been asked to appoint a committee of "public-spirited citizens" to decide whether the state's controversial Condon-Wadlin law should be repealed or revised.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Africa is about to become for the first time the major recipient of the multimillion-dollar United Nations expanded program of technical assistance.
The names of additional aides and patrons for the annual Imperial Ball have been announced by Mrs. Walter S. Gubelmann and Mrs. Stanley C. Hope, co-chairmen for the sixth successive year.

A breath of fresh air blew into the bond market yesterday in the form of the $75,000,000 issue of the mortgage bonds of the Consolidated Edison Company. The bonds are priced to yield 4.87 per cent to investors and bear a five-year protection against call.

BUFFALO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Teachers should not be awarded permanent licenses until they have passed a comprehensive examination and have shown in the classroom that they are able to improve professionally, a professor said today.
Activity increased somewhat in a few of the commodities markets yesterday. Those items showing greater activity included cocoa, rubber and the "M" contract for coffee.
The two-day-old strike of 325 office workers at American Export Lines forced the cancellation yesterday of a scheduled cruise and the postponement of two other sailings.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy disclosed yesterday that there were probably hundreds of "innocent" scofflaws who were unaware of their situations.
EUGENE ORMANDY brought his Philadelphia Orchestra to Carnegie Hall last night with two infrequently played works.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad won the right yesterday to increase the fares of its 12,000 commuters in Westchester County by 10 per cent.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 22 -- The High Court of Justice absolved former Premier Adnan Menderes today of responsibility for the death of his illegitimate son.
New York's vanishing subway and bus riders have stopped vanishing.

HANOVER, Germany, Nov. 22 -- West Germany's Social Democratic party, girding for the 1961 election campaign against Chancellor Adenauer, split today over the question of equipping the country's armed forces with atomic weapons.
ALBANY, Ga., Nov. 22 -- President Eisenhower made a quick switch from golf to quail shooting near the end of his two-weeks Georgia vacation today.
The first of two installments from the memoirs of Adolph Eichmann, who directed the round-up of millions of European Jews for extermination by the Nazis, is being published this week in Life.

Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor, stepping up a drive to break up a tow-truck racket in that borough, disclosed yesterday that he would begin presenting evidence Monday to a special grand jury.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The United States is sending a small group of Navy ships on a carefully timed visit to the west coast of Africa to "show the flag" and make friends.

Norman Mailer, the writer, was committed to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for observation. He was ordered there by Magistrate Reuben Levy, sitting in Felony Court, after Magistrate Levy had read a medical report that said Mr. Mailer was "both homicidal and suicidal."

ALTHOUGH it was written almost sixty years ago, Strindberg's "Dream Play" is more advanced than much of today's avant-garde drama, As produced at the Theatre East, where it opened last night, it is odd, perplexing and disquieting.
A report on eighteen, youths involved in gang violence in hitherto, quiet neighborhoods in Queens was submitted yesterday to Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You are correct in your editorial judgment of Nov. 21 holding that the only way to end the major menace of fire in the antiquated loft buildings around lower Broadway "is to do away with these structures entirely."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Federal regulatory agencies' common plea that they have more work than workers found no sympathy in a pair of management surveys commissioned by the Budget Bureau.

Harold K. Bradford has been elected president and director of five mutual funds affiliated with Investors Diversified Services, Inc. They are Investors Mutual, Inc., Investors Stock Fund, Inc., Investors Selective Fund, Inc., Investors Variable Payment Fund, Inc., and Investors Group Canadian Fund, Ltd.
The City Council passed a financial measure yesterday designed largely to help the Wagner administration avoid new or increased taxes in fiscal 1961-62, when a city election falls.
Happiness will wash away years of travail in the final episodes this week of "Ma Perkins," "Young Dr. Malone," "The Second Mrs. Burton" and other daytime radio serials.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 22 -- Hofstra and Queens shape up as the chief basketball powers of the Athletic Association of Long Island Colleges. This estimate is based on information supplied today in the Salisbury Club at a luncheon given by Adelphi on behalf of the six-member group.

HAVANA, Nov. 22 -- The Cuban Communist party denied today that the Soviet Union had urged moderation on the Government of Premier Fidel Castro in its relations with the United States. It denied also that Moscow had told the Cubans to quit "rattling Soviet rockets."

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Western legislators received a report today urging the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to give the "highest priority" to the creation of an "extremely mobile fire brigade" force to meet any attack on its flanks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- An international group of biologists reports development of a synthetic molecule nearly identical with ACTH, the anti-rheumatism hormone produced by the pituitary gland.

Broad St. Investing Broad Street Investing Corporation, the diversified mutual fund of the Broad Street group, announced yesterday acquisition of assets of Hall Investment Company, a $1,000,000 private investment company in Michigan.

When the American League moved yesterday to "cooperate" with Walter F. O'Malley and Commissioner Ford C. Frick, it blocked, if only temporarily, the possible return of Leo Durocher to the big leagues.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 22 -- Venezuela's new Cabinet was sworn in today. It contains three new Ministers and will hold its first official meeting tomorrow.

Directors of the Hanover Bank proposed yesterday that a one-for-nine stock dividead be paid on Feb. 28 to stockholders of record Jan. 31. To permit payment of the dividend, stockholders will be asked at the annual meeting on Jan. 18 to authorize an increase in outstanding stock from 4,500,000 to 5,000,000 shares of $10 par value each.
President-elect John F. Kennedy, on balance, was hurt by the religious issue and would have won much more strongly if he had not been a Roman Catholic, a major political analyst said last night.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 22 -- Father Tomas Maisonet, vicar of San Juan Cathedral, expressed surprise today at Archbishop James P. Davis' instructions that Roman Catholics who had voted for Gov. Luis Munoz Marin's Popular Democratic party should not be punished.
UVALDE, Tex., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- John Nance Garner diffused amiability today as he observed his ninety-second birthday.

Bridgeport, Conn., sold $2,330,000 of various purpose, general obligation bonds at competitive, bidding yesterday to an investment banking group headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank. The group bid 100.15999 with a 2.85 per cent coupon, setting a net interest cost to the city of 2.82 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The Illinois Democrats' last hope of reversing the Republican control of the state House of Representatives apparently died today when a petition for a recount was withdrawn in Fulton County.
A drive to raise $100,000 to combat juvenile delinquency here was opened last night by the Protestant Council of the City of New York.
The Union Oil Company of California is "actively" looking for acquisitions, particularly of crude oil producers, Reese H. Taylor, chairman and chief executive officer, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- A commission of the Protestant Episcopal Church said today it would recommend full communion with churches in Spain, Portugal and the Philippines that split from the Roman Catholic Church in the nineteenth century.
Controlling stock interest in Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., has been acquired by Maxwell H. Gluck, chairman and sole owner of the Darling Stores Corporation.
SENECA, S.C., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Dr. John R. Heller, head of the Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, was described tonight as standing "at that most shining point known to a human being."
With prices for top foreign films becoming prohibitive as a result of competitive bidding, American distributors are gambling more and more on pre-production investments with European film-makers.
Gainful employment has been found for six of the thirty Convair 880 jet airliners whose future has been as uncertain as the intentions of Howard Hughes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Government announced today that Table Mountain, near Boulder, Colo., would be the site of a National Center for Atmospheric Research.

ALREADY store aisles are heavily bedecked with Christmas decorations, but attractive as all this seasonal finery may be, there are undoubtedly many shoppers who would prefer to choose some of their Christmas gifts from the quiet of their own home.

"PROJECT 20," the National Broadcasting Company's periodic series devoted to backward glances at the current century, turned its attention last night to a nostalgic remembrance of "Those Ragtime Years."

Feasts and Thanksgiving It was Cotton Mather who pointed out to the people of Massachusetts that on days of "humiliation" and fasting they were not expected to abstain entirely from eating, but should restrain themselves enough to be conscious of deprivation.
In an address at Wittenberg College on Oct, 17 Senator John F. Kennedy spelled out for his Ohio audience a theme to which he alluded many times in his campaign:
Mayor Wagner and the Board of Higher Education were called on by the City Council yesterday to reject any proposed tuition charges in the city colleges.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Following is the rollcall vote by which the General Assembly adopted today a resolution seating President Joseph Kasavubu and his delegation as representatives of the Congo:
Electrical bed attachments to provide continuous monitoring of the conditions of acutely ill patients are among the devices in a new Roosevelt Hospital ward that opened yesterday.
Minnesota's Golden Gophers, after an absence of one week, bounced back to the No. 1 berth yesterday in the national football ratings by the United Press International board of coaches.
A disagreement between Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach, L.I., the Speaker of the Assembly, and Governor Rockefeller over refunding 10 per cent of state income taxes came to light yesterday.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- A steady drumming of rifle fire continued in these hills on the second day of the southern zone deer season and wise old heads here are putting all the blame on the party-deer system.

For a time yesterday it appeared that Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) had settled on an agency for its institutional advertising. But, as it turned out, that decision was still at least a couple of weeks away.
Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard, announced yesterday a $58,000,000 fund drive to strengthen the university's medical program.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The delegate from Cameroon who has led African opposition to the Soviet-bloc stand on the Congo takes pride in saying he is "a lackey."
GROTON, Conn., Nov. 22 -- The Navy's most powerful atomic submarine, the Ethan Allen, was launched today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 22 -- Navy's football team ran through an unusual practice session today in preparation for the Army game.

The New York Rangers, whose troubles appear to be mounting daily, received another shock yesterday. The National Hockey League's last-place Blues will be without Brian Cullen, a fiery center when they oppose the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The General Assembly, after a long and bitter debate, seated today a delegation headed by President Joseph Kasavubu as the representative of the Congo.

The Norfolk and Western Railway Company announced yesterday that its net income in October was $5,794,449 on gross operating revenues of $20,036,274. In the 1959 month, the carrier cleared $5,776,855 on gross operating revenues of $20,158,631.

OF recent years the Navy has developed at least two tremendous offensive weapons. One is the Polaris missile. The other is Joe Bellino. The second of these confines its firepower to the football field. The outcome of Saturday's Army-Navy game will hinge almost entirely on how effective Army technicians are in deadening the Bellino explosiveness.
Twelve men, including six furriers, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of consipiring to possess $50,000 worth of stolen mink coats and stoles.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The American Medical Association said taday that it was "standing fast" in its basic policy on foreign doctors who work in United States hospitals under a State Department exchange program.

CHRISTMAS comes but once a year, and this year it starts the day after Thanksgiving. On Friday, while many Americans will be seeking relief from the effects of holiday overeating, the nation's merchants will exhort them to get on with their yuletide gift shopping.

Kelso of the Bohemia Stable was named the horse of the year in the twenty-fifth poll conducted by The Morning Telegraph and The Daily Racing Form. Kelso is a 3-year-old gelded son of Your Host and Maid of Flight and was bred by Mrs. Richard C. du Pont, owner of Bohemia Stable.

BRISBANE, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston, a couple of teen-agers, sent the United States into the Davis Cup interzone final today by defeating Johnny Jose and Eddie Dungo of the Phillipines, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.
The American League yesterday offered a compromise proposal under which it would defer entering Los Angeles in 1961. The proposal consisted of these two points:

A young man who never played high school baseketball probably will develop into one of the best all-round players City College has had in a long time. He is Tor Nilsen, a 6-foot 4-inch junior, who scrapped engineering for geology.

A witness in the New Rochelle school case said in Federal Court yesterday that the school board had repeatedly expanded the zone for the Lincoln School, whose enrollment is predominantly Negro, so that it would absorb the influx of new Negro residents.

Directors of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad yesterday elected Milton G. McInnes president and chief executive officer. Mr. McInnes, 55 years old, succeeds Harry W. Von Willer, 64, who assumed the positions last month, when the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad and Erie Railroad merged.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- Coach John Stiegman of Pennsylvania said today he would start six seniors against Cornell in the last Ivy League football game of the season Thursday afternoon at Franklin Field.
The warm, wonderful sunshine in which metropolitan New York has been basking is a direct import from the Southwest and the Pacific Coast.
A petition to oust Carmine G. De Sapio as leader of Tammany Hall has been placed in circulation among Manhattan district leaders by two members of the Democratic reform faction.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Michie Stadium, usually reserved for formal entertainment of Army football opponents, has been transformed into a practice area for Saturday's game with Navy.
Sidney J. Ungar told a jury yesterday about his financial interests in two matters that had required approval by the Board of Estimate, of which Borough President Hulan E. Jack is a member.
Employers representing many of the city's key industries yesterday welcomed a bid to join with labor and the medical profession in seeking to curb rising hospital costs.

GENEVA, Nov. 22 -- The United States pressed the Soviet Union today to get down to serious negotiations on the issue of on-site inspection of suspected violations of the projected treaty banning nuclear weapons testing.
Sales of the chemical industry this year should total $28,000,000,000, a rise of 9 per cent above last year's record level, a leading industry official estimated yesterday.
A total of 840 persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was sixty-three fewer than in the comparable period of 1959.

A formula establishing a system of royalty payments to the International Longshoremen's Association for the movement of export-import cargoes in containers through the port of New York was announced yesterday.

Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens announced yesterday that the Port of New York Authority was studying the feasibility of erecting barriers at New York International Airport to reduce noise in nearby residential areas from planes taxiing or warming up.

The Ingersoll-Rand Company reported yesterday that net income for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $18,351,000, equal to $3.03 a common share. In the 1959 period, the company cleared $17,683,000, or $2.92 a share.

Men and women who helped develop this country are the subject of "The Unforgettable Americans," which Channel Press of Great Neck, L.I., will publish next Monday. Edited by John A. Garraty, the volume contains biographical essays by Bruce Catton, Thomas J. Wertenbaker, Whitfield J. Bell, Donald Culross Peattie, Howard Mumford Jones, Allan Nevins and others.

The nation's basic sugar law expires next March 31 and the new Congress will have to act fast after taking office in January to adopt new legislation. Yesterday the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange offered the Government some pointed advice -- namely, refrain from buying or selling sugar on its own or making sugar barter agreements with other countries.
After drifting almost unchanged for most of the day, prices on the New York Stock Exchange slumped in the final half-hour. The tape ran late for a time just before the close.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Corn futures, with gains running to 1 7/8 cents a bushel, had the unusual role of bellwether today in a stronger grain market on the Board of Trade.

PARIS, Nov. 22--Vice President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson spent forty-five minutes with President de Gaulle today. He left with a knowledge of the French point of view of many issues and in a glow of mutual admiration.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- United States District Judge Bryan Simpson has two objections to consider at a hearing on Friday on a proposed final decree to complete the reorganization of the Florida East Coast Railway Company.
"The Best Man" and "Toys in the Attic" will return to the early Wednesday night curtain time at 7:30 o'clock, starting next week.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Approved report of Credentials Committee on seating Congolese delegation of President Joseph Kasavubu.

ROME, Nov. 22 -- The leaders of Britain and Italy agreed today that an East-West summit meeting should not be attempted unless it was thoroughly "prepared" beforehand and some promise was received from Premier Khrushchev that he would be "reasonable."
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Gov. Jimmie H.Davis said tonight New Orleans public school teachers would be paid immediately.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Diplomats said today that political pressure would force the British Government to ask West Germany for further financial support of troops there should the United States obtain support costs from Bonn.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 22 -- Nathaniel A. Welbeck, the Ghanaian envoy whose ouster had been demanded by Col. Joseph D. Mobutu's military regime, left the Congo today alter the end of fighting between Congolese and United Nations forces over his presence.

The Innocenti Corporation of Milan, Italy, manufacturer of the Lambretta motor scooter, has leased part of the twenty-seventh floor in the Time Life Building, 1271 Avenue of the Amerieas, at Fiftieth Street. The company will use the space for executive offices.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Officials of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said today that they were asking five other major aluminum producers to participate in the $180,000,000 Volta River aluminum smelter project in Ghana.
Aqueduct's crowd of 19,521 divided roughly yesterday into two groups -- those who backed Jackie Leonard's eight mounts on the nine-race program, and those who bet against him.

No matter how the New York Knickerbockers perform, the result always seems the same. Last night in the feature game of a National Basketball Association double-header in Madison Square Garden, the New York team went down to its fifth straight defeat.
Joseph Nardone has resigned as New York director of the Federal Housing Administration.
The wholesale commodity index climbed to 83 on Monday from 82.7 last Friday. The daily index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 85 on Nov. 18, 1959.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Sweeping changes in the White House were forecast today by its incoming social secretary, Miss Lettia Baldridge.

THE street where it all happened was called Peaceable Lane. Somewhere in the green and pleasant land of northern Westchester County, it had been constructed by a commercial builder named Riccetti who knew how to take advantage of the flight to exurbia. He built eleven houses and sold them for $30,000 apiece to eleven middle-class families.

Frank Gifford, the New York Giants' halfback who suffered a deep concussion when he was tackled by Chuck Bednarik of the Philadelphia Eagles at Yankee Stadium last Sunday, "still has the desire" to play football.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Food and Drug Administration today ordered an end to the use of F.D. C. (food-drug-cosmetic) Red No. 1, a water soluble coal tar color that is widely used in food, drugs and cosmetics.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- President de Gaulle's plan for an independent French nuclear deterrent survived another critical test tonight when the National Assembly reluctantly expressed its confidence in the Government of Premier Michel Debre.
Mild, fair weather is expected for New York's Thanksgiving tomorrow.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 22 -- The United States Grand Prix, run here last Sunday, was the last world championship driver event of the season. It was also the last run on the championship circuit for the two-and-a-half-liter engine.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The present effort to revolutionize NATO by giving it a private stockpile of American atomic warheads dates from an informal meeting at Lake Como last Sept. 9.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Georgia's method of counting votes by "county units" is under legal challenge again.

Alco Products, Inc. Directors of Alco Products, Inc., (formerly American Locomotive Works) reduced the quarterly dividend yesterday to 10 cents a share from the 15 cents paid in each of the first three quarters this year.
Borough and division commands in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be reorganized tomorrow to modernize the Police Department.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The establishment of a Rockland County park to be used exclusively by local residents moved forward today. The county Board of Supervisors appointed two appraisers to examine three properties selected from a list of eleven recently examined by the county Planning Board.
A helicopter lifted a rail-truck-sea cargo container from a Weehawken pier yesterday to the deck of a merchant vessel anchored in the Hudson River in the first such public demonstration here.
Supermarkets usually try to outdo one another in the variety of merchandise they offer their customers.
Prices of cotton futures or the New York Cotton Exchange moved 9 points off to 3 up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The Illinois Appellate Court ruled today that George L. Ramsey, city building commissioner, acted illegally when he refused to issue a permit for wrecking of the Garrick Theatre Building, sixty-eight-year-old landmark at 64 West Randolph Street in the theatre district.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 22 -- The United States financial mission to Bonn has won almost no concrete pledges from West Germany for early contributions to relieve the dollar outflow caused by the stationing of United States forces abroad.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 22 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy and leaders of organized labor agreed today to postpone a meeting on labor's goals to the new Administration.
The second annual PAL Ball next Tuesday at the St. Regis Roof will benefit the Police Athletic League, Inc.

WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Chic Calderwood of Scotland, the British and Empire light heavyweight champion, suffered a possible broken nose in the fifth round but hung on gamely to outpoint Sonny Ray of Chicago tonight in a ten-round bout at the Empire Pool.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. urged the city's textile and garment workers yesterday to walk off their jobs if there were fire hazards where they worked.

MACY'S thirty-fourth annual Thanksgiving Day Parade will begin at 9:45 A.M. at Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street. The parade route is down Central park West to Columbus Circle and then down Broadway to Herald Square, where the parade will end at noon.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 22 -- President Francois Duvalier's Government declared martial law today, dissolved student associations and gave university students twelve hours to end a general strike and return to classes or be expelled.
THE final round of play for the masters' mixed pair championship began last night. in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here.

THE apparently inexhaustible gifts of George Balanchine came up last night with a new and ravishing manifestation of beauty when the New York City Ballet at the City Center presented the first performance of his choreographic setting of Brahms' "Liebeslieder Walzer," all of them, both op. 52 and op. 65.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Louis Joxe, a senior diplomat, was named today by President de Gaulle to carry out the President's program to prepare Algeria for ultimate political self-determination.
The crackdown on the city's night spots continued yesterday as the Police Department announced temporary license suspensions for twenty cabarets for violating work-permit regulations.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Many of the industrial leaders turned slightly dull today on the stock exchange here today. In the face of profit-taking and the hesitancy of buyers. Most changes, however, were less than a shilling (14 cents).

WARSAW, Nov. 22 -- The summit meeting of Communist leaders from forty-five countries has ended in Moscow with an "interim understanding" on disputed political and doctrinal issues, according to information reaching Warsaw from the Soviet capital.

An issue of $75,000,000 of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., first and refunding mortgage, Series S, 5 per cent bonds, due Dec. 1, 1990, will be offered today. A syndicate headed by The First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., which won the award of the issue yesterday, will place it on the market at 102 and accrued interest to yield 4.87 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- United Air Lines, Inc., said today that it had agreed to pay a "package price" for Capital Airlines, Inc., and was interested in a merger with Capital only on that basis. United told the Civil Aeronautics Board, in a brief filed with Thomas L. Wrenn, an examiner, that "if the entire Capital system is not included in the Board's approval, the merger will be abandoned."

ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- The State Motor Vehicle Bureau announced today that it was establishing a new driver's license, about the size of a credit card, and that it would be mailed automatically to every driver whose license was about to expire.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Senate investigators of gangster influence on professional boxing said today they were keeping twenty-five witnesses under wraps for their protection.
A record operating-budget request of $45,493,000 for 1961- 62 was made public yesterday by the municipal college system.

Safeway Properties, Inc., Bernard Siegel, president has purchased the three-story commercial building with a selling basement at 5216 to 5224 Fifth Avenue, corner of Fifty-third Stree, Brooklyn. The building, in the Bay Ridge area, occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is fortunate in a way that the failure of the police to tag cars followed by their frenzied activity to issue summonses has indeed occurred. It points up to the fact that the police ought to be removed from issuing summonses for traffic violations in which any standing unoccupied car is involved.

Checks made by the city in twenty-six Federal census enumeration districts indicate a population larger than the tentative figure of 7,710,346 announced by the Census Bureau in July, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame declared yesterday.
The Department of Defense yesterday withdrew its recent requests for proposals from commercial airlines on the carriage of military overseas traffic during the calendar year 1961.

The favorable trend in sales and earnings of the KimberlyClark Corporation that began a year ago was continued for the fifth consecutive quarter, John R. Kimberly, chairman, noted yesterday in issuing the financial report.

The nation's most influential group concerned with mathematics teaching has recommended a detailed program that would change drastically the preparation of mathematics teachers from grade school to college.

JOHN O'HARA'S "Sermons and Soda Water"* is a triad of novelle about life and love in our strangest of centuries. Always true life; occasionally true love. But anyway, a lot of both on the O'Hara Highway from Gibbsville, Pa., to the predestined appointment in Samarra.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 23 -- Two specialists at Dartmouth College hope to apply the technique of teaching-by-machine to medical and other graduate courses.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter published Nov. 14 Michael Belshaw has questioned the value of Senator John F. Kennedy's proposal for an American peace army to work in under-developed nations, because, Mr. Belshaw believes, this new program would not set high academic standards.
Officers of the Darling Stores Corporation were elected to top executive positions in Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Eisenhower Administration decided today to provide emergency economic assistance to Bolivia to forestall the acceptance by that hard-pressed country of an aid offer by the Soviet Union.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 23 -- The police here have turned down an offer by their chief to work a six-day week for extra pay.

Carmine G. De Sapio's days as leader of Tammany Hall are probably numbered. A petition to oust him has been circulated among Manhattan district leaders by two members of the Democratic "reform" faction, but not all reform leaders support the petition, and Mayor Wagner's views continue to be a deep secret. Those who have doubts about the petition question its timing perhaps, but not its purpose.
Work on the $83,500,000 Gowanus Expressway has advanced almost to Forty-third Street in the Bay Ridge area of Brooklyn.
The warm personal interest of a judge, a lesson learned from history and a favorable probation report yesterday gave a 17-year-old youngster something to be thankful for today.

Dr. Wernher von Braun said yesterday that, despite three straight failures in tests of unnamed space capsules, he still believed the United States would achieve a successful manned flight into orbit by the end of 1961.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- President Joseph Kasavubu of the Congo indicated today that he would agree to a visit by an African-Asian conciliation committee of the United Nations to the Congo.
The nation will observe Thanksgiving Day today with a blend of religious celebrations and family reunions, and New York will also have three parades.

The shipping industry began assaying yesterday the short-range and long-range effects of a new royalty system on containerized cargoes adopted by the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association.
The nation's production of crude oil last week increased above the seven-month high set a week earlier, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
The New York World's Fair Commission, a committee to plan the city's exhibits at the 1964-65 exposition, held its first meeting yesterday in the World's Fair offices at Flushing Meadow Park.

THE American public is drinking more wines than ever before. Oddly enough, however, there has not been an appreciable increase in wine production during the last half century. The leveling factor is that fewer peoples drank wines in an earlier age but they drank more copiously. These were a few random thoughts reflected in a recent interview with Alexis Lichine, a wine merchant and author of books on wine.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Temporary freedom was given today to three of nine young pacifists who tried to halt the launching of a nuclear submarine.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 23 -- The United States' financial mission to Bonn refused to discuss any alternatives to its demand for a direct West German payment of $600,000,000 to cover the cost of American troops here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today mail rate increases ranging from 8 to 13 per cent for all the nation's railroads.
Contract negotiations between the broadcasting networks and two performers' unions will resume at 10:30 A.M. Saturday.
The Board of Estimate's plan for a centralized program of buying trucks with capital budget money was rejected yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
THE national bridge tournament enters its sixth day at the Statler-Hilton Hotel today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The East, with three players, dominated the 1960 all-America football team selected today by the American Football Coaches Association.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- State revenues rose $374,000,000 in the 1959-60 fiscal year, Controller Arthur Levitt said today.
Alexander Bittleman, for many years the Communist party's chief theoretician in this country, has been expelled from the party on charges of aligning himself with "anti-party revisionists."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 16:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The key words in Army's mobilization plan for Saturday's big game against Navy at Philadelphia are deception, simplicity, stamina, quickness, possesion and stop Joe Bellino.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Some high officials in the Department of State were surprised by Secretary Anderson's heavy emphasis on direct payments for troop support from the Germans.

WITH social life starting at an ever earlier age, mothers must cope with the problem of party clothes for boys and girls who have not yet reached their full growth. One solution is offered at Second Act, 1046 Madison Avenue at Eightieth Street, an unusual, second-floor shop specializing in outgrown clothing.

Traders on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange were pleasantly surprised yesterday. With trade houses on both sides of the market, several big blocks of Number 7 sugar changed hands. More such sugar was sold in the day than had been sold in any whole month since the contract was started in January.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- ''Beat Army" and "Beat Navy" signs were taken from the Pentagon today on instructions of the civilian building manager. He thought they were not "dignified" and made the place look like a college campus.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Elsenhower returned here this evening after a twoweek holiday in Georgia. He and Mrs. Eisenhower will spend Thanksgiving Day at the White House.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Favoring a tax cut may be shrewd politics, but it frequently is not in the public interest. The views you express in your Nov. 18 editorial entitled "A State Tax Cut Welcome, but --," reflect an honest appraisal of a ticklish issue.

Two top executives of Doeskin Products, Inc., were arrested yesterday on a Federal complaint charging them with fraud and acting as "tools" for Lowell M. Birrell, the fugitive financier who once controlled Doeskin.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 --The Democratic-dominated Chicago Board of Elections proclaimed today the "official" Chicago Presidential vote giving Senator Kennedy a 456,312 plurality over Mr. Nixon.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) up on the near May contract to 2 to 13 points off on the others yesterday.

The directors of the Chemical Bank of New York Trust Company announced yesterday an increase in the bank's dividend rate. It was one of several increases, extra or stock dividends announced by banks here and elsewhere. Chemical Bank declared a cash dividend of 65 cents a share, payable on Jan. 1 to stockholders of record of Dec. 15.

PARIS. To a casual onlooker, the amount of fur on the Paris fashion scene suggests fear of a fast-approaching ice age. The winter streets threaten to be peopled with figures that seem to be taken straight from snowy St. Petersburg in the days of the tsars.
TUNIS, Nov. 23 -- The Tunisian Government announced today that it would support the entry of Mauritania into the United Nations as an independent state.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Government experts predicted today that sugar production in this country and the world would increase during the next marketing year but decline in Cuba, heretofore the world's largest producer.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- The State Education Department came out today against mandatory driving courses for high school students during school hours.

The New York Rangers' defensive shortcomings and an inability to maintain a lead have been stumbling blocks for the Blues this season, but last night they held their own in both departments and beat the Boston Bruins, 6 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 23 -- The United Nations alerted its armored cars tonight following unexplained activity by the Congolese Army on the capital's western outskirts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Meade Alcorn, general counsel of the Republican National Committee, said today he had "no doubt" the twenty-seven electoral votes of Illinois could be counted for Vice President Nixon when an investigation was completed in heavily Democratic Cook County.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The State and Defense Departments have agreed on a proposal to create a nuclear-armed strategic force under direct command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

An invitation to Raul Roa Jr., alternate Cuban representative to the United Nations, to speak at a City College student meeting was blocked at least temporarily yesterday by a faculty adviser, according to one student sponsor.
YESTERDAY (Nov. 23, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY First (Political) Committee) -- Resumed debate on question of Mauritania.
The musical equivalent of a fraternity party was offered at two concerts in Carnegie Hall last night by the Kingston Trio.

The final step has been taken in settlement of one of the most difficult labor problems ever to come up in the Port of New York and is further evidence of growing maturity in waterfront labor relations. We refer to the award of the arbitration board that has fixed the royalties the shipping employers will pay to the International Longshoremen's Association on each cargo container its members handle.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 23 -- Representatives of twelve countries that recently joined the United Nations will leave tomorrow on a five-day air tour of the United States as the guests of President Eisenhower.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The United Nations released new figures today on its financial crisis, showing that member states are $37,215,745 delinquent in their payments.

HANOVER, Germany, Nov. 23 -- The rebellion within the West German Social Democratic party crumbled today, assuring Willy Brandt of united party support in his bid to lead the Socialists to power next year.

LONDON, Nov. 23 (Reuters) -- Following, in translation, are excerpts from an editorial in Pravda, organ of the Soviet Communist party, concerning the third anniversary of a 1957 Soviet declaration calling for peaceful coexistence.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Grain futures prices extended their recovery move today with old-crop wheat contracts leading the advance on gains running to 2 cents a bushel.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Something is wrong with nature in these parts: the balance of animal sexes has gone crazy. The woods are full of does and fawns but the bucks have moved to Pennsylvania.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23 -- The United States Naval Academy today turned down a bid to have its football team play in the Gotham Bowl in New York on Dec. 10.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Henri Rousseau's painting, "The Football Players," was bought today by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation of New York for u37,000 ($103,600), one of the highest prices ever paid for a work of this artist.
A court order was served on Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday directing him to show why he should not be cited for contempt in failing to carry out a previous order.
Five buildings in midtown Manhattan have been sold by the Longchamps chain of restaurants for cash over mortgages amounting to $1,250,000. They were bought by investing clients of Walter-Scott Co.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Moves under way by the United States to save dollars and the overnight weakness on Wall Street unsettled European stock exchanges today.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Members of Parliaments of Western nations gave their tacit approval today to Gen. Lauris Norstad's plea for joint control of nuclear weapons by all partners of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

THE Bach Aria Group opened its fourteenth season in New York last night. The devotion of its following was evidenced by the fact that Town Hall was filled by more than 1,500 persons, who greeted the group's members like old friends.
A Greek furniture concern has come all the way to America for a furniture designer who, it seems, is going to give them back some translations of an ancient Greek design.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Prices generally declined on the stock market here today, although the selling was not heavy. Yesterday's weakness of Wall Street was one of the factors that kept buyers away. Losses, although widespread, were tarely more than a shilling (14 cents) except for the more expensive issues, which lost more.

The lull in the New Orleans school crisis caused by the Thanksgiving holidays has not solved and cannot solve the titanic struggle now going on in Louisiana between state and Federal Governments over fundamental legal and moral issues. The legal issue concerns the question of state sovereignty vs. Federal supremacy; the moral issue concerns the right to impose segregation according to color in any educational system.
The three-day strike of 325 office workers of American Export Lines threatened last night to spread to other Atlantic Coast ports and the Great Lakes area served by the line.

Various difficulties have retarded the progress of "Giants, Sons of Giants," which had been announced in May for January production. Dane Clark has withdrawn as star and Joseph Kramm as director. Their successors could not be named yesterday by Alfred Tamarin, cosponsor with Charles A. Totero.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy returned here tonight to spend Thanksgiving Day with his family. The Kennedys will have their turkey dinner at mid-day with three or four guests, whose names have not been disclosed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: E.E. Minskoff, Chief of Enforcement, Foreign Assets Control Division of the United States Treasur has announced that the object smuggled into this country from China will be sold at auction as the proceeds presumably will be pa into the Treasury.
NINETEENTH-CENTURY furnishings buffs will find a new shop, called Orchard House crowded with furnishings and accessories to a Victorian's taste.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (AP) -- George K. (Lefty) James will resign as head football coach at Cornell University after tomorrow's traditional Thanksgiving Day game against Penn, it was learned today.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The Parliamentary police have been instructed to bar a fair, slight youngish man from the chamber of the House of Commons.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- A discovery in England of Port of New York shipping records of 1699 to 1765 was reported today by Sleepy Hollow Restorations, a Rockefeller-endowed corporation that is restoring Hudson Valley shrines.

NOT every batting champion has stepped out boldly and defiantly at the season's end to collect a hatful of hits in order to clinch a treasured batting prize. In fact, only two flash to mind, Harry Heilmann and Ted Williams. Far too many have been content to sit out the pressure-laden final day or final week in order to protect their averages and gain honors virtually by default.

All Gather Together There used to be a time when grandfather and grandmother and not the football game on the television set held the stage on Thanksgiving Day, for the renewal of family ties used to be as much a part of Thanksgiving as thankfulness for Divine bounty and sharing with the less fortunate.
TORONTO, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- An easier money policy for Canada was advocated today by John S. Proctor, president of the Imperial Bank of Canada, in an address at the bank's annual meeting.
A double transfer -- from subway to s and back to subway -- will be required of passengers on the IRT Van Cortlandt Pa -242d Street line for three days next month.
John J. Cassese, the head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, pleaded guilty, yesterday in Traffic Court to parking his car illegally. He was fined $5 by Magistrate T. Vincent Quinn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Government estimated today that a retired couple 65 years of age or older needed $220 to $280 monthly income for a modest but adequate level of urban living.
The Western Union Telegraph Company asked the Post Office Department yesterday to clarify its plans for transmitting mail by facsimile
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 23 -- President elect Kennedy's two campaigning brothers, Robert and Edward, arrived tonight for talks at a crucial stage in policy planning for the new Administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- In his years as a government scientist, Dr. Morris Tepper has gained a reputation as a man who can take the ball and run with it, sometimes with an aggressive determination.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Cuba has been canning Czechoslovak hand grenades in tins marked "grated coconut" and smuggling them to Guatemalan rebels, according to Guatemalan diplomats here.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy disclosed yesterday that in the last four weeks, during which the police sharply increased trafic summonses, there had been twenty-two fewer traffic deaths than in the same period last year.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The French Government named a new Delegate General in Algeria today and took other actions designed to speed implementation of President de Gaulle's policy there and forestall gathering opposition.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman issued a call yesterday for a meeting on Monday of Manhattan district leaders affiliated with the Democratic reform movement.
WARSAW, Nov. 23 -- Polish artists have been told to get over their fascination with radical experimentation and to move closer to the people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- For reasons which may influence the Kennedy Administration to maintain the same policy, the Eisenhower Administration plans to leave unchecked an annual export of billions or more by the people of the United States.

BRISBANE, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- America's young tennis stars. Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston, must prove themselves in the next ten days if they are to carry the important doubles role for the United States in the Davis Cup campaign ahead.
The bond market ambled through a quiet pre-holiday session yesterday.

A balky performance yesterday by Sidney J. Ungar, star prosecution witness against Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan, caused Judge Joseph A. Sarafite to declare Mr. Ungar a "hostile witness."
All or part of four buildings were closed here yesterday as special inspection teams cracked down on mercantile buildings that have ignored fire-prevention laws.
Railroad stocks supported a dragging stock market yesterday and brought about a Small general advance of prices on the New York Stock Exchange.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23 -- Navy's football coach, Wayne Hardin, threw down the gantlet to Army in an oral clash today over the midshipmen's all-America halfback, Joe Bellino.
Stockholders in an increasing number of companies are receiving this kind of letter this year:
Harold L. Humes Jr., chairman of the Citizens Emergency Committee, which precipitated the controversy over the licensing of cabaret entertainers, was jailed as a scofflaw for five hours yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The United States launched its second weather-eye satellite today.
Chestnuts, a traditional Thanksgiving Day delicacy, are staging a comeback in the United States as a domestic crop after practically disappearing almost fifty years ago.

Derrick, recently purchased by I.J. Collins for $40,000 at a horses-in-training sale at Belmont Park, won the first time out for his new owner yesterday. Competing in the High Bridge Handicap that featured the program, Derrick made a dynamic closing surge to beat Georgiana Foster's Outgiving by a half length.
The only three-act play being performed in a Manhattan cabaret or coffeehouse is a surrealistic drama called "King Ubu," which caused an uproar when it was first produced in Paris in 1896.
Bernard Newman, New York County Republican chairman, is urging the party's state leaders to fix a June date for next year's New York City primary.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The Louisiana House Representatives accused President Eisenhower and the Federal courts today of "making common cause with the Communist conspiracy."

When the women members of the Nutmeg Field Trial Club ran their annual bird dog event at Farifield, Conn., last Sunday, there was no heckling from the gallery. It was forbidden. Neither was a husband allowed to bellow instructions to his wife in the field.

HOUSTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Owners of Houston's National League franchise indicated today that the Houston club would be willing to field a team next year if the senior circuit accepts a plan advanced by the American League.
Toronto moved into the picture yesterday as a strong possibility for the tenth franchise in the American League -- a franchise that a few days ago had appeared all wrapped up for Los Angeles.

Thirty-two acres on Middle Country Road in Nesconset, L.L. have been purchased by Nesconset 25 Theatre, Inc., for improvement with a combination standard and drive-in theatre. The buyer is a company headed by Joseph F. Seider of Bay Shore.
RECKLINGHAUSEN, Germany, Nov. 23 -- An international exhibition of Jewish religious art has opened in this old Ruhr city under the sponsorship of the West German federal and local Governments.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Delegates of seventeen countries newly admitted to the United Nations have been invited by Westport, Conn., to observe American home life over the Thanksgiving weekend.
Directors of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad at a special meeting on Dec. 9 will meet to consider a merger proposal received from the Missouri Pacific (Mopac) Railroad.

Charlie (Chuck) Conerly's injured left knee backfired on him again yesterday. The 39-year-old quarterback participated in the New York Football Giants' workout at Yankee Stadium, but only briefly. He threw five passes and then was not able to continue.

IN these days of frequent goodwill tours by artists in behalf of their countries, it is sometimes difficult to know just how foreign guests should be received. Which are those that come more as friendly ambassadors than as potential entrants into our competitive concert life?
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Nov. 23 (AP) -- A huge, shimmering balloon drifted across the upper Midwest today on a picture-taking mission in conjunction with the nation's new Tiros II weather satellite.

The Firestone Tire Rubber Company surprised the rubber industry yesterday by announcing price reductions on passenger car tires. Industry observers attributed the reduction to the general softness of the tire market.
In the coming season Fordham University's basketball fortunes have no place to go but up.
The State Power Authority has submitted to Governor Rockefeller proposed contracts for allocating power from the Niagara River project, which goes into operation on a limited basis next Feb. 10.

Those twenty Convair 880 jet airliners that were built for Trans World Airlines but are standing idle on the Convair ramps in San Diego, Calif., because T.W.A. cannot raise funds to pay for them may take to the air soon.
The Police Department ran up against legal roadblocks yesterday in its drive on night spots accused of violating regulations on cabaret work permits.
ROME, Nov. 23 -- Prime Minister Macmillan and the British Foreign Secretary, the Earl of Home, were received by Pope John XXIII this morning in a private audience lasting twentyfive minutes.
The Jewish chaplain of the Police Department issued a request last night to Jewish policemen to volunteer to work for Christian policemen on Christmas and New Year's.
The possibility that a jet airport might be built in the Pine Island-Florida area of Orange County is being welcomed by business, labor and banking leaders upstate.
A holiday dance marathon starring this season's debutantes started in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night with the twelfth annual Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League.

Samuel W. Banowit, a director of the Christiana Oil Corporation, has increased his holdings in that concern by acquiring 130,100 shares of the common stock, it was disclosed yesterday by the American Stock Exchange in its latest report on trading by insiders.

Last night's performance of "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan Opera had Dorothy Kirsten in the title role and Rosalind Elias as Suzuki. Both were singing in the Puccini work for the first time there this season.

The director of the State Education Department's division of intercultural relations testified yesterday in Federal Court that in 1957 he had found New Rochelle's Lincoln Elementary School "racially segregated."

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that the world Communist movement unite solidly behind Premier Khrushchev's doctrine of peaceful coexistence and of the possibility of achieving victory over capitalism without a world war.
PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The Government launched a drastic campaign today against alcoholism, one of France's most serious social and health problems.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 23 -- The East Meadow School Board contended in State Supreme Court here today that the State Education Commissioner's recent ruling permitting parents to see their children's school records was not binding on all school districts.

The Secondary School Teachers Association charged in Supreme Court here yesterday that the Condon-Wadlin Law was unconstitutional and also so vague that no city official has had the courage to invoke it.
Magistrate Matthew F. Fagan was told in Flatbush Court yesterday that "all animals, from chickens up, are unpredictable -- especially lions."
Two players who had been on waivers rejoined the New-York Titans yesterday for their American Football League game with the Dallas Texans at the Polo Grounds today. The contest will start at 11 A.M.

The police were told yesterday that it was the community-minded "nuisance" -- the "crusader" -- not the police "backslapper," who could help them to attain intelligent relations with the Puerto Rican community.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 -- Pennsylvania's passing will be matched against Cornell's swift backs in an anticipated wide-open struggle in the Ivy League football finale tomorrow before a probable attendance of 12,500 at Franklin Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson was criticized on many sides today for the way in which he sought and failed to obtain direct financial support from West Germany for United States troops there.
YONKERS, Nov. 24 -- George Sholty, driving in four of the first six events at Yonkers Raceway, won all four of his mile races tonight. Each of his horses provided better than a 3-to-1 return.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Boston strengthened its hold on first place in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division tonight by defeating the Philadelphia Warriors, 132 -- 129, before a capacity crowd of 11,003 at Convention Hall.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was interesting to note the criticism by the American Trucking Associations of one premise of your very realistic editorial of Oct. 28.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Nov. 25 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, wife of the President-elect, gave birth to a boy early this morning.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Five white men were arrested today in a move to prevent racial violence at a Negro college football game.
Forty-five heel-and-toe addicts covered the fiftieth annual 10.5-mile walk from City Hall to Coney Island yesterday without mishap despite the hazards of holiday traffic.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Plans for a court contest of the Presidential election in Cook County were made today by Republican leaders.
LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- It is time now on Thanksgiving Day, in the light of what has happened since the time when the Pilgrims ravaged the land, to define a deer hunter.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- A polite warning against turning the North Atlantic alliance into a "fourth atomic power" came today from John Strachey of the British Labor party.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 24 -- Abdul Kasem Khan, Minister of Industries of Pakistan, said at a press conference here today that foreign investors would be treated on a "first come, first served" basis and those "sitting on the fence" would miss the present "golden opportunity" offered them.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Political Committee -- Continued debate on the Palestine refugee problem.
Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation and a big British company, Consolidated Zinc Corporations, Ltd., announced yesterday plans to establish a vast aluminum complex in Australia and New Zealand.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 24 -- A permanent citizens' health committee to counsel the Montclair Health Department in the administration of its program has been suggested by a special advisory committee after a six-month study.

If the premise is accepted that the alert marketing man will make every moment count, then John W. Colpitts, who has just been named advertising manager of the Salada-Junket division of Salada-Shirriff-Horsey, Inc., must be recognized as an alert marketing man.

Domestic utilities of the General Public Utilities Corporation sold 6 per cent more electricity in the first nine months of this year than in the 1959 period, the company reported yesterday. Electric revenues were up 5.1 per cent in the same period.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, concerned over "weaknesses" in the organization of his Secretariat, has invited three past presidents of the General Assembly to consult with him.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- New Rochelle High School completed its first perfect football season in twenty-five years today by overpowering the Iona Prep eleven, 34 -- 6, in the thirteenth meeting of the two city schools.

A seven-month suspension of a proposed railroad rate cut covering coal traffic has heartened inland waterway carriers, Patrick Calhoun Jr., president of the Inland Waterways Common Carriers Association, said yesterday.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 24 -- Archbishop Francois Poirier, Roman Catholic primate of Haiti, was expelled from the country today on a charge that he had furnished $7,000 to Communist students to overthrow the regime of President Francois Duvalier.

BATON ROGUE, La., Nov. 24 -- This week's sessions here of the American Power Boat Association indicated that the ruling body of speed boating was about to enter the picture in noncompetitive pleasure boating.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Western diplomats welcomed today the reported United States plan to share some nuclear weapons with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization but raised many questions about it.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Louis Joxe, newly appointed Minister of State for Algerian Affairs, was expected today to maintain the current brisk momentum of French action in the Algerian situation by leaving for Algiers within forty-eight hours.

Mary K. Frank, Broadway stage producer, has been elected president of the New Dramatists Committee, a nonprofit organization, established in 1949, that makes it possible for young playwrights to develop the finer points of their craft.
BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 24 (AP) -- David Freed, the United States captain, today said he was convinced America would recover the Davis Cup from Australia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In recent weeks the City of New York seems to have been waging a stout legal battle against the entrenched owners of insufficiently maintained tenement properties. The following excerpt, a particularly appropriate example of municipal tradition in this matter, was recorded on the statute books of Hereford, England, in the year 1416:
A two-hour original play by Reginald Rose about the morning a school is integrated in a Southern city is being considered for presentation on "The Play of the Week" over station WNTA-TV.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 24 -- Seantor Stephen M. Young of Ohio has characterized the nation's civil defense program as a "billion dollar boondoggle."

Bucknell University yesterday was unanimously named the winner of the fourth annual Lambert Cup, emblematic of the Eastern small-college football championship. The Bisons won seven games and lost two, both to major teams.

CANDIED or glaceed fruits are characteristic ingredients and garnishes for holiday fruitcakes, plum puddings and many traditional yeast breads and cookies. They also are familiar as slivers of candied citrus peels for nibbling or as glaceed prunes and apricots in fancy paper cups beautifully packaged for Christmas giving.

New business for the nation's machine tool industry rose in October from the level of September. Net new orders for cutting and forming machine tools, used in making machinery, aggregated 355,950,000, compared with $52,300,000 in September.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- An Italian board has concluded that the crash of a Trans World Airlines plane in Italy on June 26, 1959, was caused by a gasoline explosion touched off in flight by static electricity.
John Dacey and the ship he calls "the finest in the world" are parting ways after thirty years.

SMALL fry who are lucky enough to spend their Christmas vacations in the sunny South will find a mouth-watering choice of play and swim clothes at the new South Shop in Bloomingdale's children's department.

The next crisis in the Congo will doubtless take place when President Joseph Kasavubu returns to Leopoldville, there to face the supremely difficult task of constructing a government that will be able to govern.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 24 -- The conflict between the Popular Democratic party and the Roman Catholic Church is apparently over.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Truck freight loadings, measured in tons, were 2.2 per cent less in the week ended on last Saturday than in the like week of last year, the American Trucking Associations reported today.

THERE are many merits to a winter vacation. One advantage are the varied, handsome collections of cruise-and-resort clothes that can be found in such abundance. They are enough to distract anyone from buying a winter coat.

THANKSGIVING was marked on television yesterday afternoon by one of those glowing hours that can lend such distinctive stature to the medium. It was the performance of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 1 by Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic.

Everyone had taken it for granted that Paddy Chayefsky's new play, "Gideon," would be a full-length work like his "Middle of the Night" or the current "Tenth Man." With "Gideon," which deals with the Biblical figure, the playwright disclosed yesterday that he was venturing into a different field.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Communist drive to infiltrate and influence political developments in the Republic of the Congo has been intensified recently, according to a report reaching authoritative sources here.
ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Virginia Polytechnic Institute found its lost offense in the running and passing of Warren Price today and topped its rival, Virginia Military Institute, 13 to 12.

"The White Nile," a new book by Alan Moorehead, will be published by Harper on Jan. 4. It is a description of the exploration and conquest of Central and Eastern Africa, based on the writings of explorers and military men (1856-1900) and on-the-spot research.
Worshipers gathered yesterday in churches and synagogues over the city to count their blessings and to pray for a world free from war and want.
WHEN the lights go down on "Hedda Gabler" the awkward interior arrangements of the Fourth Street Theatre disappear. Nothing matters when a fine production irradiates the hall.

For the thirty-fourth time, Macy's gave children something extra to be thankful for yesterday. It presented a parade of costumed storybook characters musicians, dancers and clowns, all accompanied overhead by gigantic balloon figures.
BONN, Nov. 24 -- Leading newspapers in West Germany expressed regret and some criticism today over the failure of the Anderson mission to Bonn.
MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- The Soviet Union and Finland agreed today on a formula to permit Finnish association with a Western European economic bloc without upsetting trade between the two neighbors.
A national trade association has been formed to represent a new segment of finance -- the real estate investment trusts that now operate with the same tax treatment as mutual funds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy's press secretary held his first news conference in the capital today without giving a single clue on the make-up of the new Cabinet.

ERIE, Pa., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- A quarterback, Gordon Bukaty of Buffalo University, tossed two touchdown passes and scored a third himself today to help the East gain a 27-26 victory over the West in the third annual Gem Bowl football game.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Detroit Lions, their passing game back in the groove, gained a 16-0 half-time lead and went on to beat the Green Bay Packers, 23 -- 10, in a National Football League contest today.
