Twenty-five American scientists and scholars, under the auspices of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, will leave for Moscow this weekend. There they will take part in the sixth "Pugwash" conference on technical problems involving world security and world peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Weather Bureau, encouraged by the success of the first two Tiros meteorological satellites, is proposing an accelerated effort to put a system of weather satellites into operation by mid-1962.
ROBERT REYNOLDS of Coral Gables, Fla., won the life masters' individual championship yesterday in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

Ronnie Bliey tallied 22 points but fell six short of tying the city scoring record as Jefferson crushed Tilden, 54 -- 24, in a Public Schools Athletic League game on the loser's field in Brooklyn, yesterday.
A three-year project seeking more effective ways for training teachers for schools in underprivileged neighborhoods will get under way in Queens next year.
Bus runs on several cross-town streets have been shortened by five to ten minutes because of the work of a special inspection squad, it was reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Six African countries urged the United Nations today to take over the administration of South-West Africa from South Africa.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Andy Bathgate and Johnny Wilson scored twice each tonight as the New York Rangers defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 -- 3, before 12,601 at the Garden. The victory lifted the Rangers out of the National Hockey League cellar and ahead of the Bruins.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- On touchdown passes of 24, 8 and 45 yards in each of the first three periods by George Koval, Pennsylvania turned back Cornell, 18 -- 7, in the sixty-seventh game between the old rivals a Franklin Field today.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Louis Joxe is President de Gaulle's choice to walk a tightrope toward a solution of the six-year-old Algerian problem, with disasters yawning on both sides. He is a 59-year-old career diplomat who has also been a teacher, journalist and politician.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- President Joseph Kasavubu left tonight for Leopoldville to try to sort out the problems of the troubled Congo.
The city Park Department says that if two 350-pound gorillas cannot break up a child's swing, neither can the boys and girls in the park playgrounds.
The National Association of Manufacturers called yesterday for industrial tax incentives and curbs on union power as essential to offset the challenge of foreign economic competition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The State Department has stated that it will "do its best" to help disillusioned African students in Communist countries to come to the United States.

Textbooks on real estate invariably urge the employment of property at its "highest and best use." But the experience of a realty concern here in attracting tenants to two unoccupied commercial buildings in the midtown area shows that the "highest and best use" can sometimes be achieved by widely divergent methods.
Millions of Americans at home and abroad yesterday celebrated Thanksgiving, a custom begun 339 years ago by the Pilgrims at the completion of their first year in the New World.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- Well-informed sources reported today that in the current Communist party discussions here Liu Shao-chi, the Chinese Communist chief of state, had found surprising support among Latin-American delegations, as veil as North Korea, Indonesian and Albanian.

The latest figures on the financial affairs of the United Nations show that member states are more than $37 million behind in their dues and assessments. Some are poor, some are negligent and some, such as Russia and the Arab States, refuse to support operations, for example, the U.N. force in the Gaza Strip, that they don't approve of.
WARRENTON, N.C., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The third victim of an air crash last night was identified today as Mrs. Barbara Clark, 30 years old, of New York.
DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Despite the fanfare surrounding the introduction of new, smaller American cars, a sizable number of imported cars still is being sold in this country.

PROFESSIONAL football certainly is not getting effete. What a television docu- mentary portrayed as "The Violent World of Sam Huff" is just as violent as it always was. But the play-for-pay set has ceased to breed a vigilante-type of player known in the trade as a "policeman."

A Walk Up Broadway Early in the summer of 1848, not quite six months after the discovery of gold in California and only three after the death of John Jacob Astor, two young lads walked up New York's Broadway with their immigrant parents.
HANOVER, Germany, Nov. 24 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin took the offensive against Chancellor Adenauer today on the sensitive issue of atomic arms for West Germany.

Still hopeful of swinging a major league deal but not optimistic about immediate prospects, the vanguard of the recently revamped Yankee front-office staff heads for Louisville today to attend the annual minor league convention, which opens next Monday.

Twenty-two young women made their formal bows to society in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last evening. The occasion was the eleventh annual Gotham Ball, the second of four balls for debutantes taking place there this week.

The Boston Celtics will make their second appearance of the season against the New York Knickerbockers in Madison Square Garden tonight. The Na- tional Basketball Association game is scheduled to start at 9 o'clock, following a high school game between Holy Trinity and St. Augustine.
CORAL GABLES, Fa., Nov. 24 (AP) -- April Skies, the 3-2 favorite with Bill Hartack up, won the $11,375 Hurricane Handicap today as Tropical Park opened Florida's long thoroughbred racing season.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Shares of many industrial leaders fell heavily in the stock market here today. The Financial Times Index of Industrial Ordinary Stocks dropped 4.9 points to 308.7.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 24 -- Eight letters from President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana to Patrice Lumumba, deposed Premier of the Congo, were published today in an effort to rebut accusations that Ghana was interfering in the Congo's internal affairs.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- Malaya, moving into the position of the world's largest producer of natural rubber, is organizing its resources to fight off the competition of the latest synthetic products.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks coasted to a 132-97 victory over the Syracuse Nationals in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header tonight. In the first contest, Elgin Baylor scored 33 points and led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 108-100 victory over the Cincinnati Royals.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- On the historic barn-like sound stages where Charlie Chaplin made "Modern Times," "Limelight" and "The Greal Dictator," a latter-day comedian was cavorting.
VIENNA, Nov. 24 -- Austrian-Yugoslav negotiations that might lead to a cooperative effort in the under-developed countries of Africa and the Middle East were begun here today.
An office workers' strike that had tied up American Export Lines' luxury cruise ships Independence and Atlantic since Monday ended at 9 A.M. yesterday.
Joey Adams, comedian and president of the nightclub entertainers' union, said yesterday that Mayor Wagner had promised to ease police regulations for nightclub performers next week.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Vice President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson said tonight that he found "considerable concern among our allies over the United States' role" in world affairs. Senator Johnson made his remark in an interview with the Columbia Broadcasting System.
EMMELJOKI, Finland, Nov. 21 -- They buried the chief of the House of George yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- James Saxton kept the Texas offense alive today as the Longhorns turned three Texas A. and M. mistakes into touchdowns for a 21-14 victory and a bid to the Blue Bonnet Bowl.
Airlines serving Bermuda from East Coast cities announced yesterday sharp reductions in fares beginning next month.
A mother who abandoned her two small children in Gimbels' toy department on Thanksgiving eve was arrested yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Shield Bearer gave most of the 20,389 fans in attendance little to be thankful for today when he took the measure of the odds-on favorite, Harmonizing, in the $25,000 added Dixie Handicap at Pimlico.

Edward Seinfeld's Clear Road stepped to victory by the slimmest of margins in the $28,400 Firenze Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The program, which started at 11 A.M. under ideal conditions was attended by a crowd of 34,800.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings, led by Hank Bassen in the nets, defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 15,859, the largest crowd in Olympia history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The agreement of the Supreme Court to hear the complaint of urban citizens in Tennessee that the apportionment of state legislative voting districts discriminates against them for the benefit of rural areas will at least draw national attention to an old political trick.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- When an export commodity expands about 100 times in volume within ten years, and twenty-five fold by value within five, it constitutes a commercial curiosity as well as a bonanza for the country concerned.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- British Government officials were said to be irritated and slightly shocked at West Germany's rejection of Secretary Anderson's plea for financial assistance.
There is no truth whatever to the nasty rumor in the American Football League that the New York Titans need a 52-point lead late in the last quarter to win a game.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson believes he accomplished one major purpose by his mission to Bonn, despite his failure to persuade West Germany to pay $600,000,000 for the cost of American troops there.

Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., the largest farm machinery producer in the British Commonwealth and one of the largest in the world, is making its entry into the Italian market through the purchase of G. Landini Figli S.p.A., maker of tractors, it was announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Heald committee recommendation to charge fee of $300 to students at our municipal colleges is not in the public interest. The City College, founded in 1847, was created for the purpose of extending college opportunities to the citizens of this community, regardless of any consideration other than merit, ability and willingness to learn.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 24 -- St. Peter's Prep defeated Dickinson, 13 -- 6, today before more than 16,000 fans at Roosevelt Stadium. The victory gave the Prepmen the city championship and their twenty-fifth triumph in a rivalry that started in 1898.
Earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 were below those of the preceding year despite record sales and production.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 24 -- A spokesman said today that the military regime of the Congo had no intention of arresting the deposed Premier, Patrice Lumumba, "for the time being."

SUCCESS, according to Sloan Wilson, can be nearly as disastrous as failure. It can be much too dearly bought. And the love of money, although perhaps not the root of all evil, is certainly the root of a good deal of it. These are irreproachable sentiments and will probably please a great many thousand readers of Mr. Wilson's new novel, "A Sense of Values."*

HAVANA, Nov. 24 -- Premier Fidel Castro and his associates expect few changes in United States policy toward Cuba. Therefore they plan no change in the course of ever-closer association with the Communist nations.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- Authoritative sources said today that West Germany was ready to resume trade talks with East Germany without insisting on tangible East German concessions on the Berlin issue.

Gross revenues of the Missouri Pacific Railroad rose slightly last month to $25,575,572 from the $25,429,344 of October, 1959. But earnings, after all charges, including capital and sinking funds, plummeted to $136,241 from $430,047.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 25 -- The voters want to replace this city's mayor-city council form of government with a council-manager administration, the League of Women Voters said today.
The School for Santa Clauses of the Volunteers of America yesterday graduated its annual class of fifty. Their "diplomas" were bells and chimneys.
Howard Kitt, very young, very left-handed and very eager to make good as a big-league pitcher, has agreed to give it a try with the New York Yankees.
YESTERDAY (Nov. 25, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY First (Political Committee -- Continued consideration of the question of Mauritania.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ended today its broad-scale general passenger investigation by establishing complex new standards for its regulation of fares.

Shareholders of Ampex and of Telemeter Magnetics, Inc., approved their merger at separate meetings held yesterday in California. Terms of the plan call for the exchange of one share of Ampex for two shares of Telemeter Magnetics, with Ampex becoming the surviving corporation.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- The United States called on seven African nations today to drop ther plan for United Nations administration of South-West Africa.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Times reporter who attended a recent press conference during which I attempted to explain measures, interim and optimum, to assure the city full value on future rock-salt deliveries, reported our discussion competently and fairly.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Republicans are considering an appeal to the State Canvassing Board not to approve the challenged Cook County vote in the Presidential election.

A 9-year-old mare came down from Narragansett Part in Rhode Island and registered a thrilling victory in a mile race at Aqueduct yesterday. Eternal Mark, owned by Martin Kaplan and ridden by Norman Mercier, beat the favored Speedy Contessa by a nose, before a crowd of 26,265.
Alexander L. Guterma, the imprisoned financier, was linked yesterday by a Federal grand jury with another master swindler in an indictment charging an $850,000 stock fraud on the public.
Eileen Weiss, the 29-year-old unwed mother who abandoned her two children in Gimbels toy department on Thanksgiving Eve, was paroled yesterday in Felony Court for a hearing on Dec. 6.
LONDON, Nov. 25--Senator Lyndon B. Johnson declared today that the United States, Britain and Western Europe would continue to work "to extend freedom."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- "Youth does something to me," laughed Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower as she presented her two nieces at a double debut tea party in the White House today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Neale Fraser of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, was upset in the second round of the Victorian tennis championship today. America's Earl Buchholz, Bernard Bartzen and Barry MacKay advanced.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York City declined $62,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York oeported yesterday. This contrasted with a rise of $8,000,000 in the 1959 week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Secretary of Defense issued two directives today to start the progressive reduction in the number of dependents accompanying service men overseas.

As things are now shaping up, the Foreign and Defense Ministers of the North Atlantic alliance, who meet in Paris on Dec. 16, will have to face up to two vital problems, the solution of which will largely determine the alliance's future effectiveness.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- A major new joint program by the Government and chartered banks to provide credit for Canadian exports of capital goods was unveiled in the Commons today by George Hees, Minister of Trade and Commerce.

"The Night the War Was Lost," a new book about the Civil War by Charles L. Dufour, will be issued next Friday by Doubleday. It is an account of the capture of New Orleans in April, 1862. The author contends that the city's fall pointed the way to the eventual triumph of the Union forces.

"Agon," that penetrating, deeply humorous and incredibly difficult piece by Stravinsky and George Balanchine, had its first presentation of the season by the New York City Ballet last night at the City Center. By now it has been in the repertory long enough to have established a permanent lucidity on both sides of the footlights, and it no longer holds terrors for anybody.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission denied six applications today for a rehearing on its opinion in the Phillips Petroleum Company case. The opinion involved rates for independent natural gas producers.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents arrested today at Phoenix, Ariz., a 47-year-old hospital chaplain wanted on a charge of kidnapping Miss Rosalie O'Connell, 17 years old, from St. Mary's Hospital at Superior Nov. 8.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Surplus property for which the Federal Government paid more than $90,000,000 was transferred to the states for educational, public health and civil defense purposes from July to September.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Traders with profits to cash held most grain futures on the defensive in relatively light dealings today on the Board of Trade.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Houston Oilers, sparked by the passing of Jacky Lee, scored a 24-10 victory over the Boston Patriots tonight and clinched a tie for the Eastern Division championship of the American Football League.
The Port of New York tossed a bouquet of feathery water plumes to a retiring lady of the Atlantic yesterday.

The recent injuries to Frank Gifford and Jim Katcavage, both lost to the Giants for the balance of the National Football League season, yesterday gave active varsity status to two members of the New York club's "taxi" squad.

Seven hundred representatives of twenty-six Protestant and seven Eastern Orthodox church bodies will convene in San Francisco for six days beginning next Sunday. Membership in the thirty-three communions totals nearly 40,000,000 churchgoers.

If the general counsel of the Republican National Committee, Meade Alcorn, is right in predicting that Illinois' twenty-seven electoral votes will wind up in the Nixon column, the nation will be facing the most serious predicament in its Presidential history since the Hayes-Tilden battle of 1876-77.
DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor continued his outstanding shooting as the Los Angeles Lakers beat the Detroit Pistons, 141 -- 128, in overtime tonight.

IN one recently opened restaurant, New York has inherited an embarrassment of riches. It is an establishment of such caliber, there is an inclination to use such expressions as "first rank" and "ne plus ultra."

United States monetary gold reserves have fallen below $18,000,000,000 for the first time in almost twenty-one years. Figures published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed that foreign governments and central banks purchased $20,000,000 in gold from the United States in the week ended on Wednesday, reducing the gold stock to $17,986,000,000, the lowest level since the week of Jan. 31, 1940.
In their reluctant search for rock bottom of the National Basketball Association, the New York Knickerbockers tumbled to their seventh straight defeat last night at Madison Square Garden.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Sharply differing views between the United States and West Germany on the nature of the dollar problem and the needed remedies for it were a major reason for the failure of the United States financial mission to Bonn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Northwest Airlines said today that the proposed merger of Capital Airlines into United Air Lines would create an airline far larger than any yet known, and would give rise to more and far greater problems than it would solve.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A furnace manufacturer has invented fire-fighting equipment that he believes will save the lives of many firemen and greatly reduce property damage from smoke and water. He calls his method fighting fire with fire.

"TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN"* is a clutch of odd stories by Elisabeth Mann Borgese, a daughter of Thomas Mann. They run an emotional gamut from the arabesque to the zany. And then back through a few diabolical landscapes that might have won notice from Hieronymus Bosch, the Flemish painter of picturesque tortures.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 25 -- Bea Toner scored three goals as the New Atlantic first team from New Jersey and New York defeated the Southeast first team from Delaware and Virginia, 6 -- 0, today. The game marked the opening of the three-day Philadelphia invitation women's field-hockey tournament at Swarthmore College.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The White House sharply denied today published reports of differences between the Treasury and State Departments over proposals for a West German contribution to United States troop costs.

An era in broadcasting ended yesterday when the Columbia Broadcasting System removed four of its radio soap operas from the air.

YONKERS, Nov. 25 -- Keen's Victorwin, driven by Robert Cherrix, scored a head victory over Senator Spangler tonight in the Briarcliff Pace before 23,232 fans at Yonkers Race-way. The winner's time for the mile was 2:02.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- President Eisenhower decided today against relaxing the present import quota on lead and zinc.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Britain's boxing authorities struck back today at Dr. Edith Summerskill's attempt to knock out prizefighting.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Johnny Pott shot a six-underpar 66 in the second round of the Mobile open golf tournament today and tied Freddie Haas for the lead at the half-way mark.

Legend and fact clashed yesterday over the births, some 2,000 years apart, of Julius Caesar, a Roman conqueror, and John F. Kennedy Jr., United States citizen.

DEMAREST, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Fourteen young women were presented this evening at the fourth annual Debutante Cotillion of the Junior League of Englewood. The event, which took place here at the Aldecress Country Club, will benefit the league's community trust fund.

For sugar men the 1960-63 crop year will be bearish -- Russian bearish, that is to say. WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy has been puzzled about how to tell his 2-year-old daughter Caroline about her baby brother, but his wife has been building up to it for a long time.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The decline in industrial shares prices gathered momentum in the stock market here today. Selling increased with the end of the fortnightly bookkeeping account period, and with investors reluctant to buy, falls were heavier than yesterday and more wide-spread.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The Brigade of Midshipmen serenaded the Corps of Cadets in hatless solemnity at the end of the Army-Navy game today. PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 27 -- The Catholic diocesan newspaper La Phalange has been ordered, under the threat of suspension, not to publish any information dealing with the current political situation here other than that contained in offical bulletins.

ATLANTA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- An Associated Press survey of Southern states shows no indication of a coalition of dissatisfied Democratic electors with enough strength to block the election of John F. Kennedy as President in the Electoral College.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- With Charlie Hodge, their goalie, turning aside every thrust, the Montreal Canadiens beat the Boston Bruins, 3-0, in a National Hockey League game before 13,139 fans at Boston Garden tonight.
The investor no longer can use laziness as an excuse for not buying mutual fund shares; he can do it by mail.
THE frantic Christmas shopping season has begun, but there is still time to make a relaxed choice.

IT'S a pleasure to find a simple, uncluttered human interest drama coming from the Russian movie makers. But "My Daughter," which opened Saturday at the Cameo, is so stilted, pretentiously staged and slow-moving that the import must be put down as only a pretty good try -- that's all.
The police drive for stricter enforcement of cabaret and other night-spot regulations has posed a threat to a noncommercial off-Broadway theatrical production that opened last night.
The National Broadcasting Company is close to fulfilling the dream of all networks -- an instant sponsor. The procedure requires no water -- only a blank check signed by a solvent advertiser.
The corporation with a taxable income of about $25,000 is flirting with higher taxes.
The railroads' proposal to repeal the ban on charging less for a long rail haul than for a shorter one over the same route was under attack yesterday.

Draft indebtedness at Latin American importers to United States exporters continued to increase in October, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank's monthly survey of twelve large commercial banks put the total outstanding at the end of the month at $192,500,000, up $6,700,000 from the month-earlier level, and the highest amount reported since August, 1953.

THE series of documentary A films based on Sir Winston Churchill's memoirs of World War II is to run for twenty-six weeks and it Would hardly be fair to reach very definitive conclusions after only a single installment.

Week Ended Nov. 25, 1960 Foreign exchange market was generally steady on moderate dealings during the past week. British pound sterling moved narrowly while the Canadian dollar was slightly irregular at times.
One of labor's most respected tacticians has enlisted in the effort to establish peaceful labor relations in the city's public schools.

The great importance of mathematics in modern society makes it essential that laymen as well as professional mathematicians be concerned with the fundamental revolution in mathematics teaching now being urged upon this nation's schools. The latest step in this campaign is the set of valuable changes in the preparation of mathematics teachers which has been recommended by the Board of Governors of the Mathematical Association of America.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer won the Mobile open golf tournament today by two strokes with a closing seven-under-par 65. His 72-hole total was 274.
A rank-and-file revolt yesterday upset a tentative settlement of the seventeen-week strike of elevator installation and maintenance crews in this city.
WARSAW, Nov. 27 -- The value of the United States dollar fell by about 10 per cent on the Warsaw black market last week.
The United States is in the midst of a "culture explosion" that very nearly blows the rug out from under those who picture Americans as ugly, status seeking vulgarians, according to a Jesuit writer.
Under balmy clear skies and in delightful 62-degree temperature it snowed in Central Park yesterday.

MARCEL, DUCHAMP, who at 73 is the most benign presence among artists who were most scandalous in youth, was awaiting the arrival of three live chickens at the D'Arcy Galleries, 1091 Madison Avenue, last Saturday afternoon.
A balmy four-day Thanksgiving week-end drew to a close last night with more than 400 dead in traffic accidents.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 -- India and the United States will cooperate in about forty high-altitude balloon flights. The flights, for the study, of the stratosphere, will begin next month.
Harry S. Truman gave an audience of 1,400 here last night his own estimate of the abilities of American Presidents.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- One of the automatic stabilizers that has been built into the American economic system to cope with slumps is performing very much according to design.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Browns intercepted five passes, but missed three field-goal attempts, and had to settle for a 17-17 tie with the St. Louis Cardinals today in a National Football League game.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 27 -- Anti-Government rioters clashed with the police and national guardsmen for the third day in a row today. One person was reported dead and twenty, including two policemen, were wounded.

Thomas Brockman, South Carolina pianist who began playing here in 1950, gave his sixth New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Many of the gifts he has shown in the past again were revealed, but there were also some of the same limitations.
DETROIT, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe set one scoring record and tied another tonight in a 2-0 victory by the Detroit Red Wings over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
A group of civilian seamen of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service is about to experience its second summer in the same year -- both of them on the cool side.
Labor plans to press for repeal of state "right to work" laws in Indiana and Utah next year.
A program of substantial chamber music was performed authoritatively in Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon by David Sackson, violinist, and Joseph Wolman, pianist.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 -- Last week's decline in steel output reflected holiday influences, and the small volume of new steel orders of the last few weeks.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. Nov. 27 -- A surplus of a million kilowatts of power, enough to keep 10,000,000 100-watt light bulbs burning round the clock may be available on the Niagara frontier when the new State Power Authority Niagara project is completed in 1962.

One of New York State's leading industries will celebrate the passing of a major milestone this week when the New York State Canners and Freezers Association holds its seventy - fifth anniversary meeting in Buffalo.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 -- This city's schools prepared to reopen tomorrow for the second week of desegregated classes while a Federal-state dispute over the issue raged unabated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Aides of Vice President Nixon said tonight that he was angry over continued reports that he was not satisfied with the support given by Governor Rockefeller of New York in the campaign.

A dynamite and blasting-powder watchman for a construction company was questioned yesterday and early today about the recent series of Sunday and holiday bombings. Detectives described him as "a red-hot suspect."

Preservation of Jewish values and traditions are vital for the constructive survival of Jewish life in America, 100 members of the American Jewish Congress were told at a one-day conference held yesterday at the Stephen Wise Congress House, 15 East Eighty-fourth Street.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 27 -- President Urho Kekkonen angrily defended today the results of his recent negotiations in Moscow and called for the formation of a coalition Government to implement them.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two events happened in the Philippines this month that should b called to the attention of the American people: the proclamation by President Carlos P. Garcia of Philippine-American Day on Nov. 15, and the unfortunate death in an airplane accident of Rear Admiral Arthur Spring, commander of the United States Naval Base at Subic Bay, on Nov. 14.

The highlight of the evening is the serving of the haggis. This national dish, according to Mrs. Baxter, is "generally washed down with a glass of good Scotch whisky." She continues: "We rather pride our-selves that we can recognize a good whisky as readily as a Frenchman appreciates a fine wine."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 27 -- Communist East Germany has let it be known that it will seek a separate agreement covering trade with West Berlin in any negotiations for a new trade pact with West Germany.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy challenged the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to put up or shut up today on its charge that he had set up a quota system for traffic tickets.

The open pair contest, last event of the American Contract Bridge Leagues's fall national championship tournament, under way here since Nov. 19, entered its fourth and final session last night at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The Eisenhower Administration correctly identify a serious disease in our economic system when it moved to plug the gold Ieak. But one can scarcely say the treatment applied was either prompt or adequate.
Free bus service to help speed racial integration in New York public schools is being urged on the Board of Education by the City Commission on Intergroup Relations.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., increased its sales in the quarter, nine and twelve months ended on Oct. 29, but earnings dipped in quarter and nine months, according to the report released today.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Prices remained steady on the stock market until about the middle of last week. But they then fell sharply.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Jack Kemp of the Los Angeles Chargers fired a 69-yard touchdown pass to Don Norton and set off a flood of points as the Chargers routed the Oakland Raiders, 52-28, in an American Football League game at the Coliseum today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- The Chicago Bears struck for two first-half touchdowns today, then stopped a Dallas drive and sent the Cowboys to their tenth straight loss in the National Football League. The score was 17-7.

HAVING experienced a number of intense emotions in Town Hall last night during the two-piano program played by Parsons and Poole, this reviewer might best sum up his reaction by saying that he was astonished and appalled by almost everything that went on.
The growing trend toward interrelationship of legitimate theatre, cabarets and coffee-houses was illustrated last week by a Chaplinesque revue called "Stewed Prunes."
Felisa Rincon de Gautier, Mayor of San Juan, P.R., attended solemn high mass and received holy communion yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Beaux Arts Trio, which is in its seventh season, gave a program of chamber music late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The selections were Beethoven's Trio in C minor. Op. 1, No. 3; Aaron Copland's "Vitebsk," and Brahms' Trio in B major Op. 8.

CARACAS, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- National guardsmen fired submachine guns into a crowd of stone-throwing rioters tonight after the anti-Government demonstrators took control of a six-block section of Avenida San Martin in downtown Caracas.
The forty-member resolutions committee of the American Municipal Association urged President-elect John F. Kennedy last night to call a White House conference on urban affairs.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- McLain Street, an 8-year-old gray gelding owned by the Duffy Stables of Rye, N.Y., became the open jumper champion of the Boulder Brook Horse Show today. With the title went the Wee-Three Stables Challenge Trophy for supremacy in the eight classes in which points were awarded.

GENEVA, Nov. 27 -- The Swiss stock markets were marked last week by an abrupt onset of selling that was followed just as abruptly by a complete reversal in the pattern of transactions. The sharp seesaw movement in prices balanced cut the changes for the weeK and the net losses and gains were held to relatively narrow limits.

David Zuckerman and Sons, owner of the twelve-story loft building at 584-90 Eighth Avenue, near Thirty-ninth Street, has purchased the adjoining three-story building at 592 Eighth Avenue. The smaller building had been owned by the seller, the John Engelmann estate, for about fifty years.
The Department of Parks will replace Stop, Yield Right of Way and Merging Traffic signs on the city's parkways in an effort to reduce accidents.
Patrons of the city's ten public golf courses, except those holding season permits, will have to pay higher fees in 1961, Park Commissioner. Newbold Morris announced yesterday.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 27 Fifty-seven representatives of seventeen countries newly admitted to the United Nations spent a typical suburban week-end here yesterday and today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The American Medical Association served notice on President-elect John F. Kennedy today that it would marshal its "tremendous strength" in an effort to kill his proposed medical-care-for-the-aged program.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21 -- Groups of United States political figures, sailors, aviators musicians, a well-known columnist and a Hollywood actress converged on Brazil last week, all intent on fostering goodwill in their specialized ways.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 27 (AP) -- United States Davis Cup hopes received a lift today and the Australian out-look darkened as the Victorian tennis championships neared a finish.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 27 -- President Kwame Nkrumah charged today that the United States, Britain and France were supporting an attempt by Belgium to regain control over the Congo.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla. Nov. 27 -- The largest convention meeting of the Investment Bankers Association of America opened here today at the Hollywood Beach Hotel. More than 1,350 distributors of stocks and bonds from all parts of the nation are registered for the meeting, the forty-ninth annual conference of the trade association.

Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country last month amounted to $3,319,145,000, an increase of 6 per cent over the $3,134,500,000 in the comparable month last year. Commercial buildings and highways accounted for most of the gain.
Mayor Wagner has directed the heads of pertinent city departments and agencies to begin at once putting into effect his program for expanded service to the city's aged residents.
PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Hard on the heels of its campaign against alcoholism, the French Government has moved to deal with another social problem -- prostitution.

The shortage of teacher could be significantly reduce if even a small percentage of women who left the profession to marry and have families would return when their children grew up, a study by the city's' colleges shows.
Andre Kostelanetz returned to the podium of the New York Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall Saturday night to lead the first of three popular-priced concerts he is to give with the orchestra this season.

New York, the smallest team in the National Hockey League, never stopped trying as it rallied for a 3-3 tie with Chicago, the biggest team, last night. A crowd of 13,044 watched the game between the Rangers and the Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- After two successive weeks of rather broad declines, the grain futures market recovered a good deal of lost ground last week.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 27 -- Stirling Moss of England, driving in front as usual, won the Nassau Trophy Race for Grand Touring cars today as this area's seventh annual week of sports car competition opened.

In politics appearances are often more important than reality. A man becomes known as Honest Vic for challenging an expense-account claim for a baked potato and thereby obtains a political asset that benefits him for the rest of his life.

Meng, President of Hunter College, questioning the activities of the Catholic Teachers Association of the Diocese of Brooklyn in connection with the alleged anti-Catholic hiring and promotion practices at Queens College.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- A Presidential commission set "high and difficult" national goals for the Nineteen Sixties today and said that taxes might have to be raised to attain them.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 27 -- Leander Henry Perez Sr., the architect of Louisiana's bitter contest to preserve racial segregation, in public schools, is no one-way tactician in his political and states rights campaigns.
ELISABETH SCHWARZKOPF gave a recital of German songs last night at Carnegie Hall, and such was the drawing power of the German soprano that an audience of more than 2,600 filled the hall.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The Philadelphia Eagles rallied for a 31-23 victory over the New York Giants at Franklin Field today and moved a step closer to the Eastern Conference championship in the National Football league.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Following are the texts of two messages today from President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- A juicy plum is about to drop off the Hollywood tree, and the bees are buzzing around.
Pete McArdle of the New York Athletic Club won the nine-mile cross-country race sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

AT a recent cocktail party, one of the foods that caused the most comment -- all of it favorable -- was simply hard-cooked eggs that had been rolled generously in freshly ground black pepper. This should be encouraging to those hostesses who will be doing all the preparations themselves for parties they will be giving in the holiday season ahead.
A cooperative attempt by the Federal Government, Union Theological Seminary and a rehabilitation center to bring emotional and spiritual help to disabled persons was announced here yesterday.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange mostly advanced yesterday. The near months fell and the distant positions rose. Options closed down 5 points to up 11. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
The major maritime unions in the nation will meet Dec. 16 to prepare for united action against ship owners in advance of collective bargaining sessions scheduled for the spring and summer of 1961.

Harcourt, Brace Stockholders of Harcourt, Brace Co. and World Book Company voted yesterday to merge the two companies. The new book publishing concern will be known as Harcourt, Brace and World, Inc., and it is believed it will be one of the five largest book publishers in the United States.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The United States, Britain and France defended today the arming of West Germany against charges by the Soviet Union that such a policy was a threat to peace.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers, hitting on 61 per cent of their shots from the floor in the first half, beat the Philadelphia Warriors, 137 -- 112, tonight.
A choral program in English and Spanish will be presented Thursday night at the Good Neighbor Church and Community Center of the New York City Mission Society.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The partners of West Germany in the European Common Market are becoming increasing annoyed at the Bonn Government's unwillingness to give any ground in the touchy and important area of agriculture.
YESTERDAY (NOV. 28, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Began debate on a declaration on the granting of independence to colonies.

HAVANA, Nov. 28 -- Premier Fidel Castro expressed the hope today that President-elect John F. Kennedy would decide that the Eisenhower policy toward Cuba must be changed. He predicted that if the United States attacked the island it would mean "suicide for Yankee imperialism."

THERE are not many quiet, soothing places for Christmas shopping, but one of the least frenetic is the Arden for Men Shop at 1 East Fifty-fourth Street. Elizabeth Arden originally planned it as an elegant nook specializing in men's gifts, and it is a good place for women to consider if they have run out of ideas on what to buy the male members of their families.

Caroline couldn't or wouldn't sit still. It is hard to sit still on one's third birthday, even though one is in church and has a certain responsibility as the daughter of a President-elect. Caroline's daddy took her upstairs into a pew behind the choir loft and, as things turned out, this was a wise thing for him to do. Caroline lay down on the pew.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Aside from the lone voice of Prof. Richard H. Timberlake in your Nov. 20 issue, it appears to be the unanimous opinion on the subject of money and international exchange that we are at the brink of a calamity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The United States will reorganize its technical aid program in Israel, beginning in July, 1962.

THERE is a growing body of opinion that holds to the belief that the cradle is the place to instill a taste for luxury. Among the subscribers to this theory are doting grandmothers, affluent Santa Clauses and a tiny, Latvian designer who creates infants' heirloom linens that can withstand many turns in a washing machine.
Minnesota, coming back from a disastrous year in 1959, was named the national major-college football champion in the final poll of The United Press International Board of Coaches yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 28 -- Programs for attracting new industry and for combating juvenile delinquency were approved today by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors.

Many persons prominent in the worlds of diplomacy, society and art will attend a concert by Birgit Nilsson at Carnegie Hall next Sunday evening. The Swedish soprano's only New York concert this season will be a benefit for the City Symphony Orchestra of New York, Inc., and the Clarion Music Foundation, Inc.
ALBANY, Nov. 28 -- More than 1,000,000 potential tax dodgers are under state scrutiny as a result of the introduction of withholding into the state income-tax system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut was reported today to be the almost certain choice of President-elect John F. Kennedy as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 28 -- Yale University has informed the Yale Center of Alcohol Studies that the forty-year relationship between the two must be ended.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- A collection of the best known clothes in the world is heading for its final public appearance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today it planned to continue to press for legislation to require pretesting of cosmetics for safety before they could be placed on the market.

Sidney J. Ungar completed his testimony in the trial of Hulan E. Jack yesterday, but was directed by the Court to hold himself "available" for possible disciplinary action for his behavior on the stand.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Final arguments were presented before the Pennsylvania Supreme Court today in an appeal for an injunction to restrain the International Maritime Workers Union from picketing the Liberian-flag ship Ore Monarch.

THE Discovery of the World,"* by Albert Bettex, is a magnificent book of colored plates and drawings about man's restless reaching toward the unknown. It comes just at the right time to remind us that the exploration of this planet has probably been quite as lively an undertaking as the one the astronauts promise us.

A healthy market for United States Treasury bills stimulated by a strong, dose of new bank money contrasted yesterday with a pallid market for longerterm United States issues, which was affected by balanceof-payment jitters.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 28 -- When the Air Force closes Mitchel Field next year, Nassau County will lose one of its oldest residents.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy has been advised by her physician to take it easy for the first six months in the White House.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The heads of the two largest United Nations assistance programs, citing the growing needs of Africa, called today for a record $150,000,000 in annual contributions.
The Federal Reserve cannot bring down intermediate and long-term interest rates further unless it is prepared to allow short-term rates to decline, a Government securities dealer said yesterday.

ALGIERS, Nov. 28 -- Louis Joxe, the newly appointed French Minister of State for Algerian Affairs, sought today to reassure Europeans here that France had no intention of abandoning them in the program for political self-determination.
Prices of commodities closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading generally was dull and listless.
Coach Doc Wiedman of DeWitt Clinton, quite naturally, says: "It's going to be a tough game. I'm worried about it."

The Pacific Sunrise Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Idemitsu Kosan Company, a major oil concern of Japan, has signed a ten-year lease on a large segment of the thirty-first floor of the International Building, at 630 Fifth Avenue, in Rockefeller Center.

A DRASTIC change of pace is being demonstrated on "The Play of the Week" over WNTA-TV (Channel 13). After devoting a fortnight to Eugene O'Neill's drama of despair, "The Iceman Cometh," the series has turned to sketches, satire and songs.

Five thoroughbred racing groups, three of them charter members, seceded from the Thoroughbred Racing Associations yesterday. The reason apparently was disagreement with Spencer Drayton, the organization's executive vice president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Four opponents of James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, sought a Federal court order today to require an election, of officers in Teamster Local 282 in New York on Sunday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Israel told the United Nations emphatically today that she refused to consider any general return of Arab refugees in the present circumstances.

Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pensylvania hailed the prospect yesterday that a new Federal leadership would marshal the country's resources at city, state and national levels to meet the urban problems that overwhelm local government.
MEYRIN, Switzerland, Nov. 28 -- Scientists from ten nations met here today to plan Europe's entry into space research.

LEYDEN, Mass., Nov. 28 -- David Baker ended a vendetta with a fairly large, wicked-looking wild canine yesterday by killing it, thereby reviving the public debate about what such things are -- wolves, coyotes, coy-dogs or coy-wolves.

Following are the texts of the opinion written by Chief Judge J. Edward Lumbard of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, reversing the conspiracy conviction against twenty defendants in the Apalachin case, and of a concurring opinion by Circuit Judge Charles E. Clark:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A team of agricultural economists painted today a less-than-rosy picture of prospects for farm prosperity in the Nineteen Sixties.

TRENTON, Nov. 28 -- Bills that would permit large increases in expenditures for public parks by three New Jersey counties and allow state scholarships to be used at any American institution were adopted by the State Senate today and sent to the Assembly.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Influences in the grain futures trade were few and minor today as dealings became draggy and price changes held generally to small fractions.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 28 -- Patrice Lumumba, the deposed Premier, has fled from his residence without the knowledge of the troops guarding him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The average discount rate on short-term bills sold by the Treasury today was slightly lower than that of last Monday. It was the second consecutive weekly decline, but the rate remained higher than the two-year low that was set only five weeks ago.
Maintenance of the status quo at New Rochelle's almost all-Negro Lincoin School is the only course now open to the school board, a former president of the board testified yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- David Ormsby-Gore, British Minister of State, denounced Soviet colonialism today and said that the Russians were "the greatest oppressors of our day."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- A number of African and Asian delegates to the United Nations have received a racist "hate" letter. The Federal Bureau of Investigation was asked today by James J. Wadsworth, chief United States delegate, for an immediate inquiry.

William Gibbs McAdoo Jr., the 65-year-old son of the late Secretary of the Treasury in the Wilson Administration, was killed yesterday when, he plunged from the sixth-floor roof of the Fifth Avenue Nursing Home.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Britain's drinkers will be able to linger a bit longer over their midday pints and will have a fifteenminute period of grace after "Time, gentlemen" under the terms of the Government's liquor bill.

A Bronx grand jury took up charges yesterday that mobsters have swindled construction companies here of $250,000 or more in a payroll-padding scheme that listed "ghost workers" on city housing projects.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 28 -- The West German Cabinet will decide Wednesday whether to order negotiations for a new trade pact with Communist East Germany.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- A group of finance companies is planning a credit-rating system to cover Britain. It would be modeled on the practice in the United States.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 28 -- Heavy picketing by Negroes and four sit-ins marked the fourth day of a new campaign of integrationist demonstrations here. An attempt at negotiations apparently broke down before a move could get under way.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 28 -- The differences between the Roman Catholic Church and the Haitian Government appeared to be widening today with the refusal of the Administration of President Francois Duvalier to recognize Bishop Remy Augustin as apostolic administrator.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- President Eisenhower served notice today that the United States was determined to take whatever decisions were necessary "to protect the integrity of the dollar."
The McGraw-Hill Publishing Company is negotiating for the acquisition of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, also a well-known publishing concern.

TOKYO, Nov. 28 -- Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange sagged sharply today. Analysts ascribed the drop to apprehensions of new United States measures to holster the dollar in ways that might adversely affect Japanese business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Representatives Charles A. Halleck of Indiana and W. Howard Smith of Virginia took steps today to keep their bipartisan conservative coalition functioning in the Eighty-seventh Congress.
A World War I infantry private, who rose to become Chief of Staff of the Canadian Army from 1955 to 1958, yesterday was named full-time president of the Toronto Stock Exchange, effective on Jan. 1.
A prime suspect in the city's recent series of bombings was sent to Bellevue Hospital yesterday as detectives began checking the story he had told them.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- The Soviet Communist party delivered today its strongest attack in months on those within the international Communist movement who are opposing Premier Khrushchev's program of "peaceful coexistence."

North American manufacturers of newsprint will have to increase productive capacity by about 30 per cent in the next ten years to keep up with rising demand, according to a study issued by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

NICE, France, Nov. 27 -- About the only major skiing race, Jean Vuarnet ever won was the Olympic downhill at Squaw Valley, Calif., last winter. It was enough. When Vuarnet went home to the little village of Morzine (population 1,815) in the French Alps, his neighbors gave him a car and named him ski director of the resort.
PARIS, Nov. 28 -- A tough, unsparing documentary film on the United States Marine Corps training program at Parris Island, S.C. -- as seen by a Frenchman -- opened here yesterday.
Former President Harry S. Truman yesterday called the American Medical Association the "biggest trust in the world and a mean one, yes, m-e-a-n -- ornery."
A phenomenon that has had a prominent role in efforts to harness the power of the hydrogen bomb is also being applied to rocket-propulsion research.

A world-wide rate war among shipping companies transporting United States cotton abroad appears probable within the next month as a result of the resignation of an American company from the Far East Conference, shipping men said yesterday.

Leopold Stokowski will take over the musical direction of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Puccini's "Turandot" at its premiere on Feb. 24. The late Dimitri Mitropoulos was to have led the opera this season.

GENEROSITY is one of mankind's most noble traits -- but not on a football field. That is one place where selfishness is rewarded. In fact, it's even admired because the open-hearted guys with giveaway tendencies invariably get swept away by their philanthropic Impulses and wind up giving away the ball game.
The men may as well be good sports about it. The bill for women's stockings is apt to go up next year.
Delegates of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday filled out a five-page questionnaire asking what they knew about a quota system for arrests, summonses and offenses.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A proposal to increase dues in the American Medical Association by $1,500,000 to $3,500,000 a year was disclosed today.
A portable radio studio that looks like a giant bratwurst drew hundreds of gawkers yesterday on the main floor of Grand Central Terminal.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 28 -- The Yugoslav Communist Government declared an amnesty today for many prisoners, but there was no indication that Milovan Djilas, Yugoslavia's most famous political prisoner, was affected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Afghanistan will offer to mediate differences between Iran and the United Arab Republic during the visit of Premier Jafar Sharif-Imami of Iran to Kabul, the Afghan capital, diplomatic informants said today.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Persistent selling by small investors caused one of the biggest setbacks of the year in the stock market here today. Despite the appearance of...

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 29 -- The ever-changing picture in the scrambled expansion plans of the major leagues saw the American League again taking dead aim at Los Angeles today in a renewed effort to operate with ten clubs in 1961.
The State Education Department has clarified its recent decision that parents have the right to inspect their children's school records, including material previously often considered confidential.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Times is giving the Louisiana story its usual excellent and complete coverage. But I still wonder how many of its readers can grasp the realities of this recurrent crisis in the South.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 -- Two public elementary schools began their second week of technically desegregated classes today. A small police guard stood by, but there were no incidents.

Obduilio Nunez of Puerto Rico gained his ninth victory of the year in ten starts last night at St. Nicholas Arena. The rising middleweight was awarded a unanimous decision over Bobby Pena of Mexico in the ten-round main event.
A "shadow board of trustees" of prominent educators will submit to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare tomorrow a detailed plan for a "liberal arts college of the future" on Ellis Island.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 27 -- Argentina's economic recovery program is being tugged between a breakthrough into real growth and a slide back into inflation as President Arturo Frondizi nears the midpoint of his six-year term.

Authors as Martyrs Authors would be the first to agree that they are an unappreciated group. When a writer has completed a novel (often despite an eight-hour job and evening hours devoted to his family) he is fortunate if even a momentary gleam of admiration for his effort passes across the face of someone who has read his book.

Volume expanded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and until early in the afternoon there seemed a strong likelihood that the long-awaited year-end rally might be starting. With the slow realization that this was not to be, floor traders gave up their early morning positions and the market closed with a moderate loss.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 28 -- The requirement that notes and deposits of the Federal Reserve System be backed by a minimum reserve of 25 per cent in gold should be repealed, the head of one of the largest commercial banks of the United States said here today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 28 (AP) -- America's Davis Cup stock reached its highest level of the season when two United States teams gained the doubles semi-finals today in the Victorian tennis championships.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 28 -- Federal agencies should follow the lead of the Tennessee Valley Authority and finance their capital needs in the public market, according to a proposal submitted to the Investment Bankers Association convention here today.
Reform Democratic district leaders agreed last night to press for Carmine G. De Sapio's ouster as New York County Democratic leader "at the earliest possible moment."

The Building Trades Employers' Association has named H. Earl Fullilove chairman of its board of governors, effective Jan. 1. Peter W. Eller, board chairman since 1949, will continue as a consultant to the association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Air Force announced today that it would close three major bases, including Mitchel Field on Long Island.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Luis Rodriguez, the undefeated Cuban welterweight, proved too strong and too fast for Johnny Gonsalves of Oakland, Calif., tonight in scoring a unanimous decision in a tenround bout.

Earnings of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway dipped last month to $3,900,966 from $4,388,534 in October, 1959. Gross revenues for, the month, however, edged up to $52,315,930 from $51,767,571 in 1959.

The Port of New York Authority was depicted in a Congressional hearing yesterday as having paid more than $190,000 in interest above the lowest available rate in its borrowings from the First National City Bank in two years.

Friendly Frost, Inc., big dealer in major appliances in the Metropolitan area, is expanding into New England through the acquisition of the County Hardware and Appliances chain. The purchase was for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock, Gerald O. Kaye chairman of Friendly Frost, announced yesterday.
Steel production is scheduled to show a slight improvement this week, but mills will still operate at less than 50 per cent of capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
The conspiracy convictions against twenty men who attended the 1957 meeting at Apalachin, N.Y., were reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
ALTHOUGH the cool summer refreshed the citizens, it left the breweries disconsolate and fretful. Bert and Harry Piel, the TV cartoon salesmen, must pay for part of the indignity.

Two writers are turning out a song and dance plot for "Carte Blanche," which has to do with the credit card vogue in the West Indies and New York. They are Dean Fuller and George Goodman, whose joint effort will be coordinated with Mary Rodgers' music and Marshall Barer's lyrics.

Plans for a $2,000,000 warehouse and industrial building were filed with the Department of Buildings yesterday by Irving Maidman, real estate investor and developer. The structure is to rise on the city block bounded by Tenth and Eleventh Avenues and Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets.

The perfect democracy, like Plato's Republic, is a philosophic ideal, but discrimination under the law of democracy is remediable. As long as it exists in this Republic there will remain a paradox that cannot be reconciled with our profession of principles as an exemplar of Western democracy. The President's Commission on National Goals rightly set "the status of the individual" as a primary concern of the nation.
The state rent administrator for lower Manhattan agreed yesterday to consider reviewing the eviction certificate he had issued against the tenants of a Greenwich Village tenement house.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 28 -- President Tito announced today that Yugoslavia's projected constitution probably would go into effect sometime in 1962.

Contract negotiators for the broadcasting networks and two performers' unions were reported yesterday to be making progress on an informal basis. The report came from a spokesman for the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, who said:

Money turned easier yesterday in one area. Federal Funds -- excess reserves that one bank can lend temporarily to another bank -- could be had yesterday for three-quarters of 1 per cent interest. Even at that low level there were no takers.

P.W. Brooks Co., Inc., and the Lee Higginson Corporation are jointly managing the sale of 450,000 common shares of the Bzura Chemical Company, Inc., at $10.50 a share. Of the shares, 350,000 are being sold by the company to raise capital to expand production of fumaric and citric acids and for other corporate purposes, including an increase in working capital.
ALBANY, Nov. 28 -- Joseph F. Carlino, Speaker of the Assembly, endorsed a $300 annual tuition fee today for New York City's municipal colleges.
The troubles besetting the New York Rangers continued to mount when it was learned yesterday that Canaille Henry, a left wing, would be lost to the club at least six weeks.
Mayor Wagner reported yesterday that he planned to ease the restrictions on cabaret workers while continuing to protect the public against the employment of unsavory persons in night spots.

L. Judson Morhouse, the Republican state chairman, intervened yesterday to delay the choice of a new Bronx Republican leader after strong opposition had developed to Representative Paul A. Fino for the office.

No. Amer. Merchandising North American Merchandising Company, Dallas, Tex., has acquired all the outstanding stock of Williamsburg Greeting Card Corporation, including its subsidiaries, of this city. North American recently acquired Metropolitan Lithograph" and Publishing Company, Everett Mass. Williamsburg's subsidiaries include Friendship Greetings, Inc.; Midland Publishing and Round Hill Studios.

Armstrong Cork Company A year-end dividend of 20 cents was voted on the common stock of the Armstrong Cork Company for payment on Dec. 22 to holders of record of Dec. 8. The year-end raises the total to $1.60 this year, the same as in 1959, when a year-end distribution of 30 cents was made.
TRENTON, Nov. 28 -- A State Senate committee demanded today the immediate dismissal of three members of the state commission that controls legalized games of chance for alleged dereliction of duty.

YONKERS, Nov. 28 -- Harness racing betting figures for New York State soared to new heights at Yonkers Raceway tonight when 22,460 fans bet $881,703 in the first four races, raising the 1960 total to $500,072,127.

Federal Judge William B. Herlands ruled yesterday that Igor Y. Melekh, Russian United Nations employe, was not entitled to diplomatic immunity and ordered him taken to Chicago to face espionage charges.

JACQUES Klein, Brazilian pianist, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. It was not his first local appearance, however, for he made his debut a year ago with the New York Philarmonic when his fellow countryman, Eleazar de Carvalho, was a guest conductor.

The 1961 thoroughbred racing season in New York will be the most ambitious in the history of the sport, with $3,800,000 in stakes money to be disbursed. John W. Hanes, chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, disclosed the plans at Aqueduct yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Following is a statement by President Eisenhower after his conferences with Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Andersen and Under Secretary of State Douglas Dillon on their mission to West Germany:

At the start of this century, Diana Holman-Hunt, the granddaughter of the celebrated painter William Holman-Hunt, was brought up by her two grandmothers. One was the handsome, "gaunt" widow of the painter -- parsimonious and "terrifyingly" strong both physically and mentally.
AS a young lawyer in 1935, Joseph Edward Lumbard undertook a risky assignment.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- The case of the disappearing ballot records enlivened and confused today the Republican investigation of the Nov. 8 election in Illinois.
WARSAW, Nov. 28 -- Italy and Poland signed a four-year agreement yesterday that marks a departure in Italian commercial policy with Eastern European countries.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 28 -- President Romulo Betancourt suspended constitutional guarantees throughout Venezuela today and called out the army to maintain order. Senor Betancourt said that violence was being instigated by extremist elements that wish to overthrow his Government and "establish a regime here like that of Cuba."
Unless the unexpected happens, the Gotham Bowl college football game may be abandoned for this year.

A system of surveillance that keeps the underworld from getting into the night club business is a protection to the public and to the decent people who prevail in the dining-with-entertainment industry. For twenty years or more the Police Department has been assisted in this purpose by the requirement that employes and entertainers have an identification card, bearing photograph and fingerprint, and that this be renewed with the department's Division of Licenses every two years.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 -- David H. Stevens, president of the American Association of State Highway Officials, warned today against improper practices in the Federal-tate road-building program.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 28 -- Max Zaslofsky, who was in the limelight for more than a decade as a professional basketball player, recently went back to school to learn how to be inconspicuous.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Preliminary tabulations indicate that compact cars are taking a greater share of 1961 model production than they are of current sales.
Madison Square Garden was no place yesterday for bystanders who couldn't keep their hands in their pockets. A man scratched his head and almost wound up pledging $1,500 for a 2-year-old filly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Defense Department will start construction tomorrow of an unusual "pulsing" atomic reactor that will take the place of nuclear explosions in testing the effect of radiation on humans.

The only cheery note at the season's first metropolitan basketball luncheon at Leone's yesterday was provided by -- of all persons -- a representative of the cellar-dwelling professional Knickerbockers.
The city is being urged by its water experts to lose no time in building a $31,100,000 water tunnel from Brooklyn to Staten Island.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 28 (UPI) -- A part settlement of a labor jurisdiction dispute between the Federal space agency and two unions sent 200 striking workers back to their jobs today at launching facilities for the Saturn and Centaur rockets.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The United Nations reported today that at least twelve of its military and civilian personnel were savagely beaten by Congolese soldiers during the outbreaks in Leopoldville from last Monday to Wednesday.

THE newest home away from home for many families today is the shopping center. A housewife can drop off her wash at the laundromat in such a center, visit a depart- ment store there, have her hair done, meet her friends for a lunch in the elegant restaurant, pick up her groceries at the supermarket and gourmet shop, retrieve her wash and return home, usually in time for dinner.

A TEXAS pair, Oswald Jacoby of Dallas and Curtis Smith of Austin, won the open pair championship in the final event of the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament at the Statler-Hilton Hotel here.
Labor and management in the city's $1,000,000,000-a-year construction industry may "strike" against elevator installation and maintenance crews.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The Weather Bureau began dispatching information from the Tiros II satellite to forecast centers today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 28 -- Maurice A. Hutcheson, president of the Carpenters Union, and William Blaier, vice president, were sentenced to two to fourteen years in prison today in the Indiana highway scandals.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Twenty-eight American Governors flew here today after a fifteen-day goodwill tour of South America. They appeared enthusiastic about the trip and reported unusually friendly receptions everywhere.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Nan Robertson's moving account of the personal plight of a Filipino physician who failed to pass the Educational Council for Foreign Medical Graduates examination confronts us with a moral dilemma.

Operations of the Northrop Corporation in the fiscal quarter ended on last Oct. 30, resulted in higher sales and earnings than a year before, Thomas V. Jones, president, disclosed yesterday. Formerly known as Northrop Aircraft, Inc., the company develops and makes guided missiles, electronic equipment, manned aircraft, target and surveillance drones.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday charged the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association was trying to seize control of Police Department policies.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 29 -- A. panel of scientists says the rapidly increasing number of chemicals for agriculture and food production demands vigilance to safeguard the consumer from health hazards.
Sales and earnings of two major department store companies in the October quarter were below results in the 1959 period, according to reports issued yesterday.
THE little stage of the Theatre de Lys crackled with gleeful irreverence yesterday under the impact of Eugene Ionesco's intellectual farce, "The Shepherd's Chameleon."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy indicated today that a major foreign-policy assignment would be given to Representative Chester Bowles of Connecticut. After an hour's breakfast conference with Mr. Bowles on foreign affairs, Senator Kennedy said at his Georgetown home that no specific post had been discussed but that they would confer on an appointment in the near future.
TETERBORO, N.J., Nov. 29 -- A cockpit device for displaying pictorially a plane's position in flight was demonstrated today on a bumpy flight to eastern Pennsylvania and back.
Boos and audience battles, plus a bomb scare, were the accompaniment last night at Carnegie Hall when a chorus of students from Belgrade University made its first appearance here.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- The West German Ambassador to France endorsed today the idea of giving the North Atlantic Treaty Organization nuclear arms and a greater degree of control over their strategic and tactical employment.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 -- John C. Mackie, Michigan Highway Commissioner, advocated today a strictly enforced minimum speed and a 75-mile-an-hour maximum speed on the nation's new system of interstate highways.
Earnings of the Rohr Aircraft Corporation in three months ended on Oct. 31 were more

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The disappearance of ballot applications from Chicago's City Hall yesterday was stamped today by the Republican National Committee as "dramatic evidence" of a scandal with "national repercussions."
MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- Premier Khrushchev interrupted a reception for Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia tonight to confer with three of his top aides.
A double of a slam contract -- a slam that the opponents have bid voluntarily, not as an attempted sacrifice -- is almost universally used as a message to partner to make an unusual opening lead.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Eisenhower Administration is still convinced that West Germany can and must take basic steps to help correct the United States' deficit in international payments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- In addition to the problems of taking over the Government, the new Democratic leaders face trouble on the male fashion front.
Barring late additions, there's only one hot potato on the legislative menu of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's twenty-fourth annual convention, for which deck-clearing begins today.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Oregon State football team voted unanimously today to play in the Gotham Bowl at Yankee Stadium on Dec. 10. But Bowl officials said an opponent had not been determined nor were they certain a game would be played.

The health and longevity of the people of Hunza, a small region of northern India, is the subject of a second book on those people to be published within a year. In March "Hunza Land: The Fabulous Health and Youth Wonderland of the World," by Dr. Allen E. Banik and Renee Taylor, was issued by the Whitehorn Publishing Company and distributed by Taplinger.
SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 26 -- Completing a month in office, the six-man military and civilian junta that rules El Salvador announced today it would hold entirely free elections.

Plans are being completed for the Mistletoe Debutante Ball, to be held at the Pierre on Dec. 23. Mrs. Robert E. Coulson and Mrs. Charles A. Dana Jr. are co-chairmen for the annual event, a benefit for the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
One hundred and twenty women eager to learn how to invest attended the all-day Woman Investor's Clinic at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Many of the nation's country clubs will have to change their policies and some may have to go out of business because of a new Federal tax ruling.
CHICAGO, NOV. 29 -- United States Attorney Robert Tieken said today that a Federal grand jury was, investigating charges of vote fraud in Illinois in the Nov. 8 election.
ROCKLEIGH, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Ground was broken here today for the first building of the Rockleigh-Orangetown. Industrial Park, which straddles the New Jersey-New York border.

ALMOST everyone, at one time or another, has felt a strong personal interest in some historic figure, be it Lincoln or Napoleon, Mata Hari or Florence Nightingale. One of the most extravagant way to indulge such an attraction and to adopt a new decorating trend is offered by Charles Hamilton's unusual and tasteful collection of "Handwriting on the Wall."

Net income of North American Aviation, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 dropped to 23,394,548 from the $30,726,134 cleared in the preceding year, the company has announced in the annual report.
A "revolution in biology" in the last five years has brought about a change in the emphasis of the research program of the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points up to 5 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The Banco Nacional De Cuba sued the Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National City Bank here yesterday for $12,141,021. The money was said to be excess collateral owed to the Cuban bank after the settlement of loans.
Routine trading, with prices narrowly mixed, characterized the commodities markets here yesterday.

The Justice Department was undecided yesterday whether to appeal to the Supreme Court against the reversal of conspiracy, convictions of twenty persons at the 1957 Apalachin meeting of underworld figures.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Separate talks on possible revision of the Southern Rhodesian Constitution will be held next week while the Constitution for the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is under review.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., has leased a store containing 10,000 square feet of space in the apartment building being erected on the east side of Second Avenue from Seventieth to Seventy-first Street. The deal was negotiated by Charles H. Greenthal Co., agents for Julius Perlbinder and Philip E. Goldfein, the builders.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A fairly general retreat broadened in late dealings on the Board of Trade today and lopped a cent or more a bushel off most oats, rye and soybean contracts. Corn futures eased.

A special legislative committee has called a public hearing to consider changes in the controversial Condon-Wadlin Law. This act provides that public employes who strike are to be automatically dismissed.
