THE inept handling of the U-2 incident, with the inexplicable bureaucratic confusion in Washington and the consequent international embarrassment for the United States, was revived last night by the National Broadcasting Company in a televised documentary on the unhappy blunders of last May, One wonders why.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- The United States charged the Soviet Union today with attempting to frame a disarmament treaty under which secret nuclear explosions could not be detected.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- Controller Arthur Levitt tentatively released three tax-reduction trial balloons into the politically charged atmosphere here today.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 29 -- There are eighteen twists and turns on the four-and-a-half-mile course here where the sports car races of the annual Speed Week are run. The site was once a commercial airport. It is just a mile from town and named after the Oakes family.

John P. Cunningham, chairman of Cunningham Walsh, Inc., has felt for some time that advertising's popular image will not be improved by speeches that advertising men make to each other at conventions.

Every conscientious income-taxpayer can be glad that the Rockefeller Administration is getting around to the job of writing a letter to about 1,000,000 New Yorkers asking why they didn't file a return for 1957. About half of these non-filers are expected to have a legitimate reason; the rest may be tax dodgers, and their evasion may go 'back past 1957, a question to be pursued later.

IN its New York debut in Carnegie Hall last night, the Branko Krsmanovich Chorus of Yugoslavia showed why it has been a prize-winning ensemble in European choral competitions year after year. For it sings with an almost Unparalleled brilliance and technical perfection.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that manufacturers' sales, inventories of raw materials and new orders declined in October.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

A Newark real estate broker testified yesterday that he had paid a Port of New York Authority official $9,575.38 in one year in the belief he had to do so to get leases of authority property for clients.

White, Weld Co., Inc. and associated investment bankers offered to the public yesterday 817,391 common shares of Ginn Co., Boston textbook publisher, at $24.50 a share. The offering is the first to the public of the company's common stock.
Moshe Sharett, former Israeli Premier and Foreign Minister rejected a proposal last night that he take on a role of active leadership in world Zionism.
CAIRO, Nov. 29 -- The Congo Government's move to expel the United Arab Republic's Ambassador drew an attack by Cairo on the United Nations today.
The Alabama Highway Authority sold $15,000,000 of bonds, due from 1962 to 1981, at competitive bidding yesterday to a group of investment bankers headed by the First Boston Corporation.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- Political analysts looking for clues to the Democratic victory in New York State this fall will find few of them in the campaign expense records.
A showdown that threatened to split the powerful Transpacific Freight Conference has ended in a compromise.
The arrest of Dr. Robert Soblen yesterday as a spy added another name to the list of cans charged with passing in-native and naturalized Ameriformation to the Soviet Union.
RYE, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- The adoption of cluster planning for new houses in Westchester County to avoid further inefficient urban sprawl was asked tonight by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian.
The cruise ship Argentina went 400 miles off her course Sunday to get a critically ill seaman to St. John's, Nfld., for surgical treatment.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I am on jury duty for the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York. I am disillusioned.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Ghana urged Portugal and Spain today to grant immediate independence to their African colonies.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., Nov. 29 -- The proposal to close Mitchel Field is causing concert among merchants and among residents of the school districts here and in Uniondale.
A New York award for royalty payments to longshoremen handling containerized cargoes must be extended to all Atlantic and Gulf ports, a dock union official said yesterday.

Stocks continued yesterday the retreat begun on Monday but early in the afternoon put on a gentle rally. The slightly better prices then held to the close but remained well below the final levels for Monday.
Dr. Robert Soblen, a brother of the imprisoned Soviet spy Jack Soble, was charged yesterday with wartime espionage, a crime punishable by death upon conviction.
"All cities, like all families, have suffered from the inflationary pressures in the post-war years."-- Mayor Wagner in his annual report to the City Council April 5, 1960.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Justice Department today announced the seizure of a large quantity of vitamin and mineral preparations at the Cambridge, Mass., plant of E.R. Squibb Sons under an order issued by the Federal District Court at Boston.

PRESCRIPTIONS of diplomats in the news tend to conform to a cliche: they are, it seems, the silent (or not so silent) "trouble shdoters" who somehow always manage to produce the miracle solutions for their foreign ministries Herbert Adolphe Heinrich Blankenhorn, West Germany's Ambassador to France, has been shaped by many of his biographers into this cookie-tin pattern of the striped-pants "trouble shooter."
In a new move to cut down on Gracie Mansion's food bills, Mayor Wagner ordered the Park Department yesterday to start food-buying controls that would bar all unauthorized persons from eating there.

A vast new deposit of molybdenum has been discovered near Taos, N.M., by the Molybdenum Corporation of America, it was disclosed yesterday. It represents the first, major find of the strategic metal in more than four decades, and, if fully developed, could be the second largest molybdenum mine in the world, the company said.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Pentagon officials said today that they expected the outgoing Administration's defense spending budget for the next fiscal year to amount to more than $42,000,000,000.

There is a growing belief among highly placed banking sources that the extraordinary outflow of short-term investment funds from the United States in response to higher interest rates abroad may be nearing its end.

Are the New York Knickerbockers finally through being patsies for the rest of the National Basketball Association? They certainly gave that impression last night as they rallied from an 18-point deficit and downed the Detroit Pistons, 118-107, at the Madison Square Garden.
Joe Bellino, Navy's brilliant halfback, was an overwhelming choice yesterday for the twentysixth annual Heisman Memorial Award as the outstanding college football player of 1960.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: The chairman of the American Committee for France and Algeria, Clifford Forster, is certainly misinformed when in a letter to The New York Times, published Nov. 13, he states that the Algerian people have expressed their overwhelming desire to be integrated with France by voting for it in the last two referenda.
Negro pupils should not be permitted to transfer out of New Rochelle's Lincoln Elementary School solely because of their race, a Negro educator contended yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The chief of the Army's Corps of Engineers said today that the $1,200,000,000 "brick-and-mortar" phase of building toppriority missile bases would be completed on time, despite "real problems."

United States participation in the United Nations Convention on Commercial Arbitration now seems assured, an official of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce said yesterday.
A Boards of Education hearing on collective bargaining for teachers provided new evidence yesterday of wide differences of opinion among teachers here.

The Importance of the Latin American, nations as major sources of supply for the United States has been underscored by a report by the United States Department of Commerce. The Government agency has analyzed this country's raw material imports from all sources since 1959.

BASEMENTS generally are associated with bargains, and the lower level of Dilbert's Thirty-fourth Street Supermarket, which opened this morning, is no exception. Nevertheless, it is decidedly different -- for the items being offered at generally competitive prices are specialty foods from all parts of the world.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 29 -- Venezuelan troops occupied the plant and suspended the Communist daily newspaper Tribuna Popular today. Meanwhile, dutbreaks of violence continued in various parts of Caracas.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A walkout by Italy's temperamental Nicola Pietrangeli turned the Victorian tennis championship into a near-American monopoly today.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Anthony Wedgwood Benn, the reluctant peer, carried to the House of Commons today his fight to avoid becoming a member of the House of Lords.

HALF-HOUR sightseeing trips around Manhattan on American Airlines' jet-powered Electras leave La Guardia Airport on Saturdays from 2 P.M. on. They continue until 6 P.M. if requests warrant. Fare is $4.95 a person and includes tax and free souvenirs for children.
A Staten Island ferryboat carrying 2,000 commuters to Manhattan collided with a Norwegian tanker in fog in New York Harbor yesterday morning. Three persons on the ferryboat were injured slightly.

Some of the employes of the city's Real Estate Department who were responsible for irregularities that led to reorganization of the department two years ago still hold sensitive positions, it was charged yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- American investment in British industry has not provoked any Boston tea party in this country as yet.
HONG KONG, Nov. 29 -- Communist China made a point today of stressing its friendship with Communist Albania.

Robert Moses, former chairman of the City Slum Clearance Committee, testified yesterday that he had been persuaded by Borough President Hulan E. Jack to support the Riverside-Amsterdam project, about which he had had doubts.

KENNETH CHERTOK, New York baritone, made his local debut last night at Town Hall. He sang a program that ranged from "Who May Abide" from Handel's "Messiah" to an aria from Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin."

Prices declined all along the line in the bond market yesterday. Long-term United States Government issues dropped 5/8 of a point during the day and rallied to close with losses of 1/4 to 3/8 points. Intermediates were off 2/32 to 6/32 and bills slid 2 to 5 basis points.

Good attendance and sizable placement of orders was reported yesterday at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America. More than 1,200 rooms at the Sheraton-Atlantic and New Yorker Hotels are occupied by exhibitors at the five-day event, which ends tomorrow.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he had decided to seek re-election to a second four-year term in 1962.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 -- Tax reform by the Administration of President-elect John F. Kennedy is likely to explore the field of liberalizing tax write-offs by business for the depreciation account, the Investment Bankers Association was told here today.

From effigy to ecstasy in one season -- that's the story of Coach Murray Warmath and his Minnesota Gophers, crowned national college football champions yesterday in the season's final Associated Press poll.

HAVANA, Nov. 29 -- The New York Times and one of its correspondents in Cuba, Max Frankel, were accused by the Communist newspaper Hoy today of deliberately lying about the relationship between Premier Fidel Castro and the Cuban Communist party.
PARIS, Nov. 29 -- The literary world was in an uproar today over charges of fascism and anti-Semitism against the recently designated winners of the Goncourt and Femina book awards.
Christopher Cannella, accused of being one of the masterminds behind payroll padding on city housing projects, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday on a charge of grand larceny.
BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- "The next few years will see almost a complete revolution in the chemical rocket industry," an Air Force symposium was told today.

Aetna Insurance Directors of the Aetna Insurance Company have declared the regular dividend of 65 cents plus an extra of 40 cents, payable on Jan. 3 to holders of record of Dec. 14. No extra was voted last year.
The American Municipal Association was told yesterday that the key to urban problems was effective interdepartmental coordination through the White House.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 997 persons were injured in the city last week in traffic mishaps. This is a decrease of 149 from last year.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 -- A white mother accompanied by her 6-year-old daughter struggled today with angry demonstrators trying to enforce an 'anti-integration boycott. The police stopped the scuffle that followed.

YONKERS, Nov. 29 -- No. 13 proved lucky tonight for Goldie Herman, a 5-year-old mare owned by L. L. Herrin of Charlotte, N. C. She scored a head victory over Swarttey Hanover in 2:09 2/5 on a sloppy track in the Dobbs Ferry Trot before 18,822 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 29 -- The United Nations command said today that it had no knowledge of Patrice Lumumba's whereabouts and disclaimed responsibility for the deposed Premier's escape from his guarded residence.

In the first half of this concert in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, Guy Fallot, French 'cellist, played with exceptional beauty and fire. He began the program with the Suite No. 2 of Caix d'Hervelois, and he played it with all the grace and charm that such eighteenths-century music deserves.
Navy and Yale will share the Lambert Trophy for the next year as the result of the first tie vote in the twenty-five-year history of an award that symbolizes top Eastern ranking in college football.

LAST September, at the high tide of the autumn flood of important new books (and of books which their authors and publishers hoped were important), still another novel by C.P. Snow was published. Because "Strangers and Brothers"* is an old book originally published in England in 1940 I postponed discussion of it here until competition for review space should become less furious.
The sale of 200 motion-picture features for showing on television was announced here yesterday.
The Miroar Stable's- 3-year-old gelding Long Gone John scored a two-length victory at Aqueduct yesterday over ten allowance milers in the $7,500 Silver Lake Purse.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov, 29 -- Saudi Arabia is seeking a United Nations resolution urging that former Arab properties in Israel be administered by a United Nations official who would collect revenues and use them for the relief of Arab refugees.

THE National Orchestral Association opened its season with a concert last night in Hunter College. It was the first time in the organization's career that it had played there. John Barnett conducted, and as usual the program was an interesting one.

On the Banks of the Vistula From the banks of the Mississippi to the banks of the Vistula is a formidable distance in this day and age. Early this month crowds in Warsaw were acclaiming the philosophical humor and inimitable stories of one of America's thoroughly indigenous Midwestern writers.
Hal March is set to star in "Come Blow Your Horn," scheduled to open here early in March.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A committee of Roman Catholic Bishops called today for "an unmistakable national protest" against the production and exhibition of immoral films.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 29 -- The Laotian Treasury has not received authorization to release United States aid funds for October and November.
MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- The Hallelujah publishing house, a local adventure in underground private enterprise, has foundered.

Three sisters, the wives of men jailed as plotters against Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, the dictator of the Dominican Republic, were reported to have died there in a strange accident.

The Communists have won a battle in Venezuela. The problem now, for all supporters of democracy and social justice in that country and in Latin America as a whole, is to see to it that the Reds do not achieve their main objective. This objective is the overthrow of the Betancourt regime.

Tennessee Gas Transmission Company announced plans yesterday for realigning its corporate structure so as to separate its regulated gas pipeline business from its oil operations and other non-regulated activities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- High officials of the American Medical Association urged today a drastic tightening of the chemical standards for establishing guilt of drunkeness or drunken driving.
A TREND is appearing in Manhattan's beauty parlor business, and it has nothing to do with, a new hair style.
A suit was filed yesterday in Supreme Court challenging the right of Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to require identification cards of entertainers and other cabaret employes.
Trinidad Oil, a British company, owned producing properties and a refinery in Trinidad, marketing operations in other areas of the Caribbean, and refining and marketing facilities in Canada.

A demonstration was made yesterday of a new animated film device called Technamation, a process researched and developed over a twelve-month period by Gold Medal Enterprises and Technical Animations, Inc.
THE vast run of small striped bass, stretching all the way from the Jersey beaches to the tip of Long Island, is still in full course -- increasing if anything.
Jim Lee Howell, the coach of the New York Giants, denied reports yesterday that he would "go along with rookies rather than use veterans."

The Brooklyn Tech Engineers built a bridge on the mud of Randalls Island and over the DeWitt Clinton line yesterday and inched their way to the football championship of the Public Schools Athletic League.
The general executive board or the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners has affirmed its "complete faith, and confidence" in two leaders convicted of bribing an Indiana highway official.
The New Haven Railroad, struggling to revitalize its passenger operations, will offer half fares to all travelers on week-ends and to women every day.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The stock market wiped out part of yesterday's decline and closed on a firm note here today.
LAMONT, Alberta, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Sixteen high school students died today as a freight train smashed into a school bus and dragged it a quarter mile into this central Alberta town.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Even Winston Churchill, will be 86 tomorrow, can no longer be considered young or notably vigorous. Nevertheless his hugely complete hero, in luminous moments, still shines with brief but undimmed brilliance.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Times editorial of Nov. 18 pointed out that a tax rebate at this time would not be an Unalloyed blessing to the citizens of New York State. The Public Education Association would like to endorse your position by documenting one of the needs mentioned in the editorial -- increased aid for education.

Though some elements in the world, from Cuba to the Congo to Indonesia, still look to the Left for Utopia, the Left itself in all its many shadings is beginning to develop a pattern suggesting that in varying forms and degrees it is turning to the Right.
The Fiesta Mexicana, a cocktail dance to be held Dec. 11 in the Embassy Room of the Gotham Hotel, will benefit the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital at Denver.
THE New York City Ballet opened the fourth week of its season last night at the City Center.

The Bohack Realty Company has sold the one-story taxpayer at the southwest corner of Fresh Pond Road and Woodbine Street, Ridgewood, Queens. Pe-Jo Realty, Inc., Joseph Rosenblum, president, the buyer, paid cash for the property.
NORWALK Conn., Nov. 23 -- The off-again-on-again project of reconditioning this city's last monument to its early days is once more under way.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Senator John F. Kennedy joined in the festivities at his daughter, Caroline's, belated birthday party today. Her grandfather, Joseph P. Kennedy, was in on the celebration, too.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- The Soviet Union demanded today the withdrawal of United Nations troops from the Congo.
TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- The state commission that regulates legalized bingo and similar games of chance was strongly defended by Gov. Robert B. Meyner today.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The National Institute of Economic and Social Research said today that Britain was moving into a difficult period economically. In the current issue of its Economic Review, the institute noted that economic expansion had, for the present, stopped in this country. National output was probably no higher in the third quarter of the year than in the first, the review noted.
Julius Bachrach moved back to the city yesterday after a six-month stay in the suburbs. Was he glad to be back?
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 29 -- Warren C. Giles expressed confidence today that the major leagues would arrive at a satisfactory solution to their territorial differences.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States is expected to extend recognition within a few days to the new regime in El Salvador, informed sources said today.
YESTERDAY (Nov. 29, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued debate on colonialism.
Two expelled members of the International Association of Machinists sought reinstatement yesterday under the union democracy provisions of the Landrum-Griffin Act.
A memoir published today quoted Adolf Eichmann as having said before he was apprehended that he had no regrets for his role in the mass killing of European Jews.

BASEBALL'S upper echelon is so filled with lightweights these days that it hardly can afford to lose one of its few heavyweights, Frank (Shag) Shaughnessy. But the massive, Shag has just retired as president of the International League and the sport will have to struggle along without one of its wisest, most dynamic figures.

Two owner-breeders, hoping to build a powerful Adios racing dynasty in New York State, yesterday purchased Adios Day, a 4-year-old chestnut son of the 2:00 sire, for $17,000 at the Old Glory Sales at Madison Square Garden.

Directors of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company have voted to recommend to stockholders that the capital be increased from $12,000,000 to $24,000,000. Under the proposal to be submitted to stockholders in March the par value would remain at $10 and the new stock would be paid for by transfer from surplus to capital.
As the Jasper director of athletics and coach of basketball, Ken Norton is extremely loyal to Manhattan. But there are times when the mention of his team causes him to take a walk.
ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Tabs to make 1960 license plates valid through 1961 will go on sale tomorrow at offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau.

With three games remaining the Baltimore Colts are well out in front of their National Football League rivals in passing and scoring. The St. Louis Cardinals still lead Baltimore in total offense but they have only two games to go.

It is good news that the Eisenhower Administration is planning to extend recognition to the new regime in El Salvador. If any criticism were to be made, it would be to wonder why we have waited so long.

Governor Rockefeller's announcement that he would seek a second term was widely interpreted yesterday as an effort to quell dissension among Republican that might adversely affect his legislative program.
A rebellious group of Bronx Republican district leaders bowed last night to the wishes of L. Judson Morhouse, the G.O.P. state chairman, to defer the selection of a new county chairman.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 30 -- Armed Leftist students converted a half-finished building on the campus of the Central University here into a fortress tonight and called "Stalingrad."

YONKERS, Nov. 30 -- Against the wintry background of the season's coldest night, Yonkers Raceway closed out its 114-night session tonight with a mutuel handle of $2,532,335, running its season total to $208,690,597.

THE idea of doing classic stories for young viewers is so eminently sound on the surface that the discriminating set owner can only wish good fortune for any such venture. It is a doubly saddening chore, therefore, to report that last night's opening installment of "The Three Musketeers" never rose above period tedium.
New York City's competitive position on teachers' salaries has shown marked improvement in the last year, although its maximum rates are still well below those of many suburbs.
The work of the American Women's Voluntary Services will be furthered as a result of a theatre party at the Dec. 20 performance of "Critic's Choice" at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

Ohio University, with an enrollment of nearly 8,000 and an unbeaten football record that includes victories over three opponents of major rank, yesterday was named national small-college football champion for 1960.

Stock prices made a modest gain on average last month on the New York Stock Exchang. The stock market showed sharp advances in the first two weeks of the month, after which changes were held within a narrow range.
Treasury issues registeve moderate gains in the bond market yesterday after a strong opening.

The first three grants-in-aid of $1,000 each have been awarded by the Mary Roberts Rinehart Foundation. The winners, all of whom are working on novels, are Duane Unkefer and Roy Bongartz, both of New York City, and Dorothy West of Oak Bluffs, Mass.

An intercity helicopter service between the business centers of New York and Philadelphia became a distinct possibility yesterday with the filing of an application by New York Airways before the Civil Aeronautics Board.

IT is no news to anyone that the last few days before Christmas can be the most hectic of the year. Here are a few ideas to help schedule preparations so that the homemaker can greet the holiday in a rested, organized manner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Farm, product prices rose less than one-half of 1 per cent between Oct. 15 and Nov. 15, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Thirty-five football players no older than 13 and no heavier than 115 pounds are sure they are the best kids' team in the world.

Baseball's top brass made no reported progress yesterday toward picking the number from eight to ten that will satisfy the American League's 1961 expansion ambitions without causing pain to the National League.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 30 -- The Soviet and East European Communists have made an ostentatious display of cordiality toward Yugoslavia recently.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney said today that live polio virus vaccine that can be taken by mouth probably would not be available for next summer's polio season.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 15 points yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

KOCA POPOVIC, Yugoslavia's Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, in many ways typifies the political leadership that has emerged in Yugoslavia. As a mark of the role he plays, he left for Italy yesterday on a visit to cement the increasingly friendly relations between Rome and Belgrade.

Maxwell B. Bassett, a director of the Nuclear Corporation of America, has acquired 21,752 shares of the company's stock through conversion of $10,876 principal amount of debentures, it was disclosed yesterday by the American Stock Exchange in its latest report on trading by insiders.

Failure of the joint labor-management committee on work rules in the steel industry to fulfill its mission on time is discouraging news, not only for steel but also for other industries, and the public. The problem it was assigned to solve is basic to almost every industry these days: the deployment by management of its working force in the interest of greater efficiency and lower operating costs.
While the aluminum industry as a whole has been cutting production in the wake of softening demand and reduced profits, one newcomer to the field continues to set a brisk pace.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The reaction of the Russian delegate, Valerian A. Zorin, to the charges of Soviet colonialism mada on Nov. 28 in the United Nations General Assembly was prompt and vigorous -- sufficiently so to indicate the appropriate sensitivity on the point.
The secretary-treasurer of a New Jersey masonry concern was arrested in the Bronx yesterday as a leader in an alleged payroll-padding scheme for construction work at city housing projects.

THIS space having been occupied for nearly two weeks with the results of inter-city and national tournaments, there was inadequate opportunity to pay a last tribute to Nan P. DeWolf (Mrs. W. Ashley DeWolf), who died here on Nov. 18 at the age of 75.

Delaware Hudson The directors of the Delaware Hudson Company reduced the quarterly dividend yesterday to 35 cents a share from the 50 cents distributed in previous quarters. The declaration will be paid on Dec. 28 to stockholders of record of Dec. 9.
The ominous portents have proven true. Bert and Harry Piel are dead.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, which has been operating in the red for twenty-one consecutive months, rolled up another large deficit in October.

Keller Breland of Hot Springs, Ark., who has taught all sorts of animals to follow man's orders through psychology, thinks that dog breeders devote too much attention to physical type and too little to behavior characteristics.

A floor in the forty-story office building constructed recently by Samuel Rudin at 80 Pine Street has been leased by Eastabrook Co., investment bankers. The lessees, who have a main office in Boston and branches throughout New England, plans to move their New York office in February from 30 Wall Street.

Last night's recital in Town Hall by Ivan Davis reaffirmed the success that greeted the young Texas-born pianist's New York debut a little over a year ago. His latest appearance was part of the award given him for winning the Franz Liszt Piano Competition here last April.
Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan has asked the Board of Estimate to ease a manpower shortage now hampering his investigations into alleged irregularities in the city government.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- Plans for strengthening civic education in the secondary schools of nine Northeastern states were made known here today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Two officials of the Hungarian Legation in Washington, were stopped by the state police near here today after the Hungarians had spent more than an hour apparently observing an Army missile base.
A wave of conservatism in voting toned down requests for aid from Washington by the American Municipal Association as the group wound up its thirty-seventh annual congress yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Dollars Anonymous -- a private move to honor the New Orleans schools superintendent -- today flooded Dr. James F. Redmond with money in unmarked envelopes.
UNTIL the gag wore itself out from overexposure, press box tenants amused themselves in the early stages of the 1947 season by asking a seemingly innocent question of their mates.
The nation's production of crude oil continued to rise last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

The electric guitar, which has been relatively static in jazz during the last twenty years, is being presented in a new light this week at the Half Note Club, 296 Prince Street. The innovator is Wes Montgomery, a member of the Montgomery Brothers Quartet, which may well be the most fraternal musical group to reach New York since the arrival of Guy Lombardo and his Royal Canadians (four of whom were Lombardo brothers).

The Huguenot Society of America will hold its annual luncheon at the St. Regis Roof Saturday. This year's guest speaker will be Kenneth E. Hasbrouck, president of the Huguenot Historical Society of New Paltz, N.Y.
Aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange fell a little more than one-half of 1 per cent yesterday as the market went through another confused and confusing session.
BUFFALO, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- A blizzard-led storm system crippled transportation in upstate cities today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller called on the nation today to work toward confederation with other nations and "end the disparity" between the Communist and the Western tactical forces.
On a day more suitable for winter sports, sponsors of a new Long Island golf course spoke of spring and lush fairways yesterday.
Steel wages will go up today, but major steel producers plan no immediate increase in prices.
VINELAND, N.J., Dec. 1 -- The Training School at Vineland announced today that it had made formal application to acquire Ellis Island for an international diagnostic center for mental retardation.
A letter mailed from the United States outpost at the South Pole last Saturday afternoon reached The New York Times at 10 A.M. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The supplemental airlines protested to the Defense Department today over the reported use of foreign airlines to fly the families of American service men home from Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla, Nov. 30 -- The shrinkage in foreign financing in the United States market in 1959 and 1960 is not likely to continue for the long run, the Investment Bankers Association was told at a session of its annual convention here today.
The case of seven Negro children who are seeking admission to a predominantly white school in New Rochelle was put off yesterday until Dec. 12 in Federal Court here.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- On his eightieth birthday today, a quiet, rather saintly professor emerged into the limelight of newspaper acclaim as an "apostle of equality," "puritan militant" and "passionate prophet."
The Norfolk and Western Railway, one of the most profitable in its field, took steps yesterday to become one of the largest and the most profitable.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -- There was no stampede of Hollywood producers today breathing defiance of the Roman Catholic Bishops committee's criticism of the movies' moral tone. But neither was there any chorus of "mea culpa."

June Havoc is the third star to be recruited for the overseas troupe, designated as the Theatre Guild American Repertory Company, which Lawrence Langner, president of the Guild's Foundation, is forming. She will join Helen Hayes and Leif Erickson.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Gov. William G. Stratton said today that the State Electoral Board, which he heads, might withhold certification of Illinois' twentyseven electoral votes for President-elect John F. Kennedy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins scored twice in the last six minutes tonight and tied the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game.

ASK any woman what electronics means to her and the conversation will stop. She might possibly mumble something about IBM computers or messages to the moon before changing the subject. But on Dec. 9 her vocabulary may expand to an astonishing degree.
Futures prices for commodities moved generally lower again in dull trading yesterday on markets here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- A representative of the Soviet bloc told the General Assembly today that "areas leased in foreign lands" should be considered as colonies and should be given the right to independence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff are considering plans to modify the United States' military strategy that governs the retaliatory use of long-range nuclear-armed bombers and missiles.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 30 -- Moise Tshombe, President of Secessionist Katanga Province, strongly restated today his opposition to any central Government of the Congo.
A ranking Industrialist endorsed last night a labor plea for the establishment of joint machinery to foster economic growth and promote more harmonious union-management relations.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 -- Following is the text of a ruling handed down today by a three-judge Federal Court in the New Orleans school desegration case:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Peter Jan Monge, a high school student whose letter was published on Nov. 19, bases certain arguments against the reform movement in the Democratic party upon substantial misstatements of fact.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company declared a dividend of 25 cents a share today and announced that its salaried officers and supervisory personnel would go back on full pay on Jan. 1.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
An intensified investigation of Greenwich Village cabarets that employ homosexuals was promised yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner Edward McCabe.
City Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson said yesterday he would like to "crack down" on child care agencies that gave only "token compliance" to anti-discrimination laws in accepting children.

United Press International named its 1960 all-American college football team yesterday. The players were chosen by the ballots of a record number of 402 sports writers and broadcasters from all parts of the country.

A leading iron ore company has warned its employes that it expects 1961 to be a dismal year for the steel industry and that company operations will have to be sharply curtailed as a result. It blamed the cutback also on increased competition from foreign ores.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Any move to put off a United Nations decision on Algeria will be opposed by Asian and African countries, an Algerian spokesman declared yesterday.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Stockholders today approved the sale of Allied Laboratories, Inc., of Kansas City, Mo., to the Dow Chemical Company on Dec. 30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The State Department plans to seek appointment of seven United States Ambassadors, to new African nations as soon as President-elect John F. Kennedy names his Secretary of State.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 30 -- The motions o two opposition parties to debate infringement by censorship on freedom of expression in Israel were defeated in the Knesset (Parliament) today.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- A double-header space rocket developed a malfunction and was destroyed in flight today, frustrating, a United States bid to put a pair of satellites into orbit around the earth.
OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Nov. 30 -- Representatives of western Fire Island resorts met last night to decide how to oppose a threat of automobiles on this island.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- An Arab spokesman described the Palestine refugee problem today as "the direct outcome of the lacK of statesmanship on the part of the United States."
A burglary case led the police yesterday to a man accused of having practiced dentistry profitably for three years at cut rates while licensed only as a Swedish masseur.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Dennis Ralston and Chuck McKinley today appeared to be the best United States doubles hopes for the Davis Cup after Italy and Australia jarred American optimism in the Victorian tennis championships.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- The United States announced today that it made a $20,000,000 cash advance to the United Nations Saturday.
A rank-and-file group in Local 807, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, undertook yesterday to enjoin an election for local officials scheduled for Sunday.
GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- The East-West negotiations on a treaty to end tests of nuclear weapons are expected to recess soon until after the inauguration of President-elect John F. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy scheduled conferences tomorrow with four men who have figured prominently in speculation about his Cabinet.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 30 -- The Government announced today it had crushed a pre-dawn revolutionary attempt by Peronists.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 30 (AP) -- State Treasurer John A. Kervick disclosed today that New Jersey's four race tracks handled more than $291.5 million in bets during the 1960 season.
Genesco, Inc., achieved record sales of $321,191,149 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 while earnings of $8,207,420 were the second highest in the company's history, the report disclosed yesterday.

One of the world's rarities, a "white" tigress arrived in the city yesterday en route to Washington. The animal, actually a sort of tattletale gray but having blackish stripes, was billed as the first of her type to arrive in this hemisphere alive.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Holy Cross College, whose invitation to the proposed Gotham Bowl football game in New York was rescinded last night as the players prepared to vote on it, turned down a new invitation offered late today.
The Police Department is preparing to crack down on gambling, prostitution and liquor violations during the coming holiday season.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 30 -- Fighting was reported today to have broken out between forces of the neutralist Laotian Government and the Right-Wing opposition headed by Gen. Phoumi Nosavan.
A permanent state conservation center at the New York World's Fair was recommended yesterday by the executive committee of the fair corporation.
THE National Board of Fire Underwriters gives the following safety suggestions for the use and enjoyment of Christmas trees:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The executive council of the building and construction unions authorized its president today to review wartime no-strike agreements as a first step toward ending stoppages at missile bases.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Industrials rallied further on the stock market here today. Prices were marked down at the opening as a precaution following the publication of an economic review which said that it we increasingly clear that Britain's economy was moving into a difficult period.

TRENTON, Nov. 30. -- Chief Justice Josepn Weintraub of the State Supreme Court and Gov. Robert B. Meyner warned New Jersey's municipal magistrates today to stop fixing traffic tickets and crack down more severely on scofflaws.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Tunisia will join leaders of the African members of the French Community for a four-day parley on the Congo and other African problems.
The Federal Maritime Board moved yesterday to prevent the disintegration of the steamship conference system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Serious crime in the United States increased 11 per cent over last year's figures for the first nine months of this year.
Park Commissioner Newbold Morris said last night that he would institute rigid controls today over the consumption of food by uninvited guests at Gracie Mansion.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics posted their ninth straight victory by trouncing the Detroit Pistons, 125-110, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

The Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union will conduct a ten-meet indoor track and field season beginning Saturday, Dec. 3. Harold Bogrow, the men's track are field chairman of the organization, said yesterday that the season would run through Jan. 21.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- England, placid, prosperous and powerful, paid little attention when, on Nov. 30, 1874, a son was born to Jennie, the young American wife of Lord Randolph Churchill, third son of the Duke of Marlborough.

Cranberry Sauce of the Elmendorf interests won the $30,050 Queens County Handicap that marked the final day of the New York State racing season yesterday. A crowd of 30,176 investors turned out at Aqueduct for the valedictory, which was a fitting enough one for some longshot players, inasmuch as Cranberry Sauce returned $43.70 for 2 straight.

With the reported blessing of Governor Rockefeller, the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions will consider revision of the Condon-Wadlin Law forbidding and penalizing strikes by governmental employes in New York State. Assemblyman John L. Ostrander, chairman, has called a public hearing for Dec. 21 in New York City to get the views of municipal employe groups and others.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson has appealed personally to Henry Ford 2d to consider the United States' gold-dollar drain before carrying out plans to buy full ownership of Ford's British subsidiary.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- The Handley-Page Aircraft Company said today it was negotiating with a United States concern on "many matters" but denied that these included the sale of the company to American interests.

HAVANA, Nov. 30 -- Maj. Manuel Fajardo, chief of operations against the anti-Castro rebels in the Escambray Mountains of central Cuba, was killed early today in a gun battle. Three militiamen were wounded.

The Old Glory harness horse sales completed a three-day stand at Madison Square Garden yesterday, highlighted by the sale of Mr. Budlong, a 4-year-old pacer, for $47,000 and Darn Valley, a 3-year-old trotter for $37,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The official 1960 population of New York City is 7,781,984, the Census Bureau reported today.

The Florida Development Commission sold $14,500,000 of Hillsborough County road revenue bonds, due from 1964 to 1990, at competitive bidding yesterday. An investment banking group headed jointly by Smith, Barney Co. and Blyth Co., Inc., bid 100.1018 for the bonds, with 6, 4 and 4.20 per cent coupons, setting a net interest cost to the borrower of 4.2182 per cent.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 30 -- An agreement to centralize the metropolitan wholesale meat industry in Jersey City is being completed by the New Jersey Public Market Commission, and the Wholesale Meat Terminal Operating Corporation of New York.
Those who still fret and fume over the possibility that electronic music might become the music of the future should have been at Caspary Auditorium last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy endorsed today plans for early Congressional approval of minimum wage and aid-to-education bills.

A Congressional investigation heard testimony yesterday that Port of New York Authority officials had received $4,148.71 in entertainment and gifts from the agency's insurance brokerage concern in twenty-one months.
An indoor winter wonderland opened at the Coliseum yesterday day with colorful displays of outdoor equipment for every winter sports enthusiast -- even those who think they already have everything.

Four employes of the city's Department of Real Estate were suspended yesterday while a hearing by the State Investigation Commission into alleged irregularities involving them went into its second day.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 30 -- The Superintendent of Schools here today ruled out elaborate Christmas pageants and parties as a "waste of time, effort and money."

Ships of Peace The ship Baltika which arrived at an East River dock some months ago in a great surge of peace propaganda, was finally utilized to haul back to the Communist heartland glittering fruits of capitalism's best industrial efforts in the form of sleek cars refrigerators, television sets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The United States charged today that a Cuban Army officer "intentionally and in cold blood" shot and seriously wounded an employe of the United States Embassy outside a Havana night club eleven days ago.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 30 -- Modern living in high-income suburbs has created special problems for the elderly, persons, speakers said today at a Westchester County forum on the aging.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Treasury published today its rules for reporting the finances of foreign subsidiaries of American companies, substantially liberalized in comparison with the rules it proposed last month.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 30 -- The Pacific Coast League took a 2,400-mile stride westward tonight when it announced the award of a 1961 franchise to Honolulu.

THE first annual Christmas Book Open House will be held at the bookstore at the Bank Street College of Education, 69 Bank Street, next Tuesday. The shop specializes in contemporary classics for children.
YESTERDAY (Nov. 30, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued debate on question of colonialism.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like to take issue with your editorial of Nov. 22 concerning the Japanese elections.

Richard Rodgers has received a proposal but does not know what to do about it. The composer has been invited to appear as host and narrator on "The Gershwin Years," a ninety-minute special television program to be produced by Leland Hayward.
Flotations of new securities, both of bonds and stocks, rose in November from the year-ago levels.
IN the world of cuisine, an electric blender knows no national boundaries. It is equally at home with a Spanish gazpacho, a French creme du Barry or German potato pancakes.

THE President played golf somberly that day and later asked for a declaration of war. The President was Woodrow Wilson; the day April 2, 1917; the conflict was World War I, excellently passed in review by Pierce G. Fredericks in "The Great Adventure."*

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 23:
BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- The eyes and ears of jet-age pilots are deluged with so much flight data that they sometimes cannot absorb it all.

Last August, it was reported that Jason Robards Jr., Hume Cronyn and John Gielgud had endorsed the potentialities of "Big Fish, Little Fish." They are all set now. Mr. Robards and Mr. Cronyn are to be costarred as a publisher and art teacher, respectively, in Hugh Wheeler's new play, to be staged by Mr. Gielgud.
A DIAMOND anniversary was celebrated last night in Carnegie Hall. The Boston Symphony Orchestra opened its seventy-fifth New York season there last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower entertained Vice President Nixon and other Cabinet officials and friends at dinner tonight.
"ALL THE WAY HOME" is a simple and searching play about commonplace things like love and death and the need to go on living.

Undeterred by previous defeats of their effort to rule or ruin the United Nations, the Soviets have now launched new attacks on this world organization, on Secretary General Hammarskjold and on the U.N. force in the Congo.

The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan found itself yesterday in the unusual position of having charged two men with the same murder. The defendants are brothers and both, according to the police, have confessed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- First notices today of intention to deliver on December contracts attracted more than the usual amount of interest in grain futures trading. They were the major considerations in the pits and sparked a heavy volume of dealings.
The prosecution rested its case yesterday in the retrial of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan on charges of conflict of interest and conspiracy to obstruct justice.

ANOTHER attempt will be made in January to cut the deer herd in Westchester County, the Conservation Department has announced. Hunters who have not killed a buck elsewhere in the State will be permitted a couple of short seasons, aggregating ten days, to try for a deer of either sex in Westchester.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 -- A three-judge Federal court refused today to suspend school desegregation here and struck down state laws designed to thwart the process.
The ever-mounting costs of security in the atomic age were responsible for two widely different defense decisions in the last two weeks.

Six libel actions seeking a total of $7,250,000 were started in State Supreme Court here yesterday by Elizabeth Taylor, the actress, and her husband, Eddie Fisher, the singer, against the publishers and editors of various motion picture "fan" magazines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Secretary of the Treasury Anderson, whose abilities that include tactical skill are justly rated by the President to be very great indeed, is ending his brilliant Government career with an experience common to public servants on whom unpopular tasks devolve.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov 30 -- Foreign Minister Koca Popovic left for Rome today on an official visit that will cap the increasingly friendly relations that have developed with Italy during the last six years.
The New York Giants and Charlie Conerly will be ready for some action when the Dallas Cowboys visit Yankee Stadium Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Venezuela accused the Dominican Republic tonight of preparing an attack against the Government of President Romulo Betancourt.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., disclosed, yesterday that earnings this year would decline about 5 to 8 per cent a common share. Last year, the world's biggest chemical company cleared $8,92 a share. The dip would mean that du Pont this year would clear $8.20 to $8.54 a share.
ROME, Dec. 1 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury arrived here today for a "courtesy visit" with Pope John XXIII.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Nov. 27 and certain of your news dispatches were sharply critical of Secretary Anderson's recent mission to Germany. You implied that our balance of payments problem does not require action of the type requested by Secretary Anderson and indeed that the problem can be solved by relatively modest and simple measures.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- African and Asian states served notice today that they would not be bound by the big powers' "gentlemen's agreement" on how the seats of the Security Council are to be distributed.
TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Dec. 1 (AP) -- The captain's wife was taken off a storm - battered, stranded Liberian freighter today, while he and his twelveman crew were left aboard.
When Andrew Heath made his debut here three years ago, he boldly opened his program with Elliott Carter's Piano Sonato, a no-nonsense contemporary work.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Five African members proposed today that the General Assembly request all states "to consider and respect the African Continent as a denuclearized neutral zone."

President-elect Kennedy's announced selection of Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut as his Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare will be greeted with general approval. It was no surprise to learn that Mr. Ribicoff was entering the Cabinet; the only question was which post he would be given. Mr. Kennedy's choice is a sound one.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 30 -- The United States and Chile have reached substantial agreement on how to apply President Eisenhower's $20,000,000 grant for earthquake repairs in southern Chile. However, serious disagreement has developed over the best use to be made of a $100,000,000 emergency loan appropriated by Congress "for the reconstruction and rehabilitation of Chile" after last May's earthquakes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
A proposal that would give city teachers with specialized training $1,000 extra a year was discussed yesterday by top school officials and a special labor committee appointed by Mayor Wagner.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Doc. 1 (UPI) -- George Bayer, a 245-pound former football star, shot a seven-under par 30, 35 -- 65 today for a three-stroke lead after the first round of the $15,000 West Palm Beach open golf tournament.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 1 -- The opening of the final leg of the new $50,000,000 Cross Westchester Expressway was set today by the state for the last week of this month. It extends from white plains to Elmsford.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- A Government spokesman said today that the leader of the Right-Wing Laotian military forces had agreed to join a coalition of all political parties, but later the Rightist forces were reported to have launched a new attack against Government positions.
WHEN Harold L. Humes Jr. was released from the detention pen last week after an altercation with a magistrate, he declared that he was going home to read Thoreau. He quoted, accurately enough.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and George A. Smathers of Florida have been tapped for key leadership roles in the Eighty-seventh Congress.
Special mail, citrus and flower trains will be run by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad in the Christmas season to cut delays in regular commuter trains.

For pleasure-boat families, the Christmas season in these Nineteen Sixties is a far cry from those days when, the present crop of parents and grandparents were young. Then it was a time for choo-choo train toys, dolls, toy soldiers and noisy rub-a-dub drums.
Member banks of the Federal Reserve System operated with a higher level of net free reserves in the week ended on Wednesday than at any time in the last six years.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 29 -- Though the smog-laden wintry fogs have descended on this Communist capital, obscuring the hills of Buda from the plains of Pest, there is a marked improvement in the general atmosphere.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 1 (AP) -- The state's highest court turned down today the $65,000,000 claim of minority stockholders of a banana-hauling railroad against the United Fruit Company, the railroad's major customer.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe, assisting on Detroit's first goal early in the third period, set a National Hockey League scoring record tonight. However, goals by Don McKenney and Charlie Burns later in the period carried the Boston Bruins to a 3-2 victory over the Red Wings.
LOUISVILLE, Dec. 1 -- The minor leagues, still in the dark on what will be in store for them if the majors expand, today offered to help the big fellows.

CHARLES XII, according to the late Frans G. Bengtsson, was a military genius. Bengtsson, according to Eric Linklater, was a literary genius and his biography, "The Sword Does Not Jest: The Heroic Life of Charles XII of Sweden,"* was the justification of his life.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday directed approval of a twelve-year "stair-step" integration plan for Dallas public schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Negotiations on possible West German relief for the United States balance - of - payments problem have been renewed in Bonn.

E.E. Dale Shaffer, president of the Michigan Racing Association, was elected president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations yesterday. Shaffer was chosen for a one-year term to succeed John G. Cella of the Oaklawn Park race track, at the T.R.A. convention at the Hotel Plaza.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- On or about Jan. 20, Connecticut will get its first foreign-born Governor in 277 years. John Noel Dempsey will succeed Abram Ribicoff as the state's top office holder.

Between taking pot shots at the Lambert Trophy selection committee for bracketing Yale with Navy as Eastern champion, Ridge Rifey circulates some interesting items on the Oregon team that Penn State will face in the Liberty Bowl at Philadelphia on Dec. 17.

Earnings of Montgomery Ward Co. for the three and nine months ended with October were about half those of the corresponding periods last year, despite larger sales, the report of the big mail-order concern disclosed yesterday.

A PHOTOGRAPH in the catalogue of Elaine de Kooning's exhibition of semiabstract oils at the Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue, shows her approaching a huge canvas carrying a brush about to deliver it the coup de grace.

The Chrysler Corporation had good news for its stockholders yesterday. Directors voted an extra year-end dividend of 50 cents, payable on Dec. 29 to holders of record of Dec. 12. No extra was distributed last year. The previously declared quarterly dividend of 25 cents will be paid on Dec. 14.
BONN, Germany, Dec 1 -- An official effort has begun here to prepare the West German public for acceptance of the Atlantic Alliance as a key political institution of the future.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Government today prohibited the use of safrol and oil of sassafras as flavorings in foods and beverages -- including root beer and sarsaparilla.

Sales of the May Department Stores Company for the quarter, nine months and year ended on Oct. 31 were well ahead of those for the corresponding periods of the preceding fiscal year, Morton D. May, president, reported yesterday.
Official city sanction for Shakespeare performances in the schools this winter was voted last night by the Board of Estimate in a heated session. The vote was 12 to 10.

With hot rods and racing cars currently in vogue, a new automotive engine kit that allows hobbyists to make a variety of custom engines is now available. The Customizing Auto Engine hobby kit, by Monogram Models, Inc., contains 134 detailed parts with the model scaled to one-eighth the actual size of a Chevrolet 238 cubic-inch displacement standard auto engine.
Baseball's top executives completed the drafting yesterday of amendments to Rule One designed to ease the growing pains of the major leagues.

CANNES has its movie festival, Edinburgh has its music and drama festival, but the most unusual festival of all, perhaps, is held in the French village of Caen, the capital of lower Normandy. Each spring a jury of eighteen judges sits in solemn ceremony to determine the finest tripe dish in the world.

Many socially prominent New Yorkers have taken tickets to the Jan. 10 concert benefit of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue Hospital, according to Mrs. Henry C. Alexander, Mrs. Peter F. Fleischmann and Mrs. William Barclay Harding, the co-chairmen.

THERE was a time when bridge experts thought they were simply more intelligent than nonexperts, but they, were troubled by one aspect of the evidence. Certain nonexperts could make millions of dollars, or create deathless literature and art, or evolve scientific principles on a Nobellian scale, while the bridge experts could not.
Investors in bank stocks, unlike those in many industrial securities, can look back on waning 1960 with satisfaction. A survey made by M.A. Shapiro Co., Inc., dealer in bank stocks, shows this:
Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, said yesterday he hoped President elect John F. Kennedy's Administration would release more Government news to the public than had been done.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Republican party intensified its campaign today to show vote fraud in the election of Senator Kennedy.
A woman whose husband was killed in 1958 in a head-on collision between a car he was driving and one she was operating settled a $350,000 damage suit in Federal Court yesterday for $22,000.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Prime Minister Macmillan denied today an assertion in a newspaper article that he had advocated the merger of the United States and Britain.

Four composers who have been scholarship winners at the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood, Mass., in past summers, sponsored a program in Judson Hall last night for the performance of their works. It was a concert that did credit to each composer.
A MAJOR assault will begin tomorrow on the great striped bass in the surf of the Outer Banks of North Carolina, which nobody has been able to catch on hook and line.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -- George A. Newton, the St. Louis investment banker who will carry the top credentials of the stock and bond distribution business over the next year, is a lawyer turned financier. And, in the making, the lawyer was a University of Colorado backfield star who was a formidable name in the football competition of the Western Conferences of thirty years ago.
BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Welfare Commissioner Mary Evelyn Parker said today Louisiana had agreed to two major Federal demands expected to settle the dispute over the needy children program.
The American Motors Corporation raised its quarterly dividend yesterday for the second time this year despite a reduction of 19.7 per cent in profits for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The rules of the political trade do not require a party politician to support the leadership of another indefinitely, even when that other has been the Presidential nominee. The trade rule goes no further than the requirement of active assistance to the party candidate, in the campaign by politicians who expect the same assistance in campaigns of their own.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A combination of the Thanksgiving holiday, seasonal declines and a general business slowdown resulted in sharp decreases in rail and freight loadings last week, both industries reported.

William B. Bergen, president of the Martin Company, said yesterday he expected this country's expenditures for space activities to soar to $12,000,000,000 to $15,000,000,000 a year over the next decade. In the fiscal year to July 1, 1961, expenditures of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration are budgeted for $325,000,000, compared with $145,000,000 in fiscal 1960.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 1 -- The State Attorney General's investigation of Suffolk County affairs, due to end this month for lack of funds after five years, may be turned over to the State Investigation Commission.
City Administrator Lyle C. Fitch is expected to report soon on a long-discussed plan to centralize inspection agencies to prevent scandal.

Washington, Dec. 1 -- Following is a transcript of a new conference by President - elect John F. Kennedy and Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut and the texts of statements by Senator Kennedy and Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 1 -- Venezuelan workers ignored today a Leftist call for a general strike.
Exploration and economic development of space without Government contracts is planned by the General Electric Company, Ralph J. Cordiner declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Nov. 26 were 2 per cent below the level of a year earlier. Only the Boston district, up 4 per cent, showed a gain.

HAVANA, Dec. 1 -- Fragments of a satellite launching rocket fired from Cape Canaveral, Fla., fell on the north coast of Oriente Province, yesterday afternoon and touched off a renewed cry of "Yankee aggression" from the Castro regime.
Futures prices for commodities moved generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges.

Representative Emanuel Celler was quoted yesterday as having threatened to investigate the Port of New York Authority unless one of his clients was permitted to bid on an authority concession. Mr. Celler flatly denied the charge.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Export sales of American goods rose again in October, the Department of Commerce reported today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley linked Illinois Republicans to Southern Democratic foes of President-elect John F. Kennedy today.
Stocks declined yesterday for he fourth successive session but were looking strong and bouncy at the close.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack rested his defense yesterday in his retrial on charges of conflict of interest and conspiracy to obstruct justice. He did not take the witness stand.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 -- Mexican sugar growers expressed disappointment today at the decision of the International Sugar Conference to reduce basic, export sugar quota's by 15 per cent in 1961. Mexico had hoped to have its 1960 quota of 75,000 tons increased considerably, as it plans to increase its sugar output by some 50,000 to 1,550,000 tons in 1961.

Connecticut has an unusual Democratic political problem: an embarrassment of riches. With a population of 2,510,265 and eight electoral votes, it is a small state. Yet it has no less than five men of Cabinet stature, all of whom are being urged on President-elect John F. Kennedy for consideration in making up the new Democratic national administration.
MEYRIN, Switzerland, Dec. 1 -- Western Europe completed here today a first move toward a cooperative ventur into outer space.

The University of Pittsburgh announced last night that a team of its biochemists had synthesized a substance identical, biologically, to the hormone ACTH, which stimulates the body to produce cortisone.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy selected Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut today as his Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. It was the first Cabinet appointment for the forthcoming Administration.
TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- Middlesex County has more industrial plants than any other in the state and 78 per cent of the available jobs in the county are filled by its residents.
Frigid winds charged through Yankee Stadium yesterday, adding a note of urgency to the morning workout of the New York Football Giants.
Proposals aimed at keeping the wholesale meat industry from moving to New Jersey were announced at City Hall yesterday by Warren Moscow executive assistant to Mayor Wagner.

A plot of vacant land 275 by 250 feet at the southeast corner of Boston Road and Hoe Avenue, the Bronx, has been bought by investment interests which were represented by Nathaniel D. Gribin. The property is near East 174th Street and Southern Boulevard and is assessed at $51,000.
The Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday an increase in earnings for the quarter ended on Oct. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Senator Henry M, Jackson said today he would resign as chairman of the Democratic National Committee when President-elect John F. Kennedy was "firmly installed in the White House."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The current U.N. debate on the granting of independence to colonial countries and people is being followed with great interest all over the world.
YESTERDAY (Dec. 1, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued debate on colonialism.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 -- Dr. I.I. Rabi, Columbia University Nobel laureate in physics, criticized the American system of higher education here today for "a general process of spoon-feeding."
The State of California plans to offer at competitive bidding $95,000,000 of school building aid bonds next Jan. 11, Bert A. Betts, state treasurer, announced yesterday.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased their borrowings from the Federal Reserve Banks by $14,000,000 to a daily average of $113,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
THE wind may suddenly assume a lion's roar, but it cannot scare a lamb from the New York scene. Right now is a good time to buy lamb, for supplies are high and prices relatively low.

The Houston Corporation elected a new president yesterday, deferred and revised outstanding loans and announced expansion plans. All measures were designed to put on a profitable basis the pipeline network which supplies Florida with natural gas.
A series of filmed documentaries made by the British Broadcasting Corporation, including one on socialized medicine, will be televised here by station WNTA-TV (Channel 13).

There have been various kinds of "interposition" in the row over school desegregation in Louisiana. There has been "interposition" by mobs who have threatened and insulted school children and their parents -- including at least one white child and her white parents. There has been "interposition" by adolescents in calendar years, or in intellect, who sneered at and reviled ministers of the Gospel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- Evidently placing little faith in Santa Claus, Jerry Lewis has concocted for himself a $500,000 Christmas present, and was manipulating today with the gusto of a parent with an electric train.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 1 -- The Congo severed relations today with the United Arab Republic.

Although it received at least two completely favorable notices and respectful approval in part from the rest of the critical fraternity, "All the Way Home," Tad Mosel's dramatization of James Agee's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, "A Death in the Family," will end its run at the Belasco after tomorrow night's performance, the fifth.
MASSENA, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- A last-minute policy change is keeping the St. Lawrence Seaway open until midnight tomorrow.

Armour Armour Co. lifted its dividend rate on the common stock yesterday with the declaration of 35 cents a share for payment Jan. 15 to holders of record of Dec. 19. In previous quarters shareholders received 30 cents a share.

MONTREAL, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored two third-period power-play goals after almost dissipating a three-goal lead and went on to rout the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 -- 3, tonight in a National Hockey League game enlivened by a ten-man brawl.
The Port of New York Authority conceded yesterday that it formerly had split up its insurance business for "patronage."

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Fairleigh Dickinson University, which started as a two-year junior college in 1942, announced today that it would help to establish an independent junior college to open for the 1961-62 academic year.

Charles Van Doren pleaded not guilty yesterday to a charge of perjury after his lawyer and Chief Special Sessions Justice John M. Murtagh had clashed over the question of Mr. Van Doren's entering a plea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Weather Bureau placed into operation today an electronic "weathei plotter" that is able to draw hemispheric weather maps faster, more accurately and cheaper than human hands can.
Cold weather enabled snowmaking machines to swing into action for the first time this season in the Catskills, Berkshires and Poconos.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Prices of most industrial shares drifted lower by pennies in the stock market here today, although there were a few firm spots.

WlLLIAM SHAKESPEARE, a fellow who never quite qualified for membership in the Baseball Writers Association, dismissed the entire subject by airily asking, "What's in a name?" He thought he proved his point when he added that a rose by any other name would smell as sweet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A leading critic of the Federal regulatory agencies, Louis J. Hector, proposed today that Congress give President-elect John F. Kennedy broad authority to reorganize them.
Automobile production in the nation last month fell slightly from the October level but was sharply higher than that of November, 1959.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec 1 (UPI) -- Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, and Earl Such holz of St. Louis won their semi-final matches in the Victorian tennis championships today and set up the first all-American final in the eighty-year history of the tournament.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- 1 Profit takers stayed on the job in the grain futures pits today and whittled wheat, corn and soybean prices down slightly. Oats and rye recovered some of their broad losses of yesterday.
The market for Treasury securities was strong yesterday in active trading.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Senator Walter J. Mahoney gave his views about reducing state income taxes today, and the Republican party found itself with a third policy on the subject.
One of the nation's outstanding private art collections, which includes works by Rembrandt, Manet, Corot, Goya and Degas, has been left to a fund here.

An extra shopping day in November helped the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area to lift sales 2 per cent above the 1959 level, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -- Within two years, equipment permitting automatic, no-hands landing of airplanes will be available for use by private industry, Lieut. Gen. Elwood R. Quesada (U.S.A., Ret.), administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, declared here today.
The City Investigation Commission and the State Investigation Commission took time out from investigating yesterday to argue about a missing witness.
Mayor Wagner has submitted to Governor Rockefeller a city fiscal program calling for $260,492,000 in increased state aid and additional taxing power for the city fiscal year starting next July 1.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 1 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones, Republican of Bergen County, challenged Gov. Robert B. Meyner and the Legalized Games of Chance Control Commission today to submit facts to support their attack on a Senate committee headed by him.
The American Telephone Telegrmaph Company announced yesterday that it was working on a plan for a flat monthly rate for unlimited long-distance calls by business users.

THE pomp and circumstance of political life mean little to Abraham Alexander Ribicoff. Since his election as Governor in 1955, he has conducted Connecticut's affairs with simplicity. He has no press secretary and issues no press releases.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- A balance sheet of dead and wounded in five years of terrorist attacks in France attributed to Algerian nationalists -- 2,998 killed and 7,287 wounded -- was published today by the French News Agency on the basis of semiofficial figures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Clark Clifford, liaison man for President-elect John F. Kennedy, held his fifth post-election meeting today with Wilton B. Persons, assistant to President Eisenhower, on the transition of Administrations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Pentagon withdrew today the opportunity enjoyed by overseas military personnel to buy Scotch, Canadian, French and other foreign liquors at service-operated stores, usually at taxfree prices.
PEPPERELL, Mass., Dec. 1 -- A sturdy building beneath a meadowed-hillside in this rural town became today an official storage center for member banks of the Boston Clearing House Association.

New trans-Pacific air fares went into effect yesterday, following their approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board. The new fares, which will be effective through March 31, 1963, were adopted by the International Air Transport Association conference at Cannes, France, last September and October.

The forces and personalities in Africa are discussed in a in Africa are discusseed in a new book by Gwendolin Carter, Professor of Government at Smith College. To be called "Independence for Africa," it will be issued by Praeger on Dec. 21 in hardbound and paperback editions.
IN "Little Moon of Alban," which came to the Longacre Theatre last night, James Costigan makes an eloquent plea for the healing power of faith and forgiveness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Admittedly embarrassed and concerned, Defense Department officials conceded today that parts of a satellite launching rocket, destroyed yesterday over the Atlantic, probably had fallen on eastern Cuba.
Two independent foreign-flag steamship lines are rebutting shipping conference charges of unfair rate-cutting practices in the trade from Japan to the West Coast of the United States.

New York University's basketball team, which reached the semi-final round of the National Collegiate championships last year, opened the 1960-61 campaign last night with a 105-54 victory over a touring University of Toronto squad.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) --Britain's ninety-two major soccer clubs were asked today to consider giving longer contracts and bigger bonuses in a move head off the threatened players strike.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Union announced today the launching into orbit of a second five-ton space ship carrying two dogs and other animals and insects.
