It was assumed that an attempt would be made to bring the ship and its passengers safely back to earth in the same way as the first Soviet animal-bearing space ship was retrieved last Aug. 19.
A drive to remove Carmine G. De Sapio as leader of Tammany Hall appeared yesterday to be moving toward a showdown.
WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 1 -- An exhibition of thirty-one paintings and sculptures from the Museum of Modern Art will be on view at the Country Art Gallery here for five weeks starting Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller declined today to join in President Eisenhower's designation of Vice President Nixon as "the head of the Republican party for the next four years."

A Doctrine disdained In the complicated etiquette of international diplomacy there is a long-standing tradition that the most effective answer to an unwelcome message is complete and contemptuous silence.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- A Latin-American representative proposed today that the United Nations take a closer look at the colonial system in the modern world before demanding its immediate and unconditional abolition.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1 -- Angry white women attacked by-standers today as signs of a break appeared in a boycott of the city's two desegregated schools.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Dec. 1 -- "Tell me what you do and how much you used to earn and I will tell you whether you are for or against this revolution," a Santiago student remarked.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- The Communist summit conference here has ended with the issuance of a communique stating that the participants Had "familiarized themselves with each other's views and positions."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1(AP) -- The New York Knicks repulsed a second-half rally and broke the Boston Celtics' nine game winning streak tonight with a 116-111 victory in a National Basketball Association game at Convention Hall.

ICE skaters stand on the fashion sidelines. Almost all of the design, excitement in skater sports is directed toward the ski slopes. The woman who goes in search of something new and dashing to wear at an ice rink is often turned away by the snow shop proprietor or advised to visit his nearest competitor.
Plans to hold the Gotham Bowl game at Yankee Stadium this year were abandoned yesterday.

A military uprising in a country as important as Argentina cannot be dismissed as inconsequential, especially when it is a widespread plot involving a number of places. At the same time it is much more important to note that the late revolt was quickly suppressed and that the great majority of the armed forces and their top officers remained loyal to the constitutional government of President Frondizi.

Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division, First Department, called upon the organized bar last night to concern itself far more seriously with the inferior courts, where the general public gets its "image of the law in action."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 7 points (10 to 35 cents a bale) yesterday, except far July, which was nominally 5 points off.

The block in Jackson Heights, Queens, bounded by Leverich and Sixty-ninth Streets, Thirtyfifth Road and Thirty-fifth Avenue, with the exception of a small parcel at Leverich Street and Thirty-fifth Road, has been purchased by Arthur G. Cohen, lawyer and real estate investor.
Gracie Mansion's controversial back-stairs hospitality collapsed yesterday when Mayor Wagner's food bill was ordered held to $14 a day.

Edwin Cox, chairman of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., had some Interesting observations to make about advertisers and advertising in a speech he made this week. He spoke before, the meeting in Detroit of the East Central Region of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Lynn A. Townsend has been elected administrative vice president of the Chrysler Corporation, it was announced here today.
Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson ruled yesterday that block booking practices in selling motion pictures to television outlets violated a section of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
The Air Force announced yesterday a "priceless scientific dividend" on the flight of the Discoverer XVII satellite capsule last month.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reference is made to your editorial of Nov. 24 and more particularly to that portion which states that the Democratic party offers candidates of "generally inferior quality for public office in New York City."
FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 2 (AP) -- German sports fans are pondering big placards posted around town today announcing in big letters, "Amerikanisches fussballspiel."

A key witness who told the State Investigation Commission here Wednesday that he had paid kickbacks to four employes of the city's Real Estate Department is driving to Miami. His move has apparently stalemated a city inquiry into the department.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- All but one of the familiar smells are back in autumnal Paris. There is the fragrance of dead leaves, of dank seaweed in the oyster stalls, and of sweet nougat and sugared nuts in the booths of itinerant venders. And there is that oddly agreeable odor of mist and coal smoke.
Kuwait had awarded a large oil exploration concession area in the Persian Gulf to the Royal Dutch-Shell Group for a bonus of $84,000,000, it was disclosed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A universal golf club, if it becomes popular, will threaten the caddying profession. A player can easily carry his own -- a single club and a small wrench.
Joe Bellino of Navy and Pervis Atkins of New Mexico State provide the devastating halfback punches on The Associated Press 1960 all-America football team, which boasts a line averaging 226 pounds.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold asked President Joseph Kasavubu today to insure that "due process of law" was followed in the Congo regime's treatment of former Premier Patrice Lumumba.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- After breakfast with Vice President Nixon, Governor Rockefeller said today that the "closest cooperation" was developing between them to make the Republican party "a constructive, positive force" instead of "a negative force."

FORTUNATELY for the collector, the supply of old master drawings of quality appears to be almost inexhaustible. Two attractive groups are now on view -- Baroque and Rococo Theatre Designs at the Seiferheld Gallery, 158 East Sixty-fourth Street and a more miscellaneous selection at Durlacher's, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

ROME, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a Vatican communique issued today on the meeting of Pope John XXIII and the Archbishop of Canterbury and of a statement issued on behalf of the Archbishop:
With ocean-going ships moving into or out of New York Harbor every forty minutes last month, New York continued to be the busiest port in the nation.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 2 -- The Yankees finally got around to talking about ballplayers instead of franchises today.

When the postponed elections to the United Nations Security Council take place next week there will be a new test of the rapidly growing weight of the Afro-Asian group. This bloc now constitutes just under a mathematical 50 per cent of the total membership, and it quite understandably is demanding a larger voice in the U.N.

The Mosler Safe Company has expanded its office equipment business through the purchase of more than 50 per cent of the shares of the Harbor Metal Products Corporation and the Harbor Sales Corporation of Belmont, Calif.

Kenrich Petrochemicals, Inc. Stockholders of the Kenrich Petrochemicals Corporation at a special meeting on Dec. 27 will vote on the company's acquisition of the Laribee Wire and Equipment Corporation in exchange for 700,000 shares of Kenrich's Class A stock.

Acting only four days after it was convened, the special Queens grand jury investigating tow-truck operations indicted eight men yesterday on charges ranging from conspiracy to attempted extortion and bribery.
OMAHA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Defense Secretary Thomas S. Gates Jr., fresh from a conference with top admirals and generals, counseled today against new changes now in United States defense structure.
The New York Shipbuilding Corporation, may have to lay off 3,000 men in February unless new construction contracts are obtained, a spokesman at the shipyard in Camden, N.J., said yesterday.

Delaware sold $3,299,000 of school and capital improvement bonds due from 1961 to 1980 at competitive bidding yesterday. The bonds were awarded to an investment banking group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. on a bid of 100.539 with a 3 per cent coupon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "The New College Plan," mentioned in The Times of Nov. 29 as one of the prototypes of the college proposed for Ellis Island, was written by a group of four faculty members from the sponsoring colleges, including Donald Sheehan of Smith, Stuart Stoke of Mount Holyoke and Shannon McCune (chairman) of the University of Massachusetts.
A MAN's home may be his castle but it does not always look like one. However in the case of Fritz Ziegler, there can be no doubt about it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today a merger of three United States affiliates of the Canadian Pacific Railway, which will operate in the future as a unified corporation to be known as the Soo Line Railroad Company.
IN Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, a violinist wearing a sport shirt, sweater and slacks made an impressive New York debut. He is Regis Pasquier, and he has just turned 15.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- A special state committee today called for a major expansion of libraries serving college and university students, researchers and the professions. It estimator the cost at $7,850,000 in state aid.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Navy-dominated Pacific Command will get its first Army chief of staff early next year. Maj. Gen. Verdi B. Barnes will succeed Vice Admiral Herbert D. Riley in Hawaii.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points up to 15 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Industrial share prices rallied after a dull start in the stock market here today, but they still closed with a majority of small net losses. The Financial Times industrial shares index fell 1.3 points to 300.5, for a loss of 3.1 points on the week.

ALTHOUGH the national tournament played here Nov. 19-27 was not the biggest ever, the championship events limited to high-ranking players drew far bigger entries than they had at any tournament before, including the statistically bigger tournament at Los Angeles.
ROME, Dec. 2 -- The Most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, became today the first head of the Anglican Church to call upon a Pope in Rome.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United States moved today to aid refugees from what it called the "Communist-controlled" regime of Premier Fidel Castro in Cuba.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2 -- It was reliably reported today that the Foreign Ministry had protested to Spain on the ground that she had allowed the former Argentine dictator, Juan D. Peron, to break the rules of political exile.
NATICK, Mass., Dec. 2 -- Despite several decades of research, scientists still do no know whether the human body adjusts to cold.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The British attitude toward the United States proposals on a nuclear force for NATO, the main outline of which are fairly well known, is complex.

THE homemaker who avoids entertaining at this busy time of the year but would like to make a small contribution to her friends' parties might consider Gimbels' festive holiday coasters. Made of greer rubberized plastic, they come wreathed in holly leaves complete with tiny red berries.
In its valuable series of resuscitations, the American Opera Society offered one that was more than usually rewarding when it produced Handel's "Hercules" at Town Hall last night.
William Z. Foster, chairman emeritus of the Communist party in this country, received permission in Federal Court yesterday to go to the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia for medical treatment.

New York and Chicago commercial banks bought in volume Treasury securities with a year or less to run yesterday. As a result, Treasury bill prices rose 2 to 6 basis points. Intermediate issues gained up to 8/32 as the buying spread to longer issues.
CAIRO, Dec. 1 -- Tea and television are the preoccupations of Cairo.

More than $219,000,000 of debt securities of utilities and local governments are scheduled for sale in the new capital market next week. The heavy calendar is in marked contrast to the relatively light calendars of the last two weeks.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- France's big conservative Independent party nominally part of the Government majority, virtually rejected today President de Gaulle's Algerian policy and castigated other aspects of his program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Following is the text of President-elect John F. Kennedy's statement today naming David E. Bell of Cambridge, Mass., as his Director of the Bureau of the Budget:

MIAMI, Pec. 2 (AP) -- Eddie Johns and Nick Ryder scored touchdowns for Miami in the fourth quarter tonight as the Hurricanes defeated the Air Force Academy, 23 -- 14, before 29,678 fans in the Orange Bowl. The game was the last of the season for both teams.
"OUR AMERICAN HERITAGE" took a look at Andrew Jackson, the first President to come out of the West, on Chahnel 4 last night.

Nearly all of the three thousand firemen who applied have received permission to take outside jobs under the Fire Department's recently relaxed policy on "moonlighting." Nine thousand men are eligible for such jobs.

Mrs. Marshall F. Dancy and Mrs. Oliver A. Vietor, co-chairmen of a theatre party to be given under the sponsorship of the Volunteer Associates of the New York Botanical Garden, have announced a partial list of subscribers to the event.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- A $1,000,000 boardwalk-area modernization program here is scheduled to be completed by summer.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Iona College's basketball team scored an 87 -- 41 victory over the University of Toronto in O'Connell Memorial Gymnasium tonight.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Judge E. Arnold Forrest today imposed prison sentences on eleven of fourteen boys convicted of rioting after a football game between Norristown and Ridley Township high schools last year.

Sweeping hook shots by Clyde Lovellette and long push shots by Woody Sauldsberry carried the St. Louis Hawks to a 139-133 triumph over the New York Knickerbockers in overtime at Madison Square Garden last night.
United States and Canadian churchgoers support nearly two-thirds of all Protestant missionaries serving in countries other than their own, the Missionary Research Library reported here yesterday.

CHERRY PLAIN, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Mrs. Liza Fosburgh didn't get a shot at a deer today. But she advanced one more shameless step in her long-time claim that she can coax worms from the ground by rubbing an axhead on a driven stake, causing a vibration that sounds like a grunt.

THIS is the peak period for persimmons. The fruit is now about as plentiful as it ever gets in this area, which is not saying too much. Despite its honorable association with this country's early settlers, the persimmon is none too popular in the East. On the West Coast, however, it is another story and it is used to add color and flavor to many a salad in addition to being eaten as is.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy today named 41-year-old David E. Bell as his Budge Director.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Southeastern Conference dominates a twenty-five-man South squad named today for the twelfth annual Senior Bowl football game here Jan. 7.
An experimental project in integration that permits pupils to transfer to schools outside their neighborhoods will be enlarged next fall and will provide transportation for elementary school pupils.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Jules Vaucron, a slightly harassed but prosperous-looking French business man, is beginning to think that he lives on trains. He is a good illustration of what the European Common Market means to the men who make and sell things.

SOUTH POLE, Nov. 30 -- A young Japanese scientist, who spent the just-ended winter at this desolate scientific outpost, believes he has found a connection between hissing radio signals from outer space and the flashing colored "southern lights" of the aurora australis.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 2 -- United States and West German experts have gone to work to sort out some of the possibiliites by which Bonn could help stem the drain on American gold reserves.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The chairman of the Republican National Committee said today that election frauds might become an issue in the campaigns of 1962 and 1964.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The 1961 track and field championships of the National Amateur Athletic Union will be held in New York on June 23 and 24, the A.A.U. announced today at its national convention.
Sea trials for two $12,000,000 freighters for the American Export Lines fleet will be held in the next two weeks, one on the Pacific and one on the Atlantic Coast.

Broad St. Trust The Broad Street Trust Company, Philadelphia, declared a regular quarterly dividend of 60 cents a share payable on March 15 to shareholders of record of March 1. It also said a proposed 5 per cent stock dividend, payable on March 15 to holders of record of Feb. 15, would be voted upon by stockholders at the annual meeting.

The Allied invasion of Normandy will be restaged on a Hollywood scale next summer, when Darryl F. Zanuck begins filming World War II battle scenes on their actual locations for his multi-million-dollar production of "The Longest Day."
YESTERDAY (Dec. 2, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued debate on question of colonialism.
Sooty city firemen rubbed their aching backs and bandaged blistered fingers last night as they finished thirty-six hours of fighting a blaze with shovels.
The Anglican Archbishop of Canterbury remarked in Rome the other day that the "cold war" that had divided the Christian churches in the past was passing.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- There have been times when travelers, passing a house on the edge of Ex-moor, have encountered a stocky figure in old mud-daubed clothes happily hacking at a hedge or grubbing in a ditch.
College basketball (1960-61 edition) will have its debut at Madison Square Garden tonight with a triple-header. The St. John's, Manhattan and New York University quintets are on the bill.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Joe Kuharich, whose Notre Dame football team this year matched the worst record made by the Fighting Irish, received a three-year extension of his coaching contract today.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers' star rookie, Jerry West, scored two baskets in the final thirty seconds as the Lakers rallied for a 120-117 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Sir Leslie Munro told the United Nations today that four years of effort had shown no progress toward easing Soviet occupation of Hungary.
Trading was slow and featureless on the commodities futures markets in New York yesterday.
"THE TASTE OF INFAMY,"* by Charles O. Locke, is a novel showing that crime doesn't pay -- but honesty can be awfully expensive.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- A new method of attempting to sustain a fusion, or thermonuclear, reaction in a spark chamber has been proposed by two distinguished Swedish physicists, Drs. Hannes Alfven and Erik Smars, Both are members of the Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 -- The perennially challenging Sugar Ray Robinson and hard-bitten Gene Fullmer, the defending champion, meet tomorrow night in their third and presumably definitive match for the National.
KENT, Ohio, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Favored Clemson scored a 78-67 victory over Syracuse tonight to open the Midwestern invitation basketball tournament at Kent State University.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The resignation of Donald W. Young, Deputy Motor Vehicle Commissioner, who was reprimanded for his campaign fundraising tactics, was reported today by the State Tax Department.

HANS ROSBAUD started the last of his two weeks with the New York Philharmonic by conducting some very modern pieces on the first half of his concert. Two of them, Schoenberg's Five Pieces for Orchestra (Op. 16) and Webern's Six Pieces for Orchestra (Op. 6), are by way of being classics.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 -- Ten white pupils were rushed past angry demonstrators into classes today as a boycott of one of two desegregated schools here declined in effectiveness.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Claiborne B. Carter's Little Limey, ridden by Freddy Kratz, won the Chinella Purse, the feature race at Pimlico today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- John F. Kennedy stood this morning in the sunlit doorway of his Georgetown home, his breath condensing on the frosty air. He was, as usual, without hat or overcoat.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 2 -- Westchester County today notified all its forty-six towns, cities and villages that they should prepare to follow a good-neighbor policy among themselves beginning Jan. 1.
City College's swimming team won nine of eleven events and defeated Manhattan, 64 -- 27, yesterday at the Beavers' Wingate pool.

Trying Byron, realty operator, has contracted to buy the building containing eighty-two apartments and ten stores at 81 to 93 Featherbed Lane, near Macombs Road, the Bronx. The property, 150 by 100 feet, is assessed at $310,000.

HONG KONG, Dec. 2 -- Political observers here believe that a major point debated at the world Communist summit meeting in Moscow concerned whether militant or peaceful tactics should be adopted by the Commumist parties in non-Communist countries, particularly in Latin America, Africa and Asia.
A churchman who was 4 years old when Lincoln was first elected wag honored yesterday in the Interchurch Center at a luncheon noting his birthday, which is today.

Pierre E. Salinger and Hebert G. Klein, press secretaries to President-elect John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon, respectively, agreed yesterday that the press as a whole had tried to report the Presidential campaign fairly.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 2 -- Patrice Lumumba, his hands tied behind his back, returned here tonight as a prisoner of Col. Joseph D. Mobutu, head of the army regime.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Sponsors of a proposed nation-wide credit rating service for installment-plan buyers are trying to persuade Britons that they are not going in for "snooping."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Senate investigators today tabbed Herman (Hymie the Mink) Wallman, a New York boxing manager, as a key witness at hearings starting Monday on alleged gangster influence on professional boxing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The scheduled airlines of the United States asked the Government today to ease visa requirements for foreign tourists.

Alfred C. Fuller left his home in Nova Scotia when he was 18 years old to make his way in the world and lost his first three jobs. Making and selling brushes was an expedient to which he turned when no one would hire him.

The Kennedy political organization will help settle the dispute over the leadership of Tammany Hall in an effort to strengthen the Democratic party for the Mayoral election next year and the state election in 1962.
Federal mediation efforts to head off a strike of delivery workers against the city's major daily newspapers made "small progress" yesterday, a mediator said.

A former economic assistant to President Eisenhower urged President-elect John F. Kennedy yesterday to pick a Secretary of the Treasury "whose philosophy, character and ability will inspire confidence in the future of the dollar."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 2 -- The resistance of Leftist rebel students crumbled tonight after a silent twelve-hour siege by Government troops who had threatened to rout them by force.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Alternate flurries of buying and selling pushed the grain futures market up and down today but it finished virtually unchanged for all commodities except rye, which rose 1 1/4 cents.
The Board of Estimate adopted a 1961 capital budget of $695,858,848 yesterday. That is $3,792,907 more than was recommended by the City Planning Commission on Nov. 1.
Thirty-eight World War I fears relived their wartime years and served the cause of history here yesterday, watching old films and that conflict turned up by the Air Force Museum.

NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Dec. 2 -- In a tiny new building behind the sprawling main plant of its Merrimack Valley Works, the Western Electric Company began yesterday the full-scale production of synthetic quartz crystals.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Rain forced the postponement of today's matches in the Victorian tennis championship. If the bad weather continues tomorrow the first all-American men's singles final in the eighty-year history of this tournament will be permanently washed out.
Food stocks led a ragged advance of prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. As groups, steels, business machines and building materials also showed appreciable majorities of plus signs.
The 11-month-old great-grandson of the late Secretary of State John Foster Dulles was found dead in bed under an electric blanket yesterday morning.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Sammy Snead defied strong winds and showers today and shot a two-under-par 36, 34 -- 70 for a 138. He took a two-stroke lead in the second round of the $15,000 West Palm Beach open golf tournament.

Moore-McCormack Lines and Lloyd Brasileiro asked the Federal Maritime Board yesterday to dismiss a complaint by the River Plate and Brazil Conference against a controversial revenue pooling agreement proposed by the two lines.

The Chase Manhattan Bank has taken a look at the economy and sees nothing worse, so far, then a "moderate Recline." In its latest survey of business conditions, the bank does note that some important business indicators have moved down since July -- notably, the gross national product, industrial production, housing starts, employment.

In the first change of ownership in fifty years, two five-story store and apartment buildings at 1010-12 Second Avenue, near Fifty-third Street, have been sold by Albert Gommel and Abraham Salansky. The buildings, on a plot 40 by 70 feet, were bought by the Netmar Croporation.
HAVANA, Dec. 2 -- The United States has requested the Cuban Government to return to the United States fragments of the space rocket that fell in Oriente Province Wednesday.
TORONTO, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Toronto Star, Ltd., reported today net earnings of $1,374,578 for its fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.
ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The words "under God" in the Pledge of Allegiance were upheld as constitutional today by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court here.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 2 (AP) -- A new trial of the $500,000 libel suit brought by the Montgomery Police Commissioner, L.B. Sullivan, has been requested in Circuit Court by The New York Times.
The presentation of eight Hungarian-American girls was one of the highlights of the ninth annual Piarist Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
Representative Emanuol Celler, the chairman of a House inquiry, denounced the Port of New York Authority's executive director yesterday for what he termed an "outrageous delinerate falsehood."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Twenty-five years ago this week New York City dedicated First Houses, the first low-rent public housing project in the United States to be built and operated by a local authority.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 -- Assembled leaders of the Protestant Episcopal Church were unanimous here in hailing today's meeting in Rome between Pope John XXIII and the Most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 2 -- Yugoslavia disclosed today that discussions looking toward agreements on minor border questions were under way with most of her Soviet-bloc neighbors.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 2 -- A United States plan to create a strategic nuclear force under joint control of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be sent to member nations for study within a few days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- James M. Landis suggested today a Presidential office to "coordinate" the policy of the regulatory agencies in transportation and perhaps other fields.

Football odds-makers yesterday quoted the New York Giants as 14-point favorites over the Dallas Cowboys, cellardwellers in the Western Conference of the National Football League, for their game at Yankee Stadium tomorrow.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Last-minute difficulties arose today to complicate the scheduled opening Monday of the conference for reviewing the Constitution of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
Deputy Police Commissioner Edward J. McCa.be last night ordered Sherman Billingsley to get a police identity card if he intended to continue his activities at the Stork Club.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- The third Soviet space ship went out of control today and burned out as it plunged into the earth's atmosphere.
OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Dec. 2 -- The ferryboat Fire Island Belle plowed across Great South Bay today to carry a special task force opposing automobiles on this resort island.

Two television performers' unions and the radio-TV networks reached agreement yesterday "in principle in all substantive areas" on terms for a three-year contract. There had been the threat of a strike since Nov. 15, when the last contract expired.

An Australian actor who has appeared in only one Broadway show has been selected to play the major role of the American drama-critic-turned-for-sign-corresspondent in Howard Teichman's comedy, "Julia, Jake and Uncle Joe."
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- The United States was advised today to remove strings from the aid it extends to the new nations of the world and to stop using educational assistance as a political weapon.

DAVID ELLIOTT BELL, the Harvard economist appointed Director of the Budget in President-elect John F. Kennedy's Administration, is a "moderate New Dealer devoted to a balanced budget. His problem now is this: How to provide the money for the President-elect's pledged program of expanded welfare, foreign aid and exploration of space and still balance the budget without raising taxes.

Culinary ideas for holiday entertaining and the clothes to wear at home on festive occasions were combined yesterday in a fashion show and cooking demonstration entitled "Pots and Pants" at the annual meeting of the Fashion Group.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 2 -- President Eisenhower will recommend that the Federal Governmant reimburse the New York Police Department for at least some of the extra costs of maintaining security during the recent visits of Premier Khrushchev, Premier Fidel Castro and other dignitaries at the United Nations.
PARIS. ALTHOUGH the ready-to-wear collections did not reveal too many secrets about what new fashions will be seen on the streets this summer, there were many ideas for resort and beachwear.
A pre-Christmas shake-up of police sergeants, touching almost all of the eighty-one stations in the city, was announcer yesterday by Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.
ROME, Dec. 2 -- Pope John XXIII is a gregarious, talkative man of 79 whose robust stoutness cloaks the fact that he has great energy and a will of steel.
Designers engaged to plan the World's Fair of 1964 have resigned because they were not permitted to design it as they wished.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Average wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 119.6 per cent of its 1947-49 base, during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- Walter Ulbricht, Communist chief of East Germany, suggested today that the Soviet Union had won an important ideological victory over Communist China at the Communist summit conference in Moscow.

Broadcasts From the Metropolitan When opera-lovers listening to 108 radio stations across the country tune in this afternoon to Verdi's "Nabucco," for the first of twenty weeks of Metropolitan Opera broadcasts, they will be helping to open the thirtieth year of one of America's favorite cultural institutions.
TRENTON, Dec. 2 -- New Jersey expects to save more than $50,000 a year by purchasing drugs by their generic names rather than by highly advertised brand names.
Mrs. Henry Ittleson will be honored Wednesday at the fifth anniversary celebration of the Social Work Recruiting Committee of Greater New York.
DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- Michigan is expected to take a first step next week revising its tax structure. The object is to increase state revenues.

IN this emotional, hurriedly gathered and written volume, C. Wright Mills, Professor of Sociology at Columbia University and author of "The Power Elite," undertakes to present the Cuban version of the "truth about Cuba" as it seems to stand today and announces that he finds it "compelling" and "persuasive."

Saul Blickman, engineer, manufacturer, big-game hunter and photographer, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital following a heart attack. Mr. Blickman, who lived at 115 Central Park West, was 74 years old.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 3 -- Employment opportunities restricted to person 50 years old or older are being provided by a voluntary group here called Senior Consultants of Nassau County.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 3 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu, the Congolese Army's chief of staff, announced today that Patrice Lumumba was transferred last night to the garrison town of Thysville, eighty-six miles southwest of here.

CONCORD, N.H., -- All signs point to a banner skiing season in New Hampshire this winter. In the first place, snow already has fallen on the Presidential Range and, secondly, one of the forecast skiing contests in the country will be staged at Wildcut Mountain, near Gorham.
Heavy production has pushed cocoa prices to the lowest level in three years. The supply-demand ratio indicates even lower quotations but several intangible factors are preventing further declines.
In recent years the Molybdenum Corporation of America has been burdened with a vexing problem: It had no molybdenum.

TO THE EDITOR: Your article on the film library of the Museum of Modern Art ("Making Music -- Silent Style," by Joanne Stang, Oct. 23) came vividly to mind when I saw for the first time D.W. Griffith's "The Birth of a Nation."
The Junior league of Brooklyn recaptured the mood of 1910, the year of its founding, at its Golden Anniversary Ball last night at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

ON Dec. 11, 1920, Enrico Caruso -- then 47 years old and at the height of his fame -- was forced out of a performance of Donizetti's "L' Elisir d'Amore" in circumstances that have become almost legendary.
A plucky Brooklyn youth saved his 15-year-old girl friend Friday night by clinging to her abductor's speeding car.

PITTSFIELD, Mass -- Deep thinkers around here long since uttered the aphorism that the hope of the ski trails of tomorrow lies in the infants of today, and in the northeast states of this nation it is well known that to think is to act.
Last week's Moscow announcement that the largest international Communist congress ever held had ended focused world attention again on the present situation and power of this movement.

THE last of the radio soap operas has faded into electronic oblivion. Gone from radio are the daytime serials that once were the staples of the networks, the darlings of the soap and cereal sponsors; that provided empathic drama for twenty million housewives.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Two months after the Labor party conference approved Britain's unilateral nuclear disarmament, Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Parliamentary Labor party, appears to be 'making slow but steady progress toward reversing the decision.

AS editor of Audubon Magazine for the past several years, John K. Terres has received and answered many letters from people who want to tell him about an unusual (to them) experience they have had with a bird or animal.

MONTPELIER, Vt. -- Winter sports have become big business in Vermont, and judging from the rate at which new facilities keep going up, ski resort operators are confident that the 1960-61 season will equal last year's, which brought a record $19,500,000 into the Green Mountain State.

At a time of education ferment and reform, the textbook is caught in the crossfire of conflict. Last week, during the meetings of the National Council for Social Studies in Boston, serious charges were leveled against the content of high-school texts in history and economics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Statistics on the outgoing Eighty-sixth Congress indicate the magnitude of the problem that President-elect John F. Kennedy may face in bringing his fellow Democrats into line behind his 1961 legislative program.
EDMONTON, Alberta, Dec. 3 -- Leon Balcer, Transport Minister of Ottawa, opened the $20,000,000 Edmonton international Airport today.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 3 -- A two-year rift in the Fairfield County Republican committee was ended today.
WARSAW, Nov. 30 -- Polish officials are considering radical steps to improve the nation's inefficient and inadequate repair and service enterprises.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- Bill Kilmer and Bobby Smith led the University of California at Los Angeles to a 27-6 football victory over Duke's Blue Devils at the Memorial Coliseum today before 23,357.
TRENTON, Dec. 3 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones, leader of the powerful Republican organization of Bergen County, will announce his candidacy for Governor on Wednesday.
The American steamship industry is approaching containerization with great caution, an examination of the nation's shipbuilding program showed last week.

STE. AGATHE DES MONTS, Que. -- An unusual development is taking place in the Laurentian resort country: cross-country skiing is coming back into popularity. In six years as Governor of North Carolina, Luther Hartwell Hodges, a 62-year-old businessman turned politician gained two major reputations.

HERE is a title page that tells as much about a book as its jacket and without a blurb's panting adjectives. Consisting of facsimile extracts from columns of this newspaper since its founding in 1851, set off by illustrations from historical collections, plus a scene-setting introduction to each decade between the Eighteen Fifties and the Nineteen Fifties, this evocation of 110 years of the creative and performing arts in America merits a supreme adjective: superlative.

IT is strange how simple things and simple incidents weave a way into a life and often shape its ends; or is it the Destiny that Shakespeare says "shapes our ends, rough hew them how we will"? Well, I suppose that things and incidents are parts of that Destiny that raises us up or knocks us down.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3 -- Shots and shouts of rebellion echoed again in Latin America this week in the latest eruption of symptoms of the region's drama of continuing political and economic instability. THE job of replacing a broken pane of glass in windows or storm sash is a comparatively simple home repair project. The glass can be replaced while the window sash remains in place in its frame -- though the job will be easier if the sash can be removed first and laid horizontally while the work is in progress.

In the height of the all-star shopping season came a letter from a Mr. Grossman of Brooklyn. He wrote: "I am up to HERE, reading about all-city, all-county and all-neighborhood teams."

Ninety-nine housing authorities that have subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration are calling for submission of bids on Dec. 13 for $100,356,000 of temporary notes for the financing of low-rent projects.
Activity on the commodity markets yesterday was described by traders as "sluggish."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- President-elect John F. Kennedy said tonight he and his wife, with two children now, were looking for a house in Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Supreme Court held today that a bus terminal restaurant operated as "an integral part" of interstate bus service may not segregate passengers who are on a trip across state lines.
ATLANTA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Stuart G. Tipton, president of the Air Transport Association, attacked proposals today to establish a single Federal department for all transportation.
An intensive study of the city's sprawling pension systems was ordered yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The city is now paying $236,297,000 a year into employe pension funds.

In the first change of ownership in fifty-four-years, the sixstory apartment house at 21-25 East 110th Street has been sold by the estate of Annie Tow to Trimil Properties, Inc., which immediately resold the property to the 21-25 E. 110th Street Corporation.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 5 -- South Africa withdrew today the passport of Alan Paton, author and outspoken critic of the Government's white supremacy policies. No explanation was given.
The running battle between two city agencies and the State Investigation Commission flared again yesterday.

WHEN Peter Muller-Munk designs an appliance for the home he tries to let a woman's thinking give reason to every nut, bolt and sheet of steel he selects. This approach has made the Pittsburgh inidustrial designer largely responsible for the architectural look in equipment, the room-divider refrigerator and the center-drawer refrigerator that have been executed by Westinghouse.
A Brooklyn judge warned two officers of a securities concern yesterday to make restitution of $103,000 to customers "or go to jail for a long time."
EXPERIENCED rubber-bridge players know how often an apparently hopeless three no-trump contract is made when the declarer can start by running a long suit.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Le Ski a Paris, an improbable exposition dedicated to the proposition that all Frenchmen and tourists in France should wear skis, has been packing them in at the exposition grounds at the Porte de Versailles.
Thirty-ton asphalt rollers and big wire-spinning machines are putting the final coverings on the Throgs Neck Bridge for the official opening on Jan. 11.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A strike by baggage handlers paralyzed London Airport tonight. The walkout was called after a porter was detained and questioned by detectives investigating the theft of a mail bag. The porter was later released.

For the sixth consecutive meeting of the U.N. General Assembly "the question of Algeria" is being debated. Yesterday it was before a committee and in due course it will arrive at a plenary meeting of the Assembly itself. One speaker held the floor yesterday morning. This was Mongi Slim of Tunisia.
PLAINVIEW, L.I., Dec. 5 -- A helicopter toured the nine elementary schools here today to notify eighteen excited youngsters that they had won an essay contest.
Erskine Childers, Ireland's Minister for Transport and Power, unfolded a picture yesterday of a nation in transition -- from a laggard agricultural community to a thriving industrial estate.

GENERAL ASSEMBLY Elected Felix Schnyder United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees; approved report of Social Committee concerning assistance to refugees; continued debate on granting of independence to colonial countries and peoples.
A merger of three photo finishing concerns into an organization with seven plants throughout the country was announced yesterday in Washington.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- "You didn't think much of last night's show, huh? The tidal wave ? Look, amigo, you're lucky that screen wasn't blank * * * "
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 to 23 points up today. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The International Boxing Club purchased Frank Carbo's "goodwill" by paying his wife about $40,000 in three years, a Senate subcommittee was told today.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- John Morgan's two free throws in the final five seconds lifted the Detroit Titans to a 70-68 basketball victory over Utah State tonight.

DALLAS, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The American Football League draft concluded tonight with the Boston Patriots selecting Joe Bellino, Navy's star halfback. Many other standout players were chosen by teams in the year-old professional loop.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 5 -- We are emtarking today on a six-day fishing trip into the outer Bahama islands, with Capt. Milton Pierce, aboard his ninety-foot cruiser Blades. Besides the captain, the first mate and Mrs. Pierce, who will provide the galley delicacies, the party numbers seven.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- President Eisenhower showed a wholesome respect but no enchantment today at his first encounter with "the Enchantress," a blue eyed "white" tigress from Rewa, India, on its way to the National Zoological Park.
Prestige and Meridians The current tendency to evaluate, national prestige against progress in astronomical skills and space navigation is not so much a sign of the times as one might think.

Dick Powell will be the host of a one-hour weekly filmed adventure series to be televised during the 1961-62 season by the National Broadcasting Company. He also will star in a drama role every third week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: W. Stevens Sheppard's letter, published Nov. 30, touches upon a subject of deep interest to the bar and the public -- the amount of time devoted by judges of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York to the handling and trial of cases before them.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Leyland Motors, Ltd., announced tonight that it had made an offer to acquire the common stock of Standard-Triumph International, Ltd., for L17,500,000 ($49,000,000).

LONDON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Pete Dawkins, the former Army all-America halfback, will be an Oxford University "ace in the hole" tomorrow when he lines out for the Dark Blues in the annual rugby game against Cambridge University at Twickenham.
Long-term debentures of Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company aggregating $75,000,000 are being placed on the market today priced at 102.567 for 5 per cent coupons to yield 4.85 per cent.

Stanley Babin, who gave a recital last night at Town Hall, is a young pianist whose career started off with a splash. He made his debut in April, 1955, as a Concert Artist Guild winner, and in his third season of New York playing he appeared with the New York Philharmonic and the Brooklyn Philharmonia with only a single night between the two engagements.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 5 -- The seven major coffee producing countries of the Western Hemisphere in a communique ending two days of secret sessions expressed a willingness to have all signatories to the World Coffee Agreement accept a 10 per cent reduction in export quotas for the Ociober-to-March period, if deemed necessary to maintain the stability of the international market and to protect price levels.

The largest bowling alley in New York State and one of the largest in the country will open in February at Covert Street and Irving Avenue in Brooklyn. The $2,500,000 project, to be known as Ridgewood Lanes, will have ninety alleys.
A composite picture of the harm that bacteria can do to the soft tissues of the mouth has been drawn by scientists at the National Institute of Dental Research.

A proposal that Jamaica seek to become an office headquarters center for all of Long Island was placed yesterday before business leaders of the Queens community who are seeking to have it redeveloped.
IT has been said that trying to describe Alan Paton is as futile as trying to describe St. Paul's Cathedral.
The improved tone that appeared in the bond market late last week persisted in transactions in United States Government securities yesterday.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service assigned additional peacemakers yesterday to head off possible strikes by mechanical and circulation department employes of the city's major daily newspapers.
Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, announced yesterday that he had called a meeting of Democratic Congressmen from New York for Thursday afternoon.
Lorne (Gump) Worsley, the doughty New York Ranger goalie, will be ready for another crack at the Detroit Red Wing, tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.
The stockholders of the International Paper Cpmpany gave overwhelming approval to a proposed three-for-one split of the common stock at a special meeting here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently, while serving as host to a group of civic leaders visiting the World's Fair site, Robert Moses was asked about the central concept of the fair and his reaction to the proposal of President Heindel of Wagner College that it be planned now for ultimate use as an international university.

IT has not been too many years that the Pittsburgh Symphony has been making an annual trek to New York. Last night the orchestra returned to Carnegie Hall, with William Steinberg in charge, to play Mozart, Haydn and Beethoven.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- The Chevrolet and Cadillac divisions of General Motors Corporation announced today record passenger car sales for November and for the first eleven months of 1960. Chevrolet sold 143,500 cars at retail in November, according to Edward N. Cole, its general manager.
The Curtis Publishing Company and its consolidated subsidiaries operated in the red in the third quarter, resulting in sharply reduced earnings for the first nine months of this year.
IN "Uncle Harry," which began an engagement last night on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13, the man of the title is a bachelor who is coddled and sheltered by his two spinster sisters.
MOSCOW, Dec. 5 -- The Soviet Union called upon the United Nations tonight to disarm the forces of Col. Joseph D. Mobutu, Congolese army chief of staff.
The International University Foundation announced yesterday that it had formally applied for permission to establish "a center of education in world affairs"on Ellis Island.
Neither a New Jersey farmer nor a New York City taxi driver could be reckoned as choosing an easy way of life. Raphael Gomez, who has chosen both, is facing a new crisis in his unusual career.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 5 -- Gendarmerie forces from Oriental Province that are backing Patrice Lumumba were reported today to have invaded a border area in Equator Province. Fighting was said to be continuing.

Doron K. Antrim, a freelance author of many magazine articles dealing with music and music appreciation, died at his home, 150-39 Hoover Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, Sunday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

Gross revenues of the Stanley Warner Corporation and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 27 were a record of $132,153,700, S.H. Fabian, president, said in a report released today. In the preceding fiscal year, gross revenues from theater admissions, merchandise sales and other income amounted to $123,877,700.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5 -- Disturbances surrounding the public school desegregation controversy have taken a heavy toll here in economic and social terms.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The State Department ordered today an "orderly cessation" of foreign aid procurement in eighteen countries, most of them in Europe, and in Hong Kong.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The Goncourt Academy rescinded today the literary award it offered fifteen days ago to Vintila Horia, Rumanian writer-in-exile. It was the first such action in the academy's fifty-seven-year history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- President Eisenhower summoned the Secretaries of State, Treasury and Defense today to be on hand at the White House tomorrow for policy discussions with President-elect John F. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A rocket engine five times more powerful than any developed thus far by the United States will be ready for flight tests by 1963, it was reported today. The rocket is expected to be able to send multi-ton pay loads into space by the middle of this decade.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 5 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy received proposals today for a sweeping reorganization of the Defense Department. They included suggestions for a single military staff and the abolition of the separate departments of the Army, Navy and Air Force.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The Government set in motion today legislation to provide funds for refurbishing Britain's horseracing tracks, improving British racing breeds and offering higher prize money.
Stocks fell yesterday for the fifth time in six trading sessions. Save for utilities and foods, no major group was strong, yet the over-all loss was moderate.

The I.B.M. World Trade Corporation, a subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation, has leased more than 20,000 square feet on the ninth floor of the News Building, 220 East-Porty-second Street.
Sid Luckman and Lou Little were among nine men inducted into the Football Hall of Fame yesterday. Two of the group had been named posthumously.
BYRD STATION, Antarctica, Dec. 2 -- Research on the winter winds that howl across this snowy plain, sometimes for weeks without a letup, has borne a new theory to explain Antarctic blizzards.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Some six hundred years ago King John the Good of France created the franc, after having promised his subjects to establish "perpetually in the kingdom a good, stable money that neither he nor his successors henceforth could change." That promise was soon to be broken and about the only thing that has remained constant about the franc through the centuries has been its name.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- A third autopsy will be performed tomorrow morning in the death of William Harth, a 40-year-old cosmetics executive, whose body was found Aug. 14 in a pond three miles east of here.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 5 -- Premier Souvanna Phouma called on the United States today to halt shipments of arms and ammunition to the Right-Wing rebel forces of Gen. Phoumi Nosavan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Three Cuban diplomats in the United States have left their posts.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- After debating whether to retire from boxing, Sugar Ray Robinson today announced a series of European bouts in which he will bill himself as the world middleweight champion.

A COMMON complaint by hostesses is that they spend most of the Christmas season in their kitchens. No matter how pretty a dress is donned for an occasion, its luster is lost when hidden beneath the common kitchen apron.
Steel production is scheduled to continue its downward Slide this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Prime Minister Macmillan declared today that the "ultimate aim" in central Africa must be to establish "a way of life which all races may share in friendship."
WASHINGTON IT is no particular news that Arena Stage is host to another hit. During the past two seasons, that has almost become standard practice.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Inventories of unsold new domestic automobiles have reached a

TO judge by "Upstairs and Downstairs," which popped into the Sixty-eighth Street Playhouse yesterday, good domestic servants are not the only help that's scarce in England these days. It appears there is also a shortage of first-class writers of movie scripts.
GENEVA, Dec. 5 -- The nuclear test-ban conference recessed today until after President-elect John F. Kennedy takes office.

The jury in the Hulan E. Jack case listened for nearly six hours yesterday to contrasting descriptions of the Manhattan Borough President's ethics as both sides summed up their arguments. The Jury will get the case today.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Pierre Lagaillarde, who twice led insurrections by Europeans in Algeria, was in flight today with tour associates. It was believed that they might be en, route to Algiers to make a new challenge to the Government in Paris.

MOSCOW, Dec. 5 -- United States scientists attending a conference on disarmament problems said today that they had found "a great gap in thought" between Soviet and Western experts on the implementation of practical steps toward disarmament.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The lawyer for the Nixon Recount Committee said today his first move would be a petition to the State Electoral Board when the preliminary review of the Presidential vote in Cook County had finished.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Some banking authorities fear that Christmas business in the Northeast and Midwest will be hampered by shortages of coins, particularly pennies.
ALGIERS, Dec. 5 -- Surprised Europeans in Algiers questioned tonight the motives of Pierre Lagaillarde's flight and wondered if a new revolt was hatching.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Following is the text of a report today to the Security Council by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold on the situation in the Congo. It consists of a report to Mr. Hammarskjold by Rajeshwar Dayal of India, his special representative in the Congo, and of two letters from the Secretary General to President Joseph Kasavubu.

Yale University's 1960 undefeated league football champions dominated the coaches' all-Ivy team announced yesterday. Five of the six Elis nominated by Jordan Olivar were chosen by the other seven league coaches.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- The Soviet Union sought full-scale United Nations backing today for Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier of the Congo.
President-elect John F. Kennedy flew to New York last night for a day's visit.
Ten persons wore injured -- three seriously -- in a freakish accident yesterday morning at the busy intersection of Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6 -- As the embattled major leagues headed for a showdown session tomorrow on whether the American League should be permitted to invade Los Angeles in 1961, there appeared a ray of hope tonight that an amicable settlement might be reached.

Stock prices fell until noon yesterday, then climbed steadily to the close, ending with a respectable gain. Brokers noted that the bad news that had been washing over the market in recent days seemed to be generally ignored.

THE 147-year-old Krupp industrial empire in West Germany, bigger and richer now than ever before, has Alfried Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach as its stern monarch, but its premier is a dapper, jolly man of proletarian stock who loves to take pinjabs at pompous directors.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 10 to 25 points (50 cents to $1.25 a bale yesterday.

The cordial meeting between President Eisenhower and President-elect Kennedy at the White House yesterday was symbolic of the stability with which the transfer of power ought to be made in a functioning democracy. It is a mark of American political maturity that the handing over of the reins is normally accomplished with as much ease and goodwill as was indicated yesterday by both major participants.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 6 -- The Student Council at Fairleigh Dickinson University here, consisting of twenty-eight members, resigned tonight in a dispute with the administration. A five-member executive board remained, however, to serve as a liaison group with university officials.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a member of the Board of Higher Education of the City of New York since 1913 I feel especially bound to bespeak public opposition to some of the central features of the report released last week by the Heald Committee on Higher Education in New York.

PORT ARTHUR, Tex., Dec. 6 -- The American Merchant Marine Institute urged the Army Corps of Engineers today ton make several major improvements in the Sabine-Neches Waterway. This is one of the major oil tanker areas in the nation, serving Beaumont and this port.
The Detroit Red Wings will counter with Hank Bassen as their goalie when they skate against the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League gamo at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Bonds of the Northern States Power Company of Minnesota, with a 5 per cent interest coupon, are being offered to the public today in the amount of $35,000,000. Broad interest in the issue in investing circles yesterday made it clear that the issue would be a quick success.
The San Diego Unified School Distrlct, Calif., borrowed $10,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction.
TRENTON, Dec. 6 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner rejected today a request by New Jersey's major railroads for tax relief.
The American Heritage Foundation approved plans last night to work for state voting-law reforms in 1961.

TRENTON, Dec. 6 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy carried New Jersey in the Nov. 8 election by a 22,091-vote margin, according to the official canvass certified here today by the State Board of Canvassers.

JOSEPH FUCHS is the kind of violinist who makes you listen not to himself but to the music, and there is no higher compliment you can pay an artist. Last night in a recital in Town Hall, Mr. Fuchs performed this service again with Brooks Smith as a perfect partner at the piano.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- A resolution calling for expansion of the eleven-nation Security Council was turned down tonight by a vote of 42 to 36 in the General Assembly's Special Political Committee. An unusual combination of Communist and Western votes defeated the measure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The baptism of John Fitzgerald Kennedy Jr. will take place at 4 P.M. Thursday in the chapel of Georgetown Hospital. The Rev. Martin Casey will officiate. He is pastor of Holy Trinity Church in Georgetown, which the President-elect and Mrs. Kennedy attend.

Former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind said here yesterday that he had mailed to the United States Supreme Court and the parties concerned his final report as special master in the Colorado River litigation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 6 -- Yugoslavs heaved a cautious sigh of relief today at the first glimpse of the communique issued after the meeting of world Communist leaders in Moscow. It did not seem to be so bad as some had anticipated.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- International communism's confidence in the leadership of the Soviet Union is expected here to prompt Premier Khrushchev to press for negotiations with the West early in the new year.

WHEN Christina, the former Queen of Sweden, died in her Roman exile in 1689 she was 63 years old, an eccentric, dumpy, ugly little woman who had long since passed the peak of her fame. The daughter of Gustavus Adolphus, the soldier king and the greatest Protestant leader in the Thirty Years War, she had ruled Sweden for ten years -- badly, in the opinion of many of her subjects.
A 25 per cent increase in personal incomes of the people of the world is possible in the next decade, Paul G. Hoffman, managing director of the United Nations Special Fund, said yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- The Metropolitan Regional Council will seek the early enactment of laws to give it formal legal status.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Georges H. Dapples, counsel for the Nixon Recount Committee, said today he would ask the Stain Electoral Board to certify the slate of Republican Presidential electors pledged to Vice President Nixon.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 6 -- The Soviet Ambassador accused ths United States today of fomenting the civil war that is splitting this strategic Southeast Asian nation.
Glenn Gould, brilliant Canadian pianist and composer, filed a $300,000 damage suit yesterday against Steirtway Sons and one of the company's employes.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Corn futures prices continued their steady climb today oh the Board of Trade and took oats along, but other grains and soybeans met moderate resistance and lost ground.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Kenny Lane. 140 pounds, of Muskegon, Mich., rallied in the late rounds and posted a majority decision over Lahouari Godih of Algeria, 141 1/2, in a ten-round fight at Convention Hall tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- The United States made it clear today that it would support a declaration submitted by Asian and African nations calling for an end of the colonial system throughout the world if some minor difficulties could be adjusted.
A highly unpleasant but apparently harmless odor seeped through Manhattan last night. The source was suspected to be an unidentified chemical plant in the Carteret, N.J., area.
The Institute of Pacific Relations, impoverished by having lost its tax-exempt status from 1955 to last March, is quitting New York for Vancouver, B.C. at the end of the month.

Old Blues, Old-Reds and Old Greens who have won their letters in life turned out 1,400 strong at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night for the third annual $50-a-plate awards dinner of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, designated as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Kennedy Administration, said today that medical care for the aging and Federal aid to education would occupy most of his time at the next session of Congress.
HAVANA, Dec. 6 -- The National Bank of Cuba has virtually exhausted its reserves of dollars and other convertible currencies in the opinion of financial and diplomatic observers here.
The Manhattanville Community Centers, in cooperation with Lord Taylor, is sponsoring a gift certificate benefit in place of the usual theatre benefit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Commodity, Credit Corpotation's investment in price-support programs on Oct. 31 amounted to $9,120,773,000.

The report of the President's Commission on National Goals, prepared by eleven leaders in education, business and labor, will be published next Monday by Prentice-Hall. To be called "Goals for Americans," the volume presents a statement of the basic elements that should be included in the national agenda over the next decade, with critical studies of significant problems in economics, government, education, foreign policy, science and other key areas.
A leading anti-Zionist accused the Government last night of letting itself be forced by Israeli legislation and Zionist propaganda to set American Jews apart from other Americans.
A policy of "firm resistance" to demands that products made by members ou the Infants' and Children's Coat Association be "footballed" was urged last night by Joseph L. Rubin, executive director.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Several lines of criticism of the Union of South Africa were under taken here simultaneously today, but with slim hopes of accomplishing their objectives.
Savings banks and other institutional lenders may be forced to compete aggressively for new mortgage loans next year, a leading housing expert predicted yesterday.

The cabaret license of the Stork Club was ordered suspended yesterday for violation of police regulations. The suspension will start Thursday afternoon, Dec. 15, and continue for four days, which means the club faces that week-end without music for dancing.

WEMBLEY, England, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Henry Cooper, the British and Empire heavyweight champion, got off the canvas with a badly cut eye in the tenth round to gain a decision over an Argentine heavyweight, Alex Miteff, tonight.

AN hour's informal banter with five comedians -- Buddy Hackett, George Burns, Jimmy Durante, Joey Bishop and Groucho Marx -- was presented over Channel 4 last night in the first network exposure of David Susskind's "Open End" program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The defense reorganization proposals made yesterday by a committee headed by Senator Stuart Symington were under fire at the Pentagon today.

PARIS. AN outstanding designer in the ready-to-wear field is Gerard Pipart. A fastidiously dressed young man of 27 years, he has a babyish face that is a surprising contrast with his suave self assurance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- There are now 130 cities in the United States with populations of 100,000 or more. Ten year's ago there were 107.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, Dickie Moore and Jean Beliveau provided the answer today as to why the Montreal Canadians were first in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Air Force disclosed today that it was developing a space capsule that would take a monkey deep into the Van Allen radiation belt to determine the space peril for human beings.

Alfred Drake, who is recalled for his portrayals in "Oklahoma!," "Kiss Me, Kate". and "Kismet," has made a decision about his next show. He will be starred in the title role, of "Kean," a musical based on Jean-Paul Sartre's drama of the same name.
Prices for comodities futures on the New York exchanges were mixed yesterday in generally dull trading.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- French and other Atlantic Alliance diplomats viewed the Moscow communique as indicative of a tactical victory for Premier Khrushchev over the Chinese Communists and their allies. But they wondered what price Mr. Khrushchev paid for his victory.

THE violence, fear and the rowdy, passionate zest for living that flamed through the Dublin of the Easter rising roar through Sean O'Casey's "The Plough and the Stars." Whatever the disputations over the merits of the Irishman's later, more expressionistic, works, this play belongs to the grand ones of the contemporary theatre.

Robert M. Harriss, realty invettor has bought 78 to 84 Cortlandt Street, a group of six buildings, three to five stories high, from Maurice Epstein. He has taken title to the property, which consists of the entire block front on the north side of the street from Washington to West Streets.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 6 -- The United States has found no encouragement in Venezuela for a plan to convoke soon a new conference of American foreign ministers to seek far-reaching sanctions against Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Eisenhower conferred for more than three hours today with President-elect John F. Kennedy in an unusual White House meeting devoted mainly to the responsibilities of United States leadership of the West.
Yonkers Raceway yesterday increased the value of two major stakes by $25,000 apiece. This will make the estimated gross of each $110,000 for 1961.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners today recommended changes in the formula for dividing revenues from long-distance east-west railroad freight business. The proposed revisions would give Eastern and Midwestern Carriers a larger share than they now receive.
The pricing of new AA-rated public utility, bonds to yield 5 per cent to investors brought a stir to the bond market yesterday.

Three independent directors of Investors Mutual, Inc., filed with the Federal District Court here yesterday a report denying alleged charges of wrongdoing on the part of the board and also of the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., a private partnership.

A BOARD Capt. Milton Pearce's fishing boat Blades II off Nassau, Bahamas, Dec 6 -- The seas are still a bit rough after the contrary winds of the last weekend and our party of seven is awaiting the promised quieter waters of Exuma Sound before attempting any serious fishing.
The latest statement of world Communist policy appears to be a compromise document in which concessions were made by both the Soviet and Chinese Communist parties.

An involved plan for possible play-offs that could determine the National Football League's Western Conference champion was announced yesterday morning by Pete Rozelle, the league commissioner. The plan, with dates, sites and byes, would be used only in the event of a tie for the Western Conference title.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Stock market prices declined here today as buyers remained hesitant and selective.

The adoption of two preferential policies in the United States Government's purchasing of overseas transportation was urged yesterday as a major means of overcoming the deficit in the nation's balance-of-payments account.
Representatives of more than 70,000 waterfront workers in the Port of New York met yesterday to map strategy to try to curtail the policing powers of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- It is improbable that many U.N. envoys discern the reality of what General de Gaulle wishes to achieve in disputed Algeria. They can hardly be blamed France's President, for delicate political reasons, has deliberately obscured his plan behind a screen of Delphic utterances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The United States published today for the first time pictures of atomic bombs of the types dropped on Japan fifteen years ago. Under Congressional pressure, the Defense Department and Atomic Energy Commission jointly released the pictures, with the reluctant approval of the Slate Department.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Pierre Lagaillarde and the four others who fled with him to Spain from trial here as insurrectionists in Algeria can return to France only as prisoners or as victors in a new uprising against the French Government.

Footballs take erratic, bounces off as well as on the field. For instance, Oregon probably would not have qualified as an opponent for Penn State in the Liberty Bowl at Philadelphia a week from Saturday if it had not been for a couple of significant off-field developments.

A Federal mediator will meet today with employer and union negotiators in a last-ditch effort to avert a strike of truck drivers and other deliverers on the city's major daily newspapers. The strike, which could bring a general suspension of publication, is threatened for midnight tonight.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- The Public Safety Commissioner here was discharged today after he had displeased the Mayor by a promotion in the Police Department.

American Biltrite Rubber Co. The board of the American Biltrite Rubber Company yesterday dropped the quarterly dividend to 10 cents a share from the 20 cents a share declared in previous quarters and voted to pay a 4 per cent stock dividend.
Th Federal Maritime Board has rejected protests by twelve foreign nations against features of United States shipping regulations involving foreign vessels.

TWO things happened simultaneously last night at the Metropolitan Opera, and it is hard to say which caused more enthusiasm in the audience. One was a new production of Gluck's "Alcestis," an opera not heard at the Metropolitan since the 1951-52 season.

SOME of the most sought-after jewelry to be wrapped and given this Christmas will bear the name of Jean Schlumberger a French designer who crossed the Atlantic and became one of the most illustrious names in the jewelry industry.

The long-awaited statement of last month's world Communist conference in Moscow has finally been published. Its contents must disappoint anyone who hoped that the long and tortuous negotiations might do something to help the cause of world peace. After one has waded through the mass of verbiage, the central policy directive becomes plain.
A number of Protestant clergymen in the New York area have applauded the Blake-Pike proposal for organic union of four major churches.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday that the city had reduced its outstanding long-term debt by $70,000,000 in the five months since its fiscal year began on July 1.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 6 -- Dan Gurney, the Riverside, Calif., driver, ended a long spell of ill luck here on Sunday when he won the 243-mile Nassau Trophy sports car race.
A local law approved by the City Council yesterday authorizes the city police to enforce the regulations governing the operation of private parking lots and garages.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 6 -- Israeli customs inspectors have begun to examine the personal possessions of members of the United Nations staff who enter or leave the Israeli sector of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Two major Florida contractors told House investigators today that they had made cash payments to state highway officials to "expedite" their share of Federally aided roadbuilding projects.
A Brooklyn physician was indicted yesterday on charges of heading an abortion ring that grossed $250,000 a year.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 6 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano Indicated today that negotiations would open soon in Washington on West Germany's proposals to help ease the United States' dollar drain.
Michael H. Prendergast's Democratic troubles appeared yesterday to have cost him a $17,000-a-year job as a member of the State Thruway Authority.

THE highest-ranking players, who are notoriously arrogant in appraising their own skill, make partial amends by trusting their partners' judgment. When one partner bids a suit so as to imply that he does not need support in it, the other partner usually passes and gets out of the way.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Two distinct approaches to the goal of Protestant unity came sharply into focus today at the triennial general assembly of the National Council of Churches.
Hulan E. Jack was found guilty yesterday on two counts of conflict of interest and one of conspiracy to obstruct justice.

THE Whitney Museum of American Art, at 22 West Fifty-fourth Street, opens its 1960 annual exhibition to the public today, with eighty-four sculptures and 154 drawings and no paintings -- the museum having instituted a policy last year of alternating painting with sculpture and drawing in its contemporary American surveys.
An advisory commission of inquiry composed of leading citizens will be appointed by the Board of Education to help formulate its policy on collective bargaining.
Telecasters of four nations have joined to form a new international organization designed to produce documentaries on world topics.
Nothing seems to lift National Basketball Association teams out of the doldrums like a visit with the New York Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Holders of $144,000,000 of the $750,000,000 of Series F and G savings bonds maturing next year have exchanged them for an issue of marketable bonds maturing eight years later, the Treasury reported today.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., Dec. 6 -- A determined group of 200 Nassau and Suffolk County citizens, who overflowed from a jammed meeting hall to the sidewalk outside, met tonight to protest the closing of Mitchel Air Force Base.
Seven New York State utilities have chosen the General Dynamics Corporation to develop what is described as the country's largest nuclear-powered electrical generation plant.
WASHINGTON, Pec. 6 (UPI) -- A Cuban diplomat told the police today he was physically attacked by his superior when he refused to return to Havana for what he feared was imprisonment.
The sixty-fifth annual Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers, which opens today at the Waldorf-Asotria Hotel, will close Friday evening on a historical note.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 6 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu, head of the army regime, denied today that Patrice Lumumba, the deposed Premier, was being detained under inhumane conditions.
Two more taxicab drivers were robbed in Manhattan early yesterday, one by four men and the other by two men. Suspects were taken into custody in each case.

A $3,300,000 eyeglass lens plant, said to be one of the most highly automated such facilities ever built, will be opened today in Barnwell, S.C., by the Shuron Optical Company, a division of Textron, Inc.
Alexander Bittelman, expelled from the Communist party last month after many years as its chief theoretician in this country, called yesterday for abolition of the party's national secretariat.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold reported that the United Nations wag threatened with "financial bankruptcy."
