WANTAGH, L.I., Dec. 6 -- Two children were killed when a fire swept through their home here today.

The Buildings Department has ordered four more "ramshackle" apartment houses, containing sixty-four tenants, shut down and evacuated on the ground that they are unfit for human habitation. Three are in Brooklyn and the fourth is in Manhattan.

DALLAS, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The American Football League today took its first step toward establishing a player pension plan. Directors of the loop's eight teams voted to set aside a "five-figure" sum as a player benefit fund.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I hope that President-elect Kennedy will do more than have previous Administrations in regard to winning the friendship of the newly independent African nations. I speak in particular reference to sending American Negroes on peace missions to Africa.
KARACHI, Pakiston, Dec. 6 -- United States and Filipino business men disagreed sharply today on how foreign investors should be treated.

"STAR OF WONDER" is the name of the new sky show at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street. It is an attempt to identify the Christmas Star that shone in the sky of the Wise Men nearly 2,000 years ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- A Saudi Arabian Minister hailed President-elect John F. Kennedy today as a "great, great leader," because of his support of freedom for Algeria.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Dec. 7 -- Communist China indicated today that it proposed to hew to its particular brand of ideology notwithstanding the manifesto signed by eighty-one Communist parties that was issued in Moscow yesterday.

Lalor Gardens, a garden apartment building for 206 families at Lalor Street and Stenton Court, Hamilton Township, near Trenton, has been sold by the estate of Joseph Curcillo. It was bought by Lalor Gardens, Inc., a syndicate of Essex County investors represented by Philip Mandelbaum, lawyer.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- President de Gaulle's plan for an independent French nuclear striking force became law today after seven weeks of debate and without the direct approval of Parliament.
Harold Stephens has brought Hardin-Simmons its second major-college passing championship in four years.
Four members of Actors Equity have switched their allegiance from the playhouses of Broadway to the lecture halls of Broadway and 120th street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- House Republican leaders, easing into the controversy over who will make Republican policy, in the next four years, agreed today that this right should rest with members of Congress.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Harvest Moon, coming from far off the pace, closed with a rush and won the first of a series of Florida endurance handicaps at Tropical Park today. A 36-1 shot, Harvest Moon defeated the favorite, That Lucky Day, by a neck.
American industry can meet the challenge of foreign competition for domestic and overseas markets, Stanley C. Allyn told 1,600 fellow industrialists yesterday.

The likelihood that Hulan E. Jack might hold on to his $25,000 post as Mannattan Borough President beyond the end of this year gained strength yesterday.

Plans for a combination rail and bus service along the rapidly growing north fork of Suffolk County were announced yesterday by the Long Island Rail Road.

A sampling of the best parodies in the English and American language will be published Monday by Random House. "YANKI, NO!," the documentary film that recently has been something of a cause celebre in the television industry, was shown last night on Channel 7. The congregation of The Riverside Church met last night to ratify the constitution of the new United Church of Christ, thus becoming part of that merging denomination.

A $40,000,000 issue of thirty-five-year Potomac Power Company bonds is being offered to the public today at a price to yield 4.95 per cent.

Columbia opened its basketball season by defeating City College, 53 -- 42, at University Hall last night.

Interests represented by Nathaniel D. Gribin have taken title to a vacant plot of land 70 by 88 feet on the east side of Cabrini Boulevard at Village Lane, a private street, in upper Manhattan. The buyers paid cash for the parcel, now the only vacant land on the boulevard.

The ten-story Jamaica Savings Bank Building at 160-16 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by the Realty Equities Corporation. The buyers are clients of Robinson, Silverman, Pearce, lawyers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was indicted with two other persons today on charges of having misused more than $500,000 in union funds.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moves 14 points (70 cents a bale) upto 3 points (15 cents) off yesterday. The new July contract was bid up 25 points at the close. Other gains were in the near months.

The Maryland State Roads Commission borrowed $12,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highway construction. The money was raised on serial obligations secured by gasoline taxes and due from 1962 to 1976.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 7 -- The housing shortages and high rents experienced by moderate-Income families in Westchester County were attributed to state rent controls today by an organization of landlords.

The International Harvester Company, the nation's largest maker of farm equipment, had sales for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 of $1,294,800,000, or 5 per cent less than last year's record volume. The estimated figures were revealed yesterday by Prank W. Jenks, president, in a special report to stockholders.
YESTERDAY (Dec. 7, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued debate on colonialism.

The Department of the Interior is one of the most important and, in the East, least known of the major arms of the Federal Government. It is the principal guardian of America's great heritage of publicly owned or controlled natural resources, including some 750 million acres of land -- one-third the total area of the United States.
TRENTON, Dec. 7 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones called adequate state leadership the "greatest need" of the Republican party in New Jersey and promised today to provide it.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 7 -- The Portuguese Government has reported to its Western allies that the Soviet Union has signed an agreement to establish a submarine base and important radio installations in Guinea on the West African coast.

Universal Controls, Inc., reported yesterday that gross revenues increased 5 per cent to $11,017,056 in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 from $10,498,378 in the 1959 quarter. Net profit, however, dipped to $1,285,723, or 14 cents a share, from $1,492,582 and 15 cents a share.

Two key New York Congressmen are scheduled to confer separately with President-elect John F. Kennedy today on the troubled Democratic situation in the state. The two are Representative Charles A. Buckley, the Democratic leader of the Bronx and long-time supporter of Mr. Kennedy, and Representative Eugene J. Keogh of Brooklyn, who was active in rounding up votes for the President-elect in New York before the Los Angeles convention.

THIS was just before the $50-a-plate dinner of the National Football Foundation at the Waldorf-Astoria the other night when nine heroes of yesteryear formally were inducted into the Hall of Fame. The reception room soon resembled a grid-iron Valhalla so cluttered was it with immortals.
Six middle - income housing projects planned under the state's limited-profit program received rapid approval yesterday from the City Planning Commission.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 7 (AP) -- If people desire milk in other ways than it comes from the cow, give it to them, the manager of the Metropolitan Cooperaitve Milk Producers Bargaining Agency told his annual meeting today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Yugoslavia announced today that she was withdrawing her diplomatic mission from Leopoldville and recalling her twenty-one-man contingent from the United Nations Congo force.
Fordham University announced yesterday that tuition rates would be increased $300 a year starting July 1.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 7 -- The battle of the Ca Dinh River, marked by the fiercest fighting thus far in Laos' three-sided civil war, appears to have ended in a draw.

The Lionel Corporation is expanding its electronics business through the acquisition of the Telerad Manufacturing Corporation of this city and Flemington, N.J. The transaction involved 99,000 shares of Lionel stock, which, at yesterday's closing price of 28 on the New York Stock Exchange, amounted to $2,772,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Five prominent economists agreed today that business was in a mild slump.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 7 -- A Discoverer satellite was put into orbit today in another test to perfect a military reconnaissance system.
MANILA, Dec. 7 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Ambassador to the United States, warned tonight that the Philippine position as a sugar supplier to the American market "cannot be taken for granted."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- President Eisenhower reminded the nation today that the 100th anniversary of the Civil War would be observed from 1961 to 1965, and asked Americans everywhere to take part in commemorative ceremonies.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- A compromise proposal on Algeria has been offered privately. It was felt here today that it might be accepted by both sides.
Under the approved plan of reorganization for the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company, Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson yesterday appointed directors for the railroad and its real estate company.

THE New York City Ballet at the City Center last night turned its back for a moment on ballet-ballet and went in for a fun piece called "Jazz Concert" for its fourth premiere of the season. It was, to be sure, a high-brow fun piece, for its idea was to stage four musical works by three long-hair composers writing under the influence of American jazz.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- The best Republican vote-getter in Illinois today dimmed G.O.P. hopes to withhold the state's twenty-seven electoral votes from President-elect John F. Kennedy.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday to try at once to find effective ways to protect the city's 40,000 to 50,000 taxicab drivers from hold-ups and murder.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Jet airliners contribute to air pollution during take-off, the American Institute of Chemical Engineers was told today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Department of State official spoke out today against restrircting the export of private capital or curtailing American travel abroad to reduce the United States loss of gold and dollars.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 7 -- A key Government witness against a Teamsters Union official convicted of tax evasion narrowly escaped death this morning when a bomb wrecked his wife's car.
Apparently the New York Rangers don't listen to their Coach, Alf Pike. Alf keeps telling them to go all-out for sixty minutes and press the opposition.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7 -- The possibility that the public schools of New Orleans might have to close because of lack of funds appeared greater today.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday to fight in the 1961 Legislature for the city's anti-slum bills killed at Albany early this year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Jet airliners contribute to air pollution during take-off, the American Institute of Chemical Engineers was told today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Department of State official spoke out today against restrircting the export of private capital or curtailing American travel abroad to reduce the United States loss of gold and dollars.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 7 -- A key Government witness against a Teamsters Union official convicted of tax evasion narrowly escaped death this morning when a bomb wrecked his wife's car.
Apparently the New York Rangers don't listen to their Coach, Alf Pike. Alf keeps telling them to go all-out for sixty minutes and press the opposition.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were unchanged to 17 points off. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Playing in rain and cold, four professionals broke par by one stroke today to lead the field after the first round of the national senior open golf tournament.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Heard address by Premier Mamadou Dia of Senegal.
A number of major changes in the merchandising divisions at Stern's, Forty-second Street department store, were announced yesterday by Jerome F. Swartsberg, managing director.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Amid partisan sniping and contractor contriteness, a special House subcommittee today showed a broad pattern of roadbuilders' payments to Florida state highway officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Following is the transcript of a news conference by Presidentelect John F. Kennedy and Adlai E. Stevenson on Senator Kennedy's offer to name Mr. Stevenson representative to the United Nations:

THE human figure is stalked in two current exhibitions of sculpture. But whereas Karl-Heinz Krause takes a direct approach in his bronze nudes at the Borgenicht Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, Abbott Pattison, who is showing abstract metal constructions at the Feingarten Gallery, also at 1018 Madison Avenue, dismembers and rearranges the human form in many a fantastic and capricious fashion.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Charlie Burns scored twice with his team short-handed as the Boston Bruins whipped the Chicago Black Hawks, 5-1, tonight before the smallest Garden crowd in more than two years.

Random House, Inc., book publisher, has subleased the first floor In the building at 24 East Fifty-first Street from the Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation. John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker, arranged the sublease, which is for eight years.

ALGIERS, Dec. 8 -- The Frehch administration announced tonight stern measures to break, the general strike that Europeans have called by word of mouth for tomorrow to mark the arrival in Algeria of General de Gaulle.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Japan and the Philippines, bitter wartime enemies, signed today a historic treaty of amity, commerce and navigation.
Management of the Alleghany Corporation answered yesterday a rebuttal by the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., of Alleghany charges that they had abused fiduciary privileges.
OFF STANIEL CAY, The Bahamas, Dec. 8 -- We met some Americans last night who haven't been home since they came over here for a two-week vacation ten years ago.

Arnold Uhrlass of Bayside, Queens, became the first competitor to win the Race of Champions four times when he triumphed last night in the feature event of the thirty-seventh annual edition of the Silver Skates last night at Madison Square Garden.
The plight of Jews in Africa is worsening, the Joint Distribution Committee was told last night.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- France will vote Jan. 8 to decide whether Algeria shall have immediate home rule and eventual free choice of its own political future.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 8 -- Troops loyal to Premier Souvanna Phouma struck swiftly today to subdue Left-Wing military elements and civilian groups opposing peace talks with Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, pro-Western revolutionary leader.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals criticized today the Federal Power Commission for what it said was the failure to adequately hold down prices of natural gas.
Robert B. Evans, a Detroit business man and sportsman, is building a jet hydroplane with which he hopes to capture the world's water speed mark now held by Donald Campbell of England.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Gains reaching highs of 3,459 votes for Vice President Nixon and 9,753 for defeated State's Attorney Benjamin S. Adamowski were claimed by Republicans today. A recheck of paper ballots in 863 Chicago districts neared an end.
Downtown Manhattan was brought within seven minutes of Newark and La Guardia Airports yesterday with the opening of the Downtown Manhattan Heliport on Pier 6, East Riveri at Coenties Slip.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 8 -- The Board of American Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America today adopted a record budget of $5,300,000 for 1961. This year's budget was $4,315,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- The bird trainer walked into the Hollywood-built jail cell at the Columbia studio. The prisoners were a couple of dozen canaries and sparrows, many of which will be playing small, but important, movie bits in the next couple of weeks without any previous cinematic experience.
The 1960 bull market m bonds -- one of the most trumpeted but least visible in years -- finally made its appearance yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- John F. Kennedy said today he would ask the next Congress to create a Department of Urban Affairs to direct Federal aid in solving metropolitan problems.

THE perplexing, enchanted world of childhood is the theme, of "When I Was a Child," which came to the Forty-first Street Theatre last night. It is evoked through the writing of Dylan Thomas, Shirley Jackson, Virginia Woolf, Katherine Anne Porter, Frank O'Connor and Sholem Aleichem.

PLAINVIEW, L.I., Dec. 8 -- The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation will move the production unit of its graphic equipment division from its plant here within a year because of a strike by machinists.

A counterfeit phonograph record ring -- just about ready to flood the market with bogus popular albums -- was smashed early yesterday with the arrest of nine persons in Brooklyn and three in Utica N.Y.
A Swiss mathematician has developed a diving technique that he believes will enable swimmers to descend 3,000 feet or more without armor to protect against the great water pressure.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today the establishment of a Republican "shadow Cabinet" to set the tone of opposition to the new Democratic Administration.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 8 (AP) -- John Barnum of Grand Rapids, Mich., carded a sixunder-par 65 and took a onestroke lead in the first round of the $20,000 Coral Gables open golf tournament today.
The International Monetary Fund sold $300,000,000 in gold to the United States in the week ended on Wednesday to obtain dollars for investment in interest-bearing Treasury obligations.
HAVANA, Dec. 8 -- The Royal Bank of Canada has been nationalized by the Cuban Government. The action was taken under "an agreement which the bank accepted," according to bank officials.
A Michigan bank has opened what it calls "an all-out campaign" to increase its savings account business by a direct comparison with savings and loan associations.

SHORTLY after 10 A.M. today, the curtains will lift on the Fifth Avenue side of Lord Taylor and passers-by will catch a first glimpse of the nevernever land that is the 1960 edition of the store's famous Christmas windows.

CHRISTMAS shopping to many women is nerve wracking. Confronted by traffic bottlenecks at the doors of stores or hard-to-locate departments, many shoppers wonder whether stores are planned for the merchant's or the consumer's convenience.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I feel compelled to take issue with your editorial of Dec. 2 on "Troubled Indochina" in which you state:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy's 13-day-old son was baptized this afternoon in the chapel at Georgetown University Hospital.

Charles Plohn Co. and J. R. Williston Bean and associates offered to the public yesterday 130,000 common shares of Victor Paint Company, Detroit retail paint store operator, at $12 each. Of the shares, 95,000 are being sold by the company to finance the opening of additional paint stores in metropolitan Detroit and elsewhere, and 35,000 are being marketed for the company's president, Harold S. Victor. He will own 170,000 shares after this sale.
Henry R. Labouisse has been appointed the Special Representative for Africa of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) to take effect on Jan. 1.
THERE is a recently opened restaurant in New York that is as spirited and festive as flamenco. It is La Fonda del Sol, one of the most lavish Latin-American restaurants north of the border.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Air Force, apparently intruding upon the space domain of the Army and the civilian space agency, disclosed today that it was developing a passive communication satellite.

"THE Working Mother" was the title of an hourlong telecast yesterday over Channel 4. The program, part documentary and part dramatization, studied the problems faced by the millions of American women who divide their time between homemaking and outside employment.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- The National Council of Churches for the first time in its ten-year history elected a layman as its president today.

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York dropped $114,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. This compared with a decline of $2,000,000 in the 1959 week.

Clarence Preston (Pop) Houston, the retired athletic director of Tufts College and a former president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, received the 1960 James Lynah Memorial Award last night at the annual dinner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference at the Hotel Manhattan.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 5 -- A visit today to the Csepel Engineering Works, the biggest industrial plant in Hungary, provided an indication of the progress of the consolidation of Communist power since the 1956 revolt.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 -- An annonymous New Orleans citizen advanced $16,525.86 to the New Orleans School Board today to pay forty teachers and fifteen other employes at two integrated schools. Their regular salary checks had been withheld by the State Legislature.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 8 -- A conference of international business men expressed "great concern" today at "arbitrary and discriminatory" expropriation of foreign investments.
New York will benefit as a port if railroads decide to start charging wharfage fees at Baltimore and other ports south of here, harbor officials said yesterday.
Trading on the New York commodities markets continued at a slow pace yesterday and futures price changes generally were mixed.
THE Coiffures Americana Salon, opening today at Bergdorf Goodman, is the first in a series of new beauty salons. Lavish and luxurious decor will be the rule in each.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Stuart Symington said today his committee was studying how some of its reorganization proposals for the Defense Department could be carried out without legislation.
Leaders of waterfront labor unions in the port laid informal plans yesterday for a second waterfront "unity" conference to embrace all maritime transport unions, regardless of affiliation.

An antitrust action by the Department of Justice to force the Continental Can Company, Inc., to divest itself of the Hazel-Atlas Glass Company was thrown out of court yesterday by United States District Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Government reduced the bank rate today by one-half of 1 per cent. this brought it down to 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Seasonal declines and a continued downward trend in business were reflected today in the weekly report of the rail and truck industries.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- With only six weeks to go, the makeup of the Eisenhower Administration is changing.

IT Is often a mistake to be overhasty about taking an ace, even at a slam contract where a single trick may seem very important. There are dozens of cases in which an ace should not be taken the first time the opportunity is offered.
The wholesale commodity price index remained on Wednesday at Tuesday's level of 82.8. The daily index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 84.4 on Dec. 4, 1959.

For the third successive session stocks rose yesterday but did it without any general enthusiasm. Many of the standard investment issues lost ground and leadership was generally taken by low-price stocks. Seven of the nine most active issues closed at below $25 a share.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture, in a final report for the year, today estimated that the 1960 cotton crop would amount to 14,309,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each.
HAVANA, Deb. 6 -- The crucial question around Cuba today, as one small merchant here aptly put it, is "hay" or "no hay."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy today offered Adlai E. Stevenson the post of representative to the United Nations with Cabinet rank.
Joerg Demus, a Viennese pianist who began playing here five years ago, gave a recital last night at Judson Hall. He divided his program between Schubert and Schumann.
President-elect John F. Kennedy, though he prefers to go bareheaded, will wear a black silk topper for his Inauguration.

PERTH, Australia, Friday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Early-morning showers disappeared and bright sunshine broke out today for the opening matches in the Davis Cup interzone tennis final between the United States and Italy.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Fred Haney, who spent most of his many years in baseball as a player and field manager, today was named general manager of the new Los Angeles Angels of the American League.

Nicolas Darvas, the dancer who wrote the best-seller "How I Made $2,000,000 in the Stock Market," made only $216,000 in the seven years covered in his book, the Attorney General of New York State charged yesterday.

The scene changes from department to department, and the cast of bad characters is revised, but the story is the same, monotonously, shockingly the same as more and more graft is uncovered in the Wagner administration. Hardly a day passes without some new disclosure of corruption, or a sequel to the old.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 8 -- Dutch financial officials indicated today that the Netherlands was ready, even eager, to repay in advance a good part of its remaining postwar credit debt to the United States of about $270,000,000.

The two top officials of the Buildings Department have declared they will invoke every available resource to "restrict profiteering" on slum properties. They said they were pressing for more state laws to add to those resources.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The cut in the bank rate from 5 1/2 to 5 per cent had hardly any effect in the stock market here today. Prices of both industrials and British Government securities hardened temporarily when the announcement was made but soon resumed their downward drift.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 8 -- Paratroops under Capt. Kong Le, a Leftist, took over this Laotian administrative capital tonight, less than twenty-four hours after an earlier military take-over by neutralist forces, according to the Vientiane radio.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Dec. 3 were 7 per cent below the level of a year earlier.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Warriors used some accurate foul shooting by Wilt Chamberlain in the last three minutes tonight to beat the New York Knickerbockers, 114 -- 111, in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header before 5,201 fans.

The look of Christmas was spread over the window panes in Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital yesterday. From their wheel chairs and beds on Welfare Island, patients looked out on jolly snowmen, laughing Santas, red bells and green trees in window paintings done by Pratt Institute art students.

Jesse Owens, who won fou Olympic gold medals in trac and field for the United State in 1936, was named yeaterday as the winner of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood's annual award. Jack Twyman, the Cincinnati Royals' basketball star, and Stan Musical were recent recipients of the award.
Two rival American-flag steamship lines that established financial link two months ago moved yesterday to integrate their services.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Canada made a new proposal today in an attempt to break the deadlock between the Western and Soviet-bloc powers over a resumption of talks on world disarmament.

Rinksiders who know have labeled St. Lawrence this season's potential Eastern college hockey champion. Other leading contenders for the two Eastern berths in the National Collegiate championship tournament are Boston College, Rensselaer, Polytechnic Institute, Harvard and Clarkson.
The steel industry's sudden interest in establishing overseas production facilities apparently is snowballing.
A seventy-eight-hour engineering spectacles will be staged during the Christmas' holidays in the Harlem River.

Soviet delegate Valerian A. Zorin is using his temporary position as this month's president of the U.N. Security Council to do what his predecessor, Jacob Malik, did a decade ago. Mr. Malik abused his powers to push the cause of Russian-controlled North Korea against free South Korea. Mr. Zorin is abusing his powers to push the cause of Soviet Russia in the Congo.
Recent experience at a number of major medical centers in the nation suggests that the human body can be chilled close to the freezing point of water for many hours and successfully revived.
CROWN POINT, Tobago, Dec. 8 -- The United States will retain its naval base at Chaguaramas on the West Indian island of Trinidad for seventeen years, it was agreed at talks ending here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Professor Robert Triffin of Yale University, a specialist in international finance, called on the incoming Kennedy Administration to substitute "bold and imaginative action" on fundamental problems in this field for "the panicky action of the last few weeks."
Senator Barry Goldwater, leading Republican conservative, told 1,500 Industrialists yesterday that one of the most important tasks facing Congress was "to stop foreign economic aid."

GOOD fish come in small sizes, particularly as far as value for money is concerned. Many of the less Imposing specimens offer good eating at- tractive prices, yet are generally ignored in favor of the more glamorous salmon steak.

Reflecting the Times In this gay holiday season, when life in Our Town often seems to be one round after another of social functions, the historical-sociological-minded among us are reminded that social dancing is a vital part of life, always reflecting the temper of the times.
A man killed his estranged wife and her mother last night and then was shot to death in a gun battle with the police when he ran into the street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
Do stock brokers really welcome customers? Along Chicago's LaSalle Street the answer seems to be "no."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Friday, Dec. 9 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold warned the Security Council early today that "deeply disturbing threats had been made by" those in authority in Stanleyville, the capital of Oriental or Eastern Province, in the Congo.
If man is ever to voyage beyond our own solar system he will have to use anti-matter as fuel, an astronomer predicted here yesterday.
Loew's Theatres, Inc., is negotiating for the financing of its first two hotels, now under construction, Laurence A. Tisch, chairman, told stockholders attending the anuual meeting here yesterday.
The success or failure of a Broadway play, ordinarily of concern only to local commercial interests, will be felt as far away as Kenya.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A mistrial was declared today in the case of a telephone operator accused of having conspired to help shield James R. Hoffa from Senate investigators.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Washington State Supreme Court Judge Joseph A. Mallery accused the Negro race today of trying to deprive whites of the right to choose their associates in private affairs.

In fact, the leading parlor game in America today is the guessing contest called "Who'll be in the Cabinet?"
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- The country's principal electrical manufacturers and some of their officers and employes pleaded guilty, today to criminal antitrust charges.

The heada of city departments and agencies were ordered by Mayor Wagner yesterday to hold to "an absolute minimum" their requests for allowances in the expense budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, 1961.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Bruce Drysdale scored 28 points and was the leading playmaker as Temple beat Gettysburg, 83 -- 61, in the second game of a basketball doubleheader at the Palestra tonight. St. Joseph's College defeated St. Francis of Loretto, Pa., 87 -- 55, in the opener.
A deliverers' strike that could have forced the city's major Newspapers to suspend publication was averted yesterday.
In the first of many such appearances, Joe Bellino, Navy's much-decorated half-back, received the Heisman Trophy last night as the outstanding college football player of 1960.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Internal Revenue Service is considering a plan that could mean lower taxes for many persons.
Amerace Corp. The Amerace Corporation declared yesterday a 3 per cent year-end extra stock dividend in addition to its regular quarterly payment of 1 per cent in stock and 25 cents in cash a share.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Soviet Union said tonight it was granting loans on favorable terms to the United Arab Republic for about 100 industrial and agricultural projects. The Soviet Union already is financing a large part of the construction of the Aswan High Dam on the Nile River. It also is providing technical assistance in the project.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- The Association of Colleges and Universities of the State of New York today asked state aid to private schools in the form of tuition supplements for students and matching funds for capital construction.
The sale of $12,000,000 of highway bonds by Dade County, Fla., scheduled for Dec. 13, has been postponed indefinitely.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- James D. Norris, who had been president of the defunct International Boxing Club, told a Senate subcommittee today that it was "necessary to have a certain relationship" with Frank Carbo to "get along in the boxing business."

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped by $53,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $60,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements dropped $576,000,000 in the week to $625,000,000.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Big Eight Conference today declared a Kansas halfback, Bert Coan, ineligible and stripped the Jayhawks of their first conference football championship in thirty years.

Jack Landau has been engaged to direct "Giants, Sons of Giants," the new play by Joseph Kramm. Negotiations were concluded yesterday, according to Alfred H. Tamarin, co-sponsor of the venture with Charles A. Totero.

THE joyous wonder's of James M. Barrie's Neverland, with Mary Martin escorting young and old on her heavenly flights from reality, came to television again last night in the National Broadcasting Company's third presentation of "Peter Pan."

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Emil Mazey, secretary-treasurer of the United Automobile Workers, urged today a shake-up of the National Labor Relations Board and new laws to protect employes from unfair labor practices.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., formally acknowledged last night what the financial district had known since late Tuesday. This is that the Hughes Tool Company, wholly owned by Howard Hughea and owner of 78 per cent of T.W.A.'s stock, has "virtually completed" arrangements for long-term financing of a fleet of twenty Convair 880 jet airplanes and twenty-seven 707 Boeing jet airplanes.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 8 -- The United Nations Command denounced today what it described as an attempt by Congolese authorities to paralyze its operations here by interfering with transport.

How to ease Michael H. Prendergast out as Democratic state chairman was reported to have been a major topic of discussion yesterday at a two-hour conference in the Washington home of President-elect John F. Kennedy.
The Hertz Corporation announced yesterday a series of executive changes to become effective upon the retirement of Walter L. Jacobs, 65 years old, as president and chief executive officer on Dec. 31.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One salutary effect of the past Presidential election is that the extreme closeness of the popular vote in comparison with the larga majority of the electoral vote focused public attention once more on the urgency of abrogating the present electoral method which Arthur Krock accurately pointed out on Nov. 11 as not only archaic but misrepresentative of public opinion and a deceitful guide to executive decisions.

AMONG the many large, handsome and profusely illustrated books published this season in the hope of pleasing the tastes of affluent Christmas givers one in particular might be considered suitable for readers of this newspaper. It is "America's Taste 1851 -- 1959: The Cultural Events of a Century Reported by Contemporary Observers in the Pages of The New York Times,"* edited by Marjorie Longley, Louis Silverstein and Samuel tower.

Cold weather notwithstanding, officials of thhe Metropolitan Golf Association last night turned their thoughts to summer golf. At the annual meeting of the organzation at the Princeton Club, plans for the somewhat distant tournament season were announced.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Algerian nationalist leaders and their Asian and African supporters stiffened their demands today for a United Nations-supervised referendum to decide Algeria's political future.
An hour-long report on Negro sit-in demonstrations in the South will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company at 10 P.M., Dec. 20.

Mahler's Symphony No. 3, originally scheduled for performance by the New York Philharmonic at the end of the year with Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, will be played in the spring instead in memory of the late conductor.
A bomb planted under the hood of an automobile exploded and killed a Queens man yesterday as he turned on the ignition.

FEMININE guile can go a long way toward sweetening a man, but the image of the Tarzan type still holds sway among many men. Whether it is a cologne or scented after-shave lotion, anything that hints of an aroma is not for them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Food-research experts told a symposium on "Science and Food" today that to rule out risk in developing food additives would end progress in the field.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- When the decision was reached for the group headed by Senator Symington of Missouri to submit a written report to President-elect Kennedy of its proposals to reorganize the military establishment, and make these public, his problem of recruiting new Pentagon officials was intensified.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy urged Mayor Wagner yesterday to veto a bill that he said would make policemen parking lot attendants for garages, supermarkets, restaurants and taverns.

Three hundred and sixty-five acres of land in West Windsor Township, N.J., near the campus of Princeton University, have been purchased by a syndicate of investors represented by Louis M. Golden Jr., a Philadelphia realty broker.

Sidney J. Ungar was ordered yesterday to show cause in General Sessions Court next Tuesday why he should not be punished for contempt of court because of his behavior at the trial of Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
Birthday parties -- complete with cake, candles, favors, a present and friends to sing "Happy Birthday" -- are favored entertainment at most U.S.O.

St. John's, which is expected to be one of the leading college basketball teams in the East, will have a stern test tonight when it meets Kansas in the first game of a triple-header at Madison Square Garden.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Word that Adlai E. Stevenson had been offered the job of heading the United States delegation to the United nations traveled fast this afternoon and was well received.
New Yorkers, many of whom were strolling coatless in balmy springlike weather on Monday, bundled up last night against the coldest winds since March.

ACCORDING to a strict notation on the schedule, Brendan Behan, the Borstal boy, was due at The Players at 1 P.M. to account to The New York Times for his rowdy play, "The Hostage," and his considered view of life.
Mayor Wagner entertained a "golden chain gang" yesterday at a Waldorf-Astoria luncheon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- The first layman to head the National Council of Churches is a business man who knows more theology than many ministers.

A pageant of prominent New Yorkers costumed as Italian women through the ages or characters from the works of Gian Carlo Menotti was the entertainment highlight of the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds Ball held last night in the Plaza.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Corn and other grain futures, except wheat, bucked stiff profit taking on the Board of Trade today and ended with fairly steep losses in spots.
NEWARK, Dec. 8 -- The City Council today approved a $600 salary increase for next year for policemen and firemen, despite, a warning by Mayor Leo P. Carlin that he would veto the measure.

Henry Brandon, a United States correspondent for The London Sunday Times, interviewed seventeen "outstanding, articulate Americans" and one Englishman, Peter Ustinov, about America and Americans. He gives their comments in "As We Are," which Doubleday will publish Jan. 27.

Demolition of six fifty-year-old houses on the south side of Sixty-sixth Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues was started yesterday to make way for a $3,000,000 religious school for Temple Emanu-El.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Officials of three states told the Supreme Court today there was nothing unconstitutional about laws that prohibited or restricted commercial activities on Sunday.
Major league baseball was splurging itself yesterday on having solved its immediate expansion problems without plunging into a civil war that could have disrupted the entire professional structure.
David Dubinsky contended yesterday that no single group in the country could claim that President-elect Kennedy owed it anything for his victory at the polls.

The city will pay its 23,500 Policemen and women $2,800,000 before Christmas for their over-time in guarding foreign government dignitaries during the United Nations General Assemly session here last October.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Louis C. Wyman, New Hampshire attorney general, filed a motion in Merrimack County Superior Court today asking that Dr. Willard Uphaus be kept in jail until he "purges himself of contempt by complying with a court order."
Two employes of the State Rent Commission were accused yesterday of taking bribes. One of them was suspended. The circumstances under which the other resigned two weeks ago were put under scrutiny.

YESTERDAY (DEC. 9, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Elected Turkey, Chile and the United Arab Republic to nonpermanent seats on Security Council and elected El Salvador, Ethiopia, France, Jordan and Uruguay to the 'Economic and Social Council.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy has talked to Arthur J. Goldberg, a leading labor lawyer, about the post of Secretary of Labor.
A call for 100 New York National Guardsmen to help reenact the first battle of Bull Run was made last night by maj. Gen. James C. Fry, retired Army officer, who will direct the show.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 30 -- Traveling north on the Bel grade-Novi Sad highway, a motorist turns right at the corner by the Evangelical church in this Vovovodina farm village to reach the home of Bosko Borovac.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 9 -- A bar and grill in Passale County was prohibited today from showing New York Giants home football games on television.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Times of Nov. 15 carried a profile of Lloyd J. Rittiner, president of the Orleans Parish School Board. The article states that the backers of his candidacy for office were representing various organizations, including the League of Women Voters.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics turned on the speed for a 146-123 victory over Cincinnati tonight in the National Basketball Association.

Botany Industries Negotiations for a merger of Botany Industries, Inc., and H. Daroff Sons, Inc., a privately owned manufacturer and retailer of men's suits in Philadelphia and Baltimore, were reported yesterday in trade circles.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The grain futures market yielded to selling pressure in late dealings today on the Board of Trade and closed with small losses in corn, oats and rye.

OFF BLACK POINT, Great Guana Cay, Bahamas, Dec. 9 -- We spent the night here after a glorious day of fishing in Exuma Sound. We went ashore in the evening to be entertained by the natives in a series of dances, with a palm-frond fire on the beach the setting, for the grand finale.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 9 -- Gov. LeRoy Collins formally opened today Florida's only underwater vehicular tunnel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- One of the main tasks of the incoming Democratic Administration will be the establishment of a "better balance" within the field of national transportation policy, Harold F. Hammond, executive vice president of the Transportation Association of America, declared today.

Although economic conditions in Israel are improving steadily, the country still needs the millions of dollars donated through the United Jewish Appeal to settle new immigrants, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The president of a Georgia road-building company testified today that it had passed out money, race track trips and oteher favors to officials charged with supervising highway construction in seven southeastern states.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec.9--Premier Souvanna Phouma of strife-torn Laos fled here by plane tonight with his family and a group of Government Ministers from Vientiane.
The Pennsylvania State School Building Authority is planning the sale of $23,000,000 of serial bonds on Jan. 18.

Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba and Federico Thompson of Buenos Aires, Argentina, are expected to weigh in slightly under the 147-pound welterweight limit at noon today for their fifteen-round title fight tonight in Madison Square Garden.

The oilers of Diesel tugboats operated by seven railroads in the Port of New York will vote tomorrow on whether their jobs are to be progressively abolished. The prospective agreement is to take effect Dec. 31.

RAYMOND MICHALSKI, a boyish-looking basso who made a successful New York recital debut last year, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall last night for another appearance. This one was as appealing as the first.
The bond market continued strong and active yesterday but profit-taking in the afternoon slowed the pace of trading and shrank the day's gains.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- British spokesmen plan to urge at next week's Atlantic alliance meeting the widest diversification of means of delivering the West's nuclear weapons.

A proposal to place a four-year limit on college competition was resoundingly defeated yesterday by the Eastern College Athletic Conference. The proposal was beaten despite the support of the colleges at which he amendment was directed.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Marquette University today dropped intercollegiate football and track, for financial reasons. The action drew angry protests from the football coach, Lisle Blackbourn, and about 2,000 students, who demonstrated on the campus.

BY tradition, fruit cake is an important part of the Christmas season. Commercial bakers of the cakes often feel they must take note of that fact by embellishing their products with fanciful garnishes.

CLEVELAND, Ohio,. Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The General Electric Company today blamed rising costs of "labor, material and transportation" for its decision announced yesterday to close two of its lamp plants -- one here and one at Oakland, Calif.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Attempting to avert a strike, heads of the English professional soccer clubs agreed today offer their players more money and better contract provisions.
ALGIERS, Dec. 9 -- A European strike in protest against the presence of General de Gaulle in Algeria closed down most shops here today and crippled Algerian transport.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 -- The campaign of intimidation against white parents who have been attempting to send their children to integrated schools here was stepped up today. Attendance dropped.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The General Accounting Office today cut off funds for a State Department branch after the department had refused to give Congress information dealing with possible "malfeasance of Foreign aid personnel" in South America.

Allan P. Kirby lost a round yesterday in his battle to retain control of the Alleghany Corporation. At present, he is chairman, president and the largest single stockholder of the big diversified holding company.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The State Education Department today, created a special committee to' effect a compromise in the current, dispute over its ruling that parents can examine school records of their children.
LEONIA, N.J., Dec. 9 -- A game of musical chairs -- with the State Highway Department calling the tune -- has annoyed a widow deprived of the home she had lived in here for thirty- two years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Following are the texts of a report on the Congo situation by Rajeshwar Dayal,United Nations representative, and of a protest by him to the provincial authorities in Stanleyville, as presented to the Security Council today by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold:
The Forest Hills man killed on Thursday when a bomb blew apart his automobile had a record of nine arrests on minor charges dating from 1950, the police disclosed yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner appeared tonight to have won a major victory in his struggle to induce the State Senate to approve a cent-a-pack increase in the cigarette tax.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) --The White House released a study today recommending readjustments of United States air services abroad and urging a close watch on the competitive practices of foreign airlines.
A substantial reduction in the number of pedestrians killed or injured while jaywalking has been recorded in the two years since anti-jaywalking laws were introduced here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Western diplomats here foresee an incrase in world tensions and heightened competition between Communist and nonCommunist worlds, particularly in under-developed areas.

KARL BOEHM has been conducting at the Metropolitan Opera since 1957, but not until yesterday afternoon had he been heard as a symphony conductor in this city. He is taking over the New York Philharmonic for two weeks, and for his first concert he chose music by Mozart, Hindemith and Brahms.

In immediate application of the new Communist manifesto calling for an intensified international "class war," a new name for the cold war, the Soviets have launched diplomatic offensives on three fronts as examples of Communist action in this stage of "peaceful coexistence."

IMAGINE a woman wearing this silhouette -- a hat tipped over her forehead, a coat or dress with shoulders stiffened like a board and extending out over bare arms, her waistline pulled in somewhat with a wide sash, and a short, skinny skirt. Around her neck is a single strand of marble-sized pearls. On her feet she wears flat-heeled patent leather dancing school pumps.

THE newest addition to the ever increasing number of Far Eastern shops in New York City is Collector's Orient, which opens its doors today at 137 East Sixty-first Street. Although most items at this shop are recherche, one-of-a-kind pieces, there are some small "treasures," which are moderately priced and might make unusually decorative Christmas presents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- James D. Norris conceded to a Senate subcommittee today that Frank Carbo had been a useful "expediter" or "convincer" in lining up Carmen Basilio, Tony De Marco, Willie Pep and Jake LaMotta for International Boxing Club fights.

Sales of the Canada Dry Corporation in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 exceeded the $100,000,000 mark for the first time in its history, while earnings were the second highest on record, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
Two talented young American artists shared yesterday afternoon's Town Hall program, sponsored by the Concert Artists Guild.
CARACAS, Dec. 9 -- The oil Industry here is convinced that any Government effort to enforce maintenance of high export prices will inevitably lead to a further loss by Venezuela of her world markets.
A conference on migrant labor offered specific suggestions yesterday on how community agencies could carry out their responsibilities to the laborers.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a participant in the recently concluded sixth annual NATO Parliamentarians' Conference, I should like to make a few observations.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 9 -- This administrative capital of Laos, seized yesterday by army units who proclaimed strict neutrality and retaken this morning by self-styled neutralists of distinctly Leftist bent, braced itself today against possible attack by advancing pro-Western forces of Gen. Phoumi Nosavan.
The British colony of Hong Kong has assumed a rather daring image on television, stage and screen with such presentations as the "Hong Kong" series and "The World of Suzie Wong."

Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union voted here last night to approve a new two-year contract recommended by their leaders. The vote assured uninterrupted delivery of nine major New York newspapers with a combined daily circulation of 5,500,000.
Norman Mailer, the writer, was declared legally sane yesterday by Bellevue Hospital psychiatrists and released in $2,500 bail on a charge of stabbing his wife.

A new, purportedly revolutionary computer development was disclosed by the Sperry Rand Corporation yesterday. The disclosure was made, at the "suggestion" of the New York Stock Exchange, five days before the company had planned to issue a news release.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A special committee of the Organization of American States adopted recommendations today to reform and revitalize the Inter-American Economic and Social Council.

A five-story building containing forty apartments and six stores, at 998 Longwood Avenue, corner of Fox Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Arlene Corporation. It occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet and was bought by the 998 Longwood Company for cash over mortgages of $120,000.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- The Soviet exploration ship Ob carrying this nation's sixth Antarctic expedition was reported today approaching the Soviet station at Lazarev, where it will land a construction party.

AS part of its program in religious drama, the Union Theological Seminary presented last night the first of seven scheduled performances of T.S. Eliot's verse drama, "The Family Reunion." As an exercise in giving students a balanced knowledge of the theatre's literature -- the avowed purpose of the program -- Mr. Eliot's drama with Spectral overtones serves admirably.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 9 -- President Elsenhower thanked Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York today for a $10,000 contribution for aid to Cuban refugees in the United States.

LESS than five months ago, Capt. Kong Le, a slight, unassuming young paratrooper, was an obscure and almost unknown junior officer in his country and completely unknown outside of it. Since then, he has risen to become one of the political leaders in Southeast Asia.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 9 -- Hofstra College posted its sixteenth straight basketball victory and Adelphi College rallied for its first triumph of the year at Woodruff Hall tonight.
Futures prices for commodities on the New York exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. Prices of three commodities were up, those of three others were off, and the rest were unchanged or mixed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--The Administration was reported today to have expressed concern to Congress that more nations, including Communist China, could shortly emerge as nuclear powers.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Pete Campbell scored 31 points to lead Princeton's basketball team to an 85-72 triumph over Navy tonight. It was the third victory for the undefeated Tigers.
To make pictures, man through the ages has used varying techniques: the dribble method, finger painting, and brushes, trowels, sponges, blotters, rags and other aids.
Police Commisioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that detectives would drive taxicabs in an attempt to trap hold-up men and killers who are preying on cab drivers.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- One week, ago I wrote there was "danger in the air" of France but it had not yet begun to produce its familiar smell. Three days later Lagaillarde, the poor man's D'Artagnan, and other anti-de Gaulle conspirators had skipped to Spain. The familiar smell is back.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents) down to 11 points (55 cents) up yesterday. The far months were strongest.

PERTH, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The United States counted on Barry MacKay today to stave off imminent defeat and prevent a possible disaster in the Davis Cup interzone final series against Italy.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 (AP) -- William Finegan, a top labor leader in Cleveland, and, one of Ohio's largest department stores were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on two counts of violating the Taft-Hartley Act.
MOMENTS PRESERVED"* is a big book of fine photographs in black and white and color by Irving Penn. They reflect our time's places and personalities with great style.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Paris political circles concluded tonight, on the basis of President de Gaulle's first, day in Algeria, that he was clearly determined to carry through his program for Algerian home rule despite noisy opposition from European demonstrators.

ROBERT GOLDSAND returned to Carnegie Hall last night for what has become virtually an annual New York appearance. The pianist began his program unconventionally with Hindemith's Sonata No. 3, continued with an Adagio in B minor of Mozart and Schubert's "Wanderer Fantasy," and ended with the six Paganini-Liszt etudes.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- The new president of the National Council of Churches called on American Protestantism today to make its voice heard in every area of life.
Albert W. Twitchell of Rutgers University yesterday was reelected president of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association at the group's annual meeting at the Manhattan Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- It's Green Bay's power against San Francisco's shotgun attack in tomorrow's contest between two of the three clubs sharing the top spot in the National Football League's Western Conference.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- The General Assembly elected Chile and the United Arab Republic today as nonpermanent members of the Security Council. It failed to make a choice between Liberia and Portugal for a third seat.
Foreign competition and how to meet it was one of the big questions of concern to American industrialists as the annual meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers ended last night.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Bob Goalby shot his second consecutive four-under-par 67 today for a 134 and a one-stroke lead at the half-way point in the $20,000 Coral Gables open golf tournament.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to point out two errors made by Ulf Christiansen in his letter published Nov. 30 on "Algeria's Aspirations." He writes that on the two previous occasions mentioned in Clifford Forster's letter (Nov. 13), the Algerians did not vote for integration with France but "for or against de Gaulle."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The United States and Communist Romania agreed today to set up exchange programs in the fields of graduate study, science and industry, theatre and movies, and sports and tourism.
Gil McDougald, the Yankees' versatile infielder, retired from baseball yesterday after thirteen years in the game.

City Colleges and the Public The city colleges in the metropolitan are have been catapulted into public notice by the Heald Report recommending that in the future $300 a year be charged to all but the most needy students.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Republicans contesting the election that gave John F. Kennedy a plurality of less than 9,000 in Illinois took their first formal court action today.

A lively week is forecast for the new capital market. Sale of more than $250,000,000 of fixed-interest securities are slated, with most of the volume to be made up of state and local government issues.
In the heaviest trading on the New York stock Exchange since May 18, aggregate market value advanced nine-tenths of 16 per cent yesterday and stocks closed at their best levels of the day.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- While President de Gaulle, on the heroic level, follows his destiny and that of France in Algeria, his fellow-citizens are prosaically "following the steer" at home.
NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Unbeaten Boston College bettered its scoring record tonight with a 110-96 basketball triumph over Connecticut.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- Even the experts are stumped.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The fortnightly bookkeeping account on the London Stock Exchange ended today with share prices falling further.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Morocco called on the United Nations today to intervene "energetically if necessary" to put an end to the six year-old war in Algeria.
CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A New Hampshire judge rejected today a state prosecutor's plea to keep Dr. Willard Uphaus in jail after next Tuesday, the day the 70-year-old pacifist will go free.
A collection of letters from George Bernard Shaw to an American actress and painter will be made public Wednesday, disclosing a relationship that is scarcely hinted at in works on the playwright.

With the recent addition of two imports to Louis Malle's "Elevator to the Gallows," the Times Film Corporation Is preparing a package of three Gallic crime dramas for American release in 1961. The acquisitions are color adaptations of works by two of America's top mystery writers, and are directed by a movie veteran and a leading exponent of the "new wave."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Saturday, Dec. 10 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has pledged the resources of the United Nations for the evacuation of European civilians in the Congo who have been threatened with reprisals over the arrest of former Premier Lumumba.
Mayor Wagner conferred in Washington yesterday with Robert F. Kennedy on the Democratic situation in New York City and the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 9 -- United States scientists have bored into the molten core of a Hawaiian volcanic lake as a rehearsal for generating electric power from the residue of underground nucear explosions.
More trouble piled up yesterday, for Sidney J. Ungar, a principal in the transaction that led to the conviction of Hulan E. Jack on charges of conflict of interest and conspiracy to obstruct justice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets dipped 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 119.5 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
HAVANA, Dec. 9 -- About 1,000 workers of the Cuban Electric Company marched to the Presidential Palace tonight to protest an attempt by Communist elements to seize control of their union.

IN one of the strong "athome" games played frequently in New York, when four or five of the leading players get together for rubber bridge, the deal shown presented challenges to everyone in the game.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- J. Russell Duncan, president, and four directors of the Minneapolis-Moline Company resigned today.

The first African regional conference of the International Labor Organization, meeting at Lagos, is an important event not only for Africa but other areas as well -- especially for the more economically advanced nations which now recognize the urgent need of the African countries for economic and technical aid.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- Losses of hundreds of millions of rubles in capital investment funds diverted to overambitious projects and in industrial and construction equipment were charged today to bad planning by the chiefs of a number of important economic regions throughout the Soviet Union.

A key part of the Government's program to aid small business is the establishment of small business investment companies. These are specially licensed concerns permitted to supply equity capital and longterm loan funds to small businesses.
FOR the last two years the Lutheran Foundation for Religious Drama a non-profit, church-sponsored theatre organization, has been jealously working to revitalize the drama within the church.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9--Walter P. Reuther told the United Automobile Workers today that, in addition to seeking improved pension contracts with auto companies, "we must also fight on another front for medical care for the aged."
St. John's set up a heavy crossfire from the free-throw line and from the corners at Madison Square Garden last night and brought down the Kansas quintet, 66 -- 54.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial concerning the licensing of cabaret employes neglects to observe that there is no basis in law for this procedure, nor could there be under the Constitution. The police are required by law to license cabarets themselves.

Chock Full O'Nuts Corp. The 1,300 employes of Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation, restaurant chain, were told by William Black, president, that they would get a Christmas bonus of more than five weeks' salary.

Pico Warehousing,. Inc., has purchased the six-story commercial building at 38-40 North Moore Street between Hudson and Varick Streets from Pettit Reed. The Robert R. Rainey Company was the broker. The plot is 50 by 87 feet.

The annual erosion of drill-shed floors begins today with the Bishop Loughlin Games, the first major meet of the schoolboy indoor track season. The 102d Engineers' Armory will reverberate to the thunder of 3,400 athletes from 142 schools, the biggest turnout in the seven-year history of the event.
An acrimonious dispute between a city magistrate and a lawyer who accused him of convicting people before he tried them drew a capacity crowd of spectators into Gamblers Court yesterday.
TLEMCEN, Algeria, Dec. 9 -- President de Gaulle came today to a "new Algeria" where Moslems cheered him and Europeans fought the police and soldiers to demonstrate against him and his policies.

The French Government Tourist Office is turning its attention seriously to the American market for travel to the French Caribbean islands and to the possibility of a direct connection between France and the Southern American states through Florida's airports and seaports.

With his own political fortunes and the future of France at stake, President de Gaulle has embarked on a crucial mission to Algeria. His purpose is to persuade the many turbulent and mutually hostile elements there to accept his plan for Algerian self-determination, even if this should lead to an independent "Algerian Republic."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Government, in its largest antimerger case, moved today to block the Phillips Petroleum Company of Bartlesville, Okla., from acquiring control of the Union Oil Company of California, Los Angeles.

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Manon Lescaut" at 2 P.M., and "La Boheme" at 8 P.M. Edgar Roberts, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Louis and Aida Kohnop, duo-pianists, Town Hall, 5:30; Bach's Christmas Oratorio, the Masterwork Chorus, Carnegie Hall, 8, and Rey De La Torre, guitarist, Town Hall, 8:30.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Duke's taller Blue Devils overpowered Penn State's basketball team tonight, 69 -- 46.

THE series of science programs prepared by the Bell System was resumed last night on Channel 4 with a study of genetics that tantalizingly circumvented the matter of the effects of radiation on human reproduction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The man who invented the Link trainer for blind flying appeared this week as the inventor of equipment to explore the oceans depths.

Psychiatrists who have been monitoring their patients' dreams as they occur indicated yesterday that the early dreams of the night usually involve recent happenings, while the later ones, except for the last, are rooted more deeply in the past.

Universal Bible Sunday will be observed tomorrow in a number of Protestant churches here and over the country. In the city the observances will be sponsored by the New York Bible Society, which is dedicated to the dissemination of the Scriptures.
New Yorkers shivered through the coldest day of the season yesterday -- a windswept day during which the temperature dropped to 15.8 degrees in the early morning.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 9 -- The United Nations took emergency action today to protect Europeans in Stanleyville following death threats from supporters of Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier.
One of the last remaining free individuals in the increasingly institutionalized business of oil exploration is the independent "leasehound" -- and now he has been institutionalized too.
The extravagant holiday display that has made Fifth Avenue a tourist's as well as a shopper's delight in December continued yesterday when Lord Taylor unveiled its Christmas windows.

THE mysterious pyramid of colored boxes towering in Stuart Becker's window at 1053 Third Avenue turns out to be a hat enthusiast's dream. There is a box for every creation. These boxes come in five graduated sizes in a choice of oval, square and round shapes.
A visiting British stage director has charged the American theatre with being under the influence of parasitic elements.
Arrangements have been completed for the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, considered by many "the fun party" of the debutante season.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- Goals by Earl Ingarfield, Red Sullivan and Ted Hampson gave the New York Rangers a 3-0 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins before 10,560 spectators tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- Scientists, engineers, business men and Government officials concerned with the peaceful applications of atomic energy will meet here next week to review the new industry's progress and discuss its problems.
JESSELTON, North Borneo, Nov. 20 -- A breeze of optimism is blowing across this British colony, which emerged from World War II with its cities shattered and its economy In ruins.
The Soviet Union's leading track and field coach has charged publicly that track and field sports in the United States are completely professionalized, a form of "big business."

HONOLULU, Dec. 10 -- Capt. Gene W. Jones of the 6593d Test Squadron made his second catch of a satellite capsule today when he and his crew aboard Pelican III snagged the Discoverer XVIII nose cone west of Hawaii.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -- The Los Angeles Chargers were forced to rally three times to subdue the stubborn Denver Broncos, 41 -- 33, and sew up the Western Division title of the American Football League today.
Edgar Roberts, pianist, made his New York recital debut in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

ORCHESTRAS: The Boston Symphony, led by Charles Munch, gave the New York premiere of William Schuman's Seventh Symphony, "a work of decided force." . . . The Pittsburgh Symphony was on its mettle when it played here under William Steinberg, "one of the moat efficient conductors."

Retail trade in this area continued to lag behind the 1959 levels. Reading department store executives estimated sales as 2 to 3 per cent below the 1959 level. The major factor again was this year's later Christmas. The holiday fell two days earlier in 1959.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- An angry young man with a fierce look and tousled hair stepped off a train at Istanbul's Haydarpasha Station one cold winter afternoon in 1951.
S, Silent TO its publisher there came the other day a money order and a request for a single copy of "The Elf-Conscious Society," by Eric Larrabee.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 10 -- An eignt-nation consular mission flew today to Stanleyville to assist-United Nations officials in protecting Europeans and Americans in terror-stricken Oriental Province.

To the Drama Editor: HOWARD Taubman writes that the Broadway version of "Advise and Consent" is an "unsavory account of political intrigue on high levels," that if one accepts its premise, "you will hail it as a fearless exposure," and if you don't it's a "loaded condemnation of the liberal position."

THE changing of the guard is about to begin, and who can say that the world has ever seen a pageant that could match it? In a few weeks' time, the oldest President ever to sit in the White House will be on his way, and after him will go, one by one, that tenacious breed of men who held the seat of power around the world in the middle decade of the twentieth century.
WITH the end of the professional football season approaching, the Columbia Broadcasting System is planning to resume its "Sunday Sports Spectacular" to fill a winter void for the sports fan.

BOSCAWEN, N.H., Dec. 10 (AP) -- New Hempshire will release on Tuesday a controversial figure after a year's imprisonment. He is Dr. Willard Uphaus, a 70-year-old pacifist and former Methodist lay preacher.

As far as the Norwegian Seamen's Federation is concerned the adage about "the healthy life of the seaman" is a false cliche. Ships' cooking appears to be as great a hazard as any other facet at sea by Norwegian sailors.

At the rate of one article a year, the Third (Social) Committee of the U.N.'s General Assembly is plodding ahead with its work on the so-called Convention on Freedom of Information. Just a year ago, it adopted a Preamble and Article 1, which guaranteed to journalists "freedom to gather, receive and impart" news without governmental interference -- but by changing the original word "seek" to "gather" it reduced the article to virtual ineffectiveness.

IF it had not been for the volleyball game last summer, it is possible that Jim Lee Howell never would have suspected the fires that burn deeply within Lee Grosscup, the kid quarterback of the Giants. But volleyball indicated to the perceptive coach that the 23-year-old boy from Utah might also reach stardom some day as a football operative.
The growth of the world's merchant fleet continued during the year ended June 30, 1960, Lloyd's Register of Shipping said last week.

A RECENT series of six accidents in Connecticut killed eleven persons -- this in a safety-minded state. It was a shocking reminder of the extent to which the nation's highways have become scenes of slaughter.
