OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 10 -- A benefit auction featuring Christmas floral decorations will be held by the North Country Garden Club of Long Island Monday at the home here of Mrs. John B. Marsh.

To the Travel Editor: I read your article "Tourists and Gold" with particular interest, since I had just written a letter as a private citizen very much concerned with our gold-loss problem to the Secretary of State proposing precisely what you seem to oppose.
An example of why two-story design has traditionally been one of the most economical for home construction may be found in a model house recently opened in Smithtown, L.I.

IN "The Bramble Bush," the late Charles Mergendahl strove with considerable success to graft character facets and moral dimensions onto the sexual improprieties of a fictional New England town. Now "The Next Best Thing" comes along with similar facets, dimensions and heavily organic attitudes toward romance.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 10 -- The leaders of the Marxist movement in Venezuela have decided that the time has not yet arrived for a successful rebellion to overthrow the regime of President Romulo Betancourt.
A Long Island realty company is introducing catering halls as an added attraction to its bowling alleys.

MIAMI, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Florida A. and M. University shocked Langston of Oklahoma with a 20-point outburst in the first period tonight and went on to win the Orange Blossom Classic, 40 -- 26. More than 40,000 football fans watched in the Orange Bowl.

WHATEVER became of the movement for simplified spelling? Fleetingly, it came to public attention again when the announcement was made a few years ago that Bernard Shaw had left a large sum of money intended to further a radical revision of written English.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 10 -- Winthrop Rockefeller's four-year effort to build a model school system in the central Arkansas town of Morrilton was rebuffed at the polls this week.

IN "First Degree," William M. Kunstler, a lawyer and writer on law, has assembled a collection of eighteen famous American murder cases. All of them were public sensations in their day and many of them have appeared in other crime anthologies.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 11 -- A manifesto designed to guide Communists throughout the world called today for a unified struggle against "imperialist countries headed by the United States" in all major trouble spots.

THE tentative plans of President-elect John F. Kennedy to hold live televised news conferences during evening hours could be a constructive forward step in bridging the gap that tends to separate the average citizen from the seat of government.

FICTION THE PATHFINDER. James Fenimore Cooper. (Pocket-Washington Square Press. 60 cents.) This 1840 novel was published fourteen years after "The Last of the Mohicans," but catches Natty Bumppo (Leatherstocking) at a more tender time of life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, has been ordered to appear Tuesday at a Senate hearing that will touch on the bombing of an auto in New Jersey this week.

A REPORT in pictures and text of an eleven-week trip through Asia in 1958 makes up this book. It can be heartily recommended both as a fascinating introduction or superior guidebook for those who have never seen the varied countries stretching from Japan through Pakistan, or as a nostalgic reminder for those who once knew and loved some part of Asia.
The seventy-eighth annual convention of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association ended last night with the election of eight men to the Lacrosse Hall of Fame.

EARLY this year two stereo disks that were destined to turn the recording industry topsy-turvy made their first appearance on those lists of best-selling LPs that are followed anxiously by everyone who makes or sells records.

IF you find it entertaining and instructive to compare a copy with the original, you might contrast Bruce Cassidy's THE FLOATER (Abelard-Schuman, $2.95) and Ed McBain's SEE THEM DIE (Simon Schuster, $2.95).

An educational campaign to remove some of the mysteries of real estate for potential investors is advocated by a realty man who specializes in finding investment outlets for estates, institutions and individuals.
TRENTON, Dec. 10 -- The New Jersey Highway Department has received a $23,000,000 proposal calling for a vast network of belt freeways and roadways in and around this capital city.

Miss Susan Hathaway White, daughter of Mrs. Dyett White of New York and Nantucket, R.I., and Woodward White of Baltimore, will be among the young women to be presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 19.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 10 -- St. John's College of Annapolis has announced plans to establish a new college patterned on its highly individual liberal-arts program.

BINGHAM, Utah, Dec. 10 -- Two weeks before Christmas this once lusty, brawling mining town feels tower than the bottom of Bingham Gulch, which it occupies. Reason for the dumps: this Christmas will be Bingham's last.

TO write of miracles is one thing, to write of fictional miracles is another. The double suspension of disbelief is apt to be disconcerting to many readers, and Rosalie Lieberman was certainly not lacking in courage when she wrote this sequel to her whimsical novel, "The Man Who Sold Christmas."

The question in the minds of business men these days is: How serious is the downturn and how long will it last? The degree of sluggishness varies to a marked extent according to type of business. By the same token, recovery in different levels of industry and trade will occur at different times.
The moratorium on nuclear tests should not be allowed to continue beyond two more years, a former scientific delegrate to the Geneva test-ban conference said yesterday.

A small army of baton twirlers, some bent on qualifying for the national championships to be held next month in St. Paul, Minn., invaded White Plains recently to display their skills. Herewith views of some of the steppers.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 10 -- We have just ended a six-day fishing expedition in waters in and around the cays of the Exuma Island chain of the Bahamas. It was a highly productive cruise insofar as fish were concerned and an unforgettable one for scenic splendor and interesting people.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- The Pine Tree State, a thriving summer playground for generations, has been slow to realise that its deep white snow can bring in just as many of those long green bills as its dark blue lakes, but this winter it will make a major effort to attract the sports-minded tourist.
TRENTON, Dec. 10 -- Nine New Jersey counties must increase their expenditures substantially in the fiscal year beginning July 1 as a result of the 1960 Federal census.
Louis and Aida Kohnop gave a two-piano program yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

IN his newest book Walter Teller has performed a considerable service for the arm-chair mariner. The book is a selection from the writings of five perceptive and far from laconic American sea captains. "None of these captains," Mr. Teller reminds us, "was a professional writer.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 10 (UPI) -- A smooth Long Beach City College football team led by Lonzo Irvin and Dee Andrews today captured the National junior college championship with a 38-16 victory over Tyler, Tex., in the fifteenth annual Junior Rose Bowl.

HOLLYWOOD. HUNDREDS of thousands of Roman Catholics will stand up in church today and pledge themselves to observe the dictates of the Legion of Decency on which motion pictures are fit to see and which aren't.

Junior and debutante committees have been formed to assist in planning a party for the Association Home at the evening showing of the movie "The Sundowners" on Dec. 21 at the Radio City Music Hall. The stage presentation will be "The Nativity."

TO THE EDITOR: I, TOO, share Philip Roth's concern for accuracy, particularly since I note that he has inadvertently misquoted me by improving my grammar (for which kindness many thanks). The quotations attributed by me to Mr. Roth were taken not only from his prepared speech but also from his frequent extemporaneous remarks and from his extended answers to questions from the audience.

In slum-studded East Harlem, insurgent Democrats have banded together in a political reform movement that poses a new threat to Tammany chieftain Carmine G. De Sapio and district leaders loyal to him.

The wrist watch has finally penetrated the last stronghold of the old-fashioned pocket watch -- it has been accepted by a major railroad as meeting the standards of time-keeping required for its operating personnel.
To the Travel Editor: Apropos Sylvia Freedman's letter, "Vive les Americains," (Nov. 27), I would like to tell you the experience my wife and I had with an "American" in Cordoba, Spain.

PROFESSOR of Latin and Dean of the Faculty of Arts at the University of Birmingham, England, Donald R. Dudley is one of those rate historians who is able to clarify and develop an arresting statement.
BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- After a further 90 minutes of riotous West Indian run-getting, Australia's batsmen slowed the first cricket test to pedestrian pace on the second day.

THE plethora or passive entertainments to which children are subjected in our movie-and-television-oriented age is a source of concern to many parents. Today's "ersatz" entertainment, they feel, robs youngsters of the thrill of taking part in the mounting excitement that live theatre represents.
THE Horticultural Society of New York, Inc., will present its Christmas Flower Show from 1 to 4 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon in the Colonnades Ballroom, the Essex House, 160 Central Park South.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- "Conflict-of-interest" abuses in the $41,000,000,000 Federal-state highway program "ought to be looked into" further, Representative John A. Blatnik said today.

John Camien, a 16-year-old senior from Sewanhaka High in Floral Park, L.I., was the surmise victor in the mile run last night in the Bishop Loughlin schoolboy games at the 102d Engineers Armory. The meet opened the local indoor season for high school track and field athletes.

The Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball will be held on Jan. 2 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Before the dinner dance there will be a reception for thirty young women in the hotel's Astor Gallery.
HONOLULU, Dec. 10 -- Sugar industry leaders, faced with demands by the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union for a new one-year contract, are girding for difficult negotiations.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Captain Jones first sighted the capsule at 25,000 feet above the Pacific Ocean and snagged it on the first pass, the Air Force said here.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 -- Japan's relations with the United States and Communist China are expected to dominate the thirtyseventh special session of the Diet (Parliament) which was formally convened this morning by Emperor Hirohito.
WHAT happens to music and musicians when a country is in the throes of revolutionary change?
Reform Judalsm has not broken with Jewish tradition but is a continuation of it, the Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman said yesterday in his sermon to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.
With only a few weeks of the 1960 calendar left, a long-heralded bull market in bonds finally came into view last week after lurking "just around the corner" for most of the year.
LONDON. DURING the late Sir Max Beerbohm's long career as a caricaturist, essayist and critic, many prominent Britons, captains and kings alike, felt the public pink of his stilettolike pen.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 10 -- Laudy L. Lawrence's 7-year-old Beau Diable set a track record of 3:35 3/5 for two miles and a sixteenth today at Pimlico in winning the $21,225 Pimlico Cup Handicap.

FOLLOWING in the train of Botticelli, Flaxman, Dore, and others, Robert Rauschenberg has chosen to illustrate Dante's "Inferno." His thirty-four pictures, one for each canto, on view at the Castelli Gallery, are done in a combination of mediums and swarm with metaphorical and symbolical ideas that convey, in an entirely personal way, a peculiar and peculiarly private response to the poet's adventures on that nightmare expedition.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- The American League today revealed an early Christmas "gift" of sixteen minor league players to its new Washington and Los Angeles clubs. Price tags ranged up to $25,000 a player.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 10 -- Lavaliere, a tiny thirty-foot ketch that Howard Foht of Miami and Erie, Pa., appeared to have entered merely for the sixty-one-mile ride, last night emerged the surprise winner of the fifth annual Miami-to-Palm Beach yacht race.
HONOLULU, Hawaii, Dec. 10 -- Mayor Neal S. Blaisdell and the City Council have come under fire for their decision to scrap plans for an $8,000,000 war memorial municipal auditorium.

BROADER HISTORY -- The state of Pennsylvania has stamped the word "mandated" on its new World Cultures curriculm. In so doing, it assures that each high school graduate will have had at least one semester, and hopefully one year, of exposure to the cultures of hitherto neglected areas of the social studies curriculum.
WARSAW, Dec. 10 -- Cardinal Spellman is being quoted in public dicussion here on the possibility of German-Polish reconciliation to the considerable embarrassment of the Roman Catholic Church.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson, when asked today if he would accept or reject the post of representtative at the United Nations, replied: "I will do my duty."
ATLANTA, Dec. 10 -- Georgia legislators are discussing publicly the possibility of a change in state segregation laws to prevent school closings in the Atlanta school integration case.
MERCURY, Nev., Dec. 10 -- Project Pluto, which may develop an atomic-fueled ramjet missile about five years hence, is approaching a critical testing stage.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hartman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Elizabeth Hartman, to Robert Morris Rodney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney of DeKalb, ILL.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Air Force's retrieval today of the capsule from its Discoverer XVIII was the fourth successful recovery in six attempts, three in the air and one from the sea.

Manhattan Island is suffering growing pains. Address books are dating rapidly as one industry after another makes a move or plans one. Individual concerns engaged in similar pursuits tend to cluster in a single building or an area, and they often move as a group, which makes it easier for customers and for salesmen.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The Government moved quickly today to stave off any Right-Wing demonstrations in France that might be designed to match those by supporters of "French Algeria" in, Algiers and Oran.
Prospective home buyers are frequently haunted by the fear that money they have paid on deposit to a development builder will be lost if the builder should fail in his venture.

WHEN the group photography show presents work of varying ability and approach, the advantage for the visitor is an opportunity to make comparisons and to draw conclusions, thus helping to establish personal goals for one's own work.
BRANSON, Mo. -- In the year 1223, St. Francis of Assisi, who loved animals and children, enlivened Christmas by restaging the Nativity scene with real cattle and donkeys in the nave of his church.

Among the wealthy and the well-to-do, the word for the personal income tax rates ranging up to 91 per cent is "confiscatory." No one is surprised to hear them say it.

ARCADIA, Fla. -- The Census revealed that, during the last ten years, Florida has absorbed two million new residents. Amid all the excitement about new seats in the House of Representatives, the mushrooming construction of new towns tort retired persons and the booming resort areas, even Floridians sometimes forget that there are many small towns in the state that have changed hardly at all in the past seventy or eighty years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Mr. Dillon said today he had "not been offered a position" in President-elect Kennedy's Administration. He said in a statement that he had read news reports "speculating" that he had been offered a post.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 7 -- As Lord Byron reported about Belgium's capital in Napolenonic times, everything here is as "merry as a marriage bell."

In African Struggle In a West Algerian town last Friday Charles de Gaulle pushed through friendly Moslem crowds while in the background Europeans shouted imprecations against him. He said of the hostile clamor, "Shouts, noise -- that signifies nothing."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Getting a fine defensive effort from John Havlicek and 29 points from Jerry Lucas, Ohio State's basketball team routed Army, 103 -- 54, tonight.

LAKEWOOD, N.J. -- This Central Jersey resort is an unusual place because, despite its proximity to the now cold Atlantic Ocean, its temperatures from November to May are markedly moderate and its humidity is low.
These days when Mrs. Randolph C. Harrison goes to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx all she has time to see is the inside of the administration building.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 8 -- Portugal appears to have united in support of her 71-year-old Premier-dlctator, Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, as a result of the African-Asian criticism In the United Nations of Portugal's "colonial" policies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The glib assumption that Lyndon B. Johnson wall continue to "run the Senate" from the Vice Presidency continues unchallenged here despite impressive historical evidence suggesting that it simply cannot be done.

HAVANA, Dec. 10 -- The Royal Bank of Canada in Cuba, which was nationalized by the Government last Thursday, is being permitted to withdraw its capital stock, an unimpeachable source here indicated today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 -- King Gustaf VI Adolf conferred Nobel Prizes today on a French poet, two scientists from the United States, one from Britain and one from Australia.

PERTH, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 11 -- A fighting comeback by Barry MacKay provided both a cushion and encouragement today for America's doubles team, which hoped to put over the knockout punch in the Davis Cup interzone final.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- A big season is shaping up for Key West, the pendant in the chain of the Florida Keys. This southernmost city of the continental United States escaped serious damage in Hurricane Donna, and it is hoping to play host to a considerable number of the winter vacationists who formerly used this port primarily as a departure point for Havana.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- In the rebirth of midtown Philadelphia, four more skyscrapers are scheduled to rise next year on sites virtually within the shadow of William Penn's statue atop City Hall tower.

A SURPRISING variety of birds may be attracted during the winter in New York City if one has a garden or if there are trees and shrubs in the vicinity. Proof of this is offered by the Rev. Robert M. C. Griswold, rector of The Church of the Holy Apostles at 360 West Twenty-eighth Street.
A group composed mainly of young families is seeking to revive the Robert Owen cooperative apartment development which had been planned near Cooper Square.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10 -- Yale's swimming team opened its fifty-fifth season today with a 67-27 victory over Pennsylvania in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet.

MUSIC, money and the world of jazz sit for their portraits in three revealing photographic picture books newly published. Other recent volumes interpret the state of Missouri, provide an informal tour of New York City and take a look at a phase of America's musical past in the South.

THE meeting ground for the lovers of jazz and folk music is growing wider. Recording and research activity in the area of country blues has been increasing, and gives indication of continuing to be alive for some time to come.

Charles S. Desmond, Chief Judge of the State Court of Appeals and chairman of the state Judicial Conference, will give key legislators this month a consolidated report on judicial trends and needs in the state.

Viruses are entities on the borderline between the living and the non-living. They can reproduce themselves only by harnessing the reproductive mechanism of specific host cells which they parasitize. They are much smaller than bacteria and can be seen only by an electron microscope that magnifies more than 100,000 times.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- A 46-year-old Binghamton lawyer emerged this week as the leading contender for the post of Republican Majority Leader in the Assembly next year. He is George L. PARIS, Dec. 11 -- President de Gaulle's Algerian policy hung in the balance tonight, in the opinion of observers here. There was some question as to whether it would be possible to proceed with French plans for a referendum Jan. 8 in the atmosphere of insecurity created by the three days of European and Moslem demonstrations.

All the good that had been accomplished by the New York Rangers in two periods last night at Madison Square Garden was undone within forty-seven seconds in the third period. The Boston Bruins scored two goals and earned a 2-2 tie.
GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- The International Commission of Jurists condemned South Africa's apartheid policy today as a "morally reprehensible" violation of the rule of law and of human rights.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 11 -- Human cells that orbited the earth thirty-one times last month through a rain of radiation from a massive solar flare are still alive and reproducing normally.
THE woman who seeks a new career that does not require technical training or previous experience may find a vocation in helping other women to find a home.
Philip M. Klutznick, one of the nation's leading real estate developers, was elected general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5 -- 1, tonight for their eighth straight National Hockey League victory.

LAST year, Peter Serkin, the pianist son of Pianist Rudolf Serkin, made his New York debut in one of the New School Concerts given in Greenwich Village. Yesterday, the boy, now 13 years old, returned to the series for a second appearance.

HOUSTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- George Blanda, still hobbling from an ankle injury, threw three touchdown passes and kicked a 53-yard field goal today as the Houston Oilers defeated the Buffalo Bills, 31 -- 23. The victory clinched the Eastern Division championship of the American Football League for the Oilers.

One of the strong selling points of mutual funds is that their investment decisions are made by professionals. The idea is to have an experienced backstop for the person who has enough money to invest but not enough time to work out a good investment program for himself.

TWO or three times a year, Philip Morris Klutznick, who yesterday was elected general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, takes a jet plane to Israel, where he is creating the "most modern port city in the world."

Dealers in over-the-counter securities last week saw renewed buying both on the part of professionals and the general public. The market moved higher each day, except Wednesday, and at Friday's close the National Quotation Bureau's price index of thirty-five "off-board" stocks stood at 102.18, the high of the week and 0.38 higher than a week earlier.

PARIS, Dec 11 -- The Comddie Frangaise produced Corneille's "Polyeucte" this afternoon for the first time in seven years. But the status of the tragedy as a repertory piece here is better indicated by the fact that today's matinee was the 674th time the celebrated French company has done "Polyeucte" since it was written in 1642.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 11 -- A thaw is in progress in Hungary.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Beginning in January of 1961, the nation will begin a five-year commemoration of the Civil War. Today the National Centennial Commission announces the formation of a committee on advertising to assist business in the formulation of their advertising plans to commemorate the anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- American businesses now employ more than 3,000,000 workers and produce $35,000,000,000 of commodities each year in enterprises abroad, the Department of Commerce reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Bill Wade lumbered 66 yards for a touchdown in the third quarter today and led the Los Angeles Rams to a 10-3 upset victory over the Baltimore Colts.

CAIRO. ONE block from the Nile River and around the corner from Shepheard's Hotel, one will find a local shopping center. Not a shopping center as Americans know it, but merely a group of very small stores.
DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Earl Morrall, in his first starting assignment of the season, guided the Detroit Lions to a 23 -- 14 triumph over the Dallas Cowboys today.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 11 -- The West German Government is prepared to let formal trade relations with the Soviet Union lapse unless Moscow retreats from its uncompromising stand on the so-called Berlin clause.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The earth's population is expanding this year by the equivalent of Italy's 50,000,000 inhabitants.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy relaxed in the warm Florida sunshine today before heading back to snow-clogged Washington and a series of major Cabinet appointments scheduled for early this week.

THE grape harvest in New York State's champagne district had special significance this year. The gathering of a bumper crop from the vineyards sloping down to Lake Keuka, one of the Finger Lakes, marked the beginning of a second century of champagne-malting for Great Western Producers, Inc.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : After reading the rather disappointing report of the President's Commission on National Goals one can only wonder at the lack of purpose in our national mood that required the establishment of such a group.
A new kind of "prospecting" for stolen goods on the waterfront has turned up thousands of dollars' worth of goods, the Waterfront Commission has reported.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- The leaders of the Democratic minority in the Legislature today renewed their plea for a public referendum on the question of legalizing and taxing off-track betting.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Frank Mahovlich scored four goals tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game.

Michael H. Prendergast, in seclusion since Friday, will return to his office here today to fight to retain his position as Democratic state chairman.

Best Co., women's and children's specialty store chain, has purchased for cash the Grand Apparel Company of Milwaukee, Wis., it was announced over the week-end by Walter Strickland, president. The price was not disclosed.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Mrs. Kennedy remained in sunny seclusion today -- a way of life she hopes to maintain at this winter resort through the holidays.

BATON ROUGE, Dec. 11 -- The special session of the State Legislature reconvened tonight after a five-day recess and almost immediately received a call from the Governor to another thirty-day session. It would begin next Saturday, twenty-four hours after the term of the present session expires.

WHEN Evelyn Waugh and the rest of us were younger there was little doubt as to who was the most reliably comical of British novelists. But some years back Mr. Waugh turned morose, angry and serious, and surrendered his title.

It was a good clean-up.

Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, hopes to spark several tax changes during the next session of Congress, some of particular interest to small business men, one of interest to taxpayers generally.

"Camelot," which has been the subject of almost as much long-range planning as Project Mercury, has now been spoken for by a London producer for two years ahead of time.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Douglas Dillon, United States Under Secretary of State, arrived today to sign the charter of the new twenty-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 -- Lou Rossini took no backward glances as he departed for home today. The New York University basketball coach had spent a distressing California week-end.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The grain futures market worked in a generally bullish cycle last week and nearly all contracts finished well upward, with old-crop wheat and soybeans leading the advance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A series of immediate emergency actions will probably be proposed to President-elect John F. Kennedy by his special committee on depressed areas.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP) -- New York today won the annual Lockett Cup tri-city squash racquets matches by defeating Boston, 5 -- 2. New York yesterday had beaten last year's winner, Philadelphia, by 6 -- 1. Boston defeated Philadelphia, 4 -- 3, this morning.

Even though no United States shipping line is serving it, the trade route between the Great Lakes and the Caribbean area has been called essential in the overseas transport complex of this country.

FOR many non-Christian children, the Christmas season seems an unendurably long time to spend on the outside looking in. While the city's Buddhist children have Christmas trees and the children in Moslem and Ethical Culture families sing carols and exchange Christmas gifts, Jews, the city's largest non-Christian group, are forbidden by their religion from taking part in the celebration.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 10 -- Of all the wonders of the world, this city is the one that ought to be seen by the man of business.

The selection of a successor to Hulan E. Jack as Borough President of Manhattan may provide the arena for a high-stake test of strength between Mayor Wagner and Carmine G. De Sapio. The outcome could influence politics in New York for many years to come.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Communist bloc stepped up its aid to under-developed nations in 1960 to more than $1,000,000,,000 but United States officials are less concerned by these efforts than they were two years ago.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Governor Rockefeller called on the 1961 Legislature today to approprite $850,000 for two new programs to prevent delinquency among boys and girls between the ages of 15 and 17.

Taxes cover a vastly greater share of hospital care in New York City than in the United States as a whole, according to the Hospital Council of Greater New York.

A study "in depth" of the office of the Secretary of State will be published Dec. 27 by Prentice-Hall. In "The Secretary of State" seven essays depict the office as constantly developing to meet new conditions and problems.

SOME of the best television extant comes from "Camera Three," the modest Sunday morning program that quietly goes about exploring new visual paths and frequently achieves a far higher level of substance than more publicized undertakings.

Union photoengravers voted yesterday to seek strike sanction from their international officers if seven New York newspaper publishers fall to accept any one of four alternative proposals they have made for a new contract.

FLOWERS of every description pattern Ernestine's new Italian dinnerware designs, which have Just arrived at Carole Stupell, 54 East Fifty-seventh Street, a shop noted for its correlated table settings.

YOUNG people, especially if they are idealistic, naturally give out a quality of re freshing sweetness. In a big city, it is especially welcome, and late yesterday afternoon the Welch Chorale, a freshfaced group of thirteen men and eighteen young women, filled Town Hall with sounds that reflected their own goodness.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Under the shadow of political troubles today, the Islamic Republic of Mauritania anticipates a bright tomorrow, her 36-year-old head of state, Mohktar Quid Daddah, declared here recently.
Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" will have its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera next Monday. The work will be seen in the production introduced last march.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 12 -- United States dollar-saving measures will not affect Japan's plans for economic expansion and liberation of trade, Premier Hayato Ikeda told the Diet (Parliament) in a formal policy speech today.

A Protestant Episcopal priest defied the laws of his church yesterday by refusing to read from the pulpit a pastoral letter issued by the Episcopal House of Bishops.
TRENTON, Dec. 11 -- A long-standing dispute between New York and New Jersey over air pollution was pointed up again last week by an obnoxious odor that permeated Manhattan Tuesday night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers called for broad Federal action today to combat unemployment and economic depression in the coal fields.

BALTIMORE. Dec.11 -- A new steamship line has applied to the Federal Maritime Board for subsidy rights covering operation of large combination passenger-cargo liners.

HAVANA, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Premier Fidel Castro was reported today to have narrowly escaped injury when his Soviet helicopter had engine trouble while he was inspecting troop operations against an armed uprising on two fronts in Las Villas Province.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Cleveland ruined Chicago's title hopes today by intercepting seven passes as the Browns routed the Bears, 42 -- 0, in a National Football League game. Three of the intercepted passes were run back for touchdowns.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Important new discoveries in the far reaches of space were reported today by the Carnegie Institution.

Hunter College's experiment in training teachers through closed-circuit televisoin was reported yesterday to be working out well.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- With the volume of business low, a relatively small amount of selling depressed the prices of industrial shares in the stock market last week.

The demand for marriage counseling is so great that the 3,000-member Family Service Association of America can't come near filling it, says Clark W. Blackburn, its general director, according to the AP.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The woods are ours again. The strangely clad men who have come out from the city to stalk and kill the deer have left, and the blue jay no longer screams his warning hourly from the treetops. The gray squirrel no longer chatters and scolds at intruders, but busily hunts and stores nuts.
Despite some easing at the end of the week, cotton futures finished Friday with net gains for the week ranging from $1.15 to $2.50 a bale.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The violence In Algeria spurred backstage activity here today to mobilize pressures for United Nations action to end the long struggle between France and the Algerian rebels.

The city's first snowstorm of the season swirled up from the Texan plains yesterday and covered the metropolitan area with a fall expected to exceed four inches. Seven inches had piled up in parts of the suburbs by early morning, and there were drifts of up to two feet.

BOUGIE, Algeria, Dec. 11 (AP) -- While his troops clashed with Moslem mobs m the Algerian capital, President de Gaulle sought today, with apparent success, to sell his concept of an "Algerian Algeria" to the Moslem masses in the interior.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization will hold consultations on possible action to offset Soviet intervention in Laos, diplomatic informants said tonight.

Investigations of track accidents by the Interstate Commerce Commission and roadside spot checks conducted under its supervision confirm the need for better maintenance ractices, a commission staff member has told truckers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- -- The first in a series of annual volumes reviewing the work of the Supreme Court has been published by the University of Chicago Law School.
GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- The Swiss stock markets failed to find any stimulating factors last week. In the absence of any pick-up in volume, prices continued their slow decline.
PIERMONT, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Three volunteer firemen found a 15-degree day with a whipping northwest wind just right for a dip in the Hudson River today.

Jane Fonda, who made her motion nature and Broadway stage debuts earlier this year, will make her television debut next month in a starring role.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Monday, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- The New Prime Minister, Keith J. Holyoake, whose conservative National party won 46 of the 80 House of Representatives seats in last month's election, was sworn in today with his Cabinet.

The Lambert Trophy, emblematic of Eastern major-college football supremacy, was presented to Navy and Yale yesterday at a reception in the Hotel Manhattan. Bucknell received the Lambert Cup as the section's top small college eleven.

Brown, Madeira Co., investment securities, has leased offices in 50 Broadway, near Exchange Place, through Herman W. Hertweck of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker. The lessee is at 1 Wall Street and will move about Jan. 1.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Selective demand on the stock exchange here today helped industrial shares score modest rises. The Vinancial Times index of industrial common stocks was lifted 1.7 points off Low point for the year to 305.1.

Highway travel was almost nonexistent yesterday in the metropolitan area. Streets and roads were clogged by the snowstorm that started Sunday, and high winds kept piling up drifts to re-block plowed arteries.

The United States Court of Appeals ruled here yesterday that United States Treasury bonds redeemed at par for payment of estate taxes must also be computed at par in the valuation of an estate when the market value was less than par.
Eleven bona fide heroes and one heroine plunged through snow and snarled transportation yesterday to attend a lunch in their honor at, the Commodore Hotel.

VIENTIANE, Laos. Dec. 12 -- Quinim Polsena, pro-Communist head of the government here, declared today that "we will fight to the last drop of blood" If Vientiane is attacked by the forces of the pro-Western Gen. Phounii Nosavan.

THE first snowfall of the season brought delight to winter sports fans, ski shops and department stores, which are bulging with tempting wares. Particularly colorful this year are ski sweaters from all parts of the globe.

TUNIS, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Ferhat Abbas, the Algerian rebel chief, called today for urgent United Nations intervention in riottorn Algeria. He called for a referendum controlled by the Mr. Abbas, whose Moslem government-in-exile is backed openly by the Communist bloc, made his plea for intervention in a message to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
Trading in commodities on the New York exchanges yesterday was dull.
The dismissal of a policeman for holding an outside job while on sick leave was upheld here yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich.

The writer of the following letter, author of "Doctor and Patient in Soviet Russia," has written widely in the field of Soviet medical care. He is with the Russian Research Center, Harvard University.

Ratification of an agreement abolishing oilers' jobs on Diesel tugboats operated here by seven railroads aroused the vigorous dissent yesterday of oilers employed on the tugs of still another railroad.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The State Department, which Dean Rusk will take over Jan. 20, bears little resemblance in size or scope of duties to what it was twenty years ago.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in coat. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
THIS reporter has long been blessed with what might be called kibitzer's luck.
Gale warnings flew here yesterday as harbor winds of twenty to forty miles an hour tore barges from their moorings and prevented the docking of about thirty freighters.
ATLANTA, Dec. 12 -- A Negro elementary school here was bombed before dawn today.

A WRITER can hardly be said to have arrived until he has been parodied. The wounds received are in the price of fame. Few gifted parodists trouble to waste incisive ridicule on the obscure and the unknown.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Mississippi's eight and Alabama's six unpledged Presidential electors agreed after a five-hour session today to vote for Senator Harry F. Byrd in an effort to bar John F. Kennedy from the Presidency.

Shutdowns and early closings of city and suburban stores and factories, die-hard women Christmas shoppers in ski pants, and perfume deliveries by sleigh -- all these stemmed from near-paralysis of business by yesterday's storm.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Employment conditions continued to worsen in November, the Labor Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A Presidential fact-finding board dismissed today union demands that the size of crews on railroad-operated tugs and ferry boats in New York Harbor be frozen at present levels.
The decision of Chester Bowles to leave his seat in Congress to devote himself to advising Senator John F. Kennedy on foreign policy in the Presidential campaign ran true to form.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The University of Louisville turned back Georgia Tech, 74-65, in the opening round of the Bluegrass invitation basketball tournament tonight. It was the Engineers' first loss of the season.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- Lady Lawford, mother of Peter Lawford, the movie star, beamed today as she bantered with photographers during her first day as a jewelry saleswoman here.
A new type of nylon yarn said to increase the fatigue resistance of tires by more than 00 per cent was announced yesterday by the Chemstrand Corporation.

Assembly Products, Inc. The directors of Assembly Products, Inc., voted yesterday to pay a year-end dividend of 10 cents a share on Dec. 28 to stockholders of record of Dec. 19. A year ago the company did not declare a cash dividend, but distributed 5 per cent in stock.
Public and parochial schools in the city and suburbs as well as most private schools and colleges and universities were closed yesterday because of the overnight snowstorm.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Braulio Baeza, the riding sensation of the Tropical Park meeting, won five races today and took a commanding lead in the jockey standings.
Impassable roads, late or nonexistent mail and milk deliveries, and closed stores, offices and schools were the rule yesterday in Westchester, Fairfield and Rockland Counties.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Bill Rigney was appointed manager of the Los Angeles Angels today. Los Angeles is the new West Coast baseball entry in the American League.
Operations of the Cudahy Packing Company during its eventieth year which ended
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Republican legislators urged Senator Paul H. Douglas today to confine planned legislation for distressed areas to areas that are chronically in economic trouble.
A 192-year-old diploma awarding the Bachelor of Arts degree to one of Columbia College's most distinguished graduates was returned to the university yesterday. Columbia will put it on exhibition.
Steel production this week is scheduled to remain below 50 per cent of capacity for the fourth consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The "big three" of the African nationalist leaders attending the constitutional conference here on the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland walked out of the talks tonight.
ALGIERS, Dec. 12--Violence continued in Algeria today, raising the official figure for those killed in the last two days to ninety, including eighty-four Moslems.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- A former all-America half-back who is leading a drive to restore football at Marquette University said tonight he felt his campaign would be successful.
The problem of increasing youth unemployment is to be taken up at 10:30 A.M. today at a high-level conference in City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The snowstorm brought most Government work to a halt in the nation's capital today and disrupted life in general from New Jersey southward.
HANS RICHTER-HAASER is a pianist with a magnificent sense of line.
HAVANA, Dec. 12 -- Leaflets calling on Cubans to rise In arms against the regime of Premier Fidel Castro were dropped on Havana and its suburbs by an unidentified plane last night.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- An air traffic control expert warned today that the nation faced a "hopeless" traffic jam in the sky within forty years. He said it would be as bad as the current automobile congestion.

MADRID, Dec. 12 -- Pierre Lagaillarde, who fled here last week from his trial in France, was reliably reported today to be living in an apartment in a northwest suburb of Madrid under constant police guard.

PERTH, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Chuck McKinley said he was sorry over a racquet-tossing incident, and David Freed, the United States Davis Cup captain, took steps today to quiet a storm over what Australians are calling "unsportsmanlike conduct" by American tennis players.
The storm that swirled across the metropolitan area yesterday gave New York its heaviest early season snowfall in Weather Bureau records.
BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- One of the worst pre winter snowstorms on record crippled industry and transportation in central and southern New England today. Northern reaches escaped relatively lightly.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Dec. 12 -- -- A celebrated art collection, long a subject of controversy -- the treasures of the Barnes Foundation gallery in Marion will be opened to the public in a matter of weeks.
The New York Rangers yesterday promoted 21-year-old VVayne Hall from the Kitchener (Ont.) Beavers to bolster their weakened left-wing situation.
The management of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., moved yesterday to revitalize its news division to counter the recent successes of the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Ike Williams, a former lightweight boxing champion, told a Senate subcommittee today a tale of stolen purses, bribe offers and fraudulent bouts. He ended his testimony with the bitter conclusion that if he had it to do over again, he'd take a bribe and throw a fight.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 12 -- The Moroccan Government informed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold tonight that it was forced to pull its armed forces out of the Congo because the United Nations was no longer striving to safeguard peace and defend the "legal authorities" there.
The snowstorm that hit the Atlantic Coast yesterday caused postponement of many sports events in the East.
BOSTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The American League today was forced by the storm to postpone for twenty-four hours the drafting session for its two newest entries.
Broadway's legitimate theatres were deluged by hundreds of calls from theatregoers in the suburbs who found themselves unable to reach town yesterday because of the blizzard.
ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- The Liberal party provided the votes that carried New York State for Senator John F. Kennedy, the state's official election canvass showed today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- Scientists working with quantities of matter as minute as a billionth of a gram have produced the first pure chemical compounds of the man-made element californium.

Black-Clawson Co. The Black-Clawson Company, manufacturer of pulp and paper mill equipment, has announced the acquisition of the plastic extruder business of the Aetna-Standard division of the Blaw-Knox Company.

The New York Knickerbockers, hungry for victory, will meet the Boston Celtics in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header tonight at Madison Square Garden. In the first game, starting at 7 o'clock, the Cincinnati Royals will oppose the Syracuse Nationals.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Lybia faces the brightest economic prospects the country has known in modern times through the discovery of oil in her deserts. Yet it will be 1962 before any considerable revenues begin to flow from this source, Libyan executives point out in a memorandum advocating sustained help from the United Nations over the next few years.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: I am writing you in the hope of correcting an error which has caused me considerable embarrassment.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- The worst snowstorm in a quarter of a century lashed the Philadelphia area today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
A real estate management organization here has established a supervisory service for owners of residential property. It will aid the owner whose property is being operated by a lessee.

To fill the most difficult post in the Cabinet, that of Secretary of State, President elect Kennedy yesterday made an absolutely first-rate appointment. In naming Dean Rusk, President of the Rockefeller Foundation, Mr. Kennedy merits the congratulations of Americans, irrespective of party, and of the people of the whole free world.

MRS. John. F. Kennedy, the future First Lady, picked Oleg Cassini, New York designer, to create part of her inaugural wardrobe and the formal gowns she will wear during the winter social season at the White House, according to United Press International.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12 -- Sam I. Roseberg, attorney for the New Orleans School Board, said today the Supreme Court ruling was not a final determination of the Federal District Court's integration order; it was only denial of a stay pending an appeal.
Industrial construction may prove the "sleeper" in the building picture for 1961, according to Clifford S. Strike, president of F.H. McGraw Co., heavy construction concern of New York.

"Person to Person," the Columbia Broadcasting System interview program that has been an the air since October, 1953, will ,be discontinued after the telecast of Dec. 22. A C.B.S. spokesman said that the program "eventually ran its course."
